Dear Brothers

Many enquiries have "been received regarding the availability of the compilation, "JEHOVAH’S WITNESSES — ALTERNATIVES TO BLOOD TRANSFUSION IN MINORS." This volume was prepared locally for the use of area doctors willing to cooperate with Witnesses, providing medical care without the use of blood transfusion. Results have been extremely favorable.

Because of the many requests for copies from other areas and the continuing local demand we have printed a good supply of a new edition titled, "JEHOVAH'S WITNESSES — ALTERNATIVES TO BLOOD TRANSFUSION." It has a few more articles and deals with minors and adults. If you feel they can be used beneficially in your area you may wish to obtain some copies.

Please note that these books are primarily intended for the use of doctors because most of the articles are from medical texts using medical terminology. If an elder feels he could make use of the publication, we do not mind if he keeps a personal copy. For example it could come in handy when visiting a hospital administrator to deliver a copy for the hospital library. During the discussion the elder would have his own volume to refer to when explaining some of the features. However it should be stressed that this publication is not intended for indiscriminant circulation or uncontrolled usage, -T-hus—we ■req^-est- tha-t it not be kept- in the Kingdom-Hall library. If a publisher desires the publication for a few days the elder could make his copy available if he felt it would be beneficial. Misuse should be avoided. In one instance, after being approached too frequently by a well-meaning sister armed with a handful of medical articles, a local surgeon's disposition was converted from 'friendly* to 'hostile.* However in the great majority of cases if a doctor is 'handled discreetly' results will be good.

If there are any doctors in your area who have been friendly it may be desirable to give each one a copy of this book. Hospital administrators will usually accept copies for the hospital library. In such cases it is essential that we do not ask for a contribution for the book. To obtain copies please use the enclosed "BOOK REQUEST” forms using one for each book required.

These volumes were prepared privately and have been designed to assist our brothers and sisters in seeking medical help compatible with their Bible-trained consciences. The Canadian Branch office is aware of this book and has not discouraged its publication. We would certainly appreciate hearing any favorable experiences you have in using this compilation. Please accent .our warm regnrds-

Your brother, Alex Trost

JEHOVAH'S


WITNESSES


alternatives


to blood


transfusion


November 1973


JEHOVAH'S WITNESSES

alternatives to blood

transfusion

November 1973

PREFACE

When a patient is critically ill, complete recovery is the common desire of the patient, the family, the doctor, the hospital staff and the family’s presiding minister.

That is no less true when a patient is one of Jehovah’s Witnesses. This religious body does not adhere to so-called ‘faith healing’ and is not opposed to the practice of medicine. When ill, members seek medical help. They appreciate the growing number of doctors who have responded to their needs with kindness and with consideration for the patient’s conscientious beliefs. The ONE AREA of treatment in which there have been some problems at times is in the use of blood and its derivatives.

Purpose of Volume

This volume has been prepared to ease the situation for all involved by making known the good results of accepted medical alternatives to the transfusion of blood or its derivatives. The results have generally been not less successful than where blood is normally used. “The use of Ringer’s lactate solution has become as acceptable as whole blood in shock and surgery patients,” states the Journal of the American Medical Association.1 It is admitted that even postoperative complications have usually been fewer.2

It is not the purpose of this work to try to direct those in health services. It is merely to acquaint them with what their colleagues are doing to meet the needs of a growing segment of the community that conscientiously refuses to allow the ingestion of blood by any means. Even the diet of Jehovah’s Witnesses excludes blood, such as in blood puddings or blood sausage.

Famed heart surgeon Denton Cooley and others have developed new techniques in providing major surgery for Jehovah’s Witnesses and their offspring.3 Instead of resorting to time-consuming and unnecessary court actions these specialists have devised procedures acceptable to the patient or guardian and won the respect and confidence of those whose consciences would not permit blood transfusion. Confrontations were avoided. Resulting publicity was extremely favorable. Cooley now considers ‘bloodless surgery’ as “routine” and “superior” to using techniques utilizing blood4 and no longer views these patients as “special cases” with liabilities. 2,3

It is believed that there is a good number of doctors desirous of becoming better acquainted with progress being made with ‘bloodless’ surgery, (not just for Jehovah’s Witnesses, but for other patients) where use of blood with its known risks is avoided. Such information could also be useful in situations where blood supplies become exhausted due to catastrophies.

Sooner or later a doctor may be faced with an emergency case where someone refuses blood for himself or a child on religious or conscientious grounds. It is hoped that the information presented here will stimulate preparatory measures on the part of medical teams so that when the Emergency Unit receives a patient who forbids blood transfusion, there can be immediate administration of alternate treatment already familiar to the team on duty. Such advance preparation would eliminate the hesitancy and confusion mentioned by Doctors Minuck and Lambie:

“Often in the case of the Jehovah’s Witnesses' the surgical team becomes emotional, confused and irrational, because the patient’s liability is religious rather than physical. Jehovah’s Witnesses are not the only religious group which must refuse to accept certain aspects of accepted medical practice on religious grounds. Other groups such as Roman Catholics also must refuse some forms of medical treatment, and we accept their point of view. Similarly the Jehovah’s Witness’ beliefs should be respected and tolerated.” 5

The value of advance preparation and research to meet such emergencies hardly needs emphasis. It is also hoped that some hospital boards will examine the feasibility of offering facilities for alternative treatment to those who seek it and to qualified doctors (though not on their staff) experienced in rendering effective treatment without the use of blood transfusion.

In cases that are not emergencies, we hasten to assure that Jehovah’s Witnesses are continually reminded to inform family doctors ahead of time as to their .position on the use of blood. This is to avoid last-minute situations creating problems for doctor and patient.

Understanding Witness Patients


Normally patients are not familiar with treatments available. They leave it to the doctor to do what he feels best. It is understandable that having a patient disagree with the doctor on type of therapy can be an unusual experience for the doctor, especially if the patient or parent or religious associate suggests some treatment unknown to the doctor. This is not meant to challenge the doctor’s experience or ability, but to respectfully try to resolve the difficult situation for both doctor and patient.

Some Witness patients may not be familiar with alternatives to blood in certain cases; they appreciate the doctor who takes the matter in stride and proceeds to get information about other treatment instead of losing sometimes valuable time in trying to persuade the patient to change his mind or compromise beliefs ‘because life is at stake.’ Or, where no emergency exists the doctor can offer preventative treatment. (For example: pre-natal therapy to decrease the possibility of a mother giving birth to a newborn suffering from a hemolytic reaction.)6

The unlikelihood of getting a Witness patient to ‘change his mind’ about use of blood cannot be overemphasized. They will not renounce their faith. Just how deep-seated and sincerely held, are their beliefs may be hard to appreciate in a world of declining faith, but time and life may be saved by recognizing one is dealing with a resolute people. At the same time, they are not unreasonably stubborn. Also due to their faith, the doctor will not be dealing with a people who will be abnormally upset emotionally when faced with a critical situation that calls for courage.

What About Minors?

If Jehovah’s Witnesses did not love their children and want them to live they would not go to a doctor or a hospital. As a matter of belief they love life and good health; they consider both as sacred and to be protected and preserved, both for themselves and their offspring. They are life-oriented. That is why they do not smoke, do not seek abortions and have success in keeping adults and children from becoming victims of mind-and-health-de straying drugs. In fact, it is also one of the reasons why they abstain from blood transfusions; they feel them to be a threat to life rather than a means to preserve it. One recent authoritative report shows the annual mortality rate in the United States could be as high as 35,000 from just one complication, namely, hepatitis.7


It has been the general practice of Witness parents to take their children, when ill, to doctors and hospitals for medical treatment. However they feel that on numerous occasions there has been an unjust trampling of rights when they have requested treatment without blood transfusions. Often in serious illnesses where blood transfusion is commonly used, the doctor: a) purposely delays treatment and avoids communication with the parents, thinking they will succumb to the pressure and anxiety; b) attempts to prevent the parents from taking their child to another doctor who will provide alternate therapy; c) without advising the parents that he will not treat without blood and with no information to them of his present intentions, secretly initiates legal proceedings to remove the child from parental custody, so that when parents are finally given notice (often 24 hours or less!) of the court hearing there is little time to obtain legal counsel and prepare well and it becomes next to impossible to find another doctor to treat the patient (who by now has perhaps reached a critical stage that did not obtain at the outset). The doctor may be acting according to his own conscience, but when he overrides the conscience of the parents and it becomes a matter of conscience vj. conscience, then it has become truly a religious or spiritual matter. After all, in allowing for alternatives one is not agreeing to certain death for the child, as would be the case, many feel, in the matter of an abortion.

Surely doctors recognize that no treatment is 100% effective in all cases. There are failures and successes, with some treatments more effective than others. That is why many cooperative doctors have not sought legal custody of children of Jehovah's Witnesses to enforce a treatment in which they cannot assure success or freedom from complications. When a child is critically ill the doctor may conscientiously feel the use of blood is the best treatment he can offer. However when the parent refuses blood transfusion, in evaluating the total situation, would it not be preferable to administer a treatment compatible with the conscience of the parent or the child even though the doctor sincerely feels it a degree less effective? This is the course suggested by a Council of Judges in the United States of America: “If there is a choice of procedures if, for example, the doctor recommends a procedure which has an 80 per cent chance of success but which the parents disapprove, and the parents have no objection to a procedure which has only a 40 per cent chance of success ■ the doctor must take the medically riskier but parentally unobjectionable course.”8


Treating the whole patient is the best treatment. As one medical report3 puts it: “The challenge of religion versus medicine has been well met, and much has been gained. Doctors have learned that they may be called upon to modify their management of a patient’s illness when there are factors more important to the patient than his own health or even his life. The patient’s ideals and honor must be respected.”

In the Divine arrangement of things the child is born into a family unit and the instinctive tendency is there for the care and well-being of the child. Does either “nature” or experience teach us that a child is better off with decisions involving life being made by institutions or individuals contrary to the wishes of the parents? Dr. Arthur Kelly9 has argued that the patient “is not to be coerced even though we may think that Big Brother knows best. I am prepared to go further and to state that I believe that parents of minors and the next of kin of unconscious patients possess the right to interpret the will of the patient and that we should accept and respect their wishes ... Enforcement, except by explanation and persuasion, is not our function.” He also said: “Holding these views, it should come as no surprise that I do not admire the proceedings of a moot court assembled at 2:00 a.m, to remove a child from his parent’s custody.”9

Where some have not acknowledged the alternatives and have insisted on custody of a minor to do according to their own will the doctor-patient relationship is adversely affected. Will the parent in the future seek medical services, even in an emergency? Will he trust a hospital as a place where his rights and beliefs are respected? In a good number of cases babies have died in spite of blood transfusions given, producing an awkward situation for the doctor who must explain the tragedy to parents whose wishes have been overridden. What if they demanded an autopsy that showed the baby died from a reaction to the blood? Parents in some instances have transferred their child to another hospital or doctor to get alternative treatment that has been successful. Newspapers blow up these incidents all out of proportion and there is bad publicity for doctors, hospitals and Jehovah’s Witnesses. This is all avoidable.

For these reasons it is difficult to understand why adult and child patients and parents of the latter have regrettably been subjected to verbal abuse such as threats and ridicule, (even by nurses) and in some cases denied treatment, at a time when all concerned ought to have been most interested in comforting, reassuring and encouraging the patient and rendering the treatment needed, even if an alternative. Minors seeking ‘legal’ abortions are not taken to court by anti-abortion doctors to ‘save a life.’ Roman Catholic mothers are not forced to have an abortion that will ‘save a life’ even when they are unwed minors. Then why the attitude encountered with Witnesses refusing blood?

In some cases parents have been declared guilty of neglect so that custody of the child could be transferred to give a transfusion. In view of the points above this is only pretended neglect and not actual. Is it not odd that in this day one could have the following situation on the same floor of a hospital: In one room, doctors are working with a court order to transfuse, in the uterus, an unborn child to ‘save’ its life, to prevent its ‘neglectful’ parents from ‘killing’ it; in the next room, for some flimsy reason, ‘on demand,’ a baby is being aborted, being ‘killed’ by parents and doctors!

It is to avoid any of these unfortunate situations that the following collection of articles is presented. It is not possible for any doctor today to keep up with all that is coming out in the medical field, or to research every specialized problem. Since we are interested in alternatives we are willing to do the research and supply the articles that will make it possible for the doctor to be confident that he can treat Witness patients successfully. Of course, the coverage given in this volume is not exhaustive. Only a few of the many available articles have been selected for each category as these best illustrate the success of alternatives. Additional information can be had in most cases by consulting the bibliography. Alternative treatments appear first. The sections on blood transfusion complications and comments are included to show that some doctors of experience and prestige are repeatedly voicing concern because of the general disregard for the dangers involved in a blood transfusion. The concluding portion produces articles from publications of Jehovah’s Witnesses to make clear their official stand on blood transfusion and other medical questions.

Besides the reprints from medical journals in this volume, there are additional articles in a similar compilation entitled: “Jehovah’s Witnesses - ■ Alternatives to Blood Transfusion in Adults.”

Additional information on specific cases may be had from religious associates of the patient, preferably from the presiding overseer of the local congregation of Jehovah’s Witnesses. (See telephone listing under “Jehovah’s Witnesses.”)

It is our sincere hope that the information presented in this volume will be interpreted as a genuine endeavour to improve a situation where there has been some misunderstanding and, as a result, some undesirable consequences for patient and doctor, and at times, the hospital. May it result in better communication between all concerned. It is our hope that it will help to provide better health care for Jehovah’s Witnesses and their families; an improved doctor-patient relationship;improved hospital and medical facilities for those refusing blood transfusion treatment; an appreciable decrease in confrontations over religious beliefs and medical treatment; elimination of unfavorable publicity for doctor and patient, and a restoration of the patient’s right to privacy as to his sickness or treatment; a greater awareness of the growing trend to use alternatives to avoid complications in the use of blood; an avoidance of any possible hesitancy on the part of either the medical team to treat without blood or the patient to seek medical care. This should not be difficult if all genuinely are concerned for the patient’s recovery.

Respectfully, rather than think their position to be in any way wrong, Jehovah’s Witnesses continue to follow the Divine and apostolic direction as stated in Acts 15:28 & 29, according to the New English Bible: “ ‘It is the decision of the Holy Spirit, and our decision, to lay no further burden upon you beyond these essentials: You are to abstain from meat that has been offered to idols, from blood, from anything that has been strangled, and from fornication. If you keep yourselves free from these things you will be doing right.’ ”

References

  • 1. Fluids Effective in Shock, But Why? JAMA 202:32,33, October 23, 1967. (Section BAB-33)

  • 2. Simmins, Jr., C.W., et al: Vascular Surgery in Jehovah’s Witnesses. JAMA 213:1032-1034, August 10, 1970. (Section BVS-41)

  • 5. Minuck, M., et al: Anesthesia and Surgery for Jehovah’s Witnesses. Canad Med Assoc J 84:1187-1191, May 27, 1961.

WP Witness parents believe that many do not appreciate how seriously they view their obligation

to properly train their young how to avoid mind and body-destroying practices:

WRT Right to choose medical treatment ...........................,

by J. Lowell Dixon, M.D.

the handling of blood dates back to God’s pronouncement to Noah immediately after the global flood, over

be taken into the body as food. It was not to be eaten, nor to be stored, for the "soul” or the life was in the

ne Viewpoint

Jehovah’s Witnesses are not religious fanatics under some organiza-


The Reason Why


A major problem for many doctors is the refusal of Jehovah’s Witnesses to allow blood transfusions. Neither doctor nor patient seems to find it easy to understand the position of the other, and yet both have the same objective in mind—• to save the life of the patient.


tional edict which proscribes the ministrations of doctors and hospitals. To the contrary, when mediem care is needed, Witnesses are anxious and willing to undergo whatever treatment is necessary to sustain their lives. Doctors are consulted regularly, often noting Witnesses to be very cooperative patients.

The adamant stand of Jehovah’s Witnesses regarding blood transfusions arises out of their conviction that the Bible is the inspired and truthful Word of God, Jehovah.Their determination to obey the Bible causes them to dedicate their lives to the worship and service of Jehovah. To them, maintaining faithfulness and integrity to their Creator is of paramount importance. What is a medical issue to the doctors, then, is a scriptural one to the Witnesses. A measure of real understanding, therefore, is necessary for all concerned in the care of Jehovah’s Witnesses.

Biblical Injunctions

The saend respect for blood antedates the Christian era by many centuries. In fact, divine regulation for 4,300 years ago. Then, for the first time, God granted permission to man to add meat to his diet, saying, "Every moving animal that is alive may serve as food for you.” But at the same time God added, "Only flesh with its soul—its blood—you must not eat.” (Genesis 9:3,4) Before that time the blood question had not been raised since man had eaten only bloodless fruits and vegetables.

Later, when the nation of Israel was brought into a covenant relationship with God the restriction on blood was again emphasized. Specific instructions were given for preparing animals that were to be used as food. Man, catching a -wild animal or fowl for consumption,was required to pour the blood out of the body and to cover it with dust. "It is a statute to time indefinite for your generations, in all your dwelling places: You must not eat any fat or any blood at all.” Again it was stated that one "must not eat the blood of any sort of flesh, because the soul of every sort of flesh, is its blood.” (Leviticus 3:17; 17:14) Absolutely no blood, regardless of the source, animal or human, was to blood. It belonged to God who demanded that it be poured out, unused, upon the ground.

A Serious Sin

The matter could not be taken lightly. Any violation of the law on blood was a serious sin against God, and God would call the law violator to account, as indicated in Leviticus 17:10: "I shall certainly set my face against the soul that is eating the blood, and I shall indeed cut him off from among his people.” This was not a simple dietary regulation, but rather it involved a matter of actually sinning against God, a capital crime worthy of capital punishment. No special dispensations were allowed for times of stress in which one might be justified in taking blood into the body. No exceptions were made for peculiar circumstances or emergencies. Very simply—man was not to take blood into his body.

God’s Law

What about non-Jewish people not under the Mosaic Law covenant? They too are bound to obey God’s law given to Noah regarding blood,

14/Point of View/ETIIICON

Volume 10, No. 7

for all mankind are descendents of Noah. Furthermore, a few years after the death of Jesus, Christians were commanded to "abstain . . . from blood.” (Acts 15:20) This served to put non-Jewish Christians on notice regarding Jehovah’s law on blood.

To those who question that such command should be given a literal application, Jehovah’s Witnesses point to the context of the scripture. There it can be seen that four things arc mentioned as being "necessary’' for the Christians—abstention from "things sacrificed to idols and from blood and from things strangled and from fornication.” (Acts 15:28, 29)

Again, the scope of this decree, like the ones given to Noah and the nation of Israel, is not limited as to time and is not restricted to animal blood, nor to the taking of blood into the body through the mouth. Christians are told simply to keep themselves free from blood—as free, one might well argue, as from idolatry or fornication. Notwithstanding the modern relaxed attitudes on sexual freedom, to Jehovah’s Witnesses the Bible’s position seems equally and unmistakably clear, both as to fornication and blood transfusion.

Some have mistakenly interpreted this stand of Jehovah’s Witnesses as one in which an individual is exercising his "right to die.” In this they are wrong. There is no such suicidal fanaticism in the thinking of Jehovah’s Witnesses. The very opposite is true. They are determined to exercise every precaution, at whatever cost, in order to obey Cod’s law and thereby be assured of life, if not now, then in the future under Cod’s kingdom rule.

Significantly, the history of modern blood transfusion therapy has not established blood ' - a panacea, nor even as an absolutely safe treatment. It is certainly no discredit, therefore, to Jehovah’s Witnesses who refused blood transfusions on script!” al grounds, when in the past it was looked upon as the great lifesaver.

Jehovah’s Witnesses readilv admit !bat their stand on the blood issue does occasionally work a hardship on their doctors, whose medical training inculcates in them great respect for and confidence in the blood transfusion. Too, theexperience of doctors has been that the religious convictions of many patients are, as a rule, not rigidly held, bi instances where these beliefs conflict with medical treatment it is ordinarily a simple matter to receive some special permission from a church official and the treatment in question is instituted. It is easy, therefore, to understand how such professionals, at times, find it difficult to cope with the unwavering stand of Jehovah’s Witnesses.

Reasonable Request

Jehovah’s Witnesses believe that to ask their doctors to give consideration to their scripturally trained consciences on the matter of blood transfusions is a reasonable request. In making such requests, the Witnesses are willing to relieve their doctors and hospitals of responsibility for any adversity that may be due to their not taking blood transfusions. With all due respect and appreciation for the sincere and well-intentioned efforts of the medical profession, the main concern of Jehovah’s Witnesses is the maintenance of their integrity to Jehovah God, whose law is perfect and whose promise is life eternal for those who serve Him faithfully. (Psalms 19:7-11)

Dr. J. 7 f'well Dixon is a graduate of the University oj Oklahoma Medical School, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. After a surgical fellowship al the University of Minnesota Hospitals, Minneapolis, Minnesota, Dr. Dixon spent many years in private practice in general surgery. He is presently the medical director for the Watchtower Society, Brooklyn, New York.

ETII ICON/Point of View/15

A. D. KELLY, M.D.

Secretary of Canadian Med. Assoc.

432 Aequanimitas

Cannd. Med. Ass. J.

Feb. 18, 19G7, vol. 96


AEQUANKMITAS

TWO MISTAKES

Adjacent columns of my paper a few months ago carried the contrasting stories of the death of 15 civilians when bombs blasted their native village, and of the efforts of doctors in a Detroit hospital to save the life of an injured Canadian youth whose religious convictions forbade the acceptance of blood by transfusion. Five pints were administered despite his repeatedly stated objections and those of fiis mother. I believe that both incidents are rgRrettakte-mistakes, the first occasioned by faulty military intelligence and the second by faulty appreciation on the part of intelligent doctors of their role in treating their patient.

A spokesman for the Detroit hospital is reported to have said that the patient had been “dumped into hospital here because a couple of Canadian hospitals didn’t want to be stuck with him.” I don’t know whether this was the motive for his referral across the river, but I can understand the reluctance of a hospital and its medical staff to become involved in either a religious controversy or an imminent death. Our instinct is to employ all measures to save a life, but there are occasions when primum non nocere is the overriding consideration, and if the Canadian hospitals in question "dumped” the patient to relieve themselves of a moral dilemma they did the patient, and themselves, harm.

Subsequent information establishes tire fact that the patient’s parents exercised their rights by removing their son from the Henry Ford Hospital, admitting him to another Detroit institution where amputation of an injured leg was performed without the administration of blood.

The dispatch from Detroit quoted the Administration of the Henry Ford Hospital as follows: “There is judicial precedence (sic) which indicates doctors may carry out steps they deem necessary to -save a patient’s life.” This statement was apparently made to justify the treatment of the patient by methods which he declined to accept. If this is actually the state of the law and jurisprudence in Michigan, I think that it is not only bad law but very dangerous doctrine and I propose to state what I conceive to be a doctor’s duty and the extent of his authority in administering treatment.

Although victims of highway accidents such as the case under discussion have little option in seeking medical aid, patients usually have not only the right to consult a physician or to refrain from doing so, but they also have the right to accept or reject the treatment recommended. You and I may think that a patient is ignorant, superstitious, wrongheaded, bigoted and stubborn in his attitude, and this may well be the case, but he is the ultimate custodian of his own person. Unless the law categorizes him as a danger to the public health, as in wilful refusal to accept treatment for such communicable diseases as pulmonary tuberculosis or venereal infection, he is not to be coerced even though we may tlfink that Big Brother knows best.

I am prepared to go further and to state that I believe that parents of minors and the next of kin of unconscious patients possess the right to interpret the will of the patient and that we should accept and respect their wishes. Holding these views, it should come as no surprise that I do not admire the proceedings of a moot court assembled at 2:00 a.into remove a child from his parent's custody.

The rights of the individual in our society are being impaired and eroded by many laws, Customs, rules and regulations and 1 think it high time that doctors’ orders should be recognized for what they are—-our best advice according to our currcrit knowledge. Advice and counsel are ours to give and for the patient to accept or disregard- Enforcement, except by explanation and persuasion, is not our function.

I once took a course in medical jurisprudence and ethics taught by the late Gideon Silverthrone, a salty character who brought to his task long experience, considerable wisdom and very good judgment. He described in colourful detail how he, as a young surgeon, attended a child with acute fulminating appendicitis for whom the obvious treatment was appendectomy. The parents, ignorant, inarticulate clods, had an instinctive and unreasoned fear of hospitals and surgeons and they said NO. They persisted in rejecting Dr. Silverthrone’s advice despite bis best efforts at persuasion, which, I think, included his categorization of them as potential murderers. He did not, however, cease to attend the patient and he watched the disease progress through localized peritonitis to appendiceal abscess which clearly indicated to him his patient’s early demise. The denouement was that the abscess ruptured into the colon, drained itself and the patient recovered. Two lessons were underlined by my teacher: can’t order people to do what they don’t want to do and we can’t predict the outcome of a jgiY€O.,_casp eis_disregar

even if our superior knowledg


Medical omniscience is a very rare commodity and the dicta of yesterday are being modified antT*"' superseded by the new knowledge of today. Let us" not, in our pride, become arrogant and demand this subjection of our patient’s will. I consider it preferable that certain individuals should die before their time than that we should undermine their ultimate right and duty of being the custodian of their own health.                                      A.D.K.

M£g>iCINE

Terry and the Parents

When 5-vear-old Tern' Johnson was brought to the Massachusetts General Hospital suffering; from a serious congenital heart defect last spring, there was little question that open-heart suj-gery could make the child well. The trouble was tli.it Teno's parents refused to permit the operation because they are Jehovah’s Witness!-s, and their I aith flatlv prohibits the nse~of blood transfusions. Fin '!y, after struggling with the dilemma i<« months, the Boston doctors worked out an ingenious method of proceeding without transfusions, using a technique that not only makes complex operations possible for Jehovah s witnesses but promises also to reduce the need for often scarce banked blood in the entire field of surgery.

Young Terry’s medical problem was Tetralogy of Fallot, a complex of lour defects of the heart and its blood vessels. The child had been born with a quartersize hole between the left and right pumping chambers of his heart that permitted blood that had not been adequately replenished with oxygen to circulate through his body. In addition, an Overgrowth of muscle tissue in the right pumping chamber restricted blood flow to the artery carrying blood Io tin- lungs, further reducing the oxygenation of his blood. Both of these defects had. caused

Newsweek, January 18,1971


enlargement of the right ventricle and a displacement of the aorta, the main artery leading to the body. As a result of this galaxy of disorders, Terry was chronically short of breath and exhausted, and chances that he would survive to adulthood were slim.


Adamant: The physicians explained to Terry’s parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Johnson of Athol, Mass., that there was a 90 per cent chance of correcting the child's condition by surgery, but the operation necessitated blood transfusions. Terry's father, a self-employed truck driver, adamantly refused on the ground that his religion proscribes the administration of “anima! products,” including blood. He even turned down a proposal to remove some of Terry’s own blood and store it until it was needecT

The doctors were stymied. Transfusions would be essential in Terry’s case because the heart-lung machine that would take over the circulation of his blood while his own heart was being repaired inevitably damages red blood cells and affects the clotting ability of the blood, posing the threat of post-’: operative bleeding problems. They knew that Houston’s famed 'cardiac specialist, Dr. Denton Cooley had performed openheart surgery on Jehovah’s witnesses without transfusions. But Cooley’s patients had been adults and the surgery had been done with extraordinary speed, minimizing blood damage. Because of Terry’s small size, a greater percentage of his blood would be subjected to the deleterious effects of the heart-lung machine, and the complexity of his condition meant that the operation would take hours.

The doctors considered going to court Jo obtain temporary custody of the bov so that they could operate without his parents’ consent, an alternative that has been used periodically in other Jehovah’s witness cases. Then the Johnsons proclaimed that they would not take Terry back into their home if such a course was taken. In the face of this, plus some adverse comment in the local press, the doctors sent Terry back homo while they pondered other wavs to solve the dilemma. “The parents were very calm and reasonable, even though they were insistent on a strict interpretation of theirr religious rules,'' recalls heart surgeon I Jr. ^Jorthner J, Bucklev. “We weic willing Io bend over backward.”

By last fall, the,physicians had worked out a plan. They would drain 2’z pints of Terry’s blood into three plastic bags that would remain connected to a blood vessel in his left arm during the operation. Since the blood had technically never left the child’s body, it could be returned to his blood stream after surgery without.being considered a transfusion in the religious sense. J'o replace this blood during surgery, anesthesiologist Dr. Mvron B. Laver recommended administration of a mild salt solution called Ringer’s lactate. The solution is often used in the treatment of shock resulting from serious blood loss following injury or burns. And Laver had tested it on dogs several years ago as a potential blood replacement during surgery.

Headline: Terry’s operation was on Oct. 1. During the one and a half hours Ire was on the heart-lung machine, 6 pints of Rutger's lactate were administered through his right arm. diluting the red cells in his circulation from 60 percent down to 10 per cent. “His blood was thin enough to pass the headline test,” notes Laver. “You could read headlines through it.” To compensate for the lack of oxygen-carrying red blood cells, the doctors speeded up his circulation with the pump, making the red cells do double duty. When the surgeons had repaired Terry’s heart, the pump was switched off and the blood in the plastic bags flowed back into his body. The Ringer’s lactate was excreted normally. Soon, Terry’s red blood cells were back t<> normal and since the clotting ability ol his blood was unimpaired, his recovery was uneventful..“He was asking lor tomato soup the next day,” savs Laver.

The same technique has now"been usrcd on a dozen other patients at the hospital, none of them Jehovah’s wit--nesses, illustrating its promise in many types of surgery. In an account to .be .published in The New England Journal of Medicine, the doctors predict that the use of the patient’s own stored blood and Ringer’s lactate will reduce the risk of hepatitis, often transmitter! by banked i.blood. Moreover it could help surgeons overcome the chronic shortage of pre-~ clous blood. Jlut had it not been for Terry s unusual dilemma, the method might not have been tried at all.~*

RELEASE FROM LIABILITY

To...........................Hospital, and the medical and nursing

personnel having anything to do with the case of......................

You are hereby notified and instructed that I do not wish any transfusion of whole blood, blood plasma, packed cells, blood fractions or blood derivatives to be used in the treatment of this patient. I regard the transfusion of blood and blood products as unnecessarily dangerous treatment producing too many bad effects to justify the risk. It is also contrary to my faith as one of Jehovah's witnesses.

I recognize and understand that the attendant physicians have advised that they are of opinion that blood transfusion is necessary perhaps even to save the life of the patient, i do not share their opinion and adhere to the instructions given in this notice.

This restriction leaves open the use by transfusion or otherwise of Ringer's lactate solution, glucose or other volume expanders not derived from blood.

This matter has been carefully considered by me and my instructions are not going to change because I or the above-named patient is unconscious.

The hospital, the medical and nursing personnel caring for the above patient are hereby released from responsibility and liability for any and all untoward effects which flow from the decision not to accept the treatment prohibited in this release.

DATED this day of                  ,197   .

Patient, Parent or Guardian

1/73

98 Medico-Legal; Consent for Treatment

Canad. Med. Ass. J.

Jan. 14, 1967, vol. 9G


MEDICO-LECAL

Consent for Treatment

T. L. FISHER, M.D.,° Ottawa, Ont.

YT IS an axiom of practice that nothing may be done to or for a patient without that patient’s permission. Even though a doctor thinks that without treatment a patient may come to harm, without consent he may not administer the treatment he considers necessary. A doctor is not Cod, nor is he a dictator, and he may not impose treatment against a patient’s wishes, A pafierit ordinarily is his own master. Garrison, J., in a judgment said it this way: “No amount of professional skill can justify a substitution of the will of the surgeon for that of the patient.” The dictum would be equally true were thewords “the doctor” substituted for “the surgeon”.

There is one exception to the rule. When a patient is unable because of his condition to give consent but needs immediate treatment if health or life is to be preserved, the doctor has a duty to administer the emergency treatment even without permission and to continue giving necessary treatment without permission until, and only until, the patient has recovered sufficiently to be made aware of his condition and to have his permission sought; then the patient, once again, becomes his own master.

Under all other circumstances doctors must comply with the wishes of a patient; there must be consent for treatment.

Permission is equally valid whether implied, formally sought and given, or actually written, even though implied permission should be accepted only under circumstances that make it clear that permission actually was implied. The patient for example who, without any prompting, consults a doctor, volunteers a history, supplements the history by answering questions, allows an examination, listens to advice and acts on it, has given implied permission and would have difficulty in maintaining that he had not given consent.

Patients however, like doctors, can change their minds and sometimes do. Then, if a patient be dissatisfied and if circumstances allow the inference that permission for treatment had not been obtained, the patient may claim he had not in fact given permission. Under some circumstances, therefore, a doctor should obtain a pa-

•Siicret.iry-Treasurer. Canadian Medical Protective Association, Suite 115, 20 Nepean St., Ottawa 4. Ontario. tient’s consent in writing so that there may be demonstrable evidence of prior consent, Written consent should invariably be sought, and treatment should not be given until it has been obtained: when the treatment is likely to be more than mildly painful; when it carries appreciable risk; when a mutilating procedure is to be <hmr. Doctors ordinarily do not think of their as mutilating. It often is, however. The doctor tends to think of the preservation of health or .life rather than of the mutilation that may result from the means to the end, but he must remain aware that procedures like amputation of a limb or of a breast are mutilating procedures. Finally, written consent should be obtained prior to any treatment that will result in the ablation of a body function.

Consent by itself is;not enough; it must be informed consent. It should be sought and obtained only after a patient has been given an explanation of the condition from which he suffers, of alternative means of treatment, of the treatment being recommended and of the reason for the recommendation of that particular treatment. If they are significant, risks should be mentioned even though courts have held they need not be so forcefully presented as to frighten a patient away from necessary treatment. Only when such an explanation has preceded a request for consent can the consent be considered an informed consent.

To inform a patient is not always as simple as the simple expression “informed consent” suggests. An explanation must be adapted to the patient so that, to the best of the doctor’s judgment, the patient has the fullest possible understanding. It should be obvious, for example, that a technical, involved explanation may not be explanatory, may actually be confusing to the uneducated, dull patient; on the contrary, a non-specific, general explanation may be: insufficient and unexplanatory to the highly educated. bright individual who may need, for his understanding, much more detailed reasons. To the best of the doctor’s ability to judge the patient, therefore, the explanation must be explanatory, and only after it has been given should consent be sought.

Verbal consent ordinarily is obtained by the doctor. He sees his patient, decides what is the

Canad. Med. Ass. J.

Jan. 14, 1967, vol. 96


Medico-Legal: Consent fob Treatment 99

matter, informs the patient and advises the patient what he thinks should be done, either by the patient himself or by the doctor. If the treatment, commonly an operation, be deferred and done at another time and place, misunderstanding is more likely than when treatment is begun immediately-.

Among the services to doctors for which hospitals have commonly, almost universally, accepted responsibility, when patients are admitted to hospital, is that of obtaining signed permission for treatment and for surgery. There can be no doubt that by this routine, permission is obtained much more consistently than would be the case if each individual doctor had to get signed permission himself. Since the hospital ordinarily asks the patient to sign permission because doctors seldom do, the incorrect opinion is held by many doctors that the hospital needs the consent. It docs not: doctors do. Hospitals do not give medical treatment and do not perform surgery: doctors do. They should be grateful that hospitals so commonly relieve them of the necessity of getting the consent form signed but should remain aware of two things: it is they to whom consent must have been given and it is they, the doctors, who must assure themselves that the necessary written consent has been obtained and is on file.

Recently two doctors have been faced with threats of legal action because it has been claimed no consent for surgery had been given. In neither case had written consent been obtained. In one, however, the circumstances leading up to the operation made it amply clear consent must have been given and the patient abandoned the claim. The issue is still uncertain in the other action; it is not yet known whether the doctor can demonstrate that he had given the patient a proper explanation of her condition and had obtained her consent to surgery.

This kind of claim against doctors should never be possible. Doctors should assure themselves the patient has had his condition explained to him, and when doctors review charts before treatment or operation they should confirm that the patient has signed consent and that the completed consent form is on the chart.

See alsos

"Life or Death — Whose Decision?"

Section DRT-31




Two,


1958 i T. \


WITHOUT

TRANSFUSION



•I-.-


■

si


WITHOUT

TRANSFUSION

Whole human blood has saved countless lives, but even when this scarce commodity is available it cannot always be used.

The usual relaxed atmosphere in the operating theater was missing. Although major surgery is never a light-hearted airair, it is rarely the grim, tightlipped scene portrayed in films and television Miraculous as modern surgery may seem to the uninitiated, most operations follow a course the surgeon has seen many times. The light banter passing back and forth over the towel-draped form of the patient does not arise from negligence or lack of alertness, but rather from the confident routine of a familiar task. But today's business was not routine.

The atmosphere was not so much tense as intent. The surgical team was not nervous, but they were visibly concerned. A conflict existed between current medical opinion and religious beliefs The religious beliefs had won, but physicians were not certain the patient would win also. Lying still on the operating table and breathing lightly under the anesthetic was a 39 year old woman facing open heart surgery to correct a serious heart valve defect. She was a )eho-va h' s Witness whose religious be -liefs forbade the use of blood trans-fusions—even though she might die without them.

The members of this religious group believe that if they submit to transfusion they will lose all opportunity for life after death. And they will he ostracised by their associates for the remainder of this life. Their belief is based on numerous biblical prohibitions against eating blood, "You must not eat the blood of any sort of flesh, because the soul of every sort of flesh is its blood" (Lev. 17:13,14), and "I shall certainly set my face against the soul that is eating the blood, and I shall indeed cut him off from among his people" (Lev. 17:10). In the eyes of Jehovah's Witnesses, receiving a blood transfusion is the same as feeding on the blood of another.



Baylor surgeons had the task of repairing one valve in the woman's heart and replacing another with an artificial valve, a double procedure not without risk in any patient. They felt the bloodless operation was possible, but it presented two major difficulties. First, they would have to use a heartlung machine to put oxygen into the blood and to keep that precious supply of oxygen flowing through the patient's brain during the time her heart was stopped. This life-saving device normally needs about three pints of blood to prime its pumps and fill its tubing and blood reservoir before it is connected to the patient.

Secondly, if any emergency arose in which whole blood was needed —leaking of a repaired blood vessel, the slightest mis-step in procedure causing a rapid loss of blood, or excessive hemorrhage after surgery—the surgeon's hands vould be tied from saving the parent's life. The woman had signed a release absolving the doctors from responsibility in such a situation, but a simple piece of paper could .never erase the memory of failure nor release them from a moral responsibility.

To prime the pump of the heartlung machine they used, instead of blood, a five per cent solution of dextrose, a simple sugar, in distilled water. This would dilute the patients blood somewhat, but, hopefully, not beyond her limits of tolerance. As for emergencies, the only answer was not to let them occur. If they did, it would take more than medical skill to handle them.

The operation began. An incision was made. The breast bone, which would quickly heal after the operation, was sawed through exposing the living, beating heart. Working swiftly, surgeons joined human tissue with the inanimate steel and plastic of the heart-lung machine. This was the critical moment.

"Everything secure?"

"Yes sir, ready to go."

"Pump on."

Ready hands flashed over switches. The hum-click of the heart-lung machine filled the still air of the operating room. The crystal purity of the dextrose solution grew pink-tinged, then red, then crimson as it mixed with the patient's own blood. A silent, waiting minute ticked by, then another.


"How's she doing?"

"Holding steady. Encephalogram and cardiogram normal. Arterial and venous pressure steady. Look's like we're in good shape."

"Alright, let's get on with it."

The heart was stopped and opened. The first valve was repaired, the second deftly excised and the artificial vaive, a small ball in a cage, fitted snugly in place and sutured in. The surgeons worked rapidly, using as little time as possible without crossing that fine line which borders on incautious haste. Every bleeding vessel was quickly clamped and tied. Every drop of blood escaping from the heart was caught up with a suction probe and returned to the artificial circulation.

For those watching through the observation window, the time crept by. The operating team was too intent to notice its passage. Finally the heart was closed. Electrodes were placed on either side.

"Current!"

The heart, after lying still nearly an hour had begun to function with an uncoordinated, spasmodic twitch when its blood supply was reestablished. In medical terms it was fibrillating—beating, but not pumping blood effectively. The electric jolt came. The heart hesitated. Then, with a firm beat, it resumed the steady contractions it had maintained for a lifetime.

"How's it look?"

"Heart action normal, pressure normal. ! think we're in."

"O.K. Let's close up and go home."

The reservoir of her own blood remaining in the heart-lung machine was slowly drained back into the patient, returning the irreplaceable, oxygen-carrying red blood cells with a minimum of loss. Excess fluid from the dextrose solution used to prime the pump would be speedily removed from the patient's system by her kidneys. A row of sutures closed the incision in her chest. The operation was over successfully—but would the patient live?

Sixteen days later she left the hospital under her own power. X-rays taken six months later showed her heart had shrunk from its overworked, enlarged size to nearly normal, and a full year after her operation she was still doing well.

Since that memorable day, Baylor surgeons have successfully operated on numerous Jehovah's Witnesses and other patients without using the formerly customary blood transfusions. Although it would seem to make surgical procedures more risky, they have found there are actually advantages in not using large amounts of replacement blood. Economically it is a large advantage; the dextrose solution is only a fraction of the cost of whole blood. The complex blood type matching procedure is not needed, eliminating another cost and a possible source of error. And the ever present danger of transfusion hepatitis is removed. The slight temporary anemia resulting from blood dilution seems quite manageable with iron supplement treatment, and it does not appear to retard the patient's recovery. And obviously, any procedure which lessens the drain on scarce blood bank reserves leaves that much more of the priceless ’ substance available for other emergencies.

The challenge of religion versus medicine has been well met, and much has been gained. Doctors have learned that they may be called upon to modify their management of a patient's illness when there are factors more important to the patient than his own health or even his life. The patient's ideals and honor must be respected. Sometimes, as in the case of surgery for Jehovah's Witnesses, the modified procedures developed can be of wide medical benefit to other patients.

Surgeons rest easier when they know a supply of blood is available to them. But "bloodless" open heart surgery is no longer the breath catching phrase it once was. Now, when a surgeon arrives at the operating theater on days when this procedure is to be followed, the atmosphere is relaxed as usual. It is a routine day.

VOX ME®

— ....

Our Unforgivable Trespass

Jack Kevorkian, M.D.

Scene: Saturday night in a city hospital. An anemic six-year-old child must undergo an emergency major operation. Several blood transfusions will be necessary before the surgeon can begin his work. Without the transfusions chances of survival are nil; the outlook is greater than 50-50 if the blood is given. But the parents refuse permission for transfusion! They will allow surgery, but blood is not to be given to their child. Their religious principles absolutely proscribe jt. All argumentation is to no avail. Doctors and hospital officials are perplexed, angered, and even outraged. Hurriedly a meeting is held. What to do? The courts are closed till Monday. There’s only one recourse. A judge is called, and an emergency “court" session is held in his home. After this due process of law, the child is made a temporary waif and a ward of the court. Authority is immediately granted to the medical personnel to proceed with transfusions and surgery. The blood is given. The operation is performed. And all ends well.

Or does it? One can say only that most ends well, for the will of the majority triumphed in the above dramatic situation—the will of the doctors, nurses, technologists, judges, administrators, and lay masses composing society. They are the "good guys” who saved a life despite the stupid, narrow-minded, misguided, fanatic obstinacy of two pitiful human beings who should know better. These two are part of the antipodal minority who, if they are realistic, do not hope to be

Address: 498 Beverly Island Drive, Pontiac, Michigan 48054.

heeded in the illogical rush of modern society.

Posed, however, is a far more profound problem than the superficial judicial treatment described here would indicate. Criss-crossing through it are divergent concepts of the importance and meaning of religion and law, of disease and health, and of life and death. Such concepts and the reactions to them are grounded firmly in a wide spectrum of subjectivity, scrutiny of which has taxed the greatest philosophical minds. To even begin to probe their connection with the problem at hand is hopelessly beyond the scope of this brief exploration of insight and understanding and, perhaps, even of sympathy for the child's parents.

The first obvious question is crucial: Which is the highest ideal and the greatest Good, religion or secular law? If one answers law, then for him the problem doesn't even exist. He can stop here, for the greatest Good in theory will have prevailed over a lesser (by definition) Good in practice. This is consistent and logical, but basically irreligious or atheistic.

If one answers that both are equally Good, the conflict becomes insoluble. The morality of any action concerning it would, of necessity, become unassessable in any instance. The concepts "law” and "religion” would be artificial indefinable, and fundamentally inseparable. He, too, can stop here.

Now, if religion or any sort of faith in the supernatural is higher than law, then the problem is again easily resolved. Where the two conflict, religious tenets will prevail. But just what is religion? Does a highly unorthodox snake-handling cult constitute a religious faith?


Would its doctrines supersede law? It seems to me that any group of individuals professing a certain faith, no matter how extraordinary or “fallacious" it may seem, ought to be allowed to exercise the principles of that faith, even at the risk of possible bodily or spiritual damage to themselves, so long as others outside that faith are in no way threatened or endangered. Thus law, in this example admittedly a lesser Good, should not supersede faith except to protect non-believers (just as in epidemics of contagious diseases the rights and liberties of an individual are restricted by law to protect the welfare of the community). Deadly snakes may harm some one not directly concerned with ritual handling, and the practice could justifiably be regulated by law. On the other hand, if receiving a blood transfusion is contrary to the religious teachings being followed by an individual, judicial enforcement would be immoral; for society would thereby have invoked a lesser Good to violate a higher principle in a situation not threatening, by any stretch of the imagination, any person or group holding any other belief or philosophic view.

Even if such intervention were assumed to be ethical and logical beyond question, one could not be sure that the action taken would indeed be beneficial for the individual concerned..It is true today that blood transfusions under certain circumstances are undeniably beneficial, and that to doubt this bordeis on insanity. At the same time o'tie' should bear in mind that to have doubted the medical efficacy of us ing leeches for exsanguination- -even in the treatment of undetected or unrecognized anemia—at tin*

jiine it was practiced several centuries ago would likewise have been branded insanity and heresy of the highest order. Can any rational man say with sincere certainty that the use of blood transfusions will not be looked upon as utter foolishness several centuries hence?          ~

The point in all this is clear. Current medical procedures are at best only relatively beneficial, being based on empirical knowledge and experience. Knowledge yet to be gained is not only infinite in amount and quality; it vastly outweighs that which we have. In other words, everything humans think or do is based on relative ignorance, not on relative knowledge. This very precarious situation is easy to ignore. To compound things by using that precarious state to justify forcible desecration of a defenseless citizen’s own spiritual world would be tolerable only to a callous, passionate, and reckless organism such as man. If in the future blood transfusions are adjudged to be a form of "leech medicine,” then posterity will have cause to damn us doubly. That is the risk the "good guys” are taking, though to them it may seem specious or small.

Up to this point many might agree without a great deal of persuasion. What seems to be unacceptable is the concept of endangering the life of an innocent ignorant child through scrupulous adherence to religious doctrine. One should not lose sight of tii'e fact that prF mary responsibility for the rearing and welfare of a child rests witlr the parents. They are closer to the child both physically and spiritually than the impersonal corporation called "society.” They have the right—indeed, almost a duty—to impart their religious or philosophic doctrines (within the framework mentioned earlier) to the child. Their right has priority. If the parents choose to live or die according to the dictates of a certain creed, then the child should follow suit. In essence, both act involuntarily; in either case, parent or child, the effect is caused by what is designated as divine revelation, and not by human volition or caprice.

The dilemma boils down to a vital philosophical argument: in questions involving personal highest principles of parents versus law of society, which should hold sway? If the latter, as is now the case, then pure socialism is the greatest Good, and Plato’s Republic is the bible, and one could never know (or care) which principles might be foisted on whose children. Organized religion would be no more than a meaningless farce and a mockery; the state supreme.

Perhaps the most fundamental question is what is the value of terrestrial life, anyway? Is it to be valued above all else? If so, then society’s present outlook is correct. Save the life of the child at all costs! Spend ail the money; use all the material; smash all doctrines! Socrates be damnedl

If not, if there is some principle higher than life, if Socrates’ point did get across, then the “good guys” are wrong. The life of the child becomes less important than the, integrity of the religious principles to _which the parents adhere and according to which they wish to raise him.

Maybe the warmth of a historical example will drive home this point more firmly. Most people in the Western World profess to be Christians. They respect other Christians and almost deify the early martyrs who were fed to the lions in ancient Rome rather than renounce their faith. Almost deify them! Yet those early martyrs joyously allowed their own children to die in lions’ jaws. Innocent, ignorant children! And the martyrs are idolized, because 2,000 years ago they were the “good guys” who apparently professed exactly the same principles as the "good guys” do today, and who luckily didn’t have to worry about the transfusion problem complicating the harassment of Nero’s legions. Why for religious reasons can the involuntary; artificial (and much more grotesque) death of children then be almost divine, and the involuntary but entirely natural death of the same kind of children for the same reasons now be almost criminal? After all, in both instances minority beliefs were and are involved. What’s the difference?

Lack of reason and common sense, and emotionalism, and hypocrisy—these make the difference; and it’s a big one to most minds!


RELIGION AFFECTS PRACTICE OF MEDICINE

TEXAS MEDICINE

r°W 66, Dtcembtr, 1970


A!l mankind seems to have a basic hunger for understanding of God and yet the physician and clergyman, both of whom are involved with helping their fellow man to more abundant life, have traditionally appeared to be the antithesis of each other regarding religious matters. While the preacher said of death, "God wills it,” the physician cursed his own ineptness and fretted, "If only I knew a little more!”

Today these attitudes are changing; physicians and clergymen are realizing that they both have an important place beside the sickbed and that they need to work in harmony. The physician needs to learn anything he can about his patient's fears, family problems, beliefs, and motivations for life. And the clergyman needs to understand his parishioner's illness, its seriousness, its implications, its economic stresses, and the patient's guilt feelings, fears, doubts, and unnamed dreads.

The effort to bring medicine and religion closer together is not an attempt to turn clergymen into "junior psychiatrists." Nor is it an open invitation to the preacher to get his theological licks in while some poor sinner is flat pn his back.

Pad of the program is to help the sick person’s minister be an adequate representative of the patient’s image of God, because there are many ways to see Him.

Another part of the program is to help the physician recognize that religion does have something to do with medica 1 decisions. I am a Presbyterian, but when I treat a nJ i I ness that affects the body, mind, and spirit of the person in my care, it is what he believes that is important.

His beliefs, not mine, are the ones that affect his response to treatment. His beliefs, not mine, are the ones that cause him to feel fear, doubt, and guilt.

If my patient does not believe in blood transfusions, what i think _about them does not matter. If : treat a Roman Catholic for a fertility problem, the fact that I see nothing wrong with collecting a sperm specimen in a bottle for study is unimportant; what matters is that my patient believes coitus interruptus is evil and masturbation is unthinkable. I need to know what the Orthodox Jew believes about food, organ transplants, and autopsies; I need to know what the Christian Scientist believes in his innermost soul.

it is the faith of the patient that we doctors need to understand and respect. Whether our own

25

religious belief is strong or nonexistent, it Js a human conviction which we have ns right tg impasg en §ny ethsr person^ Especially when he is iij and frightened.

No longer are physicians and clergymen on opposite sides of a controversy.

We are at last beginning to converse with each other about our common responsibility to the sick.

Here are some medical problems that deserve conversations with men of God:

A mother of four small children has a lump in her breast and is making plans to enter the hospital for biopsy and possibly radical surgery. What does she fear? What can we do? If you were her doctor, would you call her minister? If you were her minister, would you call her doctor? How can we, working together, help her through this fear-ridden crisis?

A young man with a new job and a new son—working hard to make ends meet—is hit by a car driven by an uninsured motorist, and sustains a compound, comminuted fracture of the tibia. He lies in bed with ropes and pulleys and sandbags and pain—and bills. No money is coming in, but it is costing $100 a day just to lie there, and for how long? What can we do? Can the preacher help? Can the doctor help more than just by putting things together and putting on a cast? What are this man’s fears and frustrations? What is his faith?

A lifelong friend brings his anguished problem: His daughter, a fine and intelligent girl, is pregnant. The young manhonorable and filled with remorse—is willing, but not eager to marry her. How do you help return a sorrowful human to a useful life with dignity, and rebuild sufficient seif respect?

Being a doctor can be a lonely business

26

sometimes. Being a clergyman must be a lonely business, too. When it comes to eare of whole person, I believe we arg both on the same team.

We physicians can take a new look at what Ambroise Pare wrote nearly 400 years ago: ‘‘I dressed him and God healed him.”

Grant F. Begley, MD, Fort Worth.                 .

TEXAS MEDICINE

THE PEDIATRIC CLINICS OF NORTH AMERICA

February 1965 Vol. 12 No. 1

92                                       Pitfalls in Hematology

226. Believing that the parenteral administration of iron is rarely indicated.

There is good reason to consider using the safest form of parenteral iron (Imferon) in patients with iron deficiency when a significant bowel disorder (intolerance) exists or when there is parental irresponsibility. Many consider Imferon to be a safe medication. According to some, iron may be as safe to give intramuscularly as orally. Oral iron poisoning is an important cause of poisoning in children.

228. Giving transfusions for mild (asymptomatic) anemia.

Except before nonelective surgery, the correction of hemoglobin levels above 6 gm. per 100 ml. is not usually indicated, since the benefits do not outweigh the possible risks of a transfusion reaction.

Pitfalls in Hematology

93


231. Giving unnecessary blood transfusions.

Some still give transfusions—for a “boost”—to semi-chronically ill children with a whole blood hemoglobin level between 8 and 10 gm. per 100 ml. There must be recognition of the fact that the mortality and morbidity rates of transfusion are not negligible. If the anemia in presurgical patients is treatable and the operation is elective, the anemia should be corrected medically. There should be discussion of this problem between the pediatrician and the anesthetist.

See also Section DLGJ-32 (p 113) for a judge’s comment on the legal aspect.

MEDICAL yvORLU «S □ January 8, 1971

SSCHLE CELL 'CORE9

THE PBCMSE,

THE PERIL

Urea combats crises of disease but can cause dehydration


Contrary to some newspaper headlines, urea will not cure sickle cell disease. But rapid intravenous infusions of urea seem highly effective in reversing sickling crises, according to Dr. Robert M, Nalbandian, associate pathologist at Blodgett Memorial Hospital, Grand Rapids, Mich., and principal architect of this widely publicized approach. Moreover, maintenance doses of oral urea—mixed in invert sugar" or glucose—may prevent the painful episodes, reduce hospitalization and chronic care, and confer full life spans on sickle cell anemics.

' The urea approach, however, got a much frostier assessment from hematologists who gathered recently in the soft winds and sunshine of Puerto Rico. Many experts at the American Society of Hematology meeting in San Juan were dubious about urea’s efficacy. They also questioned the theoretical basis of the regimen, emphasized the dangers of urea infusions, and attacked the Detroit press conference that triggered last month’s national news coverage.

Dr. Nalbandian told mwn that he will no longer release his protocol to physicians who might be interested in trying this therapy. “We have now enlisted enough bona fide investigators to begin a closed clinical trial to determine the real efficacy of urea,” he said, and warned that attempting to use urea without his specific protocol could result in “serious misadventures.”

Obtaining the evidence needed to convince critics may take several years, Dr. Nalbandian admitted. So

Pathologist Nalbandian shows evidence of how I.V.

infusions of urea convert sickled red cells into normal disk shape.


far, intravenous infusions of urea have been tried in only 22 patients during 30 sickle cell crises. Experience with the oral prophylactic regimen is limited to three patients.

The task will be complicated by the changeable manifestations of sickle cell anemia and the subjective evaluations of pain and other symptoms rendered by its victims. “At best, the researchers will be trying to evaluate a variable response to an agent in a disease with a very variable course,” said Dr. Helen Raney, professor of medicine at the School of Medicine of the State University of New York at Buffalo. As the nation’s estimated 45,000 sickle cell anemics and their physicians stand by, urea could join dozens of other agents emerging during the past decade as a “possible” solution, but not the answer.

But there is a more immediate and profound effect of the urea research —on the estimated two million Americans who possess the sickle cell trait. The Grand Rapids-Detroit group has developed three tests that are specific for the pathogenic hemoglobin S (HbS) molecule, including an automated assay which can identify the heterozygous carrier of the sickle cell gene at a cost of only pennies per test. A growing body of scientific evidence this past year clearly indicates that the sickle cell trait can no longer be considered a benign state, said Dr. David G. Nathan, chief of the division of hematology at Children’s Hospital Medical Center, Boston. Identification of trait-carriers could be an enormous health benefit to the country’s Negroes, who are the almost exclusive possessors of the trait. ■

Both the urea test and the urea therapy rest on a molecular sickling theory proposed by Dr. Makio Murayama, a soft-spoken Japanese-American biochemist from the National Institutes of Health. Working in a tiny jam-packed laboratory in Bethesda, Md., Dr. Murayama developed a hypothesis that hydrophobic bonds form between interacting tetramers of HbS

continued

SICKLE CELL CURE’ conNnued under deoxygenated conditions. These chains then become organized into microcables, forcing the red blood cells into their characteristic tachtoid shapes, which subsequently occlude the microcirculation.

Putting this theory to work in vivo to break the hydrophobic bonds, Dr. Nalbandian rapidly infuses urea mixed in invert sugar or glucose through a central venous catheter and maintains blood urea levels ranging between 150 to 200 mg%, “At these levels, the urea diffuses out of the bloodstream, through the interstitial spaces, and into the sickled cells at the occluded arterioles and capillaries,” hypothesizes Dr. Nalbandian. “This molecular surgery reverses the sickling, allows blood flow to return to normal, and relieves the pain symptoms.”

The oral prophylactic scheme involves a daily urea intake of as much as lf>0 gm. "In general, we give each patient about 10% of the total dose of intravenous urea needed to abort a crisis,” said Dr. Nalbandian, The daily requirement of urea is divided into four doses and dissolved in a citrus-flavored soft drink to cloak the bitter taste. The patient drinks a bottle of urea-laden pop once before each meal and once before going to sleep. Since pharmaceutical urea sells for about a dollar a pound, Dr. Nalbandian figures that the daily maintenance dose of the chemical costs about a dime.

Although it is still too early to have much data from the oral urea trials, more evidence is available from the 30 I.V. infusion attempts, the first of them last March in Kalamazoo, Mich. Dr. Garth Schultz, then a medical resident at Blodgett Memorial Hospital, was treating a sickle cell anemic student from West Africa. Although an initial attack partly remitted with narcotics and antibiotics, the patient soon returned to the hospital with increased fever and even more pain in his chest, sides, and neck.


When this crisis proved refractory to morphine and other therapeutic regimens. Dr. Shultz consulted Dr. Nalbandian and instituted urea therapy. Eleven hours later, the patient noticed some pain relief and after 36 hours said he had no pain.

Since then. Dr. Shultz has used I.V. urea to treat one other sickle cell anemic. Dr. Nalbandian has supervised therapy in Grand Rapids for two patients, and from one to three crises have been treated with urea infusions in Seattle, Chicago, Detroit, Philadelphia, and Flint. Mich. However, the largest collection of cases belongs to Dr. Paul R. McCurdy, associate professor of medicine at Georgetown University School of Medicine and a medical officer in hematology at District of Columbia General Hospital.

Speaking in the grand ballroom of the Puerto Rico Sheraton Hotel, Dr. McCurdy said that he was “cautiously optimistic” after trying I.V. urea for 18 crises in ten patients. (ln 13 such episodes, the victims responded so well to the treatment that they could be released from D.C. General’s ER without analgesics.

Dr. McCurdy prefers to maintain patients at 100 mg% rather than the recommended 150 or 200. This might account for the five treatment failures. The main reason for Dr. Me-

Biochemist Murayama uses his model of two deoxygenated interacting tetramers of S hemoglobin to explain sickling action—the formation of hydrophobic bonds and displacement of darker beta-S globulins laterally.

Curdy’s caution is a “Niagara-like diuresis,” amounting to as much as 20 or 30 liters in 24 hours, which accompanies intravenous urea infusion. Unless fluid intake can be maintained, a patient will develop severe dehydration possibly leading to convulsions, subdural hematomas, and even death. “The slightest evidence of dehydration must be counteracted immediately,” emphasized Dr. Nalbandian.

“As a result of the widespread publicity, I am afraid that some people are trying this therapy without the proper guidance or safeguards,” said hematologist Frank Gardner. “Even if urea has value, you may get deaths attributed to this approach rightly or wrongly, leading the FDA to ban its use.”

Indeed, Dr. Donald L. Rucknagel of the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, reported that a four-year-old patient arrived in his medical center severely dehydrated after supposedly receiving urea therapy at another hospital. The child had also sustained a cerebral 'hemorrhage, and urea could not be held responsible for her death, said Dr. Rucknagel. but he voiced grave “concern” over the safety of his therapy.

That’s a mild word for the discussions behind closed doors and in private conversations, where the gloves came off. Charges of irresponsibility and sensationalism met with countercharges of scientific ignorance and illiteracy. Critics branded the initial press conference as “terribly premature” and “disgraceful.”

Hematologist Walter H. Seegers, chairman of the department of physiology and pharmacology at Wayne State, said the news briefing was held primarily to find support for further urea trials. “Dr. Nalbandian didn’t do anything but go out and beat the bushes for money,” said Dr. Seegers. "L know all of the research team personally and they have long records of productive and reliable reporting. 1 don’t know of any study with a better theoretical background that tits together so well.”

“He has performed a real service by making other scientists look at a different model for the sickling process and its direct application to therapy,” said internist Stephen Foster of the blood resources F'anch of the National Heart and Lung Institute. “However, the anecdotal information available is almost useless in evaluating where we stand on the urea question other than to say that it constitutes an avenue of approach which needs further study.”

This cool and dispassionate news may not sit well with the one in every 500 American Negroes who is homozygous for hemoglobin S and faces a life expectancy of only 20 years, with much of that time spent in pain and recurrent illness. Last year, the Journal of the American Medical Association and Lancet published reports of hemolytic episodes and deaths under anesthetic conditions in trait patients. Then the New England Journal of Medicine printed an article describing sudden death among four black recruits who were taking basic training at Ft. Bliss, Tex. Dr. Stephen R.
