    Willi Parents’ Permission


    Hamilton Spectator, Thursday, Nov. 7, 1968


    ■ i

    O-.VjJ


    Leukemia Victims ‘Used As Guinea Pigs’

    o


By MAX WICKENS Spectator Staff

BURLINGTON—Some of Toronto’s sickest child leukemia *y i c t~ i m s are spending theirr~lying days as guinea jiigs_ in the quest for drugs~To help their fellow sulferers"

Dr. Marilyn Sonley, chief paediatrician at Princess Margaret Hospital was speaking during “Burlington Clinic Day” — an annual refresher-symposium for members of the general practice staff at Joseph Brant Memorial Hospital.

Dr. Sonley emphasized the experiments w ere carried out with the full consent of the childrens’ parents.

“The parents are fully advised as to the possibility the drugs could have an adverse affect — even kill,” she told about 30 doctors and nurses from Joseph Brant Memorial Hospital.

“But the parents' usual reaction is: ‘What else can we do? He’s going to die soon anyway’.”

THE EXPERIMENTAL doses, she said, are “always last drugs” — final shots given when the child “already is in bad shape.”

The experiments are a touchy matter, Dr. Sonley noted, explaining “a lot of people had fears about putting children into controlled studies. They worried that it might not be regarded as ethical.”

Even so, she said, tests of this type and other trial combinations of drugs administered to children in less advanced stages of the disease — a cancer which attacks blood-making tissue — have brightened the leukemia picture.

Although st.ill_.a-fatal disease, cinki sufferers — under cfrug treatment — were now returning to normal life for three to five years instead of spending two or three months doomed, dying and bed-ridden.

ONE CHILD has survived 15 years. Many others have plunged headlong into a full range of school activities ranging from student politics to athletics. One young victim recently took Metro championship awards in track and field events.

Apart from the parents, Dr. Sonley said, “we try to tell as few people as possible of the diagnosis (of leukemia).”

To explain their regular hospital visits for drugs and examination, “we tell the children they’ve got a peculiar form of anemia and need regular monthly treatment.

“We try to encourage the parents to get the children back to normal life. We try to suppress their ideas of giving the children horses or a last trip to Disneyland.”

THE PARENTS are also advised against telling friends and neighbours of their child’s, condition.

"We don’t want gossip getting back to the children —. their friends telling them ‘we hear you’re going to die soon’. Leukemia is not an automatic sentence to death in the next five months.”

Earlier -in her address. Dr Sonley noted that modern control of infectious disease has left cancer second only to accidents as the major cause of child deaths over the age of one year.

Of these, leukemia attacks about 50 children in every 1,-000,000. In Metro where there are about 1,000,000 children, new cases arrive at the rate of about one a week at Princess Margaret Hospital.

Dr. Sonley delivered her address during a Burlington Clinic Day — an annual series of refresher seminars for general piactice staff members at the local hospital.




THE JOURNAL OF THE MAINE MEDICAL ASSOCIATION

__                                                                                                                                      S$t

Dietary Management of the Chronically Uremic Patient

Our Experiences at Maine Medical Center

.                     Miss Phyllis B, Cushman, R.D.**

Tze importance of diet therapy in the treatment of izz-zev failure has been recognized for many years. With —e development of the artificial kidney and kidney transplantation, proper dietary restriction has remained nnportant for a number of reasons. With careful dietary management, the length of time between treatments on the artificial kidney may be extended and the total num-net of treatments and the total cost may be reduced.

Dietary control of kidney failure is not simple. The type and severity of kidney disease varies among individuals, and diet varies to meet these needs. Time may produce variation in the presence and severity of certain symptoms in individual patients, and therapy must change to meet the needs at the particular moment.

Dietary treatments of renal failure, and dialysis can maintain the patient until kidney transplantation is possible

There are three types of low protein diets in use at present. There is no firm basis for using one of these unless there is objective evidence of nitrogen retention, as in uremia.

The three types of protein diets are:

  • 1. The Low Protein, Low Sodium, Low Potassium Diet.                              .

This diet normally contains 40 grams of varied protein sources with a 500-800 mg. (21-35 mEq.) sodium limitation and a 1500 mg. (38 mEq.) potassium limitation. Fluids may or may not need to be restricted. Adjustments in all four components may be made as the condition demands. This diet is most often used in the early stages of uremia and may be used when a patient is receiving dialysis.

  • 2. Electro dialyzed whey or E D W diet.

This diet contains E D W,® a low protein commercial product from Wyeth Laboratoryy It is available at present to a few Dialysis Centers for investigational purposes. It is high in calories and low in protein, sodium, and potassium. By using it, dialysis treatments are needed less frequently thus reducing cost and allowing the centers to dialyze more patients. The major difficulty is its poor acceptance by the patients.

  • 3. The Modified Giovanetti Diet

This diet consists of selected proteins in the amount of 18 to 20 grams. Sodium, potassium and fluids may or may not be limited according to individual needs. The physiological basis is still not completely understood. 1 However, by providing a delicate balance between essential and non-essential amino acids, it enables the body to use its own wastes efficiently. It is known that the diet cannot be liberalized without upsetting the balance and precipitating a return of symptoms which had been alleviated by adherence to the Modified Giovanetti Diet.

The Maine Medical Center has two Modified Giovanetti Diets available: the first, restricted to 20 grams of selected protein, 800 mg. (35 mEq.) sodium and 1500 mg. (38 mEq.) potassium; the second, restricted to 20 grams selected protein with no limitations on sodium or potassium. We restrict fluids only when ordered. The criteria for fluid restriction is a consideration of the volume of urine formed and the insensible fluid loss. The sodium in diet #1 can be further restricted by using unsalted butter or it can be increased by adding salt in preparation or after, preparation of foods. The potassium in diet #1 should not be further restricted as this would reduce calories to inadequacy. A minimum of 2000 calories is essential in order to avoid tissue protein catabolism with its undesirable effects as discussed later.

The selected protein of both Modified Giovanetti Diets consists of 1 egg and 61/2 oz. milk providing IB1/? grams of protein of high biological value. The remainder of protein is made up of 3 slices of special low protein bread, 1 serving of cereal, and 3 servings of select vegetables. This provides the minimal requirements of essential amino acids except methionine, and as little of the non-essential amino acids as possible. A second egg may be used in place of the milk. Meat, fish and poultry are not used because they contain relatively greater amounts of non-essential amino acids. Endogenous protein turnover is reduced to a minimum by giving only the bare minimum requirements of the essential amino acids daily. In uremia, endogenous urea along with ocher nitrogenous products can be reutilized in the synthesis of non-essential amino acids if the minimal requirements of essential amino acids and calories are provided in the diet. Some of the "complete” protein foods should be included at each meal to provide the most effective mixture of amino acids.

Calories from carbohydrate and fat sources must be adequate to avoid catabolism of tissue protein as much as possible. The energy needs of the body take priority over other functions. The body normally tends to use carbohydrate as its main source of energy, but if it 14 not sufficiently available tissue protein catabolism may result. Catabolism of protein adds to the excretory load for urea and potassium. A reduction in tissue break-nineteen HUNDRED AND SEVENTY—JUNE down retards the release of potassium from the cells into the extracellular fluid including vascular space. A high potassium blood level threatens cardiac function and may affect the nervous system.

The provision of adequate calories at low protein, low sodium, and low potassium levels is difficult because the selection of foods is so limited. The choice of carbohydrate is critical since significant amounts of protein are present in all the "bulk” carbohydrates. The special low protein bread is essential in this respect. The Maine Medical Center uses Dietetic Paygel P Wheat Starch Flour available from General Mills to make this bread. Other brands available are:

  • 1. Self-Raising Wheat Starch Flour (Mac Dowell Brothers, Ogdensburg, New York). This one is not suitable for restricted sodium diets.

  • 2. Resource Baking Mix** (D. M. Doyle Pharmaceutical Company, Minneapolis, Minnesota).

  • 3. Cellu Lo/Pro Low Protein Baking Mix** (Chicago Dietetic Supply Company, La Grange, Illinois).

  • 4. Low Protein Dry Mix (University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario).

The special bread made from Dietetic Paygel P Wheat Starch Flour is of unusual texture, almost a cross between bread and cake. It is preferred toasted by most patients. It must, however, be handled with extreme c.ire as it crumbles easily. There are other items, desserts and muffins, that may be made, and our diets may be rearranged in the future to include them.

Alcohol is a good source of calories but its use must be balanced against fluid restrictions and local attitudes. D. M. Doyle has another product available which can be figured into the diet and is useful in providing calories with no protein. This product, Controlyte,® when prepared according to the directions on the can provides 370 cc fluid, 1000 calories, 20 mg. (.87 mEq.) sodium ind 8 mg. (.20 mEq.) potassium. Between meal feedings are desirable to provide a continuous source of talories thus minimizing tissue catabolism.

The potassium allowed in diet "1 should be spaced throughout the day to avoid sudden blood level increases. Potassium and sodium are found in many foods naturally. Foods with a high content are excluded, where a limited amount of moderately high content foods ■Tijy be used to make the diet as palatable as possible. I he method of preparation of vegetables affects the po-ussium content. Raw vegetables usually have a higher p otassium content than those cooked in a large amount ■ of water and drained well, because some of the potas-lum is in the discarded fluid. Draining of canned vege-’■ffiles and fruits not only reduces fluid but reduces the N'assium content to some degree.

Actually Resource Baking Mix from Doyle Pharmaceutical Company and Cellu Low Protein Baking Mix from Chicago dietetic Supply Company are the same basic product. It was :irst made and sold by General Mills, and it is still being made by them but is distributed only by Doyle and Chicago dietetic Supply House.

115

Both sodium and potassium are involved in the maintenance of fluid balance. In uremia, fluid intake and fluid output must be carefully balanced. Fluid intake may be normal if no edema is present. Since the malfunctioning kidneys are unable to concentrate and dilute the urine, the excretion of waste products is impaired. Fluid intake may be increased slightly to help the body excrete waste products. Fluids normally need to be decreased late in the course of renal insufficiency. Water may be removed by dialysis, therefore, allowing some patients a higher fluid intake than would otherwise be possible. There are three sources of water to the body; water itself, water contained in foods, and water formed by oxidation of foodstuffs in the body. The latter normally figures about 400 millilitres daily. If fluid retention is extreme, considerable attention to the water content of the food may be required. Within the last three years, however, we have only had to figure the water content of every food for two patients. Normally we need only to eliminate juices, drain fruits and cut down on beverages. As stated earlier, an additional egg could replace the milk if necessary. Fluid allotment should be spaced throughout the day to eliminate thirst.

Nausea and vomiting may initially interfere with acceptance of adequate intake. A blenderized preparation of the diet, therefore, may be better tolerated at first. The major part of the diet may be given in the form of nourishing liquids; gruel, eggnog, fruit juices, melted popsicles and the allowed beverages. We have also been requested to make the diet bland, but this rigidly restricts choices and the monotony is overwhelming. It is impossible to plan a Diabetic Modified Giovanetti Diet since in essence the Modified Giovanetti Diet relies on high carbohydrate foods and the Diabetic Diet necessitates low carbohydrate intake. Sweet foods have been nauseating at first to some patients and this restricts calories too much to make the diet really adequate. Sour-balls counteract the sweet yet greasy mouth sensation of which the patient complains, and sourballs are high carbohydrate with nil protein, sodium and potassium. The allowed gingerale often alleviates nausea and headache.

We specify two cups of Casco® gingerale may be used daily. It is not our policy usually to state brand names in diet copies or use them in teaching, but in some cases we find it beneficial. When writing the Modified Giovanetti Diet #1, we decided to test in our laboratories the beverages we were using since we were all aware that the water used in preparing them did make a difference in their sodium and potassium content. Therefore, we specified particular beverages in order to make this strict diet as accurate as possible.

Once chronic renal failure is apparent, reversal of the basic disease process is virtually impossible. Symptoms can be improved however. Soon after the Modified Giovanetti Diet is instigated as therapy; vomiting, nausea, anorexia, and diarrhea rarely occur. It may be necessary to dialyze the patient before therapy is started, and some

THE JOURNAL OF THE MAINE MEDICAL ASSOCIATION

7 bysicians feel every patient with severe chronic uremia should be given at least one dialysis. These gastrointestinal symptoms are common in patients on standard protein diets. Any indiscretion by patients on the .'■fcdined Giovanetti Diet usually results in a return of gastrointestinal symptoms within 12-24 hours. The onset — terminal uremia may be delayed for several months, besides lengthening life, the Modified Giovanetti Diet makes the patient feel better and he may even be able rc work. The diet is helpful in prolonging the time be-rore repeated dialysis is necessary and sometimes decreases frequency of treatments once they are started.

Treatment by diet is essential even though dialysis removes accumulated wastes. Greater freedom in intake rc some degree may be possible but a controlled diet reduces potentially harmful changes in blood composition between treatments. For instance, by controlling sodium, ■ excessive fluid accumulation between treatments is avoided. Thus high blood pressure is avoided, and the chance of congested lungs and edema is lessened.

There are some disagreements still in regard to dietary treatment for these patients. One is related to treatment on dialysis days. Some feel strongly that diet therapy should not be disregarded at this time because complications might arise, and because they feel it is too difficult for the patient to readjust to the strict diet. Others feel three eggs should be added, and the electrolyte and fluid restriction may be lessened on dialysis days. The eggs they feel compensate for the protein loss.

There are still some unresolved problems. Previously we stated that the methionine requirement was not met by the diet. Some feel, therefore, that 250 milligrams of methionine should be given twice daily as a supplement. Some references, however, state that there is no evidence that the supplement improves ■ the patients' condition. In some cases anemia, invariably a symptom of uremia, is increased when the Modified Giovanetti Diet is utilized; in other cases it is decreased. It also does not often respond to vitamin and iron supplementation. The physician may wish to prescribe iron, calcium, and B complex vitamins, especially folic acid as supplements since the diet is apt to be deficient in these nutrients. Thiamine aids in the metabolism of carbohydrate.

A low protein diet is difficult for many people to accept especially since most Americans are great protein consumers. Most people eat more than is necessary for good health. The Modified Giovanetti Diet is hard to accept since it is so restricted. The Physician and Dietitian must work cooperatively; the physician explaining the purpose of the diet adequately and repeatedly, the dietitian teaching the diet and aiding in meal planning. Those patients who are best informed about their disease and its treatment are most able to receive benefits from the diet and from dialysis. Enthusiasm on our part is a must. Motivation of the patient is extremely important. Teaching should be started early. The patient and his family should be taught about food composition, the reasons for exclusion or inclusion of specific foods, and the importance of reading labels if sodium and potassium are restricted. Follow-up upon discharge is essential, The preferred schedule is every week for 2-3 months, then every three months if the patient is getting along well. The discharged patient must assume the ultimate responsibility of adhering to the prescribed diet and of keeping his follow-up appointments. If the Dietitian and the Physician have done their duty and have taught him well, it is his choice and his life.

Appendix

Modified Giovanetti (Giordano) Diet #1

This Modified Giovanetti Diet may be used for selected patients with renal failure. The diet is planned to supply enough protein in food eaten to minimize breakdown of body stores of protein; to provide the essential amino acids; to minimize the intake of the nonessential amino acids; to maintain caloric equilibrium; and to adjust electrolyte imbalance. The diet is essentially high carbohydrate, low protein (20 gms.), moderate fat (minimum 2000 calories), low sodium (800 mg.), and low potassium (1500 mg.). The diet is deficient in iron, calcium, phosphorus, and the B complex vitamins, therefore the physician may wish to prescribe supplements.

The aim is to provide all the essential amino acids in the allowance of 1 egg and 6V2 ounces of milk daily. The other calories are in the form of carbohydrate and fat, as protein free as possible.

Three meals and in-between meal beverages have been planned. It is essential that the diet be consumed in full. However, some other item may be saved for in-between feeding if desired.

FOODS TO BE INCLUDED:

Milk - 6V- ounces daily

Egg - 1 daily

Cereal - I unsalted serving chosen from:

Cornflakes 1 cup (Van Brode)

Cream of Rice 34 cup

Cream of Wheat 34 cup

Puffed Rice 1 cup

Bread - 3 slices Special Low Protein Bread

Vegetables - 2 from List A and one from List B (in amounts stated). Use fresh, canned without salt, or frozen if no salt or sodium has been used in processing.

Fruits — 4 servings (in amounts stated),

Desserts - 2 popsicles, 8 sourballs and 5 butterballs.

Beverages - 1 cup (150cc) tea, 2 cups (240cc) Casco gingerale, 1 cup (240cc) Snow Crop frozen lemonade (reconstituted as directed), and 1 cup (240cc) Coca Cola or Pepsi Cola or 34 cup (120cc) Cranberry juice.

Fats - 5 tsp. butter or margarine.

Miscellaneous - Sugar, honey, maple syrup and jelly as desired to increase calories; pepper, bay leaves, caraway, cinnamon, gariic, ginger, dry mustard, nutmeg, oregano, paprika, parsley, rosemary, and tarragon in moderation for flavor.

FOODS AVOIDED:

Milk - Any in excess of 6)4 oz. allowed. Buttermilk, cream.

Eggs — Any in excess of 1 allowed.

Cheese - All.

Meats, Fish, Poultry — AU.

Cereals — Any in excess of 1 serving allowed. Any kinds not

NINETEEN HUNDRED AND SEVENTY—JUNE


listed in Allowed list. Spaghetti, noodles, macaroni, and rice. Bread — All except 3 slices Special Low Protein Bread.

Vegetables - Any in excess of the three servings allowed. Baked beans, beet greens, catrots-raw, celery, dandelion greens, kale, Lima beans, legumes, lentils, mushrooms, peas, potato chips, potatoes-French Fried, soybeans, spinach, and Swiss chard.

Fruits — Any in excess of 4 servings allowed. Avocados, dates, melons (except watermelon), prunes, and raisins. ■

Desserts — Cakes, cookies, custard, gelatin, ice cream, junket, pies, puddings, and sherbet (unless water ice).

Soups — All. Bouillon cubes.

Beverages - Milk (in excess of 634 oz. daily allowance), buttermilk, cocoa, coffee; tea, Coca Cola, gingerale, Pepsi Cola in excess of servings allowed; other carbonated beverages.

Fats - Salad dressings and peanut butter.

Miscellaneous — Commercial baking pow'der, baking soda, salt, vegetable salts, salt substitutes, Accent, condiments, pickles, olives, nuts, and popcorn.

THE JOURNAL OF THE MAINE MEDICAL ASSOCIATION

General Mills, Inc., Specialty Products Division, 9200 Wayzata Boulevard, Minneapolis, Minn. 55440. It is packed in No.

10 tins (enough for approximately 4 loaves). Cost $2.50 post paid for one can and $13.50 for one case of six cans. Delivery rime is approximately 2 weeks. Sodium-free baking powder can be obtained from the pharmacist without a prescription. The recipe is:

Tartaric acid                   7.5

Potassium bi-tartrate         56.1

Potassium bi-carbonate      39.8

Cornstarch                  28.0

Bread Recipe - 1 loaf, 27 slices (3/8") thick 1 tbsp, sugar

114 cups warm water

1 pkg. dry active yeast

3 tbsp, sugar

31 tsp. Na free baking pow-

34 tsp. salt

2'4 cups DPP Wheat Starch

34 cup hydrogenated shortening


der

Place 1 tbsp, sugar and water in a large mixer bowl. Add yeast and stir until dissolved; let stand five minutes. Add dry ingredients and shortening. Beat at low speed, scraping sides of bowl until ingredients are moistened; then beat 1 minute at high speed, scraping sides of bowl with rubber spatula. Scrape sides of bowl; cover with towel and let stand at room temperature for 30 minutes. Grease loaf pan, 9 x 5 x 2%" or 8% x 434 x 2 5/8"; set aside. Bear bread mixture down, approximately 25 strokes; pour into greased loaf pan. Cover with towel and let stand at room temperature for 30 minutes. Hear oven to 375°. Bake 55 minutes. Cool bread thoroughly. Refrigerate 1-2 hours after it has reached room temperature.

NOTE.-

Do not pack flour. If bread mixture is like pie crust, add 1-2 tbsp, water; if like pancake batter, add 1-2 tbsp. DPP Wheat Starch. Cover opened can of flour carefully with aluminum foil. To cut bread, use a serrated or an electric knife and cut from bottom to top. Freeze any portion of bread which cannot be eaten in two days — wrap and seal carefully. To thaw, let stand at room temperature 3-4 hours.

Butterhall Recipe

Butterballs are made like butter frosting. The approximate recipe for 50 is 34 lb. butter, 2 cups confectionery sugar and vanilla to flavor. There should be enough sugar to form firm balls when mixture is rolled out. Balls should be thoroughly chilled.

RECIPES FOR MODIFIED GIOVANETTI DIET

Onion Scrambled Egg

1 tbsp, chopped onion           I egg (+2 tsp. water-option-

1 tsp. butter                         al)

pepper to taste

Melt butter in a small frying pan. Saute onion until tender. Slightly whip egg (with water). Pour over the onion and scramble. Serve at once.

Hash Brown Potato (Use as 1 B vegetable and 2 butter) 1 small cold boiled potato 2 tsp. butter 2 tbsp, chopped onion          pepper to taste

Peel and grate potato. Melt butter in a small frying pan. Add onion and potato and fry over medium heat; turn occasionally to obtain desired brownness.

Carrots with Herbs ’A cup canned carrots 1 tsp. butter 2 tsp. water Vi - 34 tsp. sugar

dash of pepper

dash of nutmeg

dash of chopped parsley dash of tarragon


Saute carrots in butter, water and sugar by shaking pan and stirring constantly. When hot, add seasonings and serve.

Fresh Fruit Compole

Make a light syrup of 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water, a piece of lemon rind and a stick of cinnamon. Cut apples and pears in quarters and cook until fruit is tender. Measure out your allowed servings.

Other Suggestions for Use of Herbs with Vegetables Summer Squash with Nutmeg

Summer Squash with Butter, Sugar and Cinnamon Broccoli with Oregano

Modified Giovanetti (Giordano) Diet #2

This Modified Giovanetti Diet may be used for patients with renal failure when abnormal retention of sodium and potassium is not present. The diet is planned to supply enough protein in food eaten to minimize breakdown of body stores of protein; to provide the essential amino acids; to minimize the intake of the nonessential amino acids; and to maintain caloric equilibrium. The diet is low in protein (20 gms.) with liberal use of pure carbohydrate and fat to provide a minimum of 2000 calories. The diet is apt to be deficient in iron, calcium, phosphorus, and the B Complex vitamins, therefore the physician may wish to prescribe supplements.

FOODS TO BE INCLUDED:

Milk — 634 ounces daily.

Egg - 1 daily

Cereal — 1 serving chosen from; 34 cup Cream of Rice, Cream of Wheat, Oatmeal, Rolled Wheat, Bran flakes, Wheaties; 1 cup Cornflakes, Puffed Rice, Puffed Wheat, Rice Krispies; 1 large biscuit Shredded Wheat.

Bread — 3 slices Special Low Protein Bread

Vegetables - two from List A, one from List B (in amounts stated).

Fruits - As desired except avocado. Use sweetened often to add calories.

Desserts — Fruit or popsicles.

Beverages — Coffee, rea, carbonated beverages, lemonade and Kool-Aid.                                             .

Fat — Butter, margarine and oils as desired-use freely to increase calories.

Miscellaneous — Sugar, honey, syrups, jam, jelly, hard candy as desired to increase calories; salt, pepper, vinegar, and spices as tolerated.

FOODS AVOIDED:

Milk — Any in excess of 634 oz. allowed. Cream.

Eggs — Any in excess of 1 allowed.

Cheese — AIL

Meats, Fish, Poultry - AU.

Cereals - Any in excess of 1 serving allowed. Any kinds not listed. Spaghetti, noodles, macaroni, and rice.

Bread - All except 3 slices Special Low Protein Bread.

Vegetables — Any in excess of the three servings allowed. Baked beans, Lima beans, legumes, lentils, peas, and soybeans.

Fruits — Avocado.

Desserts — Cakes, cookies, custard, gelatin, ice cream, junket, pies, puddings, and sherbet (unless water ice).

Soups — All.

Beverages — Milk (in excess of 634 oz. daily allowance)> milk drinks, and cocoa.

Fats - Mayonnaise and peanut butter.

Miscellaneous — Nuts.

nineteen HUNDRED AND SEVENTY—JUNE

117


listed in Allowed list. Spaghetti, noodles, macaroni, and rice. Bread — All except 3 slices Special Low Protein Bread.

Vegetables - Any in excess of the three servings allowed. Baked beans, beet greens, carrots-raw, celery, dandelion greens, kale, Lima beans, legumes, lentils, mushrooms, peas, potato chips, potatoes-French Fried, soybeans, spinach, and Swiss chard.

Fruits - Any in excess of 4 servings allowed. Avocados, dates, melons (except watermelon), prunes, and raisins. ■

Desserts — Cakes, cookies, custard, gelatin, ice cream, junket, pies, puddings, and sherbet (unless water ice). Soups — All. Bouillon cubes.

Beverages - Milk (in excess of 6bb oz. daily allowance), buttermilk, cocoa, coffee; tea, Coca Cola, gingerale, Pepsi Cola in excess of servings allowed; other carbonated beverages.

Fats - Salad dressings and peanut butter.

Miscellaneous — Commercial baking powder, baking soda, salt, vegetable salts, salt substitutes, Accent, condiments, pickles, olives, nuts, and popcorn.

' enough for approximately 4 loaves). Cost $2.50 post t— - "r one can and $13.50 for one case of six cans. Delivery sne is approximately 2 weeks. Sodium-free baking powder n: be obtained from the pharmacist without a prescription, “be recipe is:

3read Recipe — 1 loaf, 27 slices (3/8") thick . tnsp. sugar

l-» cups warm water

1 pkg. dry active yeast

3 tbsp, sugar

tsp. Na free baking pow-

% tsp. salt

2% cups DPP Wheat Starch

34 cup hydrogenated shortening


:s:

P_ace I tbsp, sugar and water in a large mixer bowl. Add yeast and stir until dissolved; let stand five minutes. Add dry ingre-t.er.ts and shortening. Beat at low speed, scraping sides of powl until ingredients are moistened; then beat 1 minute at t.gh speed, scraping sides of bowl with rubber spatula. Scrape 5.des of bowl; cover with towel and let stand at room temperature for 30 minutes. Grease loaf pan, 9 x 5 x 2%" or 8% x 4% x 2 5/8"; set aside. Beat bread mixture down, approximately 25 strokes; pour into greased loaf pan. Cover with towel and .et stand at room temperature for 30 minutes. Heat oven to 375’. Bake 55 minutes. Cool bread thoroughly. Refrigerate 1-2 hours after it has reached room temperature.

NOTE;

Do not pack flour. If bread mixture is like pie crust, add 1-2 tbsp, water; if like pancake batter, add 1-2 tbsp. DPP Wheat Starch. Cover opened can of flour carefully with aluminum foil. To cut bread, use a serrated or an electric knife and cut from bottom to top. Freeze any portion of bread which cannot be eaten in two days - wrap and seal carefully. To thaw, let stand at room temperature 3-4 hours.

Butterball Recipe

Butterballs are made like butter frosting. The approximate recipe for 50 is 34 lb. butter, 2 cups confectionery sugar and vanilla to flavor. There should be enough sugar to form firm balls when mixture is rolled out. Balls should be thoroughly chilled.

RECIPES FOR MODIFIED GIOVANETT1 DIET

Onion Scrambled Egg

1 tbsp, chopped onion          1 egg (+2 tsp. water-option-

1 tsp. butter                         al)

pepper to taste

Melt butter in a small frying pan. Saute onion until tender. Slightly whip egg (with water). Pour over the onion and scramble. Serve at once.

Hash Brown Potato (Use as 1 B vegetable and 2 butter) 1 small cold boiled potato 2 tsp. butter 2 tbsp, chopped onion          pepper to taste

Peel and grate potato. Melt butter in a small frying pan. Add onion and potato and fry over medium heat; turn occasionally to obtain desired brownness.

Carrots with Herbs 34 cup canned carrots 1 tsp. butter 2 tsp. water 34 - 34 tsp. sugar

dash of pepper

dash of nutmeg

dash of chopped parsley dash of tarragon


Saute carrots in butter, water and sugar by shaking pan and stirring constantly. When hot, add seasonings and serve.

Fresh Fruit Compote

Make a light syrup of 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water, a piece of lemon rind and a stick of cinnamon. Cut apples and pears in quarters and cook until fruit is tender. Measure out your al-lowed servings.

Other Suggestions for Use of Herbs with Vegetables Summer Squash with Nutmeg

Summer Squash with Butter, Sugar and Cinnamon Broccoli with Oregano

Modified Giova-netti (Giordano) Diet #2

This Modified Giovanetti Diet may be used for patients with renal failure when abnormal retention of sodium and potassium is not present. The diet is planned to supply enough protein in food eaten to minimize breakdown of body stores of protein; to provide the essential amino acids; to minimize the intake of the non-essential amino acids; and to maintain caloric equilibrium. The diet is low in protein (20 gms.) with liberal use of pure carbohydrate and fat to provide a minimum of 2000 calories. The diet is apt to be deficient in iron, calcium, phosphorus, and the B Complex vitamins, therefore the physician may wish to prescribe supplements.

FOODS TO BE INCLUDED:

Milk — 6% ounces daily.

Egg — 1 daily

Cereal - 1 serving chosen from: 34 cup Cream of Rice, Cream of Wheat, Oatmeal, Rolled Wheat, Bran flakes, Whearies; 1 cup Cornflakes, Puffed Rice, Puffed Wheat, Rice Krispies; 1 large biscuit Shredded Wheat.

Bread — 3 slices Special Low Protein Bread

Vegetables — two from List A, one from List B (in amounts stated).

Fruits — As desired except avocado. Use sweetened often to add calories.

Desserts - Fruit or popsicles.

Beverages - Coffee, tea, carbonated beverages, lemonade and Kool-Aid.

Fat - Butter, margarine and oils as desired-use freely to increase calories.

Miscellaneous - Sugar, honey, syrups, jam, jelly, hard candy as desired to increase calories; salt, pepper, vinegar, and spices as tolerated.

FOODS AVOIDED:

Milk — Any in excess of 6% oz. allowed. Cream.

Eggs - Any in excess of 1 allowed.

Cheese — All.

Meats, Fish, Poultry — All.

Cereals - Any in excess of 1 serving allowed. Any kinds not listed. Spaghetti, noodles, macaroni, and rice.

Bread - All except 3 Slices Special Low Protein Bread.

Vegetables — Any in excess of the three servings allowed. Baked beans, Lima beans, legumes, lentils, peas, and soybeans.

Fruits - Avocado.

Desserts - Cakes, cookies, custard, gelatin, ice cream, junket, pies, puddings, and sherbet (unless water ice).

Soups — All.

Beverages — Milk (in excess of 634 oz. daily allowance), milk drinks, and cocoa.

Fats - Mayonnaise and peanut butter.

Miscellaneous - Nuts.

Winter Squash

,7-CML LOW PROTEIN BREAD

' -^el P Wheat Starch (DPP Wheat Starch) is available from General Mills Inc., Special Products Division, 9200 Wayzata Boulevard, Minneapolis, Minn. 55440. It is packed in No. 10 tins (enough for approximately 4 loaves). Cost $2.50 post paid for one can and $13.50 for one case of six cans. Delivery time is approximately two weeks.

Recipe — 1 loaf, 27 slices (3/8

1 tbsp, sugar

134 cups warm water

  • 1 pkg. dry active yeast

3 tbsp, sugar

34 tsp, double acting bak-

fhick)

ing powder

1 tsp. salt                  '

2% cups DPP Wheat Srarrh

34 cup hydrogenated shortening


Place 1 tbsp, sugar and the water in a large mixer bowl. Add yeast and stir until dissolved; let stand 5 minutes. Add dry ingredients and shortening. Beat at low speed, scraping sides of bowl until ingredients are moistened; then beat I minute at high speed, scraping sides of bowl with rubber spatula. Scrape sides of bowl; cover with towel and let stand at room temperature for 30 minutes. Grease loaf pan, 9 x 5 x 244" or 834 x 4% x 2 5/8", set aside. Bear bread mixture down, approximately 25 strokes; pour into pan. Cover with towel and let stand at room temperature for 30 minutes. Heat oven to 375°. Bake 55 minutes. Cool bread thoroughly. Refrigerate 1-2 hours after it has reached room temperature.

NOTE;

Do not pack flour. If bread mixture is like pie crust, add 1-2 tbsp, water; if like pancake batter, add 1-2 tbsp. DPP Wheat Starch. Cover opened can of flour carefully with aluminum foil. To cut bread, use a serrated or an electric knife and cut from bottom to top. Freeze any portion of bread which cannot be eaten in two days - wrap and seal carefully. To thaw, let stand at room temperature 3-4 hours.

Acknowledgment

The author would like to acknowledge the assistance of W. H. Austin, M.D. in reviewing and making suggestions regarding the manuscript. He notes that in our experience the BUN may be a less sensitive index of renal function while the diet is being used and creatinines should be followed as an alternative.

References

Berlyne, G. M. and Shaw, A. B.; "Giordano-Giovunetti Diet in Terminal Renal Failure.” Lancet, 2:7, 1965.                  ■

Betlyne, G. M., Shaw, A. B. and Nilwarangkur, S.: "Treatment of Chronic Renal Failure. Experiences with a Modified Gio-vanetti Diet.” Nephron, 2:129, 1965.

BRITISH MEDICAL JOURNAL 7 OCTOBER 1972

Activated Charcoal Rediscovered

Sir,—Your excellent leading article (26 August, p. 487) on activated charcoal omitted to mention one of its modern therapeutic applications. Since I960 we have used activated charcoal in uraemic patients. We had previously found that charcoal effectively adsorbed certain uraemic substances directly from plasma or gastrointestinal contents (creatinine, uric acid, urea, phenols, guanidines, organic acids). A dose of 20-50 g of activated charcoal daily often results in an impressive clinical improvement, mainly on the gastrointestinal disturbances of the patient (oral fetor, anorexia, nausea, vomiting). No side effects were noted during continuous treatment for 4-20 months.1 More recently we have devised a simple apparatus for direct perfusion of blood through granular activated charcoal (charcoal artificial kidney), and we have reported the good results we have had with this method in cases of renal failure and severe barbiturate poisoning.25 Others have also published reports.67—I am, etc.,

Hippocrates Yatzidis

Aretaieon University Hospital, Athens

I Yatzidis, H., Nephron, 1964, 1. 310.

  • 2 Yatzidis, H., Proceedings of the European Dialysis Association, 1964, 1, 83.

  • 3 Yatzidis, H., er al.. Lancet, 1965, 2, 216.

* Yatzidis, H,, Proceedings of the 3rd In ternational Congress of Nephrology, p. 290. Basel, Karger,

  • 5 Yatzidis H., in Acute Barbiturate Poisantng, ed. H. Matthew. Amsterdam, Excerpts Med tea Foundation, 1971.

i Andrade, J. D., et al.. Transactions of the American Society for Artificial Internal Organs, 1972 18, 473.

78 The Spectator, Wednesday, March 28, 1973

Hamilton; Ontario Canada


for chronic kidney cases

BALTIMORE CAP) - A Johns Hopkins University medical researchei' has developed a diet regimen he says could replace or reduce the need for dialysis in patients suffering severe kidney disease.

The procedure sharply curbs proteins in a patient’s diet and substitutes for them keto acids — the components left when nitrogen is removed from proteins.

Although the body’s protein needs continue to be met, the combination of a strictly meatless diet and keto acids does not produce the toxic blood wastes that must currently be removed by blood- ■ cleansing dialysis, says Dr. MacKenzie Walser.

FOR SOME patients the re- ; gimen could eventually reduce or replace costly dialysis and high-risk organ transplants, Di. Walser said.

Dr. Walser said the cost of a daily keto acid dose could be less than $10 a week if they were commercially produced, compared with $300 a week for two or three dialysis treatment.

While the system still requires considerable research before it can be widely ap-nlied. the pharmacology and ! experimental therapeutics professor said: “It is clear that for patients with certain levels of severity, the treatment can replace dialysis.”

DR. WALSER said patients whose kidneys function at two I to 10 per cent of the normal level appear to be the most suitable candidates for the dietary regimen. The treatment does not prevent deterioration of kidney function, he emphasized.

A report on Dr. Walser’s findings in the current edition of the Journal of Clinical In-i vestigation indicates the sub-1 stitution df keto acids allowed I six of 10 volunteers to go , without dialysis up to nine i months at a time.

Keto-acids plus rfoeti uremia

Researchers at Johns Hopkins have devised a form of keto-acid therapy which, combined with a low-protein diet, decreases the rate of urea formation to the point where—in some patients, at least-intervals between dialysis may be significantly prolonged.

The investigators give their patients daily doses of five keto-acids—analogs of essential amino acids, along with the special diet. Use of the keto-acids diminishes the rate at which urea appears in the urine and body fluids, and the results are superior to those of more conventional administration of the amino acids themselves with the diet and to those obtained with the low-protein diet alone.

Drs. Mackenzie Walser, A. Will Coulter, Shrikant Dighe, and Frank R. Crantz theorize that urea nitrogen is reutilized for conversion of the keto-acids to essential amino acids, lowering blood urea concentration.

The investigators explain (J Clin Invest, 52:678) that they administered the alpha-keto-analogs of valine, leucine, isoleucine, methionine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan and histidine (to one patient)-along with the remaining essential amino acids-to ten patients with severe chronic uremia. The patients also received a low-protein diet adequate in calories. Keto-acid dosage (based upon estimated protein requirements) varied from 6 gn. to 14 gm daily. The patients fell into three categories: ■ In the least severe category was a patient who had a urea clearance of 5ml/min, and dietary management with no supplements was adequate to maintain good health.

a The second category included six patients who had more severe renal failure, with urea clearances between 0.6 ml/min and 2.2 ml/min. They could be maintained on diet alone only with continued symptoms and progressive weight loss; without strict dietary control they soon required dialysis.

■ Four other patients had urea clearances less than 0.5 ml/min.

In five subjects, the mixture of keto-acids and amino acids was given for 15 to 18 days, followed by a control period of several days. Net nitrogen intake (intake minus urine protein nitrogen) averaged 1.81 gm/day. During the control period, net nitrogen intake averaged 1.79 gm/day. Negative nitrogen balance was observed during the control periods. In the last week of keto-acid administration, rate of appearance of urea nitrogen in urine and in body water averaged only 0.64 gm/day.

In every patient withdrawal of keto-acids was followed by increased urea nitrogen appearance, averaging 1.55 gm/day. All five "improved clinically while on keto-acids,” and no change in their clinical status could be detected during the brief control period.

In two patients (J.W. and I.C.), periods of keto-acid administration were followed by periods of administration of essential amino acids only. Patient J.W. was studied twice: once when he still had appreciable renal function (2 ml/min to 3 ml/min urea clearance) and later when he was becoming anuric. In the first study, changing from keto-acids to amino acids at constant nitrogen intake had little effect on urea appearance or nitrogen balance. However, in the second study, urea nitrogen appearance was essentially zero during 17 days of keto-acid treatment but increased by 0.97 gm±0.06 gm on changing to amino acids. In patient I.C., changing from ketc-acids to amino acids was associated with "small but significant increases in urea appearance.” The average increase in urea nitrogen appearance on switching to amino acids was 0.5 gm/day.

Dr. Walser and his co-investigatora are particularly interested in the findings in patient J.W., who was maintained on keto-acids with no urea accumulation as his urea clearance fell from 0.49 ml/min to 0.17 ml/min over a period of several weeks.

Peritoneal dialysis on days 31 and 36 resulted in a reduction of serum urea nitrogen (SUN) from 206 mg% to 65 mg% and serum creatinine from 32.4 mg% to 14.4 mg%. He was then maintained on keto-acids for 26 days, during which SUN rose only to 86 mg%, while creatinine rose to 29.6 mg%. Urine output during this period fell from 200 ml/day to zero. Nevertheless, he "improved clinically” and was discharged on keto-acids on day 43, returning for weekly visits.

"He was oriented, alert, and free of vomiting during this period,” note the researchers. Readmitted on day 58 because of "mental confusion and symptoms of uremic pleuritis,” he received dialysis, was again discharged, anuric, but died one week later.

The investigators emphasize, however, that keto-acid administration "may be of no avail” if uremia is too severe initially, citing the cases of four patients who had high initial SUNs. Their high blood levels of urea did not vary markedly, although two of the four patients "responded more favorably” when given keto-acids after dialysis. ■

The investigators observe that no accumulations of keto-acids in plasma or urine could be detected and no toxicity was identified.

Dr. Walser strongly emphasizes that' the keto-acid treatment still requires considerable evaluation, that it can’t prevent kidney deterioration, and that it is useless when the kidney ceases to function, n

42j


.MEDICAL WORLD NEWS/April 27. 1973


Postgraduate Medical Journal (July 1971) 47, 499 500.

Haemodialysis-associated hepatitis

Ronald Finn M.D., M.R.C.P.

Liverpool Regional Urological Centre, Sefton General Hospital, Liverpool 15

Summary

Outbreaks of hepatitis have occurred in renal units all over Europe and the U.S.A, and have carried a high mortality.                 ...... ........

This is an iatrogenic disease, transmitted by blood from carriers of SH. virus, uraemic patients often suffering subclinical attacks.

The risks to the staff of these units are so high that they should not be asked to undertake this work if outbreaks cannot be controlled.

Outbreaks of hepatitis have occurred in many haemodialysis and transplantation units in this country. Similar outbreaks have occurred in Europe and the United States. In many cases these outbreaks have been large and there has been a significant mortality, especially among the staff. There can therefore be no doubt that haemodialysis-associated hepatitis is a real clinical entity. As it has occurred following the introduction of haemodialysis it can be classified as an iatrogenic disease, and it is certainly the most important iatrogenic disease that we have yet produced.

The Liverpool outbreak

The Liverpool outbreak has involved fifty-seven cases. It started in 1966 and is now under control, but not extinguished, in 1970. These outbreaks tend to be large and long-lasting. Patients, staff and relatives who help in dialysis are affected, but it is typical of these outbreaks that the disease is more severe in the contacts than in the patients. There has been a variable morbidity but no mortality. We have been fortunate as other outbreaks have involved a significant mortality. This long-lasting and severe outbreak has led to a severe retardation of our haemodialysis and transplantation programmes.

High density SH carriers

One may ask why these epidemics occur, and the reason is to be found in the way SH virus is handled by norma and uraemic subjects. Most of these outbreaks .re caused by the SH virus. If a normal person is infected with the SH virus, the incubation period of up to 3 months is followed by a short viraemia followed by a clinical attack of hepatitis, and following this SH antigen can no longer be detected. In contrast, the uraemic patient is unable to mount a normal clinical hepatitis and often has a subclinical attack, or even no demonstrable attack, ■ but then proceeds to become a chronic carrier of the virus. Uraemic patients have deficient immunological responses and are unable to destroy the virus and so become carriers. These patients carry very large numbers of virus particles and may be called high density SH carriers, and this makes their blood highly infective.

High Mood exposure technique

These highly dangerous SH carriers are then treated by haemodialysis which might be called a high-blood-exposure technique. Dialysis involves repeated access to the arterial and venous systems and an extracorporeal circulation. This means that despite every precaution some blood spillage is inevitable with repeated haemodialysis. It is, then, easy to see how a blood aerosol of highly infected blood settles on some exposed area and gains access to the circulation by means of some microscopic abrasion. Haemodialysis-associated hepatitis is therefore due to the combination of a high density carrier state with a high-blood-exposure technique. Once you have a uraemic SH carrier on a dialysis unit, spread is almost inevitable to dialysis staff, both medical, surgical and technical. Five members of the laboratory staff, who have never entered the unit, were affected, thus proving beyond reasonable doubt that the infection is blood-borne. If the patients are put on home dialysis spread to relatives is common. Other patients on the unit also become infected, and they may become SH carriers. We have one patient who has been an SH carrier for at least 4 years and hence these patients present a continuing hazard to staff. Even if they are dealt with by home dialysis they require occasional hospital admissions, and this constitutes a real and continuing hazard.

Ethical considerations

The risks to staff include the immediate hepatitis morbidity and mortality. Long-term theoretical

500                                       Ronald Finn

risks include cirrhosis and hepatoma. There is always a theoretical risk that the virus will mutate and then spread into the community, thus leading to a widespread public health hazard. Contact with an SH carrier on a dialysis or transplantation unit, therefore, involves a considerable risk to the staff as the infectivity rate is high. One may, therefore, ask whether it is justifiable to ask nursing and technical staff to run this risk, and I. suspect that it is • not. I have eventually come to take the extreme view that we must learn to prevent these outbreaks, otherwise it will become unethical to expose healthy young staff to these risks, and haemodialysis and transplantation facilities will have to be seriously restricted. If this position be accepted, then the future of haemodialysis and renal transplantation will depend on our ability to control these outbreaks.

Prevention of further outbreaks

Fortunately I think we now have the knowledge to prevent these outbreaks. The key advance has been the clinical application of the SH antigen test as most of the serious outbreaks have been due to serum hepatitis (MS-2) (Turner & Bruce White, 1969). Outbreaks of infective hepatitis (MS-1) occur, but they do not appear to be as serious and tend to be of short duration. All patients must be SH screened before admission to dialysis and transplantation units. The SH virus usually enters the dialysis unit by means of blood transfusion, and the amount of blood transfused must be seriously curtailed. Blood transfusion cannot be avoided completely, but when essential the blood should be screened for SH antigen. The other safeguard is only to use blood from donors who have given at least five previous donations without trouble. Because of the long incubation period infection has usually spread to other patients before it is noted that a member of staff is infected. It has, therefore, usually been found that there are several SH carriers on infected units, and this makes the task of controlling the epidemic much more difficult. The large hospital-based dialysis units are therefore highly dangerous and they should be replaced by smaller four-bedded units concentrating on home dialysis training and the holding of small transplant pools. This is an important step, and it is to be hoped that the Department of Health will revise its policy concerning the ideal size of a dialysis unit. If these measures are strictly observed, I think that future outbreaks can be largely prevented, and it need hardly be stressed that prevention is the only logical policy to adopt.

Theoretical coasiderataons

There are several interesting theoretical aspects of these outbreaks. It is likely that what we call clinical hepatitis is an immunological battle taking place in the liver to destroy the hepatitis virus. When a patient dies of hepatitis, it is probably due to an uncontrolled immunological response, or what may be loosely termed a hypersensitivity reaction, It is, therefore, logical to treat these patients with large doses of steroids, and we have done so with good results. This brings up the whole question of treating severe inflammatory disease with steroids in addition to providing antibiotic cover. If the immunological battle is not successful the patient becomes a carrier, but comes to no harm, and this again indicates that clinical hepatitis is due to the body’s reaction to the virus and that the virus is non-toxic. Uraemic patients develop tolerance to the virus and there are several other links between the liver and tolerance. Antigens presented to the spleen induce antibody formation, but antigens presented to the liver are less likely to do so and successful liver transplantation can be carried out in the pig without immunosuppression. Somewhere in this area may be the clue to the solution of the transplant problem. Haemodialysis-associated hepatitis is undoubtedly an iatrogenic disease, and this leads one to the perhaps paradoxical realisation that the results of medical research will not always be beneficial. Powerful therapeutic techniques are inevitably accompanied by the risk of serious side-effects and iatrogenic disease is likely to become a growing problem as scientific medicine advances.

Reference

Turner, E.C. & Bruce White, G.B. (5969) SH Antigen in haemodialysis-associated hepatitis. Lancet, Si, 121.

Fluids Effective



The use of Ringer’s lactate solution has become as acceptable as whole blood in shock and sur-rerv patients. Rut the key questions of why it is effective and how much of the fluid to use remain controversial.

A primary rationale for crystalloid solution infusion has been correction of an extracellular fluid “deficit,” created by a “shift” into intracellular spaces. This phenom'-enon was described by G. Thomas

Shires, MD. and University of Texas Southwestern Medical School colleagues in 1961.

During the recent American College of Surgeons clinical congress in Chicago, Dr. Shires chaired a session which featured seven papers focusing on this body fluid shift. The majority concluded that it did not exist. The result was a lively afternoon.

The investigators presenting data included teams from the University


of California at Los Angeles, Canada’s McGill University, Walter Reed Army Institute of Research, and the Navy Medical Research Institute.

The UCLA studies included patients monitored before and after cardiac surgery as well as dogs in hypovolemic shock. Reporting their data were Eberhard Roth, MD, Louis C. Lax, MD, and James V. Maloney, Jr., MD, all Los Angeles surgeons and physiologists.

Intravenous injections of isotope labelled compounds and computer extrapolations were used to determine both extracellular fluid volume (ECF) and red cell volume. Sodium sulfate S 35 was used to assess ECF. Red cells were tagged with sodium chromate Cr 51. Periodic blood samples were taken.

Among eight patients after general surgery and nine following open heart procedures, no ECF deficit could he found, Dr. Roth reported. In fact, after open heart procedures, an ECF increase of 9.6% was found. After correcting for the fluid given during and immediately after surgery, however, the calculated ECF volume was only 0.6% less than preoperative levels.

In animals, bled to a mean arterial pressure of 50 mtn Hg, an apparent ECF deficit of about 40% was evident initially, the UCLA investigator noted. If time were allowed for isotope equilibration in the body, the apparent deficit was halved. (Most investigators now recognize that different isotopes require varying lengths of time to distribute properly. Considerable disagreement exists about what these times are under varying conditions, however.)

The UCLA investigators also pointed to two other “sources of error”—which together virtually eliminated their evidence of an ECF deficit. If allowances were made for ECF removed in shed blood and draining catheters placed in other than femoral arteries—thus forestalling hind limb ischemia— the ECF deficit in the shocked dogs was only 5.7%.

“This deficit is insignificant, since it is due in part to transpiration,

fluid loss through respiration, urine excretion, . . . and blood samples,” said Dr. Roth.

More than 60 soldiers with various injuries suffered in Vietnam have been studied for evidence of fluid shifts by the US Army Surgical Research Team, based at Washington’s Walter Reed Army Institute of Research. No evidence for a reduction in interstitial fluid volume or a shift in ECF itself has been found, according to Capt. Robert W. Anderson, MC, USAR.

The casualties, who included both patients in hemorrhagic shock and those with minor injuries, were studied an average of 74 minutes after incurring their wounds. The field studies used sodium sulfate S 35 to monitor ECF and iodinated I 125 serum albumin to determine plasma volume.

Corrections also were made for therapy administered during the study. All the severely-injured patients survived the shock period.

When found, the fluid deficits detected were slight and could be attributed to exogenous factors— principally dehydration or transcapillary refilling.

Those casualties who had weighed themselves before going into the field had lost an average of 4.8% of total body weight in the period prior to injury. When wounded, these soldiers were usually wearing heavy “flak jackets” and full combat gear. A group of less severely injured controls, the victims of in-camp accidents, showed no such phenomenon and no ECF deficit.

“We gained the impression in these severely injured young males that impaired capillary perfusion, rather than fluid shifts, was the problem requiring immediate correction,” Capt Anderson commented.

Other papers during the shock session included one from the University of Alabama indicating that intracellular fluid in surgical patients did not change even though the ECF was sharply elevated by fluid infusion and other factors.

In contrast to the majority of the afternoon’s papers, evidence of an ECF decrease was found in ne-

JAMA, Oct 23, 1967 o Vol 202, No 4 phrectomized dogs and rats undergoing hemorrhagic shock in University of Kansas experiments.

In addition, tissue studies confirmed a heterogenous distribution of sodium sulfate S 35 volume through incorporation of the isotope into cells of various organs. Patterns of sequestration differed with time, however. Parallel experiments with tritiated water, radioactive inulin, and radioactive chloride ions confirmed that the kinetics of fluid response to shock is a constantly changing pattern.

“Measurements which reveal deficits in functional ECF in shock and surgery are probably approximations which define momentary time-dependent alterations in transcapillary exchange,” said Paul R. Schloerb, MD. Such evidence for endogenous fluid shifts reemphasizes the need for use of salt-con-taining.fluids like lactated Ringer’s, the Kansas investigator said.

The building evidence against ECF-ICF shifts seems, in part, a commentary on the increased use of isotopes for indirect measurements. The technique first used by Dr. Shires and his Dallas co-workers has been both refined and changed by dozens of teams during the past six years.

At issue now arc both the newer conclusions being drawn and tenuous technical considerations: what isotopes to use, when to measure, how often, what weight to give urine loss and a dozen other questions.

“You have opened an old wound,” Dr. Shires commented to one of the speakers.

Complicating the picture is the obvious clinical fact that aggressive use of Ringer’s lactate solution benefits patients. Although the fluid may or may not be counterbalancing a drastic ECF-ICF shift, it seems to be serving other useful purposes that remain unknown.

The clinical and laboratory teams agreed on one point. A dangerous trend toward overuse of fluid therapy exists.

The restoration of normal physiology and function cannot be accomplished by inundation, Dr. Shires pointed out.

55

JAMA

O THE JOURNAL of the

American Medical Association

March 29. 1971 Vol 215, No 13


Electrolyte Solution in Surgical Patients Refusing Transfusion

Seymour Gollub, PhD, MD; Robert Svigals, MD;

Charles P. Bailey, MD; Teruo Hirose, MD; and Clara Schaefer

Major blood loss in 13 surgical patients was treated by infusion of crystalloid solution alone, supplemented by colloid plasma expander when necessary. Neither whole" blood nor any of its components or fractions was employed at any time. For losses of 21 % to 66% of blood volume, Ringer's solution, administered in three to five times the volume of blood loss, produced physiologically significant intravascular fluid increments equalling one fifth to three fifths of the shed blood. Colloid solutions were required to sustain blood volumes or blood pressure for patients with blood losses in excess of 1,200 ml, otherwise clinically significant edema was manifested. One week after surgery, blood volumes averaged 90% of original values. The death rate was three thirteenths. The average hospital stay was prolonged 3.4 days.


The practice of using crystalloid solutions as the sole or major fluid for the treatment of blood loss has been reported from diverse clinics.114 Such solutions have varied in composition from simple sugar-water (5% glucose in water) to complex balanced buffered polyionic preparations (lactated Ringer’s solution). The clinical conditions for which they have been employed extend from those involving low trauma and small-volume blood

From St. Barnabas Hospital, Bronx, NY.

Reprint requests to 4422 Third Ave, Bronx, NY 10457 (Dr. Gollub). loss to open-heart surgery and resuscitation of severely wounded battle casualties.

However, this practice has not met with general acceptance—even for low-or moderate-grade blood loss and trauma, \Vhole blood appears to remain the overwhelming modality of choice for fluid resuscitation, in spite of the known dangers associated with its use. Though the ob-jections to use of crystalloid solutions by surgeons and internists are varied, a common belief is that only colloid solutions will achieve and sustain a satisfactory replenishment of blood volume, and further, whole blood or red blood cells (RBC) are required to maintain the hemoglobin at desirable levels—generally thought to be 11, 12, or 13 gm/100 ml.

This communication presents a body of clinical experience with exclusive use of crystalloid solution as alternate therapy to blood transfusion in cases of high-trauma surgery with major blood loss. Though it describes, in many ways, extremes of clinical practice, it may contribute to a clearer understanding of results of nonhemic fluid resuscitation, and help to define safe limits of its employment.

Thirteen consecutively studied cases of a group of surgical patients subjected to a wide range of trau-matice procedures are presented (Table 1). All sustained major blood loss. None received blood or any blood fraction at any time. All were members of the Jehovah’s Witness faith. Crystalloid solution in the form of Ringer’s solution or lactated Ringer’s solution was the sole or major resuscitative solution employed. Fluid administration was based on blood pressure or blood volume determination. No attempt was made to use blood loss as a basis for fluid administration.

Table 1.—Patient Study Group

Improved

Methods

Blood volume was determined by an isotopic method with use of a gamma ray counter and iodinated serum albumin (RISA). Hematocrit levels were corrected for plasma trapping.15 Red blood cell mass and plasma volumes were corrected for whole-body hematocrit values.10 Administered fluid volumes and urine volumes • were carefully recorded and totalled. A highly accurate weighing bed was employed for each patient’s weight. Specific gravity of blood and other isosmotic fluids was assumed to be 1.0. Blood loss was estimated from the reduction in total RBC mass. The “expected blood volume” at any period was estimated to be the previously determined blood volume minus the blood loss sustained during the interval. Total retention of fluids was calculated as the difference between total administered volumes and total urine excretion, or alternately as the algebraic sum of the weight change plus the blood loss. Intravascular retention of administered fluid was calculated as the difference between the measured blood volume and the expected blood volume. Extravascular distribution of administered fluid was calculated as the difference between total fluid retention and intravascular retention. These methods have been extensively described elsewhere.®

Findings in Present Study

Figure 1 shows the magnitude of operative blood loss of individual patients in relation to the extent of operative trauma. For the low-trauma group, blood loss was negligible. However, as noted later, these patients had sustained major blood loss prior to admission. For high-trauma surgery -mostly openheart procedures—blood loss ranged from 21% to 66% with the modg clustering about 40% blood volume. Figure 2 relates the total volume of nonhemic fluids administered during surgery and four hours afterwards to the volume of blood loss sustained. In general, for major blood loss, fluid volumes of three to five times blood loss were administered. Patient 2 received 500 ml artificial colloid solution in the operating room. No other patient received colloid solution during surgery or for four hours thereafter.

The general distribution of the retained fluid for the high-trauma group is indicated in Fig 3. Large-volume urination was an invariable result of this regimen. However, most of the fluid administered was retained. The intravascular space retained little, averaging 10% of fluid administered (range, 5% to 19%). Based on fluid volume retained, the intravascular retention averaged 16% (range, 8% to 28%). These figures do not include patient 2, since she received colloid during operation. Examination of Fig 3 reveals that as the volume of administered fluid increased, there was little if any intravascular gain. The liquid appeared to go to the extravascular spaces primarily, with most of the remainder eliminated as urine.

Though the intravascular retention of crystalloid fluid was a small percentage of administered fluid, the large volumes employed produced a physiologically significant volume increment. This is shown



  • 1. Direct relationship between extent of blood loss and trauma of operation for high-trauma surgery. Mode averages 40% of blood volume.

  • 2. Tendency to administer fluid volumes as direct function of volume of blood lost. Generally fluid volumes administered were three to five times blood loss volume.

    the hematocrit levels rose quite slowly thereafter.

    Changes in RBC mass and blood volume are shown in Fig 6. The data are average values and standard deviations for patients who had heart surgery. The observations include all surviving patients at a given time. Three points are worthy of note. There was a greater relative fall in RBC mass than in blood volume after surgery. During the first week, the RBC mass was relatively stable, and increased slightly during the second postoperative week. The plasma volume, however, showed a progressive increase starting immediately after surgery. This provides the explanation for the falling hematocrit values seen in Fig 5. In Table 2 there is a summarization of certain statistics relevant to the patients’ clinical course. The six patients who sustained blood volume losses greater than


in Fig 4. In general, from one fifth to three fifths of the blood volume loss was restored by administration of a crystalloid fluid. Patient 2 received colloid solution during surgery and thus had a higher replenishment, There was no apparent relationship between blood volume loss and replenishment of volume with crystalloid solution.

Absolute hematocrit values of venipuncture blood are given in Fig 5. The data are not complete since the number of observations tended to decrease as the postoperative interval increased. The general trend observed is an initial sharp drop as a result of surgery, followed by a more gradual reduction for three or four days thereafter to a low point in the low 20’s or high teens. Approximately one week after the operation, the reticulocyte counts had increased to their maximum values of 7% to 10%;

1,200 ml failed to maintain adequate cardiovascular dynamics as reflected in systemic blood pressure, measured blood volume, or both. These patients received artificial colloid solutions to increase and sustain the intravascular volume. Under the conditions of marked plasma dilution, the volume increment produced by 500 ml of dextran 70 was observed to be considerably greater than the 600 or 700 ml obtained with more conventionally treated patients. The systems involved in producing patient morbidity were principally respiratory, renal, and cardiac.

Four instances of pulmonary edema were noted. Three occurred in patients who subsequently died. Two of these patients were given very large quantities of crystalloid fluid without colloid supplementation. Consequently, an abnormally large portion of the fluid was dis-

tributed extravascularly. It appears likely that this was a major cause for the pulmonary edema.

The mortality of this group was three thirteenths or 23%. The patients died at two, three, and eight days postoperatively. Their demise appeared to reflect the nature of their disease, the trauma of the surgical procedure, and the response to the fluid resuscitative regimen.

Comment

This communication describes key hematologic changes of 13 surgical patients whose clinical management perforce did not employ blood or any blood fraction at any time. The patients may be divided into two main groups, a low-trauma group consisting of two patients admitted with low RBC mass and hematocrit levels due to serious pre-surgical blood loss who were subsequently subjected to low-trauma surgery, and a high-trauma group consisting of nine patients with relatively normal blood indices who were subjected to acute, large-volume blood loss associated with heart surgery, mostly of the “open” type.

The low-trauma patients (6 and 7) were admitted with hematocrit values of 15% and 17% respectively, after continuous bleeding for a period of one to two weeks. Both were pale and weak. They were, however, alert, well-oriented, and cooperative. They did not evidence respiratory distress while lying in bed. Blood pressure was normal (120/80 and 140/80 mm Hg) and heart rates were increased (100 and 140 beats per minute) . Immediate surgery was performed in both cases with operative blood loss less than 200 ml.

At five and ten days after the operation, respectively, these patients, both in the Intensive Care Unit concurrently, were sitting beside their beds, quite pale but alert and comfortable and reading the newspaper. Their respective hema-



3. For high-trauma group of patients, as volume of administered fluid increased, distribution was mainly to interstitial space. Intravascular compartment received small and apparently nonincremental amount of administered fluid.


4. Replacement of blood loss by crystalloid solution alone varied from less than 20% to more than 60%. One patient who received artificial colloid expander in addition to crystalloid had complete volume replacement of blood loss.




  • 5. Large-vessel hematocrit values show abrupt and progressive decrease up to third postoperative day and return towards normal thereafter.


  • 6. Red blood cell mass (cross-halched bars) shows abrupt decrease after surgery which continues for first postoperative week. By contrast there is progressive increase in plasma volume (dotted bars) starting from immediate postoperative period.



tocrits at the time were 12% and 13%. At the time of the lowest absolute RBC mass values, these patients had 4.7 and 8.8 ml of RBC per kilo of body weight, respectively. The lower figure appears to be close to the safe lower limit, if the clinical course of these patients is typical. Their recovery was prolonged but uneventful. These patients differed from the heartsurgery group in many significant respects: the red cell mass loss was gradual; the administration of crystalloids was gradual, so that the rate of hemodilution was gradual; the systemic pathology was minor; surgery was brief and low trauma; and anesthesia was brief. Such patients present only a minor challenge in clinical management.

The heart-surgery patients, by contrast, were subjected to major, high-trauma surgery, for serious, relatively long-standing disease, and had an acute reduction of RBC mass of from 20% to 60% and a blood volume decrease of 15% to 30%, The duration of operation varied from two to four hours. Most cases were of the open type, thus having the extra burden of mechanically traumatized blood as well as significantly diluted plasma in the postoperative period.

Fluid replacement consisted of Ringer’s solution, or lactated Ringer’s solution in the main, supplemented with artificial colloid solu-tion as judged necessary. Volume administration was based on clinical status, supplemented by laboratory tests. No “formulae” for replacement volumes were employed. In general, it was calculated that resuscitative fluid volumes administered were of the order of three to five times blood loss sustained. As the volumes of administered fluid grew larger, disproportionately greater increments were distributed to the extravascular space.

The second most significant volume distribution was via the kid-

Table 2.—Patient Morbidity

Patiert

7

Respiratory insufficiency, bilateral pedal edema

7

1

1,000 ml postoperatively, day 1

D“               i

250 mt postoperatively, day 1

8

400 ml postoperatively, day 1

D°

High

5

....

Hypotension, generalized edema, pleural effusion, pulmonary edema, hematuria

D”

3 .

*D = Died.

neys to the bladder. The intravascular space received the least. This may explain the varying “distribution ratios” noted previously between the intravascular and extra-vascular spaces. The present data suggest that such distribution ratios are not meaningful, or at least not applicable under the conditions of this experience.

Although the crystalloid fluid was a poor “volume expander” in terms of efficiency, the large volumes resulted in a physiologically significant intravascular volume increment (20% to 64%) of blood loss. The degree of replenishment of intravascular volume was not related to the amount of blood loss, or to the volume of fluid administered. Hemodilution caused hematrocrit values to fall to the range of the high 20’s to low 30’s immediately after the operation and they continued to fall for the next three days to the range of the high teens to low 20’s. This latter fall was the result of a stable RBC mass diluted by an increased plasma volume. Similar observations have been reported previously for patients treated with partial hemodilution.17 The replenishment of the RBC mass by RBC production was sluggish, regardless of the administration of various hematinic preparations employed in some patients. Immediately after the operation the RBC mass had decreased to 50%. Two weeks later it had increased to 65%, of its initial amount.

Certain features of clinical man-ageme'nt™are.....worthy df~note\""ft‘ be

came obvious that fluids were best administered according to overt physiological signs and symptoms.

The data strongly suggest that there is a limit to the safe employment of crystalloid solution alone as volume replacement for shed blood. Those patients sustaining a loss of up to 1,200 ml of blood apparently were able to tolerate volume replacement with crystalloid solution alone. For the six patients with blood losses greater than 1,2(55 ml, it was necessary to supplement the crystalloid infusion with colloid solution at some time in the first 24 hours after operation to maintain a satisfactory intmva^ular~volum\' When this was not done, ie, when the attempt was made to replace blood loss in excess of 1,200 ml with crystalloid solution alone, very large volumes were needed, and serious edema, especially pulmo-

nary edema, was manifested. In the postoperative period, patients whose hematocrit values were in the high or middle teens generally fared better with tracheostomy and respiratory assistance. Our impression is that in the lower ranges of RBC mass, weakness of the respiratory muscles can contribute to poor ventilation, insufficient gas exchange, and eventual vascular collapse. Meticulous hemostasis was of prime importance, since lost RBC mass could not be replaced for religious reasons.

We believe that this experience may be of value for surgery of more conventional patients, those who accept blood transfusion. It may be estimated that the number of transfused units of blood could be reduced by 50% if physicians would use crystalloid solutions for fluid resuscitation in place of the initial 1 or 2 units of blood employed for volume expansion. This single step alone would bring about a drastic reduction in hepatitis and effect a most desirable change in the quality of available stores of heterologous blood for transfusion. The fact that crystalloid solution alone, in the absence of artificial colloid solution, was able to be employed successfully in high-trauma surgery of adults with blood loss up to 1,200 ml is offered as support and encouragement for this practice.

This investigation was supported by the John A Hartford Foundation and aided by the US Army Surgical Research and Development Command.
