THE EXPOSITOR, BRANTFORD, Tuesday, June -LJ9]2

Answer to donor shortage? —        -                 (

Bloodless surgery' reduces hazards of transfusion

By C. G. McDaniel AP Science Writer

CHICAGO (AP) — “We don't throw around a bottle of blood willy nilly anymore,” says Dr. Stanley Dudrick.'

Thus does one surgeon characterize a growing trend toward “bloodless sur ger y,” when it is possible and applicable.

Two goals of bloodless surgery are to avoid potential hazards from transfusions, including transmitting the liver disease hepatitis, and to reduce the need for blood donors. At present, about seven million blood transfusions are given every year in the United States, and there’s a shortage of donors.

Dudrick, of the University of Pennsylvania medical school and chief of surgery at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Philadelphia, has helped develop one alternative method of blood replacement.

This involves building up the blood before and after surgery v(ith various nutrients, such as amino acids and iron, to make transfusions unnecessary.

Other techniques involve the heart-lung machine, lowering of blood pres sere, and cryosurgery or freezing. There are still other procedures.

Not all patients can be treated with the blood buildup method, Dudrick said in an interview. They must be fairly healthy and the surgery must not be urgent, to allow time to build up the blood.

Dudrick said; “It is amazing how fast patients come around" in response to the nutrient build-up.

a It was “sort of a ritual” inj j the past to replace lost blood| I unit for unit, he arid. ’

The blood-build-up t e c h-nique has been used cliaically at the University of Pennsylvania hospitals for about four years, he said, and has been used at major medical centres around the U.S. for the last two.

Surgeons do not uniformly accept the method, because it means extra work to build up patients before and after surgery, he said.

j “The easiest thing to do Is| to hang a bottle of blood,” Dudrick said, noting that some still rely on the transfusion when it might not be necessary.

Dr. James E. Eckenhoff, dean of Northwestern University medical school, has been a leader in development of surgical techniques involving bypotension—the lowering &t blood pressure—to~ reduce blood loss in certain problems.

This is particularly useful in surgery of the head and neck and the upper extremities, in nonwurgery and in plastic surgery, he said.

The hypotension technique, Eckenhoff said in an interview, “can markedly reduce

the loss of blood and the need for replacement.”

This technique has had wider use in Britain, where Eckenhoff, an anesthesiologist, worked in perfecting it at Queen Victoria Hospital in East Grinstead.

A decade ago, surgeons replaced blood if the loss exceeded 403 or 500 cubic centimetres, about a pint, hut now replace much of lost blood with nutrient solutions, he said.

The transfusion itself may cause death, he said, noting that one of every 4,COT to 5,000 bottles of blood has fatal effects.

In comparative studies, patients whose blood pressure was lowered, required less than half the amount of replacement blood required by others undergoing the same procedures.

Eckenhoff said surgeons now think that patients who are not in severely deteriorated condition can sustain a loss of up to one quart of blood without replacement.

The Korean and Vietnamese wars also taught surgeons to work with less donated blood, Eckenhoff said, because there was not enough to meet the needs of men injured in battle.

A leading heart surgeon. Dr. Denton Cooley of the Texas Heart Institute, Houston, said he is not opposed to j blood transfusions but “the ,■ I fact is evident now that most g J major surgery can ba

• without transfusion.”          *

Cooley, noted for open heart surgery and as a pioneer in heart transplants, said some

■ doctors use blood tranBfeforis ? “as a'crutch” or because"the । | blocd is available.               1

“We continue to do cur surgery with a minimum of transfusions,” Cooley said in an interview. “Our goal is to see how little we can use?’

Four Harvard Medical School researchers—Dr. S. Mortimer J. Buckley, W. Gerald Austen, Allan Goldblatt and Myron B. Laver—have developed a technique for diluting the patient’s blood, then reinfusing his own after oar-gery.

The patient’s temperature is lowered, slowing his metabolism. Eighty per cent of bin blood is removed and stored. At the same time, the blond is replaced by three times as much nutrient solution as blood withdrawn. Circulation is maintained through the heart-lung machine.

With this technique, Buck-ley said, it is possible even to suspend circulation during Usa repair procedure on some patients, placing them in a state of suspended animation.

Other forms of Woodless surgery include cryosurgery, which involves freezing, to remove malignancies and treat certain other conditions.

Anestiiestolocy, Vol. 33, No. 2, August, 1970

The Anesthesiologist and fc Cardiac Surgeon

D&ntGst A. Co&tey, M.D.*

New and rapidly changing techniques in cardiac surgery have steadily increased the burden placed upon the anesthesiologist during the past two decades. Not long ago, the anesthesiologist had, and often exercised, the prerogative of recommending that operation be deferred because df an inordinate anesthetic risk. Now he is practically obliged by modem practice to accept the assignment and share the challenge, striving desperately with the surgeon to salvage the patient by his determined skill with -intra- and postoperative anesthetic techniques, assisted by pharmacologic and respiratory support. Today, intensely cyanotic patients, many of them newborn infants, undergo thoracotomy for cardiac repair. Adult patients with advanced acquired heart disease are seldom refused operation unless irreversible myocardial damage or advanced pulmonary, hepatic, or renal disease is present. Recently, for example, moribund patients with terminal irreversible heart disease have undergone cardiac transplantation and Recovered. The close alliance necessary between surgeon and anesthesiologist demands that the anesthesiologist continually familiarize himself with cardiac diseases and new surgical procedures designed to treat these diseases in order to anticipate the special problems during and after operation.

The era of open intracardiac surgery began about 15 years ago with the introduction of total-body hypothermia combined with caval inflow occlusion. The limitations of this method were many, and it was soon replaced by the technique of temporary cardiopulmonary bypass. Pumps and oxygenators have not yet been standardized in all centers, and wide varieties of both are used today with safcfac-. tory results. For the past six years we have used exclusively the plastic disposable bubble diffusion oxygenator primed with 5 per cent

0 Chief of Surgery, The Texas Heart Institute of St. Luke’s and Texas Children's Hospitals, Houston, Texas.

dextrose solution, and have kept the patient normothermic. In addition to its important advantages of convenience, economy, and absence of certain cardiopulmonary and hematologic complications, this method also allows surgeons to perform open-heart surgery on Jehovah’s Witnesses without using bicod—a special problem for the anesthesiologist who is concerned with blood replacement. We have done open-heart operations on 70 Jehovah’s Witnesses without using blood before, during, or after operation. Disc oxygenators primed with fresh heparinized or even ACD bank blood still remain the choice in some hospitals. At one time a hyperbaric environment for cardiac surgery seemed an attractive prospect and was used in many newborn infeats. Because of its cumbersome erjaapment, complicated physiologic problems (mainly respiratory), and hazard to personnel, .most centers now use this method only for medical, and not for surgical, problems. The membrane-type oxygenators with ultra-thin silastic z/iembranes have attracted interest recently; they promise prolonged cardiorespiratory support in the desperately ill patient Other types of mechanical oxygenation are unsatisfactory for this purpose since they require prolonged direct exposure of blood to a gaseous interface. The membrane oxygenator will not, however, replace the simpler and more efficient bubble diffusion and Aiming oxygenators for openheart surgery.

■Almost daily advances are befog made in surgery for congenital heart disease, as one anomaly after another becomes operable. One exciting example is the complete correction of transposition of the great arteries—an anomaly long considered to be incurable. Tnmcus arteriosus, another complicated defect, is correctable with a composite homograft of ascending aorta and aortic valve. This homograft has been used successfully in severe cases of tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonic valve atresia and in cases of transposition of the great vessels with large ventricular septal defect. At pres-

526


DENTON A. COOLEY


127

ent, the only remaining barrier to surgical repair of congenital cardiac anomalies is severe pulmonary vascular sclerosis and fixed pulmonary resistance.

Surgical treatment of acquired valvular disease now consists primarily of total valve replacement, although some indications for valvuloplasty remain. Thromboembolism is by far the most common and difficult complication of valve replacement with synthetic prostheses. Fortunately, these complications are rare in aortic valve replacement, in which prosthetic valves serve satisfactorily. For the mitral annulus many modifications of prostheses have been tried experimentally and clinically, yet none has proved entirely satisfactory; the search for an “ideal” mitral prosthesis continues. Recent reports of composite stinted grafts using homo- or heterograft semilunar valves or valves fashioned with autologous viable fascia lata are promising.

The cardiac surgeon still finds his major challenge in surgery for advanced primary myocardial disease. Coronary atherosclerosis is the most prevalent cause of this disease, although a variety of cardiomyopathies also are recognized clinically. Cardiac transplantation, first attempted clinically two years ago, has prolonged the lives of many patients. At least ten of about 150 such patients throughout the world have survived a year or more after cardiac transplantation. In one patient operated upon in our hospital a two-staged cardiac replacement was performed, using a total cardiac prosthesis for the first stage. The prosthesis supported circulation and life for 64 hours until it was removed and a cardiac allograft inserted. Although the patient died 32 hours after allografting, this case may represent a significant step forward in total cardiac substitution, since for the first time prolonged

Anesthesiology August 1970 circulatory support was successfully achieved. Hopefully, the experience will stimulate others to attempt similar bold techniques in dying patients, particularly when death in the operating room is the alternative.

Since the introduction of coronary arteriography using Sones’ technique, revascularization of the ischemic heart has been attempted in a more deliberate, practical manner than previously, when less precise diagnostic methods were employed. During the past few years implantation of the internal mammary artery into the myocardium has been performed in several thousand patients, but within the past few months the technique has been replaced by a direct attack upon the occluded coronary artery. Using the autologous saphenous vein graft bypass so successfully employed for the occluded superficial femoral artery, cardiac surgeons are anastomosing coronary vessels one or two millimeters in diameter to aortic or coronary grafts. While results at this early stage are being highly acclaimed, one must maintain a healthy skepticism for the future of these operations; too often have new methods in the. difficult area of cardiac surgery enjoyed initially spectacular but very brief histories. Meanwhile, the anesthesiologist must continue offering his cooperation, indulgence, and valued assistance to the cardiac surgeon in a mutual effort to improve and expand the surgical attack upon coronary disease.

“Death and sorrow will be the companions of our journey; hardship our garment, constancy and valor our only shield. We must be united, we must be undaunted, we must be inflexible.” These impassioned words of Winston Churchill (1940) may serve to describe the task for these two comrades, surgeon and anesthesiologist, brought together in this struggle for progress in cardiac surgery.

567


Friday, Nov IS, 196S

Open Heart Surgery

Without Blood Transfusion

Arthur C. Beall, Jr., MD; Ellard M. Yow, Jr.; Robert D. Bloodwell, MD; Grady L. Hallman, MD; and Denton A. Cooley, MD, Houston

DEVELOPMENT of the pump oxygenator for open heart surgery and clinical progress over the past decade now allow successful surgical correction of most congenital and acquired cardiac lesions. For many years, however, procurement of large quantities of blood necessary for primir.g most pump oxygenators used for these o e rations taxed blood banking facilities throughout the country and limited use of cardiopulmonary bypass in emergency situations. Dem, onstration of the adverse effects produced by such a pool of homologous blood further emphasized the advantages of eliminating this blood prime.1

The feasibility of priming extracorporeal circuits with a variety of nonblood solutions soon was established,2 3 4 5 6 and in April 1962, we adopted a technique of open heart surgery using disposable plastic oxygenators primed only with 5% dextrose in distilled water.7 With this technique extracardiac blood loss usually was replaced with banked acid-citrate-dextrose blood as during any major operative procedure. However, our policy has been to limit transfusion to only that amount of blood absolutely necessary, in order to reduce the incidence of hepatitis / and other complications of administering blood.

It now appears that many patients undergoing open heart surgery do not require blood transfusion either during the operation or at any time during the period of hospitalization, Furthermore, it is possible to offer benefits of such operations to individuals of the Jehovah’s Witness religious faith, who will not accept transfusion of blood or any of its products.8 The purpose of this report is to review experience with open heart surgery using this technique with emphasis upon a group of 157 patients in whom no blood was necessary.

Technique of Operation

This method of open heart surgery is illustrated diagramatically in Fig 1. The superior and inferior venae cavae are drained by gravity into a disposable plastic oxygenator which is stretched on a metal frame. Raising or lowering the I- ight of the frame adjusts flow rate by changing the distance between vena eaval level and the base of the oxygenating column. Blood

Fig 1.—Drawing illustrating technique of open heart surgery using disposable plastic oxygenators (see text).

568


OPEN HEART SUHGERY—BEALL ET AL

is driven up the oxygenating column by the oxygen dispersion system as gas exchange occurs. Oxygenated blood then passes over stainless steel sponges coated with antifoam and through a filter into an anguish'd arterial reservoir. From the base of the reservoir a roller pump returns blood proximally through a common femoral artery into the aorta. Coronary sinus return and bronchial arterial blood is collected by a left ventricular sump and by an intracardiac aspirator and is passed through a cardiotomy reservoir into the base of the oxygenating column.

, The oxygenator is primed with 5% dextrose V ln distilled water, 20 to 30 ml/kg of , body weight, to which is added heparin sodium, 30 mg/liter of priming solution. In infants weighing less than 13.6 kg (30 lb) a single unit of fresh, heparinized blood is required due to the infant’s small, blood volume in relation to the priming volume of the oxygenator and tubing. Except in such infants all solution remaining in the oxygenator and tubing at the completion of the intracardiac procedure is returned slowly to the patient through the femoral artery. When necessary, banked, acid-citrate-dextrose blood is given intravenously to replace extracardiac blood loss, but such transfusion is used only for specific indications and is withheld unless blood loss exceeds that which is compatible with smooth recovery from operation.

Clinical Material

During the four-year period from April 1962 until April 1966 this technique of open heart surgery was used in 1,818 patients admitted to St. Luke’s Episcopal, Texas Children’s, or Ben Taub General hospitals, Houston. Overall results were most gratifying as compared to those obtained using homologous blood priming. Among these patients were 157 in whom no % blood was given at any time during the entire period of hospitalization.

Seventy-three of these 157 patients were male and 84 were female. They varied in age from 21,-j to 67 years with an average age of 22.4 years. Although 11 of the patients belonged to , the Jehovah’s Witness religious faith and blood could not be used, transfusion was withheld electively in the other 146, since its use was not considered necessary.

The various operations performed are summarized in the Table. Although the majority of these open heart procedures without blood were for repair of congenital cardiac lesions,' quite a number of more complicated operations such as aortic or mitral valve replacements were included. Many of these patients undergo-

Opsn Heart Surgery Performed Without Blood

Operation                               Number

Congenital lesions

Repair atria! septal defect

Repair ventricular septa! defect

Pulmonary valvulotomy

Resection subaortic muscular hypertrophy

Repair sinus venosus defect

Aortic valve commissurotomy

Repair supravalvular aortic stenosis

Repair atrial and ventricular

septal defects

Repair tetrology of Fallot

Repair sinus of Valsalva fistula

Acquired lesions

Mitral valve replacement

Aortic valve replacement

Tricuspid valve replacement

Mitral valve annuplasty

Mitral valve commissurotomy

Aortic valve commissurotomy

Repair ventricular aneurysm

Resection and graft ascending aortic aneurysm

Total

ing prosthetic cardiac valve replacement without blood were the subject of a previous report from this center.8

Results

Among the 157 patients in whom open heart surgery without the use of blood was, performed, there were only two deaths, a mortality of 1.3%. One death followed mitral valve replacement in a 56-year-old man who died suddenly of an uncontrollable arrhythmia on the day of his scheduled discharge from the hospital, at which time his hemoglobin level and hematocrit reading were within normal limits. The other death occurred in a 36-year-old woman after repair of a very complex congenital anomaly. In this patient of the Jehovah’s Witness faith survival might have been possible with transfusion, but she steadfastly refused to accept blood and died on the fourth day after operation with a hemoglobin level of 6.8 gm/100 cc and an hematocrit reading of 21%.

Anemia did not prove to be a problem in this group of patients, as can be seen from Fig 2. Although hemoglobin and hematocrit levels fell to an average of 10.4 gm/100 cc and 31.9%, respectively, one week after operation, these mild blood loss anemias responded to oral administration of iron. No difference in wound healing was notecT be-

PRE-OP

24 HRS. POST-OP

1 WEEK POST-OP

Fig 2.—Graft illustrating average changes in hemoglobin levs! and hematocrit reading in 157 patients undergoing open heart surgery without use of blood.

tween these patients and those in whom transfusion was used.

Comment

The described technique of open heart surgery using disposable plastic oxygenators primed with 5% dextrose in distilled J water offers significant advantages over methods requiring pooled, homologous blood to prime the pump oxygenator. Various physiological functions appear far bet-J ter maintained than when a blood prime is used,® and this appears of particular importance in regard to. rengdAtoKtion in patients with advanced acquired valvular disease.10 Preparations for operation are simplified v considerably, especially blood banking requirements. And, elimination of the need to obtain large quantities of fresh, heparinized blood now allows immediate availability of / cardiopulmonary bypass for emergency operations, such as pulmonary embolectomy.11

In addition to the use of pooled homologous blood to prime various extracorporeal circuits, routine transfusion of banked blood to replace operative blocd^loss^milTilitsr j for milliliter has become far too commonplace with open heart surgery. The concept of keeping up with blood loss as it occurs is advantageous when blood loss is massive, but loss of large quantities of blood is not a necessary accompaniment of intracardiac surgery. Efforts toward minimizing blood loss during open heart surgery can reduce significantly amounts of transfused blood required and eliminate its need altogether in quite a number of patients, as illustrated by the present report.

/ Blood loss of 500 to 1,000 ml usually is tolerated by an adult^'J‘and'''c^apensa^~ tion for even larger losses is possible by use of plasma expanders. Even in those patients in whom some blood replacement is mandatory, the number of transfused units should be kept to the minimum necessary for smooth recovery of the patient. Until better screening techniques for blood donors are developed or until demand for blood is reduced, only by minimizing donor exposure associated with open heart surgery can the incidence of posttransfusion hepatitis associated with open heart surgery be lowered significantly from figures running_a^tg]tLaa-21%.12 Furthermore, reduction in the amount of blood given also reduces the pos- , sibility of transfusion reactions associated with human error or with minor blood group incompatibilities missed in routine crossmatching.

A significant result of this approach to open heart surgery has demonstrated that many patients requiring intracardiac repair actually do not need any blood during the entira period of hospitalization. This has allowed acceptance for operation of patients v belonging to the Jehovah’s Witness religious faith, rather than denying them benefits of needed surgery. Certainly one prefers to retain the option of using blood transfusion should it prove to be indicated, but such limitation often is outweighed by the risk inherent in the patient’s cardiac lesion without correction should the surgeon refuse operation under terms imposed by the patient’s religious convictions. Moral and ethical consideration of major surgery in Jehovah’s Witnesses has been reviewed by Fitts and Orloff.13 Legal implications are perhaps even more complicated. However, unless the surgeon is able to treat a patient of this faith on terms imposed by this J religion, regardless of medical circumstances, he must not accept the patient for treatment.

With demonstration of the adverse effects of using large quantities of homologous blood to prime pump oxygenators for open heart surgery, we adopted a technique using disposable plastic oxygenators primed with 5% dextrose in distilled water. Extracardiac blood loss usually was replaced with

570


OPEN HEART SURGERY—BEALL ET AL

banked, acid-citrate dextrose blood as with any major operative procedure. Such a technique now has been used in 1,818 clinical cases and overall results have been most gratifying as compared to those obtained using homologous blood priming.

Among these patients were 157 with assorted congenital and acquired cardiac defects which were corrected by open heart surgery without the use of blood at any time throughout hospitalization. Eleven of these patients belonged to the Jehovah’s Witness religious faith whose steadfast convictions would permit no blood or blood products of any type to be used. In the majority of those who received no blood, however, transfusion was withheld electively because it was not considered necessary,

Anemia was not a problem in these patients, and there were only two deaths, one / of which was totally unrelated to absence of blood transfusion. This experience reemphasizes that blood transfusion should be used only for specific indications, even in patients undergoing open heart surgery. Such an approach not only reduces possible transfusion reactions, but also other complications of blood therapy such as homologous serum hepatitis.

This study was supported in part by the US Public Health Service (grants HE-03137 and EEE-05387) and the Houston and Texas heart associations.

References

Arch Surg—Vol 94, April 1967

Cardiac Valve Replacement for Congenital Mitral Valvular Disease in Children

By Robert D. Bloodwell, Grady L. Hallman, Dan G. McNamara, and Denton A. Cooley

PATIENTS WITH MALFORMATIONS OF THE MITRAL VALVE causing advanced hemodynamic changes and severe disability during childhood may be managed only by excision and replacement of the mitral valve. Structural alterations of valves in most patients with congenital mitral stenosis, mitral insufficiency, and complete atrioventricular canal defects prevent successful correction by valvuloplasty.

Improved design of prosthetic valves, including low-profile lenticular valves for patients with small ventricular cavities, permit valve replacement during childhood.1'2 Cloth covered seating rings should decrease thromboembolic complications and permit incorporation by ingrowth of autologous tissue.34

This report is concerned with 21 children in whom mitral valve replacement was used for management of congenital valvular malformations.

Clinical Material

Since November 1965, 21 children between and 15 years of age have undergone excision and prosthetic replacement of congenital defects of the mitral valve in our institutions. Only those with severe hemodynamic alterations or intractable cardiac failure and growth retardation were selected for operation.

Six patients had congenital mitral stenosis, 2 of whom had typical “parachute mitral valve” deformities (Fig. 1).B Ten patients had congenital mitral insufficiency,0 one of whom had an associated septum secundum atrial septal defect and another recurrent mitral insufficiency after annuloplasty had been performed 3 years previously. Five patients had complete atrioventricularis communis, in one patient associated with pulmonary valvular stenosis. One of these patients was operated upon secondarily after a previous attempt at suture repair of the mitral valvular component of the defect.

Three patients ages Hz, 3Jz, and 6 years had undergone resection of coarctation of the aorta, 2 weeks, 1 year, and 3 years previously. One of these patients with mitral insufficiency and a 15-year-old boy with mitral stenosis had a patent ductus arteriosus divided previously. Three patients underwent concomitant aortic valvulotomy.

From the Texas Children’s and Ben Taub General Hospitals and the Departments of Surgery and Pediatrics, Baylor University College of Medicine, Houston, Texas.

Robert D. Bloodwell, M.D.: Assistant Professor of Surgery, Baylor University College of Medicine. Grady L. Hallman, M.D.: Associate Professor of Surgery, Baylor University College of Medicine. Dan G. McNamara, M.D.: Associate Professor of Pediatrics, Baylor University College of Medicine. Denton A. Cooley, M.D.: Professor of Surgery, Baylor University College of Medicine.

Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Vol. 4, No. 1 (February) 1969                   9

10

BLOODWELL ET AL.

Fig. 1.—Specimen removed from 6-year-old girl with “parachute mitral valve” causing mitral stenosis. Note thickened leaflets, funnel shape, single papillary muscle, and shortened fused chordae tendineae. The only openings in subvalvular region are several narrowed spaces which seriously limit blood flow through mitral valve.


Pulmonary hypertension was present in 14 patients including each of those with complete atrioventricular canal except the child with associated pulmonary stenosis.

Methods

Cardiopulmonary bypass was provided by a disposable plastic bubble oxygenator using the hemodilution technique under normothermic conditions.7 Elective ischemic cardioplegia was used in all patients except in 3 early cases. Double open-caged ball-valve pros theses were used in 4 patients and low-profile lenticular valves were used in all subsequent patients including each with atrio-ventricular canal and all except the first patient with congenital mitral stenosis. Cloth covered discoid valves were used in all patients during the past year. Anticoagulant drugs were omitted in several of the early patients since control of dosage is difficult in children, but this method of reduction of thromboembolic complications seems important enough to urge its use even in these young patients. Anticoagulants did not prevent recurrent thrombosis which lead to the death of one patient 9 months after mitral valve replacement.

Results

Follow-up of these children after valve replacement extends from 2 months to 2JS years (Fig. 2).

Two patients experienced thromboembolic complications. A 6-year-old girl has recovered without sequelae from a cerebral embolus which occurred 6 months after operation; no similar episodes have occurred in this patient during the past year. Recurrent thrombus formation in a 12-year-old girl led to her death 9 months after operation, despite secondary' valve replacement and intense anticoagulant therapy.

Three early deaths occurred among the 21 patients, yielding a hospital

Two of these patients were operated upon as a desperate attempt at salvage of patients in intractable pulmonary edema after intensive medical management had failed to improve their clinical condition (Table 2). One had associated endocardial fibroelastosis with poor left ventricular function; therefore, correction of mitral insufficiency was ineffective in improving his cardiac output. One child with Marfan’s syndrome experienced mitral insufficiency and acute pulmonary edema after rupture of chordae tendineae. The third death occurred one day after operation in a 2/2-year-old child with complete atrioventricular canal.

Two late deaths occurred after operation. Although initially improved by ball-valve replacement for recurrent mitral insufficiency 3 years after mitral annuloplasty, a 12-year-old girl experienced recurrent thromboembolic episodes. Removal of the prosthesis which was encased in thrombus and

secondary replacement with a discoid prosthesis was followed by repeated embolic episodes which led to her death 9 months after mitral valve replacement. Cardiac failure and pulmonary hypertension were also features of her clinical course.

A 13-year-old child died 6 months following radical repair of complete atrioventricular canal after initial clinical improvement. Bacterial endocarditis was diagnosed because of recurrent fever and terminal valve insufficiency despite no bacterial growth from all blood cultures.

Fig. 3.—Roentgenogram of chest in same 6-year-old girl as Figure 1 A, before and B, after mitral valve replacement with discoid valve prosthesis into narrow mitral annulus. Coarctation of aorta resected 3 years before. Valve replacement done because of cardiac failure and severe pulmonary hypertension. Although para-valvular leak required reoperation 3 months after valve insertion, patient now improved.

Dacron cloth covered silicone disc prosthesis used. Child has grown and resumed normal activities.


Fig. 5—Roentgenograms of chest A, before and B, 2 years after radical repair of complete atrio-ventricular canal in 4-year-old boy. Discoid mitral valve prosthesis inserted in conjunction with patch closure of confluent ventricular and atrial septal defects. Pacemaker implanted 2 weeks after operation for intermittant complete heart block. Clinical condition continues to be excellent one year after operation.


Reduction in heart size and resumption of body growth is indicative of the remarkable clinical improvement demonstrated by most surviving patients (Figs. 3, 4, and 5).

CARDIAC VALVE REPLACEMENT

15


function is demonstrated by catheterization studies obtained in a 9-year-old child thought to have primary pulmonary hypertension most of his life (Table 3). Pulmonary artery pressure was equal to aortic pressure before operation. Resection and replacement of a “parachute mitral valve” with a discoid prosthesis was performed with concomitant aortic valvotomy for associated aortic valve stenosis. Hemodynamic studies one year after operation demonstrated a pulmonary artery pressure of 65 over 20 mm. Hg with a mean pressure of 35 (preoperative values were 120 over 85 with a mean pressure of 100 mm. Hg).

Comment

While knowledge of the long-term fate of artificial valves is incomplete, certain children with severe disability due to advanced congenital deformities of the mitral valve can be managed only by valve excision and prosthetic substitution.8-11 Possibility of the need for secondary valve replacement to provide for increased cardiac output as the child grows12 is circumvented by the opportunity to employ a small-sized adult valve in most of these patients with a dilated mitral annulus.

Valvotomy is unsatisfactory for correction of congenital mitral stenosis due to the advanced nature of structural changes in such a valve. Mitral an-nuloplasty is preferred by some for correction of congenital mitral insufficiency.13 Although such procedures may result in symptomatic improvement and often decreased heart size, nearly all reported cases retain some degree of mitral insufficiency with persistent systolic murmurs.0’13 Our experience with annuloplasty in adults has been equally disappointing.

Experience with the radical repair of complete atrioventricular canal defects using a valve prosthesis in conjunction with patch closure of the confluent ventricular and atrial defects has provided an encouraging outlook for these patients for whom the previous outlook for operative correction was poor.

Cloth covered low-profile prosthetic valves provide a means of replacing the mitral valve in children with a decreased chance of postoperative thromboembolic complications and the potential of providing adequate valve function into adult life.

Summary

Certain congenital defects of the mitral valve causing severe disability during childhood can be managed only by valve excision and prosthetic substitution.

Mitral valve replacement was performed in 21 children for correction of congenital mitral stenosis in 6, isolated congenital mitral insufficiency in 10, and complete atrioventricular canal defects in 5. Three patients underwent concomitant aortic valvulotomy. Fourteen patients had pulmonary hypertension and 3 had undergone previous repair of coarctation. Nine patients were in congestive heart failure.

Three hospital deaths occurred in patients operated upon for intractable failure; one had associated endocardial fibroelastosis, another acute mitral

16


BLOODWELL ET AL.

insufficiency from Marfan’s syndrome, and another complete atrioventricular canal. Two late deaths occurred; one due to recurrent thrombus formation on the prosthesis, and the other from bacterial endocarditis and cardiac failure.

The low-profile discoid valve with minimal protrusion into the left ventricle is particularly suited for mitral replacement in children. Small adult-sized prostheses were used permitting growth and development of the children. Cloth covering of the seating ring permits incorporation by ingrowth of autologous tissue and decreased thromboembolic complications.

Although the long-term fate of prosthetic heart valves is uncertain, the management of severe congenital mitral deformities by valve replacement has provided remarkable clinical improvement in these children.

medical communications i960


If raedical therapy with osygem, digitalis, etc., is not successful in controlling symptoms, surgical treataent becomes necessary to prevent a fetal outcome. Total correction of the anomaly is, of course, ideal therapy and is possible ia some anomalies such as patent ductus arteriosus and coarctation of the aorta. “Open-heart” surgery is necessary in lesions sack as total anomalous venous return, and pulmonary and aortic stenosis. The added risk of open surgery in infants should be avoided in certain anomalies that can be treated by a staged technique. A palliative operation is performed during early Infancy and definitive, open operatioa is deferred until the patient has reached a m optimal age and size. This eshibit illustrates the two-stage approach to the treatment of infante with tetralogy of Tallot, complete transpositioBs of the great vessels, and ventricular septal defect. '

BCR-33



Problem:


Hypoxemia and cyanosis due to decreased pulmonary blood flow (because of pulmonary stenosis) and right-to-left shunt through VSD.



7 It


Solution:


First Stage


Systemic-pulmonary shunt to increase pulmonary blood flow and relieve hypoxemia.



Technique: Intrapericardial ascending aorta - right pulmonary artery shunt.

We prefer to anastomose the ascending aorta to the right pulmonary artery but standard Blalock (subclavian-pulmonary) or Potts (descending aorta-pulmonary) anas to mo ses can be done.

ballot


Total Correction


At the age of 6-8 years total correction is done using cardiopulmonary bypass. The previous anastomosis is closed, pulmonary stenosis relieved, and the VSD closed with a Dacron patch.

Tetr alogy of Fallot


Three month old infant with tetralogy and severe hypoxemia. Note normal size heart with up-tilted apex and concave pulmonary conus. Pulmonary vas cular markings severely decreased. Systemic pulmonary shunt done with relief of hypoxemia.

Two months after shunt operation. Note increase in heart size and pulmonary vascularity.

COMMENT

Most infants who require shunt operations for tetralogy ar® less than 4 years of age, and many are in the first year of life. Although we occasionally use the standard anastomoses described by Blalock and by Potts, our current preference is for an intrapericardial anastomosis between the ascending aorta and Ilie subjacent right pulmonary artery. This anastomosis involves minimal mediastinal dissection; it can be done readily even with a right arch; and it can be combined with other operations such as atrial septectomy should transposition of the great vessels be present. The principle advantage of this anastomosis lies in the ease with which it can be closed through the ascending aorta at the time of total repair.

Transposi tion


Of The Great Vessels


Problem:


Hypoxemia due to failure of flow of sufficient oxygenated blood from the pulmonary (left-sided) circuit into the systemic (right-sided) circuit. High left atrial pressure and pulmonary congestion.



Solution:


First Stage


Creation of atrial septal defect improves intracardiac mixing and relieves left atrial hypertension.






Technique: Atrial Septectomy (Blalock-Hanlon procedure)

COMM ENT

Atrial septectomy provides satisfactory palliation of hypoxemia in newborn infants with transposition of the great vessels. Often this operation must be performed as an emergency without antecedent cardiac catheterization or angiocardiography. At the age of 3 or 4 years definitive diagnostic studies are performed and the patient is evaluated to determine the feasibility of total repair. The presence of increased pulmonary vascular resistance, pulmonary stenosis, or ventricular septal defect greatly increases the risk of total correction. At present we avoid operating upon such patients except in unusual circumstances. The ideal candidate for complete correction is one with an intact ventricular septum and a pressure in the left ventricle less than 85 mm. Hg. systolic.


Problem:


Heart failure due to left - to - right shunt.



Solution :


First Stage


Banding of main pulmonary artery to reduce magnitude of shunt and relieve heart failure.



14


Tech nique: Pulmonary artery banding



f paten z sutured in

inctsjcn. , ' futures


Second Stage


Inferior ri suture^, avoidi conduct!® bundled


RB


Smail defect closed


suture


Total Correction

At the age of 5-6 years total correction is dose asing cardiopulmonary bypass. The VSD is closed with a Dacron patch. The band is ent and pulmonary artery reconstructed if necessary.


Illustrative Case


Age 2 months. Severe intraet-able cardiac failure. Note cardiac enlargement and increased pulmonary vascular markings. Pulmonary banding done with relief of heart failure.


Age 4 years, prior to open-heart surgery. Heart is at upper limits normal size. Pulmonary vascular markings normal.

Six months after closure of VSD and reconstruction of 1 2 pulmonary artery with un-° eventful recovery. Heart size and pulmonary vascularity normal.

FIRST STAGE

Pulmonary Artery Banding

81*

1**

COMMENT

Medical therapy can control cardiac failure in the majority of infants with ventricular septal defect. If heart failure is intractable or if repeated episodes of pneiiEosiia occur, operation is necessary. In the early years of cardiopulmonary bypass in our institution (1956-1959) open-heart repair of ventricular septal defect during the first few months of life resulted in a mortality of 42%. These discouraging results led to the adoption of pulmonary artery banding as the procedure of choice when surgical therapy became necessary during the newborn period. Most of the patients who died after banding Erad multiple c .rdiac anomalies.

We believe that pulmonary artery banding is rarely indicated beyond 12 months of age. If a patient can be carried on medical therapy to this point, he can usually be followed for several years until open-heart repair can be done.

Total repair has been performed in our institation at an average age of 4 years. The defect is closed with a Dacron patch using temporary cardiopulmonary bypass and the pulmonary band divided. If the pulmonary artery cannot be dilated to normal caliber, the constricted area is opened with a longitudinal incision. This incision is then closed transversely or an elliptical patch of pericardium is sutured into it to widen this area.

»

Annals of Surgery, Vol. 173, No. 6, June 1971

Cardiovascular Surgery in Newborn Infants:

Results iu 1,050 Patients Less than One Year Old

Grady L. Hallman, M.D., Denton A. Cooley, M.D.

From the Texas Heart Institute of St. Luke’s-Texas Children’s Hospitals,

Houston, Texas 77025

The highest mortality from congenital heart disease occurs during the first year of life. More than one fourth of infants born alive with anomalies of the heart and great vessels die before they reach one month of age, and 60 per cent die before one year if not operated upon.23-24 A variety of anomalies are capable of causing heart failure and hypoxemia, the physiologic derangements that constitute the main indications for operation. Medical therapy is employed initially but often provides inadequate relief. In these cases survival depends on surgical alteration of cardiac anatomy and function, and operation must frequently be performed on an urgent or emergency basis.3-2’ r-s

Clinical Material

Between January, 1954, and October, 1970, 1,050 infants less than one year of age underwent palliative or corrective surgical procedures for congenital cardiovascular anomalies. Sixty per cent were 3 months old or less, and 80 per cent were 6 months old or less (Table 1).

The main indications for operation were refractory heart failure (as in patients with left-to-right shunts or valvular obstructions), hypoxemia (as in patients with decreased pulmonary blood flow and right-to-left shunts), and tracheoesophageal compression (due to vascular ring anomalies). When symptoms were not relieved by medical therapy with oxygen, digitalis, and diuretics, palliative or curative operation

Presented at the Annual Meeting of the Southern Surgical Association, December 7-9, 1970, Boca Raton, Florida.

was scheduled, frequently as an emergency. In many cases the patient’s critical condition precluded cardiac catheterization and angiocardiography, so operation was performed on the basis of clinical diagnosis alone.

Results

Of the 1,050 patients in this series who underwent palliative or curative operations for congenital heart disease, 291 (28 per cent) died (Table 2). Postoperative improvement in the 759 (72 per cent) survivors was gratifying, with significant relief of cardiac failure or hypoxemia. Since total correction of certain complex anomalies during the newborn period is associated with formidable mortality, these infants were treated in two stages; a palliative operation was performed during the first year of life and total correction deferred until later years when open-heart technics could be applied with greater safety.

Anomalies Treated in One Stage

Total correction was accomplished in one stage in 397 patients, most of whom had anomalies correctable by closed technics, although some required cardiopulmonary bypass or caval inflow occlusion. Mortality for this group was 21 per cent (Table 2). One hundred and ninety patients had tricuspid atresia or miscellaneous anomalies that could not be surgically corrected and therefore were treated by one-stage palliative operations. Ninety-three of these patients died after operation.

1007


1008

Table 1. Age Distribution in 1,050 Infants Undergoing Cardiovascular Surgery

HALLMAN AND COOLEY


Age (Months) No. Patients Per Cent

0-3           627          60%

4-6           202          20%

7-9           125          11%

10-12           96           9%

1,050          100%

Ann. Surg. • June 1971

Vol. 173 ■ No. 6 tic valvotomy under direct vision. Ten (31 per cent) of these patients did not survive operation.

Pulmonary Stenosis. Pulmonary stenosis with intact ventricular septum produced severe heart failure requiring pulmonary valvotomy in 30 patients. Both closed trans-ventricular valvotomy and open operation with caval inflow occlusion have been used in the past, but the preferred technic in recent years has been open valvotomy with cardiopulmonary bypass. Most of the nine (30 per cent) patients who died after operation had a small right ventricle.

Vascular Ring. Compression of the trachea and esophagus by anomalies of the aortic arch system (such as double aortic arch, right arch with left ligamentum arteri-osum, and retroesophageal right subclavian artery) caused symptoms severe enough to warrant operation during the first year of life in 18 patients. A left posterolateral incision was used and the offending vessel was divided. Vessels were removed from the retroesophageal area when feasible, and the ductus or ligamentum was divided. The esophagus and trachea were dissected to release any constricting fascial bands.15-16 In most patients the anomaly causing compression was a double aortic arch. All 18 patients with vascular ring survived operation.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Drainage. Fifty-one patients with cardiac failure required operation for total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage. Supracardiac, cardiac, infracardiac and mixed types were encountered and all required cardiopulmonary bypass. The common pulmonary vein was anastomosed to the left atrium, the patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect was closed, and the connection between the pulmonary vein and systemic venous system was ligated.9’12122 Twenty-nine patients (57 per cent) died after operation.

Tricuspid Atresia. Tricuspid atresia was surgically treated in 66 newborn patients.

Table 2. Results of Cardiovascular Surgery in 1,050 Neieborn Infants

Anomalies Treated in Two Stages

1009


Most had decreased pulmonary flow with severe hypoxemia and underwent systemic-pulmonary shunt for palliation.19 The few patients who had increased pulmonary flow due to associated ventricular septal defect or transposition underwent pulmonary artery banding. Occasional use of cavopulmonary shunts yielded discouraging results. Thirteen (20 per cent) of the 66 patients with this lesion died after operation.

Miscellaneous Anomalies. Complex, often incurable anomalies such as truncus arteriosus, atrioventricularis communis, single ventricle, and endocardial fibroelastosis were found in 124 patients referred for operation during the first year of life. Surgical efforts in these patients were generally palliative. In those with hypoxemia, systemic-pulmonary artery shunts were used to increase pulmonary blood flow. Atrial septal defects were created to promote intracardiac mixing in patients with transposition of the great vessels, and pulmonary artery banding was employed where increased pulmonary blood flow was producing heart failure. In a few cases clinical or laboratory diagnosis was doubtful and exploratory thoracotomy was performed as a a final, desperate effort. Even palliative procedures were not possible in many of these patients because of unfavorable anatomy. Mortality for this heterogenous group of 124 patient was 65 per cent (80 deaths).

Anomalies Treated in Two Stages

Four hundred and sixty-three patients had major anomalies that would require cardiopulmonary bypass for total correction (Table 2). To avoid the excessive risk associated with open heart procedures in the newborn period, we utilized, a two-stage approach, with a closed palliative operation performed first, deferring total correction until later in life.

Tetralogy of Fallot. Severe hypoxemia was the indication for operation in 144 patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Since an effective and safe palliative procedure is

HALLMAN AND COOLEY


1010 available for this lesion, total correction in these patients was deferred to an older age, and all underwent systemic-pulmonary artery shunts. We used the Blalock 2 and Potts 26 technics in earlier cases, but have recently preferred an intrapericardial anastomosis between the posterior aspect of the ascending aorta and the subjacent right pulmonary artery.13’20 Mortality in this group of patients was 17 per cent (24 deaths).

Transposition of the Great Vessels. Patients with transposition of the great vessels, the most common cyanotic anomaly requiring operation during infancy, exhibited severe hypoxemia with or without congestive failure. Here again, a first-stage, palliative procedure was chosen to avoid the risk of open-heart repair during the neonatal period. We used a modified version of the Blalock-Hanlon 1 technique that improved intracardiac mixing by creation of an atrial septal defect.11’ 17>18 However, since 1967 most infants requiring intervention for transposition have been treated by balloon atrial septostomy, as described by Rashkind,27 obviating the need for the Blalock-Hanlon operation. In patients with an associated ventricular septal defect causing increased pulmonary flow and pressure, the pulmonary artery was banded after the atrial septum was excised or balloon atrial septostomy performed. Some infants had pulmonary stenosis and also received a systemic-pulmonary artery anastomosis. Of the 171 patients who underwent operations for transposition, 43 (25 per cent) died.

Ventricular Septal Defect. Intractable heart failure caused by a ventricular septal defect warranted operation in 116 patients. Open-heart repair was used between 1956 and 1959 in 31 of these patients, and 13 (42 per cent) died. This high mortality prompted us to adopt a staged approach. Since 1959, 85 patients have undergone pulmonary artery banding with a mortality of 23 per cent. Mortality for the entire group Ann, Surg. • June 1971 Vol. 173 • No. 6 of 116 patients with ventricular septal defect was 28 per cent (33 deaths).

Pulmonary Valve Atresia. Hypoxemia was extreme in the 32 patients with pulmonary valve atresia. Systemic-pulmonary artery shunts were used in most of this group, since, except in rare instances, the usual small size of the right ventricle and pulmonary annulus made valvotomy impossible or impractical. Special care was taken to construct the anastomoses small enough to lessen the chance of cardiac failure. Fifteen patients (47 per cent) died after operation.

Discussion

Rapid advances in surgical treatment of congenital heart disease during the last few decades have enabled correction or palliation of many cardiovascular malformations previously considered incurable. Accurate clinical diagnosis is more important today than ever before, since we now have an array of effective surgical procedures that, if performed promptly and appropriately in the newborn child, may save lives otherwise doomed at infancy. Moreover, improvement in technics of general anesthesia for small infants has lowered significantly the risk of thoracotomy in this age group.28

The poor prognosis in general for infants with congenital heart disease not surgically treated holds true for individual lesions as well. Seventy-five per cent of infants showing symptoms of coarctation of the aorta die before they are one year old.25 An average survival of only 5% months has been reported for a group of unoperated newborn patients with transposition of the great vessels.1 Mortality during the first year of life for patients with tricuspid atresia is 66 per cent without operation; for tetralogy of Fallot it is 55 per cent.21 All patients with pulmonary atresia and intact ventricular septum, and 80 per cent of those with total anomalous pulmonary’ve-

Ann. Surg. - June 1971 CARDIOVASCULAR SURGERY IN NEWBORN INFANTS

Vol. 173 - No, 6

1011


nous drainage die during the first few months of life if not operated upon.13’14

If initial medical therapy is successful in patients with severe symptoms of congenital heart disease, operation may be deferred until an older, more favorable age is attained. But when medical treatment is ineffective in ameliorating these symptoms, as it so often is, operation should be performed without delay, and on a clinical basis alone if the patient is too ill to tolerate cardiac catheterization. Although hypoxemia and cardiac failure are the principal indications for neonatal surgery, experience has shown that other findings may signify the need for operation: for instance, syncope, increasing cardiomegaly, electrocardiographic evidence of left ventricular strain, or discovery on cardiac catheterization of significant gradients, shunts, or pulmonary hypertension?

The best surgical procedure for an infant with congenital heart disease is that which will offer the most physiologic benefit with the least operative risk. Lesions such as patent ductus arteriosus or coarctation of the aorta can be safely corrected with closed technics. Total correction of anomalies such as tetralogy of Fallot or ventricular septal defect, on the other hand, requires extracorporeal circulation, an added risk in neonates. These anomalies are best treated in two stages using a palliative operation first (when medical therapy is not successful ) and doing the corrective procedure later in life. Usually the palliative operation will salvage the patient until a more favorable age and size for open-heart surgery is reached. For some lesions such as total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage no consistently effective palliative procedure exists, and complete correction with cardiopulmonary bypass must be attempted. Other complex anomalies such as tricuspid atresia are not surgically correctable and palliative measures must suffice.

Most deaths in this series of 1,050 patients occurred within 12 to 24 hours after operation; yet patients who survived usually did so with, and because of, dramatic improvement in hypoxemia and cardiac failure. This suggests that surgical intervention in these seriously ill infants must be definitive and provide major physiologic benefit if the patient is to survive more than a few hours.

This series included many patients who were extremely poor operative risks and many desperate cases of exploratory operations performed on the remote chance that a correctable or palliable lesion might be found. Had selection of patients been limited to those with lesions susceptible to correction or palliation, survival rate would have been greater. In view of the high mortality during the first year of life in unoperated infants with cardiovascular disease, we believe that the 72 per cent survival reported in this paper justifies aggressive surgical treatment in the newborn period when symptoms do not respond to medical therapy.

Summary

Maximum mortality in patients with cardiovascular anomalies occurs during the first year of life when 60 per cent die unless operated upon. A variety of anomalies can cause hypoxemia and/or cardiac failure and when symptoms do not respond to medical therapy, operation must be performed to prevent fatal outcome.

Between 1954 and 1970, 1,050 infants underwent non-elective operations during the first year of life for major cardiovascular anomalies including patent ductus, coarctation, aortic stenosis, pulmonary stenosis, vascular ring, total anomalous pulmonary' venous drainage, tricuspid atresia, tetralogy' of Fallot, transposition of the great vessels, ventricular septal defect, pulmonary valve atresia, and miscellaneous anomalies. When feasible,’ corrective operations were performed. In patients with complex anomalies such as transposition of the great vessels a palliative operation was chosen, deferring

HALLMAN AND COOLEY


1012

total correction until a more favorable age for open-heart surgery was reached. Survival of 72 per cent in this unselected series demonstrates the value of surgical treatment in patients with cardiovascular anomalies producing intractable symptoms during the critical first year of life.

Epsilon-Aminocaproic Acid for Bleeding

After Cardiopulmonary Bypass

Allen I. Midell, M.D., Grady L. Hallman, M.D., Robert D. Bloodwell, M.D., Arthur C. Beall, Jr., M.D., James J. Yashar, M.D., and Denton A. Cooley, M.D.

ABSTRACT The effect of epsilon-aminocaproic acid (EACA) in reducing bleeding after cardiopulmonary bypass was studied in 73 patients who undertvent open-heart operations for the repair of intracardiac lesions and resection of ascending aortic aneurysms. Forty-eight patients received EACA prior to the onset of bypass and 25 did not receive EACA. Bleeding during and immediately after operation in patients with acquired lesions was substantially less in the treated group than in those who had not received EACA. The results of the study indicate that EACA may be effective in reducing bleeding after cardiopulmonary bypass for acquired cardiac disease and that further use and study of this agent is justified.


T1 xcessive bleeding after cardiopulmonary bypass represents a serious problem which complicates the recovery of patients J undergoing an open-heart operation. Profuse bleeding may occur in spite of reversal of heparin anticoagulation with protamine and in spite of adequate hemostasis during operation. Abundant experimental and clinical evidence has shown that various changes in the coagulation mechanism regularly occur after extracorporeal circulation [1, 3, 6, 8, 9, 11—15, 17-19], Changes occur in both the plasma and the cellular constituents of blood. One of the significant changes producing excessive postoperative bleeding is the release of a plasminogen activator which converts plasminogen to plasmin, resulting in fibrinolysis [9, 11, 12, 14, 15, 18],

Epsilon-aminocaproic acid (EACA), acting as a competitive inhibitor of plasminogen activator, has been effective in controlling hemorrhage in isolated patients experiencing excessive bleeding and has yielded similar results in the experimental laboratory [3], The purpose of our study was to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of EACA in controlling hemorrhage.

From the Cora and Webb Mading Department o£ Surgery, Baylor College of Medicine, and the Texas Heart Institute of the St. Luke’s and Texas Children’s Hospitals, Houston, Tex.

Supported in part by U.S. Public Health Service Grants HE-05435, HE-05387, and HE-03137.

Accepted for publication Nov. 30, 1970.

Address reprint requests to Dr. Hallman, Texas Heart Institute, 6621 Fannin, P.O. Box 20434, Houston, Tex. 77025.

MIDELL ET AL.

CLINICAL MATERIAL

Seventy-three patients who were placed on cardiopulmonary bypass during repair of an intracardiac lesion or resection of an ascending aortic aneurysm are included in this study. Forty patients were male and 33 were female. The patients ranged in age from 1 to 81 years with an average of 16 years; the average age of the female patients was -11 years and of the male patients, 50 years. Five patients were below 12 years of age,

A variety of operations for congenital and acquired cardiac disease were inchided (Tables 1, 2). The two procedures performed most frequently were mitral valve and aortic valve replacement. These operations, together with resection of an ascending aortic aneurysm and mitral annuloplasty, comprise all the operations in this series done for acquired disease—52 patients, or two-thirds of the series. The remaining 21 operations were performed for correction of congenital heart defects, although the majority of the patients were adults when operated upon.

Cardiopulmonary bypass was conducted under normothermic conditions using a disposable plastic bubble oxygenator primed with 5% dextrose in water. Blood flow during bypass averaged 50 ml. per kilogram of body weight per minute.

Forty-eight patients received EACA* intravenously immediately prior to the initiation of cardiopulmonary bypass, while 25 received no EACA. The patients were matched according to age and weight insofar as this was possible. The first 48 patients were studied by giving alternate patients EACA (125 mg. per kilogram of body weight) prior to bypass. From our experience with the first 48 patients, however, the advantages of EACA seemed so obvious that the remaining

25 were all treated with EACA. Blood loss during and up to four hours after operation was measured by the return from the chest tubes.

RESULTS

When the patients in each group were divided according to the operative procedure performed, it was seen that the bleeding that had occurred in certain categories of patients who had received EACA was significantly less than in the corresponding categories of patients who had not received EACA. This was particularly noticeable in patients with acquired cardiac disease requiring valve replacement. The average blood loss among those with acquired heart disease in the treated group was 575 ml. as compared with 1,360 ml. in the untreated group.

Among all patients with congenital heart disease, regardless of age at the time of repair, an average blood loss of 1,263 ml. occurred in the untreated group as compared with 952 ml. in the treated group. Patients with subaortic stenosis, ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, and anomalous pulmonary venous return all had less bleeding when treated with EACA, although there are relatively few patients in each category (Table 2) and the difference between the treated and untreated patients was not as marked as it was in those with acquired disease.

In the entire series, 2 patients required reoperation for bleeding in the immediate postoperative period. One of these had received EACA prior to bypass.

MIDELL ET AL.

TABLE 3. PATIENTS GROUPED ACCORDING TO BLOOD LOSS WITH AND WITHOUT USE OP EACA

EACA

2B

23“

8

1000-1500

2b

6a

1500-2000

1

3

2000-2500

0

5

2500-3000

I

0

Greater than 3000

0

0

Total

48

25

"Including 1 child.

“Including 2 children.

The first patient, a 1-year-old infant who was treated with EACA during correction of transposition of the great vessels, was bleeding from multiple diffuse points in the chest wall and mediastinum. The second patient, an adult who underwent repair of an atrial septal defect without receiving EACA, also was bleeding from multiple points in the chest wall.

If all the patients are classified according to the total amount of blood lost, it is evident that the great preponderance of patients treated with EACA lost less than 1,000 ml. (Table 3). Twenty-one of the 24 patients who lost less than 500 ml. had been treated with EACA; and of the 48 patients -who received EACA, 44 (42 adults and 2 children) lost less than 1,000 ml. in the postoperative period.

COMMENT

Trauma to the cellular elements of the blood during cardiopulmonary bypass results in destruction of and damage to red cells and platelets. Clot-promoting and heparin-neutralizing factors released from these damaged cells result in a state of potential hypercoagulability. Intravascular clotting consequently occurs, resulting in an abnormal consumption of clotting factors. These developments in turn stimulate production of antithrombin activity and the release of plasminogen activator, which results in fibrinolysis [11, 13, 18].

Activation of the fibrinolytic enzyme system has been described by several earlier investigators [15, 18], but the degree and frequency of fibrinolysis and the factors affecting it remain obscure. Gans and Krivit [11], in a study of 44 patients, found that plasminogen activator was released in 40 of the patients during extracorporeal circulation and that operations for acquired heart disease were associated with the release of significantly more activator than were operations for congenital defects. On the other hand, a recent study by Beall and his associates [1] of 24 patients undergoing extracorporeal circulation with a plastic bubble oxygenator primed with 5% dextrose in water revealed the presence of plasminogen activators without actual fibrinolysis in most of the patients studied.

EACA for Bleeding After Cardiopulmonary Bypass

In this study, we found no patient in whom the administration of EACA in the dosage described was deemed responsible for any untoward effect. Considerable mention has been made in the literature regarding undesirable effects of EACA. A fatal case of glomerular capillary thrombosis with renal failure has been reported recently, and the dangers of the effect of EACA on cardiac performance have been noted to be substantial [4]. The cardiovascular effects appear to be mediated mainly through release of catecholamines and may result in arrhythmia and hypotension [5, 16].

The results of this study indicate that EACA may be effective in significantly reducing bleeding after extracorporeal circulation, particularly in the case of acquired cardiac lesions that are treated with valve replacement. We realize this study is inherently limited by the relatively crude measurement of blood loss through chest tube drainage as well as the relatively small number of patients in the series. Nevertheless, it would appear from the results obtained that EACA may be effective 'when used during operation for acquired cardiac disease. The significantly high level of plasminogen activator previously shown to occur during operations for acquired heart disease may explain the favorable results noted with EACA in these patients [9], Despite the inability to demonstrate circulating fibrinolysins among 24 patients undergoing extracorporeal circulation in an earlier study from this institution [1] and despite such factors as diminished circulating platelets, prolonged prothrombin time, altered fibrinogen levels, and inadequate techniques for control of bleeding, all of which may contribute to faulty hemostasis and are unaltered by EACA, we found that EACA helped to diminish postoperative bleeding in some of the patients studied.

REFERENCES

  • 1. Beall, A. G., Jr., Strawn, J. R,, Tillerty, W. V., and Cooley, D. A. Effects o£ extracorporeal circulation on fibrinolytic activity in man. Clin. Res. 14: 238, 1966.                                  '

MEDICAL WORLD NEWS December 13, 1968


Anesthesiologist Edward Crawford holds cool hand of boy going into deep hypothermia to permit cardiac arrest during surgery.

BAK W FOR HEART RHB

At the age of three months, Michele weighed only eight pounds. She had a congenital heart defect, and doctors at the University of Washington Hospital in Seattle gave her but a few weeks to live. Her condition was so grave that a surgical team headed by Dr. David H. Dillard decided to try open-heart surgery using a technique of surface-induced deep hypothermia they had developed in animal studies.

Michele was anesthetized with ether, placed on a plastic sheet, and lowered into a cooling tank where she floated on ice water. As thermometer readings dropped, bags of crushed ice were packed around her to lower her temperature still further. When her rectal temperature reached 78° F, she was removed from the tank and put on the operating table for the first incision. Her temperature continued to drift down and hit 63° F.

At this point, 4 cc of Young’s solution was injected into the aortic root to induce cardiac arrest. The heart was stopped for 32 minutes while the surgeons corrected the routing of the tiny infant’s pulmonary venous circulation that drained into the coronary sinus. The surgical field was almost bloodless. Today, three years later, Michele is healthy, lively, and growing normally. Her IQ is 140.

Surface-induced deep hypothermia has since been used by the Seattie physicians on 25 other infants too young to tolerate the heart-lung machine. Without corrective surgery for congenital heart defects, says Dr. Dillard, none of these infants seemed likely to live. Eleven have survived the openheart surgery.

The survivors include Michele and four others out of the ten infants who had total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage, four of seven who had transposed great vessels, one of three who had pulmonary atresia, and one of three who had complex ventricular septal defects. The procedure has also been tried in cases of aortic atresia, aortic stenosis with hypoplastic left ventricle, and double outlet right ventricle, but these three infants died.

“Mortality can perhaps be associated with the anatomy and over-all condition of the infant,” ventures Dr. Dillard, who acknowledges there are still too few cases for significant correlation. “Our youngest patient was only a few days old.” he notes, “but our youngest survivor was 42 days old.” All who survived correction of great vessel transposition or total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage were younger than six months.

Dr. Dillard, who is associate professor of surgery, suggests that there is some “special problem, still undefined” in transposition of the great vessels. One boy with this defect went into a prolonged period of cardiac arrest two days after surgery and is now somewhat retarded, with an IQ in the 80 to 90 range. Two other infants had pulmonary insufficiency after initial recovery from surgery, and mild impairment of psychomotor development is suspected in one. None of the children who have survived. Dr. Dillard reports, evidence any neurologic damage from the hypothermia itself.

In the extensive research with does and puppies that preceded their clinical use of induced hypothermia, the Seattle investigators noted that some adult dogs had a high-stepping gait after circulation was stopped for an hour. In later tests, they found that con tinted

28


‘ICING’ BABIES continued

perfusion of the brain with cold isotonic saline solution helped avoid this problem. They now use such perfusion with infants as well.

A nine-member team of surgeons, anesthesiologists, and pediatricians carries out the procedure. Dr. Hitoshi Mohri handles the actual cooling. A visiting scientist at the university, Dr. Mohri pioneered in the development of the technique while at Japan’s University of Sendai and has assisted with the Washington modifications.

In the gradual cooling, temperatures fall to the desired level within one to three hours. Cardiac arrest is limited to about an hour, but the entire procedure may last as long as six hours. Rectal and esophageal temperatures are monitored continuously. As the temperature is reduced, low-molecular-weight dextran is given intravenously. Deep ether anesthesia, reports Dr. Dillard, seems to be critical in obtaining desired levels of cooling without ventricular fibrillation.

All body activity is markedly decreased as the temperature drops. Blood pressure falls to around 30 mm Hg. Liver and renal function are depressed, insulin and growth hormone release are decreased, and ail metabolic processes are slowed before circulation stops. The baby breathes . room temperature air, and respiration is maintained by hand to keep ventila- . tion at relatively normal levels. Because of the depressed metabolism, this results in respiratory alkalosis and helps compensate for the circulatory curtailment.

'The Pink Get Pinker’

After the operation, all deviations gradually disappear as the infant is warmed in a warm-water bath. The heart almost always resumes its beat spontaneously, but sometimes manual ’ massage or electrical pacing is needed.

Blood that has lain still begins to circulate again, moving through the new , routes. The blood’s oxygen tension ■ reaches normal levels, and peripheral

cyanosis disappears. Says Df. Dillard:

‘ Even the pink babies get pinker.”

Postoperative advantages of hypo-' thermia, the Seattle surgeon reports, are the absence of bleeding problems and minimal respiratory complications. The infants, he says, have generally required less intensive postoperative care than perfusion patients.

The prolonged period of suspended animation possible with this method, Dr. Dillard says, makes it possible to do complete corrections on some infants who would normally be put through staged procedures. But he notes that the time for surgery is limited and that there is a potential hazard of producing heart block.

“This is not a panacea for the problems of cardiac surgery in the small infant,” Dr. Dillard warns. “Perhaps it may not even have a permanent place in such surgery. But, for now—while heart-lung .perfusion techniques are undergoing refinements that can reduce mortality and morbidity in tiny infants and while surgical procedures themselves are being improved —we are salvaging babies. Some were moribund when we first saw them. They are growing up healthy." “

30

COOLING THE INFANT HEART

Deep hypothermia by surface cooling, plus limited bypass, provide / "ideal conditions” for operations to correct congenital heart defects in neonates and infants, according to a team of New Zealanders. In describing a series of 37 such procedures, Drs. Brian Barratt-Boyes, M. Simpson, and John Neutze of Green Lane Hospital in Auckland told the American Heart Association meeting in Atlantic City that use of this technique holds the duration of total-body perfusion to a minimum, provides a completely bloodless relaxed heart, and obviates caval cannulation. All this, they add, leads to a "striking lessening of morbidity," including the pulmonary complications commonly attendant upon heart-lung bypass.

The infants in their series were cooled to a nasopharyngeal temperature of 26° C on a circulating water blanket under halothane anesthesia, and then to 22° C by a short period of total-body perfusion. Circulatory arrest at this temperature averaged 48 minutes, sufficient time to make the intracardiac repair. Postopera-tively, 20 minutes of total-body perfusion brought the temperature back up to 32° C, and rewarming by surface means raised it.to 36° C.

Thirty-three of the 37 infants survived the procedure, including 25 aged eight days to a year. The conditions treated were transposition'in 13, tetralogy of Fallot in nine, total anomalous pulmonary venous connection in six, ventricular septal defect in six, and atrioventricular canal in three. Analysis of the four hospital deaths, say the doctors, “indicates that all were avoidable; it would appear, therefore, that if no errors are made either in surgical technique or postoperative management, every infant should survive no matter how y young or how severely affected-provided the defects are completely correctable.”
