BEM-12/69

■, ANBAR TRAGEDY

... ____________.

rf HAPPENED in Cuenca, Ecuador, on the afternoon of January 20, 1989. A loaded dump truck was backing into a narrow driveway alongside an elementary school. One little girl of ten, possibly thinking the truck would pass her, remained in the driveway. As the

PRODUCES

respect for God’s

huge vehicle passed,


By "Awakar


rear wheels of the

the little girl’s dress was caught, and horrified onlookers saw her dragged under the wheels.

Hearing screams, the driver stopped and got out to investigate. Imagine the shock to see the little girl crushed beneath his truck! He had stopped right on top of her! The only thing he could do was drive the truck forward again, the great weight again bearing down upon the injured parts. As it tamed out, the wheels had passed over her left leg, then over her stomach. She was rushed immediately to the clinic, surprisingly still conscious.

When the anxious mother arrived by her side, what do you think were the first words her little daughter uttered? “Mother, I can’t die yet. I haven’t even unducted a Bible study!” And of her own accord the child was telling the nurses that no blood must be used in treating her. What? A badly injured little girl not wanting to die because she wants to teach someone the Bible? To those nurses it was just unbelievable!

A Respectful Doctor

When the doctor arrived he swiftly recommended an operation in order to find out just what damage had been done internally. The father of the child consented. but pointed out that the operation must be without blood. Never having performed such a serious operation without blood before, the doctor was shocked. However, the parents explained to him their law relative to blood.

(Lev. 17; 14; Acts 15:20) They begged the doctor to do all he could for the child, but leave upon them any responsibility for proceeding without blood.

The doctor undertook to do what he could. “Since I have my own religious beliefs and want others to respect them,” he said, “I will respect yours.”

Just before being wheeled into the operating room the child said to her father: “Don’t worry, daddy.” The hours dragged by—five of them—and during all this time of anxious waiting, what did the assembled group of relatives and wellwishers observe? The parents were calmly explaining to them that if the child should die they had the assurance of seeing her again in the resurrection. Surely an unforgettable scene!

24


AWAKE!


The confidence o£ the parents impressed. not only the doctor, but also many of those who had assembled to learn the outcome of the operation. “I am a father too,” said one, ‘‘but you show more calmness over this than I could ever show.”

Said another: “If I could have the faith like these people do, I would be the happiest man alive.”

A next-door neighbor, recently widowed, came to comfort the parents, but as she left she herself testified: “For the two years since my husband’s death I have been depressed; but seeing you and your faith in God and the hope you have has enabled me to find happiness for the first time.”

And After the Operation , . .

Mow came the time for the doctor’s report. No bone-: had been broken, but very serious internal damage had been done to organs. The main artery to the diaphragm had been cut and more than half the child’s blood had been lost. But by the lime the operation got under way the artery had already stopped bleeding, coagulation having stemmed the flow. An artery had been severed only four inches from the heart, and yet the girl did not bleed to death! The surgeon just could not understand why.

The liver had also teen split. And, due to the tremendous presslire, the stomach had been forced right through the diaphragm, rupturing it in two places. This in turn had collapsed and torn the left lung, while at the same time the pericardium surrounding the heart had teen broken. In other words, the truck had stopped just short of bursting the heart —an eventuality that would have been m= stantly fatal.

DECEMBEE 22, 156S

The doctor expressed satisfaction at how the operation had gone. He ate appreciated the calm attitude of the parents —no uncontrolled screaming or drying to unnerve him. He was able to undertake the delicate job in a much more steady frame of mind.

But there was still danger. What about the blood loss? And what about the danger from infection? Either one could prove fatal. During the long operation every inch of the intestines had to be examined for breaks. Also, there had to be a thorough examination of any organs that might have been affected. One could still see the effects of the great pressure that the child’s body had undergone—tiny blood vessels had burst on the side of the neck and in the eye.

Next morning Mimi (that’s her nickname) was awake, quite dear in mind and surprisingly without complaint off jpain from the aftereffects of the operation. The dangerous forty-eight-hour period packed and still no sign of infection. The whole staff of the clinic were astonished at how the little girl had survived the operation without Hood transfusion and was now swiftly getting back to normal only five days after the ordeal.

One week after the accident, Mimi cte released from the clinic and went on making fine progress. Then, a very sartsss complication showed up. Some type of liquid was forming around the heart, possibly due to the rupture in its surroml-ing, protective membrane. What TuiTMt happen now? It was surely an aiirateta time. If the liquid did not dissipate naturally, the child might well have to weter-go another critical operation, fcsv©5vta3 the heart

Next day a heart specialist examisted Mimi. Neither he nor her own dtetor could hide their surprise. During the night the liquid had cleared up, and everything was functioning normally.

Five and a half weeks after the accident, Mimi was back in school playing with all her little friends, the injured organs healed, and no evident effects of the terrible experience.

How could a near-tragic happening produce pleasant memories? Listen! “I was surprised at my own reaction,” said the father. “I did not know I could take such shocking news without breaking down. But right, away I knew that Jehovah was fully aware of our needs. So, whether Mimi lived or died, just knowing of God’s kindly oversight of all things gave me a calmness I have never before experienced. We have read how Jehovah strengthens his servants when under triai. Now I know he does.”

And here is what the mother said: “When I first saw my child lying there I just went cold all over. But the next moment something very warm came over me as I thought about cur complete dependence on Jehovah for everything. Jehovah’s spirit certainly does give strength and fortitude.”

And what about the surgeon? This had been the most critical operation ever performed at the clinic, and it had been successful without blood. Said the doctor: “I have learned something from this experience.” What did he learn?

Shortly afterward a university student had to be operated on for appendicitis. When it was suggested that a blood transfusion was in order, this same doctor refused, saying: “Since January I have learned that it is much better not to use transfusions.” The appendicitis patient was back in classes soon after, and was doing fine.

The overseer of the local congregation of Jehovah’s witnesses, himself a North American, was deeply impressed too. “I was struck,” he said, “by the difference in the handling of such an emergency here as compared to what may be expected in the United States or other such countries. There were no screaming headlines in the press like ‘CULT'S BELIEF MAY COST CHILD’S LIFE.’ Rather, the radio report spoke of the outstanding faith and the tranquillity of this family under trial, instead of robbing the parents of their right to determine what kind of treatment would be given the injured child, and doing so with high-handed court orders, the surgeon showed proper respect for the position of the parents and their conscientious beliefs.”

One prominent doctor declared: “You-ought to know that this case is referred to as a real miracle among men of the medical circle.” Scores of booklets explaining God’s law regarding blood were placed, many of them with doctors who wanted to have more information on such a vital subject.

Finally, Mimi herself said: “I thank Jehovah for helping me, because if I had died then many people would have thought that it was from not taking a transfusion. But now, many will know that it is best always to obey God’s law, even under critical conditions.”

AWAKE’

W„HO Crosby: Trends in Blood Transfusion          407

Anemia During Surgery

It seems paradoxical. Anemia should be detrimental, not beneficial. On second thought, however, we may perceive reasons which resolve the paradox. Although our blood normally contains about 15 gm. of hemoglobin per 100 ml., we do not require all of that oxygen-carrymg capacity when we are resting. About one-third of our hemoglobin is the margin which permits exertion. While we can live quietly and comfortably with 10 gm. of hemoglobin, we can play tennis with 15 gm. The red cells which contain the hemoglobin have functions other than oxygen transport; one of these is to increase the viscosity of the blood. With greater viscosity, more energy is needed to drive the blood through the small vessels of the micro-circulatory system, and the heart must do more work. During periods of rest, during the surgical patient’s anesthetized sleep when much of the hemoglobin is unneeded, it may be advantageous to remove the excess red cells and thereby reduce the work of the heart. (In many animals, the reservoir function of the spleen actually performs this function by sequestering as much as 30 per cent of the red cells during times of sleep and tranquillity.} By priming the pump oxygenator with fluids other than blood, the machine is required to do less work and therefore less mechanical energy is applied against the circulating red cells and platelets. There is evidence of less damage to these formed elements of the blood.

For many years, surgeons and anesthesiologists have struggled against anemia in preparing patients for operation. Is it conceivable that this struggle has not been to the patient’s best interest? Perhaps in the future the lessons learned from open-heart surgery will be extended into other areas. Patients prior to any surgery may be phlebotomized to induce a degree of anemia consistent with good oxygenation and by so doing, the work of the circulatory system will be reduced. The donated blood would provide a reserve against transfusion requirement during the patient’s operation.

One further contribution of viscosity deserves consideration. The liability to thrombus formation is increased by changes associated with increased viscosity of the blood, as for example a sickle-cell anemia and polycythemia vera. In open-heart surgery, when the pump is primed with glucose or dextran solution, the lower rate of thrombotic complications associated with induced anemia may also be related to reduced viscosity and improved perfusion of the microcirculatory system. Stagnation of the blood is thwarted, sludging is prevented, and the chance of thrombus formation is thereby diminished.

Phlebotomy for the Elderly

Extrapolation of this concept suggests that we investigate an even broader area of human distress. At the present time, thrombotic disease

From the Journals Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences, July 9, 1964-, Vol. 115.

Article 1, page ^07,                      '  ""

AWAKE’ June 22. 1972 pp„ 29,30

Synthetic Blood ‘Substitutes’

While there is no actual substitute for blood, scientists are now working on blood replacements that have proved capable of sustaining life in animals despite massive blood loss. Dr. Robert P. Geyer of the Harvard University School of Public Health and his coworkers say that rats evidently suffer no ill effects when a synthetic preparation is exchanged lor over 90 percent of their total blood supply. Monkeys live, apparently normally, after a 70-percent ex-[See also Section BSBR]

change. The synthetic product allows the organism enough time to develop new blood, which in a few days replaces the synthetic. Dr. Geyer points out that the reason for the interest in this is the well-known dangers of blood transfusions, which kill and injure thousands of persons each year. The preparation developed by the Harvard scientists has as its base a liquid fluoro-_carbon, which can transport oxygen and carbon dioxide. Dr. Geyer predicts that clinical trials on humans can be expected soon.


Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy in Chronic Hemorrhagic Shock

Robert ,S. Antonie, MI); Abraham T. K. Cockett, Ml);

Patti II. 1 .urban, MI); and James C. Thompson. MI), MA

A Jehovah’s Witness patient bled massively per rectum, but refused blood transfusion. A bleeding gastric leiomyoma was excised at eventual operation. His hemoglobin value fell to 2.2 gm/100 cc and on the third postoperative day he showed evidence of severe cerebral and myocardial ischemia and congestive heart failure developed. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy caused a reversal of all signs and symptoms of hypoxia, and the patient recovered. Blood taken from a subject breathing air at 1 atmosphere pressure has 0.3 vol% of oxygen dissolved in plasma; if the subject breathes 100% oxygen at 2 atmospheres absolute pressure, the amount of oxygen in physical solution in plasma is 4 vol%. In a patient with greatly diminished hemoglobin value, this increase in plasma oxygen may be adequate to sustain life.

Adequate replacement of lost blood is an ob-t vious tenet of the standard treatment for hemorrhagic shock. Treatment of bleeding patients who are unable to receive blood, for any reason, may present unusual problems. Members of the Jehovah’s Witness religion refuse to accept blood on the grounds that transfusion is a “feeding upon blood” which is proscribed by the Bible (Leviticus

From the departments of surgery, urology, and anesthesia, Harbor General Hospital, Torrance, Calif, and the University of California at Los Angeles School of Medicine. Dr. Amonic is now on active duty with the US Air Force.

Reprint requests to 1000 W Carson St, Torrance, Calif 90509 (Dr. Thompson).

17:11 and 17:14). They believe that acceptance of a transfusion is an unpardonable sin that will result in withdrawal of the opportunity to attain eternal life. The sincerity of their belief that the acceptance of blood or blood products constitutes a grievous sin cannot be questioned, and their treatment in the event of blood loss may involve difficult moral, ethical, and medical decisions. Fitts and Orloff1 described the problems relating to blood transfusion in Jehovah’s Witnesses and explored the philosophical conflicts that arise when a patient because of religious conviction refuses to accept standard medical treatment.

A Jehovah's Witness patient recently seen at Harbor Genera! Hospital survived following excision of a bleeding tumor and a perhaps unprecedented clinical application of hyperbaric oxygen therapy when he appeared to be on the point of death from blood loss.

Report of a Case

A 26-year-okl, married, Mexican-American male (HH 407-535) of Jehovah’s Witness religious denomination was admitted to Harbor General Hospital on Dec 20, 1967, with the chief complaint of painless rectal bleeding of one day’s duration. He had been in excellent health until 24 hours prior to admission when shortly after a normal bowel movement he passed without prodrome bright red blood and clots in an amount sufficient to fill the toilet bowl. He experienced several mild episodes of syncope. He ate nothing for the rest of the day until coming to the hospital.

The patient said he had been constipated frequently and

JAMA, June 16, 1969 • Vol 208, No 11


Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy—Amonic et al   2051


Schedule of hyperbaric oxygen treatment. Attempt to change from 100% oxygen to air during first cycle was followed by convulsion so that 100% oxygen was used continuously for first four cycles. Sy end of tenth cycle (third day in chamber), patient could tolerate short periods of breathing air at normal atmospheric pressure (surface).


stated that his stools previously had been free of blood. He had not experienced hematemesis, diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting but occasionally had been troubled by heartburn after eating spicy foods. He had been having mild, vague, cramping pain in the lower part of the abdomen during the year preceding admission which was relieved by flatus or bowel movements. In 1961 he had undergone exploratory laparotomy following a penetrating stab wound in the midepigastrium, and in 1962 had had a mild bout of hepatitis without sequelae. He denied significant alcoholic intake and took no medication.

Examination on admission revealed an alert, pale, well-developed young man in no acute distress. His blood pressure was 126/70 mm Hg; temperature, 98.2 F, (36.8 C); respiration, ,24/min and unlabored; and pulse rate," 96 beats per minute. Examination of the heart and lungs showed no abnormality. His abdomen was slightly obese and there was a well-healed midabdominal scar; no masses were palpated and no tenderness was found: bowel sounds were hyperactive. The rectum was found to contain clots of red blood but no other masses.

Findings from laboratory studies at admission included the following values: white blood cell count, 9,200/eu mm; hematocrit, 31%; blood urea nitrogen, 26 mg/100 cc; serum amylase, less than 320 Somogyi units; carbon dioxide, 27 mg/100 cc; sodium, 144 mg/100 cc; and potassium, 4.6 mg/ 100 cc. Sigmoidoscopic examination to 25 cm failed to show any abnormalities except for bright red blood clots coming from beyond the limit of the instrument. Roentgenographic studies revealed a normal chest and normal findings from a four-view study of the abdomen except for some increase in large-bowel gas. An emergency barium enema for roentgenologic examination, which was not of optimal quality, showed a colon which appeared grossly normal. The patient passed a large amount of blood per rectum following the barium enema. Two series of roentgenograms of the upper gastrointestinal tract, including studies of the small bowel, failed to demonstrate pathological findings.

The patient was observed closely and had no further rectal bleeding. The presumptive diagnosis of bleeding from the colon was made, and we decided to treat the patient ex,<< < l.irillv Despite the absence"ol visi-ule blood loss, his hematocrit level fell hum 31",', io 22% >n a 24-hour period ,mri stabilized. This decrease in liematin til was 1 bought to be due to reconstitution of the intravascular volume with 6% dextran 70 and electrolyte solutions. I [is temperature slowly rose to 102 F (38.9 C) by the third hospital day. '[’his lever was not affected by repeated tracheal aspiration. Other vital signs remained stable. The patient steadfastly refused transfusion of all blood or blood products because of his religious convictions. His wife was likewise adamantly opposed to the use of blood. She said that if God willed, she would rather see her husband dead, because if he should accept blood, he would forfeit happiness in this life and all chance of life after death.

On the morning of the fourth hospital day (Dec 24), the patient’s condition was clearly deteriorating. He was weak and dyspneic, his blood pressure was 96/40 mm Hg, his temperature was 104 F (40 C), and his hematocrit value had fallen to 13%. He then suddenly vomited bright red blood which pointed, for the first time, to a site of bleeding in the upper part of the gastrointestinal tract. Despite the patient’s refusal to accept transfusion, the decision was made to perform an exploratory laparotomy immediately.

The patient was given 4 units of dextran. Just prior to induction of anesthesia his blood pressure was 115/70 mm Hg; pulse, 120 beats per minute; respiration, 22/minute; temperature, 105 F (40.6 C); and hematocrit value, 12%. He was bathed in alcohol and placed on a cooling blanket. Tracheal intubation was performed with the patient awake and under local anesthesia. Induction of anesthesia was accomplished with 225 mg thiopental sodium in divided doses of 50 mg following hyperventilation with 100% oxygen. Inhalation anesthesia consisted of nitrous oxide, oxygen, and halothane at a flow of 25 ml of oxygen through the copper kettle on an anesthesia machine. Further relaxation was obtained with divided doses of tubocurarine chloride given intravenously, which totaled 51 mg.

The abdomen was quickly opened and exploration of the peritoneal cavity revealed a small intragastric mass palpable through the posterior of the stomach wall just distal to the gastroesophageal junction. A gastrotomy was performed 1 cm distal to this area and a 2x3-cm sessile tumor with a fresh clot on its surface was revealed. The tumor was excised and was found to be smooth and rubbery. Subsequent microscopic examination revealed the classic pattern of a benign leiomyoma. The mucosal defect was repaired and the stomach was closed. Estimated blood loss was less than 200 ml; the hematocrit value was 10% immediately following operation. The patient tolerated the procedure fairly well and satisfactory vital signs were maintained throughout. At the end of the procedure his temperature was 101.6 F (38.7 C).

The patient recovered quickly from anesthesia but shortly thereafter became agitated and confused. He had an elevated central venous pressure (18 cm water); other signs of congestive heart failure, including moist respiratory rales, cardiac gallop, and tachypnea, developed rapidly. Digitalis and diuretics were given and fluid intake was restricted. On the second day postoperatively the hemoglobin level was 2.2 gm/100 cc. By the third postoperative day the patient was disoriented and required firm restraints. Despite administration of 100% oxygen by mask he had severe respiratory distress and gasped for each breath. He complained of severe precordial pain and generalized edema and tachy-

.2052 . JAMA, June 16, 1969 • Vol 208, No 11

134-


Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy -Amonic et al



cardia developed. An electrocardiogram showed slight elevation of the ST segment which was interpreted as a sign of myocardial ischemia. Shortly thereafter he became combative and incoherent. Central venous pressure at this time was 23 cm water and the hematocrit value was 9.5%. Because of these signs of increased hypoxia and apparent impending death, it was decided to attempt to improve the patient's oxygenation with hyperbaric oxygen. He was transported to the recompression chamber at the Long Beach Naval Shipyard on Dec 27 where oxygen under pressure was administered according to the following procedure (Figure):

With the patient breathing 100% oxygen by mask, the pressure was increased within the chamber to that of a 33-foot depth (equivalent to 2 atmospheres pressure, absolute) and held for 160 minutes. The depth was then reduced to 10 feet for 30 minutes after which the chamber pressure was returned to sea level for two hours. This schedule was followed for four cycles. During the next sequence (cycles 5 through 9), the patient was permitted to breathe regular air for 10-rninute periods after 70 minutes of breathing 100% oxygen at a 33-foot depth. At surface, he continued to breathe 100% oxygen. For the remaining eight cycles (10 through 17) the patient was permitted to breathe air while under 2 atmospheres pressure for 20-minute intervals following 60 minutes of breathing 100% oxygen. Seventeen cycles were completed in three days, 19 hours, and 19 minutes. He spent the next 24 hours prior to returning to the hospital at surface pressure and received intermittent therapy with 100% oxygen.

When first placed in the chamber, the patient was ob-tunded and was speaking incoherently. Within the first 20 minutes of hyperbaric oxygen treatment he became lucid and less restless, his pulse rate fell from 140 to 110 beats per minute, and his central venous pressure was 15.5 cm water; within an hour, diuresis began. During the period of the first cycle when an attempt was made to switch from 100% oxygen to air, the patient had a grand mal convulsion. The seizure was halted quickly by inhalation of 100% oxygen by mask.

The patient remained in the chamber for five days. On the second day, his blood pH was 7.47 and blood gas determinations revealed oxygen pressure (Poj at 139 mm Hg, carbon dioxide pressure of 35 mm Hg, and standard bicarbonate level of 24.5 mEq/liter (blood samples were taken while the patient was breathing 100% oxygen at 1 atmosphere pressure). The low F<b when the patient was breathing 100% oxygen suggests that the patient’s oxygen-carrying capacity was further compromised by pulmonary insufficiency due to atelectasis with atrioventricular shunting and to cardiac failure.

The patient began to eat during the second day in the chamber (fourth postoperative day) and he had a bowel movement. By the third day in the chamber his hematocrit value was 11% and his reticulocyte count (corrected) was 4.3%. He was able to tolerate breathing air for short periods and he had no further seizures or signs of hypoxia. He was afebrile while in the chamber; the course of his high fever prior to operation was never known, although we suspected atelectasis.

At the time of his return to the hospital on Jan 1, 1968. the patient was able to tolerate intermittent periods of breathing air at ambient pressures; his hematocrit value had risen to 12% and he had no further signs of congestive heart failure. Digitalis therapy was discontinued. The remainder of the postoperative period was uneventful. The operative wound healed well and at the time of his discharge 16 days postoperative!y he was ambulant and had a hematocrit value of 26%. When last measured seven weeks postoper-atively, his hematocrit value was 42%. and the patient bad returned to his usual activities.

Comment

The first medical use of oxygen under hyperbaric pressure was by the British physician Henshaw in 1662." During the subsequent 2% centuries, the application of this technique was poorly controlled, and unfounded claims of its efficacy were often made and disputed. Current interest in the therapeutic use of hyperbaric oxygen was stimulated by Boerema and associates in 1956 in Holland.’’ They used a hyperbaric-oxygen chamber to perform major surgical procedures and to treat infections caused by anaerobic organisms?'4 This group carefully studied physiologic changes and provided a greatly needed scientific basis for hyperbaric oxygenation therapy.

The possibility of maintaining life without blood was introduced in 1960 by Boerema and colleagues' who described experiments in which oxygen at 3 atmospheres absolute pressure wTas used to increase the effective operating time in cardiac surgery with the circulation interrupted. They found that the partial oxygen pressure in the alveoli can be increased to nearly 15 times the normal value by administering pure oxygen under pressure. This group also studied the effects of diminished hemoglobin values, achieved by dilution with dextran solution, to determine if plasma alone would supply sufficient amounts of oxygen to vital organs.' Studies in pigs showed that hemoglobin concentrations of less than 10% were not tolerated by working heart muscle at normal atmospheric pressure. When oxygen at 3 atmospheres pressure was administered, however, survival was achieved with less than 0.5% hemoglobin concentration.

Use of hyperbaric oxygenation to counter hemorrhagic shock has been well studied in the, Jab- . oratory. Cowley et al"'7 found that oxygen under I -hyperbaric pressure at 3 atm altered the ir- i* reversible stage in hemorrhagic shock and m-creased survival rate in dogs from 17% to 74%. Physiologic and physiochemical changes incident to hyperbaric oxygen have been reported by several investigators.li'W K' The partial pressure of oxygen in air at sea level is 150 mm Hg. This yields a Po2 in arterial blood at about 90 to 100 mm Hg.

The hemoglobin in circulating arterial blood is 97% saturated. Each gram of hemoglobin contains 1.34 ml oxygen. With 15 gm/100 ml hemoglobin, blood contains 20 ml oxygen per 100 ml blood (20 vol%); with 2.2 gm/100 ml hemoglobin, our patient could carry only 2.95 vol% oxygen bound to hemoglobin. Under standard conditions, plasma contains only 0.3 vol% of dissolved oxygen. When a subject breathes 100% oxygen at 2 atmospheres absolute pressure as our patient did, the partial Po2 is raised to 1,520 mm Hg and the amount of oxygen dissolved in plasma is 4 vol%. Since the normal pooled arterial-venous oxygen difference is 4 to 6 vol%, this oxygen in physical solution has the potential of supplying a large portion of tissue oxygen requirements. In a patient with greatly diminished circulating hemoglobin, this increase in plasma oxygen might provide the narrow margin of support adequate to sustain life.

The lowest level of hemoglobin that will support । V

JAMA, June 16, 1969 o Vol 208, No 11

Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy—Amonic et a!   2053

life is difficult to predict. A young Jehovah’s Witness patient’wiHi an ectopic pregnancy, who was recently cared for at the Obstetrical Service of Harbor General Hospital, survived with minimal symptoms despite hematocrit readings of 7f'r. to 10%. Proper management depends upon careful" prognostic evaluation of signs and symptoms of oxygen deficit.

When our patient appeared about to die of hypoxia, it seemed logical to increase the oxygencarrying capacity of his blood by dissolving oxygen under pressure. Clearly, the appropriate medical approach to hemorrhagic shock is blood replacement; no one would advocate the use of hyperbaric oxygenation as a substitute. In the difficult situation that we faced, this unusual therapy seemed justified and our clinical experience provided a counterpart to results of studies in animals"1'” in which oxygen, driven into solution by hyperbaric pressure, maintained life. Hemoglobin levels as low as 2.2 gm/100 cc produced profound symptoms .of. hypoxia in our patient. Mental obtundation, restlessness, heart failure, and signs of myocardial ischemia all pointed to imminent death, and all V.i.were reversed almost immediately as the patient

I1 — •, 1 ■■ ------------I - III I -| I ■ 11 111-■ I TT, I--JIIUlBtl- WMlnri 1 ~l  .'Wimmi l - x -—r—-

V .breathed pure oxygen in a hyperbaric environment.

The newspaper article below is believed to have appeared in The Spectator (Hamilton, Ontario, Canada) in December 196?.

Oxyg’®B

Driten

Into Body

TORRANCE, Calif. (AP) -Doctors at Harbor General Hospital said yesterday they have kept a hemorrhaging man alive without blood transfusions by driving oxygen into his body.

Officials would not disclose the names of the patient or the doctors. A hospital spokesman gave this account:

A 26-year-old man under-' went surgery . this week for massive gastric bleeding caused by a benign tumor. The operation stopped the bleeding, but the man had lost so much blood that he needed transfusions.

Citing religious belief, the man refused transfusions. On Wednesday, the patient had reached “a near terminal point” and the oxygen treatment was started. Within 20 or 30 minutes, the man’s “vital signs” improved and in the next .1.2 hours “dramatic improvement was noted in body physiology.”

the announcement said the procedure consisted of “driving lots of oxvgen into the patient’s system/ It said oxygen is provided to all the tissues “to buy time until the patient’s own red cell production comes up to a reasonable level to take over that function and literally save his life.”

The statement said the doctors feel that the man’s own red-cell production will be sufficient by Saturday for the administration of oxygen to be stopped.

See also Section ASM and BHG

THE JOURNAL OF CARDIOVASCULAR SURGERY

MAY-JUNE 1964   VOL. 5 NO.

PAGES 251 to 256    -

The effect off transffnsioji* asnd off certain hemodynamic factors on the spontaneous control off arterial hemorrhage by

GERALD W. SHAFTAN, M.D.* CHU-JENG CHIU, M.D.,2

CARL S. GROSZ, M.D.,3 and CLARENCE DENNIS, M.D., Ph.D*

Although there are studies in the literature having to do with subtle changes in the clotting mechanism brought about by blood loss, by hypovolemia, and by transfusion, there appears to be reinark-ahly little direct observation of the possible effect of transfusion upon the security of spontaneous physiologic control of hemorrhage. Some studies which have been performed in the laboratories of the Department of Surgery of the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center appear to justify conclusions diametrically opposed to those published by Mayo and Jenkins several years ago.4

Methods

In ten experiments rabbits were employed, in ten additional experiments dogs. Intravenously administered pento-

(’) Assistant Professor, Department of Surgery, State University of New York Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, N.Y,

U) Assistant Instructor, Department of Surgery, State University of New York Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, N.Y.

(s) Assistant Instructor, Department of Surgery, State University of New York Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, N.Y.

(4) Professor and Chairman, Department of Surgery, State University of New York Downstale Medical Center, Brooklyn, N.Y.

From the. Department of Surgery, State University of New York Downstate Medical Center, 450 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn 3, N.Y.

'Supported by research funds from the State University of New York and by grants from the United States Public Health Service. barbital sodium anesthesia was routinely used. The ultimate pattern of experiments is characterized by cannulation of either the carotid artery or the jugular vein and exposure of the left superficial femoral artery or of the left saphenous artery 3 cm. distal to the crossing of the sartorius tendon. Blood pressure was recorded routinely with a Sanborn Poly-viso unit and Statham strain gauge, with cannulation either of the opposite, femoral artery or of one carotid. The central venous pressure Was also routinely recorded through a catheter tip in the region of the right atrium. In those experiments in which blood was withdrawn or replaced, it was ordinarily removed from one of the neck vessels into a standard clinical ACD plastic transfusion donor set and re-infused from this same container. In some experiments the quantitation of blood placement was accomplished by weighing of the plastic blood bag; in others by means of a syringe in the circuit. No heparin was used at any time. Body temperature was maintained by the use of heat lamps and a thermistor placed in the rectum or vagina. Blood loss was measured by the sponge weighing technique of Wangensteen.45 The ratio of ACD solution to blood volume was that utilized clinically in the hospital.

SHAFTAN


SPONTANEOUS CONTROL OF ARTERJAL HEMORRHAGE

In certain of the experiments, an effort was made to avoid the possibility of transfusion reaction by withdrawing 1000 nil. of blood from the subject four days ahead of time. In these animals the dog was transfused with 500 ml. of homologous blood and given 500 ml. of normal saline solution simultaneously during the withdrawal of the 1(KK) ml. of blood. In certain of these experiments additional blood was withdrawn acutely by cannulation before division of the arteries bleeding from which was to be studied; in others no additional blood was so drawn acutely. In two experiments, donor blood was obtained by running homologous blood through the subject animal on the morning of study.

Hemorrhage was produced by scissor transection of the minimally exposed artery. Blood was sponged from the margins of the wound without touching the area of the severed artery.

Results

Rabbit experiments: In all ten rabbits the blood pressure upon division of the exposed left superficial femoral artery fell in a few minutes to a range between 30 and 40 mm. Hg., in association with the loss of 50 to 60 ml. of blood, before bleeding ceased. In each rabbit re-infusion of this blood was followed by recurrence of hemorrhage from the arterial section site, A representative experiment is shown in Fig. 1. This was performed after standardization of our techniques and with withdrawal of most of the expected blood loss through a catheter in the vena cava. For purposes of clarification the data are presented diagram-matically in Fig. 2. There were multiple trials of transfusion under these circumstances in each of the last two rabbits, and in each instance hemorrhage recurred. Leporine experiments were aban-

RABBIT 6.25KG.

Fig. 1.—Sanborn polyviso tracing of blood pressure records during initial intravenous cannula withdrawal of blood and following section of the superficial femoral artery.

Fast paper speed 25 mm. per second; slow paper speed 0.5 mm. per second.


SPONTANEOUS CONTROL OF ARTERIAL HEMORRHAGE


dom'd because of poor survival after nufotransfusion.

Omine experiments: in the canine experiments the effect of transfusion upon bleeding was essentially the same. Repeated trials were made with almost complete consistency. In one dog 550 ml. of blood was withdrawn through the intravenous catheter, and the blood pressure was permitted to stabilize, following which the left superficial femoral artery was divided. It required fourteen minutes for arrest of blood loss to take place; at that time, 107 ml. of blood had been lost from the wound site. The dog's blood pressure spontaneously stabilized and rose in nineteen minutes to a systolic level of 120 mm.Hg., 38 mm. Hg. above the level at which the hemorrhage had ceased. At this point, without transfusion, bleeding recommenced spontaneously (Fig. 3).

There were a dozen occasions on

Fig. 2.—Assembled data from rabbit experiment portrayed in Fig. 1. Initial withdrawal of blood into citrate solution is followed by stabilization of blood pressure at a low level. Section of the superficial femoral artery at this point results in blood loss which ceases after five minutes. After a further period of stabilization, transfusion of a small fraction of the blood loss is followed within two minutes by re-activation of hemorrhage.

which bleeding recommenced following the intravenous infusion of epinephrine. In the first of these experiments relatively large doses of the drug were em-

Blood was initially withdrawn from a jugular catheter to provide for later reaction-free transfusion. Paper speed 0.5 mm. per second.

SPONTANEOUS CONTROL OF ARTERIAL HEMORRHAGE

DURATION OF BLEEDING AFTER ARTERIOTOMY

Fig. 4.—Effect of transfusion upon the duration of hemorrhage from arterial transection. Each bar represents observations on an individual dog. Lee White clotting times were normal throughout in all dogs. In the experiment represented by the left-hand transfusion graph, blood was replaced at 1 mt. for each gram of hemorrhage. In that of the right-hand transfusion graph, blood was given to keep the systolic blood pressure above 150 nim.Hg.; after exhaustion of reserve blood, 0.9% NaCI was infused. Bleeding in both dogs stopped only after the fall of blood pressure occasioned by cessation of infusion. In the Arfonad® experiments, the dog was continuously infused to keep the systolic pressure between 50 and 60 inni.Hg.

VOLUME OF BLEEDING AFTER ARTERIOTOMY

Witnou) __         After          After Blood

pretfBOtmant              "Arfonad" Withdrawal ■

Fig. 5.—Effect of transfusion upon the volume of hemorrhage after arteriotomy in the set of experiments shown in Fig. 4.

ployed, and the blood pressure rose to levels at: least as high as the control blood pressure. In subsequent experiments, a concentration of adrenalin of one part in 10,000 was infused slowly with a syringe. In at least ten of these experiments bleeding recurred at times when the blood pressure was far below the control blood pressure.

Close scrutiny of the area of the arterial wound in the groin incision over the severed artery revealed that the control of hemorrhage was accomplished by coverage of the' severed arterial ends by blood clot, which quickly became firmly enough adherent to the adjacent structures to contain the blood loss. During such periods, arterial pulsation proximally and underlying the bulk of the clot continued to be obvious. The clot was observed to contain the hemorrhage for a period; then dissection of leaking blood occurred in new direction beneath the clot. When new hemorrhage occurred, it commonly occurred as the climax of such dissection under the clot, usually at one margin. During the hypertension pursuant upon one injection of epinephrine, hemorrhage occurred by virtue of dissection under one edge of the covering clot in an area which had hitherto been pulsating for fifty-two minutes without loss of blood to the visible surface of the clot.

On two occasions the overlying clot was carefully removed with an elTort not to disturb the divided blood vessel; on each of these occasions hemorrhage recommenced. During one experiment alone (in which Arfonad® (Trimctha-phan camphor-sulfonate) had been given) such removal of the surrounding clot revealed the end of the divided artery apparently to be plugged with thrombus.

Two experiments were undertaken with the aim of determining the effect of “adequate” transfusion upon the degree of blood loss and the duration of hemorrhage. In one of these experiments, blood was transfused at a rate of 1 ml. for each gram of blood loss measured; there was a loss of 873 grams of blood in eighty-seven minutes. Bleeding continued for an additional seventy-two

SPONTANEOUS CONTROL OF ARTERIAL HEMORRHAGE

SHAFTAN


minutes and ceased only after the total amount of bleeding had amounted to ll-1/2% of the dog’s body weight (Figs. 4 and 5). In the second experiment an effort was made to stabilize the pressure by transfusion during such blood loss. As long as the systolic blood pressure was maintained above 150 mm.Hg., bleeding continued. This animal lost 1772 grams in just over two hours. This total loss represented 12.2% of the animal’s body weight (Figs. 4 and 5).

A preliminary study of the effect of Arfonad® (trimethaphan camphor-sulfo-nate), V2 mg. per ml. in 5% glucose in distilled water given intravenously, showed that maintenance of pressures in the neighborhood of 50 mm.Hg. systolic resulted in repeated oozing and cessation of oozing over a prolonged period. On each of three occasions stabilization of blood pressure after such Arfonad administration resulted in resumption of hemorrhage.

Comment

The entire project was undertaken initially in an effort to resolve in some fashion the disputed points about management of massive hemorrhage from peptic lesions. In a continuing study started in 1953 at Kings County Hospital, a group of us has tried to determine which of three methods of management of such hemorrhage provides the greatest salvage and to do so in statistically valid fashion.3 Consideration has been\ limited to patients who have lost at least 10% of the estimated normal circulating red cell mass. Up-to-date data indicate that of 121 patients treated with extreme conservatism according to the method of A.F.R. Andresen,1 the mortality rate was 18.9%. in seventy-eight patients treated by immediate transfusion and operation after the method of J. D. Stewart,6 the mortality rate was 14.1%; the mortality rate was 13.2% among ninety-one patients treated on the selective pattern first suggested by Hoerr, Dunphy, and Gray.2 Inasmuch as this study has still provided results in which the differences are not statistically significant, it seemed wise to attempt experimental laboratory clarification. It was our feeling that if we could demonstrate either that transfusion does not lead to further hemorrhage or that it does, we could achieve some, guidance in the clinical problem.

The superficial femoral artery and the saphenous artery were selected for these studies because they were found to be of such size that hemorrhage is usually spontaneously controlled short of exsanguination and yet with profound reduction of systemic blood pressure, in these regards resembling the apparent magnitude of involved vessel commonly faced in massive gastroduodenal hemorrhage.

The observations here made suggest that, under the circumstances of these experiments at least, cessation of hemorrhage from the divided artery occurs not as a result of arterial constriction and occlusion by clot formation within the lumen, but in major measure by encasement of the severed arterial defect in a rather massive clot which accomplishes this staunching of blood flow by attachment to all of the surrounding tissues. The continuing pulsation of this clot after cessation of hemorrhage, even when watched for a period of almost an hour, without further visible accumulation of air-exposed fluid blood, would suggest that the occlusion of the arterial lumen proper following such an injury must be a relatively late development. With initial slowing of hemorrhage, the clot is soft and jelly-like, a characteristic apparent upon endeavoring to keep the field dry with a piece of

J. Cardio van* Surg. - 18

SHAFTAN


spontaneous control of arterial HEMORRHAGE

gauze sponge lightly applied around the periphery. Within ten minutes, the firmness of this clot increases palpably.

Observations made after the administration of epinephrine lend further support to the thesis that the arterial lumen does not close until long after cessation of open bleeding. Here the entire clot was observed to be pulsating just prior to the administration of epinephrine. Furthermore, if the lumen hail been filled with clot, one might reasonably have anticipated that the very vasoconstriction responsible for the elevation in blood pressure should have fixed that clot more firmly in position.

The studies here reported are but the initiation of a proposed extended study of the problem of spontaneous cessation of hemorrhage and the effect of transfusion and other factors upon that cessation. We appreciate that the clean transection of a moderate-sized artery is not a common clinical observation and that these experiments will have to be extended to include a variety of types of arterial injury, chemical and mechanical.

We are thus far at a loss to explain the contrast between our observations and those of Mayo and Jenkins.

Conclusions

  • 1. Hemorrhage resulting from complete section of a branch of the superficial femoral artery in the rabbit ami the dog was observed to cause sufficient blood loss to depress the blood pressure and occasionally io exsanguinate the animal.

  • 2. Such hemorrhage appeared to be arrested spontaneously”jointly by'enclce" sure of the area of the arterial wound in adherent clot and by reduction of the head of arterial pressure. Contraction of the divided arterial end and occlusion of the lumen by clot was observed only once in the experiments here reported.

*$■ After spontaneous cessation of hemorrhage from a divided artery, renewed hemorrhage was observed to occur upon transfusion, spontaneous stabilization of blood pressure, or administration of vasopressor. This sequence was not altered by prior administration of vasodilators.

1. After arterial division, massive continning blood loss resulted from continuing transfusion sufficient to maintain normal blood pressure or to match blood loss. Cessation of hemorrhage occurred only after cessation of blood or 0.9% NaCl infusion and subsequent blood pressure depression.

[Clarence Dennis

Dept, of Surgery Downstate Medical Center 450 Clarkson Avenue

Brooklyn 3, N.Y. (USA}]

  • 3. Karlson K, E., Enquist I. F., Dennis C... Fierst S. Results of three methods of therapy for massive gastroduodenal hemorrhage. Annals of Surg., 148, 594, 1958.

  • 4. Mayo H. W., Jr., Jenkins L. B. Blood transfusion in hemorrhage from a severed artery: experimental study. Arch, of Surg., 66, 137, 1953.

The journal

of the

South Carolina Medical Association

Volume 59


November, 1963


Number 11


EXPERIENCE WITH THE SURGICAL USE OF A

NEW ABSORBABLE HEMOSTATIC AGENT (SURGICEL ABSORBABLE HEMOSTAT)’

CHARLES B. HANNA, M. D.

W. D. HASTINGS, M. D.

B. E. HAGUE, JR, M. D.

Spartanburg, S. C.

The use of the conventional gauze sponge to control capillary and venous bleeding during surgical procedures has certain obvious disadvantages, the most important of which is that it cannot be left in situ when the bleeding occurs within an organ or body cavity. Many materials have been offered as antihemorrhagic preparations only to fall short of the ideal. It is true that some were slowly absorbed but this slow absorption rate may retard wound healing. Absorbability, tissue reactivity and hemostatic effectiveness have also been reported to vary widely.

During the past war, we have had an ^‘irgicel Absorbable Hemostat, a new truly absorbable hemostatic agent. It is an oxidized regenerated cellulose fiber 0) oniiorm diameter chemically consisting of polyanhydroglucuronic acid, a compound which is not only_highly hemostatic but can be readily absorbed by living tissue.1 It has been suggested by Hurwitt et al1 that the acid

'SURGICEL Absorbable IJemostat was supplied by

Johnson & Johnson, New Brunswick, New Jersey. nature of this compound may be responsible for its hemostatic action because of a styptic effect and its marked affinity for hemoglobin and other blood proteins. They have also suggested that the artificial clot formed when Surgicel is used, may act as a basis for the formation of the physiologic clot.

The material is pale yellow, light in weight, silky in texture and available in sterile form for clinical use. When exposed to blood, it turns dark brown as a result of the formation of hematin acid by the action of the polyanhydroglucuronic acid on hemoglobin. Since the gauze itself is acid with a pH range of 3.5 to 4.5, agents such as thrombin, if added to the gauze, would be destroyed and no advantage could be expected from their combination with oxidized regenerated cellulose.1

Materials and Methods

We have used oxidized regenerated cellulose (Surgicel) in 136 patients who under -went a variety of surgical procedures including skin grafts, thoracotomies, hemorrhoidec-

SURGICEL ABSORBABLE HEMOSTAT

tomics, tonsillectomies and cholecystectomies. The various procedures and the number of paiiont> in each group are given in the accompanying table. Their ages ranged from 2 to 72 wars and the group included both white ami Negro patients. Surgicel was used in single layers, double layers and as packing. When used on skin donor sites and recipient areas, it was cut in patterns to fit the outline of the grafts.

Case Reports

  • Case 1. Skull Fracture With Brain Injury

A 33-year-old woman was admitted to the Spartanburg General Hospital, December 26, 1961. It was reported that she had fallen down steps 48 hours before admission to the hospital and that she had been aphasic for 24 hours. She had an irregular depressed laceration measuring 21/i by 3 cm over the left parietal region of the scalp.

An x-ray film confirmed the presence of a compound comminuted depressed skull fracture. The only neurological finding was complete aphasia. A depressed skull fracture in Broca's area was the presumptive diagnosis. She was taken immediately to the operating room and, under local and Pentothal anesthesia, the wound was debrided and the depressed broken bone raised to its original position. There was loss of several fragments of severely comminuted bone. An irregular laceration of the dura and of the underlying brain was also evident. The brain bled freely and re-expanded but there was still an irregular laceration with several superficial small venules bleeding slowly. The edges of the bony depression were trimmed by the rongeur until they were smooth to the fingertip. Good hemostasis of bone was obtained with bone wax. A small piece of Surgicel was cut to correspond to the size of the depressed area of the brain (approximately 1% by 2 cm) which was generally contused and was oozing fresh dark blood. The surrounding area was thoroughly irrigated with a #14 catheter and no evidence of any epidural or dural hematoma was found.

A fresh piece of Surgicel Absorbable Hemostat was then placed over the bleeding and cut area of the brain and no effort was made to suture the dura. A small Penrose drain was placed down to the dura and the wound was closed in layers.

On the fifth day after surgery, the patient began to talk. When seen about ten months later, she still bad difficulty in phrasing some of her thoughts but had control of her tongue. In general, a good result was obtained and there was an almost norma] return of the ability to speak. At one time she had slight tingling and numbness in her right arm but this was not localized and she showed no motor disability.

Surgicel was of benefit in controlling the venous hemorrhage. There has been no evidence of any untoward reaction to it.

  • Case 2. Head Injury With Subdural Hematoma

A 1 O-year-old girl was seen immediately after an accident in which she was hit by a car. She was knocked unconscious but recovered consciousness in about 15 minutes. Skull x-ray films showed no evidence of any fracture or dislocation; however, there was subluxation of the third cervical vertebra over the fourth cervical vertebra. While the examination Wits being carried out, a generalized convulsion with dilatation of the left pupil and deviation of the eyes to the right occurred. Within 30 minutes this child was carried to the operating room. Bilateral trephination was done and revealed a subgaleal hematoma on the left and a subdural hematoma on the same side. These were evacuated. Because of the edema of the brain, the dura was not closed on the left but a Surgicel gauze pack was placed over the dural opening. A Penrose drain was placed down to the dura.

After surgery, she regained consciousness and moved all her extremities. There was a recurrence of fluid in the subgaleal region but this was gradually absorbed over a two-week period. The drain was removed on the third postoperative day and there was no evidence of any irritation or toxicity from the Surgicel pack. Five weeks after the injury, the findings of the neurological examination were normal. Case 3. Cholecystectomy.

A 35-year-old woman on examination was found to be in good health except for the presence of stones in her gall bladder.

Physical examination showed the patient to be well developed but very small. Her blood pressure was 106/70 mm Hg.

At surgery the gall bladder was found to be elongated and narrowed throughout its length and largely filled with stones. The cystic duct and cystic artery were isolated separately, doubly ligated with #0 chromic sutures near the common duct. The gall bladder was removed without difficulty. The gall bladder bed was sutured with #00 chromic. When there was a slight amount of bleeding, Surgicel gauze was placed over the gall-bladder bed and a Penrose drain was placed in the foramen of Winslow. After brief observation, all bleeding from the gall-bladder bed had stopped. No other abnormalities of the abdominal viscera were found. She was returned to her room in good condition.

This woman had a normal convalescence. The drain was shortened on the second day and removed on the fourth day after surgery with no evidence of any further drainage. The post-operative course was afebrile. The Surgicel was a good hemostatic agent and caused no untoward reaction.

  • Case 4. hemoval of a Hone Cyst.

A 26-year-old male felt a sudden pain in his upper right arm when cranking a power lawn mower. On examination (in June, 1960), he was

378


The Journal of the South Carolina Medical Association

SURGICEL ABSORBABLE IIEMOSTAT

found to have a fracture of tire proximal end of the right humerus. This subsequently proved to be pathological, since a benign aneurysmal bone cyst was present-. The pathological studies made at the time of surgery (June 6, 1960), showed the lining of the cystic structure to be composed of dense connective tissue supported by abundant collagen. The actual lining cells showed interstitial hemorrhage and organizational reaction with an occasional multinuclc-ated cell. This was thought to represent aneurysmal bone cyst. There was no evidence of malignancy.

The cyst was currcttcd and the lining removed. This left an opening 214 by 3 cm in the lateral wall of the humerus. The cyst was 8 cm in length and the full diameter of the bone. The cyst wall was treated with phenol which was then neutralized with alcohol. After it was thoroughly washed out with alcohol, Surgiccl sponge was placed over the opening in the bone. The arm was strapped to the side in a Velpeau splint. The skin healed per primttm. The patient was followed by means of x-rays and clinical examinations. The bone chips served as a stimulus for new bone formation; however, a second cyst was found proximal to the first. This second cyst was about 7’4 cm long. It was treated surgically in the same manner as the first cyst. At the time of the second operation (September 24, 1960), there was no evidence of any Surgiccl remaining at the first operative site'. New bone had replaced the defect in the wall of the humerus. The Surgicel had been completely absorbed during the time lapse between the two surgical procedures. Subsequently, the bone graft lias completely solidified and the patient has a normal range of motion of the shoulder with no evidence of recurrence of cystic formation.

  • Case 5. Hemorrhoidectomy

A 48-year-old woman presented a complaint of severe pain during bowel movements. Iler general health was good. On examination she was found to have large combined thrombosed hemorrhoids. A combined hemorrhoidectomy was done with removal of the overlying skin and mucosa as well as the hemorrhoids. Surgicel with cyclomethycaine lubricant was placed in the anal orifice to control slight capillary bleeding. Convalescence was normal. The patient later came to our office for anal dilatation. The third day after surgery the fragments of Surgicel were passed without any discomfort with her first bowel movement. Healing was satisfactory. Surgicel acted as a satisfactory hemostatic agent for the minimal venous bleeding from the anal orifice. The patient had no untoward reactions.

  • Case 6. Liver Biopsy

A 29-ycar-old nurse was admitted to the hospital with a complaint of abdominal swelling and soreness in the hepatic region. Two years previously she had been in the same hospital after a blood transfusion. At that time liver biopsy was done and confirmed the diagnosis of viral hepatitis. She responded well to a high-carbohydrate, high-vitamin diet supplemented with choline chloride; however, she later developed a recurrence of the hepatitis and was critically ill, but again responded to high-carbohydrate, high-vitamin therapy. On admission in December 1962, she had abdominal distention and the liver was six cm below the right costal margin, very tender and smooth along its lower edge. In addition, she had an abdominal fluid wave. Her skin was pale but there was no definite jaundice. Liver studies were done and the bromsulfalcm test showed 14% retention at the end of two hours. Biopsy of the enlarged liver was done under local anesthesia. A wedge of the liver was excised. A plug of Surgiccl was placed in the biopsy site and it was not necessary to suture the liver surface. The wound healed satisfactorily with no evidence of any toxicity or increased drainage as a result of the use of Surgicel. Pathological study confirmed recurrent hepatitis, virus type, with scarring.

Comments

Ajmmber of reports have appeared in the literature which attest to the valuable hemostatic property and freedom from toxicity of Surgicel Absorbable Hemostat. Our experience has brought to light nothing contrary to these reports. It has only borne out and confirmed the findings of others. To cite only one report, Miller et al.3 point out that on the basis of their experience, Surgicel is particularly useful in controlling bleeding from the brain, liver and kidney. They also call attention to the fact that this preparation also helps to avoid additional trauma to the tissues from suturing or cautery which may be required if bleeding is to be controlled by other methods.

The Surgicel acted as a splint to the grafted areas of skin and controlled the capillary bleeding of the donor site. Around bronchial stumps, in the gall-bladder bed and over the disc spaces after laminectomy, a double layer of gauze seemed to work best. With diffuse bleeding of the pleura, a single sheet of gauze markedly reduced the generalized oozing. No post-operative increase in pleural effusion was rioted. In muscle injuries, in tonsil fossae and after hemorrhoidectomies, the gauze was often used as a pad or plug. The carded fiber was also used as an anal packing after hemorrhoidectomies. The gauze and the carded fiber seemed to control oozing equally well. Both usually disappeared from the anal orifice

November, 1963

379


SURGICEL ABSORBABLE HEMOSTAT

within 48 hours. These patients had daily sitz baths.

Our preference was for the gauze type of material since it could be cut without fraying and could easily be molded to the contour of the bleeding areas or organ. During more than a year’s experience, we have observed no change in the physical properties of this material on storage and in no instance has any toxic or untoward reaction been observed. When used as an adjunct to good surgical technique, this absorbable hemostatic agent is an excellent aid.

Summary

  • 1. A new hemostatic agent, Surgicel Absorbable, Hemostat, an oxidized regenerated cellulose compound of pure uniform fibers of polyanhydroglucuronic acid, has been used successfully in 136 patients who underwent surgery of various types including cholecystectomies, skin grafts, hemorrhoidectomies, bone surgery, tonsillectomies, thoracotomies, biopsies, brain surgery and other procedures.

  • 2. This preparation was found to be an efficient, readily absorbable hemostatic agent for the control of venous and capillary oozing.

  • 3. No toxic reactions or untoward effects were seen.

  • 4. The material showed no change in its physical properties on storage.

Surgical Knife

A New York doctor has invented a surgical knife designed togiinimize or eliminate _ surgery. The knife blade is vibrated electrically at about 30,000 strokes per second, over a distance of


about five thousandths of an inch. The friction of the vibrating Made creates heat which cauterizes severed blood vessels. It is thought that the procedure .could make unnecessary veins

A n { ’rterips         ' surgeryT


Surgery, Qynecolo^r &, Obstetrics,April 1969

USE OF HYDROXYETHYL STARCH SOLUTION IN EXTENSIVE SURGICAL OPERATIONS

S. GOLLUB, M.D., DAVID CHARLES SCHECHTER, M.D., TERUO HIROSE, M.D., F.A.C.S., and CHARLES P. BAILEY, M.D., F.A.C.S., New York, New York ’

Currently in the United States, the use of nonhemic colloid solutions as plasma substitutes is practically confined to dextran, either the 70,000 or the 40,000 molecular weight preparations. These solutions fulfill most of the criteria for an ideal plasma expander. However, they do possess disadvantageous properties. These include physical instability resulting in the formation of flakes of solid material; antigenicity manifesting, itself by immediate or delayed hypersensitivity reactions of varying severity; and a clinical hemorrhagic diathesis associated with defective blood clot formation, which is apparently dose-dependent. Consequently, the search continues for more suitable materials to serve as plasma expanders.

The glucopyranose polymer, hydroxyethyl starch, made from waxy sorghum cornstarch, has been thoroughly studied pharmacologically by Murphy, Thompson (6-9), and Walton and their associates and is presently undergoing clinical appraisal. It is physically stable during storage and apparently nonantigenic. However, it has been shown to be similar to dextran in eliciting a bleeding diathesis in dogs. Clinical trial of the material to date has been cautiously limited to infusion in volunteers and in hemorrhaging accident victims.

This study was designed to determine the clinical response to hydroxy ethyl starch when given instead of dextran solution as a plasma substitute to individuals subjected to extensive surgical procedures.

From the Departments of Hematology and of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery, St. Barnabas Hospital, New York.

Supported bv Contracts No, DA-49-193-MD-2566 and NoDA-49-193-MD-2655, U. S, Army Medical Research and Development Command.

MATERIALS AND METHODS

The 26 patients in this series were adults, of both sexes, who underwent extensive pulmonary or cardiovascular surgical procedures. They were divided at randominto three groups. Those in group A received hydroxyethyl starch during an operation not requiring extracorporeal circulation; those in group B received hydroxycthyl starch during cardiopulmonary bypass, either by venoclysis or as a constituent of the pump-oxygenator prime; and those in group C received hydroxyethyl starch in the recovery room, immediately after operation.

In each of these three groups, the patients were given either 250 or 500 milliliters of hydroxyethyl starch infused over a period of 30 minutes. Blood samples were drawn immediately before infusion. In the patients in groups A and C, a subsequent specimen was taken one hour after conclusion of the infusion. The total volume of either Hartmann’s or glucose-water solution, but never colloid gr blood, administered during this interval of one and one-half hours was less than 200 milliliters. Usually, it was about 100 milliliters. In group B, the second blood specimen was obtained near the completion of the entire operation, after cessation of heart-lung bypass, when the hypocoagula-ble state from heparin had been corrected by protamine sulfate, and this neutralization had been confirmed by a protamine titration method (2).

Parameters observed in all patients during 48 hours after infusion of hydroxyethyl starch included arterial and venous blood pressure, electrocardiogram, inspection of the skin for signs of hypersensitivity reactions or unusual bleeding, examination of incisions for evidence of oozing, and urinary, output.

725


Hemoglobin, hematocrit, platelet count, Lee-White clotting time, recalcified plasmaclotting time, and thromboelastography were determined before and after hydroxyethyl starch infusion. Blood volume determinations were also made for the patients in groups A and C. The hydroxyethyl starch used throughout was 6 per cent hydroxyethyl starch in 0.9 per cent sodium chloride solution, with 0.93 degree of substitution.

RESULTS

No alterations occurred in blood pressure, pulse rate, rejpiration, or urinary output. Anaphylactic reactions or unusual bleeding were not obs rved.

The results of laboratory determinations arc presented in Tables I, II, and III. These include changes in blood volume, red blood cells, and platelet count as well as results of tests of the coagulation mechanism as reflected iii the Lee-White whole bloodcloning time, plasma recalcified elutiing time, and the thromboelastographic patterns of whole blood, it should be noted that the blood volume rose modestly in almost every patient as a result of the infusion. The net increase in blood volume generally exceeded the quantity of hydroxyethyl starch given. This finding suggests some shift of water from the extravascular to the intravascular compartment consequent to the colloid osmotic action of this solution. Similar results have been observed in our experimental investigations with this substance.

The changes in platelet count for the patients in groups A and G were negligible. In Group B—patients undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass—the drop in platelet concentration was marked. However, these decreases arc entirely explicable on the basis of the effects of extracorporeal bypass on platelets and have previously been observed in the absence of administration of colloid plasma expanders (10). These data indicate no deleterious influence on the number of platelets from hydroxyethyl starch administration. The results of the Lee-White clotting time test and the thromboelastogram also suggest that, in the amounts used, there was no adverse effect on platelet function. The findings were exceptional in Patient 12 and will subsequently be discussed.

The laboratory studies evaluating the gross coagulation mechanism indicate no appreciable changes in other parameters studied, with the exception of Patients 5 and 12. Otherwise, the studies are compatible with the interpretation that hydroxyethyl starch solution in the amounts employed did not disturb the hemostatic mechanism as gauged by the clinical or laboratory criteria.

Particular mention must be made of two patients. Patient 5 of group A exhibited grossly impaired coagulation tests in the postoperative period after receiving hydroxyethyl starch. However, at no time did she demonstrate any bleeding tendency. The laboratory values arc consistent with the presence of an anticoagulant, such as heparin. We are inclined to attribute -these results to traces of heparin in the sample. Patient 12 of Group B received 500 milliliters of hydroxycthyl starch by vcnoclysis during heart-lung bypass. During closure of the thoracotomy wound, a few hours after cessation of bypass, diffuse oozing occurred from the sternotomy, endothoracic walls, and cardiovascular incisions. Clots were present, but they were soft in consistency and .unusually friable. Diffuse oozing persisted for approximately 20 minutes, and then subsided spontaneously without any special therapy having been employed. The subsequent course of the patient was uneventful. Examination of the coagulation parameters of this patient showed a low platelet count, a slight increase in the plasma recalcified clotting time, and abnormal k and ma values in the thromboelastogram. The platelet count, again, can be explained on the basis of the cardiopulmonary bypass

Gollub etal.: hydro x'yethyl starch solution in extensive operations 727

59 58

procedure. Such values, observed in the past, were not necessarily associated with bleeding manifestations. However, the combination of essentially unaltered whole blood, and plasma-clotting times, together with impaired k and ma values of the tlirombiw astogram presents findings qualitatively similar to those observed in dogs given suilicieni hydroxyelhyl starch to deliberately produce bleeding (3). Wc suspect that 'Li- p stiem exhibited a minor transient bleeding uia thesis produced partly by the hydroxycthyl starch and partly by the lowered platelet count.

DISCUSSION

Tins study was undertaken to determine the response to hydroxyethyl starch in ci: yumstances of trauma combined with blood loss, such as the extensive types of surgical procedures cited herein. We intentionally employed smaller amounts of the agent than would ordinarily be needed, with balanced salt solution for supplementation. Patients were elderly for the most part, with multiple system derangements, and had been receiving complex medication regimens for long periods* Obviously, such patients are not comparable to healthy young volunteers or accident victims. The results indicate that the hydroxyethyl starch solution was well tolerated in all but one patient. This individual transiently exhibited a minor hemorrhagic diathesis qualitatively similar to that observed in experimental animals subsequent to infusion of much larger quantities of the same solution or dextran. Bleeding in this single patient was also complicated by the low platelet count.

Jjallingcr and his associates administered as much as 1,500 milliliters of hydroxyethyl starch in patients not operated upon without encountering any adverse effects, It should be pointed out, however, that their patients did i.ut have the significant challenge to heiiKstatic function as did those of our series. Lee and his associates found “prolongation of the partial thromboplastin time -.i three patients and a minimal depression of fibrinogen in one patient. These ch; ages were temporary. None were felt to be' of clmijWil significance and were similar to so .lies utadc with 6 per cent dextran.”

In general, this investigation confirms our cxr„-riciicc with animal experimentation employing hydroxyethyl starch as a plasma expander in. that the results are quite similar to ihosc obtained with dextran, it would seem 11.an Jie new plasma expander, by-droxyetUyl starch, can be employed in the same clinical circumstances in which dextran would be indicated. The potential hazard of inducing a bleeding diathesis with hydroxyethyl starch appears likewise to be the same as that when using dextran. The treatment of this particular complication is entirely empiric to date.

SUMMARY

The new plasma expander, hydroxyethyl starch., was administered to 26 patients undergoing extensive pulmonary or cardio- ijy vascular surgery. In all but one patient, clinical and laboratory observations indicated the material to be well tolerated and >/ without significant side-effects. Hemostasis was unimpaired- One patient, who had been subjected to extracorporeal circulation, exhibited a minor, temporary bleeding defect, possibly related to the starch infusion.

A blood substitute that some day rrtay

aid surgeons perloiming tlclicate operations has been developed liyllr. Lelaml (1, Clark, fr., of the IJnirCTMiyoTtinun-nati Medical Center.

—wmrmhBiia—■—■riJ—^MCTi»uwM«<nTwwwi«»Tixrrmrrwi»cBnp*nre.li*aniTi^a^Jg>.,<_-, been used to prime heArt-lung machines and to teplace St) percent of an animal's blood supply during open-heart sur^en . After operations, normal blood supply is restored.
