TODAY'S HEALTH/NOV. 1969

Artificial

blood

sustains

BOSTON (AP> - After 35 rats survived an experiment in which jail their blood was replaced bv an artificial substance, Harvard University researchers have begun tests on monkeys and hope to extend the benefits to man.

If the work is successful, the substance could be used to preserve organs for transplants and to provide an alternative for patients who have built up a reaction to ordinary blood transfusions. Dr. Robert Geyer, the chief researcher, said yesterday.

The breakthrough, which came late last fall? had eluded the specialists for several years.

Dr. Geyer said that the closer complete transfer is approached, the more difficult the task becomes.

“TWO YEARS ago we were able to do S3 per” cerA” he said. “By jugging the ingredients — in amounts and molecular characteristics — we finally were able to achieve 100 per cent."

The blood replacement is made up of a class of compounds called fluorocarbons and is a liquid that can be milky white to dishwater grey to clear. Dr. Geyer said.

The important feature, he added, is that it carries oxygen to an organism’s cells, a job previously done only by red blood cells.

“We were almost convinced as recently as last spring that our substance would have to have at least a few red blood cells,” Dr. Geyer said, but the chemical used for the rats was totally artificial.

SINCE a body continues to produce new red blood cells all the time, it is important that they be able to mix with the artificial substance, which was the case with the rats.

Since the blood replace-ihen~C~~the rats have survived' *arid gradual!? replaced ~tEe s u b s t a n c e with their own blood.

The change to monkeys will provide more answers on the usefullness of the preparation to humans.

In the coming year the researchers plan to begin seeing if replacing blood in rats afflicted with leukemia helps to cure the disease.

Dr. Geyer said no human experiments are planned at this time, but it is hoped that “within several years” the preparation, or one like it, will be able to keep various human organs alive for days and weeks for transplants.

The Spectator, Thursday, January 4, 1973 47

U8


3SS


Replacement of Operative Blood Loss of More Than 1 Liter With Hartmann’s Solution

Benjamin Rigor, MD; Peter Bosomworlh, MD; and Benjamin F. Rush, Jr., MD

A hundred patients each lost over 1,000 ml of blood while undergoing surgery and received two to three times that volume of Hartmann's solution. Postoperative mortality and morbidity were not affected by the lack of blood in the replacement regimen. Age group and physical condition of these patients were representative of the hospital population,, and patients over 60 years old in American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) risk classifications 3 and 4 were included. Eighty-six percent of the group lost from 1 to 1.5 liters of blood; only 14% lost a larger amount. Serum electrolyte levels were unaffected. Hematocrit readings and total protein concentrations decreased but remained within physiologic limits. No unexpected complications were encountered in the postoperative period, and hospitalization was not prolonged. Only four patients required subsequent transfusions postoperativeiy.

ik (T ubstantial blood losses can be effectively replaced with balanced saline solutions if these solutions are given in sufficient quantity. Evidence favoring this proposition is both experimental1'0 and clinical.7'ia During the past two years, we have used increasing quantities of balanced saline solution for blood replacement. Our clinical records in. <Jdcate that in the past year, 100 patients who lost ^more,thaTa„jiter_plElppd_dunnEkrgaxJia±L^ loss totally replaced with Hartmann’s solution. This communication reviews the effect of this regimen on morbidity, mortality, and serum changes.

Methods

All patients operated upon between March 1, From the departments o£ anesthesiology and surgery, University of Kentucky College of Medicine, Lexington.

Reprint requests to 800 Rose St, Lexington, Ky 40506.

1966, and Feb 28, 1967, having blood losses in excess of 1,000 ml and fluid substitution with Hartmann’s solution alone were included in the study. One liter of this solution was given in the first hour of operation without regard to blood loss, and each milliliter of blood loss was replaced with 2 to 3 ml of this solution. Blood loss was determined by weighing sponges and adding this to the observed loss in the suction bottle. All patients came to surgery with a hematocrit reading of 30% or better. The patient’s physical status was classified prior to operation by the anesthesiologist according to thf American Society of Anesthesiologists’ (ASA) standard classification. Values for serum electrolytes, plasma proteins levels, whole blood values, hematocrit, and hemoglobin were determined for most, but not ail, patients before and after surgery.

Results

All major types of operation were performed (TaIHTT)7~Tut only procedures in whicE large., amounts of BToocT were lost were~mcTucTecT"in the

nnymwiii MlIMM IM un rrw*—

study, as indicated by the classification of the gen-i^Imiiiiiii Wn '   I „ iw..nmnu—1—iw ■■ 1.1111111M £ yf»»^milllll to H ■■mpUiimiiMyHH ■■ niMilWm1 ■ r nr H eral surgical procedures in Table 2. d otal gastrectomy, hemipelvectomy, bilateral radical neck dissection, and abdominal permeal resections were

I— —JTMMT-jaew.-wjn-urnr»m*lm iniiiii'Minin’**«M«rTnrirMm»aB«iMMU■ accomplished without blood replacement with fluids ■ i.i*im                                                                            n imi ii min ii MUTI i Un    

other than Hartmann s solution. All age groups were represented except children less than 15 years old, in whom losses of more than a liter of blood represented a much larger proportion of the blood volume than in adults. Twenty-three percent of the patients were over 60 years of age, and 61 % over 40, which reflects the average distribution of patients in surgery at our institution (Table 3).

’■‘Died 14 days postoperatively.


The use of Hartmann’s solution was not restricted to patients who were considered good risks (Table 4); 88% of those treated were fair to poor risks according to the ASA risk classification (classes 2, 3, and 4).

With four exceptions, the blood loss permitted without replacement ranged from 1,000 to 2,000 ml (Table 5), with the largest group (86%) having a loss ranging from 1,000 to 1,500 mi. Despite the unreplaced blood loss, the patients did well postopera-tively. Sixty-two percent were capable of leaving the hospital by the end of the first week, and 92% by the end of the second week. Only four patients were given subsequent blood transfusions, three because of overt postoperative blood loss, and one because of hypotension (blood pressure was 68/0 mm Hg). Average urinary output was excellent: 2,100 ml (range, 835 to 3,670 ml) in the first 24 hours after operation, and 2,500 ml (range, 1,100 to 4,120 ml) in the



second 24 hours. No episodes of anuria or oliguria were encountered.

Twenty-two postoperative complications were encountered (Table 6), ranging from mild to severe. There was only one postoperative death; a patient with spongioblastoma died on the 14th postoperative day with a perforated Cushing’s ulcer. Hospitalization did not appear prolonged for patients with operations of this magnitude (Table 7).

Laboratory observations indicated a slow fall of hemoglobin and hematocrit values (Fig 1) as late as 72 hours postoperatively, but the mean drop was within a restricted range, so that oxygen carrying capacity was still adequate. Total protein concentrations also fell postoperatively (Table 8), but began to recover toward normal values by the third postoperative day. Serum sodium, potassium, carbon dioxide, and chloride levels remained within physiologic limits (Fig 2).

Comment


1. Changes in hematocrit and hemoglobin values following replacement of blood less with Hartmann’s solution (vertical bars signify standard deviation)..


Replacement of the blood lost by these 100 patients with whole blood would require 258 units. The risk of transfusion reactions, contaminated


150


IAMA CrtK cz into ~ W«< on-5 c


blood, allergic reactions. and viral hepatitis attending this many transfusions is significant. Assuming that a risk of one death from transfusion complications per 1,000 transfusions and an incidence of 2% nonfaial transfusion complications would occur, we conclude that five patients were spared complications and a 26% possibility of at least one death occurring was avoided.

There are abundant experimental data indicating the effectiveness of balanced saline solutions in maintaining blood pressure following hemorrhage, when such solutions are given in sufficient amounts.'"1 In our laboratory, replacement of one third of the blood volume in dogs with Hartmann’s solution sustains the animals very well indefinitely, and replacement of one half of the blood volume is tolerated for at least 24 hours.5 This solution was superior to dextran 70, (Macrodex) levarterenol (norepinephrine) bitartrate, phenoxybenzamine hydrochloride (Dibenzyline), and even whole blood in resuscitating animals in hemorrhagic shock.11 Some of these phenomena may be explained by Shires'" theories concerning the loss of extracellular fluid during operative stress and hemorrhagic shock.

Despite the persistent tradition that blood is the only effective replacement for blood loss, the practice of using saline solutions for part or all of blood suostitution has gained ground m many centers. ' Clinical studies performed as early as I9601’ indicated that patients supported with infusions of saline solutions alone tolerated subtotal gastrectomy well. Cooley et al" and Gollub and Bailey" reported the feasibility of using saTme“soKitions alone during major cardiac operations when this was required by Jehovah's tVitnesses. Trudnowski11 noied that liberal use of balanced saline solutions conserved a total of 750 ml of bloocTper patient m major operations, and Boba7 observed the usefulness of balanced saline solutions in supporting patients in a diverse' group umlergomg 26 major operations where blood transfusions would normal-

■«- --T—ri-M-r ■ UM),,—nwn—><j                  T < n i>ini|i|ii                      M nMIWagt—riTHOC*

Iv be used.

The major objections to the clinical use of buffered saline solution as a substitute for blood loss is the dilution of hemoglobin and protein that results. However, saline replacement of blood losses in the range suffered by these patients rarely reduced serum protein or hematocrit values below physiologic limits. Hematocrit readings between

Table 8

.—Changes in

Serum

Proteins

Time (hr)

(gm/100 ml)     (gm/100 ml>

Prenperative

6,85 ±-

,28% and 40% are about equally efficient in trans-*porting~^xygen~to~tKe* cell,^ and dogs tolerate hemorrhagic shock equally well when they have hematocrit readings within this range. They are less tolerant to shock when they have readings either above 40% or below 28%.'" Total protein levels in the range found in these patients are well tolerated by dogs when plasma proteins are removed by plasmapheresis.17 In addition, the protein level rises rapidly after dilution, with complete return to normal in 48 to 72 hours, as observed in normal human volunteers by Moore?”

bsbv-53

PLASMA-VOLUME REPLACEMENT WITH HYDROXYETHYL STARCH

Britain is reasonably well served with bloodtransfusion services, and for restoring blood and plasma volume the fluids commonly used are stored blood and plasma. Though dextran is often given, especially in an emergency, few will have experience with other plasma substitutes like hydroxyeshyl starch or modified gelatin derivatives. Hydroxyethyl starch has ajiumber of advantages. Supplied as a 6% solution in saline, it is comparatively cheap, and it is said to be reproducible in quality and stable on long storage. It has a molecular weight of about 400,000 and it is said to persist longer in the blood than other plasma substitutes—usually for about two weeks. This may or may not be desirable, according to clinical and other circumstances, but its persistence raises questions concerning long-term incorporation in cells and tissues. It is prepared from waxy sorghum starch, an amylopectin which is treated with ethylene oxide, thereby introducing hydroxyethyl groups.

In 1956 Ballinger et al.1 reported that hydroxyethyl starch was as effective as dextran for treating haemorrhagic shock in dogs, and Solanke 11 12 found that it had no adverse effects when given intravenously to patients. Recently Solanke et al.13 compared the plasma-volume expansion produced in four groups of volunteer

THE LANCET, JULY 17, 1971              ,47

patients given 500 ml. of hydroxyethyl starch, dextran-70, plasma, or a commercial gelatin derivative (‘ Htem-accel ’). Plasma volume was measured by the dyedilution method, using T-1824 (Evans blue) as a tracer as soon as possible before and after the infusion. The plasma-volume expansion with dextran, plasma, and hsemaccel were about the same and similar in volume to the amount infused, but that obtained with hydroxyethyl starch was on the average more than twice the volume given. This extra effect must be due to the drawing of fluid into the bloodstream, and it is reminiscent of the immediate results after infusion of hyperosmolar dextran-40. The osmolarity of 6% hydroxyethyl starch is not stated, but presumably it too is hyperosmolar, though, unlike dextran-40, it is not excreted rapidly in the urine. Information on the duration of the plasma-volume expansion withhydroxy-ethyl starch in normovolamic and hypovolaemic states is required. The Committee on Safety of Drugs might also state any potential hazards, since hydroxyethyl starch is not yet approved for clinical use in the United States.14

Vascular Surgery in

Jehovah’s Witnesses

C. Wilton Simmons, Jr., MD; Bruno J. Messmer, MD; Grady L. Hallman, MD; and Denton A. Cooley, MD


Twenty Jehovah's Witnesses (age range: 17 months to 76 years) ! underwent central or peripheral vascular surgery for congenital

* । or acquired disease. Two patients died: one (74 years old) from myocardial infarction, the other after a subsequent open heart operation. Hemoglobin concentration and hematocrit readings were not low enough in any patient to urge blood transfusion. Hospital con-

। valescence averaged one week. Overall results compared favorably

J [ with results in other patients, indicating that a good outcome can be i obtained in vascular surgery without blood transfusion.


PATIENTS WHO belong to the religious sect of Jehovah’s Witnesses refuse to undergo any surgical procedure requiring blood transfusion, because it is forbidden by their literal interpretation of Bible passages /$• such as Acts 20,29, which charge those believing in God “to abstain from . . . blood.” The development of a hemodilution technique for cardiopulmonary bypass has allowed such patients to undergo open heart surgery without challenging their religious convictions; and since 1964, open heart operations in Je-

From the Texas Heart Institute and St. Luke’s and Texas Children’s hospitals, Houston.

Reprint requests io 6621 Fannin St, Houston 77025 (Dr. Cooley).

hovah’s Witnesses have been extensively reported.1'9 Relatively little information exists, however, on other procedures carried out in mem-zbers of this faith. Major noncardiac procedures such as pulmonary re-,/! sections, gastric surgery, and recto-। sigmoid resections have been suc-: cessfully performed in this center as I well as various vascular operations.

In this paper we detail our experience with Jehovah’s Witnesses who underwent vascular procedures without blood transfusion.

Clinical Materia'

A total of 20 Jehovah’s Witnesses have undergone central vascular or peripheral vascular surgery in this institution since 1964. The patients ranged in age fr 17 months to 76 years. Seven patients had congenital vascular disease (Table 1). Three children, each 21/? years of age, ancf one 28-year-old woman underwent division and suture of patent ductus arteriosus. Coarctation of the aorta was resected in two other children. The youngest patient in the series, an infant of 17 months, had excision of an aneurysm of the left axillary artery that had resulted from giant cell arteries.

Among the 13 patients with acquired vascular disease (Table 1) five had resection of an aneurysm of the abdominal aorta. One of these five patients also received an aorto-bilateral popliteal bypass graft, and another underwent concomitant closure of a large arteriovenous fistula between the aneurysm and the left renal vein which had caused severe left ventricular failure.7 Aortofemor-al bypass procedures were performed in three cases; aortorenal, in one. The oldest patient (76 years) received a bilateral femoral-popliteal bypass graft. One patient underwent bilateral thoracic sympathectomy with periaortic neurectomy for intractable angina pectoris, and another underwent bilateral transfemoral embolectomy. Thrombectomy of the superior vena cava was performed in a patient who had had occlusion following transvenous insertion of a pacemaker electrode.

During surgery 16 patienfs received 5% dextrose in lactated Rin-

1032 JAMA, Aug 10, 1970 ° Vol 213, No 6 O


Vascular Surgery—Simmons et al


Table 1.—Vascular Operations Performed in 20 Jehovah's Witnesses

For Congenital Vascular Anomaly

Division and suture PDA’

Resection of coarctation aorta

Resection of aneurysm of left axillary artery

Subtotal

tYo. of Patients

4

2

For Acquired Vascular Disease Resection of abdominal aortic aneurysm

3

Resection of abdominal aortic aneurysm and closure of AV fistula               '

a

Resection of abdominal aortic aneurysm and aortobilateral popliteal bypass

i

Aortofemoral bypass

3

Bilateral femoral-popliteal bypass

1

Aortorenal bypass

1

Bilateral thoracic sympathectomy and periaortic neurectomy

1

Bilateral transfemcral embolectomy

1

Thrombectomy of superior vena cava

1

Subtotal

13

Total

.              20

"PDA signifies patent ductus arteriosus.


ger’s solution in amounts ranging from 500 ml to 5,500 ml. A combination of 5% dextrose in lactated Ringer’s solution and 5% dextrose in water was administered in one case, 5% dextrose in lactated Ringer’s solution and dextran 75 (Dextran 6%) solution in another, and 5% dextrose in lactated Ringer’s solution and a 10% dextran 40 (Dextran 10%) solution in still another. One patient received 280 ml of 5% dextrose in 0.25N saline solution only.

Results

Eighteen of the 20 patients in the series survived operation, and all but one of these 18 recovered without postoperative complications. Unilateral pleural effusion developed on the sixth postoperative day in a 72-year-old woman who had undergone thrombectomy for obstruction of the superior vena cava, but this cleared by the time of hospital discharge.

Two patients died. One was a 74-year-old man who had resection of an aneurysm of the abdominal aorta and an aortobilateral popliteal bypass procedure. Hypotension devel- . oped in this patient on the first postoperative day, and two days after operation, he sustained a cardiac arrest from which he could not be resuscitated. Autopsy showed an acute myocardial infarction, hypertrophy of the left ventricle, severe coronary arteriosclerosis, and bilateral nephrosclerosis, in addition to generalized atherosclerosis of the great vessels and occlusion of the iliac and femoral arteries.

The other death occurred in a 52-year-old man who had undergone bilateral transfemoral embolectomy and then the next day had had a stenotic mitral valve replaced under cardiopulmonary bypass. Initial response was good, but severe anemia and jaundice developed later in the postoperative period. The patient’s heart rate ranged between 88 and 120 beats per minute, and there were no premature ventricular contractions. A sudden cardiac arrest on the eighth postoperative day caused his death. No autopsy was performed.

Hemoglobin concentration and hematocrit values obtained in 19 of the 20 patients averaged 13.3 gm/100 mi and 39.7%, respectively, upon admission to the hospital, and 12.8 gm/ 100 ml and 38.4% in the immediate postoperative period (one to three hours after operation). Hemoglobin concentration was decreased after operation in 11 patients, remained the same in 2, and in 6 cases was increased immediately after operation but subsequently fell below the preoperative value. In ten patients determinations were made again 24 hours after operation and averaged 12.8 gm/100 ml for hemoglobin concentration and 38.6% for hematocrit reading. Sporadic determinations were made between the first and sixth postoperative days but did not show further significant decrease in blood values. Table 2 shows a typical course of hemoglobin and hematocrit value changes in a patient who underwent resection of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The estimated blood loss during surgery was 400 ml. This patient received 1,900 ml of 5% dextrose in lactated Ringer’s solution intravenously during the procedure, and 4,440 ml of 5% dextrose in 0.25N saline solution within the first 48 hours after surgery. There was a progressive decrease in hemoglobin and hematocrit values until the fourth postoperative day when both values stabilized. The patient was discharged six days after operation.

Hospital convalescence for this series of patients ranged from 4 to 12 days and averaged about one week.

Comment

Vascular surgery is routinely performed in this hospital without blood transfusion unless specifically indicated. However, since blood loss in most vascular procedures—especially those involving the aorta and its larger branches—may be unexpectedly excessive and can occur

Table 2.—Hemoglobin and Hematocrit Values in a Jehovah's Witness*

Hemoglobin, gm/100 ml

Hematocrit, %

values

16

48

Postoperative values

2 hr

15.4

46

I day

14.6

44

2 days

14.4

43

13.4

40

4 days

12.4

38

5 days

37

6 days

12.2

37

"Before and after undergoing resection of an abdomino! aortic aneurysm.

Table 3.—Hemoglobin and Hematocrit Values in a Jehovah’s Witness Undergoing Resection of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm

Preoperative r

Values

2 hr

1 day

Postoperative Values 2 days 3 days 4 days

5 days

6 days

Hemoglobin

16

15.4

14.6

14.4       13.4       12.4

12.4

12.2

Hematocrit

48

46

44

43       40       38

37

37


suddenly, all patients undergoing such operations are typed and crossmatched for af-least 2 units of blood which, if needed, are instantly available.

The Jehovah’s Witness, whose beliefs bind the surgeon to withhold blood transfusion under any circumstances, undergoes vascular surgery with an added risk, particularly if the patient is a small child in whom even minimal blood loss represents a considerable portion of the total blood volume. If significant amounts of blood are lost at operation they cannot be restored; consequently, vascular operations in these patients demand utmost attention to technical detail.

■ Rapid and meticulous hemostasis ■ is, of course, a fundamental require

.................................................................. I n i in all vascular procedures in

  • 1 Jehovah’s witnesses.

In patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm minimal dissection of the proximal aorta is advisable before the proximal clamp is placed. No attempt should be made to excise the aneurysm. The iliac arteries should be clamped without circumferential dissection, since this could injure the iliac veins. Ligature of the inferior mesenteric artery before opening the aneurysm is advantageous if it can be done without extensive dissection; otherwise, the orifice should be closed from the inside with a suture, immediately after opening the aneurysm. Blood loss from the lumbar arteries is usually slight after removal of the thrombotic and atherosclerotic material from within the lumen. Each bleeding orifice of a lumbar artery is oversewn with a single figure-of-eight suture starting at the proximal end. After the graft is anastomosed to the proximal aortic and distal iliac stumps, little of the aneurysmal sac need be excised. It is simply sutured over the graft.

When a vascular prosthesis must be inserted below the diaphragm, it is our usual policy to employ knitted Dacron grafts which are preclotted to minimize immediate blood loss after removal of vascular clamps. In Jehovah’s Witnesses, however, we favor woven grafts since their lower porosity eliminates initial blood loss through the graft.

Results in this series of Jehovah’s Witnesses undergoing major vascular surgery compare favorably with results in other patients who receive similar operations. Whether in adults or children, hemoglobin and hematocrit values did not fflU tp levels that would indicate blood transfusion. Replacement of immediate blood loss with 5% dextrose in lactated Ringer’s solution and administration of the same fluid during the early postoperative period was enough to keep the circulation stable. ,-Lactated Ringer’s solution is prefer-jable to dextran 40, which may entourage diffuse capillary bleeding due to peripheral vasodilation, hemodilution, lowered blood viscosity, and prevention of erythrocyte aggregation.

All but two patients survived operation, enjoyed prompt recovery, and left the hospital an average of one week after surgery. No complications could be attributed to the nonrestored blood loss after the vascular procedure. One of the patients who died sustained a sudden cardiac arrest eight days after mitral valve replacement which was performed the day after bilateral femoral embolectomy. This death was related to the open heart procedure rather than to the vascular operation. Immediate postoperative values for hemoglobin concentration and hematocrit reading were within reasonable levels (11.0% and 33.5% respectively) in the 74-year-old patient who died from acute myocardial infarction two days after resection of an abdominal

aortic aneurysm. Whether myocardial infarction occurred as a chance event or was precipitated by a combination of surgical stress, generalized cardiovascular disease, and advanced age is unknown.

Since it is our policy to avoid the use of blood tranfusion whenever ' possible in all operations,2’a the pas w^° a Jehovafi’s Witness •>'| does not really represent a special j case; and we can comply with ms [.demands without undue concern. We /have found that blood tranfusion is 1 not a necessary accompaniment to A vascular surgery, but, indeed has cer-j tain disadvantages such as the risk I of hepatitis. Thus, blood is used cautiously during and after operations in our institution, and patients who refuse to accept blood can usually undergo major operations without prohibitive risk and enjoy favorable postoperative results.

Nonproprietary and Trade Names of Drugs

Dextran 40—Gentran 40, LMD, Rheoma-crodex, Rheotran.

Dextran 75—Dextran 6%, Gentran 75.

COMPLICATIONS IN

SURGERY AND

THEIR MANAGEMENT

Edited by

CURTIS P, ARTZ, M.D., F.A.C.S.

Associate Professor of Surgery of the University of Mississippi

JAMES D. HARDY, M.D., F.A.C.S.

Professor and Chairman of the Department of Surgery of the University of Mississippi

With Contributions by Sixty-Nine Authorities

Edition of i960

W. B . SAUNDERS COMPANY7

PHILADELPHIA


LONDON


Chapter 5

COMPLICATIONS OF BLOOD TRANSFUSIONS

By Ben J. Wilson

Ben J. Wilson is a Hoosier, educated at Indiana University and trained in surgery at Southwestern Medical School. Upon the resignation of his former teacher, Dr. Carl Moyer, he assumed the duties of Professor of Surgery and Chairman of the Department at Southwestern. In spite of his heavy administrative load, he has found time to carry out a                 '

fruitful program of research in the fields of electrolyte balance and shock.

A surgical procedure carries the risk of doing harm while intending to benefit; similarly the therapeutic procedure of transfusing whole blood may do harm— often only annoying harm—may sometimes induce a serious illness, and occasionally is fatal. Before blood is given, the chance of injury must be weighed in the same manner that one assesses operative risk. The complications of transfusion that one should consider in his assessment of risk will vary according to the urgency of need for blood. lATen the clinical circumstances do not demand that blood be given, the specter of transfusion complications looms greater than when the patient’s survival depends upon his receiving blood.

If a transfusion is mandatory, then, by definition, one cannot consider the risks of the therapy, but simply must be prepared to look for complications so that their presence can be detected and treatment, if any, can be begun. But knowing what the complications of transfusion are, and their relative frequency of occurrence, one may change his definition of states in which transfusion is mandatory.

The specific complications that attend the infusion of homologous blood are briefly described below relative to incidence of occurrence, cause, manifestations and management. At the end of the discussion of complications an attempt is made to quantitate the cumulative mortality occurring annually in the. United States as a result of 4.5 to 5 million blood transfusions given to more than 2 million recipients. In view of the frightening revelation of transfusion morbidity, a short section has been added in which some commonly used indications for blood transfusion in surgical patients are critically examined.

IMMEDIATE COMPLICATIONS INCIDENT TO PROPERTIES OF BLOOD

HEMOLYTIC REACTION

A hemolytic transfusion reaction may be defined as the occurrence of an increased

rate of destruction of red cells of the donor or recipient as a consequence of blood transfusion. The antibodies producing hemolytic reaction may be natural (ABO) or acquired (Kell, Duffy, Rh, Lewis, and many others), and the titer of the culpable isoantibodies which react with the red cell antigens determines in part the rate of red cell destruction that follows transfusion.

69


When hemolysis is relatively slow, there may be few manifestations, perhaps only jaundice. Alarming symptoms and signs usually attend rapid hemolysis in a conscious person; these are chills, fever, back pain, anxiety, tachypnea, occasionally with cyanosis, hemoglobinemia and hemoglobinuria. A bleeding tendency develops in about 30 per cent of persons with a hemolytic transfusion reaction, and peripheral vascular collapse sometimes attends major reactions. All symptoms are masked in the anesthetized patient even though incompatible blood has been given. A reaction may not be detected during an operation unless it is recognized.that generalized bleeding or shock may be a manifestation of a transfusion reaction. Hemoglobinemia can be found immediately after a major hemolytic reaction to blood transfusion, but hyperbilirubinemia does not appear for three to six hours. Anemia tends to develop within several hours or days, but this finding cannot be used for immediate confirmation of diagnosis. About 80 to 90 per cent of persons who have had a hemolytic reaction will suffer renal insufficiency.14

The diagnosis of a hemolytic transfusion reaction consists in the demonstration of increased destruction of red cells. The increased destruction may proceed at rates detectable only by measuring a shortened life span of red cells. However, the more dangerous hemolytic reactions are attended by rapid rates of red cell breakdown and may be detected by obtaining a sample of venous blood from the patient and performing the following tests recommended by Mollison:12

(a) Observe the plasma for brown or pink discoloration which indicates the presence of liberated hemoglobin in excess of 25 mg. per 100 ml. Concentrations less than this require that a colorimetric determination be used to quantitate the amount of free hemoglobin. All precautions to prevent hemolysis must be observed when obtaining the blood sample: viz., use a clean dry syringe and a large-bore needle (no. 18 or 20), remove the needle before transferring blood into the citrate test tube, avoid drying or clotting of blood on the sides of the syringe or tube, avoid vigorous agitation of the blood sample, but gently mix the blood with anticoagulant before centrifugation.

If the sample is obtained more than twelve hours after the transfusion, hemoglobinemia may not be present even though a hemolytic reaction did occur, since the free hemoglobin may have been cleared. Methemalbumin may still be present, however, and can be detected spectroscopically by Schumm's test.® A positive test indicates that a hemolytic reaction has taken place.

(5) Serum bilirubin concentrations may have risen three to six hours after a hemolytic reaction so that the plasma is grossly icteric. If not, the van den Bergh test may reveal an increase in the indirect bilirubin.

  • (c) Repeat the typing procedures on the recipient and perform a direct Coombs test. This will probably be positive if more than 100 ml. of incompatible blood was given to the patient, if the donor’s plasma contained an antibody or if a group O donor’s plasma contained an antibody that destroyed the recipient’s cells.

If a sample of donor blood can be obtained, repeat the typing procedures and cross-match, using the indirect antiglobulin test.

  • (d) Differential agglutinations to'determine donor cell survival may be the only means of establishing whether a hemolytic

    CAB-22


Complications of Blood Transfusions

71


transfusion reaction occurred several days earlier.

A sample of urine obtained by catheterization may reveal red or brown discoloration due to hemoglobinuria, but since hemoglobinuria may be slight and of short duration, it is often not detected. Hemosiderinuria is regularly found, provided the plasma hemoglobin concentration exceeds 25 mg. per 100 mil®'Blue particles indicate a positive test when the resuspended sediment of centrifuged urine is mixed with an equal volume of 5 per cent hydrochloric acid and 0.5 ml. of 10 per cent potassium ferrocyanide in water.

Recipients who are particularly likely to have a hemolytic reaction are those who have had previous blood transfusions, parous women with a history of hemolytic disease of the baby, and patients with hemolytic anemia..

The frequency of occurrence of hemolytic reaction is estimated by DeGowin to be 1 to 5 per 1000 transfusions. Dame-shek stated that at least 1 in 500 transfusions is followed by a reaction of incompatibility. The incidence increases as human error increases. Technicians who are infrequently engaged in typing and cross-matching procedures are more likely to make mistakes which lead to tire transfusion of incompatible blood. Reactions are occasionally unrecognized, and reports of reactions are often incomplete. A national average of 5 hemolytic reactions per 1000 transfusions probably reflects more nearly the actual incidence of this dangerous complication than does Dameshek’s estimate of 2 per 1000 which obtains in blood banks that are well supervised, where many safeguards are practiced and where data are kept to permit an accurate accounting of reaction rates. Based on an incidence of 3 per 1000 and on 4.5 million transfusions given in one year, the number of hemolytic reactions would be 13,500 annually. By using a reported mortality for hemolytic transfusion reactions of 50 per cent, the estimated yearly toll is the loss of about 6750 lives from this one complication of whole blood transfusion.

Since definitive treatment for hemolytic transfusion reactions is not known, recog-■nition of a reaction is of vital importance so that the transfusion can be stopped immediately. The most common fatal complication, renal damage, is roughly a function of the volume of ^incompatible blood received. Except in the unconscious or anesthetized person, most hemolytic reactions will be manifest during infusion of the first 50 to 100 ml. of blood. It is therefore possible to reduce the number of fatal transfusion reactions by withholding the infusion of whole blood during anesthesia and by careful observation of conscious patients while the first 50 to 100 ml. of blood is injected.

Other factors influence the severity of renal injury that follows hemolytic reactions; e.g. the state of water lack or of extracellular fluid deficiency will exaggerate the injury and contribute to the development of acute renal insufficiency. Intense renal vasoconstriction, high hematocrit level and low blood pressure are other factors that have been shown to adversely affect renal function and recovery from hemolytic states. The therapeutic corollary is that an infusion of glucose in water should be started after a hemolytic transfusion as soon as the blood is discontinued, provided a water deficit is thought to exist. If no water deficit is present, a balanced salt solution should be injected intravenously, since it will tend to alleviate hypovolemia, lessen the intensity of vasoconstriction and reduce the hematocrit level.

In most instances of refractory renal insufficiency observed by the author that have followed hemolytic transfusion reactions, blood had been given during the. emergency situation to the exclusion of electrolyte solutions to combat an existing hypotension or hypovolemia. In these in-

72


Complications of Blood Transfusions

stances a high hematocrit level ensued, resulting in severe renal tubular injury. It is likely that the incidence of acute renal insufficiency following hemolytic reactions will be reduced if water and salt deficits are promptly made up and if buffered sodium solutions are used to correct hypovolemia immediately after a hemolytic reaction. If there is no urine flow in response to water or saline infusion, treatment of the subsequent anuric phase is as discussed in Chapter 8.

There is some evidence to suggest that a renal protective effect might be gained by the use of a ganglionic or adrenergic blocking agent to alleviate the renal vasoconstriction. But the safety to the patient and efficacy of the treatment are not sufficiently established to warrant its clinical use.

High fever attending hemolytic transfusion reactions should be lowered by antipyretics and physical cooling measures. Dyspnea, especially when attended by cyanosis, requires intermittent positive pressure breathing with oxygen.

ALLERGIC REACTIONS

The incidence of allergic reactions varies from 1 to 3 per cent. Urticaria is the usual manifestation and may present as a few discrete wheals which do not itch or as giant erythematous wheals with intense itching. Occasionally severe asthma may follow transfusion (one to two persons per thousand), and in other instances facial and laryngeal edema may cause serious respiratory distress. Some reactions, especially in recipients with a history of allergy, are extremely dangerous and are attended by hypotension, cyanosis, tachycardia, facial edema and bronchial asthma. Intravenous epinephrine must be given for severe reactions, while oral or parenteral antihistamines are usually effective for the less ominous symptoms. Although allergic reactions to transfused blood are a common cause of morbidity, deaths do not often occur. In an atopic person,' or one with pulmonary insufficiency or myocardial disease, an allergic reaction Can be fatal.

The illness induced by a transfer of antibodies. may not.be apparent immediately after transfusion, but is -manifested later when the recipient comes in contact with an antigen which corresponds to the transfused antibody. Thus a patient who has received a transfusion from a person who has an allergy to strawberries may suffer asthma or urticaria when he next eats strawberries, months, after his. transfusion. Blood donors should be carefully selected to exclude those with distinct allergies.

The immediate allergic responses occurring as a result of passive transfer of antigens can be reduced in incidence, by the administration of Pyribenzamine or other antihistamines to the patient before the transfusion. This preventive measure is indicated in those patients who have previously shown allergy' following transfusion.

PYROGENIC REACTIONS .

A slight elevation of body temperature (99 to 100° F.) may often be found-during or after blood transfusion, but ordinarily the fever subsides . Within two or three hours. In about 2 per cent of all recipients the febrile reaction is more severe and is generally attended by a feeling .of coldness or by a shaking chill. The onset of fever is often delayed for one to three hours after the transfusion has begun, especially when the blood is given slowly. The fever usually subsides within eight hours. Most reactions of this kind are due to polysaccharides of high molecular weight derived from bacteria. These pyrogenic substances apparently do not produce fever until they are metabolized in some way in the recipient; thus a lag between infusion and the development . of fever is • characteristic. Pyrogens are particularly apt’ to .contaminate the citrate solution which is used as an anticoagulant in the collection and storage o£ blood. Pyrogen can be demonstrated with fair accuracy by a standard technique using intravenous infusion of the questionable substance into rabbits. When the pyrogen test is negative, other mechanisms may be at fault.

Evidence has been presented by .Crosby and by Dameshek which establishes the presence of donor plasma pyrogenic factors, and this phenomenon may contribute to the frequency with which febrile reactions attend the infusion of blood. Warming the patient before transfusion and giving the blood .at a slow rate tend to reduce the incidence and height of febrile reactions.

Febrile transfusion reactions have also been shown to occur as a result of isoantibodies against dopor white blood cells and against platelet^? These reactions are similar in many respects to those caused by bacterial pyrogens, except that they tend to occur more frequently in patients who have received previous transfusions. Febrile reactions due to these factors (leukoagglu-tinin, platelet agglutinins, plasma antibodies) can be prevented by using only washed red cells. Removal of the buff coat after centrifuging the donor blood will eliminate reactions due to the presence of white blood cells and platelets.

Since both red blood cell incompatibility and contaminated blood cause fever, a differential diagnosis of the various etiologies must be attempted whenever fever occurs as the result of a'transfusion (see Hemolytic Reaction). One usually considers the consequences of pyrogenic reaction to be evanescent and trivial after having eliminated incompatibility or bacterial contamination as a cause. This attitude is unwarranted, however, for the author has observed several fatal pyrogenic reactions. In these instances the rectal temperatures reached 106 to 109° F„ and the skin was pale, cool and dry. Absence of sweating during hyperpyrexia is evidence that the febrile reaction was in fact heat stroke.

An elevation of temperature regularly follows the intravenous infusion of pyrogen to animals even though a prior injection of antihistamine has been given, so that one should not expect to alleviate or prevent febrile reactions to transfusions with antihistamines. In fact, one study has shown that any febrile response that follows the injection of Pyribenzamine and transfusion will be 2 to 4° F. higher than if no antihistamine is given.

Mild temperature elevations should be treated with aspirin. When the fever is high or rapidly rising, physical methods of cooling must be used as well as antipyretics. For temperatures of 104° F. or higher that do not respond to antipyretics or to topical sponging and fanning, the patient should be placed on a hypothermia blanket, or surrounded with ice, until the body temperature falls to 101° F. or less. During hyperpyrexia an intravenous infusion of glucose in water will abet the attempt to lower body temperature and will .replace rapid insensible losses of water. If the expiratory phase of respiration becomes prolonged or labored during the high fever, or if cyanosis is seen, oxygen should be administered with a tightly fitted face mask, using 15 to 18 cm. of water pressure in the inspiratory phase.              ■

BACTERIAL CONTAMINATION

The contamination of blood with bacteria is more common than is generally appreciated. In one blood bank of a university hospital, cultures were made from random bottles of banked blood, and over 2 per cent of the bottles yielded bacterial growth.4 Not all the bacteria were pathogens, but this unrecognized incidence of contaminated blood is disquieting, especially when bacteria can be found even when no violation of collection technique can be discovered. Further, bacterial growth may proceed when no faults in refrigeration have occurred, for certain strains of gramnegative bacilli grow well at 4 to 10° C.,

74


Complications of Blood Transfusions

which is the ordinary refrigerator temperature span. These cryophilic bacteria are virulent, and their intravenous infusion during blood transfusion is nearly always rapidly fatal to the recipient.           „

I£ a bottle of blood that is contaminated with the more common warm growing bacteria is left at room temperature for several hours, the rate of bacterial multiplication is logarithmic, and lethally infected blood results.

The bacteria found by Pittman in contaminated blood were all capable of using citrate. In some instances this property of the contaminants causes clotting of the blood; in others hemolysis may be apparent. There are recorded instances of fatal transfusions of blood contaminated with millions of organisms per milliliter, yet there was no gross change in the blood. One must conclude, then, that continuous refrigeration of blood and a normal appearance are not assurance that the blood is not infected.

' The symptoms mimic those of endotoxin shock with peripheral vasodilatation, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, hypotension and fever. When any of these symptoms occurs, the transfusion should be discontinued and a sample of the donor blood examined by smear and Gram's stain for the presence of organisms. If the contamination is heavy and is likely to be fatal, the organisms will be apparent by a smear. If the contamination is light, a culture may have to be made to determine the presence of bacteria. If samples of donor blood are not available, the patient’s blood should be cultured. If the infection is due to the cpli-aerogenes group of bacteria, the culture will usually yield growth.

Hypovolemia has been demonstrated in septic shock and is attended by a rising hematocrit level so that treatment of the shock requires replacement of volume with balanced salt solution. Antibiotics should be given in large doses intravenously, but sustained large doses are probably not

helpful, since the bacteremia is of short duration. Many of the disastrous immediate effects of contaminated transfusions are due to the toxins infused rather than the bacteria. The use of hydrocortisone administered intravenously is probably helpful in recovery from shock caused by bacterial toxins. These measures alone may be effective treatment. Recovery from shock should not be determined by blood pressure alone, for frequently the hypotension persists for a while after treatment has effected a functional recovery. Evidences of functional circulatory recovery are mental lucidity, warm extremities, increased urine flow rate and filling of peripheral veins. Unless a total assessment of the patient is used to determine whether recovery has occurred, the tendency to boost a moderately low blood pressure by means of vasoconstrictor agents may lead to overtreatment and unnecessary complications of therapy.                                 .

BLEEDING TENDENCY

After whole blood transfusions, especially of large volumes, the development of a bleeding tendency is often observed even though no incompatibility is demonstrated. Howland10 found a hemorrhagic tendency in 33 per cent of patients who received 10 pints of blood, or more, during operation. The possible causes for this phenomenon are discussed in Chapter 6; hence only a list of factors that have been found responsible for hemorrhagic diathesis following compatible blood transfusions is given: decreased platelets, platelet defect, lack of factors V and VII, increased fibrinolysin, circulating heparin-like substances, hypoprothrombinemia and hypofibrinogenemia. Specific treatment will depend upon ■ which one, or more, of these several mechanisms is found to be at fault in a given instance. Frequently multiple clotting de- I fects are discovered, or occasionally no specific factor can be demonstrated, and

i

Complications of Blood Transfusions                75

in these instances, when blood loss becomes cumulatively significant, one must give empiric treatment. The infusion of whole blood freshly collected in plastic containers frequently helps to supply some of the depleted plasma clotting factors, as well as platelets. As long as additional red cells are needed, fresh whole blood may retard the bleeding tendency while supplying red cells. When whole blood infusions are not imperative, fresh plasma can be used. Platelet-rich infusions should be used if there are contraindictations to additional expansion of the intravascular volume and the platelet deficiency persists. Protamine sulfate in doses of 50 to 100 mg. intravenously and vitamin oxide may be used to help stanch a bleeding tendency. If the situation is desperate, or if hypofibrinogenemia has been found, intravenous fibrinogen may be used, but because of its narrow therapeutic range of activity, expense, risk of causing hepatitis and its occasional fibrinolytic activity1.? it should not be used indiscriminately. Bleeding tendencies that follow compatible blood transfusions often spontaneously cease within forty-eight hours.

Prevention of the development of a bleeding tendency can most effectively be done by restricting the use of whole blood after traumatic blood loss and during surgical operations to the minimum volume required to treat peripheral vascular collapse, without attempting complete replenishment of red cell losses. Injection of balanced isotonic sodium solutions during operations and after trauma can safely and effectively reduce the quantity of whole blood required. By avoiding massive transfusion, bleeding diatheses due to transfusions can be largely prevented.

PULMONARY CONGESTION NOT ATTENDED BY CIRCULATING VOLUME OVERLOAD

Transfusions of small quantities of blood ■occasionally are followed by the development of hemorrhagic pulmonary edema (also called congestive atelectasis). If the causative transfusion was given to a conscious person, it will usually have been attended by a febrile reaction. But hemorrhagic edema has followed transfusions given to anesthetized patients who demonstrated no reaction to the blood and in whom no renal insufficiency ensued. Although no red cell incompatibility has been demonstrated, no gross overload of circulation has been obvious and no indication that left ventricular congestive failure has occurred, the lungs have become stiff and gaseous exchange insufficient after whole blood transfusions. The clinical signs are increased rate of respiration, expiratory effort early, inspiratory effort later marked by interspace retraction, cyanosis unrelieved by oxygen, absence of moist rales, and minimal auscultatory findings early, but sibilant rales may be heard and signs of patchy consolidation may later appear. As the respiratory insufficiency becomes more prominent there is arterial hypotension with rising venous pressure. The clinical course and postmortem findings are those of primary pulmonary vascular obstruction with intense pulmonary congestion and loss of compliance.

In my experience -with this entity, treatment (positive pressure oxygen, digitalis, phlebotomy, bronchodilators) has relieved temporarily some of the signs, but has done little to stop the progression of respiratory insufficiency to death.

76       IMMEDIATE COMPLICATIONS INCIDENT TO THE

METHOD OF TRANSFUSION

AIR EMBOLISM

The true incidence of this disastrous complication is not known because a report of air embolism is tantamount to admission of negligence. Most of the fatal air embolic episodes occur as a result of hydraulic pressure infusions in which air is pumped into the donor bottle to hasten the rate of flow. If the infusion is not terminated when the bottle is empty and while blood is still in the outflow tube, several hundred cubic centimeters of air . may enter the vein in a few seconds. The air entrance may be so rapid as to produce an audible sucking sound. The possibility of this complication can be eliminated by the use of one of several devices in which air pressure is applied to the column of blood through a collapsible but impermeable partition. Air embolism has followed a loose connection between tubing and needle when the venous pressure at the point of venipuncture is subatmospheric.

If one sees air bubbles in the tubing or detects air embolism by a sucking sound, or if the patient has an untoward reaction, the intravenous infusion should be immediately discontinued. The signs of air embolism are essentially those of mechanical blockage of the right side of the heart or pulmonary arteries. Gasping respiration followed by apnea, distended peripheral veins, arterial hypotension, cyanosis and splashing crunching noises coincident with the heart beat are signs which are unmistakably due to air embolism. The patient must be turned on his left side and the head tilted down as soon as the source of air entry has been eliminated. If the volume of air is small or has slowly entered the vein, this position may allow blood to flow through the right ventricular outflow tract around the air block. But if the mass of air trapped in the heart is large, the excessive myocardial stretch renders the muscle incapable of contraction. If a large needle (no. 15) is inserted into the heart, decompression may be effected and heart beat may resume. In the event of cardiac arrest, however, a thoracotomy with direct visualization of the heart is preferable, since arrest may be due to air having gained entrance to the coronary arteries through a patent foramen ovale, the left side of the heart and coronary ostia. Decompression of the dilated left and right chambers with a large-bore needle must then be done before manual systole will be effective in restoring the heart beat.

CIRCULATORY OVERLOAD

Even when transfusions are considered mandatory, the risk of producing circulatory overload exists, especially if chronic blood losses are completely or rapidly replaced. Transfusions of excessive volumes will not ordinarily cause congestive heart failure in a recipient wrho has a sound heart, but rather will cause a plethoric syndrome characterized by livid cyanosis, tachypnea, flushing of the face and neck, increased venous pressure, patchy atelectasis, elevated systolic pressure, wide pulse pressure, loud heart sounds, slapping aortic second sound, laterally displaced apical impulse and elevated hemoglobin concentrations.

The treatment of this state is removal of blood by phlebotomy until the signs ol plethora are relieved. If a concomitant extracellular fluid volume deficiency exists, recovery is hastened by simultaneous infusion of sodium salts and intermittent phlebotomy.

Although congestive heart failure is difficult to produce by overtransfusion in healthy adults with no previous heart disease, it is easily precipitated by blood transfusions of moderate volumes in the elderly, the anemic, the debilitated or persons with damaged hearts. In fact, transfusions of whole blood have in _my experience more readily produced heart failure than noncolloid salt solutions when the latter were being used for circulating volume replacement of operative losses. Heart failure may often be manifest as a pulmonary congestive state accompanied by a feeling of chest constriction and dry cough without frank pulmonary edema and frothy sputum. The absence of moist bubbling rales and frothy sputum does not negate the diagnosis of pulmonary’ congestion incident to myocardial overload and does not eliminate -this state as being dangerous, for fulminant pulmonary edema may appear many hours later. In addition, the con- ' gested lung is vulnerable to the development of atelectasis, and the collapsed segment is highly susceptible to infection. The postoperative development of atelectasis and pneumonitis is likely augmented by transient unrecognized pulmonary congestion frequently induced by blood transfusions given during operation and anesthesia. ■

The treatment of circulatory overload producing congestive heart failure consists in phlebotomy, semierect sitting position, digitalis and positive pressure oxygen breathing with bronchodilators in a nebulized wetting agent. Diuretics usually are not required in the treatment of acute blood overloads.

Some of the thrombotic postoperative complications such as venous thrombosis of legs and pelvis, coronary thrombosis and cerebral thrombosis are possibly related to the polycythemic state and the attendant increase in blood viscosity that commonly follows transfusions, especially those given during abdominal operations. An increase in postoperative hemoglobin concentration over the preoperative level was seen in about half of 100 consecutive patients during major gastric operations even though no blood transfusions were given and electrolyte solutions were infused.21 ’The propensity to hemoconcentration is increased by the injection of whole blood. That a thrombotic tendency is present in persons with polycythemia is well known.

Decreased renal function may be another manifestation of relative red cell overload. Oliguria has been observed to follow operations and trauma for which whole blood was given to the exclusion of electrolyte solutions with resultant high hemoglobin concentrations. Urine flow was restored in some of these instances by phlebotomy if hypervolemia existed, and by infusions of salt solutions.

Many clinicians7’ 8’18 regard circulatory overload as. the most common cause of death from transfusion, although it often is not coded as the cause of death. Even more frequently, overloads are probably a contributory cause of death. If these estimates of incidence of overload are accurate, a conservative estimate of the number of deaths following transfusions in the United States each year as a result of circulatory overload would be at least equal to the number of deaths computed to be due to hemolytic transfusion reactions, namely, 6750.

CARDIAC ARREST

Cardiac asystole, ventricular fibrillation and various other less disastrous .disturbances of rhythm and conduction (bradycardia, partial heart block, T wave elevation, prolongation of Q-T interval) may attend massive whole blood transfusions. In Howland’s10 series of 130 patients who received 10 pints, or more, of blood in the operating room and in whom adequate replacement had been effected, 17 per cent died of cardiac arrest or fibrillation.

Cardiac arrhythmias and arrest are thought to have been caused by hypothermia (90° F.) incident to transfusion of cold blood, citrate toxicity, decreased ionized calcium secondary to citrate excess, hyperkalemia and acidosis from old banked blood. Perhaps a combination of these factors with or without myocardial overload

78


Complications of Blood Transfusions

as a result of an acute transfusional hypervolemia is sufficient to induce cardiac arrest during anesthesia.

Since the precise causes are not known, treatment must consist essentially in prevention, by avoiding massive transfusions by means of supplemental injection of sodium solutions (glucose in lactated Ringer’s). Stirman19 produced in dogs fatal hemorrhagic shock that was irreversible when the shed blood was returned or when extra quantities of whole blood ivere infused; but when injections of isotonic sodium solutions were made before return of the shed blood, most of the animals survived. This unique property of sodium solutions to modify fatal hemorrhagic shock is not generally appreciated, but is singularly valuable in the successful management of operative (and traumatic) hemorrhage.

When it is anticipated that large volumes of blood will be required, the blood that is used should not have been stored for more than one week, and as many pints as .possible should have been recently collected in plastic containers using heparin as an anticoagulant rather than citrate solution. This precaution would appear to be especially important when liver dysfunction is present, since citrate metabolism is dependent on blood flow to the liver and intact liver functions. The blood should be warmed to room temperature before injection. If only citrated blood is available, calcium gluconate (about I gm. for each 3 units of whole blood infused) can be given intravenously to prevent severe ionic calcium deficiencies from developing.

By electrocardiographic monitoring during replacement of large quantities of whole blood, the conduction and rhythm abnormalities may be detected and specifically treated before arrest. In the event of cardiac arrest or ventricular fibrillation the course of action and details of treatment are as given in Chapter 12.

THROMBOPHLEBITIS

Although thrombophlebitis is a common complication following intravenous injections of irritant fluids, it is not usual for a single blood transfusion to result in venous thrombosis at the site of vein puncture. The duration of the transfusion influences the incidence of local infection, so that if more than one transfusion is given through the same venipuncture, the possibility of infection and of thrombosis increases. This complication can be serious, since most hospital-acquired infections at the site of skin punctures and venous cannulations are due to resistant staphylococci. Fatal septicemias have been observed as the result of infection following indwelling venous plastic catheters.

Rotation of the site of infusion after six to eight hours will probably prevent infections and thrombosis more effectively than any other measure. If a given needle puncture site shows early signs of inflammation, or becomes painful, the infusion should be discontinued at that area. If distinct inflammatory signs are present over a thrombosed vein and the patient shows evidence of systemic infection, the vein should be ligated proximal to the thrombosed segment to prevent septic embolization.

LATE COMPLICATIONS

TRANSMISSION OF DISEASE

One of the most serious current problems of transfusion therapy is the transmission of serum hepatitis to the recipient. The incidence’ apparently is increasing, and at present there is no certain way to preclude the possibility of transmission.

Complications of Blood Transfusions

79


Methods for eliminating the infectivity of whole blood have not been found. Careful donor selection fs helpful in reducing the incidence of giving infected blood, but since there are no practical and reliable screening methods for detection of the asymptomatic carriers of hepatitis virus, selection is an inadequate preventive measure. About 1 in 150 persons is estimated to harbor hepatitis virus, and in some professional donor populations the incidence is even greater; e.g. at the University of Chicago Hospitals there was one case of hepatitis for every 127 pints transfused.?'' Five per cent of whole blood recipients in Osaka, Japan, acquire serum hepatitis. Some metropolitan hospitals in the United States have reported 3 and 6 per cent incidences of hepatitis in patients given blood transfusions. The reported incidence varies from the actual frequency as a result of the long incubation period of the disease of 60 to 160 days, when many patients are lost to follow-up.

The mortality rate of serum hepatitis_ varies from 2 to 25 per cent. In Allen’^3' series one death occurred in every 500 recipients. This does not include the persons with serum hepatitis who develop chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis and subsequently die of these com plica tions.

If one assumes a national fatality rate which is equal to that reported by Allen, serum hepatitis following blood transfusion would then cause death in 5000 persons each year. If Hoxworth’s data, taken from transfusion experiences in Cincinnati, are projected on a national basis, the annual deaths from hepatitis due to blood transfusion are about 1700. The difference in hepatitis attack rate between these two series of blood recipients is probably due to the predominance of professional paid donors in one group, while family and friends of the patients contributed blood in the series with the lower attack rate. The number of deaths each year in the nation due to hepatitis from blood transfusions is assumed to be 33OS,'which figure is an average based on these 2 reports of hepatitis among recipients.

At present there is no effective prevention or cure of serum hepatitis, although large doses of anti-inflammatory steroids may shorten the course of illness. The only way by which death from serum hepatitis can be eliminated is to avoid transfusion.

Diseases other than serum hepatitis may be transferred from donor to recipient. Transmission of brucellosis has been reported, and in Mexico the incidence of positive agglutination titers for brucellosis among donors is so high as to limit the availability of blood.

An illness resembling influenza was reported by Beutler and Dern? to have been transmitted by blood transfusions.

Syphilis can be transmitted, and routine serologic testing of the donors does not in- -fallibly prevent the use of infected blood because one third of persons with primary syphilis are serologically negative. Storage at 4° C. is helpful in reducing the transmission of syphilis, for after 4 days infected blood is probably no longer capable of causing syphilis in the recipient. Fresh blood, or that which is stored only, a short time, can transmit the disease unless the recipient is given penicillin. The incubation period is one to four months, and the first manifestations are those of secondary syphilis. A positive serologic test for syphi-. lis can also be transmitted to the recipient even though-viable spirochetes are not; this positive test does not persist for more than about three weeks.                          ■

Malaria may be transmitted by transfu- . sion and usually has a short incubation period of four to twenty days. The malaria plasmodia remain viable in refrigerated blood, so that storage does not reduce infectivity. Prophylaxis is made more difficult by the fact that quartan parasites may remain viable in the blood of a person for many years after subsidence of all symptoms and in some persons who have never experienced any symptoms of malaria. Examination of blood smears for presence of the parasites is not a practical method of eliminating the transmission of malaria because the plasmodia are too few to find. In endemic areas prophylactic administration of quinine and other antimalarial agents to recipients is necessary to reduce the transmission of malaria.

ISOSENSITIZATION

Anyone having had a previous transfusion is regarded as a dangerous recipient. His chances of having a complication with another transfusion are augmented by the isosensitization that probably occurred incident to the earlier transfusion. Hemolytic disease of the newborn and some other acquired           anemias are other ex

amples of the late consequences of previous whole blood transfusions.

Actually, about 14,000 transfusions are given daily in this country. The number becomes greater each year, so that a progressively larger segment of our population is falling into the dangerous recipient class. This would indicate that transfusions will become more hazardous and that the complication rate will increase unless more discrimination is used by the medical profession when prescribing whole blood infusions.

TRANSFUSIONAL SIDEROSIS

Many transfusions are required to produce deposits of excessive iron in bone marrow and reticuloendothelial cells all over the body. If iron is given over a long period of time, as few as twenty blood transfusions may cause hemosiderosis. Ordinarily, the persons showing histologic evidence of transfusional siderosis have received 100 transfusions. There is no effective treatment. Intercurrent exotic infections cause death of many victims of siderosis.

CUMULATIVE MORTALITY FROM COMPLICATIONS ■         OF BLOOD TRANSFUSIONS

Complications of Blood Transfusions

81


PREOPERATIVE TRANSFUSIONS

SPECIFIC DANGERS OF BLOOD TRANSFUSION GIVEN FOR ANEMIA

Causes of anemia, other than blood loss, may be masked by the infusion of blood. Pernicious anemia, folic acid deficiency or other specific anemia may seriously complicate the postoperative course when not recognized and treated preoperatively.

The inherent risks of transfusion are augmented in the person with chronic anemia who has received multiple transfusions in the past and in whom isosensitization likely has occurred, for additional transfusions may induce or precipitate an acquired hemolytic state.

Blood transfusions have a depressant effect on the bone marrow,"anH the resultant decrease in erythropoiesis may restrict the patient’s ability to spontaneously restore red cell losses that occur during operation.

An increased circulating blood volume frequently attends chronic anemia as a result of plasma overexpansion. Whole blood transfusions are therefore likely to produce overload phenomena, since the total blood volume must necessarily be oyercorrected in order that the hemoglobin mass be restored to normal. If the recipient cannot regulate this overload by rapid extrusion of plasma from the vascular tree, some form of circulatory failure will ensue. The ability to extrude plasma is impaired in patients with chronic anemia.

Respiratory inefficiency, as measured by vital capacity, pulmonary compliance and oxygen consumption rates, attends rapid correction’of chronic anemia by transfusion of whole blood or packed red cells.1

LACK OF NEED FOR WHOLE BLOOD TRANSFUSION IN SOME PATIENTS

WITH ANEMIA

Physiologic adjustments by plasma volume expansion, increased cardiac output and more efficient gaseous exchange frequently permit the patient with anemia to perform work without undue fatigue11 and to undergo operation without untoward incident.21

Prior blood transfusions have been shown not to prevent shock or lessen mortality from subsequent hemorrhage if the animal was normovolemic, even though moderately anemic, before the transfusion.17

TRANSFUSIONS DURING OPERATION

HEMORRHAGE WITHOUT SHOCK

This is not an urgent indication for blood replacement, provided there are no physiologic manifestations of hypovolemia and subsequent hemorrhage is not anticipated. When blood replacement is made for losses of less than 500 ml., one has taken the untenable position of recommending transfusion for blood losses of smaller volume than that lost by the donor, who was capable of walking out of the hospital after his contribution.

A direct relation exists between the volume of incompatible blood received and mortality.1,4 The early subjective complaints that accompany hemolytic and other transfusion reactions cannot be sounded during general anesthesia in time to prevent administration of large, probably lethal, quantities of faulty blood. One should be particularly reluctant to give blood during the anesthetized state unless the need for it is urgent.

One other untoward reaction of blood transfusion during anesthesia is development of pulmonary stiffening and vascular engorgement if an episode of hypercapnia, ■ hypoxia or asphyxia precedes the transfusion.2? Since imperfect gaseous exchange 82 frequently attends induction of anesthesia and endotracheal intubation, the likelihood is augmented that lung complications will follow the injection of blood during anesthesia.

Electrolyte solutions have been regularly used on my surgical service during operations and general anesthesia and have been effective in obviating the risks of elective blood transfusions. The postoperative com-, plications (pulmonary, wound, anastomotic) have actually been less as a result of this policy.21 The expected postoperative decrease in urine output which is supposed to be a manifestation of endocrine response to injury did not occur in those patients who received adequate electrolyte solutions during operation. Recently Randall has demonstrated that sodium retention need not attend major operations, provided operative losses of sodium salts are replaced.

HYPOTENSION WITHOUT DECREASED BLOOD VOLUME

The elevation of blood pressure that follows blood transfusion in this hypotensive state is obtained at the dear price of overloading the intravascular volume and of masking the true cause of the hypotension (e.g. bacteremia, mesenteric tug reflex, deep anesthesia, hyperthermia, and the like). Thus correction of, hypotension by stuffing the patient with blood can deceptively indicate improvement instead of jeopardy during reflex, vasoparalytic, cardiogenic and other forms of normovolemic shock.

Complications of Blood Transfusions


SHOCK WITH REDUCED BLOOD VOLUME DUE TO PLASMA AND EXTRACELLULAR

ELUID LOSSES '

The empiric use of whole blood to elevate the blood pressure in shock states due to extracellular fluid volume depletion (intestinal obstruction, diarrhea, peritonitis, vomiting, and so on) is without rational basis and is not attended by functional recovery despite improvement in blood pres-■ sure.

Renal function did not recover even though -whole blood transfusion success-' fully -restored blood pressure in dogs suffering from shock due to extracellular fluid removal by peritoneal dialysis, but when this hypotensive shock state was treated with lactated Ringer’s solution, glomerular filtration rate, urine flow and blood urea nitrogen all returned to normal.18

POSTOPERATIVE TRANSFUSIONS

BLOOD LOSS ANEMIA

The effectiveness and safety of oral or parenteral iron therapy for blood loss anemia make blood transfusion a dangerous alternative that need not often be used in the postoperative period when the fear of additional blood loss is past.

WHOLE BLOOD TRANSFUSIONS FOR NUTRIMENT

Intravenous whole blood is an incomplete food and a grossly inefficient method of feeding, since there is a slow and questionable entry' of globin and plasma protein into the protein metabolic pool. Moreover, this method of feeding is expensive and dangerous. One may lose more calories by the febrile reaction attending transfusion than he gains by the calorie equivalent in the blood.

BLOOD TRANSFUSIONS AS A TONIC

. There is little critical evidence to support the use of whole blood as a source of antibodies to confer passive immunity or

Complications of Blood Transfusions                83

help resist infection. If such need exists, the use of gamma globulin or specific immune serums would be more efficacious and far more safe.

Provided anemia or hypovolemia does not exist, no nonspecific boost of strength, morale or recuperative ability can be demonstrated to follow whole blood injection.

REFERENCES’
