R5 The Spectator, Jan o/73» P 3 (Hamilton, Canada)

Transplant recipient also got

cancer

Special to The Spectator

WASHINGTON - For the first time in the history of heart transplants, a recipient has died of a cancer apparently introduced in his body by the heart be received.

The case has been disclosed by the St. Louis University Medical Centre.

Vincent H. Dobelman, 45, was given a new heart at the St. Louis Centre last Feb. 8. It came from a man who died of a brain tumor but not, so far as the surgeons knew then, from a cancer.

The operation was the centre’s first heart transplant.

DOBELMAN showed signs of rejection, the process by which the body sloughs off foreign cells. This was normal. It was treated, as usual, by so-called immuno-suppres-sive drugs.

It became known that Dobelman might face another problem. An autopsy of the ,baart donor had shown that be suffered not from a primary brain tumor (which is almost always an isolated condition, not affecting other parts of the body) but from a lung cancer which had spread to the brain.

. On Nov. 11, Dobelman was i readmitted to the hospital ; with “muscle aches” and ; “malaise.” He developed ■ more signs of rejection, ahd । on Dec. 16 he died with a 1 clinical picture of heart fail

ure.

On autopsy, pathologists ! found extensive cancer in his heart, lungs and liver. It had obviously grown and spread fast, a common oecurence in kidney transplant patients who have also been inadvertently given new organs that bore cancerous cells.

“The extent of tumor growth.” the St. Louis doctors’ statement said, “is considered at this time to be a major contributing factor to the heart failure which caused his death.”

THE DOCTORS also said it is not certain that the cancer found in the donor is the same one that struck Dobelman. “It is unlikely that a positive statement can ever be made in this regard,” they added.

“It is highly probable that the tumor was in the heart when it was transplanted,” said Dr. Vallee L. Wilman, chief of surgery and the man who directed the transplant effort.

Even a careful exterior examination of a heart before transplant or a biopsy of heart muscle could fail to show cancer cells, said one authority. Capcer does not actually take rpot in heart must-cles, he added, but cancJr . cells may be present in the , heart circulation, and thus get transplanted.

Washington Post Service

NO... 5511 VOLs 2 426   20 August 1%6

Leading Articles


British

Medical Journal


Transmission of Disease by Blood Transfusion

Hepatitis/ syphilis, malaria, and brucellosis have all been transmitted to patients who were given whole blood or blood products. Hepatitis is by far the most serious disorder transmitted in this way, and the, incidence of the disease in patients receiving an average of two bottles of blood is about 0.8%. When plasma from relatively large pools is used the incidence can reach the alarming figure of 11.9%, but if the plasma pool is prepared from less than 10 bottles the figure falls to 1.3%. After a massive blood transfusion—and between 10 and 20 bottles is commonplace in modern heart surgery'—the risk is once again increased. This important hazard of blood transfusion is not as widely appreciated as it should be: one of the reasons for this may be the relatively long incubation period, which varies from 60 to 160 days before jaundice appears. ,

The signs and symptoms are better known. In addition to jaundice, about two thirds of patients have nausea, vomiting, and anorexia, joint pains are present in about a quarter and a skin rash may develop. The illness lasts about 30 days. Seven out of 134 cases reported by D. Lehane and his colleagues3 died. The work of G. S. Mirick, R. Ward, and R. W. McCollum3 suggested that giving gamma-globulin may reduce the frequency of hepatitis after transfusion, and there is much to be said for adopting this form of prophylaxis with large transfusions. ■

Where malaria is endemic the transmission by transfusion remains a hazard.. N. N. Duhanina and T. A. Zukova4 report 47 cases, including the transmission of quartan malaria ' to children who were given maternal blood as prophylaxis ' against measles. Another 36 cases are recorded from Yugoslavia.5 Transmission of malaria by transfusion can be prevented by the administration of chloroquine diphosphate to the recipient before the transfusion. A dose, of 600 mg. seems to be adequate.6

Transmission of syphilis is less likely because spirochaetcs are unlikely to survive for more than 72 hours in stored citrated blood,’ and transmission of brucellosis, though reported,8 must be a rarity.

Most transfusion services do not accept as donors those who give a history of jaundice. Nevertheless, even after this step is taken the known incidence of homologous serum jaundice suggests that not less than 1 in 200 healthy donors are carriers of the virus. Whole blood from donors who have lived in areas where malaria is endemic should not be transfused, though there is no objection to the use of their plasma. It is also the practice to carry out serological tests for syphilis on donor blood samples and to exclude donors giving positive reactions.

  • 1 Brit. med. J., 1966, 1, 997.

  • 2 Lehane, D., Kwames, C. M. S., Upward, M. G., and Thomson, D. R., Brit. med. J-, 194-9, 2, 572.

  • • Mirick, G. S-, Ward, R., and McCollum, R. W., Vox Sang., 1962, 7. 125.

  • * Duhanina, N. N-, and Zukova, T. A., Bull. Wld Hlth Org., 1965, 33, 853.

  • • LepeL T., ibid., 1965, 33, 856.

  • • Tiburskaja, N. A., and Vrublevskaia, O. S., ibid., 1965, 33, 843.

  • ’ Bloch, O., Bull. Johns Hopk. Hosp., 1941, 68, 412.

  • ’ Wood, E. E-, Brit. med. J., 1955, 1, 27.

GDS-52                       Vol '2 No 22         medical would uiws />»>< ■» mzi        p 4

TRANSFUSION MALARIA SNEAKING UP

Until 1967, the U S had only about one case a year of transfusion-induced malaria Since then, 27 cases have turned up, 12 of Jhem since January 1970

The Center for Disease Control, worried about_ the sharp upturn, wants the American Association of Blood Banks to tighten up and simplify its guidelines for accepting donations It proposes that blood banks reiect donations from any person who has lived in or traveled to a ma-' lanous area—not necessarily an entire country—within three years

Current AABB guidelines permit donations within six months after leaving the malarious area if the donor is asymptomatic and has not taken antimalarial drugs If drugs were taken, donations are not supposed to be accepted for two years after the chemotherapy ended Permanently rejected are those with a


history of malaria or residents of a country where it is endemic

CDC’s complaint is not so much that the guidelines are too lax, but that they are_ not rigidly enforced, says Dr Arthur S Dover He points ’out that if the guidelines had been strictly followed, only two of the 21 cases in which he has traced the infected donor would have occurred He adds, however, that regardless of whose guidelines are in effect, the "serious problem" of donor misinformation remains He says he knows of at least four cases in which the infected donor lied about his history

AABB has balked at the CDC proposal, but is still mulling it over It contends that the CDC guideline lacks flexibility and would cause the loss of many safe donors "We've had quite a hassle," says Dr Herbert A Perkins, chairman of the AABB panel considering the proposal. "We differ on whether the restrictive period should be three years, two years, or only six months What do you do. say, with the guy who passes through Saigon lor 12 hours?" Dr ' Perkins also contends that AABB's guidelines have not been in effect long enough —they were promul gated in January 1970 -to have really been put to a test

Dr Dover says CDC chose the three year limit for maximum safety, he reports one case in which the parasites had been in the donor for 32 months "A two-year interval unnecessarily increases the risk." he says

AABB's decision is expected to be worked out by the time of its annual meeting m Chicago this September ' "We are giving the recommendation very careful consideration," says Dr Perkins. "We want to get something that everyone will be happy with ”

MEDICAL WORLD NEWS


TTransfuaton Malaria

Sir: In November of 1970, we sent a communication to the journal Transfusing in which we reported that current st andanis for malaria preven-tion in blood banks were misleading and dangerous. These blood bank regulations were guidelines set by the American Association of Blood Banks Committee on Standards and the Center for Disease Control (CDC), Atlanta, Ga. At the time our paper was submitted, we hoped for early publication in order to bring the problem into the open and thereby facilitate the revision of standards.

We are particularly disturbed by some of the allegedly direct quotations and paraphrases from Dr. Herbert Pe’-kins, chairman of the Standards Committee. AABB in your article:

  • (1) ". . . We differ on ’whether the restrictive period should be three years, two years, or only six months, . . Comment: We concur with the CDC that a restrictive period of only

    July 16, 1971


    Vol. 12, No.27, pl2


    Letters t© the Editor


six months or two years is insufficient. Furthermore, six months could lie dangerous.

  • (2) ". . . What do you do, say, with the guy who passes through Saigon for twelve hours. . Comment: He must be excluded as a blood donor for at least three years. Even though Saigon is relatively malaria-free compared with most of Vietnam, it takes only one infected mosquito a mere fraction of a second to bite and to transmit malaria. Accordingly, 12 hours is more than sufficient. This example is particularly dangerous, for drug-resistant falciparum malaria is prevalent in Vietnam.

  • (3) ". . . AABB’s guidelines have not been in effect long enough-they were promulgated in January 1970-to have really been put to test. . . .” Comment: This statement presumes that the current guidelines are reasonable and safe. They are not.

Finallv, when we sent our communication (which has not yet been published in Traw.s/ic,iion,__or_officialij commented on by the AABB Committee on Standards) we mailed pre-publication copies to the AABB Committee on Standards, the CDC, and blood bank directors in the Chicago area, including Dr. Coye C. Mason. Executive Director. Chicago Blood Donor Service. Dr. Mason is also editor of Laboratory Medicine, and his staff inadvertently published our comments in Laboratoi y Medicine (Vol. 2, No. 1).

Interested readers may rind there what we believe are safe, reasonable blood bank malaria standards.

James E. Bowman, m d. Paul E. Carson, m.d. Departments of Pathology and Medicine The Pritzker Schoo! of Medicine University of Chicago Chicago

Graft-vs-Host Reaction

Following a Single Blood Transfusion

William E. Hathaway, MD, Vincent A. Fttlginili, Ml), Carl W. Pierce, MD, PhD, John H. Githens, MD, David S. Pearlman, Ml), Frederick Muschenheim, MD, and C. Henry Kempe, MD

The gratt-vs-host (GW) reaction occurred in an 11-month-old W; vnth afymphoyAasla and ’progresT swe vaccinia who had received a single whole blood ' transfusion. The principal manifestations of the GVH reaction were hepatosplenomegaly, dermatitis, diarrhea, aplastic anemia, and histiocytosis of the spleen and lymph nodes. The findings in this patient are quite similar to those of other previously reported cases of possible human runt disease. This case study emphasizes the dangers of smallpox vaccination or blood tranfusion in infants with thymic alymphoplasia or one of the variants of this syndrome.                ■

As recently as 1962, Nisbet and Heslop were able . to write “runt disease is an entity entirely restricted to laboratory animals, and . . . has no known human counterpart in clinical medicine.”' Since then, several cases have been reported suggesting fatal graft-vs-host (GVH) reaction (runt disease) in humans?" As In laboratory animals, this reaction appeared to occur when immunologically competent lymphocytes were transfused into immunologically deficient infants who had thymic ■ alymphoplasia or “Swiss-type” agammaglobulinemia. The purpose of this paper is to describe another case of human runt disease which occurred in an infant with thymic alymphoplasia following a single transfusion of whoie blood. The clinical and pathologic findings of this case will be compared with those of the previously reported cases.

Report of a Case

. .. An 11-month-old white boy was admitted to Colorado rtC, General Hospital, Denver, on Oct 27, 1966, for evaluation and treatment of progressive vaccinia. With the exception of oral thrush as an infant and occasional mouth ulcerations with slight fevers, he had been well until six weeks prior to admission when he was given a small-pox vaccina-

From the departments of pediatrics (Drs. Hathaway, Fulginiti, Githens, Pearlman, and Kempe) and pathology (Drs. Pierce and Muschenheim), University of Colorado Medical Center, Denver.

Reprint requests to 4200 E Ninth Ave, Denver 80220 (Dr. Hathaway).

tion on the left upper arm. Two weeks later a single crusted lesion was noted. This lesion became surrounded by satellite vesicles which coalesced, enlarged, and appeared necrotic. During the two weeks prior to admission the patient had a febrile course and was treated with penicillin. sulfasoxazole, and tetracycline. On Oct 20, 1966, he was admitted to a hospital in Brooklyn, NY, where he was given a 10-ml intramuscular injection of vaccinia immune serum globulin was well as 10 ml of commercial -/-globulin. Daily body temperatures of 102-103 F (38.9-39.4 C) were recorded, A superficial suYgical debridement of the lesion was done. The following day (Oct 21, 1966) a 125-ml whole blood transfusion (12-day-old Red Cross blood treated with anticoagulant acid citrate dextrose solution) was administered without reaction (male donor). The original vaccinia! lesion became worse, two new lesions appeared, and the febrile course persisted in spite of additional anti-biolic therapy (ampicillin and erythromycin). On Oct 27, 1966, he was transferred to Colorado General Hospital.

For editorial comment see pa^e 1010.

The history was unrevealing except for immunization with diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and pertussis vaccine and oral poliovirus vaccine without reaction. Pregnancy, birth, growth, and development were entirely normal. The father and mother, both 23 years old, were in good health. There were no siblings. Family history was noncontributory.

Physical examination revealed an acutely ill, well nourished, well developed, mildly dehydrated infant who weighed 8.8 kg (19.4 lb). The left upper arm was covered by a 15 X 15-cm, necrotic, crusted ulcer with an erythematous margin. Pustular vesicles were seen on the right eyelid and left ankle. The right knee was swollen, red, and tender. The liver edge was palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin; the spleen was not felt.

Laboratory Studies. — Initial studies disclosed the following values: hemoglobin, 14.3 gm/100 cc; hematocrit 47%: white blood cell count, 15,000/cu mm, with 87 segmented neutrophiles, four bands, three large lymphocytes, two 'medium lymphocytes, one small lymphocyte, one monocyte, and two eosinophiles. Platelets were within the range of low average. Reticulocyte count was 1.6%. Coombs’ test result was positive (1 + ). Urinalysis showed proteinuria (1 + ) and a few granular casts. Bacterial cultures of urine, blood, stool, nasopharynx, and vaccinia lesions revealed no pathogens. Blood electrolytes were normal except for a mild hyponatremia. Serum protein electrophoresis showed total protein of 5.0 gm/100 ml; albumin, 2.5

1016

TIME, HOSPITAL DAYS


  • 1. One day after appearance of erythematous morbilliform rash. Central necrosis of primary vaccinia! lesion is evident.


  • 2. Serial hematologic findings in patient. Note occurrence of terminal pancytopenia. E = Exchange transfusion.


gm/100 ml; «■,-globulin, 0.5 gm/100 ml; as-globulin, 1.2 gm/ 100 ml; /J-globulin. 0.6 gm/100 ml; and y-globulin, 0.2 gm/ 100 ml. Immunoglobulins were Ig<4, 216 mg/100 cc; IgA, <6 mg/100 cc; and IgM, 14 mg/100 cc. Bone marrow examination showed a cellular marrow with a slight increase in myeloid elements. Erythrocytic and megakaryocytic series were normal. No plasma cells were seen. Chromosomal analysis on direct bone marrow preparation showed 46/xy (all male karyotype). Skin tests for delayed hypersensitivity, including mumps, parainfluenza 1, 2, and 3, and Candida organisms, were negative. Phytohemagglutinin stimulation of peripheral blood lymphocytes yielded a negative reaction.

Clinical Course.—The initial clinical impression was thymic alymphoplasia with progressive vaccinia gangrenosum. Treatment consisted of methisazone, 1,000 mg every six hours orally; vaccinia-immune globulin, 10 ml intramuscularly per day, methicillin; ampicillin; polymyxin B sulfate; nystatin; and multiple vitamins. One the second hospital day respiratory distress developed and the chest roentgenogram showed bilateral apical infiltrates. Because of the possibility of pneumonitis caused by Pneumocystis carinii, pentamidine isothionate was added to the treatment regimen. The infant showed slight improvement in his general condition and became afebrile. However, on the morning of the fourth hospital day a diffuse, erythematous, morbilliform rash developed covering his entire body and-4 persisted for the remainder of his hospitalization (Fig 1). At this time the spleen was noted to be easily palpable and the liver was further enlarged. A severe diarrhea began and his general condition worsened. A repeat bone marrow examination on the fifth day revealed marked

  • 3. Histopathologic changes in regions of morbilliform rash. Left, Hyperkeratosis is marked; rete pegs are widened and contain vesicles at dermal-epidermal junction. Dermis contains diffuse mononuclear cell infiltrate (xSO). Right, Higher power reveals several dyskeratotic cells and nuclear pyknosis (X500).         .


myeloid hyperplasia and increased numbers of monocytoid and histiocytic cells. The clinical impression was that the patient was undergoing a GVH reaction secondary to the blood transfusion he receiveri prior to admission. In an effort to give passive vaccinia antibody therapy, a series of jjz- exchange tranfusions with blood from recently vaccinated donors were instituted. Each exchange (Fig 2) consisted of three units of blood irradiated with 2,300 rads to render the lymphocytes nonviable. The patient tolerated the exchange transfusions very well, but. failed to show clinical benefit. On the 13th day the infant had severe abdominal distension and melena and roentgenologic study showed pneumotosis intestinalis. Coagulation studies showed a prolonged prothrombin time and severe depression of prothrombin factor II, proconvertin factor VIT, Stuart factor X, and proaccelerin factor V. Antihemophilic factor VIII was normal. Vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma were given with cessation of bleeding. The remainder of his course was complicated by generalized edema, hypoalbu-mmemia, progression ancF necrosis oT the vaccinia! lesions, and deepening lethargy; he died on the 22nd hospital day. Figure 2 depicts the hematological data irTTeiation "to the patient's hospital course. In addition to the thrombocytopenia and granulocytopenia, a severe reticulocyto-penia occurred just prior to his death.

Pathologic Findings.—At autopsy, the infant had a large, necrotic vaccinia eschar of the left shoulder and upper left anterior and posterior thorax and many satellite lesions on the face, arms, and legs. Raised, yellow-green, friable, vac-cinial lesions were present on the tongue and in the esophagus and colon. Much nuclear and cellular debris as well as Guarnieri bodies were present at the margins of the lesions; there was minimal inflammatory response. The remainder of the skin was markedly edematous and a morbilliform eruption was visible. Histologically, the dermis was edematous. Mononuclear cells were scattered about adnexae and vessels. The epidermis showed hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, acanthosis, and epidermal proliferation of the basal layer; scattered dyskeratotic cells were seen (Fig 3). Lymphoid tissue was absent from the palatine tonsilar area, mediastinum, and small intestine and was markedly reduced in the appendix. The thymus weighed 1 gm and was present in the anterior mediastinum. It was composed of large fusiform epithelial cells, macrophages, and reticulum cells; no Hassall's corpuscles or small lymphocytes were seen. The lobular arrangement was well preserved (Fig 4). Abdominal periaortic lymph nodes con-

  • 4. Section from thymus. Preservation of lobular structure is clearly evident. Lymphocytes are absent from cortex. Medulla contains acidophilic reticulum cells and fusiform, primitive epithelial cells. Hassall's corpuscles are not present (x80).

tained few lymphocytes and were composed mostly of large histiocytes. Reticulum cells, fibroblasts, and a fewlarge mononuclear cells were present in the cortex; no plasma cells were identified (Fig 5). The lungs revealed bronchopneumonia, atelectasis, and several small vac-cinial lesions. Cultures yielded Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The 550-gm liver (normal, 275 gm) was congested and showed severe fatty change and bile stasis with increased iron in the Kupffer cells. The portal triads contained a few mononuclear cells. The spleen was enlarged, 35 gm in weight (normal. 25 mg), and showed congestion of the red pulp. Periarteriolar lymphoid tissue was .decreased. The nodules were small and widely scattered. In many, the

5, Sections from periaortic lymph nodes with two distinct histologic patterns. Left, Lymphatic channels are dilated and only a few, scattered, small mononuclear cells are present. Node is composed mostly of reticulum cells and histiocytes. Right, More cellular portion of nodes contains increased large and small mononuclear cells and histiocytes; follicles are not present (X50).

*TAL — thymic alymphoplasia.


lymphoid tissue was partly replaced by histiocytes and large mononuclear cells. Germinal centers were absent (Fig 6). Most portions of the intestine lacked lymphocytes in the lamina propria; histiocytes appeared increased. The bone marrow was markedly hypocellular and showed several histiocytes, hut few recognizable myeloid, erythroid, or platelet precursors (Fig 7). Cultures of the liver, lung, spleen, brain, myocardium, lymph node, kidney, colon, and skin were positive for vaccinia virus.

Comment

Runt disease is that form of GVH reaction which occurs in infants who are immunologically tolerant due to a disease state or immaturity, and who receive allogenic transfusions of 'immunologically competent lymphocytes. Secondary disease is the form of GVH reaction that occurs in individuals who have undergone immunosuppression by radiotherapy or chemotherapy, and who receive transfusions containing lymphocytes.

The clinical and pathologic findings of the GVH reaction or runt disease in animals are well established, but the mechanism of the production of these manifestations is not well understood. The manifestations of human runt disease are similar to those seen in animals. Tables 1 and 2 summarize the clinical and pathologic findings which have been described in the reported cases of possible human runt disease. These findings include gastrointestinal symptoms such as severe diarrhea, dermatitis evidenced by an erythematous morbill

iform rash, hepatosplenomegaly, hemolytic anemia, pancytopenia, and usually, a rapidly fatal course. Pathologically, dyskeratosis of the skin, aplasia of the marrow, hepatic necrosis, lymphoid tissue depletion, and histiocytic and monocytoid cell infiltration of the spleen, liver, lymph nodes, gut, and bone marrow are seen. Each of these clinical signs and pathologic lesions is not of itself specifically diagnostic of the GVH reaction; they can be seen in part in other diseases of the reticuloendothelial system such as severe infections or histiocytosis X." However, when these findings occur in an immunologically deficient infant with impaired delayed hypersensitivity, who has received infusions of whole blood, leukocytes, or bone marrow which contain immunologically competent lymphocytes, runt disease is a strong possibility. Proof of persistence of the graft in the form of appropriate sex chromosomal markers is additional evidence for the GVH reaction, although there is evidence in animal experiments that the grafted cells need not persist after an initial period of time to mediate the pathologic reaction.7

6. Section of spleen. Periarterial lymphoid tissue is hypocellular. Small lymphocyte cuff is partly replaced by increased histiocytes. Similar cells surround small artery at left (X160).


7. Section of bone marrow. Hematopoietic tissue appears disorganized. Immature myeloid and erythroid elements are decreased in number. Megakaryocytes are absent. Histiocytes appear increased (X160).


The similarity of the cases of human runt disease (Tables 1 and 2) is striking, especially when one realizes that the severity of the GVH reaction may be dependent on several factors including (1) degree of immunosuppression of the host; (2) the genetic disparity of graft and host tissues, ie, the difference in histocompatibility genes; (3) cell dose of the graft (both numbers and types of cells); (4) complicating infection8; and (5) degree of lymphatic tissue depletion.3

The underlying immunologic deficiency disease in each of these patients and the present case was thymic alymphoplasia or Swiss-type agammaglobulinemia'“,1' or a variant of thymic alymph-oplasia.’3''3 In all of these cases except one (Koda-waki et al), intravenous injections of varying numbers of viable lymphocytes from genetically different individuals (allogenic cells) were given. It has been estimated that allogenic lymphocytes administered intravenously in a dose of 1 X 107/kg of body weight are sufficient to produce fatal runt disease in mice, and that lymphocytes in a dose of 6 X 107/kg can produce secondary disease in man."'1,1 Acute GVH reaction was produced in an infant with maternal bone-marrow lymphoid cells in a total dose of 2.9 x 10\s In the present case lymphocytes were given in a’dose of 2.8 X 107/kg (assuming 2,000 lymphocytes/cu mm in the donor blood). It has been shown'-1 that even 17-day-old bank blood contains viable lymphocytes capable of mitotic activity in tissue culture. Therefore, it is feasible that the single transfusion of 12-day-old blood given to our patient was adequate to invoke a GVH reaction.

The case of Kodawaki and associates3 and one of those of Hathaway et al' would appear to be chronic forms of runt disease in which gastrointestinal manifestations were the predominant symptoms. The other cases of Hathaway et a? and Miller3 and the present patient all demonstrated an acute form of GVH reaction in which hepatosplenomegaly,

1019 erythrodermia, and aplastic anemia were the prominent features. The case of Rosen and others’0 may have been another example of the acute GVH reaction following a transfusion of maternal bone marrow.

Although there are no pathologic changes which are specific for runt disease in the human, several findings illustrated by the cases in Table 2 should be emphasized. Most of the infants showed a severe pancytopenia and depletion of hemic elements in the bone marrow. A myeloid hyperplasia preceded the aplasia in the present case and was prominent in the case of Kodawaki et al. A myeloid hyperplasia followed by hypoplasia of all hemic elements is characteristic of severe animal runt disease (J.H. Githens et al, unpublished data).

Dyskeratosis of the skin (Fig 3), which has been ■ observed in all the cases in which a careful examination of the skin was made (including the present one), has been described as a very characteristic finding in human secondary disease.’4 Although these same changes may be seen in “autoimmune disease” such as disseminated lupus erythemato- ■ sus, when present, they are suggestive of a GVH reaction.”

Monocytoid cellular infiltration in the portal triads and hepatic cell necrosis are quite specific pathologic changes in mouse runt disease’"'"' and secondary disease in primates.’7 In mice, the sites of necrosis are limited to the subcapuslar regions; this type of necrosis was not seen in the present case, although a few, small, focal necrotic areas were noted. These were difficult to interpret since vaccinia virus may have also been an etiologic ■ agent. Mild monocytic cell infiltration of the portal triads was seen in this patient.

Monocytoid cell and histiocytic proliferation of the bone marrow, lymph nodes, and spleen was seen in the present case as well as in the other cases in Table 2. This finding is also characteristic of experimentally induced runt disease. However, cells staining positively with methyl green pyronin were seen infrequently in the cases of human runt disease although they are often described in experi-

§ Ellipsis indicates not known or not reported.


1020


mentally induced GVH reactions in animals, especially the dog?" In the present case as well as in several of the others erythrophagocytosis and phagocytosis of nuclear debris were present, findings which have been seen in animal runt disease.

Thus, on the basis of clinical, hematologic, and pathologic findings, the present case can be considered as an example of human runt disease oc-• curring in an infant with thymic alymphoplasia who received a single transfusion of whole blood. The propositus was also given exchange transfusions with blood obtained from recently vaccinated donors in an effort to administer large amounts of vaccinia antibody. This blood had been irradiated to decrease the risk of a GVH reaction; however, the amount of radiation given may not have been enough to render all lymphocytes nonviable."1 Nevertheless, the clinical manifestations of the GVH reaction were already present before the first exchange transfusion. Our patient was extremely ill with generalized vaccinia, but appeared to become worse with the development of the manifestations of runt disease.

This case study emphasizes the serious danger of administration of even small amounts of lymphocytes (ie, a single whole blood transfusion) to a ”4 patient with thymic alymphoplasia or one of the variants of this syndrome.

This study was supported in part by Public Health Service research grants AJ-04152 and AI-01632 and American Cancer Society grant T-138-F.

Ampicillin—Penbritin, Polycillin.

Methicillin—Dimocillin-RT, Staphcillin.

  • 18. Schlesinger, M.. and Esswer, E.: Histochemical and Elec-tronmicroseopic Studies of (he Liver in Runt Disease. Amer J Path 47:371-384 (Sept) 19(55.

  • 19. Arakawa, K., el al: The Uver in Murine Transplantation (Runt) Disease. Amer -I Path 49:257-299 (Aug) 19(56.

  • 20. Binci, J.L., and Mathc, G.: Optical and Electron microscope Studies of “Immunologically Competent Cells” in Graft Reactions,. Nature 193:992-993 (March 13) 1962.                              .

  • 21. Schrek. R., and Stefani, S.: Radioresisiance of Phytohemagglutinin-Treated Normal and Leukemic Lymphocytes, J Nat Cancer Inst 32:507-517 (Feb) 1964.

JAMA, Sept 25, 1967 ° Vol 201, No 13

Partial Immunodeficiency and Graft-versus-Host Disease

If patients with defective cellular immunity are transfused with immunologically competent cells (ICC), graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) may result. It has occurred in several children with severe combined immunodeficiency (Hong, Gatti, and Good, 1968), but only once in a child with partial immunodeficiency—Wiskott-Aldrich disease (Douglas and Fudenberg, 1969).

We describe a child with partially defective cellular and humoral immunity, who developed a fatal illness, probably GVHD, after a blood transfusion.

Case Report

The only daughter, birthweight 2940 g, of unrelated parents thrived until 5 months when an upper respiratory tract infection developed, progressing to bronchopneumonia. This partially responded to oral antibiotics, but anorexia, poor weight gain, and chronic diarrhoea persisted. When admitted to hospital aged 8 months, her weight was on the third centile; she passed 4 to 5 mucousy offensive stools daily, and had bilateral lower lobe pneumonia. The liver was 2 - 5 cm below the costal margin. The spleen was not felt; small axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymph nodes, and small tonsils were present. She had congenital right ptosis.

Her pneumonia improved on intramuscular antibiotics, but oral and cutaneous thrush developed, unresponsive to topical nystatin. Gastroenteritis (ErcA. coli 0126) responded to oral neomycin and colomycin.

ARCHIVES OF DISEASES OF CHILDHOOD

August 1971 48s248 pp 571 - 574

P 571


572


Short Reports


, Fig. I.—Blood cell countslmm3, immunoglobulin levels (% of M.R.C. research standard serum for immunoglobulins G, A and M), and clinical data.

Low levels of immunoglobulins were detected, and parenteral immunoglobulin was started; two infusions of hydroxystilbamidine cleared the candidiasis, and pentamidine was given intramuscularly for 14 days for suspected pneumocystis carinii. ' The pneumonia cleared but relapsed at 13 months. She responded again to intramuscular antibiotics and a course of pentamidine. At 15 months she was free of infection on lincomycin 50 mg b.d. orally, and immunoglobulin intramuscularly twice weekly. The diarrhoea persisted despite dietary exclusion of disaccharides, and her weight was static. Progressive anaemia at 15 months necessitated a 200 ml packed cell transfusion of 4-day-old acid citrate dextrose (ACD) blood, which was well tolerated. Aged 16 months she was transferred to Great Ormond Street for further investigation. Sequential haematological and immunological data are shown in Fig. 1. IgG was initially rather low, but rose above the level ascribable to the injections. IgM was normal, IgA low, and lymphocytes few, until the terminal illness. The haemoglobin fell progressively.

Other findings included norma! platelet counts, and marrow; reticulocytes l-4°„; scrum albumin 2-1— 3-4 g/100 ml; blood urea 40-165 mg/100 ml (on high protein diet); norma! urine; hypokalacmia; excess faecal disaccharides; cultures (including 3 blood cultures) grew no pathogens; patchy shadowing at bases on chest .x-ray; dilatation of small bowel on barium meal.

Immunological function tests included anti-E isohaemagglutinin (group A Rh 1/4; ASO 40 U/ml (45 days after stopping immunoglobulin); antidiphtheria antitoxin 0-16 U/ml and antitetanus antitoxin 0-64 U/ml about I year after two doses of triple antigen, and 80 days after stopping injections of immunoglobulin. Skin tests to candida antigen and to DNCB were weakly and doubtfully positive (biopsy of the latter showed no significant lymphocyte infiltration, and a burn cannot be excluded). Lymphocyte uptake of tritiated thymidine on phytohaemagglutinum (PHA) stimulation was significantly positive (counts/min unstimulated 486, 907, and 651; PHA stimulated 12,560, 4914, and 8684) though about tenfold less than parallel controls.

Over the ensuing 3 months the diarrhoea persisted despite numerous dietary manipulations, and she gained no weight. The immunoglobulin injections were discontinued, and she remained infection free on oral ampicillin, and her general condition improved. She was given KC1 for gut loss of K. Discharge was planned, and she was transfused for anaemia.

At 18 months a 200 ml packed cell transfusion of 6-day old ACD blood from a female dohor was given. Seven days later, pyrexia and a macular erythematous rash developed; this was attributed to ampicillin which was stopped. The fever persisted, the rash became confluent with generalized subcutaneous oedema, and striking generalized lymph node enlargement. There was a conspicuous fall in polymorphs and thrombocytes, marrow aplasia, and rise in immunoglobulins and lymphocytes (Fig. 1); the direct antiglobulin test was negative. She rapidly deteriorated and died in peripheral vascular collapse 15 days after transfusion. GVHD was diagnosed clinically.

At necropsy the lymph nodes were of normal size and distribution; the thymus was small (2-0 g). The lungs were clear; there was some small bowel dilatation, but no other macroscopical abnormalities. Histologically, the thymus showed typical thymic dysplasia (Fig. 2). The lymph nodes were hypocellukir without follicular differentiation. There were very small amounts of organized tissue in the appendix and ileum; there was no lymphoid tissue in the tonsils. The spleen contained plasma cells but no lymphoid follicles.

573


Short Reports

Fig. 2.—Thymus (H. and E.


100'), showing absence of Hassall's corpuscles and poor reticular cell differentiation.


The marrow was aplastic, but contained many plasma cells and large macrophages. There were phagocytic large macrophages deep in the dermis.

Discussion

Deficiencies of individual immunological functions may occur in a wide range of combinations in any individual patient. Our child showed antibody response and cutaneous delayed hypersensitivity, and had measurable but reduced immunoglobulin levels, lymphocyte count, and lymphocyte transformation to PHA, in contrast to severe combined immunodeficiency cases, where all these parameters are usually grossly deficient.

The morbid anatomical findings were similar to those in severe combined immunodeficiency which is usually fatal in infancy (Berry, 1970) ; it is interesting that such findings may be compatible with measurable immunological function. Plasma cells in the marrow, and actively phagocytic macrophages in the marrow and skin, seen in our case, are not usual in severe combined immunodeficiency, and are suggestive of GVHD, though they could be related to her partial immunological function. Other features of GVHD (histiocytic infiltration of the reticuloendothelial system and erythro-phagocytosis) were absent. Unfortunately, both the donor and the recipient were female, so we were unable to demonstrate chimerism by chromosome studies.

The clinical course of her terminal illness was very similar to GVHD in animals, adults, and children with severe combined immunodeficiency.

In the latter it has followed transfusion of fresh blood, plasma, or marrow cells, given either for transfusion purposes, or as an attempt at radical treatment (Hathaway et al., 1965; Miller, 1967; Hong et al., 1968; Gatti et al., 1968; Kretschmer et al., 1969). In such patients, and in the case of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (Douglas and Fuden-berg, 1969) GVHD has always been fatal, except when partly tissue-matched sib marrow has been infused.

Lymphocytes are capable of mitotic activity in vitro after 3 weeks storage in ACD blood (McCullough et al., 1969), and so are presumably capable of causing GVHD. The risk of blood, fresh or stored, to patients with severe combined immunodeficiency is well recognized. GVHD apparently following transfusion of stored blood in the presence of measurable humoral and cellular immunity in our patient suggests that blood transfusions should be avoided wherever possible in a wider range of patients with immunodeficiency. If unavoidable, old irradiated washed cells should be given.

574                                   Short Reports

Summary

After transfusion with stored blood, a girl with partial immunodeficiency developed a fatal illness which was probably graft-versus-host disease.

We thank Professor O. H. Wolff, under whose care the child was studied, and Professor R. M. Hardisty for the haematological data. Requests for reprints to J.F.S. This case was presented to the Paediatric Section of the Royal Society of Medicine 27 February 1970.

Medical Journal


UNCONTROLLABLE POST-OPERATIVE HAEMORRHAGE AFTER INCOMPATIBLE BLOOD TRANSFUSION

BY

JAMES M, MOORE, F.R.C.S.EJ., F.R.F.F.S.

Senior Registrar, Hairmyres Hospital, East Kilbride

It has often been reported that a defect of coagulation may occur in obstetrical conditions and in pulmonary and.pro.static surgery. For example, it has been noted in accidental haemorrhage, amniotic fluid embolism, intrauterine foetal death, and missed abortion (De Lee, 1901 ; Dieckmann, 1936; Moloney et al., 1949; Schneider, 1951 ; Reid et al., 1953 ; Barry et al., 1955), following pulmonary lobectomy (Soulier et al., 1952), and in metastatic carcinoma of the prostate (Tagnon et al., 1952; Swan et al., 1957). One of the features of these cases has been hypofibrinogenaemia.

That abnormal bleeding may occur as a transfusion reaction is not so^wnrTnow^^aith^ugfi^iFlias’Teen' recorded by American authors on a number of occasions since it was mentioned by Drinker and Brittingham (1919). Muirhead (1951) found nine cases, while Friesen et al. (1952) investigated 11. Other examples are given by Wiener (1954) and Stefanini and Dameshek (1955). Krevans et al. (1957) studied two instances, and in a survey of the literature found 11 additional reports. No report of a case has been traced in British literature, although Moliison (1956) refers to the condition.

It is the object of this paper to give a clinical account of such a case which had a fatal termination.

Case Report ~

The patient was a single woman aged 25 suffering from a chronic gastric ulcer. In the past she had undergone appendicectomy and tonsillectomy, and sio excessive bleeding had been noted. Menstrual blood loss had been normal. There was no history suggestive of any allergib upset.

Operation.—A Billroth i partial gastrectomy was carried ■out, and it was uneventful. The anaesthetic consisted of

1201 thiopentone sodium, tubocurarine chloride, gallamine tri-ethiodide, and nitrous oxide, and a pint (540 ml.) of carefully matched homologous group O rhesus-negative blood was given. The operation was completed at 12 noon,

A second bottle of blood was started at 12.30 p.m. When examined 15 minutes later the patient was rather pale, with a slight cyanotic tinge, and there was a little staining from a stab drainage wound. There was little change during the next two hours. At 2.45 p.m.. when about two-thirds of the second bottle of blood (360 ml.) bad been given, it was discovered that it was in fact group A rhesus-positive blood wSlch~°haT~uinadvertently been transfused,"' "immediately, carefully matched "bloodlot the correct group was substituted and 1 pint (540 mi.) of 50% dextrose given in an attempt to minimize renal complications.

At 4 p.m it was noted that venous blood sent for further cross-matching would not clot, and by then there was considerable fresh bleeding from the stab wound. Only a small amount of altered bloocThad 'been aspirated from the gastric tube during the afternoon, but at 6 p.m. there was 15 oz. (450 ml.) of fresh blood and the main wound had started to ooze. The patient became weaker despite continued transfusion* and 'another laparotomy" was carried out at 7A3“pmrr.

Second Operation.—About 4 pints (2 litres) of blood was found in the peritoneal cavity with a few clots. There was a general ooze from many areas involved in the previous operation. On opening the stomach more blood escaped, but again this arose from numerous areas, many not at the suture lines. Despite all attempts at haemostasis the ooze continued. The supply of matched blood'for transfusion was temporarily exhausted during the operation, and 2 pints (1 litre) of 6% dextran in saline (“dextraven” and “ intradex ”) was given. As nothing further of benefit could be done, the stomach opening was repaired and the abdomen , closed with two drainage tubes.

It was now obvious that the patient had developed, an abnofmaTfiaejnorrhagic tendency.'

Treatment.—4 ml. of “ adrenoxyl ” (1.5 mg. of adrenochrome monosemicarbazone dihydrate) and 100 mg. of vitamin K analogue (“ synkavit’’) were given intramuscularly. IC ml. of 10% calcium gluconate was given intravenously and a rapid transfusion of matched group O rhesus-negative ■ blood continued. After consultation with the director of the regional transfusion centre at 10 p.m. the patient was given 4 pints (2 litres) of fresh dried plasma alternating with blood, and 2 g. of concentrated fibrinogen fraction. At this stage there appeared to be a slight temporary decrease in the rate of blood loss. Fresh frozen plasma was requested for her, but her condition deteriorated and she died at 1.45 a.m. on the day following operation, before it could be given.

She had received a total of 17 pints (9 litres) of blood, 3 pints (1.5 litres) of processed plasma."ancTTpintsTl'litre) or dextran7'a's well as the 4 pints (2 litres) of fresh dried plasma and fibrinogen mentioned above. In all, this repre--sents the administration of approximately 20 g. of fibrinogen, of which half had been given after the haemorrhagic defect had been recognized. In spite of this, up to the time of death, bleeding continued from' thTTfrarna^Tuoesintne abdomen and from the~gast'ric tube.

Relevant Post-mortem Findings

There was a large amount of blood and clot in the peritoneal cavity. The stomach was filled with a well-formed clot equivalent io about a pint (0.5 litre) of blood. No open vessels were identified, but there appeared to have been diffuse haemorrhage from the gastric mucosa, in which there were numerous slit-like defects several millimetres in length apparently communicating with submucosal haematomata. The liver and spleen were normal. Histological examination of kidney showed amorphous eosinophilic material, and desquamated epithelial cells in a few convoluted tubules. The lungs appeared oedematous, but there

1202                          .   .

Nov. 15, 1958 UNCONTROLLABLE HAEMORRHAGE AFTER TRANSFUSION

were no histological changes, and selective staining showed no significant intravascular deposits of fibrin.

Blood Examination.—A specimen of venous blood taken at 3.30 p.m, on the day of operation failed to clot in 24 hours, even after the addition of thrombin in excess, indicating afibrinogenaemia. Marked haemoglobinaemia was noted soon after withdrawal, proving rapid destruction of the incompatible blood. A similar specimen taken two days before operation clotted normally.

Investigations at the regional transfusion centre confirmed that the patient was group O, rhesus negative, and that she had received group A blood, which had been rapidiy destroyed. The pre-transfusion serum of the patient contained an anti-A haemolysin, and it was considered that this was responsible for the rapid haemolysis of the incompatible cells.

Discussion

The patient undoubtedly developed a haemorrhagic defect associated with afibrinogenaemia. The development of hypofibrinogenaemia has been described by Stefanini and Dameshek (1955). Among the conditions mentioned as leading to the syndrome are haemorrhagic shock and haemolytic transfusion reactions. The patient's condition was good immediately after operation, which had not been associated with significant loss of blood. Therefore, even if haemorrhagic shock can produce such a syndrome, it seems unlikely that it was initially responsible for the onset of the fibrinogen deficiency in this case. The trigger mechanism was almost certainly the transfusion of blood of the wrong group.

Acquired hypofibrinogenaemia might theoretically result from (a) defective formation of fibrinogen ; (6) intravascular clotting following the entrance of thromboplastic material into the circulation, with consumption of fibrinogen; or (c) depletion of fibrinogen by fibrinolytic or proteolytic enzymes in the blood. In this case it is unlikely that there was any defect in the formation of fibrinogen, as there was no evidence of impaired fiver function. It is possible that intravascular clotting was the cause of the haemorrhagic state, because Quick et al. (1954) have demonstrated the thromboplastin-like activity of lysed red blood cells. However, there was no evidence histologically of abnormal fibrin deposition in tissues; nevertheless a fibrin deposit could have been destroyed by fibrinolytic enzymes, the presence of which has been reported in some cases of this syndrome.

The response to treatment was disappointing although there was post-mortem evidence of clotting, Stefanini and Damashek (1955) suggested that the average amount of fibrinogen required in treatment was 2-4 g., but mentioned that 8-20 g, might be necessary, Barry et al. (1955) recommended 2-6 g. of the fibrinogen fraction in the treatment of hypofibrinogenaemia of pregnancy, but if this was not available found triple- or quadruple-strength raw plasma equally effective (1 pint (0.5 litre) of the latter strength yielding 4.4 g. of fibrinogen). In this case approximately 10 g. of fibrinogen was given after the haemorrhagic defect had been recognized, but it is possible that this amount might have produced a greater effect if more of the fibrinogen had been in a concentrated form and had been administered over a shorter period. However, the failure of the patient to ’ respond suggests that there may well have been additional factors involved.

Other coagulation elements may have been absent or diminished—for example, prothrombin. Factor V, and platelets (Green wait and Triantaphyllopoulos, 1954). Krevens et al. (1957) studied two patients after 500 ml, of incompatible blood and in both found hypofibrinogenaemia, hypoprothrombinaemia, and thrombocytopenia, with reduction of Factor V activity in one, (Incidentally, they could find no evidence of increased fibrinolytic activity, and favoured intravascular coagulation as a probable cause of these changes.) In treatment they advised fresh whole blood supplemented by fibrinogen. It may be that the fresh frozen plasma, containing some of these factors, would have been of benefit.

Two pints (1 litre) of dextran 6% in saline was given when matched blood and plasma were temporarily unavailable. In retrospect it is clear that this was inadvisable, as a number of reports have incriminated dextran as a cause of a haemorrhagic tendency (Carbone et al., 1954 ; Scott, 1955 ; McKenzie and Langlands, 1956). The mechanism of the process is not clear, and suggestions made include interaction of dextran with fibrinogen, haemodilution, production of thrombocytopenia, and prolongation of the bleeding-fime. The patient, of' course, had developed abnormal bleeding before the dextran was given, but it is possible that the dextran aggravated the haemorrhagic tendency.

Friesen et al. (1952) described similar cases in which postoperative bleeding occurred as a result of a haemolytic transfusion reaction, when over 250 mi. of incompatible blood had been given. They felt that fibrinolysis was an important factor, but considered that a “ heparinoid disturbance ” was present. Toluidine-blue dye, given intravenously to two patients in a dosage of 15 mg. per kg. of body weight, apparently corrected the bleeding tendency. Such treatment might be worthy of a trial in any refractory case.

Treatment with corticotrophin (200 units intramuscularly) • or cortisone (400 mg. intravenously) has been recommended, in addition to fibrinogen, by Stefanini and Dameshek (1955).

If the possibility of a bleeding state after incompatible transfusion had been known, the second laparotomy would probably not have been carried out, and appropriate treatment might have been started earlier.

Summary and Conclusions

A case is described in which there was fatal postoperative bleeding, associated with afibrinogenaemia, following a haemolytic transfusion reaction.

Treatment is discussed, and the following points may be of value in controlling such a condition: (1) early recognition of the fact that a haemorrhagic state has developed ; (2) administration of large amounts of the fibrinogen fraction—for example, 2-6 g., repeated if necessary—or the use of quadruple-strength reconstituted raw dried plasma if fibrinogen is not available ; (3) fresh frozen plasma, or fresh blood, if there is a poor response to adequate fibrinogen ; (4) avoidance of dextran ; (5) corticotrophin, cort'sone, or toluidine-blue dye intravenously, if not Responding.

I am grateful to Dr. John Wallace, the director of the West of . Scotland Regional Transfusion Centre, and Dr. A. S. Douglas for their assistance and advice. I should like to thank Mr. K. I. Macrossan for permission to publish details of this case.

THE BRITISH JOURNAL OF CLINICAL PRACTICE

1

Virus Hepatitis after Blood Transfusion

A. J. ZUCKERMAN, mi>, m.sc, m.g.path, dip.bact.

Reader in Virology,              .

London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, London

Infectious and serum hepatitis may be transmitted by any procedure that exposes a person to the blood or tissues of a carrier of the virus of hepatitis. Thus hepatitis may he transmitted not only by contaminated syringesand needles in medical and dental practice, by the transfusion of blood and blood products, by tissue and organ grafts but also by non-medieal procedures including accidental scratches and cuts, tattooing, the barber’s razor and Acupuncture. Mosley (1966) wrote that virus hepatitis is now the most important complication of the transfusion of blood and blood products, a fact that is perhaps not so widely appreciated.

In the early years of World War II it became apparent that high attack rates of hepatitis were associated with the transfusion of certain pools of human plasma. Presumptive evidence of the transmission of this infection by blood transfusion was noted as soon as the practice of transfusion became more widespread. The concept however of two distinct disease entities with widely varying incubation periods was accepted until 1962 when Allen & Sayman found-that in almost 51 per cent of transfusion-associated hepatitis the incubation period was less than 60 days. Possibly the more important aspect of Allen & Sayman’s work was that it stimulated the systematic observation, at least in some hospitals, of patients who received blood transfusion but there continues to be considerable controversy over just how common hepatitis may be.

In 1963 in the United States it was roughly calculated that about 1.8 million transfusions were given and it has been estimated that the incidence of clinical hepatitis associated with transfusion was 30,000 cases with nearly 3600 deaths. 11 should be particularly noted that no account was taken of the incidence of the anicteric form of hepatitis for which, in general, the accepted ratio is 1 overt case of jaundice for at least 10 actual infections, although in 1964 it was estimated that the true ratio of anicteric to icteric hepatitis after blood transfusion could be greater than 100 : 1 (Hampers et al. 1964). The figures for post-transfusion hepatitis, both in the icteric and the anicteric form, published from a number of centres in Germany, Japan and the United States are remarkably high. Thus in a recent careful study in Germany Crcntzicldt et <7/. (1966) found the overall a Hack rate of post-transfusion hepatitis to be 14 per cent. A much higher incidence based on the elevation of serum transaminase activity, which is admittedly not specific, was noted by Shimuzu & Kitamoto (1963) in Japan with an attack rate of 600 cases of hepatitis per 10,000 units of blood. Hampers’ figures from Philadelphia (1964) gave an incidence of 870 cases per 10,000 units of blood. Recent figures in this country are not available but in 1949 Lehane et al. obtained an incidence of 0.8 per cent of jaundice after whole blood transfusion and the 1954 survey revealed an incidence of only 0.16 per cent in England and Wales and 0.36 per cent in Scotland. The frequency of anicteric hepatitis in the United Kingdom is not known, and at any rate it should be noted that in the early surveys the more accurate of the nonspecific tests of liver damage such as the serum transaminases were not available. There is no reason to suppose that the incidence of transfusion hepatitis would be very much lower than those observed elsewhere even though commercially-supplied blood is not used in this country.

The overall mortality from post-transfusion hepatitis has been variously reported as 0.9 per cent (Allen & Sayman 1962); 2 per cent (Grossman et al. 1945); 12 per cent (Grady ct al. 1964); and 27.5 per cent (Ratnoff et al. 1965). The morbidity and complications following serum hepatitis are probably similar to those which may follow infectious hepatitis, although no actual figures are as yet available for transfusion-hepatitis.

Reduction in the severity, but probably not incidence, of post-transfusion hepatitis has been reported by the prophylactic administration of gamma-globulin. However the routine use of gamma globulin with blood transfusion would rapidly exhaust the world supplies of this material. The risk of hepatitis in a recipient of blood in-

10


THE


BRITISH JOURNAL OF CLINICAL PRACTICE


creases with the number of transfusions ' Allen & Sayman 1962). In their excellent survey Creutzfeldt et al. (1966) go even further in stating that the number of units of blood transfused is the decisive factor influencing the risk of hepatitis. Sex, age, primary disorder of the patient and transaminase level of the blood donor had no significant effect on the incidence of transfusion hepatitis. Therefore reduction in the risk of hepatitis can be. achieved by the judicious use of blood and the substitution of hepatitis-free blood derivatives. Note however that Mosley (1965) found that single-unit transfusions accounted for 16.9 per cent of all patients with transfusion-associated hepatitis. In the absence of specific laboratory tests for the virus of hepatitis the meticulous screening of potential blood donors and the avoidance of commercially obtained blood must continue.

Finally it should be noted that the risk of the parenteral transmission of virus hepatitis is not restricted to whole blood. Pooled human plasma carries an even higher risk than whole blood and the risk of hepatitis increases with the size of the pool. Similar observations apply to fibrinogen, and Mosley (1965) quotes the proportion .of hepatitis associated with fibrinogen as 35 times greater than among patients transfused with whole blood at two large hospitals in the United States. It also appears that the attack rate of hepatitis is related to the size of the pool from which the fibrinogen is prepared. The risk with the use of antihaemo-philic globulin is believed to be similar to that from fibrinogen. Thrombin also carries the risk of transmitting hepatitis. Gamma-globulin, stable plasma protein solution, albumen, fibrin foam and plasminogen appropriately treated are free of infective hepatitis virus (W.H.O. 1964).

Any approach to the prevention and study of an infection requires initially information about the number and type of cases. Therefore, we require in this country basic epidemiological information on transfusion-hepatitis such as the incidence of the disease, the morbidity and mortality, and to be able to define the high risk patients. This can only be achieved by systematic observation And follow-up of all patients who receive transfusions of blood and blood products.

REFERENCES

FDA FINDS HOLES HEPATfflS SCREEN

The Russian roulette aspect of whoie blood transfusion—with hepatitis as . the lethal bullet—is~a"nightmare that physicians will have to live with for some time to come.

And for the cardiovascular surgery patient or the hemophiliac who gets large amounts of biood, there will continue to be added danger. Dr. Howard F. Taswell, director of the Mayo Clinic biood bank, has determined that out of 5,000 cardiovascular surgery patients, five, or one per 1,000. died from post-transfusion hepatitis.               ■

To help tip the odds in favor of patients, the FDA is stepping up its

■The Spectator

Tuesday, June 27, 1072 65

Biood donor dimes cut in prisons ;

TORONTO (CP) - A Red Cross official said yesterday blood _ doser rimes kt most Ontario pris&ns~~Tiave beeu ,at least, temporarily because tests _ have revealed ~ a~^ffl~incldence~of serum hepatitis in samples 'of ^sonei# .   -------

Dr. STSTTiemaj), assistant national director of blood transfusion services for the Red Cross, said it is likely : that some of the clinics never will be reopened, although it is hoped most will. regulatory program of blood banks (MWN, Sept. 15). Dr. Harry M. Meyer Jr., director of the FDA's Bureau of Biologies, has just released the re- ' suits of a tough test of the proficiency of banks under direct federal supervision in detecting hepatitis B antigen.

The 250 tested banks, about 5% of the total number of blood facilities in the U.S., each received a panel of 20 coded samples. Each panel contained duplicate samples of seven sera reactive for hepatitis B antigenranging from very strong to very weak—and six samples of nonreactive sera. With the exception of two borderline samples, the buieau's labs were able to detect all positives by counterelectropho’-esis using commercial reagents

He declined to give the ex- । act number of prisons affect- j ed by the discontinuation. ■

Dr. Tieman said about 2,0(10 I units of blood were collected I last year from Ontario institutions, but the loss of such clinics likely would not ser- ; iously affect the overall); collection of blood in the ji province.                       i

The Red'Cross began test- | ing blood for 'serum hepatitis ' last year.

Dr. Tieman said such tests show the incidence of the di- 1 sease to be much higher in prisons than among the general public. He said the disease — as opposed to infee-• tious hepatitis — often is linked to the us® of drugs and comes about through the use of a contaminated needle.

He indicated that the situation in Ontario appears worse than elsewhere in Canada. j


But granted that only 25% or 30% of hepatitis cases are Au-antigenpositive to begin with, the tested banks failed miserably in detecting the positive samples. Only 14 banks scored 100% correct in the test. An example of the inefficiency: 11 banks caught seven or fewer of the 14 positives, and two of these banks only caught four. Correct responses on individual samples ran from a tow of 1.6% of the banks on weak samples, to 100% for the two strongly positive samples.

Erring on the safe side, a few banks labelled nonreactive samples as positive. Reproducibility was spotty when checked by duplicate positives—very few of the banks detected both of the very weak samples. On the other hand, 99.5% caught both very strong sera samples.

Dr. Meyer’s results leave Au antigen screening programs in a tenuous position. But the bureau is taking some remedial steps. With another set of samples, FDA inspectors went to those labs that missed definitely positive sera—to observe the labs in action and detect procedural errors.

The test will be repeated periodically by the FDA to try to improve the blood screening picture.

206


Pag® 25


R Th® Spectatora Jmataary 28/?2


CHP-64



TORONTO — About 22 of every 10,000 people who donate blood in Canada are capable of giving serum hepatitis to people who receive their blood, the first results of a new Red Cross screening program show.

In western Quebec, the rate rises to 47 per 10.000, and in penitentiaries, 87. The lowest rate, eight per 10,000, is found in rural areas.

SERUM HEPATITIS is a liver inflammation, often called jaundice, that is most frequently passed from person to person by either blood transfusion or the use of a hypodermic needle that hasn’t been sterilized between uses by different people.

It is believed caused by a virus-like particle in the blood, called Australia antigen or hepatitis-associated antigen (HAA). HAA is in the blood of a person both before and after an attack of hepatitis, but it can also exist in carriers who never have any symptoms.

A year ago, the Red Cross started screening ah its 1olood' donations for HAXTSc" screening system has been extended toTFregionaI centres. The Hamilton blood bank was included earlier this month.

THE SCREENING PROGRAM has given Canada its first accurate figures on the incidence of HAA, and as a byproduct, an index to the level

of public health in various areas. High HAA rates are found in slums, among drug users and alcoholics.

Dr. B. P. L, Moore, director of the national reference "library of" Sie Canadian Red Cross blood transfusion service, presented the study results yesterday to the Royal College of Physi- ■ cians and Surgeons.

He said that although the lab techniques for detecting HAA are not yet accurate~enough to* detect' more" ffiai f 59 pef'ceriV'bf IIAA camels.' even this amount couldreSuce the riumber_of hepatitis cases iri"'peopie who receive the“Tflbo<r~Eiv 800 a year.

Based on figures from volunteer donors in other countries, it is estimated that a maximum

ELEVEN OF the 15 regional centres are also testing for antibody to HAA, and thio blood is also considered unacceptable for transfusions. Antibody is a defensive substance which the body makes to combat a foreign antigen.

The fact that a person has hepatitis antibody would indicate that at one time he had the antigen, even if it can’t be detected now. There is no evidence that a person could transmit the disease just because he has antibody in his blood, but the Red Cosss has decided to "play it safe and not use this blood, either.

When two lab tests confirm that HAA is in a blood donation, the donor gets a letter asking for the name of his doctor and the doctor is notified of the find so that he can check the donor for liver disease. The donor also is told that he cannot donate again. The HAA blood is then stored for research purposes.

DR. MOORE SAID the first survey results have just been compiled, and no detailed analysis has been made of the regional differences in HAA findings.

Excluding the Quebec figures, the incidence is 13 for each 10,000 donors from Ontario to B.C. but in university and high school students it is 19 and 20, another unexplained difference.

Original Articles

Vol 102 No 2

burgery


Pulmonary Edema F olio wing

Blood Transfusion Reaction

James P. Byrne, Jr., MD, Salt Lake City, and John A. Dixon, MD, Ogden, Utah

Severe pulmonary edema was observed rn two patients-'following blood transfusion reactions. The amount of blood transfused was small and there zcas no evidence of fluid overload in either patient. The roentgenographic appearance is one of bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of interstitial edema. Hemolysis of erythrocytes with release of substances causing constriction of pulmonary arterioles or venules, or intravascular coagulation are possible. pathophysiologic mechanisms. Therapy consists of the usual respiratory support measures. Dextran 40, heparin sodium, and isoproterenol may be of benefit.

We have recently observed the occurrence or"~s~evere "anti potentially fatal pulmonary edema in two patients following blood transfusion reaction. Pulmonary edema is a well-known complication following blood transfusion when it is due to overload of the intravascular compartment or embolization of particulate matter contained in the transfused blood during massive

Accepted for publication Sept 23, 1070, From the University Surgical Service, McKay-Dee Hospital Center, Ogden, Utah (Dr. Dixon) and the Department of Surgery, University of Utah College of Medicine. Salt Lake City (Dr. Byrne).

Reprint requests to University Hospital, Box 30, Salt Imke City 81112 (Dr. Byrne).

transfusion therapy.1'2 Both of our patients received small amounts of bfoody both were young, and neither ' had evidence of preexisting cardiopulmonary disease. There ""vaijTno J evidence of fluid overload" in either w patient.                              ~~

The purposes of this communication are to report these cases, review the literature that is available on this entity, and to discuss the pathophysiology and treatment.

Report of Cases

Case 1.—A 34-year-old man was transferred to the McKay Hospital, Ogden, Utah, on Feb 16, 1970, for treatment of an upper-gastrointestinal tract hemorrhage. He had a ten-year history of duodenal ulcer disease proven on a previous series of x-ray films of the upper-gastrointestinal tract. One year previously he had been hospitalized for the same reason and had received 3 units of whole blood. While receiving the third unit the patient developed chills and fever and was told he had experienced a transfusion reaction.

On Feb II, 1970, the patient experienced melena and was hospitalized elsewhere on Feb 14, 1970. He received 3 units of whole blood and the gastric aspirate became clear. On Feb 16, 1970, hemorrhage again occurred. The patient became transiently hypotensive but following 2 units of whole blood the blood pressure returned to normal. Immediately after receiving

CPE-51


Fig 1.—Four hours following transfusion reaction there are bilateral patchy densities (case 1}.


Fig 2.—Eight hours following reaction minimal clearing ’ has taken place (case 1).

* Patient inspiring oxygen via nasal cannula.



Fig 3.—Progressive clearing of infiltrates (case 1).


Fig 4.—Four hours following blood transfusion reaction characteristic patchy densities are present and most pronounced in right lung (case 2).


the second unit he experienced a severe shaking chill and became febrile. Two hours later he was transferred to the McKay Hospital,

On admission to the intensive care unit the patient was in acute distress, and was having a severe shaking chill. His rectal temperature was 103.8 F (39.8 C). Intercostal retractions were present and the patient was hyper-pneic and tachypneic with a respiration rate of 40 per minute. Auscultation of the chest revealed diffuse bilateral moist rales. The nail beds were cyanotic. The hematocrit value was 43%, and the white blood cell count was 17,300 cu mm. An x-ray film of the chest revealed bilateral patchy infiltrates in both lung fields with Kerley’s B lines (Fig 1). Serum bilirubin level was 2.9 mg/100 ml. The urine did not contain free hemoglobin. Prothrombin time was 15 seconds for the patient and'12 seconds for the control. The platelet count was normal. Direct and indirect, Coombs’ reactions were negative. The eosinophil count was normal and the serum fibrinogen level was 100 to 200 mg/100 ml (normal, > 200 mg/ 100 ml in our laboratory). Blood volume was 6.5 liters measured, 5.7 liters estimated normal. The patient was begun on a regimen of intravenously administered steroids and dextran 40.

He became increasingly tachypneic with respirations of 56 per minute and developed an almost continuous cough productive of copious amounts of white frothy sputum. The central venous pressure was 4 cm HoO. The course of the blood gases is depicted in the Table. Respirations were assisted with a pressure cycled apparatus. Following blood and sputum cultures he was begun on a regimen of broad-spectrum antibiotics because of suspected pneumonia. The blood culture -was negative and the sputum culture produced a scant growth of Staphylococcus aureus. The temperature returned to normal the afternoon of admission. During the next three days the x-ray films gradually cleared and the blood gases returned to normal levels( Fig 2 and 3). Gastrointestinal bleeding did not recur. The ABO and Rh typing were checked and found to be correct. It was not possible to obtain a sample of the blood given.

Case 2.—A 16-vear-old boy sustained a .22-caliber bullet wound to the left axilla. "When seen in the emergency room his vital signs were normal. A rapidly expanding hematoma was apparent. There were diminished pulsations of the ulnar and radial arteries and motor and sensory loss in the median nerve distribution. The hematocrit, value was 40%, and an x-ray film of the chest was normal.

The patient was taken io the operating room and the wound was explored. The axillary artery was found to be completely transected and thrombosed? The damaged portion of artery was excised and a saphenous vein graft was placed. Two units of blood were given during operation. No problems were noted until on the fourth postoperative day when the hematocrit value was found to be 27%, Two units of blood were given. Shortly after completion of the second unit he had a severe shaking chill and developed a persistent cough productive of blood-tinged, frothy sputum. Respirations became rapid and he complained of chest pain. Auscultation of the chest revealed diffuse moist rales and wheezes. An x-ray film of the chest (Fig 4 and 5) revealed bilateral patchy infiltrates. Pulmonary emboli arising from the axillary vein were suspected but an axillary venogram was normal. Blood volume determination revealed a measured volume of 4.2 liters compared to 4.5 liters estimated normal. The patient was given heparin sodium. X-ray films of the chest 24 hours later revealed extensive clearing of the lungs and 48 hours after the reaction was almost completely clear. Five days after the reaction the x-ray film of the chest was normal and the patient was discharged.

Comment

The criteria which suggest a type of pulmonary edema secondary to blood transfusion as an entity other than simple overload of the intravascular space are the clinical setting and the distribution of the edema on x-ray film. All of the cases reported have occurred in patients who wore clearly not fluid overloaded but were hypovolemic as judged by calculation of fluid deficit, presence of orthostatic hypotension or a low central venous pressure. The x-ray film of the chest has revealed a picture of patchy infiltrates which are not perihilar as is usually seen in fluid overload or heart failure, but are present throughout the lungs. The edema is interstitial as evidenced by the presence of Kerley’s B lines as in case 1.

Barnard’’ first reported the case of a leukemic patient who developed pulmonary edema following the transfusion of one unit of blood and died. lie called this a hypersensitivity reaction but had no clinical or rocntgenographic evidence to clearly establish the case as a hew entity. Gould and Torrance36 in a review of 100 cases of pulmonary edema diagnosed on x-ray film of the chest,

Fig 5.—Progressive cfearing during ensuing 48 hours (case 2).


reported one case which occurred following a blood transfusion reaction. The edema was patchy throughout the lungs but they did not comment on the clinical setting. Hirsch and Caracta5 reported a patient with pernicious anemia who developed acute pulmonary edema while receiving a second unit of packed cells. The patient died and it was not possible to obtain roentgenograms or an autopsy. Philipps and Fleischner** reported three cases in which the patients were clearly hypovolemic and developed pulmonary edema which was documented on x-ray film of the chest and was present throughout the lungs. Ward et al” reported a similar case.

All of the cases of this syndrome so far recorded have described a similar situation; while receiving 1 or 2 units of blood the patient develops severe chills and a high fever. A cough productive of frothy sputum and tachypnea follows. There is either rapid progression to death or spontaneous resolution during three to five days.

The exact pathophysiology of this syndrome is unknown. An acute hypersensitivity response secondary to homologous blood is one of the most likely explanations. In the case reported by Ward et al,7 the patient developed urticaria and presumably a similar response could have occurred in the pulmonary capillaries. They also found a high titer of antileukocyte antibodies in their patient’s serum.

Arch Surg/Vol 102, Feb 1971


Transfusion Reaction/Byrne & Dixon


93


Diffuse intravascular coagulation is another etiology to be considered. Erythrocytes are known to contain large amounts of thromboplastin and hemolysis could release this factor and begin the coagulation process. As transfused blood is diluted very little before it reaches the lungs, this organ might be expected to react more actively than others. In case 1, the elevated bilirubin level suggests that hemolysis did take place and the prolonged prothrombin time and diminished serum fibrinogen level suggest that intravascular coagulation also occurred. However, a decrease in platelets was not noted. Hardaway8 found microthrombi and edema in the lungs of dogs dying of incompatible blood transfusions. Blaisdell et al8 have demonstrated the occurrence of intravascular coagulation in patients dying of post-traumatic pulmonary insufficiency secondary to interstitial edema and intra-alveolar hemorrhage. They postulate that tissue destruction causes release of tissue thromboplastin which initiates the coagulopathy.

This same mechanism, may account for the "postperfusion lung” seen following use of the pump oxygenator. Grant et al10 have demonstrated increased thromboplastin in the blood of patients following cardiopulmonary bypass. Allardyce et al36 37 have shown that microemboli occur during venovenous perfusion in dogs and occlude the pulmonary capillaries. This did not occur with venoarterial perfusion. However, they also noted a marked decrease in the occurrence of such emboli if dextran was added to the pump prime.

Vasoconstriction is another mechanism whereby diffuse pulmonary edema may occur following transfusion reactions. In a series of experiments in sheep, Halmagyi et al12 produced a marked increase in pulmonary arterial wedge pressure following injection of incompatible homologous and heterologous blood and various components of red blood cells. They postulate that destruction of red blood cells releases a substance which causes constriction of the arterioles and possibly also the venules. Veith et al13 have presented morphologic and functional evidence to show that pulmonary arteriolar constriction is the common mechanism underlying pulmonary damage secondary to shock, transfusion reaction, and pump-oxygenator procedures. Schramel et al14 and Keller et al1B noted the occurrence of hemorrhagic lung lesions following venovenous perfusion in dogs. They demonstrated increased pressure in the small pulmonary veins and suggested that venular constriction leads to engorgement and rupture of pulmonary capillaries.

Thus the basic abnormality underlying the pulmonary pathology noted in the two cases reported would appear to be obstruction to blood flow through pulmonary arte-

References

LP: Pulmonary hypersensitivity reaction after blood transfusion. Arch Intern Med 122:362-366, 1968.

  • 8. Hardaway RM; A Sasahara and M Stein (eds): Pulmonary Microthrombi in Pulmonary Embolic Disease. New York, Grune & Stratton Inc, 1965, pp 65-73.

  • 9. Blaisdell FW, Lion RG, Stallone RJ: The mechanism of pulmonary damage following traumatic shock. Surg Gynec Obstet 130:15-22, 1970. ' 10. Grant H, Siegel DU, Lillehei CW: I. Problems in hemostasis during open heart surgery: II. On the hyper-coaguloability of blood during cardiac by-pass. Ann Surg 156:14-33, 1962.

  • 11. Allardyce DB, Yoshida SII, Ashmore PG: The importance of microembolism in the pathogenesis of organ dysfunction caused by prolonged use of the pump oxygenator. J Thorac Cardiovasc Surg 52:706-716, 1966.

  • 12. Halmagyi DFJ, Starzeck B, Mc-rioles or venules or both. Whether this is a result of microembolic phenomena or vasoactive substances is unclear. Both of these mechanisms may be operative. The lung is known to contain high concentrations of the substances necessary for fibrinolysis.10 Depending upon the efficiency of the fibrinolytic system, microemboli may not persist in some instances, thus unmasking the vasoconstrictive element.
