Treatment at present is empiric and supportive with oxygen and a volume-controlled respirator. As noted, dextran may be of value as may steroids. Heparin is the accepted agent for the treatment of consumption coagulopathy and would seem to be of theoretical value. This was the only therapy given in case 2. However, there is no evidence that the intravascular coagulation which occurs in the lungs also takes place throughout the vascular space thus becoming a true consumption coagulopathy. Therefore, as Schramel et al14 point out, heparin may cause progression of the lesions. Isoproterenol may possibly be helpful and was found by Halmagyi et al12 to reverse the abnormalities of pulmonary hemodynamics associated with transfusion reaction.

Nonproprietary and Trade Names of Drugs

Dextran 40—Gentran 40, LMD, Rlteo-macrodex, Rheotran.

I soproterenol—N orisodrin e.

Rae J: The lung as the main target organ in the acute phase of transfusion reaction in sheep. J Surg Res 3:418-430, 1963.

  • 13. Veith FG, Hagstrom JWC, Panossian A, Nehlsen SL, et al: Pulmonary microcirculatory response to shock, transfusion and pump-oxygenator procedures: A unified mechanism underlying pulmonary damage. Surgery 64:95-109, 1968.

  • 14. Schramel RJ, Keller CA, Hyman AL, et al: Further observations on veno-venous perfusion in mechanical devices to aid the failing heart. Publication No. 1283, National Academy of Science, pp 160-178,1966.

  • 15. Keller CA, Schramel RJ, Hyman AL, et al: The cause of acute congestive lesions of the lung. J Thorac Cardiovasc Surg 53:743-755,1967.

  • 16. Menon IS, Weightman D, DeWar HA: The role of the lung in blood fibrinolysis. ClinSci 36:427-433, 1969.

Canada M. A. J.

Dec. 1, 1957, vol 77

TRANSFUSIONS ARE DANGEROUS’

BRUCE CROWN, M.D., Winnipeg, Man.

At least half of all transfusions are unnecessary; personally I think the proportion is much higher than that. Evers' transfusion given to a girl or to a woman of child-bearing age carries ' a hidden threat, tbe threat of the death of Tier children. It does not matter how carefully the ' donor blood is selected, the threat remains.

Why do yop transfuse? Why do you? Why do you? What is the proof that more than a small fraction of the blood that is daily poured into patients in the operating room alters the prognosis for the better? Blood has always had a mystical quality; its use in the operating room is more often mystical than scientific. And for women! Most transfusions given to women under the age of 45 ard given in relation to pregnancy—for the bleeding associated with an abortion, with a vaginal delivery, with Caesarean section—even, God save the mark, for simple anaemia. I would hazard the guess that not 5%— no, not 1%—of transfusions so given have been life-saving. And 1 woulcT hazard the guess too that at least ~as great a percentage has been death-dealing."

Death holds his cards close to his belly, and he plays them slowly; sometimes very slowly. So you forget. Or you don’t know; you’re no longer in the game when Death plays his trump. Let me tell you a story.

One day in 1951 Mrs. Schmaltz, let us call her, then three months gone in her third pregnancy, went to bed feeling well. In the night she woke to find her waters had broken, and early next morning she delivered herself of a fetus. For a day and a night she bled at home; then she went to the hospital. She was pale; her haemoglobin was not measured. She was no longer bleeding. Next day towards noon she was taken to the operating room, curetted and, while still under the anaesthetic, given a transfusion. (Luck was with the operator; she didn’t have a reaction.) Next day she felt fine and was given another transfusion, and a few days later she went home. Death played his trump card years later when a baby was born to Mrs. Schmaltz with erythroblastosis, from which it difid. before it could be transfused. The erythroblastosis was not due to the Rh factor or to any of its kith or kin but to an entirely unrelated blood group system.

Special Article: Transfusions 1037

The most careful selection of the donor blood under our present methods of selection would not have prevented the sensitization of the mother and. the sequent death of the baby. And in this case there was no question of saving the mother’s life; she was never in danger; the first transfusion was not given until 30 hours after admission to hospital and at least as long after bleeding had stopped; the second transfusion was given for no apparent reason. The giving of transfusions seems to be a conditioned reflex: abortion, transfusion; abortion, transfusion. So it goes. But why? Why? Let me tell you another story.

A 3I-year-old woman was admitted to hospital in March 1954, suffering from an incomplete abortion.1 She was of a rare blood group, and, having had eight transfusions in connection with earlier abortions, had developed antibodies which reacted with the blood of almost all potential donors. While compatible blood was being sought, her blood pressure fell to 70/50 mm. Hg, her haemoglobin from 8.5 to 5.8 g. per 100 ml. (from about 60 to about 35%). A compatible donor was found at last, but the patient had such a severe pyrogen reaction to the transfusion that it had to be stopped when 250 ml. had been given. No further transfusion was attempted: her haemoglobin was 14 grams per 100 ml, within a month.

I tell you that story before you say to me about Mrs. Schmaltz, “It may not have been necessaiy to the saving of her life, but it shortened her convalescence.” Did it? By how much? A week? Two weeks? Three weeks? Certainly with a bit of iron her haemoglobin would have been up to normal within a rnpn.th. And would she willingly’liave traded her baby’s life for those few draggy weeks? Mrs. Schmaltz had changed doctors between 1951 and 1956, so the transfuser of 1951 never knew about the bad result of his~~”good” treatment

1*11 tell you some other stories another time.

Reference

1. Buchanan, IX I. and McIntyre, J.: Brit. J. Hx-niat., 1: 304, 1955,

•From the Rh laboratory, 735 Notre Dame Ave,, Winnipeg 3. and die Department of Psediatrics, University of Manitoba.

This is the first of three articles.

208 Special Article: Dangers of Transfusion

Canail. M. A. J.

Feb. 1, 1958. vol A


TRANSFUSION OF GIRLS AND WOMEN CAN KILL THEIR BABIES0 A NOTE ADDRESSED MORE TO SURGEONS AND ANAESTHETISTS, BUT APPLICABLE TO OTHERS

BRUCE CROWN, M.D., Winnipeg, Man.

I address this note more to surgeons and anaesthetists than to others, although the facts are applicable to the practice of most doctors. A sur-' geon often knows a patient only for days, and an anaesthetist for Kours or minute's; the bad effect of a transfusion that either one may give may not become apparent for years; it may never7 be known to the man who gave the transfusion. I illustrate by four cases, two surgical, one medical, one obstetrical or gynaecological.

In 1948 Mrs. B. had an operation for a herniated intervertebral disc, during the course of which she was given a transfusion. Neither she nor her family physician knew of this transfusion until the events of pregnancy indicated that it must almost certainly have taken place; it was then proven by the hospital record. Mrs. B.’s blood was first examined in May 1950 in the second month of her first pregnancy; it contained an anti-Rh antibody with a titre of 2. At four months the titre had risen to 256. At six months it was 1024 and the .fetus died, Autopsy proved that the fetus had had erythroblastosis. In 1951 her next fetus also died. -

On April 20,1940, Adele S., aged 6, was playing round a bonfire; her clothes caught fire; she was admitted to the Children's Hospital, Winnipeg, with third-degree burns involving about two-thirds of the skin. There she remained for 12'£ months, during which time she received three transfusions, to the third of which, given some seven months after the first, she responded with a chill, sweating and fever. Fifteen and a half years later, on November 23, 1955, when she was in the second month of her first pregnancy an anti-Rh antibody with a titre of 1 was found in her blood. It continued at this level until three weeks before her expected date of delivery, when it rose to 256. Her attending obstetrician, Dr. J. R. Mitchell, induced labour at once. The amniotic fluid was yellow, containing 0.83 mg. of bilirubin per 100 ml. The baby, a boy weighing 5 lb. 4K oz., appeared very ill at birth. The cord blood haemoglobin was 10.82 g., and the bilirubin 9.6 mg. per 100 ml. The baby was given four replacement transfusions in 48 hours by Dr. W. D. Bowman, and made a complete recovery; it was a close call. macerated. She was Rh-nggative, her mother Rh-positive, her first child Rh-negative. It was eight years from the time of her transfusion to the death of her first Rh-positive babies. Seventeen years after that poisonous transfusion she lost her second Rh-positive baby, stillborn. Luckily her husband is heterozygous and can father some Rh-negative babies.

This is not written in criticism of the fact of transfusion in these cases, although the need in the first case is open to doubt. It is written to illustrate the fact that transfusion of girls or women mat y-years later kill their babies; the time intervals between transfusion and disaster in these three cases was 2 years, 15 years and 8 years; we ~Kave been aide to demonstrate Rh antibodies as long as 30 years after the last possible antigenic stimulus?

The inciting factor in each of the above cases was Rh-positive donor blood given to an Rh-negative patient. It may be objected that sensitization by this means no longer'occurs. But this is not so. Mistaken typing of blood as Rh-positive or Rh-negative still occurs; a fatal transfusion reaction due to just such faulty typing was recently reported in this Journal.1 Beyond simple Rh-positive and Rh-negative incompatibility there are other incompatibilities. The Rh blood group system itself is complex. For example, about 20% of Rh-positive ■people are of such an Rh-positive subtype (CDe.-CDe or RiRj ) that about 80% of Rh-positive donors •and practically 100% of Rh-negative ones are incompatible with them; the antibody that they are likely to .develop is an anti-Rh antibody called anti-c. The following case is an illustration.

Mrs. McP., Rh-nositive, suffered an accidental abortion in 1952, and, as part of her treatment, was given a transfusion of Rh-positive blood. In 1955 she gave birth to a baby who quickly became deeply jaundiced and required two replacement transfusions. Mrs. McP. was found to be of the above Rh-positive type, i.e. CDe.CDe; her blood contained anti-c of the Rh system and also anti-K of the unrelated Kell blood group system, both being the result of the 1952 transfusion. The baby’s erythroblastotic jaundice was due to the anti-c. Her next baby died in spite of transfusion.

I could cite you many other examples of transfusion sensitization from our files, but do I make niy point? Transfusions of girls and women can kill their babies, often many years later.

Befbkence

1. Fishek, T. L.: Canad. M. A. J., 76: 235, 1957.

•From the Rh Laboratory, 735 Notre Dame Ave., Winnipeg’

3. and the Department of Pediatrics, University or Manitoba. Tills Is the second of three articles.

When Mary N., then in her teens, had typhoid fever in 1936; she was given a transfusion of her mother’s blood. She married six years later and the following year had a nice normal baby. The next year, however, she gave birth to twins, one hydropic and the other

Every time you give a patient a blood transfusion, you’re taking a chance that he'll suffer an adverse reaction. The odds are better—or worse—than one to 20. And the more blood 'you transfuse, the greater the chance of a reaction.

Two professors of surgery from the University of Illinois College of Medicine have arrived at these odds after

reviewing the results of blood transfusion in nearly 48,000 patients. Drs. Robert J. Baker and Lloyd M. Nyhus conclude that the best way to avoid transfusion reactions is to avoid transfusion whenever possible.

But what if you find that you must give a transfusion?

Then, say the two physicians, you can at least avoid transfusing red cells unless they’re needed to save the life of the patient. And never, they emphasize, use universal-donor or unmatched / whole blood. "Colloid substitutes are equally_effective in volume expansion and carrymfinitely less risk/*

'Xndwhat if the patient reacts adversely to a transfusion despite these precautions?

For this not unlikely event, they recommend a three-step procedure: Stop the transfusion immediately; diagnose the precise nature of the reaction, assuming it to be hemolytic if there is any doubt; then give suitable treatment.

EMERGENCY MEDICINE I MAY 1370

LIGHT' ON

BLOOD

Dr. Baker and Dr. Nyhus I^vc been primarily concerned with the immediate transfusion reaction, which they define as one that occurs during or within a few days after transfusion These reactions, Dr. Baker told members of the American College of Surgeons at the annual meeting in San Francisco, are "frequently ignored by both medical and nursing staff, particularly if the reaction is transient or does not appear serious."

But according to the Illinois physicians, many of the immediate reactions are serious

For diagnostic and treatment purposes, these reactions can be considered in three categories: those alterations in the blood that, may accompany massive transfusion, sometimes called the “storage lesion"; idiosyncratic or sensitivity phenomena; and hemolytic reactions.

When you replace a major portion of a patient’s blood volume over a relatively- short period, there are likely to be considerable changes in the physiochemical properties of the circulating blood. Drs. Baker and Nyhus list the major changes as acidosis, hypothermia, citrate overload, hyperkalemia. hyperammonemia, coagulation defects, and a reduction in bacterial resistance.                  ?

The acidifying action of the acid citrate dextrose solution in which blood is stored lowers the plasma pH to 6.8 in three days, and it continues to fall thereafter. If stored blood is given rapidly, the Illinois surgeons recommend that you give 44.5 mEq. of sodium bicarbonate intravenously with every five units of blood that is transfused.

Blood taken directly from the refrigerator and infused rapidly can produce a critical fall in myocardial temperature, Total body hypothermia can also increase tissue oxygen consumption, producing a further strain on the traumatized or hypovolemic patient. Warming the blood before transfusion is the obvious solution, but Dr. Baker warns against warming the blood as a unit. With this method, carbon dioxide may accumulate under pressure. Instead, he recommends in-line warming by running the blood through 15-to 20-foot lengths of plastic tubing immersed in a water bath.

Citrate overloading due to the transfusion of stored blood may affect both the myocardium and coagulation mechanisms by depleting ionized calcium. Ordinarily, you can probably transfuse one unit of whole blood every five minutes without giving additional calcium. However, infants, patients in hypothermia or shock, and those with preexisting liver damage do require calcium replacement therapy. There can be danger in giving either too much calcium *or the chloride salt, especially to the hypothermic patient. But the administration of 1 gm. of calcium gluconate per liter of blood, say the Illinois doctors, “seems to be without significant hazard.”

I Stored blood is inevitably hypcr-I kalemic. and the leaching of potassium I from the red cells begins as early as the third day of storage. In small voL umes, the amount of potassium ion infused is of little consequence. Not so for massive transfusion, especially in patients with renal insufficiency, or for multiple transfusions over a short period of time. In these cases you would be wise to request blood that is less than three days old. continued

43

The allergic reaction is the commonest kind of transfusion reaction. In the Illinois study it occurred in one out of every 42 patients. Itching, erythema, and urticaria are the usual signs and symptoms. Sometimes there were chills and fever, not usually over 103° F., and rarely such respiratory difficulties as stridor, dyspnea, or wheezing. These effects seldom appear until more than half the unit has been transfused, sometimes not until after the transfusion has been completed.

The typical allergic skin reactions can usually be alleviated with intravenous antihistamines -Drs. Baker and Nyhus suggest 25 mg. of diphenhydramine— and epinephrine or steroids are rarely necessary. In this one instance, if this is al) the reaction amounts to, it isn't necessary to stop the transfusion. But it B necessary, the Chicago clinicians note, if the patient has chills and fever and you have any doubt at all about the cause.

I ess common than other reactions, but most serious of all, is the hemolviic transfusion reaction.' The immediate severe reaction is usually the result of an error in crossmatehing, labeling, or patient identification. Chills and fever mav appear after infusion of as little as 15 to 20 ml of blood and usually are evident by (he time 100 ml. has been given. Other possible symptoms include tachycardia and pain in the chest, flank, or back.

With this reaction especially, Drs. Baker and Nyhus stress, you must stop the transfusion immediately. At the same time, take samples of the donor blood and of the patient’s blood and ui me and send them to the laboratory for tests to deteminc the causes of the reaction. Begin an intravenous infusion of 20 gm. of mannitol. 40 mg. of furosemide l/.mi.i. Hoechst), and usuallv 50 rnliq. of sodium bicarbonate, preferably in 1000 ml. of dextrose or Ringer’s lactate solution. And though the rationale- -a theoretical modification of the antigen-antibody reaction—is unproven, the Illinois doctors recommend rapid IV injection of 500 mg. of hydrocortisone. You can also give either isoproterenol or levartcrenol (Levophed, Winthrop) to maintain tissue perfusion pressure.

Another type of hemolytic reaction is the depletion of essential coagulation elements, which can cause spontaneous bleeding. To treat this, you’ll need to identify the specific defects, but the basis of treatment is administration of fibrinogen and fresh frozen plasma. If there is clot lysis, Dr. Baker recommends IV administration of 2 to 4 gm. of epsilon aminocaproic acid and adds. “Obviously, administration of fresh, compatible, rematched whole blood should be continued as needed.”

Severe hypotension or shock may also be a hemolytic transfusion "reaction. The mechanism is~sp'e'culative, but Drs. Baker and Nyhus believe the changes can probably be reversed with IV isoproterenol, assisted ventilation, and the transfusion of compatible blood. Since pulmonary venular constriction appears to be a factor, you might try low molecular weight dextran to increase pulmonary perfusion. And, “as a last resort," give pressor agents such as levartcrenol or metar-aminol (d/wiH'w, Merck Sharp & Dohme)

The Illinois study also indicates that ''delaved hemolysis as a manifestation of hemolvtu. reaction is much more common, than is realized." In these 11m I L.'lim MW reactions, which occur after three to seven days, crossmatching may have been entirely accurate, but after infusion, the donor bkxid excites a rapid production of antibodies. Symptoms, if any. are usually slight, but the patient is often jaundiced and laboratory studies may reveal rcticulocytosis. spherocytosis. or clumps of agglutinated red '.ells in the peripheral blood.

I ransfusion can be lifesaving in patients who need it, and the possibility of cmly or late reactions is a chance you have to take. But for what Drs. Baker and Nyhus estimate to be “approximately 30% of patients” who receive transfusions that they don’t need, either to save their lives or to speed their recovery, the chance simply isn't worth taking.                    □

47


2 Hl


Camid. AI. A. J.

Jan. 15t 1958, vol. 78


Letters to ttie Editor 153

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

BLOOD TRANSFUSION

To the Editor:

In the December 1 issue, I have just read an article by Dr. Bruce Chown of Winnipeg, regarding the danger of transfusions. This article I consider most timely, anSTcom'ingr from one as authoritative as Dr. Chown, it is doubly so.

I am one who had a large practice in the days before transfusions and did fairly well, I think. With the coming of transfusions a new era began, to be followed by the introduction of antibiotics. Both these are life-savers and, being new and expensive, met with immediate response by the medical profession (early in transfusion history the patient paid at least S25.00 for a transfusion). The operation was also very dramatic and being new and expensive “must be good”. So transfusion and antibiotics became everyday treatment with resultant danger from staphylococcus and antibodies.

I know of one surgeon who stated at one time that he would not do major surgery ou a patient whose haemoglobin was below 70%. Just how many patients have developed hepatitis or other reactions, I do not' know; perhaps he does not either.

One hospital I know of reported a greater number of transfusions for one month than had been given at the Toronto General Hospital the previous year. This was in the “hey-day” of transfusions.

I hope there are fewer now. I will be looking forward to Dr. Chown’s further articles.

120-121 Medical Arts Bldg.,

Calgary, Alta., December 11, 1957.

H, A, Gibsox, M.D., C.M., F.R.C.S.(Edin.), F.R.C.S.1C.J.


To the Editor:

I agree with Dr. B. Chown (Canad. AL A. J., 77: 1037, 1957). Because I entered surgery before the flood of 'blood began, I am always am.ized_to see blood given lor ordinary operations. It seems to be quite all right to take a pint of blood from jj_ don or and"let him walk homebut wrong to lose blood during ordinary surgery! My belief is put into practice. In nearly 17.500 admissions to this general hospital we have not found it necessary to transfuse more than a dozen times. Our mortality rates comp are liyourably with those of other institutions.

Dr. Chown will appreciate the article “Chance, Design, and Discovery in Medicine” by J. H. Dible, Professor of Pathology, Postgraduate School, London, England. It is found in The Postgraduate Journal, of- 29, at page 59. Because so many of your readers arc far from libraries, perhaps yon will let me quote:

‘'Medical progress is a study of trial and error, •jf false paths, of whole generations under the sway '’f' ^rong ideas leading to wrong, treatment and God Glows what in the way of casualties—and the old tale '■‘t goes on. A friend of mice said to me the other day, fn the 18th century hundreds of people lost their s through blood being taken out (ittiiem needless h•; Cdav people are being killed through blood being i'Ht into them needlessly \ and I—who only that morning had seen the body of a young man, dead as the resultol an incompatible blood transfusion, given after an operation of convenience—could only agree with him sadly.”                   Frank RicgXll,

Elizabeth Hospital,          M.A., M.D., F.R.C.P. &

Prairie Grove, F.R.C.S.(Edin.), F.R.F,P.S.(Glas.) Arkansas, U.S.A., December 17, 1957.

VANCOUVER SUN

JUNE 25, 1965

DR. ALVAREZ SAYS:

Stitch in Time

Can Save Arm

By DR. WALTER C. ALVAREZ

Emeritus Consultant in Medicine, Mayo Clinld y

Every so often, one reads in the newspaper that an accident victim’s severed arm, hand or leg has

been sewed back on.

1 But does this pay? Does the limb later function well enough? -

It pays to the extent that when the surgeons throw blood, coming from the heart, into the arteries in the torn arm or leg, the tissues live. The.arm or leg is then likely to look better than an artificial one. '

AAA

Two doctors wrote In the Journal of the American Medical Association that some experiences of this type have shown it is worthwhile.

For instance, a boy of 12, whose right arm was rejoined below the shoulder in . 1962, can now lift a 10-pound weight and can write his name with his hand. He has sensation in all of his fingers, and can move his shoulder.

AAA

He still does not have full movement in his elbow. It is

hoped, .that more surgical work will help him further.

The other patient, a man of 44, had his right arm cut off just above the elbow. He is now working full-time as a machinist’s supervisor.

Strength is coming back in his fingers, and movement at the shoulder is only partly restricted.

★ ★

In recent years, there has been a craze for giving . blood transfusions when file patient could have recovered without it.

For several years,, some leading experts on blood diseases have been begging doctors not to order a transfusion unless it is very necessary.’*- ■

In an uncomfortably large number of cases, they say, all that happens is the pers.on.-gets an attack of serum hepatitis —■ an often serious or even fatal inflammation of the liver.


Reprinted from Canadian Doctor October 1960 Supplement

BLOOD


TRANSFUSION


W. Glen How, Q.C., Toronto

■_ ia ~i n n n n na. aa n n n n n ~   r; - r> .nnn_rm ruin n n nnnnnjnrm ti nn~i nm"

  • Chapter 1 RELIGION, MEDICINE AND LAW

"The greatest dangers to liberty lurk in insidious encroachment by men of zeal, well-meaning, but without understanding.”1

BRANDEIS

Very few questions, legal, religious, or medical have aroused as much concern in recent years as the cases involving the refusal of Jehovah’s witnesses on religious grounds to accept blood transfusions for themselves or their children. Very often the issue becomes so surcharged with emotion that it is difficult to get a balanced view of the problem and to take into account all the relevant considerations that should be weighed. One statute2 has already been passed in connection with this matter and other statutory amendments have been demanded particularly in Ontario and in Saskatchewan.

The emotional view often taken of this subject would give a very quick reply: “Take the child away from the parents and let the doctors use their own judgment. They know best.” In fact, the issue is not just that simple. At what point do we decide that the natural, God-given control of children by their own parents who love them and have their welfare at heart shall be overruled? Will the proposed medical discretion be confined to blood transfusion, or will professional men now be judges and masters to perform at will any operation — amputation, appendectomy, sterilization, etc.? Will their power of forced treatment be limited to therapeutic measures in which they can offer some assurance of effectiveness, or are they now getting carte blanche for unsure, dangerous and experimental treatment of unproved value? Who is going to accept liability when the “men of science” hand a corpse back to grieving parents and announce with scientific assurance that “the operation was a success, but the patient died”? What is to become of the law when the currently popular practice of blood transfusion goes the way of blood letting, sulfa drags and other medical practices which have enjoyed a brief fad of popularity and then disappeared? Are we prepared to accept the Nazi-Spartan theory that children belong to the state? If so, what supervision or state control is proposed to protect the people from medical abuses: or do doctors now become state officials without control and vested with unlimited discretion? Freedom of worship is guaranteed by the constitution and has been protected at great sacrifice. Does it now weigh so little in the scales of justice as to scarcely merit mention by those who in the name of “science” are prepared to trample constitutional liberties without a backward glance?

These problems are not simple. It is the function of the law to balance the claims which conflicting interests may have on its protection. This function has been well described by Mr. Justice Ivan C. Rand.

“In the structure of the law’s myriad adjustments, built of the products of the reasoning mind, molding the life of the community, neutral in its nature and operation, should reside the security of the humblest citizen: security in life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness, security against any attempts by the most powerful to invade his sanctities . . . the courts . . . are the special guardians of the freedoms of unpopular causes, of minority groups and interests, of the individual against the mass, of the weak against the powerful, of the unique, of the nonconformist — our liberties are largely the accomplishments of such men."3

In order to deal with the “myriad adjustments” relevant to this issue and to strike a balance on them it is necessary to review this matter from the standpoint of religion and medicine, as well as law.

  • Chapter 2 THE OBJECTION OF JEHOVAH’S WITNESSES TO BLOOD TRANSFUSION IS ONE OF A NUMBER OF RELIGIOUS VIEWS

THAT CONFLICT WITH CURRENT MEDICAL PRACTICE

  • A. Society commonly accepts the religious opinions of larger groups who decline to accept certain medical treatment, hut the same tolerance is not shown toward minorities, such as Jehovah’s witnesses.

Jehovah’s witnesses are by no means the only religion whose opinions cause them to refuse to accept certain aspects of accepted medical practice. Other groups such as the Roman Catholics and Christian Scientists also have religious views which cause them to refuse at least some forms of medical treatment. Such refusal by these larger groups is a well-known phenomenon that both society in general and the medical profession are able to absorb with no apparent difficulty. At least one hears no great public outcry.

With respect to Jehovah’s witnesses, however, though the number of cases has been very small, the highly' dramatic treatment given them by the press seems to have convinced many that something new has been uncovered and we must be prepared to alter the law to cope with the situation.

Some understanding of these religious views and the resulting conflicts is essential to a proper grasp of this problem.

  • B. Jehovah’s witnesses found their objection to the use of blood on the Bible.

Jehovah’s witnesses make full use of surgery and other remedial treatment that is available. They' are prepared to call in medical assistance, and to accept hospitalization or other essential treatment. Jehovah’s witnesses only draw the line where the use of blood is concerned. Their point of view is entirely different from the groups who decline remedial treatment and depend on “faith healing .

It is a matter of interest in this connection that Christian objection to the use of blood is not original with the twentieth century'. In the days of Roman persecution of Christians the Roman magistrates sought to ferret out believers in Christ by demanding that they consume blood. If they refused they were branded at Christians, subject for martyrdom. Tertullian, a famous Christian writer of the second century states, in addressing the Romans:

“Let your error blush before the Christians, for we do not include even animals’ blood in our natural diet. We abstain on that account from things strangled or that die of themselves, that we may not in any way be polluted by blood, even if it is buried in the meat. Finally, when you are testing Christians, you offer them sausages full of blood; you are thoroughly well aware, of course, that among them it is forbidden; but you want to make them transgress.”4

In order to properly' state the position of Jehovah’s witnesses on this subject the writer has obtained an official statement from the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania, governing organ of Jehovah’s witnesses. The view is stated as follows:

“Jehovah’s witnesses are Christians. They follow the principles set out in God’s Word the Bible. It is not Jewish principles but Christian principles that forbid the consumption of blood. The first council of the Christian church held by the apostles themselves at Jerusalem issued the following ordinance as governing all the Chrisitan congregation as recorded at the fifteenth chapter of the Acts of the Apostles the V.

28,29 'For it seemed good to the Holy Ghost, and to us, to lay upon you no greater burden than these necessary things; that ye abstain from meats offered to idols, and from blood, and from things strangled, and from fornication: from which if ye keep yourselves, ye shall do well. Fare ye well.’ This powerful statement of necessary things condemns: idolatry, use of blood, use of things strangled without draining their blood, fornication. Note that in this short statement two of the four items prohibit blood.. The Apostles determined these to be the necessary' things for the congregations of the Christian church. There is certainly nothing temporary about the prohibition on fornication or idolatry. By the same token, the prohibition against blood is of equal permanence: ‘abstain from blood.’ It is a permanent and unchanging rule of the Christian church.

“The decision of Jehovah’s witnesses to refuse blood transfusion has not been taken hastily. There is direct Biblical injunction against consumption of blood: the manner of taking it into the system is immaterial. ' Jehovah, the Creator, who made blood, has reserved it as sacred to himself. The blood is the life of the creature.

“From the beginning of the Scriptures, blood has been holy, reserved to God himself. This was first stated in the covenant or agreement Jehovah made with Noah immediately after the flood about 2369 B.C. — this was 855 years prior to the law given to Moses at Mount Sinai. The instruction to Noah was: ‘Every moving thing that liveth shall be meat for you . . . But flesh with the life thereof, which is the blood thereof, shall ye not eat. . . Whoso sheddeth man’s blood, by man shall his blood be shed.’ (Genesis 9:3-6) The flesh he gave to men for their consumption: the blood, the life, he reserved unto himself.

“The law given to Moses continued the principle of the sacredness of blood. It was not a dietary law, either to Noah or to the Jews. Leviticus 17:14 (AS) declares: ‘For as to the life of all flesh, the blood thereof is all one with the life thereof: therefore I said unto the children of Israel, Ye shall eat the blood of no manner of flesh; for the life of all flesh is the blood thereof: whosoever eateth it shall be cut off.’ Verse 13 states: 'And whatsoever man . . . who taketh in hunting any beast or bird that may be eaten; he shall pour put the blood thereof, and cover it with dust.’ Deuteronomy 12:23 (AS), ‘Only be sure that thou eat not the blood: for the blood is the life; and thou shalt not eat the life with the flesh. Thou shalt not eat it; thou shalt pour it out upon the earth as water.’

“The contention has been made that ‘eating blood’ is confined to consumption through the mouth. But if a patient is too weak to eat in the ordinary way, he is fed intravenously — nourishment is fed into his veins and he ‘eats’ or consumes it to sustain his body. Since intravenous feeding is eating, transfusion of blood into the veins is also eating for all practical purposes. Blood is fed into the veins for the purpose of nourishing or sustaining the body. The body consumes, ‘eats’ it: actually lives, maintains itself, on the blood of another. It is eating blood.

“Much has been said on this subject about saving life. But how does one save life? It is by obedience and not by disobedience to God’s Word that one preserves

his hope of eternal life. Those who accept Christ are in a covenant to do God’s will. If, through fear of man, they go contrary to his Word and Law the warning of the apostle Paul applies: ‘Covenant breakers are worthy of death.’ (Romans 1:31,32) Jesus warned his true followers that they would be faced with the issue of accepting God’s instructions or man’s. At Matthew 10:38 (NW) he said, ‘And whoever does not accept his torture stake and follow after me is not worthy of me.’

“For the faithful he has promised everlasting life. ‘This means everlasting life, their taking in knowledge of you, the only true. God, and of the one whom you sent forth, Jesus Christ.' (John 17:3, NW) One properly seeks to have life now, but if it should be lost, the Bible gives to faithful Christians a sure hope for themselves and their children of being resurrected back to life on this earth again under perfect conditions. Consequently the eternal welfare of our children is an abiding consideration on this issue.

“Jehovah’s witnesses do not accept the vacillating view that God's Word can be abandoned whenever human opinion makes it seem opportune. To them the Bible is an inspired book written by God himself, but transmitted to humankind by means of some thirty faithful men who recorded it. The Apostle Peter said: ‘For no prophecy ever came by the will of man: but men spake from God, being moved by the Holy Spirit.’ (2 Peter 1:21) The Bible is Jehovah’s book of law which must be followed by those who accept Him and the Saviour, Jesus Christ. Jehovah’s witnesses do accept Him and His law. They are dedicated by individually entering into a contract or covenant with the Most High God to be His people and do His will. They are therefore bound by His principles, ‘Covenant breakers are worthy of death’, (Romans 1:31,32).”

It is on this basis of a direct Biblical injunction against the use of blood that Jehovah’s witnesses found their objection. There is nothing vague or fanciful about these direct statements and their honestly held beliefs are entitled to be respected and to receive the protection of the law.

C. The beliefs of the Roman Catholic church, Christian Scientists and others cause their adherents to refuse at least some forms of medical treatment but such religious conflict with medical practice is considered quite acceptable though the result in lives lost may be. much more serious than among Jehovah’s witnesses.

There are a number of minority groups commonly described as “faith healers” who do not believe in any type of medical or remedial treatment. They rely on prayer and faith in the belief that this will effect the necessary remedy. Jehovah’s witnesses do not accept faith healing, but are prepared to use medical treatment in general as long as blood is not involved.

However, these minority groups are not alone in religious conflict with medical practice. The Roman Catholic church has maintained settled opposition to birth control by mechanical or chemical means and also to therapeutic abortions even when the life of the mother is at stake.

By way of illustration, reference could be made to a controversy that arose in New York City in 1958. The Commissioner of Health created a religious storm when he directed medical doctors to stop disseminating birth control information and therapy in all city-owned hospitals. Since the city hospitals had patients of many different faiths there was understandably an objection to this ruling and it had to be rescinded. The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York condemned birth control therapy as one that “introduces an immoral practice into our hospitals which perverts the dignity and nature of man”. Doctors and nurses were reminded of “their grave obligation in conscience to in no way cooperate in such procedures.”8 Birth control information may sometimes be necessary to protect the life of a mother, yet the Roman Catholic church because of its religious views on this subject has strongly resisted efforts of the medical profession to use this type of therapy.

Similarly with the subject of therapeutic abortions: there are times when the continuation of pregnancy to full term will result in the death of the mother. There is also occasionally the situation where continuation io full term will result in death of mother and child both. Under such circumstances the normal medical procedure is induced abortion.

The Catholic view that the soul is more important than the body does not ordinarily accept the medical view that induced abortion may sometimes be an acceptable procedure. A well-known priest Patrick A. Finney states the view in his book “Moral Problems In Hospital Practice" under the imprimatur of the Archbishop of St. Louis. The point is made as follows,

“If it is morally certain that a pregnant mother and her unborn child will both die, if the pregnancy is allowed to take its course, but at the same time, the attending physician is morally certain that he can save the mother’s life by removing the inviable fetus, is it lawful for him to do so? Answer: No, it is not. Such a removal of the fetus would be direct abortion.”15

In a statement before the International College of Surgeons at Rome, May, 1948, Pope Pius XII declared that in spite of “the understandable anguish of husbandly love” it is “illicit — even in order to save the mother — to cause directly the death of the small being that is called, it not for life here below, then at least for the future life, to a high and sublime destiny . . .”7

The religious view here expressed could result in the death of the mother in cases even where there is no chance of saving the child. This situation could also arise in relation to a mother who is a juvenile. The medical profession seems to have no difficulty in absorbing and respecting this interference with normal medical practice.

The basic thinking behind the above religious opinions seems to place the spiritual values above, or at least on a par with, the physical medical requirements. Edwin F. Healy, S.J. in his book Medical Ethics states:

“What is to be done if baptizing an immature infant in the womb of a dying mother would cause an abortion? . . If there is no other way of providing for the spiritual welfare of the child, one may baptize such a fetus while it is in the womb even though this act of baptizing will result in an abortion . . . The act of baptizing the child is a good one. From it results two effects: namely, the child’s spiritual salvation and the child’s loss of temporal life.”8

It is not proposed in this study to argue the truth or error uf these various religious opinions. Knowing they exist, and knowing that the law is no respecter of persons, is it the purpose of those who propose a removal of parental control and the disregarding of religious views to begin an attack upon the Roman Catholic church and its adherents whenever their beliefs come in conflict with medical practice? Are they prepared to go to the point where public officials and medical men would seize and forcibly abort against her will and that of the parents a teenage child pregnant as a result of rape or seduction?

Thai such problems can arise will be seen from the case of Rex v. Bourne," where a British medical doctor was charged with a criminal offence due to aborting a I5-year-old unmarried girl, pregnant as a result of rape. The doctor was tried and acquited by the jury.

Suppose the doctor has recommended this treatment as necessary for saving the life of the juvenile mother and the parents as Roman Catholic object on account of their religious views. If the medical profession is entitled to overrule the religious inhibitions of a minority, such as Jehovah’s witnesses, then we must be prepared to see the same practice followed with respect to majority faiths.

The far-reaching effect of the proposal that doctors be given carte blanche authority over people’s lives has been considered by the executive editor of the periodical The Canadian Doctor under the title “Blood Transfusions and Human Rights.” The article states:

“We are living, geographically and politically, in a country of multiple faiths. Many of those faiths, because of their greater numerical support, would not brook interference with their edicts and tenets, their professed beliefs and their religious laws . . . other countries .. . divided the individual from his right, by placing state’s right and scientific ‘advancement’ before an individual’s inalienable right to live and worship according to his conscience before God.”10

The Toronto Daily Star commented editorially on this subject:

"The Witnesses are not the only religious group which collides with 20th century scientific practice. Christian Science doctrine has nothing in common with modern medicine. Roman Catholic doctrine conflicts with some medical practice, when it forbids birth control by mechanical means or abortion even when the life of a woman might be at stake. Yet there is no mass outcry because of these beliefs, and properly so . . . {The} Witness lawyer poses a danger: ‘If one of the Witnesses can lose custody of his child because he disagrees with a certain form of medical treatment, then any parent who happens to disagree with any form of medical treatment can immediately have Iris child removed from his home and declared a neglected child.’ If precedent widened out to snatching children tor other medical treatment, let us consider first how much medical treatment of just 50 years ago is now regarded useless or even harmful.”11

There seems little question that a change of the law will definitely widen the field of medical interference in family life and in religious liberty. One’s confidence in the wise use of discretion is not strengthened by the inconsistency in the position being taken by a substantial number of physicians on this question. So far as Jehovah s witnesses are concerned, the only thing that is of importance is unfettered medical power; “saving lives” as they like to describe it. They are more than prepared to sacrifice the religious liberty of Jehovah’s witnesses on the altar of science. In Saskatchewan, however, in the medical battle against state medicine, the College of Physicians and Surgeons has used as an important plank in its propaganda the following argument:

“A government-controlled plan offers a latent but potential threat to certain dogmas and views of the Catholic Church relating to maternity, birth control and the state.”12

It would appear from this that when it comes to the politically powerful Catholic Church “saving lives” is not so important. Respect for religious liberty (or perhaps trying to influence voters) becomes a major virtue in the eyes of the College of Physicians and Surgeons. However, when it comes to stamping on the religious liberty of a politically helpless minority like Jehovah’s witnesses, there is an about-face and the grasp for medical power comes once more to the fore.

There are two faces to this picture. Frankly it is hypocritical.

These various points are raised to demonstrate that once the law decides to disregard religious opinion in the interest of what we regard as science, then it must be prepared to go right down the line and attack the strongly held views of all religious groups who dare to disagree , with accepted medical practice.

The sincere beliefs of all churches are entitled to be respected. Jehovah’s witnesses object on grounds of faith to certain medical practices: Roman Catholics object on grounds of faith to other medical practices. Our society is perfectly capable of absorbing such diversity. As the law recognizes a value to society in the moral contribution made by religion, so it must be prepared to make room for divergence of religious opinion. Respect for liberty is a foundation principle which has helped this country attain the status it has today. For a nation to break down its own principles of freedom in the interests of what appears expedient at the moment is to tear the fabric of its own integrity. There is a resultant loss of self-respect and a failure of the nation to do justice to itself and its own citizens.

Chapter J BLOOD TRANSFUSION CAN KILL

A, The Common Assumption It Is an Undoubted Lifesaver Is Insupportable: In Fact It Results in Many Deaths and Much Sickness

The greatest fallacy in this entire controversy is the bland, uninformed assumption that blood transfusion is necessarily a lifesaver. Nothing could be farther from the truth.

In fact it has been stated that 3,000 deaths annually are caused in the United States from blood transfusion.13 This means every7 year a line of corpses more than three miles long, attributable to blood transfusion. Even this figure is inadequate because the true incidence of mortality is never published. In any event, 3,000 deaths in twelve months should be enough to bring a note of caution to those enthusiasts determined to force blood on objectors.

Untold sickness is an additional result of this practice. “The diseases most commonly transmitted by transfusion are syphilis, homologous serum jaundice, and malaria.” Also mentioned are: “measles, smallpox, typhus, influenza, tuberculosis, gonorrheal arthritis and fatal encephalitis.”14

Instead of being an undoubted lifesaver: “Thoughtless prescription of blood transfusion is playing Russian Roulette with bottles of blood instead of a revolver”, is the statement of Dr. W. II. Crosby, of New York State.13 In the face of this it is being argued that the law should exert itself so people’s children can be snatched away and made available for Russian Roulette with bottles of blood.

Another doctor writes;

“Medical progress is a study of trial and error, of

false paths, of whole generations under the sway of wrong ideas leading to wrong treatment and God knows what in the way of casualties — and the old tale yet goes on, A friend of mine said to me the other day, ‘in the 18th century hundreds of people lost their lives through blood being taken out of them needlessly; today people are being killed through blood being put into them needlessly’, and I — who only that morning had seen the body of a young man, dead as the result of an incompatible blood transfusion, given after an operation of convenience — could only agree with him sadly.”16

This is a statement of Dr. J. H. Dible, Professor of Pathology, London, England. Does this sound like lifesaving? Is this something that now should be enshrined in the law?

Blood letting was at one time a standard practice of the medical profession. People lost their lives from that type of blood therapy. How foolish it would be if that practice had been fixed in the law! It is now outmoded, proved wrong.

Now “people are being killed through blood being put into them . . . the old tale yet goes on." So even doctors themselves are forced to admit people are being killed. Dr. Dible is obviously dubious about the whole practice of blood transfusion: “whole generations under the sway of wrong ideas . .. leading to God knows what in the way of casualties”. So when people are being killed by transfusions, when sickness and deaths by the thousands are the result of this practice about which some doctors are understandably dubious can it reasonably be argued that blood transfusion should now become a matter of law? What is to be done with the law when blood transfusion goes the way of blood letting as another outmoded therapy?

The real figures concerning the number of deaths caused by blood transfusion are not being published, whether by accident or design. The customary mortality estimated varies from one per thousand to one per three thousand. However, it is admitted in the British Medical Journal “the true incidence of death resulting from blood transfusion is not known”.17 Dr. Tibor Greenwait, Milwaukee, states that the blood transfused in the United States is at least a contributing factor to 1700 deaths annually. He says, however: “Though accurate data are not presently available, the mortality associated with transfusions has been estimated to be from one in 1,000 to one in 3,000 . . . The morbidity (sickness) rate is many times greater”.

Dr. Greenwait states further:

“The implication of the term ‘cosmetic transfusion’ needs no further elaboration. It is meant to ridicule the giving of transfusion without sufficient indication .. . There are many reasons which should deter one from ordering transfusions which are not clearly indicated. The danger of hemolytic transfusion reactions is perhaps the most dramatic. It is futile to speculate concerning the frequency of this complication. The incidence is certainly much higher than is suspected, for the milder forms undoubtedly pass unsuspected.”18

The figures concerning the mortality rate resulting from blood transfusion are admittedly inaccurate. If a patient is admitted to a hospital suffering from injury or some other affliction for which a blood transfusion is given, the death of the patient following the blood transfusion (even though death may be the result of the transfusion) is usually charged against the original injury rather than admit that the treatment has caused the death. Doctors customarily bury their mistakes so the full details do not become known. Some doctors are convinced blood transfusion is an inadvisable practice, but since it is

DLG-12/60 accepted, it is easier to be a conformist, to remain quiet, than to come in conflict with the all-powerful Medical Association. Conformity with current practice, the “party line”, requires lip-service on the part of physicians regardless of their own knowledge. Privately doctors have admitted to the writer that they know many more people are being killed by blood transfusions than their statistics reveal. These statements seem confirmed by the published reports that the figures commonly released on blood transfusion mortality do not reflect the real situation.

Even the published figures should be sufficient to disturb anyone thinking seriously about the subject.

“The incidence of reactions from the administration of whole blood varies between 1.0 to 5.0 per cent. Fatalities can occur following transfusions, and these are due chiefly to hemolytic reactions. ... Hemolytic reactions are still the chief danger of transfusions and continue to be the greatest cause of fatal complications of wholeblood transfusions. Hemolytic crisis can be severe, and death will occur in 40 to 66 per cent of patients experiencing a hemolytic reaction.”18

Dr. Binder, a recognized authority in this field, tells the unhappy story of his efforts to overcome transfusion reactions. “None of the patients treated in this manner survived. Two were completely unresponsive to therapy and died in hemorrhagic shock; while two others survived the initial hemorrhage with the aid of massive blood transfusions only to expire shortly thereafter. In one case the bleeding was hidden and appeared only terminally. This patient died before treatment could be started.”20 So the death of five different patients from blood transfusion is recorded in one paragraph.

The “fad of blood” has become so ingrained in general thinking that doctors who have studied the subject carefully are appalled at the casual way in which their brother physicians employ this very dangerous practice.

Consider the warning of Dr. R. A. Zeitlin, Director of the South London Transfusion Centre, as to dangers of this practice:

“The transfusion of blood has become so commonplace and simple that nowadays in some hospitals pints of blood are dispensed more liberally than beer. As a result, blood transfusion, which is by no means as straightforward as it might seem, is causing a substantial number of deaths among hospital patients in this country every year. A warning by an expert on the extent of the risks involved which is published in ‘The Medical World’ today should have a welcome effect on the ardour of the over-enthusiastic transfusionist.

“The ease with which blood is obtained encourages what have been called ‘cosmetic’ transfusions, which are performed more for the benefit of the relatives and the peace of mind of the doctor than for the wellbeing of the patient. Every year about two hundred deaths result from transfusions in Britain.. . .

“Doctor Zeitlin says that transfusions are given to hurry patients out of hospital, owing to the shortage of hospital beds. Again, the drama and glamour of a transfusion will often influence the inexperienced resident doctor to give an unnecessary transfusion in borderline cases of hemorrhage. If blood transfusions were as safe as is commonly supposed it would still be difficult to justify them in cases such as these.”21

These medical admissions demonstrate that blood transfusion is not as safe as commonly supposed.

“A blood transfusion can kill a man almost instantly on the operating table when he develops a severe allergic reaction to another’s blood. Or it causes him to come down, sometimes within hours, sometimes not for months, with hepatitis — a virus infection that results often in severe illness and sometimes in death”,22 said Brian Cahill, medical correspondent for Saturday Night.

Some of these dangers might be acceptable as a calculated risk if it could be demonstrated that there is some corresponding proof of life saving. Dr. Bruce Chown of Winnipeg, eminent writer on this subject, challenges the transfusionists to produce proof.

“At least half of all transfusions are unnecessary; personally I think the proportion is much higher than that. .. . What is the proof that more than a small fraction of the blood that is daily poured into patients in the operating room alters the prognosis for the better? Blood has always had a mystical quality; its use in the operating room is more often mystical than scientific. ... I would hazard the guess that not 5% — no, not 1% — of transfusions so given [to women] have been lifesaving. And I would hazard the guess too that at least as great percentage has been deathdealing.”®3

So if blood transfusions are dangerous and the best and most respected medical writers estimate that their value is doubtful and they are probably killing as many as they are curing, then what is the point of carrying on this type of therapy? A fortiori where do they find any sensible basis for making blood transfusion obligatory as a matter of law?

Dr. Chown even admits that blood transfusion is often more mystical than scientific. In the same vein, Dr. Zeitlin supra describes such treatment as motivated by “drama and glamour”, “performed for the benefit of the relatives”. Some would like to think that children turned over to physicians for treatment are receiving “scientific” care. But when doctors are obliged to admit that the treatment used is founded more on mysticism and showmanship than on scientific proof or really curative value, then how much more ridiculous does it become to rally the powers of the law so this mysticism and drama can now be forced on everyone whether he wants it or not!

In addition to the large number of deaths being caused by this practice of blood therapy there is also a considerable incidence of sickness of varying degrees of seriousness.

“The danger of blood transfusion, infection, hemosiderosis, and transfusion reaction are well known. Try as we may we can only reduce the incidence of the reactions. We cannot eliminate them, and patients will continue to be damaged as a result of blood transfusions,"

states Dr. W. H. Crosby in the Journal, Blood."* Consider also the comment of Dr. Robert H. Unger in

the Neto York State Journal of Medicine,

“No method has been found to eliminate the hazards of hepatitis following the use of blood in certain of its products. . . . While the vast majority of patients with homologous serum hepatitis recover eventually within four months, an appreciable number will develop complications varying from mere prolongations of the clinical course to fatal hepatitis. . .. mortality rates in smaller epidemics following the use of blood or plasma have ranged as high as 20%.. . . The prevention of homologous serum hepatitis remains an unsolved problem, the failure of ultra violet irradiation in the sterilization of plasma make the use of whole .blood and plasma a risky procedure.”33

A further study by Doctor B. P. L. Moore states:

“Despite what has just been said, these dangers must be unappreciated by many physicians, for Binder and his co-workers looked more closely into the etiology of these reactions and found that 53% of their patients who had hemolytic reactions received transfusions ‘for which the indications were questionable’ — a figure in agreement with the estimate of Chown; these authors later state that 6 out of 7 deaths in their study were associated with blood transfusions of questionable nec- ' essity.”2*

So 53 per cent of the transfusions in the foregoing study were unnecessary. Six out of seven deaths resulted from these unnecessary transfusions.

Appropriate for attention here is the commentary of the British medical writer, Dr. A. Polak, who said:

“troubles are cropping up which we cannot explain -in spite of all precautions some patients react unfavourably to transfusions which are correctly administered. Most frequently they present symptoms of fever and allergy, shivering, laboured breathing, cyanosis, low blood pressure, rashes and sometimes shock. Such conditions are always distressing and may be dangerous.”27

In an article entitled “The Yellow Menace in Blood Plasma”-* it was stated that of more than 200,000 cases of hepatitis in the American forces, approximately 100,000 had been contracted from blood transfusion.

Uncontrolled problems; dangers not appreciated by physicians; patients dying inexplicably from transfusions: complications appear to be endless. So often are medical writers obliged to admit their inability to control and eliminate the dangers from blood transfusions that it becomes obvious they are dealing with a very hazardous practice where guesswork must often replace scientific proof.

The failure of the best medical brains to cope with the difficulties arising from the use of blood, only goes to confirm the wisdom of the Creator in instructing people 1 to “abstain from blood.” By accepting His word much frustration and harm can be avoided.

But regardless of the theory upon which it is placed the evidence is clear that death and sickness on a very-considerable scale result from blood transfusion. The so-called “life saving blood” about which one reads in drama-inspired news articles, very often turns out in actual practice to be “death dealing blood”. The bland assumption that blood transfusion is necessarily a life saver is simply not true. It is founded on a one-sided presentation of the matter in the public press which has overstated and over-dramatized the case against a minority, while leaving hidden in the dusty tomes of medical literature the Achilles heel of death, sickness and guesswork in blood therapy that reveals an entirely different picture. Once it is seen that the common assumption of undoubted benefit is insupportable, or at least very dubious, the whole case for forced transfusion falls to the ground.

B. Blood Transfusion — Has It Any Real Scientific Basis?

The above question may appear extreme. Some experts do not even feel it remains open for discussion. However, experts also disagree with each other, so let us examine as evidence some of the writings that should, at least, be informative.          ■■

In this regard it will be helpful to consider briefly' the history of blood therapy' as well as the theory of blood grouping and matching. It is proposed to show that the whole theory of blood transfusion stands on a very shaky foundation. Some responsible medical writers are of the opinion that blood is unmatchable and all blood is incompatible with all other blood.

Blood the rapy is not something new, invented in the twentieth century. A history of this matter published by Doctors Zimmerman and Howell reveals:

“The ancients believed, as many do today, that the blood not only carried the vital force of the body, but that it was the seat of the -soul as well. ... It is not

91 RD


surprising, therefore, that we find ever-recurring at-temps to cure disease by blood transfusion . . ,

:“The use of blood as a therapeutic agent is as old as medicine itself. We are told of blood baths used by ancient Egyptian princes for resuscitation and recuperation. Pliny describes the drinking of the flowing blood of gladiators in the arena 'as if out of living cups’ as a cure of epilepsy. This form of treatment was advised by many of the ancient writers, including Galen. Celsus deplores the custom of the people who rushed into the area to drink the blood fresh flowing from the jugular veins of the dying victims . . . First transfusion of blood is reported to have been done at Rome in about 1490 on Pope Innocent VIII. He died as a result... . Marsilius Ficinus, the renowned Platonist (1489) advised the drinking of healthy young blood to dispel the weakness and infirmities of old age as ‘witches and monsters’ were reputed to do.”20

It is, however, mainly in the twentieth century that the practice of blood transfusion has been developed. Very early it was found that incompatible blood could produce violent reactions including death. The molecules of which blood is composed are chemically active, not passive. The blood of each individual is in balance with itself, but when foreign blood molecules are introduced into the blood stream, the natural balance is upset. There is virtually always a reaction and the molecules may react violently.

About the turn of the century it became known that there are four principal blood groups among humans which have been designated as A, B, AB and O. It was thought for some time that transfusion within these groups was safe, but unaccountable fatalities continued to occur. Later additional groups known as M and N were added to the four basic blood groups. As each new blood group was added to the list, it was thought the practice of transfusion would become safe and that the dangerous reactions from incompatible blood would disappear. Still there was trouble. It was not till 1940 that the important Rh factor was discovered.30 This again changed the picture. The search for compatible blood and the problem of cross-matching became more complex with each new discovery.

In addition to the main groups and factors mentioned there are also a number of sub-groups to further complicate the situation. When it comes to cross-matching blood in the light of the known complexities, the problem of getting compatible blood becomes bewildering.

Dr. B. P. L. Moore has said on this subject: “The known blood group antigens give rise to more than 3,000,000 phenotype combinations.”31 To try to match blood when 3,000,000 known factors must be taken into account, makes it obvious that matching is impossible. Dr. Moore’s statement only takes into account the known antigens.

So complex is the content of blood that Dr. Landsteiner,32 a leading student of the subject, has expressed the view that blood is unique to each individual, like fingerprints: there are no two alike. If no two bloods are alike, there can never be such a thing as matched blood. All blood is incompatible with all other blood save that of the same individual. As long as blood transfusions continue there will always be adverse reactions due to incompatibility in greater or less degree.

“Every individual has his own type of blood and since no two are exactly alike, you cannot with impunity put another person’s blood into your veins no matter how well typed. Your system has to get rid of it and begins to do so immediately and continues to do so until it has all been eliminated”, 38 39

DLG-12/60 “If a person is doomed to ultimate insanity, the cause of it will be found in his blood. If one is headed for diabetes, cancer, tuberculosis, etc., the poisons which eventually produce such diseases are in the blood -first and remain there.

"The poisons that produce the impulse to commit suicide, murder, or steal are in the blood. Hepatitis, boils, abcesses, carbuncles, anemia, any systemic disease, the veneral diseases, malaria — the causative poisons of all of these are in the blood even before the symptoms appear. There is no way of determining beforehand whether such poisons are present. Even tire test for syphilis is untrustworthy.

“A lot of propaganda is circulated about purifying the blood and only using the clean residue. It cannot be done. The blood-letting of yore has been superseded by blood transfusion. Of all the ridiculous medical practices of the past and present times, this present blood craze is the worst. It is not only useless where fractional blood is used, but often deadly where whole blood is used. Blood once removed from the living body becomes a dead, abhorrent, loathsome substance no matter how fractionized or preserved. It can serve no purpose whatever in sickness of any kind. In place of blood transfusions, one should use normal saline, which is the natural basis of all blood. . . .

“In performing upwards of twenty thousand surgical operations, I never gave a blood transfusion and never had a patient die from lack of it.

“I have given many ‘transfusions’ of normal Salt Solution. It is better and safer. I have used it in cases of all degrees of exsanguination and none died. Some were white as chalk and cold as stone, but they lived.”33

This is the view of a very experienced surgeon. “Of all the ridiculous medical practices of the past and present times, this present blood craze is the worst.” Dr. Shadman cannot state his view any more plainly than that. This is the “blood craze” that they now want the law to force on people.

If the foregoing theory of Dr. Shadman is correct, then every person who has a blood transfusion simply loads on his systems the double duty of getting rid of the foreign matter, inserted by the transfusion in addition to whatever disease the body was already endeavoring to eliminate. If the patient is in a state of serious illness, this added shock can be fatal.

The unique quality of blood has an important bearing on the person as an individual: “The blood in any person is in reality the person himself. It contains all the peculiarities of the individual from whom it comes. This includes heredity taints, disease susceptibilities, poisons due to personal living, eating and drinking habits,”31 states Dr. Shadman. An infant’s blood is a combination of genes, types and other features of both parents. The blood makes the child. Parents can say: “That child is us. The blood lines of our families combine in him.” But suppose the blood is drained and replaced with that of another, or a combination of several types of blood. Then who is the child? Change of blood can even change personality and disposition of the child.35

As above stated even the impulses to crime are in the blood and may be in blood that comes in a transfusion. Criminals in penitentiaries are often donors, hoping they will get time off for this behaviour. If their characteristics come out in the transfused child, the assault by transfusion will have a result of deplorable permanency. In addition to character traits there is also the problem of disease. When blood centres are set up as they often are at sidewalk level for any donor who happens to go by, the disease tests prior to blood withdrawal must of necessity be cursory. Cadaver blood is also used for transfusions and in such case the donors cannot answer questions about disease record.

Dr. Shadmau’s view that blood is individual and incapable of combination with that of another person is supported by the findings of a Canadian study on this subject by four doctors at the Montreal General Hospital. The paper on this research was delivered in Vancouver by Dr. A. S. V. Burgen. Quotation is from the Montreal Gazette:

“He said that it has up to now been assumed that allergic reactions (hives, chills, fever) were due to differences in blood types and could be controlled by careful cross-matching so that each patient received blood closely matching his own.

“But experiments in which volunteer physicians received transfusions of large quantities of plasma from other individuals indicated that it was the body’s rejection of ‘foreign’ plasma that is responsible for many adverse reactions.

“One interpretation of the research results is that every individual shows an allergic type of response to every other individual’s plasma but his own. This phenomenon is similar to that known to exist for skin grafts. Skin may be grafted successfully from one portion of the body to another portion in the same patient. But a skin graft from another person, except an identical twin, will not ‘take’.

“The doctors suggested that when allergic reactions occur, it indicates that the plasma from the transfused blood is leaking out of the blood vessels into tissues. They say that if this does take place the patient ‘is deriving relatively little benefit from the transfusion’ apart altogether from the danger and discomfort of the reaction.

“This study suggests that in a national emergency where massive transfusion of a blood substitute is vital, dextran may prove to be a more effective and safer substance than dried plasma' which has been used under such conditions in the past.”3*5

Note from the above that the basic thinking is that no one person’s blood will combine with another person’s blood. The conclusion from this study supports the view taken by Doctor Shadman supra that since no two bloods are alike, they cannot possibly combine and this form of therapy is in error. If they cannot combine or “take” there is no value. Blood is as individual and unmatch-able as fingerprints. Every blood transfusion must of necessity be incompatible to some extent.

The results of actual case studies also support the view that blood transfusions permanently upset the natural chemical balance of the patient’s own individual blood. This is especially dangerous with respect to women of child-bearing age.

Dr. Bruce Chown, Winnipeg, has analyzed a number of cases under the title “Transfusion of Girls and Women Can Kill Their Babies.” He states:

“When Mary N., then in her teens, had typhoid fever in 1936, she was given a transfusion of her mother's blood. She married six years later and the following year had a nice normal baby. The next year, however, she gave birth to twins, one hydropic and the other macerated. She was Rb-negative, her mother Rh-posi-tive, her first child Rh-negative. It was eight years from the time of her transfusion to the death of her first Rh-positive babies. Seventeen years after that poisonous transfusion she lost her second Rh-positive baby, stillborn.”

Dr. Chown adds: “This is . . . written to illustrate the fact that transfusion of girls or women may years later kill their babies; the time intervals between transfusion and disaster in these three cases was 2 years, 13 years and 8 years; we have been able to demonstrate Rh antibodies as long as 30 years after the last possible antigenic stimulus.”37

If some of the chemical disturbances of the blood resulting from transfusion are still evident, eight, seventeen or even thirty years later, it becomes obvious that introduced blood cannot possibly “take” or ever really combine with that which each individual is given at birth. A permanent incompatibility is set up within the patient’s life stream. If the patient is a woman of child-bearing age the result can be very serious.

Quite apart from the continuing difficulties that arise from unmatched and unmatchable blood, other doctors take exception to the wholly unscientific abuse of this practice.

Doctor Frank Riggall, F.R.C.S. (Edin.), has stated:

“Because I entered surgery before the flood of blood began, I am always amazed to see blood given for ordinary operations. It seems to be quite all right to take a pint of blood from a donor and let him walk home but wrong to lose a little blood during ordinary surgery! My belief is put into practice. In nearly 17,500 admissions to this general hospital we have not found it necessary to transfuse more than a dozen times. Our mortality rates compare favourably with those of other institutions.”38

Note also Dr. H. A. Gibson of Calgary, who states:

“I am one who had a large practice in the days before transfusions and did fairly well, I think. With the coming of transfusions a new era began. . .. Tire operation was also very dramatic and being new and expensive "must be good’. .. . One hospital I know of reported a greater number of transfusions for one month than had been given at the Toronto General Hospital the previous year. This was in the ‘hey-day’ of transfusions. I hope there are fewer now.”39

This doctor believes the “hey-day” of transfusions is past. There is already a retrenchment from the extreme position taken for a certain time. Some of the other medical writings indicate a probability of further retrenchment. So when blood transfusion goes the way of bloodletting into the limbo of desuetude, how foolish will be the law and the lawmakers who have enshrined it in the statute books!

Let’s be sensible about this matter of medical treatment. It is changing every day. Consider the words of Dr. A. A. Klass, of Winnipeg:301

“First and foremost is the very nature of medical practice itself. In a field of rapid discovery, the accepted treatment of today was risky yesterday; and will be obsolete tomorrow. During the period of yesterday, the treatment was new and hazardous, perhaps experimental in the eyes of the court, and few doctors would come to its defense. During the period of tomorrow it is obsolete, antiquated, proven to be wrong, condemned in the witness box and accepted as negligent by the court. It is only during the brief period of today that the treatment is right and proper and this period is made ever shorter by the rate of discovery.’

Blood transfusion can be obsolete tomorrow. In fact, the opinions and admissions quoted show clearly that many eminent medical writers are already very dubious about the scientific justification of blood transfusion. It does cause sickness. It has been medically described as a “craze”. Apparently blood is unmatchable and incompatible on the same principle of individuality that is found in fingerprints. Since there remains a substantia) doubt as to its value, how can it be argued that this is a solid foundation upon which to change the law to found a completely new departure in doctor-patient relationships?

  • Chapter 4 THE LAW IN A DEMOCRATIC STATE

SHOULD NOT INVADE THE SANCTITY OF THE FAMILY OR INTERFERE WITH ITS FREEDOM OF WORSHIP

  • A. It is a Nazi-Spartan theory that children belong to the state and that the cold-blooded wisdom of officialdom should outweigh the warmth, love and judgment of the family circle.

From a legal standpoint, consideration must be given to the interests and freedoms of (a) the family, (b) the child and (c) the community. As stated by .Lord Justice Denning, "It is simply a question of .balancing the con-' flicting interests”.40 Ip balancing these conflicting interests, it is important that fair weight shall be given to each.

  • (i) Family life and rights are sacred and are vital to the well-being of the nation

A very useful statement of proper legal approach to the various considerations of family, infant and community, is made by Mr. Justice Rand of the Supreme Court of Canada in Hepton v. Maat:41

“It is, I think, of the utmost importance that questions involving the custody of infants be approached with a clear view of the governing considerations. That view cannot be. less than this: prima facie the natural parents are entitled to custody unless by reason of some act, condition or circumstance affecting them it is evident that the welfare of the child requires that that fundamental natural relation be severed.
