It is healthier for us to recognize this, than to pretend that we are operating in a cold intellectual vacuum. And when there is litigation, we should seek not for an impartial physician, but rather for two partisan physicians who are honest, and who can present their own points of view’, subject to cross examination.”

It is true that doctors disagree violently about diagnosis and treatment. The difficulty is that when there is a case involving malpractice or blood transfusion, the disagreement is hidden and all pretend that there is unanimity of opinion. The courts do not see the real picture.

Dr. Davidson concludes:

w “Some doctors suffer from racial or religious preju-51 dice and allow this to influence their judgment ... If we allow professional freedom, then there comes with it the freedom to have all kinds of whims and peculiar ideas coloured by our own personality, rather than drawn out of scientific facts.”98

Prejudices and whims are not a sound basis for legal action, but the abdication of function by the judges in medical cases opens the door to people being discriminated against on such bases.

A revealing study of medical testimony was made by a special committee of the Bar, New York City:100

“But not all doctors who testify are equally competent . . . Nor are all doctors equally impartial. Some are above suspicion. A few are corrupt. In between are a number who become infected with bias when called as witnesses in the conventional way . . . Too often their testimony reflects the partisan source from which their compensation comes.”

If medical evidence is often partisan and unreliable in ordinary cases, how much more is it bound to be so when there is an issue that is considered, though it really isn’t so, an affront to the profession. Under such circumstances, much of the evidence is not entitled to be taken seriously.

When litigation is on any subject that touches the medical profession or a member, doctors have even been publicly counselled, not to tell the whole truth.

“Whatever a doctor says in court, he should never say anything derogatory about another doctor.

“If a doctor in a witness box thinks well of a doctor whose name is questioned, he should lay it on with compliments. If he thinks the doctor is no good, he should merely tell the court that he doesn’t know him very well.”101

This was the admonition of Dr. Robert Tuby, New York medico-legal expert speaking in Toronto, Does one see in this any desire to tell the truth or to candidly set facts before a court?

The persistent refusal of doctors to testify against one another has been described as a “conspiracy of silence”, Silverman’s article, Doctors In Court,102 discussed this conspiracy:

“(Lawyers) say it marks a widespread, dangerous and deliberate attempt of doctors to cover up one another’s mistakes, either by refusing to appear in court against a negligent colleague or by actual lying on the witness stand.”

The Post quoted three judges as saying:

“Gradually the courts awoke to the so-called 'conspiracy of silence.’ No matter how lacking in skill or how negligent the medical man might be, it was almost impossible to get other medical men to testify adversely to him . . . Not only would the guilty person thereby escape from civil liability for the wrong he had done, but his professional colleagues would take no steps to insure that the same results would not again occur at his hands.”

The conspiracy of silence is coming back on the medical profession by the enlarged application of res ipse loquitur. There is already a marked upsurge of litigation against doctors in the United States and Britain. No doubt it will increase here too. That the conspiracy of silence is not confined to the United States is shown by the fact that there are only 13 successful malpractice cases reported in Canada since Confederation.103 Does this mean there have been only 13 instances of negligence in 93 years? No: but it may indicate that the courts have been too lenient with the conspiracy of silence. The wrongs are not being ventilated. The checks and balances of the law which could serve both to recompense the injured and tn provide healthy discipline for the medical profession, have been rendered virtually inoperative. As in the United States, counsel and judges may begin to dig a little deeper: to tear the mask off silence.

The silence of the malpractice cases is repeated in the blood transfusion cases. The full story and the admitted dangers are not being brought out in evidence. Doctors who might like to testify contrary to orthodox thinking are frankly afraid of the Medical Association. The testimony given in these cases is not to be taken without reservation.

Chapter 6 CONCLUSION -

SOME PRACTICAL CONSIDERATIONS

In all legal questions, we are dealing with certain human equations that are not as simple as mathematical formulae. Actual precision, or a complete remedy for any problem, is usually not possible. If the correction of the problem is complete, then usually the remedy will create a further problem. Remedial legislation must be balanced. Otherwise it may either miss the evil aimed at or create a worse evil in itself.

While seeking to strike at the supposed evil of an infinitesimal number of cases involving refusal of blood transfusion, it is proposed there be a broad change in the law to hand over to every doctor complete carte blanche authority on every juvenile case of every kind so that no parent can ever disagree with a doctor on anything.

Parents may make decisions which will sometimes be wrong. At the same time, they certainly love their children and no one is as interested as the parents in doing what is good for them. Parents will make some mistakes and children will die, but the genius of our law over the centuries leaves this responsibility with the parents. They will suffer most from such errors, and therefore are those who will give the greatest love, thought and attention to the welfare of their own children.

On the other hand, doctors and state officials and courts also make mistakes. Their mistakes would sometimes result in the death of children too. The confirmed medical opinions of today often require to be abandoned tomorrow. Undue medical or official interference with

parents and children can result in great tyranny and the creating of worse evil and worse abuses than the occasional issues that have already arisen in connection with this matter.

In Communist Russia and Nazi Germany we have seen what happens from the loveless efficiency of science taking over where the warmth and love of family relationship should be operating. Instead of the law being extended by giving professional men further power to invade the sanctity of the home, it is submitted it has already gone too far. Parents should be entitled to a fair hearing before competent courts. “Neglected child” provisions should be confined to cases of actual neglect, abandonment of parental discretion. It is a distortion of such statutes to pretend there is neglect when in truth there is only justifiable exercise of discretion by parents in the face of medical uncertainty in the field of blood transfusion.

A further factor that must be considered in this matter is the damage that coercion can do to the medical profession itself. As long as people are allowed a choice of treatment, the medical profession must always meet the challenge of public opinion. This is healthy. It must have an acceptable service to offer to the people and the right of the patients to accept or refuse will always be a challenge to the profession to maintain a high standard. Doctor-patient relationships are very delicate and have been built up by mutual respect on both sides over the centuries. What a tragedy it will be if courts and police, instead of confidence and desire for help, now become the forces that drive people into physicians’ offices! The greatest loss from all this ultimately will be to the medical profession itself.                  ,

Even without the law being carried any further than its present position, 'civil and religious liberties of the people are being broken down. The consequence is an eroding away of the principles upon which the democratic state stands, and ultimate damage to the nation and all its people. Evil breeds evil: injustice breeds more injustice: to sacrifice a principle for expediency creates precedent that breaks clown the whole fibre of principle and personal responsbility upon which the welfare of the nation depends. Frankly, the price is too high, especially when we recall that there is no real proof of serious damage that has yet come to anyone who has not had the desired surgery'.

The liberties of the people of a free nation are entitled to much more weight than has been given to them in this issue. It is an outrage for the law, and the community must take the responsibility for it, to reach inside a home and snatch away a child, largely because the community does not agree with the religious views of the parents. This is being done to a minority, Jehovah’s witnesses, while majority groups such as the Roman Catholics who also have disagreement with medicine in other fields, are left immune. A nation that fails to do justice only injures itself.                      -

The rights of Jehovah’s witnesses as a minority are being trampled on *in this issue. One-sided press reports, “experts” with an axe to grind and the full force of vested interests flying the banners of their own self-interest are bearing down for the purpose of destroying the liberty of

HLG-12/60

an unpopular minority. By ignoring principle and seeing only sentimental expediency the community will pull down the house of democracy on its own head.

Let thinking people consider the following warning from Mr. Justice Douglas:104

“A people indifferent to their civil liberties do not deserve to keep them and in this revolutionary age may not be expected to keep them long. A people who proclaim their civil liberties but extend them only to preferred groups start down the path to totalitarianism. They emulate either the dictatorship of the Right or the dictatorship of the Left. In doing this they erase a basic distinction between our system of government and totalitarianism.

“To allow that to happen is to lose by default. Far better to lose pleading the cause of decency and or justice.”

Let us not make the mistake of regarding the objections of minorities as mere nuisances on the passage of life. Minorities with courage like Jehovah’s witnesses, who beard the brief authority of the day are at once part of the intellectual vitality of a free nation and contributors in very large measure to the freedom we enjoy.

“Five of the victims whose cases reached the Supreme Court of Canada in the last decade, and who have contributed so greatly to the clarification of our law, were Jehovah’s witnesses”,106

states Professor F. R. Scott, noted constitutional authority. The valuable part played by independent minorities is shown by Mr. Justice Rand:100

“Th? freedoms we enjoy were won by men prepared at the risk of life and liberty, to beard the brief authority sitting in judgment upon them; but are the Lilbums today guarding the ramparts to challenge those who would straight-jacket us into conformity? Must tile individual be left to be crushed by these pressures? The social tyranny of extorting recantation, of ostracism and virtual outlawry as the new means of coercing the man out of line, is the negation of democracy. Much of present Western society demonstrates the truth of the saying, that wolves fight in packs but the lion fights alone.”

The remarkable growth of this democratic state and the welfare which its people enjoy have come about under a regime of religious liberty, respect for the rights of individuals and minorities, due process of law and fair hearings for all in open courts of justice. Proper balance of interest requires that these rights be maintained. Nations who have denied such freedoms have reduced the vigour of their people and gone into the decline. Can we sensibly move off the road of liberty, the road of national success into the road of oppression, the proved road to national oblivion?

It is time now to call a halt to the thinking that is bartering principle for expediency: Law and justice for the advantage of vested interests. As a community we have a duty to do justice, to leave conscientious Christian people alone with their own families.

“He hath showed thee, O man, what is good; and what doth Jehovah require of thee, hut to do justly, and to love kindness, and to walk humbly with thy God?”107

None of these cases is precisely in point with the subject of this article because in each instance there was a total failure to provide any medical attention. There is a sharp distinction between such complete refusal of therapy and the situation where in the exercise of parental discretion parents refuse one particular form of therapy while leaving all others ■open.

For a Canadian case see Rex v. Lewis 7 Cdn. C.C. 261 which followed Reg. v. Senior. Lewis, a Christian Scientist, was held criminally liable for the death of his child which had died from diphtheria and no medical assistance of any kind had been provided. It appears that since the foregoing conviction the Christian Scientists have not adhered rigidly to this principle of tliier faith and have called in medical assistance in eases involving children.

Jehovah Witness Surgeon®

WtBi Treat Bn}wed Youth

A seriously injured 16-year-old boy who has refused a blood transfusion on religious grounds has been ordered into the care of a physician with Similar religious beliefs.                         ’

Juvenile Court Judge Ted Robertson issued the order Wcdncs- ■ day, rescinding his prior order of last Monday in which he had declared the boy dependent and neglected, placing him in the custo- 41 dy of the Dallas County Child Welfare Unit.

The boy was injured Friday in a motorcycle accident, in which both his arms and legs were broken, his skull fraclured, and 40 per cent of his blood lost, according to medical authorities, He and his parents, Jehovah Witnesses, refused to allow Baylor Hospital. doctors to administer a blood transfusion during surgery.

In testimony Wednesday, Dr. Robert J. Winslow, also a Jehovah Witness, testified he could perform the surgery without a blood transfusion. Two other doctors gave similar testimony. .

Judge Robertson ordered the patient into the care of Dr. Winslow, and the boy will be transferred to East. Town Osteopathic z Hospital Thursday.

Wednesday’s court action came after another doctor attending ■ the boy had asked for a court order to allow the transfusion as necessary in treating the youth; '''                         ■

DALLAS TIMES HERALD November 24, 1971

Ironically, Tuesday's surgery was handled by two surgeons on the staff of Baylor Hospital, according to Jehovah’s Witnesses sources, although Dr. Winslow is the attending physician.                                    .■

Dennis Vail of Waxahachie, a spokesman for Jehovah's Witnesses, explained the religious group is opposed to blood transfusions on Biblical grounds, citing such scripture as Acts 15; 20 where Christians were warned to “abstain . . . from blood.”

“Jehovah's Witnesses have been seeking justice through courts for the last 20 years in the matter or medical treatment concerning this issue. The first time we got it was '>ov. 17,1971, in Dallas, when Judge Robertson was fair enough to give us a full hearing."

Injured Boy

Recovering


Rapidly


A IS-year-old Dallas boy, injured Nov. 12 in a motorcycle accident is "making an excellent recovery" from surgery pe-formed without ThTuuse~pi> blood transfusions, according to his attending physician.

Dr. W. E. Winslow of East Town Osteopathic Hospital told The Times Herald Wednesday Aaron Washburn has encountered “no problems at ail” in his recovery from facial surgery Nov. 23 io repair his broken jaws. He said the boy has been moved from the intensive, care unit to a private room at the medical facility.

The doctor said further surgery to set the boy's arms and legs, all broken in the acci* dent, will be performed Friday and next week.               1

The case was placed in Dr. Winslow's hands Nov. 17 by Juvenile Court Judge Ted Robert^ son when the boy and his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Washburn refused on religious grounds to allow doctors al Baylor Hospslal (where the boy was initially taken) to administer a blood transfusion during sur-, gery.                              •

Jehovah's Witnesses bases their oppositon to the use of biood transfusions on scripture. ' Judge Robertson had earlier placed the Washburn boy in the custody of the Dallas County Child Welfare Unit, declaring him dependent and neglected, so the blood transfusion could be given. However, he rescinded this order and placed the young man in the care of the physician who held similar religious beliefs and testified the surgery <MHtld he t'erformed without the

Witnesses Claiming First Win in Court

' DALLAS (AP) — Members of l ing, Judge Robertson rescinded the Jehovah’s Witness religious!his order and placedlhe youth tody are claiming their first;.in the care of Dr. W. E. Win-


victory in a long battle against court'-imposed _ blood • trans^ fusions for their ill and injured.

But, religious issues aside,


the greater question may be to what extent is man master of his own body.

Jehovah’s Witnesses have


grappled with the medical es-. Jgblishment for decades over the-issue of blood.

But they have fared none too well in their opposition to transfusions, which they claim violate Biblical teaching. '

A car-motorcycle accident in ballas last month may have opened the door toward more acceptance of the demonina-tion’s belieftT

■' Aaron Washbum, 16, was riding his motorcycle on a Dallas street Nov. 12 when a truck loomed ahead of him.

The two vehicles collided in a metal-rending crash that left young Washburn a heap of blood-soaked fractures, more dead than alive.

'‘They told me I would die unless I had a transfusion,” he said.                   _

When Washbum, a Jehovah’s Witness, refused the blood, doctors sought and were granted a court order by Juvenile Court Judge Ted Robertson. “

Robertson "ordered Washburn into the custody of the Dallas County Child Welfare Unit, declaring him dependent, and neglected by fiis parents, Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Washbum.

' Later, following a court hear-slow, himself a Jehovah’s Witness.

Washburn’s arms and legs were shattered in various places. His laws were broken, his teeth missing, his skull injured. He had lost a lot of blood.

Winslow pumped glucose and other blood expanders info Washburn’s body" while peF~ forming a series of tedius oper? aliens.

' “The whole secret in what we call 'tightrope surgery’ is not to lose any blood,” Winslow explained.

“I didn’t do anything that any other surgeon can’t do provided he is careful—meticulous about his surgery. Doctors who rely on transfusions can afford to be sloppy in their surgery. They can afford to let the patient bleed. So what? They can pump him full of someone else’s blood.

“Aside from the religious aspects, transfusions are bad business.‘Look at the diseases you can get, from blood—malaria, syphilis, hepititis. You can overload the patient with blood. And when he is anesthe-tised, certain allergic manifes-'tations may not be apparent. Even blood incompatibility may not be recognized,” he said.

Noted Houston heart surgeon Dr. Denton Cooley has performed 80 open heart operations without the use of blood, Winslow said, which strengthens his views for so-called

“bloodless surgery.”

“I operated with blood transfusions for 28 years. The past four years I have not used blood. I find the patient does better,” Winslow said.

“For years and years we have, not had the benefit of being; heard in court when these '■ cases come up,” said Dennis VaU, a spokesman for the Jehovah’s Witnesses. Vail said all members of the group are considered ministers, like himself ■ although none use the title “reverend.”                        '

“A judge grants an order for •blood and the patient and his family has had nothing to say about it. This time, in the Washbum case, it was different. We went into court prepared to bring 30 persons who would testify they had under-; gone serious surgery without transfusions. We now have a precedent on the record,” he said.

“If I’m right," said Winslow,' “I don’t care what other doctors think. I believe operating without blood transfusions will become more popular' in time.77

Jehovah’s Witnesses base their opposition to blood transfusions in the Christian prohibition they say is contained in Acts 15: 19-20.

Another passage of scripture, taken from Deuteronomy, admonishes: “Simply be firmly resolved not to eat the blood, because the blood is the soul and you must npt eat the soul with the flesh.”

Greenville (Texas) Herald Banne? Al I Sunday Morning, December 26, 1971


Aaron Washhum, 18, looks over get -well cards with his mother in a Dalias hospital. Aaron and his family ar® Jehovah's Witnesses and refused to allow Aaron to have blood transfusions following his serious injury in a motorcycle-truck collision last month, even though doctors said he couldn't survive without blood. A doctor, also a Jehovah's Witness, saved Aaron without blood transfusions/

Greenville (Texas) Herald Banner

Sunday Morning, December 26, 1971

Ml



YOU WERE THE JUSXtE,


WHAT WOO YOUR DECISION BE? A


WE INVITE you to put yourself in the position of a judge in this court case from Austria:

A two-year-old girl is afflicted with leukemia. The physician handling the case orders administration of a blood transfusion. For religious reasons, the parents reject that treatment. From this point on, the physician


and he went. The parents


refuses to give any further medical treatment to the child. The child is discharged from the hospital.


The parents then search for some other treatment that might help their little girl, but, a short time later, she dies. The local authorities charge the parents with manslaughter. The case comes before the court. The public prosecutor, in his accusation, demands that the parents be punished. If you were the judge, what would be your decision?

Please read this article and get familiar with the case before rendering your decision.


maintained their stand respecting blood transfusions for their child. At that the doctor declared: “Then the case is closed, as far as I am concerned.”

Thus, from the very beginning the hospital showed intentions of discharging the child from its care if


The Disease and the Child’s Death

In May 1970, Eduard and Veronika Walter of Steyr, Upper Austria, observed that their two-year-old daughter, Irene, was very pale. They immediately consulted a pediatrician. He believed that Irene’s ailment was simply a case of malnutrition. Since her condition did not improve, the parents consulted the doctor again in September. Irene’s blood was examined, but no blood disease was found.


the parents would not agree to a certain type of treatment—a blood transfusion. That same evening, Mr. and Mrs. Walter were allowed to take their child home, without receiving any instructions whatsoever as to other methods of treat-


A. month later, toward the end of October, the child was sent to the General Public District Hospital in Steyr. Two days later, when the mother came to see the child in the hospital, she was told that Irene would have to be given a blood transfusion. Mrs. Walter explained that, as one of Jehovah’s Christian witnesses, she refused any blood transfusion for her child because of the Bible command to abstain from blood of any sort.—Acts 15:28, 29; Lev. 17:14.

Then the father was asked to come to the hospital,


ment.

Repeatedly, they asked whether there were methods of helping their child other than by blood transfusion. But the doctor said there were none. The parents took Irene to a clinical hospital in Upper Austria and thence to two nonmedi-


SEPTEMBER 22, 1972


17


cal             to Germany arid Austria.

No ©ure was found th© child. O«

5P xt?C} she &d at th© horn© ©f her w«mto to Stoyr.

Charges $r&U0ht        the Parentis

Are you under the impression that the parents actually wanted their child to die, or that they deliberately contributed to her death by their rejection of a blood transfusion? Dr, Alfred Andel seems to have felt that way, for when he made out the postmortem examination paper, he filled in Point 12 of the death certificate with the words J “Refusal of blood transfusion.” Point 12 bears the following heading: “In case of violent deaths (suicide, murder, manslaughter, accident) give details as to manner and cause of such violent death.”

The following day Dr. Andel reported the case to the Federal Police Station in Steyr. The parents were questioned immediately by the Federal Criminal Investigation Department, and they explained their religious viewpoint on blood transfusions. Moreover, they stated that the doctors had not been able to guarantee a cure, arid, knowing that transfusion of blood can also have serious, even fatal results, this reason, too, had led them to refuse a transfusion.

The police passed the report on to the public prosecutor’s office, which, in turn, obtained an opinion from the institute of Forensic Medicine of Paris Lodron University, Linz, regarding the death of Irene Walter. The final opinion of the Institute, written by Professor Norbert Woelkart and head physician Dr. Klaus Jarosch, said:

“Actually the life prognosis respecting this disease is infaust [not favorable] even with modern medication, i.e., basically a recovery was not possible, the fundamental ailment proving fatal sooner or later.”

IS

However, this same opinion wept on to say that refusal to consent to blood trans-fwpns “shortened th© child's life-span not inconsiderably.” Th® summary was that the child died from anemia due to leukemia hBS “prevention of proper medical treatmem.”

The public prosecutor’s office then filed accusation against Eduard and Veronika Walter at the Circuit Court, Steyr, on February 19, 1971. It was asserted that their refusal to consent to blood transfusion for their child was a violation of section 335 of the penal law with regard to security to life. This law says:

“Any action or default of which the acting person is able to perceive even by its natural consequences, obvious to anyone, or by virtue of specially publicized regulations or by way of his rank, office, profession, trade, occupation, or generally by way of his particular circumstances, that a danger to life, health or physical security of persons might be induced or likely to be enhanced, should, if severe injury was caused to a person, be counted as a violation of the law on the part of the guilty one and be punished with imprisonment up to six months or with a fine up to S 100,000.00 [about $4,350] and, should the death of a person result, with imprisonment up to one year.”

The accusation closes with the request that the second measure of punishment of this law be meted out.

Questions to Be Considered

What do you think about the case now? Do you agree with the public prosecutor’s charge, feeling that the guilt of the accused has been sufficiently established? Or did the parents conscientiously do all they could to save the child’s life? What likelihood was there for the child to survive or for her life to be lengthened by a blood transfusion? Was blood transfusion the only proper treatment and the best therapy in this case?

On the other hand, did the doctors do all they could do and ought to do in order

AWAKE!

to help til© child? Let us turn to some opinions of experts.          .

Whzsi Is ths Proper Therapy?

The summary in the aforementioned final opinion reads: “Death from anemia due to aleukemic lymphadenosis and prevention of proper medical treatment.” What if that which is considered “proper” treatment turned out to involve certain risks? As a fair judge you would have to take this into consideration in your opinion. Consider, then, the following:

During preliminary investigation, the parents submitted the Monatsschrift flier Kinderhedkunde (Monthly Magazine for [the German Association of] Pediatrics), Vol. 118, No. 1, January 1970, to the court. This magazine published the discourses given at the 67th conference of the German Association for Pediatrics at Saarbruecken on September 24, 1969, on the subject “Newer Viewpoints on Leukemia of Children.”

Page two states that weeks before hospitalization, symptoms of the disease are perceptible. Pages four to twelve deal with the variety of today’s most effective chemotherapeutic methods of treatment and their success. This scientific discussion on twenty-six pages of the publication for pediatrics was submitted to the Forensic Institute of Forensic Medicine of Paris Lodron University, Linz, in order to obtain a supplementary opinion.

Thereupon, the Institute summarized the discussion in about thirty-five lines and stated that “the more recent methods of treatment of acute leukemia have led to a considerable prolongation of survival.” They added: “The time of survival has been increased by modem methods of treatment to an average of 13 months.” “One even expects five times the normal period of survival.”

SEPTEMBER 22, 1972

The parents’ counsel for defense also obtained expert opinions: Professor H. Weicker, head of the Institute of Human Genetics at Bonn University and coeditor of a handbook for pediatrics, treated more than 200 children suffering from acute leukemia during twenty years of pediatric prrctice. Professor Weicker writes:

“The average life expectancy of a child with acute undifferentiated leukemia is approximately three months, if the child is not treated from the first occurrence of clear symptoms of leukemia. Irene Walter showed these symptoms in May or June (unusual paleness) and in July (enlargement of the spleen), regardless of whether they were diagnosed as such or not. The average life expectancy—without treatmentwould have been September or October 1970; this could have varied, of course, individually. The life expectancy of children with leukemia has not or has only insignificantly changed since blood transfusions have been introduced. . . .

“Only by the introduction of cortisone into leukemia therapy has the life expectancy increased to six to nine months on the average. This is why the combined cortisone-cytostatica therapy is completely in the foreground in leukemia treatment. . . . Judging the course of disease in this manner and taking into account our knowledge about the chances of survival of leukemic children, the inference of a violent death due to refusal of a blood transfusion must be rejected in the case involved. . . . There is no doubt that the chances of prolonging her life were increased considerably since the combined cortisone-cytostatica therapy was introduced, however, alone by means of this therapy and not by means of blood transfusions, customary since the forties.”

ffiisks of Blood Transfusions

Another expert asked for his opinion was Dr. F. W. Guenther, head of the city hospital of Wuppertal-Barmen, Germany. He said that he ‘entirely agreed’ with the© above-mentioned opinion of Professor Weicker and then added his own opinion:

“Being director of WUppertal-Barmen’s clinical hospital for children, which admits

19

20


AWAKE! SEPTEMBER 22, 19?2


four to five thousand patients annually, the disease features of leukemia during childhood are familiar to me. I have never seen a . child survive that was suffering from leukemia. .. . The physicians treating Irene are to be agreed with inasmuch as a blood transfusion was recommended to the parents. In this connection, however, it should be mentioned that I have observed myself that blood transfusions can cause serious, even fatal complications in leukemic patients.”

By order of the court the records of the case were sent to the head physician of the pediatric department of the Moedling Hospital, to university lecturer Dr. Ruzi-czka, to obtain an additional pediatric expert opinion.

In this opinion, Dr. Ruziczka said that a blood transfusion would have been appropriate in the case of Irene Walter as treatment for the anemia associated with the leukemia affliction. But he also pointed out the disadvantages and even life endangerment that a blood transfusion may bring about.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter were well aware of the risks involved in giving blood transfusions. They had read the booklet published by the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society entitled “Blood, Medicine and the Law of God.” This treatise, which gives documented evidence as to the various dangers involved in administering blood transfusions, was added to the court’s records.

21


The Trial

On October 27, 1971, the trial was held at Steyr. A physician of the Steyr hospital, Dr. Johann Fritz, was heard as a witness. He testified that the proposed blood transfusion would have been intended to improve the general condition of the child, namely, her striking paleness, not as the actual treatment of her disease. After the examinations that were made in cooperation with the Innsbruck University clinical hospital, the child would have been see, in the sense of the law, that refusal of a blood transfusion should be an offense against the security of the life of their child.

  • (2) Actually, the hospital would have been obliged to call upon the court of guardianship to receive further instructions as to the child’s treatment. In view of the risk involved, the court of guardianship might well have renounced a forced blood transfusion and might have respected the religious convictions of the parents.

  • (3) The experts called upon by the court pointed to the disadvantages of a blood transfusion. Thus, the parents’ refusal was not unfounded.

transferred to the next bigger treatment center in Vienna. (The child died, however, about two and a half weeks after the initial reception into the hospital!) The actual treatment would then have been administered in Vienna.

Then the public prosecutor read the bill of indictment, charging the parents as be ing guilty of or, rather, accessory to criminal offense against security of life. He demanded their punishment.

The counsel for the defense, Dr. Heimo Puschner and Dr. Hans Frieders, Vienna, argued that the parents had done more to save their child than they had been required to do by law.

If you were the judge, what would you decide? Please review the pertinent facts of the case by answering the following questions from what you have read:

What was said in section 335 of the penal law, which the parents were accused of breaking? What did the medical opinions from both sides state? What did the parents do to prolong the life of their child?

Do not let your reasoning be swayed by the thought that the child would have died anyway. According to the law, even a shortening of life is punishable. On the other hand, would the child’s life definitely have been prolonged by a blood transfusion?

Have you reached a decision? If so, you can compare it now with the judge’s actual decision in the Walter case:

The Decision

Mr. and Mrs. Walter were acquitted on the basis of the following:

(1) The accused had informed themselves sufficiently about the effectiveness of a blood transfusion and knew that there were other efficacious methods of treatment. Therefore, they were not able to

NOTE: About ten well-known Austrian specialists, including university lecturers, chief surgeons of pediatric clinical hospitals and directors of pediatric hospitals of universities in Austria declared, when questioned in connection with this case, that they personally were willing to respect the religious stand of Jehovah’s witnesses in the blood issue and that they would administer all other conceivable medical treatment, so as to help these patients. Such physicians are to be commended, for they are endeavoring to help their fellowman, and, at the same time, they show respect for the Bible-based dictates of Christian conscience.

Guides to the Judge in Medical Orders Affecting Children Council of Judges, National Council on Crime and Delinquency

Foreword

From its birth in 1907, as the National Probation Association, the National Council on Crime and Delinquency. has been vitally concerned with the administration of juvenile courts. It has taken the lead in legislative reform of these courts through the promulgation of the Standard Juvenile Court Act and the Standard Family Court Act, which have influenced the laws of every state in the country.

Statutory change alone will not solve the juvenile courts' problems. In such publications as Procedure and Evidence in the Juvenile Court, “Transfer of Cases between Juvenile and Criminal Courts,” and “Guides for Juvenile Court Judges on News Media Relations,” NCCD’s Council of Judges has implemented the statutory requirements of the Standard Acts to guide the judiciary in its difficult tasks. Significantly, in Kent v. United States, the United States Supreme Court required procedures suggested in the “Transfer” statement; in In the Matter of Gault, it required procedures enunciated in the Standard Acts and Procedure and Evidence.

107


The statutes governing the issuance of medical orders affecting children are in disarray; procedures are grossly inadequate in many courts and erratic in all; the state of the case law is confused and unanalyzed. By compiling the law on this subject, scrutinizing its basis and operation, and clarifying its goals, the Council of Judges has made another contribution to the effective and fair operation of juvenile courts.

—Milton G. Rector

Director, NCCD

CRIME and DELINQUENCY

NATIONAL COUNCIL ON CRIME AND DELINQUENCY

Volume 14


April 1968


Number 2


Preface

When a child allegedly'dying from Jack of medical attention is brought before the juvenile court, with doctors urging medical procedures resisted by the parents and, perhaps, by other doctors, the judge must decide whether to authorize the state to intervene in the child's interest. It is his awesome duty to adjudicate the conflicting claims.

All too frequently judges have had to make this decision with little knowledge and little preparation. Sometimes they have imposed their judgment on the family without a thorough airing of the facts and allegations and without guides for proper procedure and disposition. The statement below attempts to explore the alternatives open to the court in a medical emergency and to sketch the medical and legal bases, of its decision.

Proper procedures and the methods of implementing them are enunciated, and the delicate balance between the parents’ right to decide on proper medical treatment for their children and the state’s obligation to its young citizens is examined. Perhaps most important, this statement gathers together for the first time the legal and medical authorities on imposed medical treatment.

While questions of medical treatment for children against their parents’ wishes do not form a major part of the juvenile courts’ workload, it is vital that guidance in this area be available to the judge. We cannot ignore or treat hastily an aspect of juvenile court laws which literally alfccts the life or death of human beings.

—Alfred P. Murrah

Chief Judge, U.S. Court of Appeals Oklahoma City

Chairman, NCCD Council of Judges

Medical Orders Affecting Children

109


Guides to the Judge in Medical Orders Affecting Children

One of the most important responsibilities faced by juvenile courts is deciding whether to order medical treatment for children whose parents or guardians are unable or unwilling to consent to it. In spite of the difficult problems involved, juvenile court laws and other statutes provide little guidance for dealing with them. Traditionally, decisions about a child’s medical treatment fall within the province of the parent, not the court. Yet, sometimes, parents who are in all other respects fit to care for their children make medical decisions which seemingly endanger their welfare. It is important, therefore, to develop a clear-cut policy defining the limits of the court’s jurisdiction over children in need of medical care.

In all cases where the imposition of medical treatment is requested, there are important questions of substance and procedure. How extreme must the danger be to justify judicial intervention? What elements must be proved to support a Ending of medical neglect? What kind of evidence should be required at the hearing? Should the court have the power to order medical treatment without a hearing in some cases? Can notice to parents be dispensed with?

Jurisdiction

Juvenile courts have assumed jurisdiction to order medical treatment for children by joining two old doctrines of English common law.

The first of these is the traditional doctrine of parens patriae, whereby the state may intervene to protect the welfare of a neglected or errant child. It originated in the desire of the court of chancery to protect the property and morals of children whose parents were considered unfit to do so.1 There is no record of intervention by the early court of chancery to order medical treatment for children over their parents’ objections.2 Therefore, to extend the parens patriae power to the extent of overruling parental objection to medical treatment, modern courts have relied on another old English doctrine—-the doctrine that medicine is one of the necessaries of life. Since the state has the power to ensure that each child be furnished with necessaries, and medicine is a necessary, it follows that a court may order medical treatment for a child.

The common law has long recognized medical treatment as a necessary. An infant cotdd obligate himself by contract to pay for medical attention. In a 1628 decision the Kings Bench stated a principle which is still law today:

Everything which is useful is a necessary. And if an infant is injured, he may bind himself by contract with the surgeon.3

In an early New York case, the court’s responsibility to furnish medi-

r See Shelley v. Westbrook, Jac. 266, 37 Eng. Rep. 850, ch. 1817. It has been pointed out that, as a practical matter—perhaps because of a lack of facilities—the English court of chancery was originally concerned mainly with wealthy children. See Ketcham, The Unfulfilled Promise of the Juvenile Court, 7 Crime & Delin. 97-110 (1961), reprinted in Justice for the Child (Rosenheim cd. 1962).

" Under the poor laws a court could order medical treatment for a pauper, regardless of age, but there is no record that it ever did so over the pauper’s objection. See Atkins v. Banwell, 22 East 505, 102 Eng. Rep. 462 (1802) ; Wennall v. Adney, 2 Bos. & Pul. 248, 127 Eng. Rep. 137 (1802).

3 Pickering v. Gunning, Palm. 528, 81 Eng. Rep. 1204 (1629) ; see also Huggins v. Wiseman, Carth. Ill, 90 Eng. Rep. 669 (1690).

110


Council of Judges

cine to a pauper as a necessary under the poor laws was described thus:

If the pauper be sick, common sense and humanity dictate that medicine and attendance are as necessary as food and clothing, and the precise amount of such medicine and attendance could not be fixed before hand. It must depend upon the circumstances of the case. The account exhibited, as well as the order of the justices, shows the distressed condition of the pauper. The justices in their order say that “he must inevitably perish unless timely relieved,” as he had a white swelling on his knee; and it appears that the disorder terminated in the amputation of his thigh. If an order on the overseers for medical aid could not legally be made in such a case, what was to be done? Did the statute mean that the man should be left to the aid of private compassion, or to perish? The law ought not to be so narrowly construed, and the order is to be deemed sufficient to cover the expenditure in question.'42 ■

Thus, modern courts, in ordering medical treatment for children on the grounds that they are providing a necessary under their parens patriae powers, are following principles with roots deep in the common law. The decisions have based the power to order medical treatment over parental objection not only on the common law, but also on its codification in modern statutes dealing with neglected children.43 44 45

On the other hand, the New York courts have stated that the power to order such treatment did not exist at common law and is derived only from a statute which specifically holds that failure to furnish a child medical care shall constitute neglect.0

Recently, another theory has been developed which some courts have found more satisfactory than the doctrines outlined above. This theory is that the state is under an affirmative duty to preserve life. Thus, while it is doubtful that the original parens patriae power of the court of chancery extended to unborn children, one lower court decision has upheld an order entered before a child’s birth directing that the child receive a blood transfusion immediately after birth.46 A recent New Jersey case has extended the court’s protection to the point of ordering a pregnant woman to submit to blood transfusions which would probably become necessary to save her own life, on the ground that ■the life of her unborn child could be preserved only by such action.®

« Matter of Vasko, 238 App. Div, 128, 263 N.Y. Supp. 552 (3d Dept. 1933); bi re Roth-kowitz, 175 Mise. 918, 25 N.Y.S.2d 624 (Children's Ct. Kings Co. 1941) .

t Hoerncr v. Bcrtinato, G7 N.J. Super. 517, 171 A.2d 140 (Juv. Doni. Rcl. Ct. Bergen Co. 1961). hi this case, the mother, a Jehovah’s Witness, was in her fourth pregnancy. She was Rh-scnsitized after her first child; her second child had been born a “blue baby,” given transfusions by court order, and lived; the third child had not been transfused and had died.

8 Raleigh Fitkin-Paul Morgan Memorial Hospital v. Anderson, 42 N.J. 421, 201 A.2d 537, cert, denied, 84 Sup. Ct 1894 (1964). Glen Hoxv, attorney for the mother in this case, says: "In point of fact, an order was tnade against this woman when there was no serious problem at all. Two young resident doctors imagined that something might happen. A one-pint blood transfusion for an adult person is never justified. It is simply-placing her in a state of risk with no correlative value.” Letter to National Council on Crime and Delinquency, May 16, 1967, on file in NCCD Library.

Medical Orders Affecting Children

ill


It is clear, however, that any right of the court to order medical treatment extends only to a child, who is presumed incompetent to determine his own best interests. The cases permit medical intervention only on behalf of a child against the objections of the parents. The right of a competent adult to refuse treatment for himself, no matter how irrational the reental right to control the child's upbringing.

The courts’ answer to the first objection has been that when practice of one’s religious belief is detrimental to the welfare of others, it is not protected by the Constitution.47 42 48 49 Their answer to the parental-control objection has been that a parent’s rights over his children are not absolute and do not extend to the point of deciding whether the child shall live or die.11

The Doctrine of Relative Risk

The hazards faced by the child as the result of failure to provide him with medical treatment compared with those confronting him if that treatment is carried out appear to play a determinative role in the reasoning of the courts. The choice is between two risks, the risk of treatment and the risk of no treatment.

Under the philosophy of relative risk, in cases where death is imminent the courts act without hesitation to order appropriate treatment, but they are increasingly hesitant to intervene against the wishes and convictions of the natural parents when medical treatment is not a prerequisite to preserve life. For example, in one Pennsylvania case, the court refused to order an operation for rickets in the case of a young boy on the ground that no matter of life or death was involved.50

When a parental objection is clearly based on a realistic fear of the trcalineni risks, the courl may refuse to order medical treatment. The New York Court of Appeals was faced with the objections of the child as well as the parent. A fourtcen-year-old boy had a cleft palate, which had adverse consequences for his speech and his social development. His father had instilled in him his own strong distrust of medicine, so that the boy was frightened by the projected operation. In a 4-to-3 decision, the Court of Appeals upheld the discretion of the trial judge in giving controlling weight to the boy's own strong fears and refusing to order the operation.51

On the other hand, courts have upheld an order placing a twelveyear-old boy in the custody of a probation officer for the purpose of providing prolonged treatment for an arthritic condition and have ordered an operation to correct a deformed foot on a ten-year-old child.52 One court has authorized an operation for the removal of the left eye of a two-year-old child upon medical testimony showing that the child was blind in that eye, which was affected by a malignant glaucoma of the retina; that such condition was progressive; that it would undoubtedly involve the other eye; and that the operation had a 50 per cent chance of curing the malignancy.53 54

The Children’s Division of the Milwaukee County Court recently considered these cases and stated;

Whenever there is doubt about the efficacy of the proposed medical procedures and great danger or risk of death 1 ° (bild by the treatment proposed, parental discretion should control. Where 1 h(,|t' i* imminent possibility of loss of life or further serious disability due to inaction, parental discretion must give way to medical efforts reasonably propounded and cxjrcctcd to protect the welfare of the child.10

In the Milwaukee case, the Department of Public Welfare filed a neglect petition on behalf of a six-year-old boy suffering from incurable sickle cell anemia, which reduced his life expectancy to not more than thirty years. The county hospital physicians proposed that the child be submitted to a “red cell survival test” to determine whether he was suffering from hypersplenism, a disease which would adversely affeot his hemoglobin level and thus reduce his chances of recovering from an anemic “crisis” in which his life might be threatened. If hypersplenism were found, the doctors proposed removal of the child’s spleen. The test and the projected operation involved the removal and re-injection of the child’s blood as well as additional transfusions from foreign donors. The mother opposed

Medical Orders Affecting Children

113


the re-injection and transfusion, on religious grounds, and also opposed them, along with the operation itself, because of the dangers involved in the medical procedures. ,

The court held that, under the doctrine of parens patriae, the state has the power to order transfusions over a religious objection. However, in this case it found as follows:

There is serious doubt as to the efficacy or usefulness of the proposed medical procedures. Some of them are new and experimental. The blood test would confirm a suspected condition only. The operation, more dangerous than usual to this afflicted child, might alleviate or ameliorate the child's problem of maintaining a satisfactory hemoglobin level. But this would be at the cost of the loss of his spleen, whose whole function is not known, even though present knowledge does not establish further harm to a child of this age by its removal. The accompanying blood transfusions would not cure his sickle cell anemia even if they might prolong his life. Unquestionably, there is a serious risk of possible adverse effects of any transfusions. Medical advice as to the dire need for such blood transfusions has been proven wrong in this very case in the past, where the doctors have told the mother that transfusions were needed to save his life and it turned out not to be so.55

The court dismissed the petition, refusing to order the test and operation over the mother’s opposition, as "her reservations and objections to the proposed treatments are logical, reasonable, and made in good faith, entirely apart from her objections for religious reasons.”56 57

Non-Emergency Situations

Medical neglect is recognized as a condition which may lead to action by the juvenile court. Section 8 of the Standard Juvenile Court Act and the Standard Family Court Act gives the juvenile court jurisdiction in proceedings “concerning any child living or found within the district who is neglected as to proper or necessary support, or education as required by law, or as to medical or other care necessary for his well-being, or who is abandoned by his parent or other custodian."

A sampling of statutory provisions in a number of states reveals several that require an adjudication to precede a treatment order.10 Other statutes include medical neglect within their definition of neglect and make no mention of provisions for medical treatment.58 Many jurisdictions make no specific provision for medical neglect but include general neglect jurisdiction in their juvenile court law. In all these situations, provision for treatment cannot be made before an adjudication, as juvenile courts have no power to act which is not given to them by statute.

The new Wisconsin Juvenile Court Act specifically defines as neglected a child “without the special care made necessary by his physical or mental condition because his parent, guardian, or legal custodian neglects or refuses to provide it,” and it provides that only after an adjudication may such special care be ordered or provided by the court.59 Such a statute accords with the philosophy underlying the model acts.

Some statutes seem to give the court power to order medical treatment for a child concerning whom a petition has been filed before a hearing and yet, at the same time, require that the child be within the court's jurisdiction.60 Such statutes should be interpreted as requiring a definitive adjudication of neglect before treatment can be ordered.

A statute is insufficient if it gives the court power to act merely because die child is before the court—'that is, without an adjudication.61 62 In our view, a medical treatment order should not be issued without an adjudication of neglect.

A number of states provide for a psychiatric or medical diagnosis before adjudication.21 Some provision for a diagnostic examination is essential in a medical neglect case, because the finding of neglect will almost always be predicated on the medical reports. However, any pre-adjudica-tion examination must be conducted for diagnostic purposes only, and no treatment, other than routine and uncontested medical care to a child held in shelter or detention, should be given before adjudication.

This position is adopted in Section 22 of the Standard Juvenile Court Act and the Standard Family Court Act:

The court may order that a child concerning whom a petition has been filed shall be examined by a physician, surgeon, psychiatrist, or psychologist; and it may order treatment, by them, of a child who has been adjudicated by the court. For cither such examination or treatment, the court may place the child in a hospital or other suitable facility. The court, after hearing, may order examination by a physician, surgeon, psychiatrist, or psychologist, or a parent or guardian whose ability to care for a child before the court is at issue.

A diagnostic examination revealing physical injuries to a child, coupled with proof at the hearing that the child has been beaten or otherwise maltreated by its parents, may, of course, result in an adjudication of medical neglect, which empowers the court to order treatment if necessary. However, in many instances a child is a victim of medical inattention not because his parents want him to suffer, but because they have an unreasonable suspicion of doctors and hospitals, arc ignorant of proper medical and hygienic practices, or have an erroneous fear of the dangcrousness or painfulness of a proposed course of treatment. In other situations, the parents may be financially unable to provide proper treatment and do not know how to get treatment for the child at public expense. In either instance, the court may find medical neglect only on proof that the parent or guardian willfully permitted or enforced a deprivation of medical treatment and that this deprivation can lead to serious disability or disease.63

a.r> Luther W. Maples, judge of the Harrison County Court, Gulfport, Miss., and a member of the NCCD Council of Judges, would prefer to omit "willfully” in this sentence. He states: “A parent or guardian may deprive a child of necessary medical treatment because fie does not know any better or because of religious beliefs, or because of emotional fear or any other reason which would not be willful; and in some cases, it is true that it might be willful, but not in all cases.”

Missouri defines neglect as failure to provide necessary medical care, ‘‘except that reliance by a parent, guardian, or custodian upon remedial treatment other than medical or surgical treatment for a child shall not be construed as neglect when the treatment is recognized or permitted under the laws of this state.”20 This legislative desire to preserve the rights of parents to treat their children by other than orthodox medical methods extends even to children who are in the custody of the court.64 65

Such a provision is desirable, as no child should be found to be neglected if his parents are conscientiously providing the medical treatment prescribed by their faith. Except in an emergency, the state should not interfere with the intelligent and understanding decision of a parent or guardian to provide treatment according to his sincere religious beliefs. Even without a statute, no court should find a child to be neglected solely because the parent refuses the more usual medical procedures.

The suggested model statute contained in the U.S. Children’s Bureau publication, “Legislative Guides for the Termination of Parental Rights and Responsibilities and the Adoption of Children,” includes, within the definition of neglect, lack of parental care "necessary for [the child’s] health, morals, and well-being.” Most states have statutes providing for permanent termination of parental rights after a finding of a continued and consistent pattern of neglect.

Emergency Orders

When immediate medical attention is necessary to save a child’s life, to relieve a child of prolonged agonizing pain, or to save him from permanent physical impairment or deformity, it may be impossible to follow all the statutory formalities of a neglect proceeding. However, a hearing is always necessary, with some practical form of notice to the objecting parents and also to the child if he is of sufficient age and discretion to understand the notice.

In one case in which the hospital alleged that immediate blood transfusions were necessary to save a child’s life, the written complaint, pleadings, and notice were waived, but the court held a full hearing, with both the hospital and the objecting parent represented by counsel. The child had been in the hospital for thirty-six hours before application was made for a transfusion order, and the court heard the case immediately, at 8:30 P.M. After the presentation of medical testimony, the court appointed a special guardian, who authorized the transfusions; in spite of them, the child died.28 In another case, one day intervened between the filing of the petition and the ordering of the transfusion; the delay did not prove fatal.29 In a third case, a full hearing also took place before the transfusion was administered, and the patient lived.30

In a lower court case in Ohio, where the statute specifically gives the court power to order emergency medical treatment upon a single physician’s certificate, the court granted a transfusion order before holding a hearing. The court held that compliance with the hearing provisions of the juvenile court law would have been too time-consuming in the par-

28 State v. Perricone, supra note 5.

20 People ex rel. Wailace v. Labrenz, supra note 5.

so Morrison v. State, supra note 5.

116


Council of Judges

ticular case; it did not propose to delay the transfusion until “the child might be cold in his grave.”66

The fact that the statute empowered the Ohio court to grant the order merely on the certificate of one doctor before a hearing clearly helped obtain authorization for the needed transfusion before an emergency arose. Application was .made when it had become clear that a transfusion might be needed soon, but not immediately. Actually, the transfusion was not given until one week after it was authorized by the court.

By granting the order upon a doctor’s certificate without a hearing, the statute, as interpreted by the Ohio court, denies the parents their right to oppose the treatment on religious and medical grounds and thus encourages arbitrary action by medical authorities. As indicated in this very case, it was possible to hold a full hearing without harming the child; the hearing should have been held.

These cases show that although an emergency may exist from the physician’s point of view, the person may not in fact be in extremis. This does not imply that doctors do not testify in good faith as to a person's likelihood of surviving a crisis without undergoing a particular procedure. It means, rather, that medical knowledge is not sufficiently advanced to enable a physician to predict with reasonable certainty that his patient will live or die or will suffer a permanent physical impairment or deformity. Doctors tend to urge the imposition of a treatment when, in their expert opinion, death or permanent physical impairment is more likely to occur if the treatment is not given than if it is. However, it is the duty of the court to determine the seriousness of the emergency in a particular case, to press the testifying physician on the imminent likelihood of death or impairment, the chance of survival or of alleviation of prolonged agonizing pain if the proposed treatment is given, and the danger of the treatment itself.

For example, it seems clear that “blue babies” and accident victims may recover without blood 'transfusions and that large numbers of persons die or are infected with serum hepatitis from blood transfusions.67 Any medical decision that a particular procedure is necessary to save a child's life, relieve him from prolonged agonizing pain, or preserve the integrity of his body must be justified to the court as proposing the only proper procedure in the situation. If there is a choice of procedures —if, lor example, the doctor rccom-mends a procedure which has an 80 per cent chance of success but which the parents disapprove, and the parents. have no objection to a procedure ' which has only a 40 per cent chance of success—the doctor must take the medically riskier but parentally unobjectionable course.

As the cases indicate, in nearly every instance there is sufficient time to examine, before a judge, the assertion of emergency and the necessity of the proposed treatment. Doctors and hospitals anticipating the developing emergency should alert the court, which should be ready to conduct a hearing at what axe ordinarily noncourt hours; in pressing cases, the required hearing can be held in the judge's home or.at the hospital. The court must notify the parents of the hearing as soon as possible, by telephone or telegram or the police.

Careful forethought can speed the hearing process and lead to a more informed decision. Conferences with hospital personnel should alert them to the need for notifying the court quickly of a developing emergency, so that it can seek additional medical testimony. For example, in many cases of Rh blood disease,68 69 doctors can recognize the possible need for a transfusion weeks before birth and thus give the count ample time to hold a full hearing. Local representatives of religious sects, likely to be involved in litigation over medical treatment should be consulted, by die court, as such sects frequently know of physicians or nonmedical practitioners willing to treat children in emergencies in ways not offensive to parental beliefs. Judges should familiarize themselves with the basic medical literature on blood transfusion and other procedures for which judicial intervention is typically sought, so that they will be prepared to weigh both sides of the controversy put to them in an emergency.

If, after a .full emergency hearing with the parents present, the court is convinced that the treatment opposed by the parents is essential in the attempt to save the life of a child in extremis, to preserve him from agonizing pain, or to prevent permanent physical impairment or deformity, and if it is convinced that no other ■treatment method is feasible, even at great risk, and, finally, if it is convinced that spontaneous recovery is extremely unlikely, the court should issue an order authorizing the doctors to perform the specific treatment. The court should not order a treatment to be given, for cases have been found in which an unexpected recovery occurs during the hearing process itself, negating the need for the authorized treatment. The order should be reduced to writing as soon as time permits and should include findings of fact and a summary of the testimony and other evidence on which the court bases its decision. The findings are essential to permit appellate review of the order, which can be had even if the authorized treatment has been given.

Stigma of Unfitness

A finding of neglect (the traditional procedure used for obtaining emergency medical orders) presupposes that the parents are unfit to take care of the child.3,1 Af the same time, stigmatizing a parent as unfit to take care of his child merely because of his religious beliefs runs counter to the traditional protection of freedom of religion in this country. Some decisions have attempted to resolve this problem by emphasizing that the mere ordering of medical treatment does not mean that the parents are unfit or that they have, in the traditional sense, neglected the child. Thus, in overruling the parents' religious objection to a lifesaving blood transfusion for their child, the New York Appellate Division said:

Such finding, however, does not constitute an adjudication that the parents neglected their child in the ordinary meaning of the word. "Neglected” is here used in the legal sense within the meaning of the Domestic Relations Court Act.

118


Council of Judges

It in no way imports a finding that these parents failed in their duty to the child or in any other respect.70 71

However, upon identical facts, the Supreme Court of Illinois said that the parents had neglected their child by "deliberately depriving it of life,.”33                '        '         '

Statutory definitions of neglect present a jurisdictional problem. A Pennsylvania court refused to order medical treatment when the parents were found not to meet the statutory requirement of being “morally unfit.”72 This echo of the ancient English chancery concern with the moral fitness of the parents shows the inadequacy of reliance on the parens patriae doctrine in medical cases. Therefore, for jurisdictional purposes, as well as for the purpose of not stigmatizing parents who are simply practicing their religion, statutes should provide for emergency medical procedure divorced entirely from the “neglect” concept.

To this end, juvenile court laws should give the court jurisdiction “concerning any child who requires emergency medical treatment in order to preserve his life, prevent permanent physical impairment or deformity, or alleviate prolonged agonizing pain.” That portion of the law pertaining to notice of the adjudicatory hearing should also provide: “After the filing of a petition alleging jurisdiction under . . . [the above statutory amendment], notice of a hearing on the petition shall be given immediately to the parents of the child, and the hearing shall be held as soon as practicable,”

Problems of Custody

Under most decisions, a court order authorizing medical treatment is carried out by transferring custody of the child, including the power to remove him from his home, to a guardian or custodian, often the welfare department. In a case in which the arthritic condition of the child required prolonged medical treatment, the court granted custody of the child to the chief probation officer for the duration of the treatment, thus unnecessarily disrupting family life and possibly causing psychological injury to the child.73 Transfer of legal custody should not be made in these cases unless it is compelled by factors other than medical neglect. Since the court generally has jurisdiction under a neglect petition, it should order the parents to provide the necessary medical care without terminating custody. Authority for the order, in which the parents should be expected to acquiesce, should be given by statute. Section 24, subdivision 7, of the Standard Juvenile Court Act and the Standard Family Court Act can serve as a model:

In support of any order or decree under Section 8, subdivision 1 or 2, the court may require the parents or other persons having the custody of the child, or any other person who has been found by the court to be encouraging, causing, or contributing to the acts or conditions which bring the child within the purview of this Act and who are parties to the

as Mitchell v. Davis, supra note 5. Cf. Levitsky v. Levitsky, 231 Md. 388, 190 A.2d 67 (1963) . On review of custody of children of divorced parents, court gave custody to the mother, a Jehovah's Witness, but incorporated in the decree a provision that her consent to a transfusion was not necessary if a physician felt at any time during their minority that a transfusion was essential to preserve their life or health. proceeding, to do or to omit doing any acts required or forbidden by law, when the judge deems this requirement necessary for the welfare of the child. If such persons fail to comply with the requirement, the court may proceed against them for contempt of court.

If—as happens only rarely—the parent continues to resist a medical order, the court may find it necessax-y to appoint a guardian having authority to consent to major medical and surgical treatment.30 This interference with parental rights should be terminated as soon as possible, with full control over the child restored to the parents.

as See U.S. Children's Bureau, Guardianship, a Way of Fulfilling Public Responsibility for Children (1949). Sec also Comment, § 2, Standard Juvenile and Family Court Acts.

Appendix

Medical and Legal. Consequences of Blood Transfusion: An Annotated Bibliography

  • 1. Note, 15 Am. Jur. Proof of Facts 169 (1965).

This note contains an excellent discussion of blood components, blood types and blood typing systems, the Rh blood disease (erythroblastosis fetalis), and blood incompatibility. The material following p. 191 pertains to prenatal testing for Rh factor sensitivity and the methods of predicting that any given baby will be born with the Rh blood disease. Evidently, the art of testing for the disease, which leads to the "blue baby" phenomenon, is quite highly developed. Through the use of the appropriate tests, doctors should be able to give the court several weeks’ warning of cases in which transfusion following birth may be medically indicated because of Rh blood disease.

  • 2. Note, 11 Am. Jur. Proof of Facts 331 (1961).          "

This note is on the method of proving, in a civil action against a hospital or a doctor, that a plaintiff has, in fact, contracted hepatitis through a blood transfusion rather than by another means. The value of the note lies in its step-by-step elaboration of the dangers of blood transfusion. Medical jargon is avoided. Suggestions are given to the court on drawing lay explanations of medical problems from a testifying physician.

  • 3. Dunn, Blood Transfusions and Scrum Hepatitis, 15 Glkv.-Mar. I,. Rev. 497 (1966).             ■

This article gives references to medical literature on blood transfusion and to a variety of cases involving suits against hospitals and physicians for improper transfusions. The main portion is devoted to the problems encountered by the negligence practitioner. It indicates that courts have consistently denied relief to a plaintiff who acquires serum hepatitis from a properly performed transfusion, holding that the risk of hepatitis is inherent in the transfusing process. See Fisher v, Wilmington Gen. Hosp., 1 Storey (51 Del.) 554, 149 A.2d 749 (1959); Bal-dowitsch v. Minneapolis War Memorial Blood Bank, Inc., 270 Minn. 151, 132 N.W.2d 805 (1965); Whitehurst v. American Nat'l Red Cross, I Ariz. App. 326, 42 P.2d 584 (1965). On the other hand, death or serious injury from improperly performed transfusions may lead to the imposition of civil liability. See Berg v. New York Soc’y for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled, 1 N.Y.2d 499, 136 N.E.2d 523 (1956) ; Mississippi Baptist Hosp. v. Holmes, 214 Miss. 906, 55 So. 2d 142 (1951); Redding v. United States, 196 F. Supp. 871 (D.C. Ark.); Parker v. Port Huron Hosp., 561 Mich. I, 105 N.W.2d 1. A Florida court indicated recently that a transfusion may be action-

120


Council of Judges

able, even if properly performed, if the blood bank did not carefully screen donors for hepatitis. Moder v. Sayet, 196 So. 2d 205 (Fla. App. 3d 1967).

  • 4. Medicolegal Aspects of Blood Transfusion, 151 A.M.A.J. 1435 (1953).

This report, by the Committee on Medicolegal Problems of the American Medical Assocation, deals with blood groups and incompatibility and with the transmission of disease through the transfusion process. The report is fairly short and deals not only with the common disease of hepatitis, but with the transmission of syphilis, malaria, and other infectious diseases. It also covers the problem of contaminated blood ami of accidents following transfusion, including embolism.

The report contains the following statement:

Recent reports estimate the mortality from blood transfusion at the present time, even in the best-run institutions, to be approximately one death in one thousand to three thousand , transfusions. Considering that as many as 3,500,000 transfusions riiay be given annually in this country, this makes blood transfusions as important a cause of death as appendicitis and anesthesia.

Copies of this report are available from, medical libraries or from the NCCD Library.

  • 5. Committee on Plasma and Plasma Substitute of the Division of Medical Science, National Academy of Sciences —National Research Council, The Incidence, Mortality, and Prevention of Post-transfusion Hepatitis (1965).

This monograph, reviewing previously published material, was written for physicians specializing in transfusion techniques and, consequently, is extremely technical. It discusses methods of lowering the risks of transfusion, the need for better controls on blood storage and distribution, and the need for an adequate system of reporting cases of hepatitis induced by transfusion.

The Committee came to the following conclusion:

If the combination of an incidence of 5 cases per 1,000 units of transfused blood and a 12 per cent fatality rate is representative of the United States as a whole, 3,600 deaths from this disease would be expected annually. Using the same figures and stating the problem another way, the recipient of a typical transfusion of three units of blood has a little less than one chance in 500 of riying from post-transfusion hepatitis.

Copies of this monograph arc available from the NCCD Library.

  • 6. Hampers, Prager & Senior, Posttransfusion Anicteric Hepatitis, 271 N. Eng. J. Med. 747 (1964).       •

By using careful laboratory testing, these researchers found hepatitis in 18 per cent of a small sample of transfused patients, none of whom developed symptoms other than mild lethargy, anorexia, shortness of breath, and occasional nausea. They conclude that, in their hospital, there may have been over 100 cases of anicteric hepatitis, or hepatitis without jaundice, for every case of viral hepatitis.

  • 7. Grady & Chalmers, Risk of Posttransfusion Viral Hepatitis, 271 N. Eng. J. Med. 337 (1964).

This is a study of all patients transfused over a ten-year period in nine Boston teaching hospitals. Ninety-five per cent of the patients were over fourteen years of age. An attack rate of viral hepatitis of 0.6 per cent was found in the entire sample, with the youngest victim being twenty years old. This study found no deaths from hepatitis in any transfused child.                '               '

  • 8. Allan Sc Saymon, Serum Hepatitis from Transfusions of Blood, 180 A.M.A.J. 1079 (1962).                             ‘

Out of the random sampling of over 2,000 transfused patients, 2.1 per cent under the age of forty and 3.9 per cent over the age of forty contracted viral ■ serum hepatitis. No deaths resulted in the younger group, while 23 per cent of the older group died.

John F. Horty


If transfused blood causes disease, hospital may be liable



Two recent cases dealt with patients who contracted infectious hepatitis after receiving blood transfusions. In the first case, in Illinois, the plaintiff had received . several transfusions of whole blood while she was a hospital patient.

As a result, she charged, she became infected with serum hepatitis, for which she required addition-a 1 hospitalization.

In suing the

hospital, the patient alleged that the hospital furnished defective blood and should be held liable for the defective condition. The hospital contended in reply that whole human blood is not a product and cannot be the subject of a sale. Therefore the hospital, through its employes, merely performs a service in giving a blood transfusion to a patient, and is not liable for the condition of the blood.

The court stated that “while it may be true that no case has directly attached liability to a hospital for furnishing defective blood, we cannot agree that none of the cases had indicated the potential attachment of such liability.”

An earlier Illinois case, the court said, decided that liability could be imposed on retailers for selling unwholesome meat, whether the retailers were aware of the unwholesome condition or not. Under the reasoning of that case, an

Mr. llorly is director of th© Health Law Center, University of Pittsburgh, and president, Aspen Systems Corporation, implied warranty that the product sold was fit for its intended purpose would attach to the seller. The Illinois courts have moved since to approve decisions that determine that liability of the manufacturer and vendor of food is imposed by operation of law as a matter of public policy for the protection of the public, and is not dependent on any provision of contract, either expressed or implied.

The losses caused by unwholesome food should be borne by those who have created the risk and reaped the profit by placing the product in the stream of commerce, the court reasoned.
