The court went on to say that it would appear that the real reason some would refrain from calling human blood a product is the belief that those dealing in it are doctors, hospitals and blood banks who perform a meritorious service for the community and are entitled to preferential treatment from the law. However, the Illinois Supreme Court has indicated that hospitals should not be treated any differently than any other organization, at least insofar as the rules of negligence are concerned. The court then went on to quote the Darling vs. Charleston Community Memorial Hospital case as authority for this principle.

Parenthetically, it should be noted that this statement dismisses, probably for the last time in Illinois, any proposition that hospitals • because of the services they perform are likely to receive any kind of preferential treatment by the court. This is a fallout result from the Darling case that, while foreseeable, still is a change in public and judicial thinking about the role hospitals play.

The court then went on to quote from a federal case involving a community blood bank in Kansas City, indicating that for federal control purposes under the Federal Trade Commission Act, blood is considered an article of commerce and subject to the prohibitions and regulations of federal law. The court also quoted from two other federal criminal decisions which dealt with blood as if it were a product.

The court then went on to dispose of the idea that the hospital was not involved in a sale but rather in a service. The court stated that it was realistic and reasonable to hold that a sale is involved in a transaction whereby the patient comes into the possession of blood, with the hospital buying the blood from one person or organization and selling it to the patient. It is difficult for the hospital to contend that it is merely a service organization when in fact it charges the patient for the blood, rather than merely for services in dispensing it, and when, as is often the case, the hospital gets the blood as a donation or else buys it at one price and sells it at a higher price to the patient.

The defendant hospital also contended that there was no way to determine or control contamination of blood by scrum hepatitis and therefore it would be unjustifiable to impose liability on the hospital. This is particularly true, the hospital said, when the only means by which the disease can be detected results in the destruction of the whole blood. Therefore, since the blood cannot be made safe under our present knowledge, the hospital should not be held to strict liability.

MODERN HOSPITAL


In return, the plaintiff contended that blood can be made relatively safe for use by careful screening of donors and that recent research has indicated there is a far greater possibility of infection if the donor lives in a crowded, low-income area rather than in a middle-class residential area. In addition, the plaintiff indicated several tests which can be taken to indicate whether a particular donor might be a carrier of hepatitis.

The court stated that it felt dealing with this question now was premature, and that this was a matter which should be determined upon the trial.

It is. interesting to note that a 1969 New York lower court decision took a somewhat different view than the above, in a case involving a hospital and a commercial blood bank.

In 1965, the plaintiff was a patient in the defendant hospital. While there, the patient received two blood transfusions purchased by the hospital from the defendant commercial blood bank. Thereafter, the patient acquired hepatitis.

The court stated that the law in New York states that hospitals are not liable for breach of an implied warranty of fitness and merchantability when a patient becomes afflicted with serum hepatitis as a result of a transfusion of blood. The court indicated that in previous New York cases the court held that the hospital performed a service in the blood transfusion rather than selling a product to the patient.

However, the court did indicate that there was a question as to whether the defendant commercial blood bank could be held liable for breach of a warranty when it has transferred blood to a hospital for consideration and when blood is later used in a transfusion and causes the patient to contract hepatitis.

The court stated that a blood bank supplying blood to a hospital . is' completing a sale. If in fact the blood sold by the blood bank carries serum hepatitis and causes injury, it is not fit for the ordinary purpose for which it is used and in turn gives rise to a claim of breach of warranty. The court therefore sent the case back to trial to determine whether, in fact, the blood which caused the hepatitis came from the commercial blood bank involved or another blood bank.

It is obvious from both of these cases that the courts are further limiting the area in which hospitals, generally, and the suppliers particularly can escape liability. As the hospital and health business increases in volume and cost, the courts will deal more harshly with individual acts of negligence and I injury to patients and others who ■ use tire institutions.                B

66         MODERN HOSPITAL

Doctor serf to® Law

WHEM DUE CAKE

IS NO DEFENSE

The difference between a product and a service seems clear-cut. A product is a tangible object sold to a customer. A service is work done for him. In a court, however, the laws governing liability for damage done by a product are radically different from the laws that cover negligence in performing a service. The distinction between them is therefore highly significant, and it has not yet been fully resolved. Medical activities are usually classified as services, but there are exceptions.

The latest exception comes from the case of Brody vs Overlook Hospital and the Essex County Blood Bank, heard recently by the Union County (N.J.) District Court. Eugene Brody was admitted to the hospital on Dec. 18, ’66, and underwent surgery to correct a broken hip shortly there' after. During the operation, he received three pints of blood—two from the hospital’s own bank and one from the nonprofit Essex County Blood Bank. He soon contracted serum hepatitis and died in February 1967. His wife, Sarah, sued for damages.

The case was the first of its kind to come before a New Jersey court, so Judge E. Donald Steinbrugge had to decide on his own the rules under which the jury decided the case. Transfused blood, he declared, is a product, not a service, and comes under the doctrine of strict tort liability, not under negligence statutes. Those who make or sell a ^product, in this case the hospital and blood bank, are liable for any harm to the purchaser that results from a defect in the product, whether or not they could have detected or prevented the defect. The defendants could not absolve themselves by shownng that they had exercised "due care” in supplying and transfusing the blood to the decedent. Neither were they protected by the New Jersey laws that exempt nonprofit blood banks from negligence liability and limit the liability of nonprofit hospitals to $10,000.

Further, ruled Judge Steinbrugge, since there was no way to discover which unit of blood had contained the hepatitis virus, the total blood transfused would be considered the product. Even though the infection had probably come from only one of the blood banks, both were liable for any damage.

Under those rules, the jury unanimously found, both Overlook Hospital and the Essex County bank were liable. Neither had attempted to deny that the decedent’s hepatitis had come from the transfused blood or that it had been the cause of death.

The case has not yet gone to the appellate division of the Superior Court, and it is far from certain that the verdict will stand. In ruling that transfused blood comes under strict liability, Judge Steinbrugge tock as precedent several cases from states that have since legally defined blood transfusions as a service under the control of negligence statutes. At least 41 states have enacted such laws in recent years.

It may also be found that the decision that the total volume of transfused blood was the product was in violation of the "due process” clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. "Judge Steinbrugge is holding that each defendant is responsible for the actions of the other as well as for , their own,” says one attorney. "That is clearly prohibited under any number of precedents.”

Judge Steinbrugge, however, hopes that his doctrine will be upheld. "Adoption of the strict liability standard for the State of New Jersey will have' the beneficial effect of forcing hospitals to deal only with those blood banks that have good safety records,” he says. "Public policy dictates the imposition of strict tort liability on blood banks, if for no other reason than to discourage carelessness in the selection of donors.”

Other effects may be less beneficial, however. One blood bank director, for example, estimates that the price of blood could be forced as high as $50 per pint if biood banks are forced to insure themselves against liability for hepatitis infection, a              ,

64D


MEDICAL WORLD NEWS/January 5, T9 73

THE CANADIAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION

CODE OF ETHICS

Principles of Ethical Behaviour for all physicians, including those who may not be engaged directly in clinical practice.

I

Consider first the well-being of the patient.

II

Honour your profession and its traditions.

  • Ill

Recognize your limitations and the special skills of others in the prevention and treatment of disease.

  • IV

Protect the patient’s secrets.

' V

Teach and be taught.

  • VI

Remember that integrity and professional ability should be your only advertisement.

  • VII

Be responsible in setting a value on your services.

GUIDE TO THE ETHICAL BEHAVIOUR OF PHYSICIANS

A physician should be aware of the traditional standards established by his forebears and act within the general principles which have governed their conduct.

The Oath of Hippocrates represented the desire of the members of that day to establish for themselves standards of conduct in living and in the practice of their art. Since then the principles established have been retained as our basic guidiines for ethical living with the profession of medicine.

The International Code of Ethics and the Declaration of Geneva (1948), developed and approved by The World Medical Association, have modernized the ancient codes. They have been endorsed by each member organization, including The Canadian Medical Association, as a general guide having worldwide application.

The Canadian Medical Association accepts the responsibility of delineating the standard of ethical behaviour expected of Canadian physicians.

An interpretation of these principles is developed in the ensuing pages, as a guide for individual physicians and provincial authorities.

Approved by the General Council

>f The Canadian Medical Associalion June, 1970


This Code of Ethics was approved in principle by the Council of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Ontario, November 1970.


® RESPONSIBILITIES /TO THE

/ PATIENT ■

. An Ethical Physician:

Standard of care

  • i wil] practise the art and science of medicine to the best of his ability;

  • 2 will continue his education to improve his standard of medical care; ’         '

Respect for patient

  • 3 will ensure that his conduct in the practise of his profession is above reproach, and that he will take neither physical, emotional nor financial advantage of his patient;

Patient's rights

  • 4 will recognize his limitations and, when indicated, recommend to the patient that additional opinions and services be obtained;

  • 5 will recognize that the patient has the right to accept or reject any physician and any medical care recommended to him. The patient, having chosen hi's physician, has the right to request of that physician opinions from other physicians of the patient’s choice;

  • 6 will keep in confidence information derived from his patient, or from a colleague, regarding a patient and divulge it only with the permission of the patient except when the law requires him to do so;                   .

  • 7 will recommend only those diagnostic procedures which he believes necessary to assist him in the care of the patient, and therapy which he believes necessary for the well-being of the patient. He will recognize his responsibility in advising the patient of his findings and recommendations;

  • 8 will on the patient’s request, assist him by supplying the information required to enable the patient to receive any benefits to which the patient may be entitled;

  • 9 will be considerate of the anxiety of the patient’s next-of-kin and co-opcratc with him in the patient’s interest;

Choice of patient

  • 10 will recognize that he has a responsibility to render medical service to any person regardless of colour, religio_n or political belief;

  • 11 shall, except in an emergency, have the right to refuse to accept a patient;

  • 12 will render all assistance in his power to any patient, where an urgent need for medical care exists;

  • 13 will, when the patient is unable, and an agent unavailable, to give consent, render such therapy as he believes to be in the patient’s interest;

Continuity of care

  • 14 will, when he has accepted professional responsibility for an acutely ill patient, continue to provide his services until they are no longer required, or until he has arranged for the services of another suitable physician. In any other situation, he may withdraw from his responsibility for the care of any patient provided that he gives the patient adequate notice of his intention;

Personal morality

  • 15 when his personal morality prevents him from recommending some form of therapy which might benefit his patient will so acquaint the patient;

Clinical research

  • 16 will, before initiating any clinical research involving human beings, ensure that such clinical research is appraised scientifically and ethically, and approved by a responsible committee, and is sufficiently planned and supervised that the individuals arc unlikely to suffer any harm. He will ascertain that the previous research and the purpose of the experiment justify this additional method of investigation. Before proceeding he will obtain the consent of those individuals or their agents, and will do so only after explaining the purpose of the clinical research and any possible health hazard which he can foresee;

The dying patient

  • 17 will allow death to occur with dignity and comfort when death of the body appears to be inevitable;

  • 18 may support the body when clinical death of the mind has occurred, but need not prolong life by unusual or heroic means;

T’ransplan tat ion

  • 19 may, when death of the brain has occurred, support cellular life in the body when some parts of the body might be used to prolong or improve the health of others;

  • 20 will recognize his responsibility to a donor of organs to be transplanted and will give to the donor or his relatives full disclosure of his intent and the purpose of the procedure; in the case of a living donor, he will also explain the risks of the procedure;

  • . 21 will refrain from determining the time of death of the donor patient when he will be a participant in the performance of the transplant procedure or when his association with any proposed recipient might influence his judgement;

  • 22 who determined the time of death of the donor may, subsequent to the transplant procedure, treat the recipient;

Fees to patients

  • 23 In determining his fee to the patient, will consider his personal service, the patient’s ability to pay, and the fee recommended by his provincial medical association or syndicate. He will be prepared to discuss his fee with his patient and will initiate the discussion when his fee will exceed the recommended fee.

©RESPONSIBILITIES TO THE

PROFESSION

Ah Ethical Physician:

Personal conduct

  • 1 will recognize that the profession demands of him integrity and dedication to its search for truth and its service to mankind;

  • 2 will recognize that self discipline of the profession is a privilege and that he has a responsibility to merit the retention of this privilege;

  • 3 will conduct himself beyond reproach and will report to the appropriate body of his peers, conduct by a confrere, which he considers unbecoming to the profession;

  • 4 will conduct himself in such a manner as to merit the respect of the public for members of the medical profession;

  • 5 will avoid impugning the reputations of his confreres;

Contracts

  • 6 will, when aligning himself in practice with other physicians, insist that they maintain the standards enunciated.' in this Code of Ethics and the Guide to the Ethical Behaviour of Physicians;

  • 7 will only enter into a contract, regarding his professional services, which allows fees derived from physicians’ services to be.controlled by the physicians rendering the service;

  • 8 will enter into a contract with an organization only if it will allow him to maintain his professional integrity;

  • 9 will only offer to a confrere a contract which has terms and conditions equitable to both parties;

Reporting medical research

  • 10 will first communicate to his confreres, through recognized scientific channels, the results of any medical research,

' in order that those confreres may establish an opinion of its merits, before he or they present it to the public;

Addressing the public

  • 11 will recognize his responsibility to give the generally held opinions of the profession when interpreting scientific knowledge to the public and in presenting any personal opinion which is contrary to the generally held opinion of the profession, he will indicate he is doing so, and will avoid any attempt to enhance his own professional reputation;                                       ,

Advertising

  • 12 will build a professional reputation based only on his ability and integrity, will avoid advertising in any form and make professional announcements according to local custom;

  • 13 will avoid advocacy of any product when he is identified as a member of the medical profession;

  • 14 will avoid the use of secret remedies;

Consultation

  • 15 wij! request the opinion of an appropriate confrere acceptable to the patient when diagnosis or treatment is difficult or obscure, or when the patient requests it. Having requested the opinion of a confrere, he will make ava i 1 a bl c all relevant information and indicate clearly whether he wishes his confrere to assume the continuing care of the patient during this illness;

  • 16 will, when his opinion has been requested by a confrere, report in detail his findings and recommendations to the attending physician, and may outline his opinion to the patient. He will continue with the care of the patient only at the specific request of the attending physician, and with the consent of the patient;

Patient care

  • 17 will co-operate with those individuals who, in the opinion of the physician, may assist in the care of that patient;

  • 18 will make available to a confrere, on the request of the patient, a report of his findings and treatment of that patient;

  • 19 will provide medical services to a confrere and his dependent family without fee, unless specifically requested to render an account;             .

  • 20 will provide only minor or emergency services to himself or his immediate family, and these without payment;

Financial arrangements

  • 21 will avoid any personal profit motive in ordering drugs, appliances or diagnostic procedures from any facility in which he has a financial interest;

  • 22 will refuse to accept any commission or payment, direct or indirect, for any service rendered to his patient by other persons excepting only by his employees and professional colleagues with whom he has a formal partnership or similar agreement.

©RESPONSIBILITIES TO

SOCIETY

An ethical physician who acts under the principles of this Guide to the Ethical Behaviour for Physicians will find that he has fulfilled many of his responsibilities to society.

An Ethical Physician:

1 will strive to improve the standards of medical services in the community.

He will accept his share of the profession’s responsibility to society in matters relating to public health, health education, and legislation affecting the health or well-being of the community;

  • 2 when a witness, will recognize his responsibility to assist the court in arriving at a just decision;

  • 3 will, in the interest of providing good and adequate medical care support the opportunity of his confreres to obtain hospital privileges

in his community appropriate to their personal and professional qualifications.

* ‘ The complete physician is not a man apart and cannot content himself with the practice of medicine alone, but should make his contribution, as does any other good citizen, towards the well-being and betterment of the community in which he lives.'’

793

Special Communication

Life or Death—Whose Decision?

William P. Williamson, MD

Nineteen hundred years ago, Seneca, a Roman philosopher, said, “Death is sometimes a punishment, often a gift, and to many, is a favor.” As physicians, we naturally become deeply involved in matters of life and death. Most of us believe, and essentially all religions hold, that the life of each individual is a creation of the Almighty, that supreme mastery over life belongs to the Creator, and that it is man’s obligation to conserve human life as one of the noblest creations of God. Yet, whether he likes it or not, the physician’s skills, decisions, and the treatments he renders, often determine life or death for his patient.

The Problem

This problem has become more complex because of the tremendous strides made by modern medicine. Improved understanding of body physiology and chemistry, potent drugs, remarkably efficient mechanical respirators, pacemakers, and artificial organs, combined with aggressive medical and nursing care, have saved many lives, cured some diseases, and solved many medical problems. Yet, paradoxically, this very progress has created othefr problems of ethics, morals, and economics which challenge our integrity and conscience.

" ""I rememhef*"when cessation of heart beat was an observation on which we simply pronounced the patient dead; now, this is a medical syndrome known as cardiac arrest, which demands prompt, skilled, and at times, heroic treatment. Cessation of respiration is a symptom also formerly implying death, which can now be corrected by an ingenious and devilishly efficient machine known as a mechanical respirator. I have seen patients with brain-stem failure, with dilated, fixed pupils, decerebrate rigidity, and .cessation of spontaneous respiration, who have had a tracheostomy and were assisted with a mechanical respirator. With fluids, electrolytes, and good nursing care, the essentially isolated heart in

From the Department of Surgery, University of Kansas Medical Center, Kansas City, Kan.

Read before the First National Congress on Medical Ethics and Professionalism, Chicago, March 6, 1966.

Reprint requests to University of Kansas Medical Center, Rainbow Blvd at 39th St, Kansas City, Kan 66103. such a patient can sometimes be kept beating for a week. I have never seen such a patient begin to breathe spontoneously and survive, and autopsy always shows advanced liquefaction necrosis of the brain, for it “died” several days before the heart did. When did the soul leave the body? Is turning oft the respirator murder? Is there any moral or ethical difference in not starting the respirator, as compared to stopping it once it is started? An 85-year-old lady, suffering from arthritis, cataracts, and many pains, wanting to die for several years, has developed pneumonia, or heart failure, and is comatose. Must these medical illnesses be treated, forcing her, against her desire, to suffer longer? A cancer patient in a terminal state required narcotics for relief of pain, which produce semistupor to the point of inadequate fluid intake.

Murder

The unlawful killing of a human being with aforethought malice, expressed or implied, is known as murder. This, we agree, is illegal, immoral, and evil, and needs no further discussion. The physician who so acts with such malice, in his own or in someone else’s interest, is a criminal, and should be prosecuted by law. Thou shalt not kill.

Euthanasia

The act of painlessly putting to death a patient suffering with an incurable and distressing disease is called euthanasia. Though several attempts at passage of legislation to make such acts legal have been made, this has never become law in any state.1 The risks of error and abuse make this legally unacceptable. Theologically, this act is contrary to moral law because, if each human life is divine, man has no right to destroy it. This would be direct violation of the supreme dominion of God over His creation.2 Even if the patient requests death, the family approves of it, and the physician concurs, we must recognize that sometimes the patient’s desire to die is a symptom of pathological depression, which is a mental illness that is often transient and curable. The family approval might be selfishly motivated to save expense or lessen their own hardship. And what physician can be certain that he can eliminate his own emotions and motives enough ■ to be sure that he does not want the luckless patient to die, not only to end his suffering, but also to solve the whole burden of caring for him? And what authority should decide on all these quirks of human nature?

Yet, though civil law makes euthanasia a crime, there are certainly humanitarian arguments to be heard. Sometimes the issue is not life or death, but simply, should we not have some choice in what kind of death—agonized or peaceful? Should we not be able to do something for a loved one that we can do for a dog?

Blessed Are the Merciful

Not only are physicians obligated to prolong life, but also to relieve suffering. This is legal; it is moral; it is ethical; it is good. ^Compassion and mercy are self-evident qualities ffiat'1

~m~the Best of: medical tradition. Though most of us agree that legalized "euthanasia is not warranted, we do fgel duty bound and morally justified in ^relieving suffering.

We have no argument that as long as there is any chance of cure, or of prolonging a reasonable life, it is our duty to treat Lhe patient with every medical skill at our disposal. Yet, there are those circumstances, however, when we have every right to be certain that the patient is suffering the terminal events of advanced malignancy, for example. Here, each step we take can come under scrutiny—intravenous fluids, tube feedings, blood transfusions, tracheostomy, palliative ultraradical surgery. Our quandary is aptly expressed by the couplet, “Thou shalt not kill, but need not strive/Officiously to keep alive.”

The Roman Catholic church has attempted to guide the physician in this area by stating that we have a moral obligation to utilize “ordinary” means ■ to preserve life, but the use of “extraordinary” means is optional. However, the physician and the moralist do not use the terms ordinary and extraordinary in the same sense. The physician’s definition of ordinary means of preserving life are standard, recognized, orthodox, or established medicines or procedures of that era, at that level of medical practice, and within the limits of availability, and his definition of extraordinary is a medicament or procedure that might be fanciful, bizarre, experimental, incompletely established, unorthodox, or not recognized.3 The moralist’s viewpoint of ordinary ways of preserving life include not only normal food, drink, and rest, but all medicines, treatments, and operations which offer a reasonable hope of benefit for the patient, and which can be obtained and used without excessive expense, pain, or other inconvenience; extraordinary ways of preserving life are all medicines, treatments, and operations which cannot be obtained or used without excessive expense, pain, or other inconveniences for the patient or for others, or which, if used, would not offer a reasonable hope of benefit to the patient.4

Obviously, what may be ordinary to the specialist, may be extraordinary to the family physician; what is ordinary in a university hospital may be extraordinary in a small community hospital; what is extraordinary today may be ordinary tomorrow; and the same pain or inconvenience may be excessive for one patient, but not for another.

We realize that intensive efforts to maintain life can, in reality, become prolongation of dying, rather than prolongation of living, "Many times these individual decisions are clear, yet at other times, indecision and doubt arise. In questionable cases, Laforet0 has stated that it is wiser to err on the

side of active treatment rather than maintain “laissez faire” for the following reasons: (1) The physician is fallible, and the case may not be medically “hopeless.” (2) The physician, by tradition, , _ has been committed to active contention with dis-।---■ease. (3) The physician is not competent to deter

mine fully the “quality” of a given life or whether longevity is “fruitless.” (4) Even if without positive act, the physician who arrogates to himself the prerogative of determining whether life shall continue or terminate by default is in an uncomfortable moral position. (5) The discovery of new curative agents is an ever present possibility. (6) Spontaneous regression of malignancies in apparently hopeless patients has been documented. (7) Miraculous intervention is possible. (8) The physician may find that self-recrimination for errors of omission is harsher than for errors of commission. (9) Even a brief moment of mental lucidity in a moribund patient may be all-important for his spiritual welfare. (10) Extraordinary means of treatment may result in cure.

The Solution


Life or death—who decides? Each physician could recite innumerable examples of different diseases, situations, and conditions, with many variables, that would make each decision as to measures of prolonging life a debatable one. Because of these countless variables, rigid rules are impossible. Our course of action becomes a matter of moral, ethical.

a B                         n—    I TOB—MjpTpwiyiiLM ijm.uh ■wd——

and religious convictions.                       -

TonvictionsTao^^Lieswith different religious faiths. * liiiis, thisjiecntaes-a theological problem. Just as~ we should seek consultation medically "with a specialist in certain diseases, so

ance in spiritual matters wifhclergymen, who a~<C specialistsm^mlogy;"Though the purely medical tt§Ei§i!&ns should be made by the physician, consideration of the moraland spiritual aspects, as well all' guidance of tHeTumly^s thoughts and emotions,"* are proper functions of the clergy, either rabbi priesT or minister. pEysiaan may withdraw from the case if his own religious beliefs produce a' bp'n 111^t that he cannod cbnscientiously handle.

That”we”cannot' give ^satisfactory answers to all questions that arise is not disturbing to me. What is important is our wrestling with these problems. One approach to this dilemma is already being made by the Department of Medicine and Religion of the American Medical Association, who has stimulated the formation, and guided the activities, of committees on medicine and religion in each state medical society. These, in turn, have assisted in the formation of district or county committees on medi-ine and religion, who are actively arranging meet-ngs, seminars, and discussion groups betwpfip physicians and clergymen in the interest of total cgre of the sick.

At a recent meeting of the Wyandotte County Medical Society in Kansas City, Kan, the program consisted of a panel composed of a rabbi, priest, minister, surgeon, internist, and psychiatrist, discussing this very subject of prolonging life. Each physician attending the meeting brought a clergyman as his guest. This type of interprofessional and interfaith communication and understanding is a proper approach to answering some of the ethical, moral, and spiritual problems that face the conscientious physician.

However, let us also realize that religion does not have sole claim on either morality or humanitarian compassion. There are physicians who do not perform within a religious frame of reference, whose reverence for life and devotion towards relief of suffering meet the criteria of highest level of integrity, morality, and love for fellowman.

The fact that this topic has appeared for discussion in this First National Congress on Medical Ethics and Professionalism is further reassuring evidence that the medical profession is deeply con-___

cerned that rts science does not surpass its art; that we still treatjtfrg_pgtientjTmFj^^TEe^ise'ase; that*- ~ we be mercifuT^mariita.rTans, noFc'dld'aioot^scien-Fists; arid that we^To^Te!u7TeourseIverTn3^ecom?~ v'~medlcally KmmscientT For a t't " 'a fif th ere is drily One who is OmxuscienHjifre are His servants. 1 see ~ no dichotomy, or ewn any'di'lemma”'We' can, without conflict, simultaneously serve God, our creator, medical sci&ice^ our profession, and_man, our pa-"** rient, as we stny^Jtmnp^^^^rselye^n' both" the”” ■ ariTand the science of tae practice of medicine. 1

JAMA, Sept 5, 1966 o Vol 197, No 10

THE TELEGRAM, Toronto, Wed., June 17, 1370

Who controls your body, you, or God, or the Canadian Medical Association?


At its convention in Winnipeg, the CMA has grandly accepted, after 103 years, the principle of male and female sterilization, for reasons other than medical but under conditions to be established by — who else? — the CMA.

One condition supported by some delegates but tinned down by the majority would have provided that before performing the operation doctors consider the validity of the patient’s reason for wanting sterilization.

“Please, sir, may I be sterilized? I have the money for it right here.”

“Why do you want to be sterilized?”

“Weil, my wife and I already have 10 kids and I'm out of work.”

“Sorry, that’s not a valid reason.”

What charter?

if the Government were to intervene in ths private and personal Life of the individual to tins extent there would be an immediate public outcry. Under what charter have the doctors assumed this power? Sterilization is not illegal under the Criminal Code — why has the CMA forbidden it for so long?

Well, according to the association’s past president, Dr. Jack Walters, who proposed the new sterilization policy at the Winnipeg meeting: “We're policy-makers for the country. If. we say it is proper, etincal and legal then it has to be accepted.'’

That’s quite a tali order — arbiters of what’s proper, ethical and legal. Proper — by whose standards? Ethical — medically or socially? Legal — aw come off it! The law is established by Parliament and administered by the judiciary; doctors, like everyone else, are subject to the law.

Playing God is an occupational disease of doctors. They are helped into it by legend, myth, superstition and the propaganda of tire Canadian

■■lull -■ I   .1 -            I ■ _ iiju' I I     II ITI . . .-..-rtf.-

Medical Association. But what is a doctor, except a technician? We pay him to tinker with our bpdies, just as we liire a mechanic to tinker with our cars, or a plumber with a loakv pipe. We would be •

।      -----■-    . - ntn ii,nbi I—RIP—il<i‘U '.J .1 i~L<ir.i~.~ ?ir—-r-TT*~r*rw

outraged if the mechanic or plumber laid down J conditions for repairing certain defective parts.

Jusl his fee

; That's because the car is ours, the plumbing | fixtures are ours and we reserve the right io decide । what’s to be done with them.

i All we grant to the tradesman is his fee. And so j it should be with doctors.

The body is a temple, yes; but for its care or abuse we are responsible only to ourselves and God.

For legal aspects of choosing type of treatment see "Guides to the Judge in Medical Orders Affecting Children" by A. P. Murrah, Chief Judge, U. S, Court of Appeals, et al., [^Section DLGJ-32, page 234J

Phototherapy and the Jaundiced Infant

RICHARD P. WENNBERG, M.D., Seattie, Washington

In a test tube, bilirubin is converted to colorless compounds by light. A baby’s jaundice, skin cun be bleached by the same agent. Light accelerates the decline of serum bilirubin and decreases the number of exchange transfusions required. Animal studies have indicated that light can cause- metabolic changes, some of which are harmful to the young, but there is no evidence of harm to human infants. The risks, if any, are considerably less than risks of damage by excess bilirubin.


When crystalline bilirubin is dissolved in dilute sodium hydroxide and exposed to fluorescent light the solution gradually turns from yellow to amber to green, and finally to a slightly tinted, almost clear solution. As these events occur, the concentration of bilirubin falls rapidly. While the degradation products have not been determined with certainty, it is likely that bilirubin is photo-oxidized to biliverdin, then to a second yellow pigment and, finally, to other colorless compounds.

Althought this instability of bilirubin has been known for ■  —.....       I

years, a nurse is credited with recognizing the possible, clinical importance of this phenomenon. In the mid 1950’s the head nurse of a premature-unit in Essex, England observed that if a jaundiced infant were placed next to the window on a sunny day the jaundice in the exposed areas faded quickly. This led to a series of experiments reported by Cremer et al which demonstrated that serum bilirubin concentrations could be drastically reduced in jaundiced infants by exposure to sunlight or to arli-fical light?

Since this early work, phototherapy has been used in the management of physiologic jaundice in the premature, both in Europe and South America? Little attention was given to light therapy in the United States, however, until the study of Lucey and his colleagues was presented in 1968? Since then, several studies of the use of phototherapy in the prevention of hyperbilirubinemia in the. premature have been presented?-6

Table 1 summarizes five controlled studies, representing a total experience with 521 infants. For most, the lighting was provided by a group of daylight fluorescent tubes delivering 300 to 500 foot-candles of light to the infant. The babies were naked except for protective eye shields and, in some, cases, dia-f'pers. Tim results are remarkably uniform and indicate that light therapy will reduce the scrum bilirubin concentration to 50 percent of the expcct-.'d level in physiologic jaundice of the pre-maiiirc. 'The lesser values of only 17 to 19 penamt reduction reported by Gimila and Hath arc ascribed to the use of a less intense light soiirec." They sim

241

Norlhu < st Mcditiiw. ApiiJ, l!)70 ply improved the nursery lighting from the previous dim 10 foot-candle illumination to one of 90 foot-candles. As yet, effectiveness of light therapy in hemolytic disease of the newborn is uncertain, but available' evidence suggests that light exposure accelerates the decline of serum bilirubin concentrations and decreases the number of exchange transfusions required? 7

In spite of these data, considerable doubt regarding the safety and efficacy of phototherapy has been expressed by , several investigators. The reasons for this hesitancy are summarized in Table 2.

Primary concern is that products of photodeemnposition might be as toxic as their parent compound, bilirubin. Bilirubin inhibits electron transport and uncouples oxidative phosphorylation. Photodecomposed bilirubin has no apparent effect on either of these systems in isolated mitochondria? Biliverdin, however, does inhibit nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADU) oxidase when the enzyme is isolated in vitro? On the other hand, biliverdin appears to be* less fat soluble than bilirubin and thus probably does not cross lipo-protcin membranes of cell walls readily. Furthermore, nobody has been able to demonstrate a significant amount of biliverdin ciroulating in light treated infants. The concentrations necessary to produce a toxic effect are probably nc\er

24$

TABLE 1

CONTROLLED STUDIES OF PHOTOTHERAPY IN HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA OF PREMATURITY* Percent Decrease Achieved in Mean Serum Bilirubin Concentrations by Phototherapy

Number

Studied

Day of Life

Obes-Polleri              67        76                  41        57

Schwartz & Hodgman    51       47       34       47       43

Porto et al               11        12        30        55

Lucey et al             58       94       35       54       35

Giunta                  49       47        17        19        17

♦Tabulated by J. F. Lucey (Personal Communication)

TABLE 2             babies treated with photo-


Possible Hazards of Phototherapy

  • 1. Products of pliotodecomposition are toxic.

  • 2. Products of photodecomposition displace bilirubin from albumin.

  • 3. Light therapy in itself is hazardous.

  • a. Interrupts circadian rhythm

  • b. Alters endocrine function

  • c. Causes growth failure

  • d. Injures eyes attained in vivo. The remaining photo products have been shown to be water soluble, do not deposit in brain tissue readily, and are rapidly excreted without conjugation both through the liver and kidney minimizing the likelihood of any toxic effects?".

A second question has been raised as to whether the photodecomposition products may displace bilirubin from albumin. I have recently looked at this problem in the laboratory at the University Hospital, using electrophoresis and spectrophotometric techniques, and have been unable to displace any bilirubin from albumin by the addition of photodeeom-posed bilirubin. On the other hand, Odell has shown that exposure of jaundiced scrum to intense light can decrease bilirubin binding in vitro, possibly by photodecomposition of albumin itself?' Porto et al have recently presented evidence of an increase in available bilirubin binding sites on albumin in those therapy?2

A third concern—and possibly the area in which we are most ignorant—is the possibility that light therapy in itself may be hazardous. It has been suggested, without supporting evidence, that continuous light therapy could interrupt normal circadian rhythm. There have been animal studies to indicate that light exposure may alter endocrine metabolism, cause runting in rats, and cause retinal damage in monkeys. In the few children who have been carefully followed through the first year of life, however, there is no evidence that light treatment has any harmful influence oir human growth. Since infants exposed to light have uniformly been blindfolded, the effects of prolonged phototherapy on the retina in premature infants are as yet unknown. While the risks of retinal injury are probably remote, it would seem wise to continue to blindfold all infants who receive intensive light therapy, at least until further evidence is available.

In evaluating the possible ill effects of light therapy it is well to consider that the intensity of artificial light rased in phototherapy is only in the range of ■100 to 500 foot-candles as compared with 5,000 to 10,000 footcandles supplied by natural sunlight. An infant placed next to a window may be exposed to much more intense illumination than one receiving artificial phototherapy.

In view of available data, the potential hazards of light therapy are probably very small compared to the known hazards of hyperbilirubinemia in the premature infant. Boggs and his colleagues have provided evidence that bilirubin concentrations in excess of 15 mg per 100 ml might produce mental and motor impairment?3 Kemicterus can occur in sick, premature infants with bilirubin concentrations of 12 mg per 100 ml or lower. The risks of repeated exchange transfusions are well known.                      *

In spite of the usefulness of phototherapy in the management of jaundice, prophylactic treatment does present some potential clinical hazards as summarized in Table 3. Bilirubin is not only a poison—its presence also provides a warning of other diseases. If jaundice is prevented by prophylactic phototherapy,

  • TABLE 3

Hazards of Prophylactic Phototherapy

  • 1. Failure to recognize jaundice as a symptom

  • a. Sepsis

  • b. Hemolytic disease

  • c. Hepatic disorders

  • 2. Failure to recognize severity of hyperbilirubinemia

the diagnosis of any condition, in which jaundice provides a major tip-off may be delayed or go undetected. These include hepatitis, syphilis, cytomegalic inclusion disease, toxoplasmosis, rubella syndrome, diabetic mother syndrome, hereditary forms of jaundice, and the many forms of hemdlytie disease in the newborn. Failure to recognize hemolytic disease in the nursery

242

Northwest Mr dirittn Anril H)70

can result in severe, and occasionally fatal, anemia in early infancy.

Infection in the newborn is extremely difficult to recognize, and one of the signs of sepsis is unexplained jaundice. If all babies are treated propbylaeti-cally, this clue is lost. The stools of infants receiving light therapy are often brown or green and loose, which may add to the confusion since diarrhea is another presenting sign of sepsis. In addition, overheating of incubators has occurred from homemade phototherapy units and improperly ventilated commercial models; if this is not recognized, temperature instability in the infant may further mislead the physician.

Since the majority of bilirubin which is decomposed by phototherapy lies within or beneath the skin and not in the circulation, one might fail to recognize the severity7 of hyperbilirubinemia. Serum concentrations of 8 to 12 mg per 100 ml have been observed in infants who appear non-jaundiced except for the area under the blindfold. The extent to which dangerously high levels of bilirubin can be masked by phototherapy is unknown.

An additional hazard of phototherapy has recently been observed with the introduction of high-energy blue fluorescent lamps. These lamps have been recommended because they possess approximately two times the radiant energy in the absorptive band of bilirubin than do daylight lamps. However, these lamps cast a blue hue over the infants, and instances of undetected, marked cyanosis have occurred. Thus, the advantage of increased energy output is more than outweighed by the risk of missing color changes (cyanosis, rashes) in the infants, and blue fluorescent lamps should not be used for phototherapy.

In summary, the available, evidence indicates that phototherapy is effective and safe. However, patients receiving phototherapy must be followed carefully and theoretical problems which might arise from light therapy deserve continued study. Babies receiving phototherapy, especially when used projrhylactieally, require even more careful monitoring for early signs of sepsis, undetected hemolytic disease, and marked hyperbilirubinemia.

Which infants, then, should be treated with light? While the selection of candidates is somewhat arbitrary7, the following guidelines are suggested:

  • 1. All infants who are jaun- | diced.                          i

  • 2. All infants with a known j cause for hyperbilirubinemia. This includes bemoly-tic diseases, infections and infants with large hematomas or other internal bleeding, even before clinical jaundice becomes ap- i parent.

  • 3. All infants who are severe-! , ly ill and thus at greater i * risk of kernicterus, Hyaline1 membrance disease, severe anoxia, or symptomatic hypoglycemia can be dangerous.                                .

  • 4. All premature infants under \ 1500 grains, because of the greater risk for physiologic jaundice and for kernicterus at low scrum bilirubin concentrations.

Dept, of Pediatrics U. of W. School of Medicine

(98105)

REFERENCES

  • 10 Diamond. J.. Schmid, K.; Neonatal hylperbilirubi-nemia and kernicterus. Experimental support for treatment by exposure to visible light. Arch Neurol (Chicago) 18:699-702 (June) 1968.

  • 11 Odell. G. B., Brown, R. S.. Holtzman. N. A.; Dye-sensitized photo-oxidation of albumin associated with a decreased capacity for protein binding of bilirubin. Syrn-podum on bilirubin metabolism in the newborn. National Foundation. Original Article Series, In Press,

  • 12 Porto,. S. O., Prides, R. S., Goodman, H., Studies on the effect of phototherapy on neonatal hyperbilirubinemia among low-birth-weight infants II Protein binding rapacity, J Pediat 75'1918-1050 (December) 19G9.

Correspondence


British

Medical Journal


2 May 1970          299

Blue Light and Jaundice

Sir,—Your leading article on blue light and jaundice (4 April, p. 5) was welcome in drawing attention to this method of treatment which, though first developed in Britain, has been almost totally neglected here ever since. However, you seem not to have been convinced firstly, that hyper-bilirubinamia unassociated with haemolytic disease is potentially dangerous, and secondly, that phototherapy is both effective and harmless. There is, however, plenty of evidence from both in vitro experiments and clinical observation that hyperbilirubinaemia is potentially dangerous. Kernicterus is such a serious condition that even if its incidence is low every effort must be made to prevent it from occurring.

Recent work by G. B. Odell and colleagues1 has shown that the major factor determining brain damage in jaundiced infants is the fraction of bilirubin which is dissociated from albumin and therefore free f'to diffuse into cells. In a careful study of infants who had been jaundiced during the : neonatal period they found no correlation ; between the presence of brain damage at five years of age and the maximal serum bilirubin level, but that there was a significant correlation with the saturation of serum proteins with bilirubin in infancy. The saturation index provided a better assessment of the risk of hyperbilirubinaemia than did the serum bilirubin concentration. Their scries of cases included one infant with brain damage in whom the maximum serum bilirubin concentration was only 13 6 mg./100 ml., but the saturation index was abnormal. The risks arc therefore greater in infants with hypoproteinaemia. In practice it still remains difficult, however, to assess accurately when a jaundiced infant is in danger because, as your article points out, other factors like anoxia, respiratory acidosis, and the respiratory distress syndrome may be involved. But it is precisely when these conditions are present that exchange transfusion as a method of treatment becomes more difficult an<f~dan-gerous. We submit, therefore, that in such circumstances the simple method of phototherapy is particularly valuable and, . provided it is properly given, its effectiveness is tinqyestipnable._XL.h_as one great advantage —that is that the infant can be effectively treated in the incubator without undue disturbance.

The dangers of phototherapy are at present hypothetical. No ill effects have been , noted in any of the numerous reports which : have so far been published on this method of treatment. It seems likely therefore that : its dangers have been exaggerated. We would, however, agree that long-term follow up studies of treated cases are desirable and so in Chelmsford, where we have now treated pver 500 cases, a follow-up study has been started.

R. E. Behrman and D. Y. Y. Hsia2 summarized the conclusions of the Chicago symposium. Your assessment appears to have overlooked the positive recommendation they made that “phototherapy should be used for infants in whom the risks of hyperbilirubinaemia are thought to outweigh the risks of this form of treatment.” We disagree therefore with the opinion expressed at the end of your leading article that neonatal units are probably not justified in adding special lighting apparatus to the already long list of important equipment needed from limited funds. While we agree that the indiscriminate use of phototherapy should be discouraged, we maintain that more should be done to stimulate research into its correct application in suitable cases.—We are, etc.,

C. B. M. Warren.

St- John’s Hospital, Chelmsford, Essex.

P. M. G. Broughton.

Department of Chemical Pathology, University of Leeds, Yorks.

References

•I Odell, G. B., Storey, G. N. B., and Rosenberg, L. A., Journal of Pediatrics, 1970, 76, 12.

2 Behrman, R. E., and Hsia, D. Y. Y., Journal of Pediatrics, 1969, 75, 718.

482    23 May 1970

Blue Light and Jaundice

Sir,—Inasmuch as I am an “enthusiastic" supporter of phototherapy, I feel that I should comment on the ultra-conservative editorial comment, “Blue Light and Jaundice” (4 April, p. 5).

Workers in this field1 2 now recognize that bilirubin can produce learning difficulties in humans at lower serum concentrations than were previously realized. Previous studies have not detected these defects because of I inadequate testing. It is for this reason that a safe and simple method to replace exchange transfusion is needed. The statement that phototherapy is “unlikely to be adequate treatment” in preventing low bilirubin kemicterus is an opinion witfi which I certainly do not agree. Preliminary data suggest that this is the type of infant who will benefit. Phototherapy is also now widely being used to control mild haemolytic disease. There has been no convincing evidence published to support the original suggestion by Franklin3 that the photochemical products might be toxic. There is considerable evidence that these products are not toxic either in vivo, in vitro, and in human infants.4 I would ask that the author of this leading article and others read the Bilirubin Symposium4 quoted, and not just the summary as has apparently been done, for more data on this important point. I would also refer the reader to two recent articles,1 for more reassuring evidence in- human infants. Published human clinical experience for several countries with phototherapy now numbers over 5,000 cases, and no serious toxic effects have been reported to date.7 More recent studies in two human infants with Crigler-Najjar syndrome employing 1!C labelled bilirubin and phototherapy indicate that the breakdown products are rapidly and safely excreted.6


23 May 1970            483

Early feeding may have limited the incidence of hyperbilirubinemia of prematurity in one nursery in England to less than 1%, but this has certainly not been the experience in the U.S.A. Where this problem has been studied carefully, one usually finds that from 10-25% . of premature infants can be expected to develop serum bilirubin concentrations of over 15 mg./lOO mb7

The leader writer also cites a reference9 referring to a hypothesis that light might cause retrolental fibroplasia. This curious theory is certainly not widely held by many paediatricians.

I, and others, have not used ‘blue” light, but have employed broad spectrum light. One should not of course use “blue light,” especially if you want to judge skin colour. Phototherapy units are now designed so that they not only allow better observation of the infant but also free access to the infant. The leader writer’s quaint reluctance to allow even a minor change in the present lighting conditions in the nursery suggests that he knows that these conditions are indeed optimal for newborn infants. I challenge this idea. I am afraid that few doctors actually have any idea about the present lighting conditions in their nursery. Outdoor light on a bright day supplies 10,000 foot candles of broad spectrum light. I have found nurseries with 25 foot candles to 2,000 foot candles in the same nursery. Phototherapy units supply only about 300-500 foot candles of light. “.Phototherapy” is, therefore, being carried out in many nurseries without physicians being aware of it. ’’There are no data whatsoever to support the present “dim light” conditions present in many nurseries as being the best. Outdoor, lighting is used to illuminate many nurseries and “long-term disadvantages” are not apparent.

I agree that we have much to learn abhut light and its effect on human infants. The present leading article implies, however, that we know the present highly artifical light conditions are good, so why change? I would suggest that we face our ignorance on this point, examine the currently available evidence without prejudice, and then make a judgement.—I am, etc.,

Jerold Lucey.

Department of Pediatrics, University of Vermont, Burlington, Vermont, U.S.A,

  • 1 Odell, G. B.j Storey, G. N., and Rosenburg, L. A., Journal of Pediatrics, 1970, 76, 12.

  • 2 Johnson, L., Proceedings of the Society for Pediatric Research, 107 1970, Atlantic City N.J.

  • 3 Franklin, A. W., 1958, Lancet, 1, 1227.

  • 7 Lucey, J. F., Symposium on Bilirubin Metabolism, Original Article Series—National Foundation, 1970 (in press).

  • 8 Callahan E., et al., Proceedings of American Society for Study of Liver Disease Meeting, November 1969, Chicago, Ill, U.S.A.

  • 9 Riley, P. A., and Slater, T. F., Lancer, 1969, 2, 265.

    G ASTRO ENTERQLOQY


    January 1970


    Vo!. 58, No. 1

    Printed in U.S.A


PHOTODECOMPOSITION OF BILIRUBIN AND BILIVERDIN IN VITRO

J. Donald Ostrow, M.D., and Roger V. Branham

Department of Medicine, Case Western Reserve University, and University Hospitals, Cleveland, Ohio

Decomposition of bilirubin and biliverdin under intense fluorescent light was studied in vitro at pH levels ranging from 7.4 to 13.0. Photodecay of bilirubin was more rapid at a higher pH if albumin was absent, but more rapid at a lower pH if albumin was present, whereas biliverdin was more stable at a lower pH, with or without albumin. During illumination at lower pH levels, albumin stabilized biliverdin but accelerated decay of bilirubin; these effects were not altered by competitive uncoupling of bilirubin from albumin or by chelation of contaminant divalent cations with ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid. Studies with a variety of , fluorescent lamps demonstrated that wavelengths between 400 and 600 v mp were most effective in destroying bilirubin, ultraviolet light was less effective, and red light (>600 ma) was ineffective. Photodecay of both bilirubin and biliverdin was oxidative, but exclusion of oxygen did not arrest photodecay of bilirubin if albumin was present also. Presumably, albumin itself or the vinyl side chain of bilirubin substituted for oxygen as a hydrogen acceptor. By radiochromatography and by reillumination of photoderivatives of HC-bilirubin, it was shown that the process of photodecay proceeded from bilirubin to biliverdin to weakly diazo-reactive derivatives to highly polar, diazo-negative products.

Exposure of infants to fluorescent lights commonly is utilized to treat neonatal jaundice,- but the mechanisms involved and the products of bilirubin photodecay

Received June 18, 1969. Accepted August 5, 1969.

A preliminary report of this work was presented at the Annual Meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology on April 15, 1969, at Atlantic City, New Jersey, and has been published in abstract form.1

Address requests for reprints to: Dr. J. Donald Ostrow, Department of Medicine, University Hospitals, Cleveland, Ohio 44106.

The authors are indebted to Mr. Carl Allen, Large Lamp Division, General Electric Company, Nela Park, Cleveland, Ohio, for providing the light canopy and fluorescent bulbs and for the data in table 1 concerning the emission spectra of the bulbs. They are grateful also for the advice and suggestions of Dr. Edwin W. Abrahamson. Department of Chemistry, Case Western Reserve University. have not been identified. Many investigators have approached this problem by examination of the photodecomposition of bilirubin in vitro,3'10 but the conditions employed often have been neither physiological nor standardized, and the factors affecting the kinetics of bilirubin photodecay have not been evaluated systematically. The present in vitro studies were performed to assess the effects of pH, albumin, oxygen, and the wavelengths of the incident light upon the photodecomposition of bilirubin and to determine whether biliverdin is an intermediate in the process.

Materials and Methods

Materials. Crystalline unconjugated bilirubin, obtained from the Pfahnstiehl Company, Waukegan, Ill., was used without further purification. Biliverdin dihydrochloride, purchased from Sigma Chemical Company, St. Louis, Mo., was recrystallized from hot methanol.11 On paper chromatography,11 the product

15

16


osmw AND BRANHAM


Vol. 58, No. 1


migrated as a single spot, free from bilirubin, and exhibited characteristic absorption spectra in several solvents.11 Human serum albumin, in the form of Cohn fraction V, free from preservatives and containing loss than 0.02% w/w heavy metals, was purchased from Nutritional Biochemicals Corporation, Cleveland, Ohio (lot 6942). Human serum was obtained from a fasting normal volunteer, frozen in aliquots at —10 C for no more than 7 days, and thawed and centrifuged just prior to use. All other chemicals and solvents were reagent grade.

Solutions. Bilirubin or biliverdin HC1, 1800 ± 20 jug, was dissolved for 1 min in 1.2 ml of 0.1 n sodium hydroxide and then centrifuged rapidly. Most of the biliverdin did not dissolve. In a 10-ml Kimax beaker, 2.4 cm in diameter and 3.0 cm tall, 0.5 ml of the supernatant fluid was mixed with 4.5 ml of: (a) 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.25”; (b) 0.1 M borate buffer, pH 8.30”; (e) 0.1 m bicarbonate-carbonate buffer, pH 9.80”; or (d) 0.1 n sodium hydroxide. Final pH levels of these solutions were 7.4, 8.5, 9.9, and 13.0, respectively. In some experiments, 4.0% albumin was dissolved in the buffer prior to the addition of the pigment solution. In other experiments, disodium ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), sodium salicylate, or sulfisoxazole (Gantrisin, Hoffmann-Ba Roche, Company, Nutley, N. J.) was added. For studies with serum, 0.5 ml of pigment solution was added to 0.5 ml of 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 5.80,” plus 4.0 ml of serum. Initial pigment concentrations averaged 15.0 mg per 100 ml (0.26 mu) bilirubin or 3.0 mg per 100 ml biliverdin; albumin concentration was 3.6 g per 100 ml (0.52 dim). All solutions were prepared on ice under dim light.

Kinetic studies in air. Beakers containing the bilirubin solutions were centered on a sheet of white paper under an aluminum reflecting canopy which contained six 15-watt fluorescent bulbs arranged in a semicircle 10 cm from the surface of the solution. Characteristics of the bulbs are given in table 1. The ballast and igniter for each bulb, plus a built-in convection fan (RE-148 Whisper-fan, Retron Manufacturing Company, Woodstock, N. Y.), were fastened to the outer surface of the canopy to minimize the heating of the solutions, which remained at 27 to 28 C. After exposure to light, 0.1-ml aliquots were withdrawn at specified intervals for 6 to 8 hr. Each aliquot was diluted with 0.9 ml of 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 6.50” with 0.4% albumin added if the irradiated solution contained no albumin, and then stored on ice in the dark until analysis. Bilirubin and biliverdin were completely stable under these conditions. On each sample, bilirubin concentration was determined by a micromodification of the method of Michaelsson,14 direct spectral absorbance was determined at 315, 380,' 465, 575, and 650 m/?; and, where indicated, absorption spectra were obtained from

24


OSTffOB' AND BRANHAM


Vol. 58, No. 1


oxidation occurred between albumin and bilirubin.

The comparative studies of different fluorescent lights indicated that, taken as a whole, the blue-violet (400 to 500 m/t) and yellow-green (500 to 600 mp.) regions of the spectrum most effectively destroyed bilirubin, that red light (>600 mp.) was ineffective, and that ultraviolet light (300 to 400 mp.) had intermediate potency. The lesser effect of ultraviolet light may have been due in part to absorption by the glass walls of the vessel. The data comparing the pink and gold lamps suggested, however, that the spectral line at 440 nip. close to the absorption maximum of bilirubin, may be most effective of all. Sisson’s recent report20 has confirmed these observations. Cremer and co-workers7 drew similar conclusions, but their data are limited by failure to adjust for radiant energy emitted in the different portions of the spectrum.

These findings have two practical implications. (a) In handling bilirubin in the laboratory, the pigment can be stabilized in serum' or in physiological albumin solution by operating under red light and in ■ albumin-free solutions by addition of EDTA or exclusion of oxygen, (b) The emission spectrum of lamps utilized for phototherapy of the newborn should be selected within the blue-violet and yellowgreen portions of the spectrum to eliminate those wavelengths which most prominently generate unwanted side effects.30

  • 28. Odell, G. B. 1969. Effect of coupled photooxidation with methylene blue on bilirubin-binding by albumin. In D. Y. Y. Hsia [ed.], Bilirubin metabolism in the newborn. National Foundation Symposium, Chicago.

  • 29. Sisson, T. R. C. 1969. Photobiologie aspects of hyperbilirubinemia, D. Y. Y. Hsia [ed.], Bilirubin metabolism in the newborn. National Foundation Symposium, Chicago.

  • 30. Hsia, D. Y. Y. [ed.], 1969. Bilirubin metabolism in the newborn. National Foundation Symposium, Chicago.

Riboflavin Enhancement of Bilirubin

Photocatabolism in vivo1

Phototherapy has become a common therapeutic procedure in neonatal hyperbilirubinemia2 B. Despite the well-established efficacy of light therapy in reducing bilirubin levels, there have been reservations expressed with respect to exposing infants to light intensities of 300 to 500 foot candles, often continuously for periods of several days’. We have been examining the possibility

Fig. 1. Plot showing effect of FMN on rate of bilirubin photodeeoin-position by visible light in aqueous solution of 1% BSA, pH 7.4, under aerobic conditions.

of administering agents which would promote the photochemical decomposition of bilirubin in vivo, and might thus reduce either the exposure time or the light intensity necessary to reduce plasma bilirubin levels.

Experimenta I. Preliminary in vitro experiments indicated that monosodium salt of riboflavin 5'-phosphate (FMN) increases the rate of photochemical decomposition of bilirubin. Bilirubin solutions (3.36 X 10-6Af) were prepared in 6.05 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, containing 1% w/v bovine serum albumin (Armour fraction V), with and without 0.97x10 5 M FMN. These solutions were irradiated intermittantly in 1 cm quartz spectrophotometer cells located 24 in. from a projector equipped with a 500 W tungsten lamp. Absorbance spectra were recorded, versus a buffer blank, on a Cary 15 spectrophotometer at appropriate time intervals. Studies were conducted at room temperature of 22-25 °C, with solutions exposed to air. Initial bilirubin absorbance at 460 nm was approximately 40 times that of FMN, and the enhanced initial rate of decline in absorbance at 460 nm in presence of FMN, as illustrated in Figure 1, indicates acceleration of bilirubin photodecomposition bv FMN.

Potassium iodide at a concentration of ll)-1 JZ reduced the FMN enhancement of bilirubin pliotodecomposition, while showing no effect on rate of bilirubin photodecomposition in absence of FMN. This observation implicates the FMN triplet in the enhanced bilirubin photodecomposition. A further observation that the photofading of FMN is inhibited by the presence of bilirubin is compatible with a mechanism whereby bilirubin quenches the FMN triplet. Detailed studies of this photochemical process will be considered in a separate report8.

Adult male jaundiced Gunn rats0 weighing 275-400 g were dosed with 75 mg/kg of FMN administered in 0.7 to 1.0 ml of normal saline solution via the penis vein every 9 h up to 36 h and then every 12 h for the duration of the experiment. Control animals were injected at the same time intervals with normal saline solution. The backs of both the control and the FMN treated rats were shaved and the animals were placed in individual cages under a light canopy containing four 60 W daylight fluorescent lamps (Sylvania). Constant light intensity was maintained throughout the experiment by daily monitoring of light intensity with a light meter and adjustment of the lamp-to-animal distance as required. Blood sampling was performed prior to and during the exposure period by a technique^ similar to that described by Hurwitz10. Plasma bilirubin concentration was determined by a modified Malloy-Evelyn colorimetric method11. Riboflavin plasma levels encountered at the selected sampling times did not interfere with the assay for bilirubin.

Results and discussion. Both the albino and the hooded strains of Gunn rats responded to phototherapy. Preliminary studies conducted with light of 750-1100 foot candles intensity showed a rapid decline in plasma bilirubin levels, \vith no difference detectable for control and FMN treated rats. However, when rats were exposed to light of 300 foot candles, marked differences in rate of decline of plasma bilirubin levels were observed for the control and FMN treated animals, as illustrated in Figure 2. No change in plasma bilirubin was observed for FMN treated animals kept in the dark. Ln vitro studies have shown no competitive displacement of albumin-bound bilirubin by FMN at FMN concentrations up to 50 mg/100 ml.

Fig. 2. FMN enhancement of rate of plasma bilirubin decline in both albino and hooded Gunn rats exposed to daylight fluorescent lights at 300 foot candies intensity. FMN dosing of 75 mg/kg i.v., indicated by markings on the time axis.

iFDDR-3/73

Riboflavin injected i.v. at a dose of 75 mg/kg can be observed to color the skin of either jaundiced or normal rats, suggesting that at this dosage level riboflavin, like bilirubin, is distributed to superficial tissues in appreciable concentration.

As shown in Figure 2, plasma bilirubin levels in jaundiced Gunn rats exposed to light of 300 foot candles intensity, in absence of FMN administration, decline at an apparent zero order rate to a new plateau level. Animals treated with FMN and exposed to the same light intensity exhibit virtually the same plateau plasma bilirubin as non-FMN-treated animals, but the plateau is achieved more rapidly in the FMN treated animals and at an apparent first order rate.

The results of these studies suggest that there is potential for improving the efficiency of bilirubin phototherapy through systemic administration of an appropriate agent. An improved efficiency of phototherapy which would either decrease the exposure time of infants to bilirubin lights or permit use of lower intensity light (perhaps even normal room lighting) would eliminate reservations with respect to some of the potential hazards cited for phototherapy7. It is not suggested that FMN at the admittedly extraordinary dose level used in this study, nor at any other dose level, is suitable for this purpose on the basis of present knowledge. Currently an FMN dose-response study is being conducted in the Gunn rat model, and studies are in progress to determine whether FMN administration results in photo-products which differ from those produced by light exposure without FMN treatment.

Zusammenfassung. . Intravenos verabreichtes Ribo-flavin-5'-Monosodium-Phosphat-Salz (FMN) bewirkt eine beschleunigte Senkung des Plasma-Bilirubin-Spiegels bei

Gunn-Ratten, wenn diese vorher fluoreszierendem Tages-licht (300 Kerzen) ausgesetzt waren. FMN beschleunigt ausserdem den Photozerfall in vitro. Die Bilirubin-Phototherapie durch Injektion eines geeigneten Katalysa-tors wird diskutiert.

H. B. Kostenbauder and D. R. Sanvordeker

College of Pharmacy, Albert B. Chandler Medical Center, University of Kentucky, Lexington {Kentucky 40506, USA), 21 August 1972

This investigation was supported in part by research grant HD 05745-01 from the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development.

  • 6 J. E. Hodgman and A. Schwartz, Am. J. Dis. Child. 119, +73 (1970).

THE LANCET, APRIL 18, 1970

835


PHOTOTHERAPY FOR JAUNDICE

Sir,—-Most pediatricians agree that exchange transfusion js not to be undertaken lightly. It has many hazards and, despite careful technique and special safeguards, a definite mortality, which must always be weighed against the risk of kernicterus. The suggestion1 that exposure to lyjght light could lower the bilirubin concentration of some infants sufficiently to avoid exchange transfusion was received with scepticism and indifference until very recently? The typical reaction mingled disbelief with the insistence that specimens were stored in the dark and examined promptly lest the bilirubin “ went off ”,

The following case-history is of interest, since it concerns the use of light in an infant who would normally have Seen treated by exchange transfusiom

A girl was born on Nov. 18, 1969, at term after a normal pregnancy and labour. Weight 6 lb. 4 oz., condition satisfactory. The mother’s blood-group is O Rh-positive and no antibodies were detected antenatally. The father’s blood-group is A Rh-positive. The couple have one other child born in 1965; this child had severe early jaundice from presumed AO hatmoiytic disease and required three exchange transfusions.

Two hours after birth, she was jaundiced and pale. Her general condition was good and the liver and spleen were not enlarged. Venous blood hatmoglobin was 11-6 g. per 100 ml.; Coombs weakly positive; group A Rh-positive. A‘blood-film showed many spherocytes. Serum-bilirubin 44 mg. per 100 ml.

Plans were made for an early exchange transfusion, which began eight hours after birth. Cannulation of the umbilical vein and then both arteries was unsuccessful. Assistance was summoned and the second operator, although able to insert venous

1. Cremer, R. J., Perryman, P. W-, Richards, D. H. Lancet, 1956, i, 1094.              '

2. Behrman, R. E., Hsia, D. Y. Y. J. Pediat. 1969, 75, 718.

Fig. 1—Phototherapy technique.

The front of a fluorescent X-ray vicwing-box is removed and placed over the cot, its 2 tubes approximately 25 cm. from the baby's skin. The baby is undressed, except for a bandage over the eyes, and is turned regularly. The temperature is monitored, here using an electric skin thermometer, to avoid cooling. Exposure is continued for as long as necessary, two or three days being usual.

Fig. 2—Changes in serum-bilirubin and haemoglobin levels.

and arterial catheters to 10 cm., was unable to withdraw blood from either site. It was considered inadvisable to attempt any further cannulation of the arteries and an X-ray was taken of the venous catheter in position. The umbical vein had been perforated early in its course and the tip of the catheter was lying freely in the peritoneal cavity somewhere in the left hypochondrium.                            ■

,Bv this time, the baby was too unwell to withstand further operation and it was decided to await events, At 16 hours, the serum-bilirubin had risen to 13-8 mg. per 100 ml. Extra glucose drinks were ordered, phenobarbitone 5 mg. 8-hourlv was ciyep ! by mouth, and continuous phototherapy was improvised (fig. 13. J The skin blanched remarkably after only a few hours’ treatment. Bilirubin and haemoglobin were estimated 12-houriy for the next three days until the bilirubin level began to fall, (fig. 2). The initial steep rise was not maintained and the | maximum level was only 17-3 mg. (direct reacting 1-1 mg.' per | 100 ml. on the third day. The baby made an uninterrupted recovery and a simple transfusion of 60 ml. of concentrated blood was given by scalp vein on the twelfth day. She has continued to make normal progress.

Special fitments for light treatment will undoubtedly become popular, but there is still too little information on the ideal quality and quantity of light needed for the maximum effect. It may well be that cumbersome cradles of 8 or 10 fluorescent tubes will prove unnecessary. Until more is known, there is much to commend the improvised use of an inverted fluorescent X-ray viewing box with the front removed, especially since this equipment is readily available.

Charing Cross Hospital,

London W.C.2.                    HERBERT BARRIE.

Bilirubin Peril" Section F£RH-3o»

CONGENITAL NONOBSTRUCTIVE, NONHEMOLYTIC JAUNDICE*

Effect of Phototherapy

Rafael Gorodischer, M.D., Gerhard Levy, Pharm. D., Joseph Krasner, Ph.D., and Sumner J. Yaffe, M.D.

SERUM bilirubin concentrations of newborn infants can be reduced by exposure to sunlight or artificial blue light.74 75 These findings have been confirmed by many investigators in this country and (especially) abroad. More recently, phototherapy has been applied in a prophylactic manner to modify the degree of hyperbilirubinemia in premature infants.2

In the case reported below phototherapy was used successfully to reduce serum bilirubin concen-tratir>11 in an older infant with congenital, nonob-strucrive, nonhemolytic jaundice unresponsive to phei obarbital therapy.

  • Figure I. Effect of Phototherapy and Nikethamide on the Concentration of Total Bilirubin in Serum,

and the serum bilirubin value promptly fell to 7,6 mg per 100 ml in 67 hours.

Studies of glucuronide-conjugating capacity of the infant and family members are summarized in Table I. The patient excreted less than 5 per cent of an oral dose of 20 mg per kilogram of salicylamide as the glucuronide. Normally, about 50 per cent is glucuronidated and excreted into the urine. On the other hand, N-acetyl p-aminophenol (15 mg per kilogram by mouth) was eliminated normally, with a biologic half-life of 2.7 hours, and 47 per cent of the dose was excreted as the glucuronide. The normal response to N-acetyl p-aminophenol could have various interpretations: multiplicity of glucuronyl transferases; particular structure of this substrate (absence of a carboxyl group), making it more accessible to the active site of an abnormal glucuronyl transferase; and the fact that the rate-limiting factor in the metabolism of N-acetyl p-aminophenol is a step other than the glucu ronide-conj u gating process.

Bilirubin glucuronyl transferase (L'Di’GA transglucuron-ylase) activity was measured in cultured fibroblasts obtained

June

  • Figure 2. Conretitralion of Bilirubin in Serum after Slopping and Hnlailiiig of Phototherapy.

    Reprinted from the New England Journal of Medicine 282:375-377 (Feb. 12). 1970
