* SA indicates Spanish American surname.

t Two American Indians and one Oriental infant are included in the total figures.

+ Indicates duration of therapy.


concern then is the effect of bilirubin levels above 12 to 15 mg per 100 cc but below 20 mg/100 cc, The recent report of Stern and Doray9 of 23 .

premature infants with kemictefus at autopsy is of particular interest, as kernicterus occurred in 18 of the patients at levels below 20 mg/100 ce. All of these infants had hypoxia, acidosis, and hypothermia in some combination. In our own recent experience, the majority of infants with kernicterus at autopsy have been small, sick premature infants in whom bilirubin levels have never exceeded 20 mg/100 cc. The appropriate level for exchange transfusion is difficult to define for these infants, and the risk of exchange is significant in this population.

Boggs et al,10 summarizing the experience of the collaborative project, demonstrated a positive relationship between low mental/motor performance at 8 months of age and increasing peak bilirubin levels. Although evident in all birth weight groups, the relationship was most marked in infants weighing 2,000 gm (4 lb 6 oz) or less. The relationship did not begin abruptly at 20 mg/100 cc, but rose progressively becoming substantial above 15 mg/100 cc. If this relationship between low men-tal/motor performance and increasing peak bilirubin levels is confirmed by further study, it will provide a definite indication for prevention of hyperbilirubinemia in healthy prematures.

C ^^Phototherag^effectivffij^grevMUs 4 hyperbilirubinemia in the premature.

In our 47 light-treated prematures, one infant had a peak level of 12 mg/100 cc and one a level of 13 mg/ 100 cc. The remainder were all below 12 mg/100 cc. Obes-Polleri,11 Lucey et al,7 and Porto and Hsia12 have reported series of infants managed with phototherapy with comparable results. The effectiveness of phototherapy is related to the intensity of the light and the rate at which the bilirubin levels are rising. It cannot be expected to reliably control rapidly rising bilirubin levels. Hyperbilirubinemia not due to hemolytic disease, which is characterized by slowly rising levels during the first days of life, can be controlled or prevented. In addition, phototherapy can be administered as readily to sick infants as to healthy ones, as no handling of the infant is necessary.

The response of dark-skinned in

Table 3.—Summary of Peak Bilirubin Levels

Peak Bilirubin

Levels (mg/100 cc)

Study

Groups

No.

' 512

^15 - A

520

'No. %'

' No. %’ '

No.

%

Photo-

therapy

47

2   4

0   0

0

0

Control

51

30 59

13 25.5

3

6

fants to phototherapy has been questioned because of the theoretical screening effect of skin pigment. Our patient population was composed of Negro, Mexican-American, and white infants. Phototherapy was as effective in the two darker skinned groups as in the lighter infants.

None of the infants in either the control or treated groups developed significant amounts of direct acting bilirubin. During phototherapy, indirect bilirubin may be changed to water-soluble dipyrroles which are excreted in the bile. As glucuronide conjugation of indirect bilirubin is not increased during phototherapy, no increase in direct-acting bilirubin would be expected.

The most appropriate light intensity and intervals of treatment for prevention of hyperbilirubinemia have not been established. Effective light intensity may be considerably less than that used in our study and the others referred to above, where infants were nursed under light chambers. Guinta and Roth 13 studied the effect of increasing the room light in nurseries to 200 foot candles at the level of the infants. When premature infants were nursed unclothed except for diapers in these nurseries, significantly lower bilirubin levels were reported from the second to the sixth day compared to control infants in dimly lighted nurseries. Apparently'yet another variable which must be considered when evaluating premature infant care is intensity of environmental light. Intermittent light exposure has been used successfully to both treat and prevent hyperbilirubinemia.12'14 Intermittent exposure would have theoretical advantage over continuous exposure if it more closely approximated normal diurnal changes. Further study is required to establish the most effective pattern. '

Before it can. be recommended, phototherapy must be demonstrated to be safe as. well as effective. The photo-decomposition products of bilirubin must be less toxic than the parent compound, and no untoward effects of light, either short-term or long-term, be demonstrable in the infant.

Studies on toxicity of photodecomposition products of bilirubin have been complicated by the fact that the products have not been completely chemically identified. Several authors have studied the breakdown products resulting from light exposure of bilirubin in vitro. These products have been shown to be water-soluble and nontoxic when added to tissue slices of brain and liver or injected into laboratory animals.10-17 However, the breakdown products formed from exposing bilirubin to light in vitro may not be the same as those formed in vivo.

Studies of photo-decomposition in vivo have been limited to tire Gunn rat. Ostrow18 exposed adult Gunn rats to visible light following injection of bilirubin labeled with radioactive carbon. He recovered watersoluble diazo-positive derivatives which were rapidly excreted in the bile, and more slowly in the urine, demonstrating that glucuronide conjugation was not necessary for excretion of these products. They were similar to bilirubin catabolites normally found in Gunn rats, but appeared to be different from in vitro photo-decomposition products.

The evidence that breakdown products of bilirubin are not toxic to infants rests on clinical observation in the nursery and on follow-up study. The only clinical difference in infants’ behavior during phototherapy observed in our own infants and reported in other studies has been the appearance of loose green stools. These presumably represent the excretion of breakdown products in the bile. No abnormal neurologic findings or changes in behavior have been noted in the nursery in controlled studies.7-11-13 Although phototherapy has been used clinically for over ten years, and infants have been considered normal on follow-up study, no detailed studies on followup study of concurrent treated and control groups have been published. Unpublished data from three studies (J. F. Lucey, oral communication), Obes-Polleri,19 and Hodgman and Teberg 20 show no increase in neurologic or behavioral abnormalities in treated as compared to control infants.

No direct information is available of the effect of continuous light on the eyes of the premature infant. Permanent retinal damage has been reported in albino rats,21 normal rats,22 and piglets.23 Monkeys, on the other hand, showed no retinal damage after one month’s exposure (T. Kuwabara, written communication, Oct 23, 1968). The authors of all the studies carried out in infants recommend covering the eyes while the infant is under the lights. No visual damage has been reported in light-treated infants. Odell et al24 have reported changes in albumin, as well as bilirubin, following light exposure in vitro. There is indirect evidence that albumin-binding is not adversely altered in vivo as the 2- (4 hydroxy-benzine azo) benzoic acid (HABA) binding capacities reported by Lucey et al 7 were not different in control and treated infants.

The long-term effects of phototherapy are only currently being investigated in a consistent manner. Preliminary data from Ballowicz20 suggest that continuously light-exposed nursing Gunn rats are significantly smaller than the controls. Two other workers have not found retardation of growth using the same animal model (J. F. Lucey, oral communication, Oct 16, 1969).20 Preliminary studies on infants have also given conflicting results. Of the infants reported in our study, more light-treated babies were below the 10th percentile on growth curves during the first year than were controls.20 Retardation of growth has not been encountered in follow-up studies of Lucey (oral communication, Oct 16, 1969) and Obes-Polleri.19

Endocrine function in both animals and man is influenced by light exposure.27,28 The possible effect of phototherapy in the nursery on later endocrine function is entirely speculative. Some of the effects are mediated via the autonomic nervous system from receptors in the retina rather than from surface exposure and would constitute a theoretical indication for covering the eyes. Subtle or unexpected long-term changes in growth and behavior induced by light exposure of the infant could very well be missed unless follow-up studies are carried out comparing treated and control groups.

Conclusions

Phototherapy used as described jwas effective in preventing hyper-hllirubinemia in the premature in-.fant. The incidence of total bilirubin of 15 mg/100 cc or greater in control infants was 25.5%, while the highest total bilirubin in the treated group was 13 mg/100 cc. Infants were nursed miked in the incubators, and their eyes were bandaged while under the lights. Phototherapy was effective for sick premature infants and did not interfere with their care. Negro and Mexican-American infants responded as well as white infants to treatment, .

There is no evidence that photodecomposition products of bilirubin are acutely toxic. The only difference noted in clinical behavior in the nursery both in our infante and in the published studies was the appearance of loose green stools in some of the light-treated infants.

Evidence of the safety of phototherapy from long-term studies is fragmentary and conflicting. The long-term effects need further evaluation by continued follow-up studies of light treated and control infants.

This investigation was supported by a grant from the John A, Hartford Foundation.

Joseph Bamberger, PhD, constructed the light chamber used in this investigation.

Amer J Dis Child/Vol 119, June 1970

286

MEDICAL WORLD NEWS/June 13, 1969

Mil Uff FU isasss

PS SSLSSSSS B£


Since it was introduced in America

2V!z years ago to prevent jaundice in premature infants, phototherapy has both excited and dismayed pediatricians. While the technique seems effective and is simpler, safer, and cheaper than exchange transfusions, many wonder where the yellow went. But now the technique is being put to an even more controversial use—to treat neonates with hemolytic disorders due to Rh and ABO incompatibilities.

Chief among proponents of this new use is Dr. Thomas Sisson, associate professor of pediatrics and director of neonatal research at Philadelphia’s Temple University. Dr. Sisson contends that phototherapy is indeed effective once serum bilirubin levels are high and rising rapidly.

To prove that treatment can be as effective as prevention, Dr, Sisson undertook a controlled study using continuous light with 50 infants whose jaundice was due to ABO incompatibility. Using a fluorescent blue light and plexiglas shield against ultraviolet emissions, Dr. Sisson started irradiating randomly selected infants only when serum bilirubin levels reached 10 mg%. And he kept bathing the infants in the light until concentrations fell below 7.5 mg%. On the average, this took three days.

Not one infant of the group exposed to the light required an exchange transfusion, Dr. Sisson re-ported to the Atlantic City meeting of the Society for Pediatric Research. But three of the controls did. “We have not studied infants with Rh hemolytic disease in a similarly controlled fashion,” he notes, “but rather, have used phototherapy on all. Exchange transfusion was necessary only in the most severely affected. And in those few instances where irradiation was adjunctive therapy, the number of expected repeat transfusions was reduced.”

For phototherapy to be effective in these cases, Dr. Sisson says, the light must be in the blue visible range, where the most active photodecomposition of bilirubin occurs. Most nurseries use “Daylight” bulbs with only 60% of the energy as the blue type at the effective wavelength. The blue light is equally effective in white and Negro infants, says Dr. Sisson, although it does hasten darkening of the skin of Negroes.

Dr. Gerald Ente, associate director of the nursery for the newborn at Long Island’s Meadowbrook Hospital, takes issue with Dr. Sisson on the last point. Though he finds light therapy effective in hemolytic diseases, he does not consider it as effective in Negroes as in whites, even for prophylactic purposes. “It is significant,” says the New York pediatrician, “that in 2Vi years, the only baby who received phototherapy and needed a transfusion was Negro. Probably the melanin pigment blocks penetration of the effective radiation.” In 50 black infants exposed to light on a preventive basis in his nursery, the average serum peak bilirubin level was 9.6 mg%. In 30 white babies, the peak level was 8.9 mg%.

Dr. Ente, who was one of the first to use the light units, has studied “a few” Rh and ABO babies. “We tried to predict whether they would have needed exchange transfusions had they not undergone the light therapy,” he says. “Only three out of 20 actually needed exchange.” He adds: “If my colleagues had known what I was doing, they’d have killed me. But I watched those kids like a hawk.” Nevertheless, because of the pressures. Dr. Ente dropped the preliminary study.

Objections to the technique are both real and imagined, he suggests. Some physicians argue that the light may damage the eyes, cause growth retardation, overheat the baby, or adversely affect circadian rhythms. And since there is no real knowledge of what happens to bilirubin once it is


Shielding infants' eyes ensures safety of controversial phototherapy, says Temple nursery chief, Dr. Norman Kendall.

photoexposed, there are those who contend that it may not be detoxified.

But a good part of the reluctance seems to stem from the unfortunate— and for some pediatricians, traumatic —experience with oxygen therapy. “We had no idea that the oxygen was actually causing retrolentai fibroplasia in infants with hyaline membrane disease,” recalls Dr. Sisson. “Once bit, twice shy.”

While phototherapy has its theoretical disadvantages, concedes Dr. Ente, “the main objection to it seems 1 to be that it goes against the medical mind. Doctors say, ‘It’s not scientific, this physiotherapy-type device.1 Actually, it’s too simple.”

“People are worried about a machine,” says pioneer phototherapist Jerold Lucey of the University of Vermont, who started it all in the U.S. “I wish we had put the babies outside in the sun, where they’d get 20 times more light. Who’d worry about doing that? Man has been walking around

in sunshine since shortly after the earth’s crust cooled, and not too many bad effects have been noted.”

Dr. Lucey has observed 77 light-treated infants for over two years and has found no evidence of neurotoxicity or growth retardation. Thousands of babies have also been treated safely jn Uruguay and France, he notes. Dr. Lucey is continuing to keep tabs on the treatment in Europe and South America. Since the eyes of infants are routinely shielded, there is believed to be no danger that the light damages them. But Dr. Sisson stresses that the eyes must be well covered. In studies he has conducted, unshielded piglets showed destruction of cells in the outer retinal layers after fewer than 12 hours of exposure.

The biggest unknown in phototherapy is the chemical effect of the light. “Photodecomposition of bilirubin is, as far as we know, an oxidative process,” says Dr. Sisson. “We should be concerned, then, that the light may • affect or stimulate other oxidative processes in the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and blood.” According to Gerard Odell, associate professor of pediatrics at John Hopkins, it does. Test-tube studies he has conducted indicate that light affects plasma albumin as well as bilirubin. If it is damaged, then it is no longer capable of transporting bilirubin out of the body. “The fact that light lowers serum bilirubin levels doesn’t mean the bilirubin has necessarily left the body,” Dr. Odell warns. “It may be displaced into the tissues.” Until evidence is produced that the amount of bilirubin recovered outside the body is equal to the amount altered, he says, he will continue to object to using light.

According to in vitro studies by Dr. Nasrollah Hakami of Seattle’s King County Hospital, biliverdin, one of the early breakdown products of bilirubin, inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme nucleic acid dehydrogenase. Thus, by inhibiting the activity of necessary enzymes, bilirubin could be toxic to brain cells. “But,” says Dr. Sisson, “we don’t know whether biliverdin is actually produced in vivo.” Until some highly sensitive ways of measuring bilirubin products in vivo are found, the battle lines will probably remain right where they are. n

MEDICAL WORLD NEWS /lune 13, 1969      21

FERH-2/72

MINERVA PEDIATRICA Feb.

Summary

From the Department of Clinical Puericulture (Head: Prof. G. P. Salvioli), University of Bologna.

G. P. Salvioli and P. Dahacasa: Personal experience with light in the management of para-physiclogicai and Rh- and ABO-isoimmunisation-induced neonatal bilirubinaeinia. — Results with light treatment in 19 cases of para physiological and Rh and ABO isoimmunisation-induced neonatal bilirubin aemia hospitalised in the Bologna University’s Puericulture Clinic from January to August 1970 are reported. Collateral therapy included i.v. cortisone and 5 % glucose perfusions. The treatment proved satisfactory in the immunological cases and its early use is recommended. Follow-up tests performed for a number of months in 64 % of the series (haemochromocytometry, EEG, ecc.) revealed anaemia of average gravity in only 2 ABO and 1 Rh ery-■ throblastosis foetalis cases.

1972, p, 122:

Blood bilirubin values must be carefully and constantly controlled during the treatment. A watch must also be kept on parenteral liquid administrations, particularly with respect to glucose solutions, to prevent hypoglycaemia and dehydration as possible complications of' light therapy. The early commencement of feeding is also recommended as a means of avoiding marked increases in blood bilirubin levels. Overall evaluation sjowed that statistically significant falls in blood bilirubin levels were obtained in paraphysiological and ABO isoim- ’ munisation subjects; in Rh cases, the upward trend of the blood bilirubin curve was halted and exsanguinotransfusion was rendered unnecessary.

(« Min. Ped. », 24, 113-123, 1972 — G. P. Salvioli. P. Dallacasa: « La nostra esperienza sull'impiego della luce nolle iperbilirubinemie neonatali parafisiotogiche e da malattia emolitica del nvonato Rh ed ABO »]. Authors’ address: G. P, Salvioli - 1st, Clin. Pueric. Univ. - Bologna (Italy).

Legal' aspects: see page

the treated group, compared with 92 in the control group. This is again significant at the 1% level. In the treated group no ill-effects were noted during or after phototherapy. It is suggested that phototherapy can reduce the requirements for exchange transfusions in rhesus hsemolytic disease.

THE LANCET, APRIL 22, 1972

DR. REID AND OTHERS : REFERENCES

PHOTOTHERAPY IN RHESUS H/EMOLYTIC

DISEASE

Mark McC. Reid4 Garth McClure E. Marks           J. H. Elwood

Special Care Unit, Royal Maternity Hospital, Belfast, and Department of Social and Preventive Medicine,

Queen’s University, Belfast

A controlled trial of the use of photo-

Summary tjierapy      management of infants

with rhesus haemolytic disease is reported. Phototherapy was administered for 4» days, starting after the transfer cf infants from the labour ward to the neonatal special-care unit. Forty-five phototherapy-treated infants required 50 exchange transfusions while seventy-eight control infants required 132 exchange transfusions. This difference is significant at the 1 % level. 19 late exchanges were required in

0 Present address; Lurgan and Portadown Hospital, Lurgan, County

Armagh, Northern Ireland.

Introduction.

The management of the neonate with rhesus haemolytic disease and consequent hyperbilirubinemia has been by exchange transfusion.1 McMullin et al.’ demonstrated that phenobarbitone administration could significantly reduce the number of exchange transfusions required. Phototherapy has been used in the treatment of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, but we could find no published reports of its successful use in rhesus haemolytic disease. We have investigated the use of phototnerapy in rhesus haanolytic disease in a controlled trial.

Patients and Methods

.The trial was carried out over a period of 11 months in the special-care unit, Royal Maternity Hospital, Belfast. All babies with rhesus hemolytic disease were admitted to the trial. The treated group received phototherapy for 4 days as soon as the results of the cord-blood analysis and Coomb’s test were received; this was always within 2 hours of birth. There were no other dissimilarities in the management of the control and treatment groups. None of the infants received phenobarbitone during this period nor did any of the mothers receive phenobarbitone in the last 2 weeks of pregnancy. The criteria for exchange transfusion were: (1) cord-blood serum-bilirubin 4 mg. per 100 ml. or more, (2) cord-blood hemoglobin less than 12 g. per 100 ml., and (3) serum-bilirubin above 19 mg. per 100 ml. An early exchange transfusion was defined as being one done because criteria (I) and (2) were fulfilled; a late exchange was done if criterion (3) was fulfilled.

Serum-bilirubin estimations were done approximately every 8 hours (or more frequently when the infant’s clinical state indicated) in the hospital laboratory by technicians who did not know to which treatment group the infants belonged.

Exchange transfusions were performed via the umbilical vein using acid-citrate-dextrose blood prepared not more than 4 days previously. All infants who required an exchange transfusion received a 48-hour course of ampicillin and cloxicillin. Feeding was started within 6 hours of delivery. Phototherapy was administered using a 160 W phototherapy unit (Air Shields (U.K.) Ltd., Southend-on-Sea). The infant’s eyes were bandaged, and covered with dark glasses to avoid possible retinal damage?

There were more patients in the control group than in the treatment group because we had only one phototherapy apparatus. This does not affect the statistical significance of the trial.

Results

The treated and control groups were similar with respect to mean birth-weight, cord bilirubin level, and Apgar score (table i); the difference between the average gestational ages arose by chance, and almost certainly did not affect the results of the trial. 50 exchange transfusions were required for the forty-five infants in the phototherapy group, an average o* 1-1 per infant, with twelve (27%) out of the fe^v-f.ve receiving no transfusions, compared with 132 u-ls-

880

fusions on the seventy-eight infants in the control group, an average of 1-7 transfusions per infant, with twenty-four (32%) receiving no transfusions. The total number of exchange transfusions required in the phototherapy group was significantly less in the control group (pcO’OI) (table n).

The difference in the number of exchange transfusions was due to significantly fewer late transfusions (table in): twenty-six (33%) of the controls required two or more late exchanges while only four (9%) of the treated infants required repeat transfusions.

Three infants died—one in the phototherapy group and two in the control group. The infant in the phototherapy group who died was born at 27 weeks’ gestation, weighing 1045 g., Apgar score 8; this child died at 74 hours of age from respiratory failure due to the respiratory-distress syndrome, confirmed at necropsy. This infant received two exchange transfusions, one early and one late. The two infants who died in the control group were also very immature. The first was born at 31 weeks’ gestation, weighing 1480 g., Apgar score 3j this child received an early exchange transfusion and died at the age of 7 days from intestinal obstruction, and was found at necropsy to have obstruction of the large bowel due to congenital peritoneal bands. The second infant was ’ born at 29 weeks’ gestation, weighing 1160 g., Apgar score 5; this child died at 38 hours of age after having had four exchange transfusions, one early and three late. This child, wh died from respiratory failure due to the respiratory-distress synctrome, was found to have cerebral hemorrhage at necropsy. None of the infants given phototherapy seemed to have any ill-effects, in that we noticed no change in their motor activity, no diarrhoea, and no increased incidence of eye infection, although two had a transient erythematous rash which was of no great significance.

UiscEssiati

Phototherapy has been used in the treatment of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia for more than 15 years.a-e Despite the theoretical risk of ill-effects caused by photochemical breakdown products of bilirubin,’ no short-term or long-term ill-effects have been recorded after the clinical use of phototherapy.8 This is probably not surprising, because Lucey0 noted that many infants have been exposed to twenty times the intensity of light supplied by phototherapy apparatus simply by being placed next to a window on a bright day.

There are few references to the use of phototherapy in rhesus hasmolytic disease, and those that there are refer to a few cases rather than a series of patients.1’'11 Behrman et al.13 thought that repeat exchange transfusions might be avoided by the use of phototherapy, but produced no convincing evidence for this claim. Others 13,1,1 thought that phototherapy would not be an effective method of avoiding repeat exchange transfusions where the rate of bilirubin production was very much higher than in “ physiological hyperbilirubinemia However, .we have found a significant reduction in the number of exchange transfusions required when phototherapy was used in the treatment of rhesus hasmolytic disease. As one might expect, the effect is to reduce the number of late rather than the early exchange transfusions. Sisson et al.13 have shown that the frequency of severe hyperbilirubinemia and exchange-transfusion rates can be reduced by the use of phototherapy in ABO incompatibility.

The technique of phototherapy in the treatment of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia can be usefully extended to the treatment of rhesus hemolytic disease. Any method which reduces the level of bilirubin, and also the need for exchange transfusions, must be welcomed because prolonged exposure to high levels of bilirubin may adversely affect the psychomotor development of infants in later life.15 Furthermore, an exchange transfusion, even in skilled hands, carries a definite morbidity and mortality, with the risk of infection, air embolus, vessel trauma, and hepatic damage. Although we had no deaths immediately after exchange transfusions, there were several instances of significant bradycardia and respiratory depression during the exchange transfusions which might not have occurred had the exchange not been required. Another benefit is the reduced requirements for blood. The phototherapy apparatus is easy to use and its cost should be rapidly recouped by the reduction in the demands for blood and the purchase of transfusion equipment.

We thank Prof. I. J. Carr6 and Dr. W. A. B. Campbell far their permission to study their patients, and also for their advice and encouragement.

Requests for reprints should- be addressed to M. M. R.

' lass sf aaw® wawteiiss

Bnfants who start life with erythroblastosis severe enough to require exchange transfusion never quite catch up with their unaffected peers, according to the results of a University of Pittsburgh study involving almost 4,000 children.

The study confirms what many physicians have long suspected: Erythroblastosis fetalis may result in permanent neurologic deficits, even in apparently healthy survivors.

“Among children who are healthy enough to attend school, it seems that blood group incompatibility and exchange transfusion pose hazards for IQ, vision, and hearing,” says Dr. Edward R. Schlesinger, chairman of the department or maternal and child health. “The differences from normal are small, but they are consistent and tend to be where we would expect them to be—among the more severely affected.”               ,

Dr. Schlesinger’s conclusion developed from a review of the health and school records of 1,865 children who had jaundice at or immediately after birth. The children were born at Magee-Women’s Hospital or treated for jaundice at Children’s Hospital of Pittsburgh. In all the cases included in the study, jaundice was attributed to erythroblastosis fetalis, ABO incompatibility, or hyperbilirubinemia.

.su; Exchange transfusions seem to be on their way out as far as pediatricians are concerned. According to, Dp. Julian B. Schorr, director of Clinical Services of the Greater New York Blood Program'and a practicing pediatric hematologist, the total number of such transfusions in his own practice has decreased by about 70%. Exceedingly few of those still done are for ABO incompatibilities and the jaundice of premature infants, with Rh incompatibility accounting for the rest.

Phototherapy has done a great deal to cut down on the need to transfuse neonates (MWN, June 13, ’69). It has also reduced the incidence of repeat exchanges by slowing the bilirubin "rebound" phenomenon.

In addition, Dr. Schorr says that several groups of physicians have been testing the use of phenobarbital in prospective mothers a couple ‘ of weeks before birth, or in their newborn babies (MWN, June 3, ’66). This drug enhances the bilirubin-ciearing mechanism when given in doses that do not induce drowsiness. And, for the Rh-incompatibility problems, there is Rh-immune globulin, which hopefully will become a mainstay in the obstetrician's practice.


For each case, Dr. Schlesinger and his research team, which included Dr. Sati Mazumdar, associate research professor of maternal and child health and biostatistics, selected a control, matched for sex, race, and birth weight.

“We then made every effort to get the children’s subsequent health records. We sent the parents a questionnaire covering the health history and present status of each child, and followed up by letter or phone call until we had an 80% response on the index cases and a 70% response on the controls,”

From the follow-up, the team obtained 475 matched pairs of children for whom they had results of vision and hearing tests. The greatest number of poor scores on both tests was concentrated in the group of children who had erythroblastosis fetalis treated by exchange transfusion, Dr. Schlesinger reported at the American Public Health Association meeting in Philadelphia.

Among the controls, only 5% had poor vision—defined as 20/40 in the best eye. But 9% of children with a record of neonatal jaundice had poor vision by the same criteria. And almost the same percentage of children in each group had a hearing loss of 35 decibels or more, usually in the right ear, with a smaller deficit in the left.

A similar pattern appeared in the IQ test results obtained from school records of 306 matched pairs of children. Average IQ of the index cases was 110, and of controls, 112. But for children who had the most severe Rh disease—those who underwent exchange transfusion at Children’s Hospital—average IQ was 109 vs 113 for their controls. Children with erythroblastosis requiring only small transfusions, on the order of three ounces, achieved IQ scores that differed from their controls by less than a point.

Children born of mothers with ABO incompatibility showed about the same deficits as those with Rh disease. Children who had hyperbilirubinemia in the neonatal period, on the other hand, had no deficits when compared with their equally low-birthweight controls.

Dr. Schlesinger speculates that hearing loss in children who have had exchange transfusions could be caused by streptomycin, given along with the transfusion to prevent infection.

“But the entire problem of Rh incompatibility would be eliminated if the new Rh antibody were used universally,” says the Pittsburgh researcher. Current estimates indicate that 8% of white women of childbearing age in the U.S. should have the Rh antibody, but only one in four is getting it.

The Massachusetts State Health Department is currently testing an Rh antibody preparation manufactured by its State Laboratory Institute. According to Dr. Morton Madoff, director of biological laboratories at the institute, the state can produce the preparation at a cost of $6 per dose.

Clinical tests with the Rh antibody preparation are being conducted in six Boston hospitals under an investigational new drug application. If it is licensed, says Dr. Madoff, “we could immunize every Rh-negative woman of child-bearing age in the state.” ■

26H MEDICAL WORLD NEWS January 16 0 1970

Reprinted from The Journal of Pediatrics, St. Louis Vol. 82, No. 1, pp. 73-76, January, 1973

Controlled trial comparing agar, intermittent phototherapy, and continuous phototherapy for reducing neonatal hyperbilirubinemia

Low-birth-weight infants,, les than 24 hours of age, were randomly assigned to one of four therapy, groups: (1) Agar, 125 mg. by mouth every 3 hours for 4 days beginning at 18 hours; (2) exposure to blue light, 200 to 300 footcandles 12 hours daily for 4 days (intermittent light); (3) exposure to blue light continuously for 4 days (continuous light); and (4) no therapy. Infants with a positive Coombs test or sepsis were excluded. From the second day on, infants who received light continuously had significantly lower mean bilirubin concentrations than any of the other three groups. Infants who received intermittent light or agar had daily mean values which were not significantly different from those of the control subjects except on Day 4.

Harold M. Maurer, M.D.,* Clare N. Shumway, M.D., David A. Draper, M.D., and Ali A, Hossaini, M.D., Richmond, Va.

Phototherapy, regardless of skin pigmentation, is effective in both prevention and treatment of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia. Despite its frequent and widespread usage, little information is available as to how to best apply it. There is no information available to evaluate the optimal duration of light exposure or whether exposure should be continuous or intermittent. The

From the Department of Pediatrics, Medical College of Virginia.

Presented in part at the American Pediatric Society meeting, Washington, D. C., May 23, 1972.        "

Statistical analyses were supported in part by Public Health Service Research Grant RR00016-08 from the National Institutes of Health.

* Reprint address; Department of Pediatrics, Medical College of Virginia, Richmond^ V a. 23219, intensity, duration, and pattern of light exposure have varied considerably among the groups of infants who have been subjected to phototherapy by different investigators. The intensity of light has ranged from 90 footcandles of overhead environmental lighting to 200 to 500 footcandles using a light chamber; some have used blue light and others white light. Therapy has been continued for varying periods of time, continuously or intermittently, through the sixth day. Obviously, a number of questions concerning technique need to be answered, before an optimal phototherapy regimen can be arrived at. One purpose of our study was to determine whether intermittent phototherapy is as effective as continuous phototherapy in reducing neonatal hyperbilirubinemia in low-birth-weight infants.

Vol. 82, No. 1, pp. 73-76

7 4 Maurer et al.

The Journal of Pediatrics January 1973


Table I. Study groups

Group

No. of infants

p value between groups

> 0.05

> 0.05

The second purpose of our study relates to the recent report by Poland and Odell.1 They evaluated the role of the enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin in the production of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia in nine fullterm infants delivered by cesarean section. Poland and Odell gave a formula supplemented with agar, U.S.P., for the first five days of life starting at the twentieth hour. Ten infants were given the same formula without agar. Agar is thought to stabilize bilirubin in aqueous solution and prevent its bacterial conversion and reabsorption from the intestinal tract. No rise in serum bilirubin concentration occurred after the thirteenth hour of life in the agar-fed infants. More bilirubin was excreted in the feces within the first five days in infants fed formula with agar than in the control subjects. These results suggest that the reabsorption of bilirubin from the intestine can be a major cause of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia and that agar may be of therapeutic value in controlling the projected rise in neonatal serum bilirubin concentration. Our second purpose was to determine whether agar-supplemented feedings modified the course of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia in low-birth-weight infants, and to compare its effect on serum bilirubin concentration to that of intermittent and continuous phototherapy,

METHODS

Low-birth-weight infants (less than 2,500 Gm.) less than 24 hours of age were randomly assigned to one of four groups: Group 1 (17 infants) received agar powder (U.S.P., Difco Laboratories, Detroit, Mich., Lot No. 554882), 125 mg. in the first 5 ml. of each formula (Similac with iron), beginning at 18 hours and continued at 3 hour intervals for 4 days (32 doses); Group 2(18 infants) was exposed to blue fluorescent light (eight 20 watt lamps, F2OT12/B, Westinghouse Corp., Bloomfield, N. J.), 200 to 300 footcandles, 12 hours daily for 4 days (intermittent phototherapy) ; Group 3 (19 infants) was exposed to blue fluorescent light continuously for 4 days (continuous phototherapy); and Group 4 (15 infants) received no therapy. Infants with positive Coombs tests, potential ABO incompatibility, or sepsis were excluded. Infants receiving phototherapy were placed nude in the Isolettes. The distance of the lamps to the superior surface of the infant was 40 cm.

The intensity of the lamps was monitored daily. All infants received 1 mg. of synthetic vitamin Ki intramuscularly. Serum bilirubin concentrations were determined daily with a direct-reading spectrophotometer.2 Statistical analyses were performed using analysis of variance and Duncan’s multiple range test.

RESULTS                       ■ '•

Infants in each group were similar with respect to mean birth weight, mean gestational age, sex distribution, and race (9<7 per cent or more were Negro (Table I).

From the second day on, infants who received continuous phototherapy had significantly (p < 0.05 on Day 2; p < 0.01 on Days 3 to 6) lower mean serum bilirubin concentrations than any of the other three groups (Fig. 1). In contrast, infants who received intermittent phototherapy or agar-supplemented feedings had mean values which tended to be lower than those of the control subjects on Days 4 through 6, but

Volume 82

Number 1


Therapy for hyperbilirubinemia 1 5

Control —»


Agar ■■■■♦......

Intermittent Phototherapy —-O-.....

Continuous Phototherapy —O---

Age in Days

Fig. 1. Mean total serum bilirubin concentrations of low-birth-weight newborn infants in each of the four groups. (Cross bars represent means ± S.E.)


only on Day 4 was this difference significant ,(p < 0.05)..

Side effects of therapy were minimal in both light-treated groups and consisted of occasional mild diarrhea. Agar supplementation was well tolerated and no significant (p > 0.05) weight loss occurred as a result of its potential laxative effect during therapy.

DISCUSSION

It is strikingly apparent from our data that continuous phototherapy during the first four days of life is significantly superior to either intermittent phototherapy or agar-^supplemented feedings in lowering the concentration of serum bilirubin in low-birthweight infants. Its effect is obvious by the second day of life and is still apparent by the sixth. In contrast to continuous phototherapy;, the use of intermittent phototherapy (12 hours daily for 4 days) or agar-supplemented feedings results in little, if any, significant serum bilirubin reduction, when compared to no therapy. Our findings indicate that continuous phototherapy results in the lowest bilirubin concentrations in low-birth-weight infants. In a study by Porto and associates,3 in which blue light (40 watt fluorescent lamps) was turned on 75 per cent of the time during a 4 day period and resulted in lowered bilirubin levels in low-birth-weight infants, no comparison was made with continuous therapy.

With respect to agar, our results in low-birth-weight neonates failed to confirm the earlier findings of Poland and Odel!.1 They reported no further rise in neonatal serum bilirubin concentrations in full-term infants when agar-supplemented feedings were instituted. The dosage of agar employed in our study (approximately 0.5 Gm. per kilogram of body weight per day) is similar to the dosage used in their trial. Agar, U.S.P., is a dried hydrophilic colloidal substance obtained from various species of algae.4 It is rich in hemicellulose. It has been extensively used in the preservation of meat, confections, bakery products, ice cream, and cheese.5 It has also been employed medicinally as a colloid laxative and is used in commercially prepared infant formulas in the form of carrageenan. Poland and Odell postulate, on the basis of in vitro studies, that agar protects bilirubin from the action

Reprinted from The Journal of Pediatrics, St. Douis Vol. 82, No. 1, pp. 73-76, January, 1973

Controlled trial comparing agar, intermittent phototherapy, and continuous phototherapy for reducing neonatal hyperbilirubinemia

Low-birth-weight infants, les than 24 hours of age, were randomly assigned to one of four therapy groups: (1) Agar, 125 mg. by mouth every 3 hours for 4 days beginning at 18 hours; (2) exposure to blue light, 200 to 300 footcandles 12 hours daily for 4 days (intermittent light) ; (3) exposure to blue light continuously for 4 days (continuous light); and (4) no therapy. Infants with a positive Coombs test or sepsis were excluded. From the second day on, infants who received light continuously had significantly lower mean bilirubin concentrations than any of the other three groups. Infants who received intermittent light qr agar had daily mean values which were not significantly different from those of the control subjects except on Day 4.

Harold M. Maurer, M.D.,* Clare N. Shumway, M.D., David A. Draper, M.D., and Ali A. Hossaini, M.D., Richmond, Va.

Phototherapy, regardless of skin pigmentation, is effective in both prevention and treatment of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia. Despite its frequent and widespread usage, little information is available as to how to best apply it. There is no information available to evaluate the optimal duration of light exposure or whether exposure should be continuous or intermittent. The

From the Department of Pediatrics, Medical College of Virginia.

Presented in part at the American Pediatric Society meeting, Washington, D. C., May 23, 1972.

Statistical analyses were supported in part by Public Health Service Research Grant

RROOO16-08 from the National Institutes of Health.

^Reprint address: Department of Pediatrics, Medical College of Virginia, Richmond, Va. 23219. intensity, duration, and pattern of light exposure have varied considerably among the groups of infants who have been subjected to phototherapy by different investigators. The intensity of light has ranged from 90 footcandles of overhead environmental lighting to 200 to 500 footcandles using a light chamber; some have used blue light and others white light. Therapy has been continued for varying periods of time, continuously or intermittently, through the sixth day. Obviously, a number of questions concerning technique need to be answered, before an optimal phototherapy regimen can be arrived at. One purpose of our study was to determine whether intermittent phototherapy is as effective as continuous phototherapy in reducing neonatal hyperbilirubinemia in low-birth-weight infants.

Vol. 82, No. 1, pp. 73-76

Pediat. Res. 6: 246-251 (1972)

Albumin photodecomposition bilirubin phototherapy


April 1972

Chemical Variables and New Lamps in Phototherapy

Gerald Ente*371, Edward W. Lanning, Peter Cukor, and Richard M. Klein

Department of Pediatrics, Nassau County Medical Center, East Meadow, New York, and The Bayside Research Center, GTE Laboratories, Incorporated, Bayside, New York, USA

Extract

In vitro studies were undertaken to measure the effects of varying concentrations of albumin and flux on the photodecomposition of bilirubin.

By using an experimental model, the effect of albumin on photodegradation of bilirubin was determined. Synthetic crystalline bilirubin solutions (20 mg/100 ml, pH 7.4) were exposed to the same flux levels for periods of 4.5 hr. The only variable in this series was the concentration of albumin, ranging from 0.5 to 5 g/100 ml. As the the concentration of albumin increased, the reaction rate decreased (Fig. 5).

The efficiency of phototherapy was studied by varying flux levels while maintaining other variables constant. Figure 6 shows a nonlinear relation between reaction rate and flux, in which higher flux levels resulted in less decomposition per amount of flux (i.e., efficiency). More than twice the flux level was required to attain a twofold increase in decomposition rate. The effect of light fjux was such that continuous use of the lowest practical level is to be recommended.

Data are given on the comparison of the relative effectiveness of cool white, high intensity blue, and two experimental lamps. The four lamps were tested at conditions of constant distance and constant flux. The high intensity blue lamp was twice as effective as the cool wrhite. The two experimental lamps showed a 17% increase over the blue lamp (Figs. 2 and 3).

The effect of time on the spectral output of the fluorescent lamps in an experimental model was determined by using a spectral radiometer. The energy dropoff within the 420- to 480-nm region at 200 hr was approximately 20% for blue lamps and averaged 7.5% for the experimental lamps.

Speculation

As with any new drug used on the neonate, the effects of phototherapy must be categorized, and the procedure must be standardized. Further investigations are needed to determine exact in vivo decomposition products, optimal timing of exposure, differences in skin attenuation, toxicity reactions, site of action, and photobiologic and photochemical alterations and interreactions.

Introduction

Successful treatment and prophylaxis of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia with phototherapy—the use of magnetic waves of visible light—have been reported by many investigators in this country and abroad over the past 13 years [1-5, 9-14, 18, 19, 24, 25, 27, 28, 30]. Many questions regarding the physical hazards of phototherapy have been posed by investigators who have observed harmful effects produced in animals after ex-

Chemical variables and new lamps in phototherapy

247


Table I. Definitions

Flux

Quantity of total radiant power or energy, watts/cm3

Lumen

A unit of luminous flux, i.e., the capacity to produce a visual sensation

Footcandle

A standard unit of illumination (1 lumen/ sq foot)

Nanometer

Unit of wavelength 10~3 meter

Millimicron

Unit of wavelength 10'3 meter

Angstrom

Unit of wavelength 10-10 meter

Efficiency

(Percentage decomposition/unit time)/ (unit flux)

Phosphor

A substance which emits light when excited by radiation

Emission spec-

Radiant energy as a function of wave-

trum

length

posure to high intensity radiation [6, 8, 15, 20, 26]. Other obstacles to the wider acceptance of phototherapy are attributable to the complexity of evaluating the in vivo system and the difficulty of extrapolating laboratory results to the clinical situation [2, 9, 10, 17, 19, 21, 22, 25, 28].'                       •

The in vitro studies reported herein were designed to measure the effects of variations in concentrations of albumin and flux (see Table I) upon the photodecomposition of bilirubin. Also, experimental lamps were tested.

Materials and Methods

Apparatus

A light exposure box was built which allowed simultaneous exposure of three solutions by three different lamps. A Reeder thermopile [31] was used to measure the total flux (watts per square centimeter) of each lamp. The response of the thermopile is linear within 2% over the entire visible portion of the spectrum. One-millimeter precision cells [32] were used to expose solutions to lamps as well as to measure absorption spectra. Absorption spectra were obtained with a Cary model no. 14 recording spectrophotometer [33].

The lamps utilized in the tests consisted of two commonly used lamps, the cool white (GE F20T12CW) and high intensity blue (GE F20T12B), and two experimental lamps, A and B (Fig. 1). Lamp A was phosphor no. L7352 [16] and Lamp B was no. FPB 533C [23]-                .....

Reagents

Standard phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) was prepared according to the method of White et al. [29]. Crystalline unconjugated bilirubin [34] and crystallized human albumin [34] were used. Bilirubin was routinely recrystallized from methanol-chloroform solution. The first batch was subjected to ascending thin layer chromatographic analysis on silica gel plates, and no separated impurity spots were observed. The infrared spectrum of bilirubin prepared in this manner was obtained in a potassium bromide pellet. The spectrum showed only those bands assigned to bilirubin. After the pellet was exposed to daylight for several days, its spectrum showed no significant change. In this manner, it was established that bilirubin in a solid dry state was relatively insensitive to light. Test solutions were prepared by dissolving the appropriate amount of bilirubin in a minimum amount of 0.1 N sodium hydroxide solution. Albumin was added and the volume was adjusted with phosphate buffer. Bilirubin concentration ranged from 7.5.to 30 mg/100 ml and albumin concentration from 0.05 to 5.0 g/100 ml.

Fig. 1. Emission spectra for experimental lamps. Lamp A is an alkaline earth pyrophosphate. Lamp B is a strontium chlorophosphate.

Test Procedure

In the light exposure tests, portions of the test solutions were transferred to the 1-mm cells, and their absorption spectra were recorded. The cells were then placed in the light exposure box for irradiation by the appropriate lamps. Each sample was placed at a distance from the lamp which provided the desired flux as measured, with the thermopile at the front surface of the cell, except for those runs in which constant distance was employed. The lamp to sample distance varied from approximately 3 to 18 inches. Concurrently, a reference sample was prepared for monitoring any dark reaction. Periodically, the absorption spectra were obtained for both the test and reference samples in order to measure the bilirubin absorption as well as to observe any change in spectral shape. No temperature changes were observed.

In order to measure the relative effectiveness of the different lamps, samples of synthetic icteric serum were exposed to radiation from each. The concentration of bilirubin at any given time was inferred from the absorbance at 455 nm, and the rate of decomposition was measured by the decrease in absorbance at this wavelength. The lamps were tested under conditions of constant distance and constant flux.

Fig. 2. Reaction rates for different lamps at constant flux The experimental lamps are 17% more effective than the high intensity blue lamps used in clinical phototherapy. Cool white fluorescent lamps are only half as efficient as the high intensity blue.

To ascertain the effect of albumin on pbotodegi ada-tion of bilirubin, 20 mg/100 ml solutions of bilirubin were exposed at pH 7.4 for periods of 4.5 hr to the same flux levels. The only variable in this series was the amount of albumin.

Finally, a series of tests was made to determine the effect of varying flux levels while maintaining all other factors constant.

To measure the effect of time on the spectral output of the fluorescent lamps, the maintenance of the four lamps was tested with a spectral radiometer. Light from a 4-inch section of the middle of the lamp was allowed to pass through a monochrometer to a photomultiplier. The output of the photomultiplier was digitized and fed to a computer that corrected the results for instrument spectral sensitivity. The computer then printed out the energy emitted by the lamp for each 2-nm interval. Blue, cool white, and two experimental lamps were measured with this equipment.

Results

Figure 2 compares results of bilirubin sample exposures to the four test lamps. Samples were so placed that the total light flux was constant. This shows that, after 5.5 hr of irradiation, the high intensity blue lamp was twice as effective as the cool white. Moreover, the experimental lamps exhibited a 17% increase over the GE blue lamp.

In actual clinical use, lamps are placed at a fixed distance from the infant. A test run was therefore made under the conditions of constant lamp to sample distance. The results (Fig. 3) are quantitative differences which can be attributed to different lamp fluxes. For example, the blue lamp was 1.6 times as effective as the cool white, as contrasted to the factor of 2.0 found in the previous measurements. This is partially explained by the fact that at a fixed distance the flux level of the cool white was 10% greater than in the constant flux level experiments.

Figure 4 shows lamp maintenance data for a typical cool white lamp [35]. The percentages of initial output obtained after 100 hr of operation for the two experimental lamps were 91% for A and 94% for B. For the cool white lamp, the value was 96% and for the blue lamp the value was 85.7%. The percentage of initial output for the blue lamp in the 420- to 480-nm region at 200 hr was 80.9, indicating a 20% dropoff at 200 hr. Moreover, the energy output after 200 hr was constant for every 2-nm reading within this interval.

Increasing albumin concentrations retarded the photodecomposition process. Figure 5 shows the effect of


Chemical variables and new lamps in phototherapy

249


Ftg. Reaction rates for different lamps at constant distance. The experimental lamps ate more efficient than .high intensity blue, and cool white lamps are the least efficient.

Fig. 4. Lamp maintenance. Phosphor decay curve for cool white lamps. Experimental lamps exhibited 91% {lamp A) and 94% {lamp B) of initial brightness after 100 hr. The curve approached an asymptote. This suggests a lamp lifetime of several thousand hours.

increasing albumin on the reaction rate of bilirubin at pH 7.4. As the concentration of albumin was increased, the reaction rate decreased. Beyond 4 g/100 ml albumin, little reduction in reaction rate was observed.

Figure 6 shows a nonlinear relation between reaction rate and flux in which higher flux levels resulted in less decomposition per unit flux. The lower the flux level, the higher was the efficiency of the system. One implication of Figure 6 is that the most efficient use of phototherapy is with the use of the lowest possible flux level necessary to maintain the desired bilirubin concentration. It is further suggested that continuous exposure is preferable to the intermittent mode.

% ALBUMIN CONCENTRATION (grams/100 m I)

Fig. 5. Decomposition rate as a function of albumin concentration. As the concentration of albumin increases, photodecomposition rates decrease, i.e., the efficiency is lowered.

Fig. 6. Decomposition as a function of flux: the lower the flux level, the higher the efficiency (percentage of decomposition per unit flux).

Discussion

The ideal lamp for phototherapy is one that exhibits all of its emission between 450 and 460 nm. However, practical fluorescent lamps emit bands of greater than 10-nm width. The broad spectrum cool white lamp exhibits most of its phosphor emission between 500 and 700 nm. The blue lamp emits maximal energy at 450 nm and is more suitable. Confusion occurs here because we are not concerned with footcandles or lumens (see Table I), but are interested in the actual specific energy, which is measured in microwatts per square centimeter, or flux, for the specific nanometers or wavelengths involved in the process of photodecomposition of bilirubin. So, although a cool white bulb gives a higher footcandle reading on a light meter, it lacks flux comparable to the blue lamp. Again, the blue bulb gives a lower footcandle reading and emits a high relative energy concentration in the 420- to 480-nm zone.

Seeking effective narrow band phosphors, we selected two phosphor systems (Fig. 1). Most of their energy output was found to be in the desired wavelength region and their peak emissions were 4-5 times as great as that of the blue lamp.

The spectral output of all fluorescent lamps decreases as a function of time. The qualitative form of this deterioration is similar for all fluorescent lamps; i.e., phosphor decay is characterized by a relatively rapid dropoff in the first 100 hr, followed by a more gradual steady decline. The severity of the deterioration can therefore be judged by the amount of deterioration at 100 hr. For example, Figure 4 shows a lamp maintenance curve for a cool white lamp [35], The shape of this curve is similar for all fluorescent lamps; that is, the brightness approaches an asymptote. The percentage of initial output obtained after 100 hr of operation for the two experimental lamps (91% for A and 94% for B) indicates that the lamps will have a very long life (thousands of hours) under normal operating conditions.

Because of the long predicted lifetime of the experimental lamps as compared with that found by Sisson et al. [28] for the presently used blue lamps, the maintenance of these lamps was tested. Our data showed only a 10% dropoff in spectral output at 200 hr, as opposed to 44% reported by Sisson et al. [28],

Varying concentrations of albumin were investigated. One mole albumin is capable of binding two moles of bilirubin under our experimental conditions [21]. Since the molecular weights are in the ratio of ~ 100/1, 100 ml of 1% solution of albumin is sufficient for binding 20 mg bilirubin. Figure 5 shows the effect of increasing albumin on the reaction rate of biliiu-bin. Apparently, the albumin-bound bilirubin complex is more stable than free bilirubin, so that, as the concentration of albumin is increased, the reaction ratedecreases. This result shows that although more albumin is desirable because of increased binding of bilirubin, which prevents tieposition in tissue, it is disadvantageous in that it retards the rate of photodecomposition.

We studied the efficiency of phototherapy by varying flux levels while maintaining all other factors constant. Efficiency is defined as (percentage bilirubin decomposed per unit of time)/(total light flux). The lamps having the greatest efficiency will therefore theoreti cally accomplish the destruction of bilirubin with the least exposure of total radiation to the infant. The nonlinear relation between increasing flux and bilirubin decomposition as shown in Figure 6 means that ' higher flux levels result in less decomposition per unit flux. One implication of Figure 6 is that the most efficient use of phototherapy is the use of the lowest possible flux level necessary to maintain the desired bilirubin concentration, ft is further suggested that continuous exposure is preferable to an intermittent mode. With intermittent use, light might be or? for 2 hr and off for 2 hr. The ‘‘on’' period must produce the same amount of decomposition as 4 hr of continuous exposure. In order to achieve this, twice the decomposition rate must be attained. Figure 6 shows that much more than twice the flux level is required to attain a twofold increase in decomposition rate. Thus, the intermittent mode of therapy would require exposure to mud', more light. The effect of light flux is such that the lowest practical level is recommended. Moreover, continuous exposure is recommended to provide more efficient decomposition per unit of flux. Clinically, this was confirmed by Jurado-Garcia [13].

Conclusions

The experimental lamps, chosen on the basis of their emission spectra, are found to be 15-20% more effective than the high intensity blue lamps used in clinical phototherapy. Cool white fluorescent lamps are found to be only half as efficient as the blue lamps. These results are similar regardless of albumin, flux, or bilirubin level. Increasing albumin concentration retards the photodecomposition process. The effect of light flux is such that continuous exposure at the lowest practical level is recommended.

Chemical variables and new lamps in phototherapy

251

Factors Influencing the Effectiveness of Phototherapy in Neonatal Hyperbilirubinemia

THOMAS R. C. SISSON, M . D . ; NORMAN KENDALL, M . D .; RONALD E. DAVIES, Ph.D. AND DANIEL BERGER, M.S.E.E.

The rate of photodecomposition of bilirabin in vivo and in vitro depends upon the intensity of the light used for irradiation and also upon the spectral distribution of the emitted light. The action spectrum of bilirubin, the wavelength of visible light to which it is photoreactive, is equally important in producing a photochemical reaction. These studies indicate that bilirubin is most effectively decomposed by light emission in the blue range, 420 to 460 nanometers, and that the greater the energy output of the light source in this wavelength interval the more rapid the degradation of bilirubin. A significant loss of energy was found in the fluorescent lamps employed in phototherapy after 200 hours of use. This energy loss was found sufficient to retard the rate of bilirubin decay in vivo.

The effects of light on bilirubin metabolism in the jaundiced newborn infant appear to be related to:

  • 1. The action spectrum of bilirubin.

  • 2. Spectral radiant intensity.*

  • 3. The character of the plasma in which bilirubin circulates.

  • 4. Hemolytic processes and the rate of red cell destruction.

  • 5. The maturity of the irradiated infant.

  • 6. The purpose of the irradiation—preventive or therapeutic.

, Our studies1 have shown that the rate of bilirubin photodecomposition both in vivo and in vitro depends upon the intensity of the light used and upon its spectral distribution. The greater “the rnergv outnut of the light source the more rapid has been the degradation "of "the briirubin“irradiated.

Plasma with a low content of protein, in particular

Sisson—Associate Professor of Pediatrics, Associate Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology (Perinatology} and Director of Neonatal Research, Temple University School of Medicine and St. Christopher’s Hospital for Children, Philadelphia.

Kendall—Professor of Pediatrics and Chief of Newborn Services, Temple University School of Medicine and St. Christopher’s Hospital for Children, Philadelphia.

Davies—Associate Professor of Dermatology (Biochemistry), Temple University School of Medicine, Philadelphia.

Berger—Assistant Professor of Dermatology (Medical Physics), Temple University School of Medicine, Philadelphia.

* Spectral radiant intensity ■ radiant intensity per unit wavelength interval.

albumin, is characteristically found in premature infants. Free or unbound bilirubin may, therefore, circulate in high concentration with consequently greater risk of kemicterus. If free fatty acids are present in great amount they will compete with bilirubin for binding sites on albumin.

The rate of red cell destruction that may occur to a pathologic degree in the infant is of particular importance, whether due to fetomatemal blood group incompatibility, sepsis or other causes. Upon this process depends not only the increment of plasma bilirubin per unit of time but the ability of the infant to handle the quantity of bilirubin produced.

Newborn infants who are immature have difficulty in adequately conjugating bilirubin to permit its excretion, even without hemolytic disease. This is believed to account in large measure for the higher incidence of hyperbilirubinemia among prematures. Other factors of hypoxia, acidosis, etc. also play an accompanying role in this circumstance.

All these elements bear upon the purpose of phototherapy. If a prophylactic effect is sought as in the premature infant/ the intensity of light and time of exposure are quite different, than for the treatment of hyperbilirubinemia as an already existing condition. In the latter situation the length of time of treatment cannot be as leisurely as for prophylaxis. If the plasma concentration of bilirubin is rapidly increasing, as it must also in the tissues, the rise may

Birth Defects: Original Article Series. Vol. VI, No. 2; June, 1970.

100


BIOGRAPHIC DATA


Dr. Thomas R. C. Sisson is the Director of Neonatal Research at Temple University School of Medicine and St. Christopher's Hospital for Children. Philadelphia, where he is Associate Professor of Pediatrics and of Obstetrics and Gynecology (Perinatology). He received his pediatric training at the University of Rochester and Cornell University College of Medicine—New York

Hospital.

Originally trained in pediatric hematology at Cornell University Medical Center, he later turned to the field of perinatal studies at the University of Rochester-—Strong Memorial Hospital. There he headed the newborn services from 1953 to 1959 as a member of the Departments of Pediatrics and Obstetrics. From 1960 to 1965 he was Associate Clinical Professor of Pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, where he was attending pediatrician to the newborn services. Between 1 965 and 1967 he was Associate Professor of Pediatrics at the Loma Linda University School of Medicine, after which he assumed his present position.

Doctor Sisson's research interests have been

principally in the anemias of infancy and childhood, nutrition of the premature infant, bilirubin metabolism, and biologic rhythms of the infant.

be too precipitate to allow the same minimal light intensity found satisfactory for preventive therapy.

The action spectrum of bilirubin is of primary importance in the consideration of phototherapy, not only in the evaluation of its clinical effect, but also in the study of bilirubin metabolism itself. Knowledge of the rate of photodecay of this pigment irradiated under various types of visible light is incomplete. as is identification of its breakdown products. Evidence is accumulating that the photodecomposition of bilirubin is a very complex process involving products with different rates of appearance, and perhaps of differing molecular composition under varied experimental conditions, and not all identical with those in the human infant. It should be stated, if only parenthetically, that the action spectra of the breakdown products should be investigated, for were they to vary widely from those of bilirubin itself the composition of the light sources for phototherapy might be quite different from those in use at this time.

It seems a logical extension of these relationships to employ those areas in the visible spectrum to which bilirubin is most reactive. Since ultraviolet radiation should be avoided in the clinical use of phototherapy, our attention has not been focused on the effects of UV light except to a minor degree.

Not only has the action spectrum of bilirubin been of interest, but also the determination of the spectral radiant intensity of a variety of light sources under conditions of use and in comparison one with another.

Materials and Methods

The following fluorescent lamps of 20 watt input were used as light sources: red (F20T12/R), pink (F20T12/P), yellow (F20T12/GO), green (F20T12/G), blue (F20T12/B), daylight (F20T12/DA), Vitalite® , special narrow-band blue (Westinghouse).

Solutions of bilirubin (20 mg/100 ml) in human serum albumin (3.3 gm/100 ml) buffered by Sorenson’s phosphate buffer to pH 7.4 were divided into 2.0 ml aliquots and placed in small plastic Petri dishes. These were exposed to the various fluorescent lamps for 30, 60, 120, and 240 minutes at a distance of 9.6 cm.

Spectral analyses were performed on each sample in a Cary Model 14 scanning-recording spectrophotometer.

The energy output of each light source when new, and in some instances after varying periods of use, was measured by a spectroradiometer attachment to the Cary Model 14. Energy is expressed in microwatts per square centimeter per nanometer.

Results

Light Source Characteristics

We had noticed that the response of hyperbiliru-binemic infants to phototherapy was less marked when the lamps had been in use for over 200 hours. Figure 1 is a graphic representation of the energy output of blue fluorescent lamps when new and after 89, 108, and 200 hours of use.

A marked drop-off of energy, especially in the wavelengths of peak output (420-460 nm). was observed. The decrement varied from 44 to 49', after 200 hours in the range of 400 to 480 nm, which encompasses almost all the effective emission of these lamps in the blue portion of the spectrum. The data are presented in Table I.

It was apparent from these observations that the loss of energy in this rather narrow spectral range was substantial, and it was obvious from repeated clinical studies that the decrease of energy did affect the rate of decline of serum bilirubin in vivo. The clear implication is that the photodecomposition of bilirubin is dependent upon the spectral radiant intensity of the light source.

It was also observed that the decrease of serum bilirubin concentration was slower when fluorescent lamps of broad spectral distribution, ie “daylight”

102 EFFECTIVENESS OF PHOTOTHERAPY IN NEONATAL HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA

and Vitalite", were used in place of the blue lamps whose spectral distribution was more monochromatic.

To determine if the chemically effective energy of these lamps differed (though their luminosity was comparable) the output of each was measured al wavelengths from 320 to 500 nm. The percent energy of each broad-spectrum lamp was compared with that of the blue, whose output at each wavelength was taken as 100', (Fig. 2).

The daylight type of lamp had but 35'; of the output of the blue at 440 nm; the Vitalite ’ lamp had but about 35' < at the same wavelength. At 460 nm the daylight lamp had approximately 65% of the energy of the blue and the Vitalite had about 45b of the energy.

A blue fluorescent lamp with special phosphors and a very narrow range (Westinghouse Corp.) of emission (120 475 nm) and a peak output at -145 nm was also compared with the standard blue fluorescent, F20T12/B, and was found to have 440% of the energy’ of the standard at 435 nm, but only 53% at 480 nm. The use of the special blue lamp (Westinghouse) in clinical phototherapy demonstrated a very rapid decomposition of bilirubin. The rate of decline of serum bilirubin concentration was 0.09 mg/hr with the standard blue lamp, but was three times this rate, or 0.27 mg/hr, with the special blue lamp.

In summary, lamps of higher energy output were more effective clinically, and this was confirmed by in vitro studies which demonstrated a faster rate of decomposition of bilirubin in that static system (Fig. 4). This was so whether the lower energy output was due to energy loss from lamp use over a period of time or as a characteristic of the particular lamp. These findings support the concept that the spectral radiant intensity of the light source influences the photodecomposition of bilirubin.

Action Spectrum

In order to determine if there is indeed a fairly specific action spectrum for the photochemical degradation of bilirubin, this compound was irradiated in vitro in two solvent systems. One employed pooled exchange transfusion serum of an infant with severe hemolytic disease of the newborn; bilirubin concentration was 7.5 rng/lOO ml. The second employed bilirubin in buffered human albumin. Two ml aliquots were irradiated as described before. These bilirubin solutions were exposed to light from fluorescent lamps with differing emission spectra, which are listed in Table II.

TABLE il
