Special Blue

420 480

430

Although overlapping of the wavelengths emitted by these fluorescent lamps is impossible to avoid, the principal peaks of emission,' and consequently the positions of major energy output, have different characteristics. Those lamps which were found to have an appreciable effect on bilirubin had one thing in common, however, energy output between 400 and 500 nm, either from the fluorescing phosphor plus the mercury vapor spectral lines, or from the mercury spectral lines alone. Where no energy below 500 nm appears, as in red and yellow fluorescent lamps whose colored glass envelopes absorb this energy, no effect on bilirubin was observed.

The change in optical density of bilirubin in buffered human serum albumin after 30, 60, and 120 minutes of irradiation under the various light sources is illustrated in Figure 3. These changes represent a loss of optical density as bilirubin was decomposed.

Almost no change occurred under red, yellow, or pink lamps after 30 minutes of exposure, but an easily measured loss of bilirubin was registered under the other lamps. There was no significant difference among the green, “daylight,” blue, and special blue at this time interval and in this system.

After 60 minutes of irradiation marked increase of the AOD was again found in samples exposed to green, “daylight." and the two blue lamps. Ai this time a significant degree of phi'todecomposition under pink light was observed, though no further change under red, and but slight change under yellow light.

After 120 minutes the optical density of solutions exposed to red. pink, and yellow light had changed little if at all. but the samples under green, “day light,” and blue continued to decrease, demonstrating continued breakdown of bilirubin. The most distinct effect was observed in those solutions irradiated by blue and special blue lamps.

Exposure of similar samples of pooled infant .-erum under the same conditions produced information of interest. The presence of hemoglobin in the system made the analytic graphs complex and less easy to

CUMULATIVE △ O D OF BILIRUBIN (20mg,100 ml) IN BUFFERED HUMAN ALBUMIN AFTER IRRADIATION BY VARIOUS FLUORESCENT LAMPS

Fig. 3. The cumulative change of optical density (decrease) of bilirubin in buffered human albumin is shown after 30, 60, and 120 minutes of irradiation by various fluorescent lamps of differing spectral distribution. R = red; GO = yellow; Pi — pink; GR = green; DA = “daylight”; Bl — blue; SB1 = special blue.

Fig. 4. The change in ratio of absorption peaks for hemoglobin (410 mnl a.<d bilirubin (460 nm) at consecutive periods of irradiation under various fluorescent lamps demonstrates the rates and degree of bilirubin decomposition.

interpret than for the artificial bilirubin-albumin system. It was possible, however, to indicate the photodecomposition of bilirubin by determining the change in ratio of absorption peaks for hemoglobin (410 nm) ami bilirubin (460 nm) as shown in Figure 4.

It could not be determined that the hemoglobin was unaffected by irradiation over this period of time (240 minutes), but any alteration was masked by that of the 460 nm peak, and in any event was of minor degree.

This illustration offers a representation of the photodecomposition of bilirubin in hemolytic serum irradiated for 60, 120, and 240 minutes. No alteration of bilirubin could be observed under red and yellow lamps at any time during these four hours.

After 60 minutes of exposure some change under blue and daylight was determined, and a marked change under the special blue light.

After 120 minutes bilirubin decomposition had occurred under the green lamp as well, and equal to that under the daylight fluorescent.

Photodecomposition had substantially progressed after 240 minutes. This was particularly apparent from the increasing color change of the serum samples which had initially been a reddish-yellow and now were a muddy greenish-brown. In this experiment too the effect of light on bilirubin was most significant in the samples exposed to the special blue light with its very narrow range of emission essentially between 420 and 475 nm.

Breakdown Products

There is disagreement among investigators as to the identity of the products' of bilirubin photodecomposition. Because of the difficulty of studying the metabolism of this pigment in the newborn infant, recourse has been made to the Gunn rat, and to artificial serum-bilirubin solutions. The results of these studies are hard to transpose to the infant despite the sophistication of technics since different conditions obtain in the human.

Some investigators3’5 have reported the appearance of biliverdin following irradiation. We have encountered a greenish-brown pigment upon exposure of bilirubin solutions in vitro. However, we have observed absorption peaks at 375 and 650 nm, characteristic of biliverdin, only in artificial solvent systems, not in adult or infant plasma and serum from hyperbilirubinemic patients. By extraction methods and thin layer chromatography several pigments have been demonstrated, some of them evanescent in nature, but none having the solubility or spectral features of biliverdin.

The development of absorption peaks at 360, 410415 (in the absence of heme pigments), 490, and 560 nanometers has been intriguing but beyond our capacity to further identify. These various peaks do not all appear in a single solvent system, but the appearance of the bilirubin solutions, depends upon the make up, and upon pH. Some appear to be of a transient character. At this time we have some doubt that biliverdin is formed in the infant from the photodecomposition of bilirubin, but believe rather that a series of breakdown products is formed with differing rates of formation and decay: their synthesis and degradation under continued irradiation of the infant may overlap, to further obscure this already highly complex process.

Conclusion

We have concluded that the photodecomposition of bilirubin is dependent, among others, on two major factors; its action spectrum and the spectral radiant intensity of the light source used. It is known that the shorter the wavelength of emitted light the greater the kinetic energy of the photons reaching the irradiated object. Ultraviolet light will effectively decompose bilirubin in vitro. Its use in phototherapy is not recommended, however, because of the danger of injury to tissues, especially at wavelengths 330 nm and below.

Our studies have led us to conclude that blue light, with a maximum output between 420 and 460 nanometers, is the most efficient practical fluorescent light source for phototherapy, and that if rapidity of response is an important consideration in the treatment of jaundice of the newborn an adequate energy output from the light source of at least 90 xrw/cm2 in that spectral interval should be used. These recommendations do not necessarily hold for the prophylactic irradiation of the newborn who has not developed hyperbilirubinemia before the institution of phototherapy.

One cannot yet say what is the minimal amount of light energy effective in the treatment of neonatal jaundice, nor indeed is the optimal amount known precisely. However, if light is to be used as a form of therapy it may logically be managed as would be a drug or chemical compound for a specific therapeutic purpose, which it should achieve in the safest yet most expeditious manner. The prevention of kemic-terus will not permit of half measures, especially in the immature neonate wherein brain damage may occur at relatively low serum bilirubin concentrations. Therefore, the proper type of light which will decompose bilirubin in the shortest period of time with safety, would be the optimum.

The term “footcandle" as a unit of measure of light intensity in phototherapy should be discarded. Footcandles and lumens are units of measure of illumination from any light source, in reference to the photoreceptivity of the retina. A more precise unit of measurement is microwatts per square centimeter per nanometer (pw/cm’/ntii), which is an expression of the light energy reaching the object of irradiation at each wavelength emitted by the particular source of light. This measurement, does not assume an action spectrum which the other visible units of measurement do, making them inapplicable for even quaiita five determinations of such radically different action spectra as the photodecomposition of bilirubin.

Though the method to determine the action spectrum of bilirubin reported here is crude, it offer jonfirmation of the original supposition that, light • >f reasonably specific wavelength is necessary for the effective photodegradation of bilirubin. These data also indicate that the energy output of the light source at these specific wavelengths has an important influence on the efficiency of this form of therapy.

Editor’s note: nm = mg D. B.

. REFEFIEMCES

  • 1, Sisson, T. R. C.; Kendall, N.; Davies, R. and Berger, D_: Photobiologic aspects of hyperbilirubinemia. Trans. Amer, pediat. Soc., Atlantic City, N. J., 1969.

  • 2, Lucey, J.; Ferriero, M. and Hewitt, J.: Prevention of hyperbilirubinemia of prematurity by phototherapy. Pediatrics 41:1047-1054, 1968.               '

  • 3, Broughton, P. M. G.; Rossiter, E. J.; Warren, C. B. and Goulis, G.: Effect of blue light on hyperbilirubinemia. Arch. Dis. Childh. 40:666, 1965.

  • 4. Blondheim, S. H.; Lathrop, D. and Zibiniskie, J.: Effect of light on absorption spectrum of jaundiced serum. J. Lab. din.

' Med. 60:31, 1962.

  • 5. Ostrow, J. D.: Mechanism of the phototherapy of jaundice. Trans. Soc. pediat Research, Atlantic City, 1969,

(Doscussion ■

GERALD ODELL asked about the susceptibility of the protein-bound bilirubin to photodecay and why salicylate is far more effective than Gantrisin in isolating bilirubin away from human albumin. The question can be raised as' to whether part of the Gantrisin molecule is transmitting the photoenergy to the bilirubin. OSTROW replied that by adding the bilirubin onto the albumin, there is apparently ah acceleration of decay and suggests that albumin itself is involved in the oxidative process. It may be □ne of the things that is taking the hydrogens out, or at least, the oxidizing agent. GERALD ODELL then said that when he stored jaundiced serum for six months in the refrigerator, the van den Bergh reaction would be the same, but the spectral curve with the sharp peak at 460 becomes flat or dull. He assumed that it was denatured albumin that made the difference, OSTROW re plied that in the dark, albumin always stabilizes bilirubin, while this is not always true in the light, suggesting that albumin is photoactivated. The lack of change in the diazo reaction suggests that these are clearly bilirubin derivatives and not chloroform related.

PETER BROUGHTON asked whether he had followed the decay in the serum of a jaundiced patient. OSTROW said that Blondheim had published such curves. He felt the differences in the green color may be due to rates and not qualitative. For instance, the pattern would change if you altered the proportion of methanol to chloroform.

AUDREY BROWN asked if there is any data that would suggest that the human infant is putting out such alternate products normally in bile. Both OSTROW and ROGER LESTER had never performed chromatography on normal bile.

IVAN DIAMOND asked if photodecay of bilirubin includes the biliverdin step. OSTROW replied that in albumin, the green color remains for a long time, while in alkali it is very transient. KRASNER said that he could not identify biliverdin in a nondynamic system. OSTROW said that he had isolated biliverdin in the jaundiced serum of an infant after exposure to light.

COLEMAN WHITLOCK asked if these colorless products formed by photoactivity were urobilin or urobilinogen. RUDI SCHMID said that all of these compounds are bacterial reduction products and are not related to phototherapy.

ROGER LESTER explained how botanists used the evolution of oxygen by plants as an indication of the forms of light used. He felt it was important to think of bilirubin and its spectrum in terms of its sitting in an aqueous solution and when bound to protein. Bilirubin usually has two peaks of maximal absorption— one at 450 to 460 my and the other at 315 mp. LEONORE BALLOWITZ emphasized that if you use continuous light on a plant, it will destroy the photoreceptors and the plant will fail to grow. However, if you use intermittent therapy, such as night and day, it will grow satisfactorily.

DONALD SILBERBERG asked what was known about retinal damage from light. SISSON replied that he had recently done an experiment wherein the two eyes of one piglet were accidentally exposed to light for slightly less than 12 hours and the retinas were badly damaged. The piglet became blind. Electron microscopic examination revealed that the discs of the photoreceptor rods were edematous and distorted; disintegration and vacuolization had occurred, demonstrating irreversible damage to the outer retinal layers (visual cells—rods in particular) of newborn piglets six weeks after 12, 24, 48 and 72 hours of exposure to the same phototherapy lamps used in his study of jaundiced infants. MICHAEL THALER quoted Wurtman as saying that the light receptors have a fantastic sensitivity, something in the order of 10 ’. Using the best patching available, we can only reduce that to 10 ‘. Thus, current patching technics do not approach the sensitivity of the receptors. Furthermore, in the premature, the macula is a developing organ, which makes it more sensitive to damage. SISSON measured the light transmission through the eyelid of a stillborn infant and found that 2 to 3'< of light from a monochromator reached through the eyelid to the photocell. The usual type of patch also lets through about 3L of incidental light. DONALD <SILBERBERG commented that the corneal sensitivity of young infants is very low and one must be careful not to keep an eye open as it is patched.

Relationship of phototherapy and skin color — Reply

Eohnne 77

Number 6


Leite).1: to the Editor 1 0 9!)

Reply

To the Editor:

In a recent symposium, Sisson and co-workers1 reported that the decrease of serum bilirubin concentration was slower when fluorescent lamps of broad spectrum distribution such as “daylight” and “Vitalitc” arc used in place of blue lamps in which the spectral distribution was more monochromatic. At 440 nm., the daylight type of lamp had but 55 per cent, and the vitalitc had but 35 per cent of the energy of the blue light. At 460 nm., the daylight lamp had approximately 65 per cent, and the vitalitc had about 45 per cent of the energy of the blue light.

In comparing our data with those of Dr. Entc, it becomes apparent that while there is no difference in the peak serum bilirubin levels between Negro and Caucasian premature infants when both are exposed to blue light turned on 75 per cent of the time, a difference begins to emerge when one reduces both the duration of exposure to 25 per cent of the time and the intensity of the light at 440 to 460 nm. to about 50 per cent through the use of daylight or vitalitc lamps instead of blue lamps.

This emphasizes the importance of using adequate phototherapy, particularly in infants with dark skin pigment, and might help explain why this form of treatment has met with success1-3 and failure1 among some Negro infants.

Sergio O. Potto. ALT).

Rosita 8. Tildes, AU). Harold Goodman, AU). Department of Pediatries Loyola University Stritch School of Afedicine Cook County Hospital Grant Hospital Aiaywood and Chicago, III.

1100 Letters to the Editor


The Journal of Pediatries December 1970

REFERENCES

  • 1. Sisson, T., and Kendall, N.: Factors influencing the effectiveness of phototherapy in neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, in Hsia, 1). Y. 5.. editor: Bilirubin metabolism in the newborn, National Foundation-Birth Defects Original Article Series, 1970.

  • 2. - Porto, S. O., Pildes, R. S.. and Goodman, IE: Studies on the effect of phototherapy on neonatal hyperbilirubinemia among low-birthweight infants. 1. Skin color. II. Protein binding capacity, J. Pkdiat. 75: 101-5, 1969.

  • 3. Hodgeman, J. E., and Schwartz, A.: Phototherapy and hyperbilirubinema of the. premature, Amer. J. Dis. Child. 119: 473, 1970.

  • 4. Patel, D. A.. Pildes, R. S., and Behrman, R. E.: Failure of phototherapy to reduce serum bilirubin in newborn infants, J. Pediat. In press.

    IO94


    THE LANCET


    24 MA.Y 1958


(t *                                                                      -                ■

INFLUENCE OF LIGHT ON THE

HYPERBILIRUBINIEMIA OF INFANTS

R. J. Cremer*         P. W. Perryman

M.B. Lend., D.C.H.             M.Sc. Lend.

PEDIATRIC REGISTRAR              BIOCHEMIST

D. H. Richards F.I.M.L.T.

■ CHIEF TECHNICIAN, BIOCHEMISTRY DEPARTMENT

GENERAL HOSPITAL, ROCHFORD, ESSEX

In the first two weeks of life a raised serum-bilirubin level from any cause may lead to kemicterus. In those who have died, necropsy has shown staining by bilirubin of certain cells in the central nervous system, principally in the basal ganglia. The mechanism of this change is' unknown, but there is evidence that it may be caused by an inhibitory action of excessive bilirubin on essential cellular respiratory activity.

Day (1954) showed that oxygen uptake of rat brain 11 significantly reduced in the presence of bilirubin 20 mg. per 100 ml., but that no such inhibition is found with biliverdin Zetterstrdm and Emster (1956), working with liver mitochondria, showed that bilirubin at a concentration of 20 mg. or more per 100 nil. exerts a powerful uncoupling effect on oxidative phosphorylation. Lathe and Walker (1957) show that the livers of the newborn cannot conjugate bilirubin, which is unexcretable, to the glucuronides of bilirubin, which are excretable—the necessary enzymes being absent or deficient

♦ Present address: Hillingdon Hospital, Middlesex.

WAVELENGTH (myu.)

Fig. 1—Effect of light on absorption curve of icteric «crun>.


Note effect of SUNSHINE as indicated in Figure 5-

Mollison and Cutbush (19 5 1) showed that the incidence of signs of kernicterus increases as the concentration of serum-bill-rubin rises above 20 mg. per 100 ml., and that below this figure ill effects are rare. ' The prevention of a high .level of ' serum-bili-. rubin, or the ‘ destruction of this substance, or its removal from

Fig. 2—Effect of light on icteric serum.


the blood-stream, will prevent kernicterus.


This has hitherto been achieved by replacement transfusion. Where experienced staff and good laboratory facilities exist, results are highly satisfactory (Norman 1957). However, such facilities are not universal, and an alternative approach seems desirable.

Effect of Light on Serum-bilirubin

During serial estimations of the serum-bilirubin in jaundiced infants we noticed that their serum-bilirubin is highly photosensitive in vitro (Cremer, Perryman,' Richards, and Holbrook 1957). We have studied this sensitivity and tried to apply it therapeutically.

Fl®. 3—-Effect of sunlight on serum-bilirubin.


When icteric serum of infants is illuminated by white light, and the temperature is kept constant at 20°C, the characteristic 420 mp absorption peak decreases and the absorption at the red end of the spectrum, around 550-650 mp, increases a little (fig. 1). At the same time the measured serum-bilirubin level is reduced and electromotive force(E.M.F.) measurements show a positive increase in the oxidation/reduction (redox) potential of the system (fig. 2). This indicates that, under the action of light, bilirubin undergoes photo-oxidation or dehydrogenation to biliverdin or some intermediate products. These substances are more polar, and therefore probably more easily excrctable, ihan is bilirubin.

Bilirubin (van den Bergh indirect pigment), the type of pigment greatly predominating in icteric infants, is some two or three times as photosensitive as is conjugated bilirubin (van den Bergh direct pigment) (fig. 3).

These findings emphasise the need for special precaution in laboratories doing routine bilirubin estimations on jaundiced infants. We now make a practice of enclosing all our blood-specimen tubes in light-tight containers if immediate analysis is not feasible. We have found that specimens left in bright daylight may lose as much as 30% of their serum-bilirubin in an hour.

Fig. 4 shows the distribution of the photosensitivity effect over the visible spectrum.

Clinical Applications

The subjects chosen for this study were all infants in the premature babies unit of the hospital. The sister in charge of the unit had earlier reported the apparent fading away of the yellow pigmentation in the skin of jaundiced babies when they had been a short time in sunlight. It was decided, therefore, to expose jaundiced infants to sunlight and assess the results quantitatively by serial determinations of serum-bilirubin.

WAVELENGTH (m^) OF ILLUMINATION USED

Fig. 4—Spectral distribution of the photo destruction of serum-bilirubin.


Before the exposure the general trend of the serum-bilirubin level was established by the micro-method devised for this purpose (Perryman, Richards, and Holbrook 1957). To avoid overheating or excessive ultraviolet radiation, the babies were placed naked in direct sunlight for fifteen to twenty minutes (according to the sun’s intensity) and then withdrawn for similar periods before again being exposed to the sunlight. During the exposure the infants’ eyes were protected by a simple plastic shield.

Jaundice quickly disappeared from the exposed areas of skin but persisted in areas which remained in the shade.

Fig. 5—Sunshine treatment of an Icteric infant with jaundice of prematurity (case 6).



TABLE I—EPTECT OF SUNLIGHT ON ICTERIC INFANTS

i


After this intermittent sunlight treatment, bilirubin levels were again measured.

Fig. 5 shows a typical result of this treatment. Table i records the initial level and drop in serum-bilirubin in 13 premature infants with twenty test exposures. These had the so-called “ physiological jaundice ” of prematurity, and in all (except case 13, where there was a rise) there was a definite drop in serum-bilirubin during the exposure. In general, we found that the higher the initial serum-bilirubin level and the longer the exposuretime, the greater the fall in serum-bilirubin.

In view of these results, we sought a source of artificial light instead of sunshine. Guided by our work on the spectral distribution of the photosensitivity (fig. 4), we examined various light sources. Finally the apparatus illustrated in fig. 6 was devised.

This consists of a hemicylindrical stainless-steel reflector suspended on a movable gantry and adjustable for height. Eight 24 in. light blue fluorescent 40-watt discharge tubes (G.E.C.), at 2 in. separation, are arranged around the curve of the reflector. The equipment is so made that a cot may be wheeled beneath the lights, and switch-gear provides that the illumination can be cut if less than the fill! power is desired. This equipment gives light of very high intensity in the region of 420-480 mp. without any dangerous ultraviolet or X-ray components. The height

Fig. 7—Effect of artificial-light treatmen?: 023 cj Jaundiced premature Infant (cbgo 16),


of the lamp from the infant is adjusted to make use of the small amount of radiant heat emitted for keeping the infant's body-temperature at 98-100°F.

Fig. 7 shows the effect of this source of artificial light on an icteric premature infant; the coincidence of the drop in serum-bilirubin with the period of illumination is noteworthy.

Table ii summarises the results of twelve light* exposure tests in 9 jaundiced premature infants. These all show small but significant drops in serum-bilirubin. At first continuous illumination was used, but in the light of experience a routine of six hours in the lights followed by two hours out seems to give better results. 2 infants with severe jaundice due to Rh incompatibility are not included in table 11. These failed to respond to the light treatment and exchange transfusion was necessary.

TABLE II—EFFECT OF ARTIFICIAL LIGHT ON ICTERIC INFANTS

Discussion

Our results so far are insufficient for a complex statistical appraisal, but they encourage further work. From our biochemical studies, it has become clear that a complex series of chemical changes is involved.

Under the action of light, ’bilirubin seems to be dehydrogenated, and the role of hydrogen acceptors and photocatalysts is being investigated. Several compounds accelerate the photodestruction of serum-bilirubin in vitro—e.g-methylene-blue at a concentration of 10 p.g. per ml. of serum, similarly toluidine-blue and cresyl-blue, though they art less effective, and riboflavine. We suggest that the difference in degree of response to light treatment between one jaundiced infant and another and also the complete failure of some to respond may be related to lack of essential hydrogen acceptor!


24 MAY 1958           1097


ORIGINAL ARTICLES


or other factors in the circulating plasma. We have found that in the first few days of life cceruioplasmin is absent from the blood-semm, which may have a bearing on this problem.

No prospect can be entertained that this light treatment will prove a substitute for exchange transfusion in the erythroblastotic infant with active haemolysis, but the method may be turned to clinical advantage in controlling the level of serum-bilirubin in cases of jaundice of prematurity.

Summary

In some cases of neonatal jaundice the serum-bilirubin level is reduced by sunlight or by suitable artificial-light treatment.

We should like to thank Dr. R. H. Dobbs, consultant paediatrician to this group, for his interest and encouragement, and Prof. G. H. Lathe, of Leeds. We are indebted to the group engineering department of the Southend Hospitals for the design and manufacture of the cradle illumination machine.

Experience and Kelson

Briefly Recorded

“In Medicine one must pay attention not to plausible theorizing but to experience and reason together. ... I agree that theorizing is to be approved, provided that it is based on facts, and systematically makes its deductions from what is observed. . . . But conclusions drawn from unaided reason can hardly be serviceable; only those drawn from observed fact.” Hippocrates:

I Precepts.

a o o

(Short communications of factual material are ptibli'hed here. Comments and criticisms appear ' as Letters to the Editor.)

Natural Variations in Environmental Illumination in a Newborn Nursery

Phototherapy as a means of reducing hyperbilirubinemia was first reported in 19-5S bv Cremer, et al.1 Numerous studies since then have demonstrated the effectiveness of its use.2

Tentative guidelines on the use of phototherapy have been formulated from data presented at a symposium on bilirubin metabolism in the newborn.3 These suggest that 200 to 400 footcandles of the spectrum of wavelengths between 300 and 600 nm will be effective in reducing the serum bilirubin and recommend the use of equipment designed to deliver this intensity of illumination.

The possibility that environmental lighting conditions might effect neonatal bilirubin levels has been raised by Giunta and Rath4 who demonstrated that a modest increase in environmental lighting intensity (to 90 footcandles) had a statistically significant effect in reducing the hyperbilirubinemia of prematurity. Thus the intensity and duration of illumination present in any nursery might play a significant role in explaining both the considerable variatioQjn the incidence of hyperbilirubinemia from pne_ nursery to another5 as well as the reported__se_a-sonal variation in neonatal bilibubin levels.0

During the course of a study to evaluate the use of phototherapy in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit of The Montreal Children’s Hospital, we collected data on the natural variation in environmental lighting intensity depending on the amount of available sunlight, time of day, and the location of the infant within the nursery. These data are presented as an index of the variations in natural illumination which probably occur in any nursery irrespective of whatever artificial lighting is employed.

Methods

During a 1-month period (October) measurements of the intensity of illumination were

window              window

24'----,4

Illumination in foot candles

Measured 36" from the floor using

GE-213 light meter


Fro. 1. Plan of nursery room: Neon;> al Intensive Care Unit. The outside windows are located in positions A and C. Measurements of light intensity are made at a distance of 36" from tire floor. Overhead lights are located in squares A, C, G, and H.

made at specific locations within the nursery. The physical layout of the nursery including the total area and the orientation of windows is shown in Figure 1. The nursery is supplied with four 250 watt incandescent overhead lights. The infants are nursed, usually nude, in Air Shields Isolettes with servo activated environmental temperature regulators. OCT 24 2 pm

Fig. 5. Plan and methodology as for Fig. 1: Values obtained in the early afternoon but with moderate overcast conditions. Values should be compared to those in Figure 4, as a comparison between sunny and overcast conditions.

read the intensity of the incident light directly in footcandles, was used. 1 he measurements were made at the level of the infants mattress, (36 in. from the floor) with the lights on and the window blinds open.

Results

The measurements of available environmental light under different outside conditions are shown in Figures 2 to 6. From these it can be seen that the amount of illumination received by any infant varied from 15 to 2,500 footcandles depending upon his or her location in the nursery, the time of day, and the amount of sunlight present.

Discussion

Lucey and others have suggested that increases of illumination in nurseries to 100-200 footcandles, coupled with a liberal policy of exposure of unclothed infants to this light, is a safe and effective method of preventing the hyperbilirubinemia of prematurity.3 The data of Giunta and Rath demonstrated that infants exposed to environmental lighting averaging only 90 footcandles had significantly lower serum bilirubin levels than control infants exposed to environmental lighting averaging 10 footcandles.4 The data presented here suggests that ex-

EXPERIENCE AND REASON-BRIE FLY RECORDED        133

SUNDOWN

OCT 27 5:30 pm

Fig. 6. Plan and methodology as for Fig. 1: Values obtained after sundown showing a baseline illumination provided by the overhead lighting.

posure to natural sunlight yields far greater illumination levels than either of the two groups have judged as effective in controlling hyperbilirubinemia. Moreover, within our nursery the position of the baby in relationship to the source of external light appears to play a major role in determining the amount of such illumination received. Such differences as the total area and orientation of the windows coupled with variations in the local practice of nursing the infant minimally clothed allow for wide fluctuations in effective light exposure.

Summary

Measurements of the natural variation in environmental lighting depending on the amount of sunlight, visibility, the time of day, and the location of the infant within the nursery have shown a wide variation in intensity of illumination received by any infant ranging from 15 to 2,500 footcandles depending on the interplay of these factors. Both the physical structure of the nursery and the amount of sunlight available are major variables in determining the ultimate amount of light to which an infant is ex-posed. Both of these factors need to be. taken into consideration in the architectural design of nurseries and the assignation of optimal illumination standards.

Patrick MacLeod, M.D. Pediatric Medicine

Leo Stern, M.D.

Newborn Medicine

McGill University

Montreal Children’s Hospital 2300 Tupper Street

Montreal 108, Quebec, Canada

Supported iii part by Grant MT-3037 from the Medical Research Council of Canada.

Dr. Stern is a Queen Elizabeth II Scientist for research in Diseases of Children.

We arc grateful to the nurses in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit of the Montreal Children’s Hospital for their unfailing help and coopeiation in these studies. We also with to express our thanks to Mr. Samir A. Totki.i, Region.d Engine- r of the Lamp Division, Canadian General Electric Co. Ltd., Montreal, for his kind donation of the light meter used throughout this study. Finally, we wish to thank the McGill Observatory for its cooperation in accumulating the weather information.

i 04 8 Brief clinical and laboratory observations

The Journal of Pediatrics December 1969


Studies on the effect of phototherapy on neonatal hyperbilirubinemia among lowhrirth-weight infants, II. Protein binding capacity

Sergio O. Porto, M.D.,*

Rosita S. Pildes, M.D., and

Harold Goodman, M.D.

CHICAGO, ILL.

One of the unresolved questions of phototherapy in the clinical management of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia is the binding of the photooxidative derivatives of albumin. Theoretically, if these derivatives were to bind with albumin, they could compete with bilirubin for binding sites in much the same way as do salicylates and sulfonamides and increase the likelihood of kernicterus developing.1

■ Previously, using 2-(4-hydroxybenzeneazo) benzoic acid (HABA) as a means of measuring dye binding capacity, Lucey and coworkers2 reported that the sera of light-treated babies who had low serum concentrations of bilirubin had the same binding capacity as the sera of control babies who had high serum concentrations of bilirubin. On the other hand, using the same HABA binding method, Sisson and co-workers3 have shown that phototherapy causes an increase

From the Department of Pediatrics, Loyola University—Stritch School of Medicine and the Loyola University Hospital; the Department of Pediatrics, University of Illinois School of Medicine and the Cook County Hospital; and Grant Hospital.

This investigation was partially supported by grants from the Illinois Menial Health Fund and the National Institutes of Health.

^Fellow, Ely Lilly Company, Indianapolis, Ind. in albumin binding capacity when there is a decrease in the serum concentrations of bilirubin.

Recently Odell and co-workers* have developed an albumin saturation index based upon the amount of bilirubin displaced from albumin after the addition of sodium salicylate. The present paper describes a controlled study employing this technique on the sera of low-birth-weight infants who received phototherapy with blue fluorescent light.

MATERIALS AND METHODS

Studies were carried out on the 29 Negro infants described in the preceding paper/ Blood samples were collected by heel punctures daily while the lights were turned off. The saturation of albumin with bilirubin was determined according to the micromethod of Odell and co-workers? For these studies, 20 /u.1 of separated serum was pipetted into 2 cuvettes containing exactly 1.0 ml. of 0.1M phosphate, pH 7.37. The maximum absorption of each sample of serum was located between 460 and 465 mp, and the spectrophotometer was set at this wavelength. To the control cuvette, 50 pl of 25 mM. sodium salicylate was added. The cuvette samples were mixed by inversion and replaced in the spectrophotometer and read. The differences in optical density between the cuvettes was again measured.

The saturation index (S.I.) is calculated by the following formula:

AO.D. 460 nap

bO.D. 460 mp

■x 100 — S.I. (% O.D. 460 nap)


where AO.D. 460 mp represents the absolute difference between the measurement of the control cuvette and that of the cuvette to which salicylate was added, and bO.D. 460 mp is the optical density of the control cuvette after excluding the optical density at 460 mp caused by nonbilirubin chromogen.

RESULTS

As shown in Fig. 1, there was great similarity in the patterns of the saturation index and the serum bilirubin concentrations of

Brief clinical and laboratory observations 10 4 9

Volume 75

Number 6, part 1

Fig- 1- Saturation index of serum albumin with bilirubin in Negro infants treated (study group) and not treated (control group) with phototherapy. All values expressed as mean ± standard error.                 '                                             ,


the two groups. In the control group, there was an increase of the saturation index corresponding to the increased concentration of serum bilirubin, and a fall of the saturation index corresponding to the decreased concentration of serum bilirubin. In the study group, there was no significant change in the saturation index and no change in the serum concentration of bilirubin until Day 6, when there was a rebound in both the saturation index and the serum bilirubin value. As with the serum bilirubin concentrations, the saturation index was significantly lower in the study group, as compared with the values in the control infants on Day 3 (p < 0.05), Day 4 (p < 0.01), and Day 5 (p < 0.001).

Furthermore, the correlation coefficient between the saturation index and the ratio of the concentrations of the serum bilirubin expressed in milligrams per 100 ml. and the total protein in grams per 100 ml. was r = +0.604 (p < 0.01). '

SUMMARY

These data indicate that the photooxidative derivatives of bilirubin are not bound to albumin, or at least, show less affinity to albumin than either bilirubin or salicylate. These observations add to the growing body of data that these products of phototherapy are probably nontoxic and harmless.8

REFERENCES

  • 1. Odell, G. B.: The distribution of bilirubin between albumin and mitochondria, • J. Pediat. 68: 164, 1966.                        '

  • 2. Lucey, J., Ferreiro, M., and Hewitt, J.: Prevention of hyperbilirubinemia of prematurity by phototherapy, Pediatrics 41: 1047, 1968.

  • 3. Sisson, T. R. C., Kendall, N., Davies, R., Berger, D., Bunyaviroch, E., and Knutson, S.: Photobiologic aspects of hyperbilirubinemia,

American Pediatric Society-79th Annual Meeting, Atlantic City, 1969, p. 19.

  • 4. Odell, G. B., Cohen, S. N., and Kelly, P. C.: Studies in kemicterus. II. The determination of the saturation of serum albumin with bilirubin, J. Pediat. 74: 214, 1969.

October, 1970

The Journal 0/ PEDIATRICS 6 13

Effects of photodegradation products of bilirubin on myelinating cerebellum cultures

Cultures of myelinating cerebellum, were exposed to media containing bilirubin and human serum albumin and to identical media in which the bilirubin had been partially degraded by light. Starting concentrations of bilirubin were 30 mg. per cent. Cultures exposed to irradiated media in which the remaining diazotizable bilirubin was below 14 mg. per cent (representing a bilirubin to human albumin ratio of approximately 0.8:1) did not damage the cultures. Unirradiated media produced characteristic and severe damage.

Donald H. Silberberg, M.D., Lois Johnson, M.D., Henry Schutts, M.D., and Linda Ritter, B.A.

PHILADELPHIA, PA.

Since the introduction of phototherapy for the treatment of neonatal jaundice in 1958,3 a question has persisted regarding the potential neurotoxicity of the photodegradation products of bilirubin.

Evidence exists that bilirubin is converted transiently into biliverdin and then into a variety of smaller molecules which are principally dipyrroles.4 There is conflicting evidence regarding the toxicity of the breakdown products in various experimental

i

■ From the University of Pennsylvania School ' of Medicine.

Supported in part by United States Public (, Health Service Grants Nos. NB-08197-01,

NB-08075-02 (Dr. Silberberg), 5R01 NBO-6919 (Dr. Johnson), and ROi NB-HD-06899 (Dr. Schutta).

Part of this work has been presented at

2lst Annual Meeting American Academy of

Neurology, April 25, 1969, Washington, D. C.,1 and at a Symposium on Bilirubin Metabolism in the Newborn, June 6, 1969, Chicago, HLB systems. Broughton and associates5 found that a solution of bilirubin which bad been exposed to light for 32 hours had no effect on the oxidative phosphorylation of suspensions of brain or liver mitochondria. However, Hakami and associates® described inhibition of mitochondrial NADH-oxidase by the early photodecomposition products, which they presumed were largely biliverdin. Biliverdin has proved to be nontoxic to myelinating cerebellum, cultures in our previous studies.7 In this study we have exposed myelinating cerebellum cultures to media containing light-irradiated bilirubin and its photodecoinposition products in order to study the possible neurotoxicity of the breakdown products.

In previous experiments we have seen that bilirubin produces characteristic morphologic changes in the large neurons of these tissue cultures. At the ultrastructural level we have

Vol. 77, No. 4, pp. 613-618

6 14 Silberberg et al.

The Journal of Pediatrics October 1970


seen complex, electron-dense, intracytoplas-mic whorls and enlargement of mitochondria. Neuronal and glial swelling, accompanied by myelin degeneration, start within about 4 hours of exposure to toxic, concentrations of bilirubin. Swelling of the cell proceeds to vacuolization and eventual complete disruption within 24 hours in severely damaged cultures, and all visible myelin disappears.7

MATERIALS AND METHODS

Culture technique. Fragments of newborn rat cerebellum were explained onto collagen-coated cover slips and maintained in the Maximow double-cover slip assembly as previously described.7 Cultures were fed twice a week with a medium consisting of 25 per cent fetal calf serum, 75 per cent Earle's balanced salt solution with glucose added to a concentration of 600 mg. per cent, and zinc-free insulin added to a concentration of 0.2 units per milliliter. Under these conditions, 95 per cent of cultures myelinate starting about the tenth day in vitro.

Experimental media. We have incorporated bilirubin into medium in which adult human serum has been substituted for fetal calf serum so that the final albumin concentration in the medium is 2.0 Gm. per 100 ml. Phosphate-buffered saline was used to facilitate pH control.8 A bilirubin level of 30 mg. per 100 ml. was used. The medium was then exposed to two 15 watt blue fluorescent bulbs, used less than 200 hours, at a distance of four inches. Bilirubin was measured by a standard diazo method.9 Media containing identical amounts of bilirubin were kept in the dark at the same temperature as the experimental media for the same periods of time. In addition, media not containing bilirubin were exposed to the blue light for the same periods of time. Well-myelinated cultures 14 to 17 days in vitro which had been obtained from littermate newborn rats were exposed to these media and observed for 24 hours. Fifty-one cultures were exposed to unirradiated bilirubin media; 103 cultures were exposed to identical medium which was first irradiated with blue light for 3, 4, 6, or 24 hours; 61 cultures were exposed to medium not containing bilirubin which was irradiated for the same period of time (Table I). The pH of the media was controlled so that the pH remained low enough to assure toxicity in the presence of bilirubin in the unirradiated media.10”11

OBSERVATIONS

All cultures were observed by bright field microscopy before, during, and after specific experiments. Representative cultures were fixed in glutaraldehyde, embedded in Araldite, cut into one micron sections, and observed with Nomarski interference contrast optics (Zeiss). Using this technique to supplement routine bright field optics, we were able to detect by light microscopy the appearance of the characteristic intracytoplas-mic whorls which occur in large neurons in response to bilirubin damage. This technique was used to examine 17 cultures which had been exposed to irradiated bilirubin media for 24 hours. These cultures appeared undamaged when examined by bright field microscopy in the living state. Only cells which were definitely identifiable as neurons were counted, for a total of 511 neurons; 443 neurons in 17 cultures which had been exposed to irradiated but nonbilimbin-con-taining media were also examined (Table II).

RESULTS

Under our experimental conditions we found a relatively constant rate of decrease in the level of bilirubin in response to expo-

Table I. Culture exposures

Medium

No. of cultures

Unirradiated medium containing bilirubin

51

Irradiated medium containing bilirubin

103

Irradiated medium not containing bilirubin

61

215

Volume 77

Number 4 -


Effects of photodegradation products of bilirubin 615

sure to light (Fig. 1). The slope seemed relatively independent of the starting level of bilirubin and did not vary with a small change of pH.

Al! cultures exposed to medium containing unirradiated bilirubin at a concentration of 30 mg. per cent, at an average pH of 7.2 during the last 12 hours of a 24 hour exposure, showed the characteristic sequence of degenerative changes as described above (Fig. 2). Cultures exposed to media which were irradiated for 3, 4, 6, and 24 hours were completely protected (Figs. 3 and 4). When the diazo bilirubin was reduced to levels below 14 mg. per cent (resulting in a bilirubin: albumin ratio of approximately 0.8:1), no damage occurred despite the fact that the bilirubin breakdown products re

Incidence of abnormalities in cultures exposed to irradiated medium containing bilirubin, compared with cultures exposed to irradiated medium which did not contain bilirubin (Nomarski interference contrast observations). Eighteen cultures were prepared and analyzed from each group. One in the irradiated bilirubin group had many whorls, unlike the other 17 in its group, and hence it was discarded. We therefore also discarded the worst of the control cultures (see text).                                                                                                                                                      .

Fig. 1. Hours exposure to 30 watts blue fluorescent light at 4 inches; 50 per cent adult human serum, 50 per cent phosphate-buff ered saline, in Pyrex tubes.


6 16 Silberberg et al.

I he Journal of Pediatrics October 1370


Fig. 2. Cerebellum, culture 15 days in vitro exposed to unirradiated biiirubin 30 mg. per cent for 12 hours, showing myelin degeneration and neuronal swelling. (Unstained living culture. Bright field *600.)


Fig. 3. Cerebellum culture 14 days in vitro exposed 24 hours to medium originally containing bilirubin 30 mg. per cent, irradiated 6 hours with blue light, showing normal neurons. (Unstained living culture. Bright field *600.)


Fig. 4. Same as Fig. 3, showing normal myelinated axons.


mained in the medium. Exposure for less than three hours leaves the bilirubin level high enough to produce toxicity at the pH levels we used.11 Hence, we cannot determine the possible effects of the very earliest photodegradation products in this experimental system.

The Nomarski interference contrast observations of fixed cultures revealed that 3 per cent of neurons in cultures exposed to the irradiated bilirubin media developed intracy-toplasmic whorls, while 3 per cent of nonbilirubin control neurons developed identical lesions (Fig. 5) (Table II). The Nomarski method was used to further substantiate the observations made with bright

Volume 77

Number 4


Effects of photodegradation product's of bilirubin 617

Fig. 5. j4, Large neurons, cerebellum culture 16 days in vitro, normal control. (Glutaraldehyde fixation, Araldite embedding, 1 micron sections, Nomarski interference contrast [Zeiss]. x600.) B, Intracytoplasmic whorls in large neurons, 15 days in vitro exposed to unirradiated 30 mg. per cent bilirubin medium for 24 hours. (Nomarski interference contrast, x600.)


field microscopy of living cultures. This indicates the lack of toxicity of the bilirubin photodecomposition products in this system. It also shows that the whorls are not uniquely caused by bilirubin damage, but are a relatively nonspecific indicator of damage. Most cultures contain an area of necrosis within the center of the explant (central necrosis). This area has probably suffered from poor diffusion of oxygen or nutrients, and most of the abnormalities in control neurons occur within this area. The abnormalities noted as “other abnormalities” are chiefly the occurrence of intracellular lipid droplets, a frequent nonspecific finding.

As noted in Table II, one irradiated bilirubin culture was omitted from the results because it contained 47 neurons with whorls out of a total of 52 neurons. This was so out of keeping with the other 17 cultures exposed to light-irradiated bilirubin medium that it probably was deteriorating prior to the beginning of the experimental exposure. Accordingly, the worst of the control cultures was also omitted from its group of

JJL- -

FSB-43


6 18 Silberberg et al.

The Journal of Pediatrics October 1970


18; its 19 neurons included 11 with whorls.

Since only recognizable neurons were counted, we could not include the many smaller neurons which cannot be distinguished from large glial cells in these unstained cultures. However, we did count any cell containing an intracytoplasmic whorl, even if not an obvious neuron, and thus probably increased the apparent proportions of damaged cells. Conversely, if any neurons were sufficiently damaged to have lost their normal architecture but did not contain whorls, they would not have been counted. This was not probable, since the over-all condition of both experimental (irradiated) and control cultures was excellent as observed in the living state by bright field microscopy.

Since the experimental cultures were exposed to the photodegradation products of bilirubin as well as to the remaining intact bilirubin, it is appropriate to state that we could see no evidence of cytotoxicity of the photodegradation products in this experimental system. Both the experimental and control media contained 2.0 Gm. per 100 ml, (0.3 mM.) adult human albumin in whole serum, providing binding sites for both bilirubin and photodegradation products. While the culture model differs in many respects from the in vivo occurrence of kcrnicterus, we feel this can be used as additional evidence for the safety of phototherapy for the prevention of kemicterus.

SUMMARY

Cultures of myelinating cerebellum were exposed to media containing bilirubin and human serum albumin and to identical media in which the bilirubin had been partially degraded by light. Starting concentrations of bilirubin were 30 mg. per cent. Cultures exposed to irradiated media in which the remaining diazotizable bilirubin was below 14 mg. per cent (representing a bilirubin to human albumin ratio of approximately 0.8:1) did not damage the cultures. Unirradiate.d media produced characteristic and severe damage.

We appreciate the technical assistance of Mr. Dennis Martell, Mr. Tony Mignano, Miss Sandra Valenta, and Mr. Arthur Siegel, who developed and printed the photomicrographs.

Experience and Reason

Briefly Recorded

“In Medicine one must pay attention not to plausible theorizing but to experience and reason together, ... I agree that theorizing is to be approved, provided that it is based on facts, and systematically makes its deductions from what is observed. . . . But conclusions drawn from unaided reason can hardly be serviceable; only those drawn from observed fact.” Hippocrates: Precepts.                                                                                                ■

o o o

(Short communications of factual material are published here. Comments and criticisms appear as Letters to the Editor.)

The Question of diarrhea and Phototherapy

The effectiveness of phototherapy in reducing the serum bilirubin in neonatal jaundice has been well documented.1 A report2 of diarrhea appearing shortly after the institution of phototherapy has been published, and other authors have noted green loose stools in infants receiving light therapy.3-4 The lack of published data on this association prompted the present study.

Material and Methods

The charts of the 600 infants with a birth weight below 5 pounds (2,268 gm) born at Charity Hospital between February 1, 1970 and January 31, 1971 and admitted to the Newborn Intensive Care Unit were reviewed. ’ Two groups were defined. The phototherapy group consisted of infants who received a minimum of 24 hours of light therapy during the first 7 days of life. Figure 1 shows the distribution of the duration of phototherapy during the first week of life of the infants studied. With eyes shielded, infants in this group were placed under the lights continuously for 7 of every 8 hours. Those who received therapy on other schedules (i.e. longer intervals between treatments) were excluded, as were those who died before 7 days of age. The light treatment was provided with commercially available phototherapy units having eight 20 watt daylight fluorescent bulbs adjusted to the height of the incubator top (14 in.). The intensity of light at the level of the infant was approximately 800 footcandles. Jaundiced infants were given light therapy upon a physician’s order; however, no rigid criteria controlled tire initiation of phototherapy or the length of exposure.

The control group consisted of all infants who received no phototherapy at any time. Table I shows the characteristics of the phototherapy and control groups in regard to race and birth weight. Routinely, infants not requiring intravenous fluids were placed on the same formula according to a standardized schedule based on birth weight. For the purposes of this study, diarrhea was defined as the occurrence during the first 7 days of life of one or more stools described in tire nurses notes as “loose,” “liquid,” “semi-liquid,” “watery,” or “frothy.” Stools described solely as “green” were not included, nor was the etiology of the diarrhea considered. In the phototherapy group, diarrhea was recorded regardless of its temporal relationship to the therapy.

Duration of therapy (hours)

Fig. 1. Distribution of duration of phototherapy in infants with a birth weight below 5 pounds during the first week of life.

Pediatiucs, Vol. 49, No. 2, February 1972 279

280


DIARRHEA AND PHOTOTHERAPY

TABLE I

Characteristics of the Phototherapy and Control Groups

Data

1,857

Results

Table II shows the incidence of diarrhea in the phototherapy and control groups. Thirteen of the 76 infants receiving light therapy (17.1%) had at least one episode of diarrhea, as did 55 of the 371 in the control group (14.8%). The difference in the incidence of diarrhea in these two groups was not significant (X2 — 0.09).

Comment

Other authors have reported loose green stools in infants receiving phototherapy.3’4 The present study was concerned, not with the color, but only the consistency of stools. Green stools, unaccompanied by diarrhea, were not considered because of the possible confusion with meconium stools. The minimum of 24 hours of phototherapy for infants in the treatment group was chosen arbitrarily, since a lesser amount of exposure was felt to be insufficient for evaluation.

This study was made on a retro-prospective basis with the patients divided by treatment

TABLE II

Incidence of Diarrhea in Phototherapy and Control Groups

Croup

Number of Cases

Infants with Diarrhea

Percentage

Phototherapy

76

13

17.1%

Control

371

55

14.8%

and then the charts followed to determine the occurrence of the disease condition. The observations were made by experienced personnel— the nursing staff for many years have described in their notes infants* stools according to definite criteria. In addition, both groups were cared for in a single unit by the same personnel; therefore, the quality of care was similar. The data presented here do not support the hypothesis that there is a significant increase in the incidence of diarrhea among low birth weight infants receiving phototherapy. A carefully controlled prospective study would be useful for further evaluation of this question.

Summary

In a series of 600 infants with a birth weight below 5 pounds, the incidence of diarrhea among those receiving more than 24 hours of phototherapy was 17.1% (13/76), whereas the incidence in controls was 14.8% (55/371). This study fails to confirm a significantly increased incidence of diarrhea in low birth weight infants receiving phototherapy.

Juan L. Washington, M.D.

Newborn Intensive Care Unit Charity Hospital of Louisiana at New Orleans

Departments of Pediatrics Louisiana State University School of Medicine

THE LANCET, DECEMBER 5, 1970

EYE-SHIELD FOR USE IN PHOTOTHERAPY

Sir,—Phototherapy is increasingly being used for treatment of hyperbilirubinemia of the newborn, and there has been concern over the possibility of damage to the infant’s retina and macula. No commercial eye-shield is available.

Initially we used gauze pads folded in half and taped over the eyes. This method is time-consuming. Our practice is to uncover the eyes for a minimum of two hours in twenty-four, but, using the gauze pads, the less conscientious helpers tended to neglect this routine. Several infants had conjunctival discharge and inflammation; and others had skin irritation from constant changing of the tape. To overcome these problems we designed a simple eye-mask made of drawing paper (see accompanying figure). Two sizes were made—one for premature and the other for full-term infants. The tapes consist of strips of rubber band stapled to the paper. These make it easy to attach the mask with the correct tension.

The masks are lifted above the eyebrows while the infant

1155


Dimensions of mask.


is being fed, and there is no longer the temptation to leave them continuously in place. They have proved time-saving, and to date there have been no cases of conjunctivitis or eye infection. Ideally, an eye-shield for phototherapy should be contoured, and fitted with soft material on the inner surface; probably it should also allow some light to filter through. It is to be hoped that a manufacturer will produce such a mask.

Department of Pediatrics, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas 77025.

§1US. _Y asunaga

Luis Felemovicius

Arnold J. Rudolph.


DRUG AND THERAPEUTICS BULLETIN Vol, 8 No. ? March.2?f 1970 Published, fortnightly for doctors by Consumers’ Association

DRUGS AND LIGHT FOR THE PREVENTION AND TREATMENT OF

.                neo-natal jaundice ’       “ ■

•Tfie enzyme system for conjugating bilirubin is often deficient in neonates, especially the immature. Unconjugated bilirubin is not excreted well, and if the concentration in plasma exceeds about 20 mg/100 mlj unbound unconjugated bilirubin may pass the blood-brain barrier^ and cause permanent damage - kernicterus. The treatment of jaundiced infants is aimed at preventing this damage.

Exchange transfusion was originally developed for treating rhesus incompatibility and has been the main method for lowering plasma bilirubin in the jaundiced neonate. But exchange transfusion has a mortality of at least 1%_, $ and may need to be repeated frequently in the first week of life. Rec ently, two new approaches to the prevention of kernicterus have been introduced. One came from the finding that various drugs, particularly phenobarbitone, induce the synthesis of the liver enzyme which conjugates bilirubin. The other followed the discovery that illumination of icteric serum in vitro reduced the concentration of bilirubin in it, and this provided a rationale for exposing jaundiced infants to light.

DRUGS - Phenobarbitone, like alcohol, dicophane (DDT) and many other drugs, induces the synthesis of various drug-metabolising enzymes in liver microsomes, among them glucuronyl transferase,^ the enzyme which conjugates bilirubin. Neonates have little glucuronyl transferase. Moreover the inducing effect is greater in immature animals.5 As phenobarbitone crosses the placenta, its administration to the mother should induce glucuronyl transferase synthesis of the foetal liver, thus equipping the child to conjugate bilirubin at birth. This would enable the child to produce bilirubin glucuronide which is easily excreted, and which does not enter the brain. However in rats bilirubin itself induces glucuronyl transferase^ and it is therefore possible that in babies endogenous induction is already occurring once jaundice has developed. The high incidence of jaundice in premature babies may be partly due to protein deficiency which is known to impair enzyme induction- Early feeding of such babies reduces the incidence of excessive bilirubinaemia.

Phenobarbitone may also reduce jaundice by increasing bile flow$ $ and recently it has been shown to induce a protein which may take up bilirubin within liver cells.1/ This mechanism may be important, as the relative scarcity of binding sites in the neonate might be limiting bilirubin conjugation and so excretion.

EDITOR: Andrew Hcrxheimer, mb, London Hospital Med. Coll. ASSOCIATE EDITORS: Leslie H. Cape!, md, mrcp, London Chest Hospital; A. M. Connell, b sc, Md, MRCPt, Queen’s University. Belfast; F. B. Gibbcrd, mb, mrcp, Westminster Hospital, London. ADVISORY COUNCIL: J. A. Baker, b pharm, mps, Westminster Hospital, London; Prof. R. S. Illingworth, md, frcp, dph, dch, Univ. Sheffield; E. V. Kuenssberg, cbe, mb, ch b. Edinburgh; H. P. Lambert, md, frcp, St George's Hospital, London; Prof. D. R. Laurence, md, frcp, Univ. Coll. & U.C.H. Med. Sch., London; Prof. A. G. Macgregor, md, frcp, Univ. Aberdeen; J. D. N- Nabarro, md, frcp, London; Prof. Michael Shepherd, dm, mrcp. dpm, Inst, of Psychiatry, London; D. W. Vere, md, frcp. London Hospital                                                 2 5

  • 13. Yeung, C, Y. & Field, C.E. ibid. 1969, ii, 135.

  • 16. Brown, W.R. At Wong, H, B. Pediatrics 1965, 36, 745.

  • 17. Mountain, K. R. et aL Lancet 1970, i, 265.

  • 18. Davies, P.P. ibid., p.413,

  • 19. Wilson, J. T. ibid. 1969, ii, 2 14.

  • 20. Cremer, R. J. etal. ibid. 1956, i, 1094.

  • 21, Behrman, R. K Ac Hsia, D. Y. Y. J. Pediat. 1969, 75, 718.


.GAB-43                                   ....

Treatment of mothers with phenobarbitone (50 - 150 mg daily for 3 to 50 days before delivery) has consistently reduced plasma bilirubin concentrations in their infants, whether those with Rhesus or ABO-group incompatibility were excluded^® or included.Similar results have been obtained with intravenous infusions of ethanol for 3 to 96 hours before delivery.^ All these trials were adequately controlled, but it is not clear from any of them how much an infant at special risk is likely to benefit. A special study is still needed in mothers for whom early induction of labour is planned.

Treatment of Infants - Prophylactic treatment from birth has given unimpressive results both in normal and in underweight infants,^ 11 and certainly seems less effective than treating the mothers.

In infants with jaundice, phenobarbitone treatment has given inconsistent results. In a well controlled trial in Hong Kong Chinese infants with bilirubin levels between 10 and 20 mg/100 ml, the drug reduced the need for exchange transfusion for hyperbilirubinaemia from 45% to 4%.^ However in jaundiced Caucasian children with a bilirubin of less than 12 mg/100 ml, and without haemolytic disease, phenobarbitone did not seem to reduce bilirubin levels.14 15 The latter two trials must have included many babies in whom the jaundice was so mild as to require no treatment. The discrepancy might be due to differences in the types of jaundice treated, or to a racial difference.^

Unwanted effects attributable to phenobarbitone used to prevent or treat jaundice have not been reported in either mothers or children. Defective blood clotting,resembling that of vitamin K deficiency, has however been found in babies of mothers who were given anticonvulsants in pregnancy. Both phenobarbitone and phenytoin were involved. 1? Some theoretical risks which would not manifest themselves until later life have also been predicted.^ For example, brain damage might be caused by reduced steroid hormone levels in the body if steroid metabolism were increased. As the trials have reported effects only in the neonatal period, the development of the treated children should now be closely observed.

LIGHT - The exposure of jaundiced premature infants to daylight or artificial light (wavelength 420 - 48 0 nm) significantly reduced serum bilirubin concentration, particularly the unconjugated fraction, and also caused the yellow to fade in all but the shaded areas,20 This effect is trivial or does not occur in children born at full term, or with haemolytic jaundice or sepsis the mechanism remains unknown. Artificial light has been used either continually or intermittently up to the sixth day of life and its intensity has varied between 300 and 500 foot-candles. Other infants have been exposed to intermittent direct sunlight for up to two hours daily.The eyes were shaded and the body temperature monitored; with these precautions no unwanted effects have yet been noted.

CONCLUSION - Administration of phenobarbitone to mothers in the last weeks of pregnancy will reduce the plasma bilirubin of their newborn infants. The effects on bilirubin levels of giving the drug to babies is less clear and needs further study. Plasma bilirubin can also be reduced in premature children by exposing the child to sunlight or special artificial light. The two approaches are therefore to an extent complementary. The routine use of phenobarbitone for this purpose in late pregnancy is not justified at present, but it seems worth considering for mothers in whom it is planned to induce labour before term.                                                    26

The New England

Journal of Medicine

Copyright, 1971. by the Massachusetts Medical Society

Volume 284                       JANUARY 7, 1971                       Number 1

PHYSIOLOGIC JAUNDICE: THE ENTEROHEPATIC CIRCULATION OF BILIRUBIN*

Ronald L. Poland, M.D., and Gerard B. Odell, M.D.

Abstract To evaluate the role of the enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin in “physiologic" hyperbilirubinemia, nine full-term infants delivered by cesa-i rean section were given a formula supplemented with agar for the first five days of life starting at the 20th hour. Agar stabilizes bilirubin in aqueous solution and prevents its bacterial conversion. Ten infants were given the same formula without agar.

No rise in the serum bilirubin concentration oc-

I IMMATURITY of hepatic function has been cited as the major cause of “physiologic jaundice” in the newborn and increased bilirubin production a secondary contributor to hyperbilirubinemia. This hypothesis gained its greatest support from studies that reported reduced glucuronyl transferase activity in livers of neonatal guinea pigs. Brown and Zuelzer1 found virtually no conjugation of bilirubin in liver tissue from four-day-old animals, although neonatal hyperbilirubinemia docs not occur in this species. Gartner and Arias2 subsequently reported that newborn guinea pigs base a partial decrease in conjugating ability for bilirubin, but not of sufficient degree to rejijlt in nonconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Dutton et al.3 indicated that the activity of glucuronyl iransfeiase is proportional to the concentration of uridine diphosphoglucose (UDP) glucuronic acid in the assay system used, and Strebel and Odell4 have since found the specific activity of bilirubin glucuronyl transferase of liver in four-day-old rats is comparable to that in adult animals. Other investigations have also demonstrated the presence of bilirubin glucuronyl transferase activity in Ictal and newborn human infants.5'0 In view of this more recent evidence on the probable adequacy of hepatic glucuronyl transferase, to conjugate the bilirubin that is normally formed, other mechanisms for physiologic jaundice appear to warrant consideration.7

♦From the U. S. Army Hospital Specialized Treatment Center, Fort Gordon, Georgia, and the Department of Pediatrics, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine (address reprint requests to Dr. Odell at the Department of Pediatrics. Johns Hopkins Hospital. Baltimore. Md. 21205).

Supported by a research grant (Nl( HD-02268) lioni the LJ. S. Public Health Service.

curred after the 13th hour of life in the aqar-fed S infants. More bilirubin was excreted in the feces y within the first five days in infants fed formula with agar, and these infants also lost less weight than the controls. By the sixth day, total fecal bilirubin y excretion from birth wps similar in both groups. These results suggest that the reabsorption of bilirubin from the intestine can be a major cause of neonatal physiologic jaundice.

Circumstantial evidence suggests that the enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin contributes to physiologic hyperbilirubinemia, but this mechanism has not been quantitated. Goodie,8 as early as 1859, commented that jaundice in the newborn was related to “the want of a free evacuation of the meconium.” In 1937 Ross et al.9 demonstrated that anicteric infants had greater stool excretions of bilirubin during the first few days of life than comparable icteric infants. More recent clinical obervations have shown that marked neonatal hyperbilirubinemia can be anticipated in clinical circumstances associated with abnormal bowel function such as obstruction of the upper intestinal tract,10 delayed passage of meconium11 or fasting.12

The feces of newborn infants, unlike those of adults, contain bilirubin and /3-glucuronidase activity and negligible amounts of urobilinogen and urobilin.13 Intestinal jS-glucuronidase activity has also been described in the human fetus.14 The absence of an intestinal bacterial flora for the reduction of bilirubin to urobilinogen and the presence of ^-glucuronidase in the intestine during fetal and neonatal life presents a unique circumstance whereby bilirubin dighieurouide secreted into the intestinal tract could be hydrolyzed and the resulting bilirubin reabsorbed. Duodena! infusion of bilirubin in laboratory animals has demonstrated a more rapid absorption of noneoniugated bilirubin than its di-glucuronidc,15 and similar results have been reported in humans with biliary fistulas.10-17

Previous attempts to demonstrate that enterohe-patie circulation of bilirubin contributes to neonatal hyperbilirubinemia have involved orally adminis tered medicinal charcoal and the synthetic resin,

GAG-52


THE NEW ENGLAND JOURNAL OF MEDICINE

Jan. 7, 1971


cholestyramine, to adsorb intestinal bilirubin. The feeding of charcoal was associated with a reduction in the maximum concentration of the serum bilirubin only if initiated before 12 hours of age in full-term infants. No effect 011 the serum bilirubin levels during neonatal life was found when cholestyramine was given to premature infants. Measurements of bilirubin excretion in the stools were not made in either study.

In vitro studies of the action of intestinal bacteria on bilirubin in this laboratory demonstrated that agar in thioglycollate broth protected bilirubin from either oxidation or reduction during bacterial growth. Agar is an aqueous extract of seaweed that has been separated into agarose and agaropectin.20 Agar has been extensively used in the preservation of meat, fish, confections, bakers' products, ice creams and cheese’1 It has also been employed medicinally as a colloid laxative.22

Studies of acute and prolonged agar feeding in jaundiced Gunn rats have been conducted in our laborators'. The results, as s et unpublished, indicated that the chronic feeding of agar in laxative doses22 was associated with increased fecal bilirubin excretion, improved growth rates, lower mortality and partial protection from bilirubin nephropathy. Because of the encouraging results found in vitro and in the animal studies, permission for further study in’human infants was granted by the Institutions Committee for Clinical Investigation, and authorization from the appropriate representative of The Surgeon General’s Office of the Arms' was granted.

Material and Methods

The capacity of agar to protect bilirubin from bacterial alteration was tested in vitro. Bacteria! colonies were isolated from stool culture plates, inocu- _ lated into nutrient broth and incubated at 37°C. After 24 hours of incubation, 1.0 ml of the bacterial culture was pipetted into each of two sets of thioglycollate medium (8 ml per tube), of which one had been prepared to contain 0.07 per cent agar. Crystalline bilirubin (12.0 mg) was freshly dissolved in 10 ml of 0.01 N sodium hydroxide, and 1.0 mi was pipetted into each tube (final vol 10 ml, pH 7.1, bilirubin 11.5 mg per 100 ml). One set of thioglycollate tubes was not inoculated with bacteria and served as controls. All tubes were incubated at 37°C, periodically examined for bacterial growth and analyzed for bilirubin concentration at 48 hours by the method of Hargreaves.23 Typical results are summarized in Table 1.

The control tube with agar maintained its original bilirubin concentration whereas a small loss was observed in the control tube without agar. Tube sets 1 to 5 showed good bacterial growth, but the original bilirubin concentrations were maintained only in the tubes that contained agar. Each of these tubes had either gram-negative rods or cocci. Tube

Table 1. Bilirubin Concentration in Thioglycollate Medium Inoculated with Bacteria after 48 Hours of Incubation.

Tear Ski

Bl 1 IRUHIN (Mg/100 Mi )

WITHOUI AC.AR

WITH AGAR

Control

8.9

1

5.4

10.9

. 2

6.2

13.0

3

5.0

11.7

4

7.7

13.4

5

6.8

12.5

6

10.0

10.5

set 6 had been inoculated with staphylococci, and bacterial growth occurred only in the tube with agar. As indicated, the bilirubin concentration remained stable in both these tubes even in the absence of agar. A number of agar preparations have been tested in vitro for their capacity to stabilize bilirubin solutions and considerable variation has been noted. The U.S.P. agar used in the present feeding studies was one of the most effective lots, but the essential components responsible for this capacity have not been identified.

Healthy full-term infants delivered by cesarean section were selected for study because they would be in the hospital nursery for at least six days. Infants of mothers who were diabetic or had had preeclampsia were not included. The indications for cesarean section were maternal pelvic dystocia or a history of a previous section delivery. After delivery and evaluation of the infants, their parents were informed of the nature of the study, and permission was granted in each case.

Nothing was given by mouth for the first 12 hours after delivery; glucose feedings were given at .12 and 16 hours of life and formula feedings (Modilac, Gerber, 20 calories per ounce) were begun at the 20th hour. The agar-fed infants received 250 mg of agar powder (U.S.P.) in the first 5 ml of each formula beginning at 20 hours of age and continued at four-hour intervals for 21 doses.

Umbilical-cord blood from all infants was analyzed for ABO blood type and Rli factor, and a Coombs test was performed. Capillary-blood samples were collected daily between 7:30 and 8:00 a.m. for measurement of serum bilirubin. On alternate mornings a blood hematocrit, examination of the peripheral blood smear and reticulocyte count were performed. The serum bilirubin measurements were done by one of us (B.L.P.), 'who employed a 1:10 dilution according to the method of Malloy and Evelyn.21 The other blood analyses were done by the rountine methods of the hospital’s laboratory. Daily weights were recorded for each infant.

All the infants’ stools were collected for six days in Saran Wrap,* which was used as inner liners for the diapers. Each 24-hour sample was analyzed daily. The stools were scraped from the plastic liner into a Waring blcndor, suspended to a final volume of 100 ml

4 Dow Chemical Co., Midland, Mich. with 50 per cent ethanol and homogenized. Aliquots of 1 and 2 ml were analyzed for bilirubin by oxidation to biliverdin by addition of 1 per eent hydrogen peroxide in hydrochloric acid as described by Evelyn and Malloy.25 The method was modified by inclusion of 1 per cent 1-ascorbic acid to the reagent blank to prevent autooxidation of bilirubin in the blank tube.

The daily determinations of stool bilirubin were expressed as cumulative values by division of the sum of the bilirubin excretions to date by the weight (in kilograms) and the age (in days) of the infant. Thus, the six-day values represent the aver* age fecal bilirubin excretions for the first six days of life in milligrams pci kilogram of body weight per day. This means of analyzing the data was selected to minimize the differences due to the dax-to-day variations of stooling.

The results of the control and agar-fed infants were statistically compared by the use of the Student’s t-test. Since the fecal bilirubin values in Case 1 of the agar-fed and Case 2 of the control infants far exceeded any of the others, these results were excluded in the t-test computations using an r-ratio for outliers. All the stool-excretion data were included when the results were evaluated by the rank-sum test.26 ’                             ,

Results

There were nine agar-fed infants (four males) and 10 controls (six males). The birth weights, gestational ages, and frequency of blood-group incompatibility were similar (Table 2). None of the infants had positive Coombs tests or abnormal blood smears. The initial and subsequent hematocrits were comparable, as were the mean reticulocyte counts (Table 2). The agar-fed group, however, lost less weight (p less than 0.01) than the controls.

The serum bilirubin concentrations in the control infants (Fig. 1) rose from a value at the 13th hour of 4.1 ± 0.5 (mean ± S.E.) mg per 100 ml to a maximum of 7.5 ±1.4 mg per 100 ml on the fourth day of life. The agar-fed infants had a similar initial mean serum bilirubin concentration of 4.4 ± 0.9 mg per 100 ml (Table 3). In contrast to the controls, there was no increase in the serum bilirubin on subsequent days. Only one of the agar-fed infants demonstrated a- rise greater than I mg per 100 ml from the initial Serum bilirubin value, whereas five control infants showed an increase of more than 5 mg per 100 ml during the same period.

Although there were marked differences between the studs’ groups in their rates of bilirubin excretion during the first three days of life, the cumulative excretions were not significantly different by the sixth day of life (Fig. 2 and Table 4). The agar-fed infants had excreted much more of the total (six day) bilirubin eliminated in the first three days of life, whereas the control infants demonstrated a progressive increase in the stool excretion of bilirubin.
