Figure 1. Daily Bilirubin Concentrations in the Serums of Control (0) and Agar-Fed Infants (©) during Neonatal Life (Cross Bars Represent Means ± S.E.M.).

The differences between mean excretion rates for the first five days were significant (p between 0.05 and 0.01) when the results were analyzed by the Student’s t-test and corrected for the outliers (Case 1 in the agar group and Case 2 of the control group), ■ When all the daily excretion data were included and analyzed by the rank-sum test, significant differences (p less than 0.05) between the two groups were found on the second through the Ibtfrlh days of life. The greater excretion of bilirubin on the first day in the agar-fed infants was believed to occur' because some of them had received agar before the completion of the first 24-hour stool collection.

Discussion

No complications were observed with the administration of agar to the infants. The dosage of agar employed (0.5 g per kilogram of body weight per day) is within the laxative range recommended for adults, but no diarrhea or bulky stools were noted in the agar-fed infants. Unfortunately, stool weights were not measured before dilution, so that greater stool volumes could have been excreted by the treated infants.

The smaller weight loss found in the agar-fed infants is of interest but cannot be adequately explained by the present study. It is possible that the agar was responsible for greater water retention in the intestinal tract, but no evidence of distention was noted. It is also conceivable that the avoidance of bilirubin retention in the agar-fed infants prevented the development of a mild bilirubin nephropathy comparable to that described in the chronieal-

reduce neonatal hyperbilirubinemia have employed agents that can increase hepatic glucuronyl transferase activity such as phenobarbitaldiethyl nicotinamide29 and ethanol30 or exogenous administration of uridine dipliosphoglucose31 as additional substrate for the conjugation of bilirubin. All these procedures have reduced the degree ol hyperbilirubinemia quantitatively, but all infants so treated have shown the same qualitative pattern of neonatal jaundice, with a progressive rise of the serum bilirubin beyond the First day. By contrast, the serum bilirubin levels in the agar-fed infants qualitatively differed by the absence of any further increase after the initiation of agar feedings. The simultaneous elimination of further hyperbilirubinemia and the greater rates of excretion of bilirubin in the meconium stools strongly' suggest that the agar feeding was responsible for the reduction in hyperbilirubinemia by blocking the enterobepatic circulation of bilirubin.

The daily cumulative excretion rates of bilirubin in our control infants were similar to the values reported by Ross et al.,9 whereas the rates in the agar-fed infants were two to four times greater during the first four days of life. The initially low excretions of bilirubin in the control infants might be interpreted as either a primary failure in hepatic excretion or a consequence of an exaggerated reabsorption of bilirubin from the intestinal tract. The greater stool excretion of bilirubin in the agar-fed infants supports the latter interpretation. The sequestration of bilirubin within the intestine by agar associated with a possible cathartic-like action would result in a more rapid passage of intestinal contents and less intestinal reabsorption. The results of previously reported11-12 early feeding studies are compatible with the influence of early stimulation of intestinal motility on neonatal jaundice. In the present study early feedings were ot used, and the finding:; are therefore more consistent with the interpretation that agar prevented intestinal reabsorption of bilirubin by reducing the available concentration.

By the sixth day of life, the total amounts of bilirubin recovered from both groups of infants did not statistically differ and averaged 4.0 mg per kilogram per day. This value represents between 50 and 70 per cent of the derived daily- production of bilirubin, which has been estimated to range between (5 and 8 nig per kilogram per day in normal full-term infants from the rate ol carbon monoxide production32 ami redcell life-span phis shunt bilirubin formation.33 Since the content of urobilinogen and urobilin in meconium stools is negligible,5 the discrepancy between the present recovery data for bilirubin and its theoretical rate of formation reflects either alteration of bilirubin in the intestine and during the collection procedure or some other mechanism for bilirubin metabolism in the infant. The error in recovery is probably much guater, for at birth the infant has to

eliminate bilirubin already existent within the meconium formed during fetal life in addition to that formed daily from porphyrin synthesis ami heme catabolism.

The present results suggest a sequence of events that can account for much of physiologic jaundice. In utero the fetus conjugates some bilirubin and excretes i,t into the intestinal tract where ^-glucuronidase activity hydrolyzes the bilirubin glucuronide. By reabsorption from the intestine, the bilirubin of fetal origin can still be cleared by the placenta. The newborn, deprived of placental cleai.mce, must excrete bile pigment derived from two sources: that reabsorbed from meconium and that produced from daily poiphyriu metabolism. When the enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin is inter-rupti il, newly born infants can excrete tlu-ii Ictal bilirubin load without its return to the circulation. The current report supports the proposal that the reabsorption of the bilirubin that is within the intestinal tract at the time of birth max be priinaiily responsible for physiologic jaundice. Further studies are needed, however, before the clinical use of agar for the management of certain types of hyperbilirubinemia can be recommended.

References

  • 1. Brown AK, Zuelzer WW: Studies on the neonatal development of the glucuronide conjugating system. J Clin Invest 37:332-340, 1958

Prophylaxis of Neonatal Hyperbilirubinemia With Phenobarbital

THOMAS F. HALPIN, MD, ALBERT R. JONES, MD, FACOG, H. LEE BISHOP, MD and SAUL LERNER, MD, FACOG

In an effort to lower the incidence and severity of neonatal jaundice, 96 mothers were each given 20 mg of phenobarbital each night, beginning at the thirty-second week of gestation. Previous reports have suggested that such treatment stimulates the glucuronyl transferase system in the fetal liver and lowers the incidence of hyperbilirubinemia in the newborn. Serum bilirubin levels during the first four days of life were compared with those of 11 1 control mothers and infants. Treatment lowered the mean neonatal bilirubin at 72 hours after birth from 8.5 to 6,4 mg %. While 24.6% of control infants had serum bilirubin levels greater than ID mg % at 96 hours, only 7.3% of the treated infants had levels greater than 10 mg % at this time. This study concludes that treating mothers with phenobarbital is an effective adjunct in lowering the incidence of neonatal jaundice.

Significant progress has been made in prevention of Rh sensitization and the treatment of hyperbilirubinemia secondary to Rh disease and ABO incompatibility. Physiologic jaundice, however, continues to be a source of concern and has recently been the subject of several investigations.

Physiologic jaundice is thought to reflect a relative inability of the newborn’s liver to conjugate and excrete bilirubin due to immaturity of the glucuronyl transferase system. Odell1 in an excellent review article, pointed out, that the problem of physiologic

From the Division of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The Memorial Hospital. Worcester, Mass.

Address reprint requests to: Thomas F. Halpin, MD, Worcester Obstetrics-Gynecology Association, Inc, 25 Oak Ave. Worcester. Mass 1)1605.

Submitted for publication Dec 15, 1971. hyperbilirubinemia in the neonatal period is undoubtedly more complex than simply immaturity of the glucuronyl transferase system. Hyperbilirubinemia (total serum bilirubin greater than 12 mg %) may be the result of either increased bilirubin production or decreased bilirubin excretion after birth which may also be caused by: a) decreased erythrocyte life span in neonates, b) inhibition of the glucuronyl transferase system by steroids of fetal or placental origin, c) decreased bilirubin transfer from plasma into liver cells, d) lack of bilirubin degradation into urobilinogen in the intestine due to absence of bacterial flora at birth and e) persisent patency of the ductus venosus.

Nevertheless, induction of glucuronyl transferase by administering phenobarbital to the mother seems to be a workable approach to preventing neonatal hyperbilirubinemia. Brown and Zuelzer- demonstrated this possibility first in guinea pigs and their work was later confirmed by Gartner and Arias.3

In 1962, Catz and Yoffee,4 using Swiss-Webster mice, were able to induce conjugation of bilirubin in the offspring by pretreating pregnant mice with phenobarbital.

Six years later, Trolle’ ” was able to reduce the incidence of jaundice in newborns from 22.6 to 5.0% by pretreating the mothers with phenobarbital. He demonstrated that phenobarbital is more effective when administered to the pregnant woman near term than when administered to the newborn. In 1970, Doxidias" reported his ex-

Vol. 40. No. i July 1972

HAT. PIN

periencc with neonatal hyperbilirubinemia in Greece and in several islands off its coast. He concluded that “phenobarbital appears to be a sound and logical approach to preventing severe neonatal hyperbilirubinemia.” However, Cunningham,'' Rambocr? and Walker1" were unable to demonstrate the benefits of prenatal phenobarbital or its direct administration to the neonate after icterus developed.

Other objections to the use of phenobarbital are known. Maurer11 suggested that phenobarbital administered for 2 weeks or longer before delivery “altered the usual course of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia in the neonatal period.” He cautioned that the drug is known to stimulate the activity of liver microsomal enzymes that metabolize steroid hormones and long-term effects on the fetus and newborn are not known. Behrman and Fisher1- warned that treatment with a drug causing central nervous system depression must be carefully considered.

Mountain11 reported 2 infants out of 16 whose mothers were treated with phenobarbital prenatally, had clinical evidence of hemorrhagic disease and in 8 of the children, there was a decrease in Factors II, VII, IX and X which was severe in 7 of the 8. These were in mothers who had been taking barbiturates to control epilepsy during pregnancy. All of the infants responded to vitamin Kj.

The effectiveness of phenobarbital treatment is further obscured by factors such as race and sex. Yeung and Field11 reported a higher incidence of neonatal idiopathic jaundice in Chinese than in Caucasian infants. They attributed this to immature liver function. Kokosky et al''' report that newborn males have higher serum bilirubin levels than do newborn females. They also report that Caucasians have higher bilirubin levels than do Negroes, but that control Negroes still had higher mean bilirubin levels than phenobarbital-treated Caucasians. They reported no immediate side-effects in

ET A!.

newborn infants treated with phenobarbital.

DoxidiasT reported a large series of control and treated patients, starting treatment between the thirty-second and thirty-eighth weeks of pregnancy. The infants of mothers who had ingested less than 1 g of phenobarbital, had bilirubin levels on the fourth day of life which were no lower than those of the controls. However, bilirubin levels on the fourth day of life were 4 mg % or less in 60% of the infants whose mothers had ingested 1 g or more of phenobarbital and in only 23% of the controls.

We have observed for some time what was felt to be an increasing occurrence of neonatal jaundice—perhaps due to greater alertness and early diagnosis. The anxiety of the mother whose infant is jaundiced has also been observed, particularly when these infants require extended hospitalization with its attendant expense. The risks to the neonate from hyperbilirubinemia and the subsequent neurologic deficits are well known. More recently, subtle degrees of hyperbilirubinemia have been implicated in subtle intellectual and psychomotor retardation in later years. Boggs et al."'' indicate a positive relationship between increasing levels of neonatal serum bilirubin and the incidence of low motor and/or mental scores attained at eight months of age. These relationships do not begin abruptly at the 20 mg/100 ml level of serum bilirubin, but may be seen to rise progressively and to become substantial at a concentration of 16 to 19 mg/100 ml. This data, if valid, would suggest that efforts toward preventing or ameliorating neonatal hyperbilirubinemia are desirable.

The present study was undertaken with an effort toward preventing and/or reducing neonatal hyperbilirubinemia.

MATERIALS AND METHODS

Two hundred thirty-five consecutive preg nant Caucasian patients from the authors' private practice constitute the group of patients studied. Randomization was achieved

Obstetrics and

Gynecology

NEONATAL HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA

by assigning all patients with odd-numbered days as a part of their expected date of confinement (EDC) (eg, February 25 and February 27) to the phenobarbital-treated group. All patients with even-numbered days as a part of their EDC (eg, February 26 and February 28) were assigned to the control group.

Each patient in the treated group was given 30 mg of phenobarbital each night from approximately the thirty-second week until delivery. One thousand milligrams of phenobarbital had to be ingested before delivery before the patient qualified as being “treated.”

Of the 115 patients in the treated group, 19 were rejected from the study because treatment was incomplete, either because the treatment period was too short (13), they failed to take the medication (4), or atopic dermatitis developed shortly after treatment with phenobarbital began (2).

Of the 120 patients in the control group, 6 were rejected because of barbiturate ingestion for insomnia (5) or epilepsy (1). The data was thus obtained from 114 controls and 96 treated patients. A comparison of prejudicial factors appears in Table 1, demonstrating that the two groups are essentially comparable.

After delivery, cord blood was obtained and cord bilirubin, hemoglobin, Rh type, and Coombs tests performed. At 24, 48, 72 and 96 hours, heel prick specimens were obtained for serum bilirubin determination. Nursery personnel and laboratory techni-

cians were unaware of which infants were delivered of phenobarbital-treated mothers and which were delivered of control mothers. The smaller number of recorded cord bilirubins (195 of 210) represent inability to obtain adequate cord blood or blood specimens lost in transit between the delivery room and the laboratory. The smaller group of values at 96 hours represent babies discharged before 96 hours had elapsed (165 of 210).

EESULTS

Comparison of mean cord blood bilirubins between the control and the treated infants shows no significant difference. However, all subsequent determinations at 24, 48, 72 and 96 hours show that the mean serum bilirubins of the phenobarbital-treated infants are significantly lower (P < 0.001) than those of the control infants (Table 2).

Of particular interest is that the intensity of neonatal jaundice reaches its peak in the treated group at 48 hours and progressively

HALPIN ET AL


Fig I—Mean serum bilirubin of infants of treated and control mothers.

falls thereafter, while the peak in the control group does not occur until 72 hours and is just beginning to fall at 96 hours (Figure 1).

Further analysis reveals that the incidence of infants with serum bilirubin greater than 10 mg % at 72 hours is 30.7% in the control group and only 14.6% in the treated group. At 96 hours, 24.6% of the control group still have scrum bilirubins in excess of 10 mg%, while only 7.3% of the treated group still have this degree of bilirubinemia (Figure 2).

The total group of 210 infants were then divided into four groups: a) formula-fed controls, b) breast-fed controls, c) formula-fed treated and d) breast-fed treated.

No significant difference in serum bilirubins in the first 96 hours of life could be demonstrated between those controls who were formula-fed and those who were breastfed. Similarly, there was no significant difference in the serum bilirubins in the first 96 hours of life between those treated infants who were breastfed and those who were formula-fed.

A difference appears when the total group of 210 infants are separated according to sex. Phenobarbital-trcated females had lower serum bilirubin curves than phenobarbital-trcated males and similarly, control females had lower serum bilirubin curves than control males. In fact, the curve for phenobarbi-tal-treated males is nearly the same as that for control females (Figure 3).


Fig 2—Percent of infants in treated and control groups whose serum bilirubin exceeded 10 mg %.


Obstetrics and Gynecology


NEONATAL HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA

Fig 3—Mean serum bilirubins of infants of treated and control mothers, demonstrating lower serum bilirubin of female infants in each group.


DISCUSSION

The present study suggests that treatment of the pregnant female during the last 8 to 10 weeks of gestation with a minimum total in breast milk interfere with bilirubin conjugation by the newborn's liver.

No instance of hemorrhagic disease was seen in the 96 infants whose mothers were treated with phenobarbital, despite Mountain’s79 warnings. This is probably due to the fact that all of the infants were routinely given vitamin Ki immediately after birth.

NEONATOLOGY                            .

CHARCOAL THERAPY OF

NEONATAL JAUNDICE

A Preliminary Report on a Promising Method for Reducing the Need for Exchange Transfusions

JOHN P. CANBY, Maj., MC.

Chief, Pediatric Service, Martin Army Hospital, Fort Benning, Georgia

T

1LN neonatal jaundice, a frequent problem in newborn nurseries, exchange transfusion has been the only effective method to date of controlling the bilirubin levels.

Recently, several authors have discussed the “enterohepatic bilirubin shunt” in man-—so named because any unconjugated bilirubin which may reach the intestinal lumen is rapidly reabsorbed (shunted) into the blood stream.1- 2 The following study was performed to take advantage of this phenomenon, using charcoal to adsorb bilirubin and block this circulation. The preliminary results, which seem to show a marked reduction in the need for exchange transfusions, form the basis of this report.

METHODS

All newborns exhibiting an unusual degree of jaundice from whatever cause were admitted to the study. Although Rh and ABO incompatible patients were included, the severe jaundice in most of the infants had no demonstrable cause and was looked upon as “idiopathic.”

For this study, an unusual degree of jaundice was defined as a total serum bilirubin level higher than 10 milligrams per 100 milliliters at 2-1 hours of age, or 15 milligrams per 100 milliliters at 48 hours of age.

Activated charcoal (Darco 60),* suspended in water as a 10 per cent solution, was fed at the first sign of an unusual degree of jaundice, ft was given by gavage in 5-cc. increments, each containing approximately 0.5 Gm. of charcoal, every two hours. This program was continued until age 120 hours with normal full term infants and up to age 168 hours with the smallest premature infants, or until tire abnormal serum bilirubin levels had fallen to more acceptable levels.

In the nursery at Fort Benning, a community with a resident population of approximately 115,000 which is predominantly white, the newborn infants ate led 5 per cent aqueous glucose solution starting at age 12 horns. Breast nursing or cow’s milk formula is begun at 24 hours of age. Mothers are generally discharged on the second day post partum.

During the period of the study, all infants observed to be unusually jaundiced were fed only cow’s milk formulas. Penicillin, streptomycin, kanamycin, and occasionally Chloromycetin were the only antibiotics administered in the nursery. Vitamin K was administered as a 1 milligram dose once only, on discharge from the delivery room. The technics of feeding, bilirubin determination, and drawing of

* Atlas Chemical.

178


Vol. 4 No. 3 CLINICAL PEDIATRICS

blood, and the criteria for doing an exchange transfusion, did not change during the study.

The data for the control group were obtained by retrospective study o( all records of infants receiving an exchange transfusion from January I, 1963 to November 30, 1963.

The experimental study group, which was compared statistically with the control group, consisted of (a) those infants with serum bilirubin levels corresponding to those in the "obligatory” or “indeterminate exchange” zones (whether or not hemolysis was evident) of Allen and Diamond,3 and (b) all infants who received an exchange transfusion during the study period December 1, 1963 to May 16, 1964.

A comparison of the data from the control period and the period of this preliminary experimental study showed that the relative proportions of stillbirths, previable births, premature births in various weight groups, birth weights of term infants, Rh sensitized .and ARC) sensitized infants were nearly equal in each group.

Although occasionally a venipuncture was performed, most of the serial bilirubin readings were done on heel puncture blood collected at four to eight hour intervals, using the technic of Meites and Hogg.4 Macro bilirubin tests were performed by the technic of Mallory and Evelyn.5

Exchange transfusion was carried out whenever it appeared as if the indirect bilirubin reading would exceed 20 milligrams per cent by the fifth day of life. The exchange transfusions employed 400 to 500 cc. of whole blood per exchange—an amount equivalent to two infant blood volumes.

RESULTS

During the period January 1, 1963 to November 30, 1963 (the control period) there were 3,009 live births; 53 exchange transfusions were performed on 27 infants; and one death occurred during an exchange transfusion.

During the experimental study period (De-<ember I, 1963 to May 16, 1964) there were 1.562 live births, yet only 12 exchange transfusions performed on nine infants seemed necessary. There were six other infants in this group who developed serum bilirubin levels in the "ii determinate" zone, and two other infants wlo developed serum bilirubin levels in the “obligatory” exchange zone. These were given charcoal orally and are included in the statistical tabulations.

When the experimental and control groups compared statistically by the chi square technic, the observed difference of the exchange transfusion rates between the two groups could be expected to occur, by chance alone, less than one time in 1,000. Of course the significance of this finding is affected to some extent by the fact that eight of the infants in the experimental group required no transfusion. Although there is no assurance that the total serum bilirubin levels of the latter infants would have exceeded 20 milligrams per 100 milliliters, all but two eventually did attain levels of 18 to 20 milligrams per 100 milliliters. In no infant was the direct serum bilirubin reading greater than 1 milligram per 100 milliliters. It is reasonable to assume that all eight infants would have required one or more transfusions, had charcoal not been administered.

DISCUSSION

During the first 'few days of life, bilirubin metabolism differs from that in the normal child. Due to “immaturity" of the infant's liver, with relative lack of glucuronyl transferase, excretion of conjugated bilirubin is impaired with resulting accumulation of serum bilirubin, mostly as indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin.® The feces of newborn infants contain large amounts of unconjugated bilirubin,’-® and this content is increased in hemolytic disease of the newborn. Presumably, the bilirubin is transported across the intestinal mucosa cells into the intestinal lumen from the blood stream. Furthermore, there is absence of bacterial reduction of excreted bilirubin and large amounts of beta-glucuronidase, of probable visceral origin, are to be found in the intestinal lumen, possibly contributing to the presence of free bilirubin

CLINICAL PEDIATRICS Motch 1955

in the intestine.1 As a result, an abnormal amount of unconjugated bilirubin thus becomes available for reabsorption into the body from the gastro-intestinal tract.

Lester and Schmid, using C14, have demonstrated that unconjugated lipid-soluble bilirubin is absorbed readily from the intestinal tract whereas conjugated water-soluble bilirubin is not absorbed, thus preventing reabsorption of a potentially toxic material.2 Previously, it had been demonstrated that humans afflicted with Crigler-Najjar syndrome, as well as the animal counterpart, the Gunn rat, have an enterohepatic bilirubin "shunt.” Since most of the bilirubin in the newborn is present as unconjugated bilirubin, there should also exist the potentiality for an enterohepatic bilirubin shunt in the infant.

Ulstrom has recently confirmed that such a "shunt” does exist in the normal full term infant.10 By feeding normal newborn infants activated charcoal at four hours of age, he was able to cause a significant reduction in the maximum serum bilirubin concentrations attained, as compared with control infants. Furthermore, by the use of C14 labeled bilirubin, he was able to show that bilirubin solutions could be rapidly decolorized by addition of activated charcoal by adsorption onto the charcoal. Such activity was not impaired in vitro in the presence of added muconium or newborn stool.

It would seem, accordingly, that prevention of reabsorption of unconjugated bilirubin from the gastro-intestinal tract might effectively prevent high blood levels of unconjugated bilirubin from occurring in some individuals. That such is possible was shown by Lester in Crigler-Najjar rats, and by Lotts-feldt in a human with biliary atresia with the aid of the resin cholestyramine.11’12 Since charcoal seems to be more effective than cholestyramine in adsorbing bilirubin tn vitro,10 it should be more effective than cholestyramine in vivo.

Vol. 4 No. 3 CLINICAL PEDIATRICS

MEDICAL WORLD NEWS February 17, 1967

Charcoal Each Keeps Jaundice Away

A New Jersey pediatrician is feeding charcoal to icteric infants to reduce their serum bilirubin, clear the jaundice, and eliminate the need for full exchange transfusions.

After preliminary testing in more than 100 babies, the new regimen is now routine procedure at Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital in Camden, N.J. Several years ago, Dr. Anthony J. Repici, chief of the hospital’s pediatric service, heard the treatment discussed at a medical meeting, though where, and by whom, he does not recall. Since then, having used charcoal extensively. he estimates that the need for exchange transfusion at the hospital has been cut by more than 90%. “We’ve had no toxicity and no trouble from the charcoal.’’

Al! jaundiced newborn babies with scrum bilirubin levels over 10 mg% arc given 0.5 gm of charcoal in their formula every three hours, Dr. Rcpici says. Since the practice at the Camden hospital has been to wait until the serum bilirubin reaches 20 mg% before undertaking full exchange blood transfusion, the charcoal regimen affords treatment at an earlier stage. Therapy is continued until the scrum bilirubin stabilizes at less than 10 mg%. Although all types of hyperbilirubinemia arc treated with charcoal, Dr. Rcpici has obtained the best results in infants whose jaundice is not caused by Rh incompatibility.

Charcoal’s Action Undetermined

Charcoal is distasteful to the babies, and it is hard to get them to take it and keep it down. The nurses assigned to Dr. Repici’s busy neonatal service, which cares for 3,000 infants • each year, dislike, giving the charcoal feedings. But, says the Camden pediatrician, they find it far preferable to the three-hour preparation required for a full exchange transfusion.

Neither Dr. Repici nor Dr. Robert L. Breckenridge, the pathologist with whom he monitors the babies’ bilirubin levels, is certain of the charcoal formula’s mode of action. “We believe that charcoal absorbs bilirubin from the intestinal tract,” the pediatrician suggests. “The more you draw off, the more will go into the intestine, so that the large excess of bilirubin in the body will be drawn out.”

At Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital, he says, the mortality rate from full exchange transfusions is less than 1 %. But at other hospitals, where the risk of the transfusion may be as high as 5%,. Dr. Rcpici points out .that the nonsurgical treatment could have a decided advantage.

The New Jersey pediatrician has been using charcoal for several years. But “I can’t say this is the last word in treating neonatal hyperbilirubinemia. We intend to get more data on what is taking place. But we are doing something for these babies.” ■

MEDICAL WORLD NEWS/February 17, 1967

The Lancet • Saturday 13 December 1969

ETHANOL KN PREVENTION OF

HYPERBILIRUBINEMIA IN THE NEWBORN A Controlled Trial

Richard Waltman Frank Bonura

Gabriel Nigrin            C. Pipat

Departments of Obstetrics and Gynecology and Pediatrics of the Brooklyn-Cumberland Medical Center, Brooklyn, New "            York 11201       '        '

Summary


Ethanol was administered intravenously to 26 near-term and term

pregnant patients before labour and during early labour in various doses to cieterniHW the effect on bilirubin levels in the newborn. 18 patients at term, free from obstetric complications, were randomly selected as controls. A statistically significant reduction of serum-bilirubin levels in infants in the third, fourth, and fifth days of life was observed in the group whose mothers were treated with more than 100 g7"of 'etli'anol prior tn delivery. ‘‘The-findings suggest a simple." safe, aniTexpedient agent which may be used to prevent raised levels of bilirubin in. the newborn—levels which may affect mental and motor development in the first year of the infant’s life.

Introduction

Several clinical reports have advocated the oral administration of barbiturates during the last two to eight weeks of pregnancy,1 3 as prophylaxis against high serum-bilirubin levels during the first week of the infant’s life. It has been shown in rabbits, guineapigs, and mice that the enzyme glucuronyl-transferase, which is deficient in the first few days of life and is obligatory for the conjugation of free bilirubin, is enhanced by phenobarbitone injected into the pregnant animal several days before birth of the offspring.4’5 At the molecular level, many lipid-soluble drugs when administered to animals or to man induce an increase in the endoplasmic reticulum of the hepatocyte. These microsomal membranes are associated with drug-detoxifying enzymes. The functional counterpart of the morphological alteration results in an increase in hepatic enzymatic activity.4 Ethanol has been shown in rats as well as humans to be oxidised not only by hepatic alcohol dehydrogenase (A.d.h.) but by an adaptive microsomal enzyme system different from alcohol dehydrogenase.7’8 Microsomal enzyme induction initially stimulates oxidative enzymes but its activation eventually spreads to enzymes involved in hydroxylation, reduction, and glucuronidation.0 The possibility of induction of bilirubin glucuronidation by ethanol prompted us to 7633

administer this agent to near-term and term pregnant patients and to observe the effects on bilirubin levels in the newborn during the first five days of life.

We have studied three groups:

Group A received 100-115 g. of ethanol from three hours up to ninety-six hours (median time twenty hours) prior to delivery (15 cases).

Group B received 100 g. or less of ethanol from less than three hours to more than ninety-six hours prior to delivery (11 cases).

Group C (control) received no ethanol (18 cases).

We excluded patients who received phenobarbitone or phenylhydantion and patients with severe preeclamptic toxaemia because of reported low neonatal serum-bilirubin levels 10 in the infants of such patients. Diabetics, Rh-isoimmunised, or bleeding patients, and patients whose personal history reveaied mild-to-moderate consumption of alcohol during the last month of pregnancy were excluded.

Method

150 ml. of 95?,, ethanol prepared as a sterile solution in the hospital pharmacy was added to 850 ml. of physiological saline thus making a 14-25'’,, solution of ethanol. The solution was administered intravenously, generally at 2 ml. per minute and occasionally at up to 4 mi. per minute (found not to be well tolerated). The patients’ blood-pressure and pulse-rate and the feta! heart-rate were carefully noted during the period of administration. Blood specimens were drawn at prescribed regular intervals for determination of maternal serumelectrolyte and ethanol levels. Giggling and euphoria were observed, but nausea and/or vomiting was noted only at rates of 4 ml. of ethanol per minute. The sedation in labour consisted of small doses of pethidine (meperidine) and promethazine hydrochloride (‘ Phenergan ’)—drugs whose administration during labour does not effect serum bilirubin levels in the neonate." The Apgar score at one and five minutes after birth was recorded. Cord-blood was drawn at the time of delivery for Rh typing and bilirubin determination, and bilirubin levels were determined daily for the first five days of life by the method of Malloy and Evelyn 11 (micro-modification) from the infant’s heel-prick blood. All infants were carefully followed in the nursery by the paediatric staff, and no significant differences were noted in the infants of the control versus the ethanol-treated group relative to feeding, behaviour, or weight-loss.

Results

Mean serum-bilirubin levels were significantly lower in the ethanol-treated patients (group A) at the third, fourth, and fifth day of life than in the controls (group C) (P<0'001) (see accompanying table). 11 patients who received less than 100 g. of ethanol either less than three hours or more than ninety-six hours before delivery are not charted (group B). Their infants showed mean serum-

bilirubin (s.b.) levels not significantly different from the control levels. The highest level of s.b. in group A was 75 mg. per 100 ml. (I case), and among the controls (group C) 10 had higher levels than this. 6 infants in the control group showed levels of S.B. above 9-5 mg. per 100 ml. Only 1 infant of the 15 of the ethanol group (group A) had a peak s.b. above 5-7 mg. per 100 ml. compared to 13 of the 18 in the control group (see accompanying figure). The highest mean peak s.b. was 4-75 mg. per 100 ml. (J 0-345) in the ethanol group compared to 7-51 mg. per 100 ml. (±0-634) in the control group; this difference is highly significant (p< 0-001). Birth-weights were all above 2636 g, in the control group, while in the ethanol group there were 3 infants below this weight (2183, 2409, and 2466 g.). No patients were delivered under general anaesthesia. The Apgar scores were all above 8 out of 10, except for 1 patient in the ethanol-treated and 1 patient in the control group with an Apgar score of 7, and 1 infant in the ethanol group, weighing 2409 g,, who had an Apgar score of 6; this infant responded promptly to resuscitative measures.

Discussion

/ The administration moderate amounts of ethanol to pregnant women from three to ninety-six

I hours before delivery I resulted in signifi-' cant'y lower levels of s.b. in term or nearterm infants. The mechanism remains to be elucidated. It was

Plasma-eotal-bllirubin levels In ethanol-traaecd and control groups.

The difference between the highest mean level in the treated group (4-75 ±0-345 mg. per 100 ml.) and the control group (7-51 ±0-634 mg. per 100 ml.) is highly significant (p<0-001). noted by Rcmmcr,” and confirmed by Conncy and Burns,1'1 that administration of phenobarbitone to rats enhanced liver microsomal drug-hydroxylatingactivitics (N.A.i>.f.ii.2-depcndcnt drug-metabolising and steroid-hydroxylating enzymes). This enzymatic activity was accompanied by a proliferation of the endoplasmic reticulum of the liver parenchymal cells which was evident on electron-microscopic sections. The phenomenon was regarded not as a damaging or toxic effect on the hepatocyte but as an adaptive reaction to foreign substances.15 The process was non-specific since many substances (including over 200 lipid-soluble carcinogens, insecticides, and foreign and non-physiological agents) stimulate enzyme synthesis.” Depending on the duration of treatment and the dosage of xenobiotic agents, the oxidative enzymes are first stimulated, and the inductive effect spreads to enzymes involved in hydrolytic, reductive, and glucuronic-acid-transferase activity. Though membrane proliferation and enzyme induction are intimately related, the response to the administration of puromycin and actinomycin D (inhibitors of D.N.A.-dependent r.n.a. synthesis) suggests that two different genes and messengers are involved.17 Many drugs and foreign agents, including bilirubin, are excreted in the urine as glucuronides—some by direct esterification, others after prior hydroxylation. The final steps in glucuronidation involve U.d.p.g. dehydrogenase, a supernatant enzyme, anda microsomal enzyme, glucuronyl transferase, both deficient in the newborn and increased in rats by the administration of phenobarbitone. In rats the increase in drug-hydroxy-latmg enzymes as well as the u.d.p.g. dehydrogenase after treatment with drugs is rapid, but the glucuronyl-transferase enzyme increase is characterised by a two-day lag period.1H Bilirubin metabolism in the newborn has been reviewed by Ode.ll ethanol metabolism by Isselbacher and Greenberger and Lieber21; and the effect of phenobarbitone and jaundice by The Lancet.-2 Phenobarbitone was found to effect bilirubin metabolism through an enhanced hepatic uptake, conjugation, biliary excretion, and bile-flow. Recently, Lieber and DeCarli 7 have reported that the chronic administration of alcohol to humans acts like phenobarbitone by increasing hepatic microsomal drugdetoxifying enzymes as well as proliferation of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum. In addition both these substances increase the microsomal cytochrome P450 (focal point where molecular oxygen, substrate, and reducing-power meet) and enhance cholesterol biosynthesis. Yet after only two days of ethanol consumption by volunteers, alterations in hepatic architecture were observed.2'7

Ethanol passes easily through biological membranes and placenta and reaches the fetus readily. Yet when mothers, receive ethanol and arc quite inebriated their infants generally show no respiratory depression at the time of delivery.31 The fetal liver possesses only a fraction of the a.d.h. of the adult; the activity increases linearly and becomes comparable to that in the adult’s liver at five years.25 Even with low fetal ethanol levels, and a deficiency of a.d.h. activity, enhanced adaptive microsomal stimulation may result. 90-98% of the ethanol absorbed is completely oxidised and the remaining 2-10% is eliminated primarily

THE LANCET, DECEMBER 13, I960

1267


through the lungs and the kidneys.20 By contrast, the transplacental fetal localisation of phenobarbitone, especially in the region of the 4th ventricle (site of the respiratory centre) and the fetal liver,, results in the retention of this xcnobiotic drug for a considerable time.20

It has been reported from a survey of 23,000 cases 27 that s.b. levels in the newborn above 7-5 mg. per 100 ml. may be associated with low mental and/or motor scores at eight months of age. We suggest that ethanol be administered in high-risk deliveries, where a raised serum-bilirubin level might be anticipated or is suspected.28 Perhaps premature infants and term Chinese and Indian infants, who apparently have an immature liver functional capacity for bilirubin conjugation,28 should be carefully selected for further investigation. Premature infants especially should be studied. In these infants kernicterus may ensue at serum-bilirubin levels of 12 mg. per 100 ml. or less when these arc associated with acidosis, asphyxia, hypoglycaemia, or respiratory distress syndrome—not unusual accompaniments of premature births.’0

This treatment involves the pleasant oral consumption of small amounts of alcoholic beverage during the last week or two of pregnancy. Several patients with a history of alcohol consumption during the last few weeks of pregnancy bore infants who showed relatively low levels of s.b. during the first five days of life. Inductive effects on other enzyme systems must also be evaluated.

We thank Dr. Alan Reid, director of laboratories, for the chemical determinations, and the entire resident staff of the departments of obstetrics and gynaecology and pediatrics for cooperation. We are especially indebted to Dr. Sheldon ■ Bleichcr for the computerised statistics and review of the manuscript.

Requests for reprints should be addressed to R. W., Brooklyn-Cumberland Medical Center, 121 Dekalb Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11201.                           ■

The Lancet • Saturday 26 December 1964

IMMEDIATE FEEDING OF PREMATURE INFANTS WITH UNDILUTED BREAST-MILK

Victoria Smallpeice

M.A., M.D. Lond., F.R.C.P., D.C.H.

CLINICAL DIRECTOR

Pamela A. Davies M.B. Glasg., M.R.C.P., D.C.H.

LECTURER

P2E.DIATRIC DEPARTMENT, UNITED OXFORD HOSPITALS

The timing of the premature baby’s first feed, and no less its content, have for some years been controversial matters. During the late 1940s the hazards of aspiration and the presence of cedema were advanced as reasons for starving the infant during the first 48 hours of life or longer (Clifford 1947, Smith et al. 1949). That this regimen led to improved survival was not unanimously accepted (Ylppo 1954, Gleiss 1955), but the advocates of starvation probably outnumbered its opponents, at least in this country and the United States, during the 1950s. Although in the past few years starvation has been less rigorously practised, premature infants are seldom fed intensively in the first few days. The placenta nourishes these infants, if not always effectively, then at least continuously, until they leave the uterus. It seems irrational to interrupt the process just when the infant is exposed to greater risks than he will meet during the next four decades. Suspecting that some of the complications of this period might be caused or prolonged by delayed and inadequate nutrition, we carried out a trial of immediate feeding, which we have briefly reported elsewhere (Smallpeice and Davies 1964).

Patients and Methods

The trial was started on Nov. 1, 1962, and continued until March 31, 1964. Infants with birthweights of 1-2 kg. (2 lb. 3 oz.-4 lb. 6 oz.) were chosen. The mortality among those weighing less than 1 kg. is so high that we excluded them from the trial. Those between I and 2 kg. should all be viable, and this is the real challenge. 119 infants weighing between 1 and 2 kg. were either born in or admitted to the Radcliffe Infirmary, Oxford, during this 17-month period. 8 had to be excluded from the trial—2 because of oesophageal atresia, 5 during the early part of the trial who died within 4 hours of delivery without being fed, and 1 whose admission from outside was delayed until the 4th day—leaving a total of Ill infants. All the very immature babies, and many of the larger ones, were fed from birth by indwelling tubes. Shortly after delivery, a polyvinyl feeding tube was passed through the nostril to the stomach taking care that it was well down; the tube could occasionally be seen through the thin abdominal wall as it entered the

TABLE I—DETAILS OF INFANTS STUDIED

■ —

Later-fed

12 (27%)

7374

stomach. It was then securely fixed, right across the cheek, with waterproof adhesive. Tubes were changed weekly. Early bottle or breast feeding was encouraged, so that the tube could be dispensed with as soon as possible.

We followed a fixed schedule of feeding during the first 4 days of life. The 24-hour periods were calculated from the time of birth, and not from the time of the first feed. Undiluted human breast-milk was given throughout in the following amounts:

n             ez. per lb. ml. per kg. body-

y         bndy-yjeighi wight (<jppr^g.)

  • 1 1

  • 2 17,

  • 3 2

  • 4 27,

As the trial progressed, most babies were getting their first tube-feed within 2 hours of birth. For very small or distressed infants the 24-hour total was divided into hourly portions to lessen the bulk of feed entering the stomach at any one time. The interval between feeds was lengthened to 2 and then 3 hours as soon as possible, but, when necessary, hourly feeding was continued for the whole 4 days. A third of the babies had small regurgitations, which were not allowed to interfere with the schedule. 3 infants, all below expected birthweight, had an initial period of bilestained vomiting, abdominal distension, and delay in the passage of meconium. After examination, feeds were continued and increased as usual, and the symptoms persisted only for a short time. There was no diarrhoea. We adopted the standard birthweights for gestational age for singletons (kindly supplied by the National Birthday Trust from their perinatal-mortality survey of 1958); any infant whose birthweight was lower by more than twice the standard deviation than the standard weight we regarded as under expected birthweight.

This was not a controlled trial, but we have included for comparison observations made during the same 17-month period on 45 babies of comparable birthweight at the Churchill Hospital, Oxford. These babies were not fed until 4-32 hours after delivery. The majority had some feed during the first 24 hours, but the amount, and the rate of increase over the 4 days, were considerably less than in our trial. We describe the babies in the trial proper as “ early-fed ”, and those at the Churchill Hospital as “ later-fed We made certain comparisons with a third group: infants weighing 1-2 kg. born before this trial, who were starved for at least 24 hours; these we call “ late-fed ”.

Blood-sugar was estimated only in early-fed infants. In 50 of them an ‘ Autoanalyser ’ glucose-oxidase micro-method for true glucose was used, and in 27 others the method of Folin and Wu for total reducing substance. Two or more estimations were made on consecutive days during the first 4 days of life, and the lowest value for each infant was recorded.

Serum-bilirubin was estimated in both early-fed and later-fed infants if they were even slightly jaundiced. This was done in the laboratory of whichever hospital the infant was in, both laboratories using the same modification of the Tannhauser method. Proven cases of blood-group incompatibility were excluded.

Results

Table I shows the birthweights of the infants, and the incidence of multiple pregnancy, respiratory distress, and deaths.

Blood-sugar

In 27 early-fed infants the mean lowest value for total reducing substance was 60’1 mg. per 100 ml.

Fig. 2—Minimum blood-glucose in infants with birthweight of 1—2 kg.

Lowest blood-glucose levels in 50 other early-fed infants are shown in fig. 1. The mean of all these values is 43 mg. per 100 ml. But the mean for 13 infants below expected birthweight is 31 mg., which is significantly lower than the 48 mg. for the remaining 37.

Serum-bilirubin

The maximum bilirubin levels of 75 early-fed infants and 30 later-fed infants are shown in fig. 2. Of the early-fed, 12 (16%) had levels of 15 mg. per 100 ml, and above. 1 of these, with a reading of 19-5 mg. per 100 ml. on the third day, had an exchange transfusion. He had not been admitted until 8 hours after birth, and did not have the full schedule of feeds in the first day, 21 (70%) of the later-fed infants had levels of 15 mg. per 100 ml. or over. Exchange transfusion was necessary in 8.

DAYS AFTER BIRTH serum-bilirubin in infants with birthweight

The mean maximum bilirubin level for the 75 carly-Rd infants was 10-1 mg. per 100 ml., and for the 30 later-fed infants it was 16-6 mg. per 100 ml. The difference between these two is statistically significant at the 5% level. In the past, when infants were starved for 24 hours or longer bilirubin levels at the Radcliffe Infirmary followed the same pattern as in the “ later-fed ” group at the Churchill Hospital.

Times of Regaining Birthweight and First Passage of Meconium

Table n shows figures for 3 groups of infants: early-fed, later-fed, and late-fed. The differences between the early and late groups in times of regaining birthweight, and of first passage of meconium, are significant at the 5% level.

Discussion

Choice of Feed and Technique

Various kinds of feed have been advocated for premature infants (Corner 1960, Silverman 1961), including human breast-milk (Hess and Lundeen 1949, Crosse et al. 1954). Breast-milk is today scarce, and we have reserved it particularly for the all-important first few days of life. Wilkinson (1963) says that the newborn kidney is often judged immature by standard tests, but in fact it functions adequately when the infant is fed human breast-milk, and there is only a very small residue of water, sodium, and potassium to be excreted. Cow’s milk, on the other hand, has a higher sodium, potassium, and chloride content. There is no real evidence that the premature infant’s digestion is impaired, though fat absorption may vary

TABLE II—TIMES OF FIRST PASSING MECONIUM AND OF REGAINING

_         BIRTHWEIGHT

—

Early-fed

Later-fed

Late-fed

First meconium passed: No. of infants       . .      ,,

90

34

28

Mean time (hr.)    . .     ..

16-8

230

41-4

Birthweight regained: No. of infants       ..      .,

84

33

137

Mean time (days) ,,     ..

9-8

11-2

14-5

(Gordon and McNamara 1941). Diluting the milk merely reduces the number of calories, dilutes the gastric juice, and presents the kidney with an extra load of water, so we give undiluted breast-milk from the start. We see no merit in prolonged feeding with glucose; for, in the period of , weight loss after birth, energy is provided by catabolism of ■ protein, fat, and carbohydrate (Widdowson 1961), and it seems logical to provide them as soon as possible. McCance (1959) has emphasised the stabilising effect of growth in the newborn, and the importance of maternal milk in effecting this growth.

The alleged dangers and difficulties of early feeding of small premature babies have been overstressed. Apart from the 3 infants with temporary functional intestinal obstruction, we did not see significant vomiting, abdominal distension, or diarrhoea, described as hazards in many standard paediatric textbooks. We do not wish to underrate the risk of aspiration, but, with modern feeding techniques, which can be quickly taught by an experienced nurse, it should seldom occur. Even with the prevailing shortage of staff we feel that delayed feeding entails a greater risk. True aspiration pneumonia in infants is nearly always associated with some other gross lesion. The one infant who was found to have an aspiration pneumonia at necropsy also had a sizeable ventricular hsemorrhage. In a few infants who came to necropsy, milk was found in the nasopharynx and sometimes in the trachea; but Gardner (1958) has shown that this can occur after death, and we have confirmed his findings. Food may, of course, well up the cesophagus in a moribund infant, because of decreased tone.

The indwelling polyvinyl nasogastric tube scarcely disturbs the infant. The tube should be well down into the stomach, and may pass on to the duodenum. The baby breathes almost entirely through the nose, but seldom seems worried by the tube in one nostril. When nasal infection occurs, which is not often, there tends to be more discharge from the intubated nostril. Gastrostomy with a blow-off vent (Berg et al. 1946) is said to avoid the supposed hazards of nasal obstruction, and, by allowing food to escape through the vent, to lessen the danger of reflux and aspiration. But tube-feeding is a very much simpler procedure, and our nursing staff has been eminently successful with it.

We do not favour intravenous feeding, because we think the infant’s greatest need is milk.

Hypoglyccemia

The levels of blood glucose and total reducing substance in early-fed infants show the wide range of values characteristic of the first few days of life; 8 infants had levels of 20 mg. per 100 ml. or less, but none had convulsions. Among the last 4000 babies born at the Radcliffe Infirmary there has been only 1 case of symptomatic hypoglycemia —in a larger baby than those in this series, who should have had more feed in the first 24 hours. Recent studies of symptomatic neonatal hypoglyccemia (Cornblath et al. 1959, 1964, Brown and Wallis 1963, Neligan et al. 1963) have shown the susceptibility of infants below expected birthweight (particularly males and the smaller of twins), the risk of permanent cerebral damage, the quick response to intravenous glucose, and the inefficacy of oral glucose. Factors other than low blood-sugar levels are almost certainly implicated when symptoms arise. Cornblath et al. (1964) suggested that the low glycogen stores at birth, together with an abnormally sensitive insulin-release mechanism, are responsible. Aielichar et al. (1962) have shown that in newborn babies, fat, either in breast-milk or as free fatty acids, produces a rise in blood glucose. We believe that symptomatic neonatal hypoglycaemia is largely due to delayed or inadequate feeding. This could explain the different incidence in various centres (Farquhar 1963, Wybregt et al, 1964).

Hyperbilirub incemia

We repeat that this was not a controlled trial. Two laboratories were involved, but they worked closely together, and several of the higher levels in the later-fed group were checked in the second laboratory. In addition, factors known to be associated with jaundice (Barton et al. 1962, Wood et al. 1962) were more frequent in the early-fed group. We therefore regard the difference in bilirubin levels as genuinely significant. The direct co.rrslatiqn. between increased weight-loss and hyperbilirubinemia, reported by Taylor et al. (1963), is relevant.

Hubbell et al. (1961) found that bilirubin levels 72 hours after birth were significantly lower in early-fed than late-fed infants. Laurance and Smith (1962) suggested that early feeding would lower bilirubin levels, and Lardinois (1963) thought that the volume offered was even more important than the content. On the other hand Haworth and Ford (1963) found no difference in bilirubin levels, nor, incidentally, in blood-sugar levels, between babies starved for 36 hours, and others fed from the age of 4 to 6 hours on 5% glucose. Too gradual an increase in calories could account for their results. Brown (1962) cited Johnson and Day (1957), who described the depression of leucocyte motility by bilirubin, and Bernstein and Landing (1962), who tentatively ascribed necrosis of testicular epithelium and islets of Langerhans to bilirubin intoxication. It is surely right to keep the bilirubin levels as low as possible, and reasonable to suppose that nourishment provides a healthier cellular milieu than starvation for the maturation of the enzymes necessary for bilirubin conjugation. We feel that the rate of increase is as important as the content and time of starting feeds.

Respiratory Distress

Wilkinson et al. (1962) have shown that early feeding with undiluted breast-milk will rapidly correct the chemical chaos in the extracellular fluid of newborn infants who have undergone surgery; this supports McCance.’s (1959) concept of growth as all-important in maintaining normal homceostasis.

Respiratory distress presents a more complicated problem. According to Nicolopulous and Smith (1961), excessive tissue destruction, shift of water from cells to extracellular space, hyperkalatmia, and excessive excretion of sodium occur in the first 48 hours in all premature infants, but especially those with respiratory distress. Beard et al. (1963) demonstrated prolonged acidosis and increased catabolism when infants with respiratory distress and low Apgar scores were deprived of fluid and calories in. the first 48 hours.

The reported results of intravenous treatment with glucose and alkalis are inconsistent (Usher 1963, Hutchison et al. 1964). Such regimens supply calories, but they need constant attention and adequate laboratory facilities. We suggest that, until larger controlled trials prove the need for an intravenous regimen, these infants should be fed from the beginning. It is not true that infants with severe respiratory distress cannot be fed. 38 of them, fulfilling the diagnostic critera of Usher (1961) and Miller (1962), were fed according to our schedule. 19 died, all but 4 weighing less than 1-5 kg. (3 lb. 4 oz.). Several had associated conditions such as intraventricular haemorrhage.

Nutrition and Growth

Recent evidence suggests that, when the birthweight is small, delay in regaining it is associated with later neurological abnormalities and intellectual impairment (Freedman 1961, Churchill 1963, Drillien 1964). Drillien (1964) found that children subjected to early starvation often developed handicaps, and suggested that delay in feeding might have serious after-effects. Spastic diplegia is the commonest neurological abnormality of infants of very low birthweight (McDonald 1963). Churchill (1963) found the premature infants with spastic diplegia had taken considerably longer to regain their birthweight than normal infants of similar birthweight. Dehydration caused by prolonged withholding of food may well alter the cerebral blood-flow. Infants below expected birth- . weight often have a high haematocrit at birth, so dehydration is especially dangerous for them. We cannot yet, of course, report on the neurological sequelae of our trial.

Stoch and Smythe (1963) emphasised the importance to brain growth of nutrition in infancy. Hammond (1961) thought that, in the growth of malnourished animals, brain took priority over other tissues. Lat et al. (1961) showed that restricting the food of suckling rats in the first 3 weeks of life not only impaired growth, but also reduced activity, inquisitiveness, and capacity to learn, regardless of how much they were fed after this early period.

Conclusion

The Lancet (1963) said: “We need to know whether the simple matter of the time of feeding the premature. baby is important or not. It could affect his whole future.” i We believe it may, because early and adequate feeding not only lowers his serum-bilirubin level, but almost eradicates symptomatic hypoglycaemia. Even more important may be the correlation in very small infants between spastic diplegia and delay in regaining the birthweight. We have shown that this delay can be reduced.

We are very conscious that many well-meant “advances” in the care of the premature baby over the last 20 years have been disastrous. Perinatal mortality for infants. weighing 1-2 kg. at birth was lower in the single full year of the trial (1963) than in any year since 1952 when records ' were first available. This does not suggest the upsurge of a dangerous new regimen, though the improvement must be maintained. Minor difficulties were encountered at the beginning, but the scheme is now a matter of routine and has been extended to larger sick infants. It has been carried out despite an almost continuous staff shortage, and much credit is due to those members of the nursing staff who have pioneered it, and obtained supplies of breast-milk despite early discharge of the mothers.

The arguments for early and adequate feeding of these babies seem to us forceful. It is fully justified if hyperbilirubinemia can be reduced and symptomatic hypoglycemia largely eradicated; still more if shortening the period taken to regain birthweight reduces neurological sequela:. We think that it made the early neonatal course of these infants less complicated, and their resistance to infection greater. Although only a large controlled trial could settle these matters finally, it was necessary to show ’ that this type of feeding is possible.

We are grateful to Dr. Hugh Ellis who generously allowed all babies in this weight group to be under the care of one of us (V. S.) during the period under review; Dr. R. H. Wilkinson who undertook the biochemical investigations; to our colleagues in the neonatal department; and to Sister Barbara Tubbs and Sister Moira Campbell who have been responsible with their staff for the care of the babies. Mr. D. Golding, of the Oxford Regional Hospital Board, kindly undertook the statistical analysis.
