Wybregt, S. H., Reisner, S. H., Patel, R. K., Nellhaus, G., Cornblath, M-(1964) jf. Pediat. 64, 796.

Ylppb, A. (1954) Ann. patdiai. Penn. 1, 99.

THE USE OF THE BIOFLAVONOID COMPOUNDS IN THE PREVENTION OR REDUCTION IN SEVERITY OF ERYTHROBLASTOSIS FETALIS

WARREN M. JACOBS, M.D., F.A.C.S., Houston, Texas

Erythroblastosis fetalis is major cause of fetal loss, as well as of certain cases of cerebral palsy. Since the incrimination of the Rh-Hr system about 15 years ago as the prime factor concerned with the production of erythroblastosis fetalis, countless articles dealing with this subject have appeared. The ideal solution to this problem would be to find some substance that would either prevent this antigen antibody reaction from taking place, or prevent placental transmission of the fetal cells which initiate the reaction, or even prevent placental transmission of the antibodies themselves. To date, although many substances have been tried, nothing has been found that would accomplish any of these ends. At present the management of erythroblastosis fetalis is based upon treatment of the affected baby after delivery has taken place (1, 2). The value of exchange transfusion is well known and will not be discussed here.

THE RATIONALE FOR USE OF THE BIOFLAVONOID COMPOUNDS

The mechanism of Rh iso-immunization is based upon the concept that Rh positive fetal cells enter the maternal circulation through some break in the placental Capillary system. Once these cells are in the maternal circulation antigen antibody response is set up with production of Rh antibodies. These then freely cross the placental barrier back into the fetus and attack and destroy the fetal red cells. Since the maternal and fetal bloods do not mix, it is logical to think that the fetal cells cross the placental barrier

From the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Baylor University College of Medicine, Houston, because of some break in the capillary system. Javert states that in normal pregnancy varying degrees of decidual bleeding take place. He further states that the normal conditions which cause decidual bleeding are dilatation, engorgement, and stretching of the veins to the breaking point, and trophoblastic erosion, invasion, and perforation of the decidual veins. Mengert and his associates, in working with cells tagged with radioactive iron and also using cells with sickle cell trait, have shown that in a normal pregnancy a certain small number of fetal cells gain entrance to the maternal circulation, probably through some break in the capillary system. Increased fragility in the capillary bed is a venular defect. In 5 human subjects observed with spontaneous petechia formation in the bulbar conjunctiva, Lee, Goebel, and Fulton stated that the petechia were associated with venular changes. These latter consisted of annular and saccular widening, with reduced venular blood flow velocity in the widened portion, a turbulence of blood flow, and an observed escape of red cells from this distorted segment. In most instances, it was possible to sec that the walls of the venule usually had a tricornered tear through which the blood cells escaped. It is conceivable that this may be the mechanism for the escape of fetal cells into the maternal circulation. Since the bioflavonoids oppose this action it is possible that when given during the course of a pregnancy this crossover of fetal cells may be reduced or even prevented. Since the bioflavonoids have an antihistamine action, this may also be of benefit, since Rh-Hr sensitization is an antigen antibody reaction.

234 Surgery, Gynecology & Obstetrics • August 1956 Vol. 103

However, it must be stated that the antihistamine drugs have been tried in the past without much success. Finally, increased capillary fragility in the baby is a prominent feature of erythroblastosis. These three factors then—prevention or reduction in capillary fragility of the placenta, antihistamine reaction, reduction or prevention of capillary fragility in the baby—are the basis for the use of bioflavonoid compounds in the treatment of Rh iso-immunized women.

MATERIAL AND METHODS

Since most Rh negative women never develop antibodies, it would be. a long and almost impossible task to evaluate the results of this therapy in all such patients. In this report only mothers with previous definite evidence of immunization are used. It is generally agreed that once immunization has occurred, each additional Rh positive child will be affected, and probably somewhat more so than his predecessor. Obviously, antibodies which are already present cannot be reduced or destroyed, but it is hoped that further crossover of fetal cells and additional iso-immunization may be prevented or kept at a minimum. This report deals with 6 cases of previously Rh immunized mothers treated with cvp, the trade name of a bioflavonoid compound, during the course of their present pregnancy. Twelve such mothers received therapy with cvp, but 6 were discarded from the series, 5 because the babies proved to be Rh negative (all of these husbands were heterozygous positive), and 1 because the previous history of immunization was doubtful. The dosage of cvp used in these patients was 6 capsules daily, which consists of 600 milligrams of the bioflavonoid compound. This therapy was started before the fourteenth week of pregnancy, since it is believed that crossover does not occur prior to this time.

CASE REPORTS

  • Case 1. Mrs. P. M., a 25 year old white para 1-0-0-1, was Rh negative. Iler husband was heterozygous Rh positive, genotype CDE/e(d)e.

The patient had received intramuscular Rh positive blood tvhen she was an infant. Results of titer studies made prior to her first pregnancy were as follows; blocking titer, positive undiluted strength only; agglutinating titer, negative; indirect Coomb’s test, negative. Her first delivery was in January 1954. The results of titers prior to delivery in this pregnancy were as follows; blocking titer, 1 to 32; agglutinating titer, negative; indirect Coomb’s test, strongly positive.

The baby was a male, weighing 6 pounds 9 ounces. Moderately severe erythroblastosis was present. He was treated by exchange transfusion. The neonatal period was essentially uneventful but secondary anemia developed about 7 days after delivery. He was treated by 2 additional simple transfusions and left the hospital about 3 weeks after birth.

The patient’s last menstrual period had been on September 3, 1954 and the expected date of delivery was June 10, 1955. cvp in a dosage of 6 capsules daily was begun on October 15, 1954. Initial titer studies show'ed the following results: agglutinating titer, negative; blocking titer, 1 to 16; indirect Coomb’s, strongly positive. Her prenatal course was essentially uneventful. At 38 weeks’ gestation, results of titers were as follows: agglutinating, negative; blocking, 1 to 32; indirect Coomb’s, strongly positive. Labor was induced by amniotomy on May 30, 1955, in approximately the thirty-ninth week of gestation. Delivery was performed by outlet forceps and left mediolateral episiotomy after a 6 hour uncomplicated labor.

The baby was a 6 pound 9 ounce male, in good condition. Results of laboratory studies on the cord blood were as follows: hemoglobin, 18 grams; red blood cell count, 5 million; Rh positive; direct Coomb’s, positive; serum bilirubin, 3.5 milligrams per cent. The baby at this time still showed no evidence of jaundice and appeared to be a healthy infant. Exchange transfusion’was done because of the patient’s past history and because the baby did have a strongly positive direct Coomb’s. The attending pediatrician and the obstetrician, who had also taken care of this patient and her baby during her first pregnancy, both believed that this baby was healthier than the first one and probably could have survived without an exchange transfusion. The baby had an uneventful neonatal period and left the hospital with the mother on the fifth postpartum day.

  • Case 2. Mrs. H. G., a 34 year old white para 3-0-1-2, was Rh negative. Her husband was heterozygous Rh positive, genotype CDE/c(d)c.

Her first child was Rh positive with no evidence of erythroblastosis; the second child, Rh negative. Her third pregnancy terminated in a 7 month stillborn due to hydrops fetalis.

Her last menstrual period had been on September 25, 1954 with the expected date of confinement July 2, 1955. cvp in a dosage of 6 capsules daily was begun on January 1, 1955. Results of initial titer studies were: blocking titer, negative; agglutinating tit<T.

Jacobs: bioflavonoid compounds to prevent erythroblastosis fetalis 235

negative; indirect Coomb’s, negative. Iler prenatal course was essentially uneventful. No titer changes occurred at any time during the pregnancy, all remaining negative. Spontaneous labor occurred and delivery was made per low forceps with midline episiotomy on July 2, 1955.

The baby was a 5 pound 11 ounce female, in good condition. Laboratory studies on the cord blood were reported as follows: Rh positive; direct Coomb’s test, negative; hemoglobin, 20 grams; red cell count, 5.6 million; serum bilirubin, 2.1 milligrams per cent. There was no evidence of erythroblastosis. Laboratory studies were repeated in 4 hours and there was no appreciable change. The baby had an uneventful neonatal period and left the hospital with the mother on the third postpartum day.

  • Case 3. Mrs. O. W., a 31 year old white para 2-0-0-2, was Rh negative. Her husband was heterozygous Rh positive, genotype CDE/c(d)e.

Her first child was Rh positive with no evidence of erythroblastosis. Her second pregnancy terminated at 8 months with a stillborn due to hydrops fetalis.

Her last menstrual period had been on August 15, 1954 with the expected date of confinement May 22, 1955. Results of initial titers were: agglutinating titer, negative; blocking titer, negative; indirect Coomb’s, negative, cvp therapy in a dosage of 6 capsules a day was begun in December 1954. Her prenatal course was essentially uneventful. No titer rise occurred at any' time throughout the course of pregnancy. Indirect Coomb’s test on the mother was consistently negative. Spontaneous labor occurred and delivery was on May 11, 1955.

The baby was a 6 pound 15^2 ounce female with no gross evidence of erythroblastosis. Laboratory studies on the cord blood were reported as follows: hemoglobin, 16 grams; red cell count, 5.2 million; serum bilirubin, 1.6 milligrams percent; Rh positive; direct Coomb’s test, negative. Laboratory studies were repeated in 3 hours and no appreciable changes were noted. The baby had an essentially uneventful neonatal period and left the hospital with the mother on the third postpartum day.

  • Case 4. Mrs. D. N., a 37 year old white para 7-0-0-7, was Rh negative. Her husband was homozygous positive, genotype CDE/C(D)E.

The first 5 children w'ere apparently all normal with no evidence of erythroblastosis. During the sixth pregnancy, the blocking titer rose to 1 to 32 prior to delivery, and a positive indirect Coomb’s was also obtained on the mother at this time. The baby had moderately severe erythroblastosis and was treated with exchange transfusion resulting in an uneventful neonatal period. During the seventh pregnancy the blocking titer also rose to 1 to 32, and a positive indirect Coomb’s was also obtained on the mother prior to delivery. This child also had a moderately severe erythroblastosis w'ith a strongly positive direct Coomb's test. Treatment of the infant was with exchange transfusion. The baby had an essentially uneventful neonatal period.

Her last menstrual period had been on February 19, 1955. The expected date of confinement was November 26, 1955. cvp therapy of 6 capsules a day was begun on May 17, 1955. Results of initial titers were as follows: agglutinating, negative; blocking, negative; indirect Coomb’s, negative. Her prenatal course was essentially uneventful. No titer rise occurred during pregnancy. Spontaneous labor was uncomplicated and delivery was on November 21, 1955.

The baby was an 8 pound 7 ounce male, in good condition, with no gross evidence of erythroblastosis. Laboratory studies on cord blood were reported as follows: hemoglobin, 17 grams; red blood cell count, 5.7 million; Rh positive; direct Coomb’s test, negative; serum bilirubin, 4 milligrams per cent. Laboratory studies were repeated 3 hours later with no appreciable change. The baby had an essentially uneventful neonatal period and left the hospital with the mother on the third postpartum day.

  • Case 5. Mrs. F. L., 26 year old white para 3-1-0-2, was Rh negative. Her husband was heterozygous Rh positive, genotype CDE/c(d)e.

Her first child was normal with no evidence of erythroblastosis. The second child had severe erythroblastosis. The child was treated with exchange transfusion and survived after a stormy neonatal period. One spontaneous abortion occurred at 2 months following this second pregnancy.

Her last menstrual period was on October 9, 1954. The expected date of confinement was July 16, 1955. cvp therapy in the dosage of 6 capsules a day was begun early in January 1955. Initial titer studies showed; agglutinating titer, negative; blocking titer, 1 to 8; indirect Coomb’s, strongly positive. Her prenatal course was essentially uneventful. At the thirtysixth week, results of the titer studies were as follows: blocking titer, 1 to 16; agglutinating titer, 1 to 2; indirect Coomb’s, strongly positive. Labor was induced with pitocin on June 20, 1955, and spontaneous delivery with midline episiotomy was accomplished after an uncomplicated 6 hour labor.

The baby was a 4 pound 12 ounce female in good condition, with no gross evidence of erythroblastosis at birth. Laboratory studies on the cord blood were reported as follows: hemoglobin, 19 grams; red blood cell count, 5.8 million; Rh positive; direct Coomb’s, strongly positive; serum bilirubin, 6.3 milligrams per cent. Because of the past history of this patient and because of the strongly positive direct Coomb’s test, exchange transfusion was done. The baby had an essentially uneventful neonatal period and left the hospital with the mother on the fourth postpartum day. It was the opinion of both the attending pediatrician and the obstetrician, who had also taken care of this patient in her last pregnancy, that this baby was less affected than the last one, and could probably have survived without an exchange transfusion.

236 Surgery, Gynecology & Obstetrics ■ August 1956

  • Case 6. Mrs. A. S., a 29 year old white para 4-0-0-4, was Rh negative. Her husband was heterozygous Rh positive, genotype CDe/c(d)c.

Her first 3 babies apparently were unaffected. The fourth baby was a severely erythroblastotic infant, who was treated with exchange transfusion and survived after a very stormy neonatal period. The blocking titer just prior to delivery in this pregnancy was 1 to 512, and a strongly positive reaction to an indirect Coomb’s test was obtained on the mother at this time.

Her last menstrual period was on December 24, 1954. The expected date of confinement was October 1, 1955. Therapy with cvp in a dosage of 6 capsules a day was begun on February 1, 1955. Initial titer studies showed; blocking titer, 1 to 256; agglutinating titer, negative; indirect Coomb’s, strongly positive. Her prenatal course was essentially uneventful. At the thirty-seventh week titer studies were reported as follows: blocking, 1 to 512; agglutinating, negative; indirect Coomb’s, strongly positive. Spontaneous labor was uncomplicated and delivery occurred on September 22, 1955.

The baby was a 7 pound 8 ounce female, in good condition, with no jaundice noticed at birth. Laboratory studies on cord blood were reported as follows: Rh positive; direct Coomb’s, weakly positive; hemoglobin, 20 grams; red blood cell count, 5.4 million; serum bilirubin, 5.0 milligrams per cent. Because of the past history, and because the baby had a positive Coomb’s, an exchange transfusion was done. The baby had an uneventful neonatal period and left the hospital with the mother on the fourth postpartum day. It was the opinion of both the pediatrician and the obstetrician, who had taken care of this patient in her last pregnancy, that this baby was a healthier baby and less affected than her predecessor.

DISCUSSION

The seemingly most dramatic results were obtained in Cases 2, 3, and 4. These patients, although having delivered erythroblastotic infants before, showed no~titer rise throughout their pregnancies, and the present infants were completely unaffected, as evidenced clinically and by laboratory studies. In Cases 1, 5, and 6, base-line titers were present early in gestation, which apparently represented holdover antibody titers from previous immunization. In all of these the titer rise was only slight. One would expect that under ordinary circumstances these infants would be at least as severely affected as their predecessors, and probably more so. However, it was the opinion of the attending physicians in all of these cases that these infants were healthier and less affected than the previous ones. These infants received exchange transfusion because it would not be fair to compromise the current principles of therapy of erythroblastosis fetalis on the basis of an unproved drug, but it was believed by all concerned that because these infants were only mildly affected exchange transfusion probably was not necessary. It would be rather presumptuous to forecast a cure-all for erythroblastosis fetalis on such a short series of cases. However, based on these cases, there is evidence that the bioflavonoid compounds do have some value in the prevention or reduction in severity of erythroblastosis fetalis. Only similar studies with larger series of cases such as these will give the ultimate answer, and such studies are now being undertaken. For the present time, however, it must be emphasized that the best available treatment of erythroblastosis fetalis is the proper timing of delivery and exchange transfusion in the newborn infant. These principles should not be put aside in favor of an, as yet, unproved drug.

REFERENCES

  • 1. Jacobs, W. M. Modern concepts in the management of the Rh negative obstetrical patient. Med. Rec,, Houston, 1955, 49: 422.

  • 2. Jacobs, W. M., and Kohn, M. I. Erythroblastosis fetalis; a review of 73 cases, Obst. Gyn., in press.

  • 3. Javbrt, C. T. Decidual bleeding in pregnanev. Ann. N. York Acad. Sc., 1955, 61: 637.

  • 4. Lee, R. E., Goebel, D., and Fulton, T. A. Anatomical and functional change in the peripheral vascular system during certain induced increases in vascular fragility. Ann. N. York Acad. Sc., 1955, 61: 660.

  • 5. Mengert, W. F., and associates. Placental transmission of erythrocytes. Am. J. Obst. Gyn., 1955, 69: 678.       '                   '

Surgery, Gynecology & Obstetrics January i960

I         FURTHER EXPERIENCE WITH BIOFLAVONOID

|        COMPOUNDS IN RH IMMUNIZED WOMEN

WARREN M. JACOBS, M.D., F.A.C.S., Houston, Texas

In 1956, a preliminary report dealing with the use of bioflavonoid compounds in Rh immunized mothers was published (1). Much has been written on the effect of bioflavonoid compounds on prevention of capillary fragility, and it is fairly well accepted that the mechanism of Rh isoimmunization is based on the concept that Rh positive fetal cells enter the maternal circulation through a “break” in the placental capillary system. Many investigators have shown with various techniques that, in normal pregnancy, varying degrees of capillary placental “breaks” occur with decidual bleeding and escape of fetal cells into the maternal circulation. If these capillary “breaks” could be eliminated or reduced, thus eliminating or reducing the transfer of Rh positive cells into the circulation of an Rh negative mother, the degree of iso-immunization might possibly be minimized. In Rh negative mothers previously immunized by Rh positive blood transfusions or pregnancy, further iso-immunization might be prevented. Rh antibodies are small and freely cross the placenta, hence antibodies already present would not be affected, but if further transfer of fetal cells could be prevented, further degree of iso-immunization might be forestalled. Six cases were presented in an attempt to illustrate this point, but 6 Eclated cases prove very little.

It is believed that if a comparison of Rh negative mothers given bioflavonoids throughout their pregnancy could be made with a similar group not given bioflavonoids but otherwise handled identically, i.e., pre-

J ioni the Department of Obstetrics and Genecology, Baylor •diversity College of Medicine, Texas Medical Center, Bous-hi. term delivery if feasible and early exchange transfusion to the newborn infant, more evidence as to the value of this drug could be ascertained.

MATERIALS AND METHODS

Seventy-one Rh negative mothers immunized by either pregnancy or blood transfusion with Rh positive blood, i.e., having delivered one or more erythro-blastotic infants or having received a transfusion with Rh positive blood and having demonstrated Rh antibodies in the nonpregnant state, were studied during a given pregnancy which resulted in an Rh positive baby. The final outcome in this group was compared with that in a group of 32 Rh negative mothers similarly immunized, but having received bioflavonoids in the form of CVP capsules of from 400 to 600 milligrams daily, beginning early in pregnancy and continuing until delivery. The two groups were otherwise managed identically—preterm delivery if feasible and prompt exchange transfusion to the newborn.

RESULTS

Group 1 consisted of mothers who had delivered 1 or more infants with mild to moderate erythroblastosis but survived, or mothers who had been immunized with Rh positive blood but had had no previous pregnancy.

Thirty-two such patients in the nonbioflavonoid group were observed. One infant was a hydropic stillborn; 9 were severely jaundiced and anemic and died in the immediate neonatal period in spite of attempts at exchange transfusion. Twenty-two were moderately affected, were given one or more exchange transfusions, and survived.

33


34 Surgery, Gynecology & Obstetrics ■ January 1960

The survival rate was 22 of 32, or 68.8 per cent.

Sixteen such patients in the bioflavonoid group were observed. One infant was severely affected (hydrops) and died shortly after birth. Fifteen were moderately affected and all survived after exchange transfusion. The survival rate was 15 of 16, or 93.7 per cent.

Group 2 consisted of mothers who had delivered 1 or more live-born infants who died in the neonatal period in spite of all attempts at therapy.

Twenty-four such patients in the nonbioflavonoid group were observed. Seven infants were hydropic stillborn and . 17 died in the immediate neonatal period. None survived in this group.

Six such patients in the bioflavonoid group were observed. One infant was a hydropic stillborn; 2 died in the immediate neonatal period; 3 survived after 1 or more exchange transfusions. The survival rate was 3 of 6, or 50 per cent.

Group 3 consisted of mothers who had delivered 1 or more previous stillborn infants.

Fifteen such patients in the nonbioflavo-

VOL. 110

noid group were observed. All 15 delivered hydropic stillborn infants.

Ten such patients in the bioflavonoid group were observed. Two infants were hydropic stillborn. Two died almost immediately after birth. Six infants survived after 1 or more exchange transfusions. The survival rate was .6 of 10, or 60 per cent.

SUMMARY

A total of 71 patients in the nonbioflavonoid group produced a total of 22 surviving infants, or 30.9 per cent, whereas a total of 32 patients in the bioflavonoid group produced a total of 24 surviving infants, or 75 per cent.

Offhand, these results would seem striking but it must be admitted that the ' bioflavonoid group is small by comparison and that larger numbers of patients must be treated before more definite conclusions can be reached. Such studies are in progress and future reports will be forthcoming.

REFERENCE

1. Jacobs, W. M. Use of bioflavonoid compounds in the prevention or reduction in severity of erythroblastosis fetalis. Surg. Gyn. Obst., 1956, 102: 233.

EXCERPTA MEDICA Section 10 Obstet & Gynec March 1967 p. 94


In the course of further studies on the action of the C-P vitamin complex in the prevention of hemolytic disease of the newborn, after the 3 cases described in 1961, another group of 6 pregnant women with Rh isoimmunization were treated during pregnancy with 2 00-400 mg daily of bioflavonoids and vit. C. In the 9 cases treated prophylacticaHy, the fetal survival rate was 55.50%, as compared to 44.40% in a group of untreated women. Healthy children, 12 Rh positive and 1 Rh negative, were born of 13 pregnancies in 9 Rh-neaative wo-jnen without sensitization who were treated throughout pregnancy with 2 00 mg of bioflavonoids daily. Some aborted babies revive on their own: MD

W1XXIPEG ICPI - Abortion is l. lot m "legalized killing" and cannot be justi-ned by the "illogical" and ‘'ludicrous" arguments put forward to justify it, Dr. 1.

’ C, Merry, a pathologist at the Itiimipeg General Hospital. said yesterday.

He tok! ab Hit 1,500 delegates to the Canadian Hospital Association meeting that cxaminaU >n of t le developing babies thm hn\. been killed by abortion shows that these are humans.

Som? aborted babies have revived on their own, he said. One baby boy was "found whimpering in a garbage bag by the hospital incinerator. waiting to be burned.” He said those who take part in abortions become "blase” to such occurrences.

He said he had brought photographs of aborted fetuses to the meeting, but that these "had been cen-sored." 0 ff ic i a 1 s at the meeting said the slides could not be shown.

Merry described the slides he would have shown, saying these would have illustrated that abortion "is the destruction of human life.”

"Sonne doctors and churches try to justify abortion by calling it necessary for the social and mental health of the mother or by saying that the unborn child is "something less than human.” he said. He called this argument ludicrous.

"if we are to solve out-social and economic problems by killing. :t is totally dlog.c.il to duotroy that unborn child."

V-h" not then destroy grossly abnormal children, such as hydrocephalics— those suffering Iron; water on the brain—who cost society about $6,150 a year to keep? he asked \ similar logic should call for the killing of large numbers of senile persons who are kept in chronic hospitals for about $13,000 each a year.

Merry said aborted infants have been used lor medical experimentation, that doctors and nurses who take part in abortions even- ' t u a 11 y become brutalized and hardened and that abortions have helped promote sexual irres’r'mtbility

"Canada is the only country ii the world to have legalized abortion fur nonmedical reason‘d before contraception was made leg i — by a matter of some Iwo weeks, ' he said.

Doctor’s statement attacked

This week, Dr. W. W. Watters of McMaster University made the statement that abortion should be regard

HABP-32

' '                                 The Spectator, Friday, June'6, 1969

Legalized abortion called case of ‘selective slaughter’

OTTAWA (CP) - Legalized abortion is “selective, slaugh-luE—Senator Rheal Belisle (PCOntario) told the Senate yesterday during debate on second reading of proposed Criminal Code amendments.

“Abortion is a crime


against humanity" a ruthless-, cold-blooded" elimination of a human life already in existence, “ he said.

He was supported by Senator J. M. Macdonald (PC-Nova Scotia) who called abortion “a crime which calls to the very heavens for vengeance” because it is perpetrated on defenceless beings.

THE CODE amendments, already approved by the Commons,, would empower three-member committees - to allow therapeutic abortions in approved hospitals where _ it was certified a mother’s life or health was endangered by continued pregnancy.

The bill would also permit homosexual acts between consenting adults in private.

Senator Belisle said legal homosexuality in Canada would be a menace, not only to youth, parents and the family, but to society itself.

“To vote for these amendments is to vote for more crime and violence,” he said. “We need stronger laws against sin and crime, not the licensing of homosexuality.”

BOTH SENATORS expressed fears that more liberal abortion laws would lower the value of human life and might lead to removal of other groups from the law’s protection.                      •

“If we accept this in principle, we need only the passage of time to reach the position, of placing a lower value on other stages of human life whether it be the aged, the infirm, the deformed person or those who don’t agree with us,” Senator Belisle said.

aS theory that abortion

does not stand up when... ope considers that it is. forced on the unborn child.”

Senator Macdonald warned that once the sanctity of human life is attacked at the weakest point, “then step by step it can be brought into question all along the line.”

ABORTION WAS a serious violation ^of moral. law-. To pass the amendment ’ would be an act contrary as well to the “noble tradition of the legal s y s t e m” which was meant to protect life, not destroy it.

Senator Belisle said it has been established by outstanding medical experts that the fetus after five days is a human being. To kill an innocent human being was wrong..

“Society must protect the human fetus as it does the baby fresh from the maternity ward,” he said.

Large numbers of persons totally rejected any suggestion that abortion was the cure-all for squalor, misery and hunger.

“EVEN THOUGH we know that many babies leaving the hospital will live in the slums of Toronto, Montreal or in impoverished Indian settlements, no one seriously advocates a compulsory abortion law such that the child is not to be brought into these miserable surroundings.

“We know that there are better answers than this.”

Senator Belisle said abortion would seem to answer many problems of the welfare state which promised security from the cradle to the grave and then allowed abortion to remove the possibility of any access to the cradle.

England had a great housing shortage. This would appear to be one of the reasons for passing a law allowing abortions for social reasons.

“We here in Canada are now faced with a housing shortage, while in the city of Toronto people who are unable to find homes are turning their children over to the Children’s Aid Society. Do we contemplate the same solution there?” he asked.

Debate on the amendments was adjourned..

HABS-12/72                         .

4 The Spectator, Tuesday, December 12, 1972

Abortions rise by almost one-third

OTTAWA (CP) — Abortions in the first six months of 1972 increased by nearly 33 per .cent over the same period in 1971, Statistics Canada reported yesterday.

Hospitals reported 18,801 abortions on Canadian resi-* dents in the "first" half of 1972, up from 14,168 for the same period in 1971. There were 16 abortions performed on women with foreign residence.

In terms of the number of live births, the abortion rate js one for every 10 live births or 10.1 per cent. ~

THE FIGURES were reported in the daily bulletin issued by the health and welfare division of Statistics Canada.

All provinces showed increases compared with rates for the first half of 1971. The largest increase in actual numbers was in Ontario, where there were 9,844 abortions in six months of 1972 compared with 7,267 in the same period in 1971 — an increase of 35 per cent.

The largest percentage increases were in the Yukon and Northwest Territories. They showed an increase of 300 per cent based on halfyear figures of 24 in 1972 and 6 in 1971.

NEWFOUNDLAND, which reported 77 abortions in the first half of 1972 compared with 30 in the same period in ■ 1971, had a percentage increase of 156 per cent.

British Columbia again had the highest rate of all provinces, the report said, with 22.4 abortions for every 100 live births. However, it showed the smallest increase — 16 per cent — compared with the 1971 period.

Newfoundland had the lowest abortion rate with 1.2 abortions for 100 live births.

When to ciamp the umbilical cord— whether immediately after delivery or a few minutes later—has been a controversial question for years. Now a South African obstetrician goes beyond even those who advocate late clamping. He says flatly that the cord should not be damped at all on the mother’s side.

The time needed to complete the third stage of labor and the blood loss in this period can be greatly reduced if the cord is left unclamped and allowed to bleed, claims Dr. Michael C. Botha, senior resident in the department of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Cape Town. Dr. Botha, who is spending the year as a fellow in gynecologic surgery at the University of Louisville, maintains that damping obstructs the normal mechanism of third-stage labor and can actually create the complications of retained placenta, postpartum hemorrhage, and Rh isoimmunization.

At the root of Dr. Botha’s ideas

HELPED

are his Observations that primitive Bantu women traditionally do not touch the cord until after the expulsion of the placenta and that they seem to find the third stage of labor far less troublesome than Western sophisticates. He reports in the South African Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology (Vol. 6, No. 2) that he saw the unusual obstetrics cases occurring in a population of 26,000 Bantu over a ten-year period. “I found many other complications, but a retained placenta was seldom seen. If called to a case, I usually found that only the terminal part of the membranes was still in the vagina and had merely to be lifted out.

Blood transfusion for a postpartum hemorrhage was never necessary.”

When bearing-down pains begin, parturient women of the most primitive Bantu tribes squat on their-haunches, as if defecating. Once the infant is born, the woman remains in the squatting position, watching her new baby. The placenta then delivers itself without any maternal effort. After the placenta has been delivered ' —by gravity—the membranes usually remain in the vagina. The woman then raises herself on her haunches, and the membranes fall out. Only then does she attend to the cord.

Besides avoiding certain postpartum complications, this method of delivery also seems to result in a bloodgain for the infant. Dr. Botha cites a 1965 study indicating that about 89 cc of blood flows down the cord from the placenta after delivery c’ the child—blood that would be wasted if the cord were clamped and cut early.

With these findings in mind, Dr. Botha has managed 800 parturient white women over the past ten years, using oxytocic drugs, letting the cord bleed, and applying the Brandt-Andrews maneuver to help in the expulsion of the placenta. In none of these cases was the placenta retained, nor did any of the women suffer a postpartum hemorrhage that made a blood transfusion necessary.

To assess more precisely the effects of leaving the cord unclamped, Dr. Botha did a comparative study of 60 consecutive deliveries among white women. He clamped the cord in 30 and left it unclamped in the other 30. The cases were selected irrespective of age or parity, and the deliveries were all normal.

In these patients, the uterus was not handled until after the expulsion of the placenta, and the placenta was not handled until the mother felt the urge to bear down after the birth of her baby. The blood from the cord and from the uterus was collected separately and measured.

The third stage of labor was much quicker when the cord was left unclamped than wrhen it wras clamped, says Dr. Botha. The mean duration was 3.5 minutes when the cord was

32 MEDICAL WORLD LEWS/Earch 14, 19u9

South African specialist says letting the cord bleed on

placental side eases completion of labor



Traditional routine of Bantu women. which apparently reduces postpartum complications, is to attend to the umbilical cord only after placenta has been expelled. This practice is the inspiration for procedure recommended try Cape Town obstetrician.

left unclamped and 10.5 minutes when it was clamped.

In addition, when the cord was not clamped, the mean blood loss during the third stage was much less than when the cord was clamped—3.30 oz as against 7.86 oz. One patient whose cord was clamped lost 26 oz of blood, and the placenta was removed manually to prevent further bleeding.

One of the cord-not-clamped women did lose 15 oz of blood— but it was found that she had needed a blood transfusion for postpartum hemorrhage after a previous delivery. Moreover, in two other deliveries she had lost more than 20 oz of blood each time. Another of the patients in the unclamped group lost only 4 oz of blood, although she had had a severe postpartum hemorrhage in a previous delivery.

In these 60 patients, the expulsion of the placenta was studied radiographically. A radiopaque material was injected into the placenta through the umbilical vein by means of a gastric infant-feeding tube. Then, in the unclamped cases, the cord was allowed to drain while x-ray pictures were taken at one-minute intervals. The first picture was taken immediately after the injection

In the not-clamped cases, only three x-ray pictures could be taken because the placenta began emerging at the vulva three minutes after delivery. But in the cases where the cord was clamped, x-ray pictures taken continued

UNCLAMPED CORD confrrtuecf eight or more minutes after delivery of the infant showed the placenta in situ.

The function of the uterus in the third stage of labor, notes Dr. Botha, is to separate the placenta, to expel it, and to control hemorrhage. All this is effected by contraction and retraction. At delivery of the infant, micro-separation has already occurred due to the uterine retraction that takes place in 1 the second stage. The placenta sepa-I rates because it cannot reduce its own surface area, although the surface to which it adheres does shrink. The same applies to the membranes. “This separation can be illustrated by sticking a postage stamp to a piece of stretched elastic,” says Dr. Botha, i “When the elastic is allowed to shrink, ; the stamp will peel off.”

The placenta is forced in the direction of least resistance, toward the lower segment of the uterus and the vagina. “If the cord is bled, this proc-| ess is so rapid that retraction has not yet taken place in the cervix, and the placenta, reduced in size, is expelled without resistance into the vagina. If the patient is sitting on her haunches, the placenta will fall out by gravity.”

Hemostasis depends on the crisscross arrangement of the uterine muscle, and the tortuous course of the maternal blood vessels supplying the placental site runs through the interstices of these muscles. “These gaps are closed by retraction, thus obliterating the supply of blood to the placental site. Greater retraction, therefore, favors less bleeding.”

So, says Dr. Botha, anything that promotes retraction will quicken separation and expulsion and will reduce . the blood loss. Allowing the placental end of the cord to bleed freely or keeping the cord intact until the placenta is completely expelled, he says, has this effect.

■ “In both methods, the placental volume is reduced and, therefore, uterine contents are reduced by approximately 90 cc of blood,” the South African obstetrician says. “Retraction takes place, squeezing more blood out of the placenta and reducing its size still further.”

If, on the other hand, the cord is clamped, then the “counterresistance

MEDICAL WORLD NEWS/Mcr-h 14.

from the placenta may be so great that retraction may come to an end. The placenta will then be separated by retroplacental blood, which, in my opinion, is not normal but abnormal. This takes place slowly, and by the time the placenta is separated, the cervix has also retracted. The placenta is bulky, due to the blood it contains, and expulsion is difficult. If expulsion is not possible, the inevitable result is that in a certain percentage of cases the placenta will be retained, with associated postpartum hemorrhage.”

Finally, as other investigators have shown, Rh-negative women bearing Rh-positive babies rarely develop antibodies when the placenta is allowed to separate and to be delivered spontaneously with the cord unclamped. This finding, says Dr, Botha, fits in with other evidence that the major risk of isoimmunization occurs during the third stage of labor.

Two Reasons in 300 Years

The reasons given for clamping the cord are few and somewhat tenuous, says Dr. Botha, in a 1909 textbook on obstetrics, Dr. J. G. Williams reckoned that tying the maternal end of the cord served only to avoid bloodying the bedclothes. And the great Glasgow obstetrician J. M. Munro Kerr later referred to the maternal ligature as a means of knowing if the cord had been lengthened so as to see if the placenta had separated. According to Dr. Botha, these two statements are the only reasons given in the literature dating back to 1682 for clamping the maternal end of the cord.

“It would appear,” he concludes, “that we have interfered with normal labor since the 17th century, that we have, in fact, obstructed the normal mechanism by clamping the cord, thereby creating a number of complications.” Therefore he advises giving oxytocics to help the uterine muscle retract, severing the cord after the birth of the child and allowing the placental end to bleed, and, when the bleeding has stopped, removing the placenta during the next contraction. This procedure, Dr. Botha notes, is now routine at the University of Cape Town, a

THE LANCET 493

494 SEPTEMBER 73 1963


Preliminary Communications

TRANSPLACENTAL FCETAL HAEMORRHAGE

AFTER PLACENTAL INJURY DURING ■DELIVERY OR AMNIOCENTESIS

Transplacental haemorrhage may result from operative procedures that damage the placental site. Such bleeding into the maternal circulation may occur during casarean .section or manual removal of the placenta.1-We here report further evidence of significant bleeding into the mother’s circulation during these procedures, and also during amniocentesis. As amniocentesis is now a common elective diagnostic procedure, we think that this complication and its possible significance should be known.

,               OUR STUDY

Fcetal cells were detected in the maternal circulation by the acid-elution technique of Kleihauer and Betke? The technique and its sensitivity are described elsewhere.4 We estimated the quantity of fcetal cells in the maternal circulation from the number of fcetal cells seen during a I O-minute scan of a slide preparation.4

TABLE I—PLACENTAL TRAUMA AND BLEEDING

Diagnosis

No. of women studied

No. of women with more than 1 ml. foetal blood in their circulation

Normal delivery ..     ..

121

- 1

Cxsarean section ..     . -

87

Manual removal of placenta

15

3

Table I shows that trauma to the placenta may cause such bleeding. Caesarean sections were performed because of difficulties in labour, previous sections, placenta prtevia, preeclampsia, and cephalopelvic disproportion. The frequency of fcetal haemorrhage seemed to be independent of the indication for the casarean section. In most cases specimens were taken only after delivery, and one could not be certain whether the transplacental haemorrhage had occurred before or after the procedure, jn one patient in the casarean section group, a sample taken before surgery was negative, whereas after delivery it was estimated that about 8 ml. of fetal blood had entered the maternal circulation. At times~~the"quantlties entering the maternal circulation were large. Only one subject in the normal group was estimated to have received as much as 4 ml. of fetal blood, whereas seven of the caesarean group and all three in the manual-removal group had more than 6 ml. of fetal blood in their circulation. The largest amount was 20 ml.

Thirty-five patients with pre-eclampsia and forty-nine patients with deliveries that required manipulative assistance (mostly mid-forceps) were also studied. In each group only

® Anti-D levels ere expressed as the reciprocal of the antibody titre in saline and albumin. Using the capillary-tube and short albumin-tube techniques respectively? •

one woman had more than 1 ml. of fetal blood, and therefore the frequency did not significantly exceed that of the normals.

Thirteen women were studied immediately after amio-centesis had been performed for the antenatal assessment of Rh haemolytic disease.80 In four the procedure was unsuccessful and the surgeon thought he had entered the placenta with the needle. In two of these four patients the aspirated blood was examined and found to be of fetal origin. In all four women, massive transplacental passage of fetal cells had occurred (table llj. The estimated volume of fetal blood lost into the maternal circulation varied from 10 to 50 ml. These women all had anti-D antibodies before they were tapped. In the three women carrying Rh-positive fetuses, an antibody rise of two dilutions or more was found 2 weeks after the procedure.

DISCUSSION

The importance of manual interference with the placental site was brought to our attention recently by observations in three severe cases of anaemia of the newborn, which were proved to be the result of transplacental fcetal hemorrhage. In two of these three patients, the baby had been born by cesarean section, and delivery had been through the incised placenta. Although this has not been a common cause of this form of neonatal anemia,81 82 Apley et a83 l.84 have described a case of fetal exsanguination owing to transplacental bleeding after injury to the placenta by a Drew-Smythe catheter. Two cases, probably similar, have been reported by Russell et al.85 86

Our findings suggest that operative procedures which damage the placenta can cause massive transplacental hemorrhage, possibly resulting in fcetal exsanguination or jsoimmunisation the mother.11-18~These results confirm those recently reported by others of the dangers of cesarean section and manual removal of the placenta.87 They further indicate that amniocentesis may cause fcetal hemorrhage into the maternal circulation, presumably by damage to the placenta. In our cases the bleeding was of a magnitude which was capable of compromising the life of the foetus and causing a rise in the antibody titre in the mother.

These studies were supported by a Canadian National Health Grant and a U.S. Public Health Grant.

Alvin Zipursky m.d. Manitoba

Assistant Professor of Paediatrics

Janet Pollock

Registered Technician

Bruce Chown

M.d. Manitoba

'612 MARCH 23, 1968


ORIGINAL ARTICLES


THE LANCET


TRANSPLACENTAL HAEMORRHAGE AFTER

‘ EXTERNAL CEPHALIC VERSION

.   '            Andrew Pollock

M.B. Glasg., M.G.J’ath.

SENIOR KISOISTRAlt, OiJl'AHTMLN r OK 11A'.MATOLOGY, SOUTHERN GENERAL HOSPITAL, GLASGOW S.W.l

..          A pregnant woman had an attack of

Summary 1  7 ...   .         .    ...

hxmoglobinuria after external cephalic version tinder anaesthesia. This was shown to be due to , leakage of incompatible blood from her feetus into her own ■ circulation. The case may have important implications * regarding Rh sensitisation.

Case-report

The patient, a 22-year-old primagravida, had been well throughout pregnancy and had no relevant past medical history. At 35 weeks an attempt at external cephalic version was unsuccessful and this was repeated, still unsuccessfully, after the patient had been sedated. 1 week later she was admitted to hospital, where external cephalic version was performed under general anresthesia by an experienced operator who stated that no unusual degree of force was used.

The patient’s subsequent progress gave no cause for anxiety until 4 hours later when she passed dark-red urine. No red blood-cells were seen on microscopic examination, but on spectroscopy, the urine showed the characteristic bands of oxyhatmoglobin, and this (measured as cyanmcthatmoglobin) was present in a concentration of 0'2 g. per 100 ml. Further investigation of the pigment showed that it was resistant to alkali denaturation (Betke 1959) in the manner of fcctal Hb, while on starch-gel electrophoresis (Hutchison ct al. 1963) performed the next day, it moved well ahead of normal adult Hb but just behind a fresh sample of foetal Hb,

The patient’s Hb level and rcd-blood-cell indices were normal. There was a leucocytosis (18,700 per c.mm.) but, apart from a neutrophilia, the stained film showed no abnormality. The reticulocyte-count was 2% and the direct Coombs test was negative. On a film stained after elution in citric-acid buffer (Kleihauer et al. 1957)however, occasional fcetal red bloodcells were seen. The plasma contained free oxyhaemoglobin, and Schumm’s test for metharmaJbumin was strongly positive.

The patient’s blood-group was O Rh positive, and her serum contained anti-A and anti-B at a titre of 1/64. No irregular antibodies were detected by Coombs or enzyme techniques.

She was symptom-free throughout, and her temperature and pulse-rate remained normal. The foetal heart-rate at the onset of the hatmoglobinuria was 160 per minute, but this fell to 140 per minute over the next 2 hours and remained steady. She passed a further specimen of reddish urine containing a trace of Hb 5 hours after the first, but no Hb could be detected in the next specimen the following morning. Very occasional fcctal cells could still be detected in blood-films up to I week later.

It was clear that a transplacental haemorrhage had occurred, and although the volume of urine voided was, not known accurately, the foetal blood-loss was estimated to be at least 25 ml. It was predicted that the child’s blood-group would be A or B, and 4 weeks later this prediction was confirmed when the patient gave birth to a live girl, blood-group A, a low forceps operation being required because of delay in the second stage of labour. The child was rather limp at birth but was rapidly revived and has remained well. 2 days after birth the child’s Hb level was 16-3 g. per 100 ml., and the direct Coombs test was negative. At this time the anti-A titre of the mother’s serum was 1/64 and a weak a-haemolysin was present. The placenta showed evidence of a small area of separation.

.                Discussion

Levine et al. (1941) were the first to postulate that fatal-maternal haemorrhage was the cause of Rh sensitisation and haemolytic disease of the newborn. Cases showing presumptive evidence of fcetal-maternal bleeding were subsequently recorded (Wiener 1948, Wickster 1952), but it was only in 1954 that Chown (1954) described a case of massive transplacental haemorrhage with clear serological proof of fcctal red blood-cells in the mother’s bloodstream. Iltumorrhagds of this magnitude arc probably rare: only one Case leading to severe anaemia in the infant has been seen in the past 4 years at this hospital (1800 deliveries a year). Evidence of an incompatability reaction is rarer still, and although Chown (1954) reported a probable transfusion reaction of this type, I have been unable to trace a record of another case showing htcmoglobinuria.

In contrast, the importance of small leaks from the fcctal to the maternal circulation has become increasingly apparent, since a simple method for the detection of fcctal red blood-cells in blood-smears has been available (Kleihauer et al. 1957). Several groups of workers have investigated the occurrence of these leaks (Taylor and Kullman 1961, Fraser and Raper 1962, Zippursky et al. 1963a, b, Woodrow et al. 1965), and their relationship to Rh sensitisation is clearly established. Many workers consider that most of the sensitising leaks happen at or about the time of delivery (Woodrow ct al, 1965), and the prophylactic use of high titre y-globulin to prevent sensitisation is based on this assumption. Krieger (1966), however, concluded from a serological study that two-thirds, of Rh-sensitised mothers are affected before delivery. The) incidence of transplacental haemorrhage is increased by i manoeuvres such as caesarean section, manual removal of ( ' the placenta, amniocentesis (Zippursky et al. 1963a, b), and forceps delivery (Taylor and Kullman 1961), as well as after accidental haemorrhage (Fraser and Raper 1962). /

Despite these observations little attention seems to have ■. been paid to the possible effects of manipulations per- 1 formed before delivery, even though the dangers of external ■ cephalic version (particularly under anaesthesia) are well i known, and include separation of the placenta (Greenhill/ 1960). Further work is in progress to determine the incidence of transplacental haemorrhage after cephalic version. Blood-samples from fourteen patients undergoing external cephalic version without anesthesia have so far been examined as part of a larger series ’(Pollock and Chen 1968). In twelve, where blood-samples taken before and after cephalic version were available, no fatal cells were seen in either specimen. In a further two cases only samples taken after cephalic version were available and in one of these specimens, from a patient who had a small accidental haemorrhage after version, a significant number of foetal cells was seen. Meanwhile, I suggest that the risk should be considered before attempting this manipulation on a Rh-negative patient, particularly since sensitisation at this stage cannot be prevented by injection of y-globulin, since this might cross the placental barrier and cause .haemolysis of the fatal red blood-cells.

"l^hanlc Dr. J. W. Whitelaw and Dr. T. E. Torbet for helpful

comment.

Zippursky, A., Pollock, J., Chown, B., Israels, L. G. (1963a) Lancet, ii, 493. — — Neclands, P., Chown, B., Israels, L. G. (1963b) ibid. p. 489.

Drug-Induced Hemolysis: Biochemical Considerations

NASROLLAH T. SHAHIDI, M.D.

' It has been known for many years that certain drugs often referred to as “hemolytic” will cause red cell destruction in some susceptible individuals. Among various biochemical defects which predispose to drug-induced hemolysis, erythrocyte glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6-PD) deficiency is by far the most common. It has been estimated that there are at least 100 million individuals with G-6-PD deficiency. While occasionally the drug itself may act as an “oxidant,” in most instances, however, the biotransformation products of the “hemolytic” drugs are responsible agents. Major biologic reactions involved in formation of “oxidant” metabolites in vivo are deacetylation of aromatic acetamido compounds, N- or ring-hydroxylation of aryl amines, ringhydroxylation, and O-dealkylation of phenolic compounds. It is believed that “oxidants” either by autooxidation or through coupled oxidation with oxyhemoglobin generate hydrogen peroxide or free radicals which, if not destroyed by cellular defense mechanisms, will oxidize reduced glutathione, hemoglobin and SH dependent enzymes. These oxidative processes will eventually damage the red cell membrane leading to the leakage of potassium and hemoglobin.

Introduction

The fact that certain drugs possess hemolytic effects has been known since the end of the last century. The hemolytic activity of phenylhydrazine and acetylphenylhydrazine was first described by Dreschfeld in 1888.1 Smillie was probably the first to draw attention to the individual susceptibility to the hemolytic effects of drugs.2 He reported severe hemolytic anemia in a small percentage of his patients treated with betanaphthol for hookworm. Similar observations have been made following the use of 8-aminQquinolone derivatives as antima-larials.3 4 These latter observations led to the discovery of an intrinsic abnormality of red cells3 and low concentration of reduced glutathione (GSH)G which was later shown' to be due to a deficiency of erythrocyte glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6-PD).

Among various biochemical defects which predispose to drug-induced hemolysis, erythrocyte G-6-PD deficiency is by far the most common. Other erythrocytic defects such as hemoglobinopathies

Shahidi—Associate Professor, Department of Pediatrics, University of Wisconsin Medical School, Madison.

* Supported by a grant from N.I.H. AM 11879-2.

BIOGRAPHIC DATA


Dr. Nasrollah T. Shahidi received his B.S. degree from the University of Montpellier. France, and his M.D. from Sorbonne University, Paris. He received his pediatric training at the Hopital-des-Enfants Matades. Paris; Baltimore City Hospitals, Baltimore, Maryland and the Children's Hospital Medical

Doctor Shahidi is the


Center in Boston, where he also served on the faculty for three years, author of numerous scientific papers in the field of hematology, and a member of several scientific societies. He joined the University of Wisconsin Medical School in 1966 as an Associate Professor in the Department of Pediatrics, and as the Hematologist and Director of Research in the Hematology Laboratories at the Children's Hospital.

Birth Defects: Original Article Series. Vol. VI, No. 2; June, 1970.


10 DRUG-INDUCED HEMOLYSIS: BIOCHEMICAL CONSIDERATIONS


predisposing to hemolysis by drugs, defective synthesis of GSH, or GSH reductase deficiency are scarce,8 Abnormal drug biotransformation resulting in excessive formation of oxidant metabolites in vivo, as recently described,9 is probably also uncommon'.

According to a recent WHO report there are more than 100 million persons with G-6-PD deficiency.1(1 Since these individuals are potentially susceptible to a variety of commonly. used drugs, one is always faced with the possibility of iatrogenic hemolysis. Since the discovery of G-6-PD deficiency a voluminous body of literature has appeared. Most investigations, however, have focused on the quantitative and qualitative aspect of G-6-PD. The nature of hemolytic agents, the biochemical mechanism leading to hemolysis and particularly the interaction of hemolytic drugs, or their biotransformation products, with various G-6-PD mutants, have not been fully explored. The aim of this discussion is to focus attention on these less emphasized or still debated aspects of drug-induced hemolysis.

For a better understanding of the hemolytic action of some of the well-known drugs the first part of this paper will be concerned with the discussion of their biotransformation and the nature of their active (“oxidant”) metabolites. The second part will be devoted to the discussion of the effects of these “oxidants” on the red cell, and the mechanism whereby they cause hemolysis.

8. The Nature of "Oxidants" Derived from Some ©if the Well-Known Drugs

Most drugs when ingested undergo significant biochemical transformation. The products of biotransformation are not only different, chemically, but also pharmacologically from the administered drugs. Among various biochemical reactions involved in the biotransformation of common “hemolytic” drugs deacetylation of aromatic acetamido compounds, N-by-droxylation of aryl amines" ring-hydroxvlation of aryl amine and phenolic compounds and O-dealkvla-tion are of particular interest. Table I summarizes some of the well-known drugs and the products of their biotransformation suspected to cause red cell damage. While in most instances these metabolites have been isolated from the urine or blood in man, occasionally conclusions have been drawn from animal studies. Although many of the reactions which drugs undergo in laboratory animals are found to occur in man, the rate of these reactions, however, is often different. Furthermore, not only does man differ from laboratory animals in the rate of biochemical reaction involving drugs, but various groups of people differ from one another in this respect. Consequently, in addition to the nature of toxic metabolites, their con- , centration in the blood and the rate of their inactivation have to be considered.

Among various aromatic acetamido compounds ac-


TABLE 1

■’Hemolytic" drugs and their "oxidant" metabolite

DRUGS      REDOX METABOLITES OXIDIZED FORM






Cl




A) Acetanilide. A-1) Phenylhydroxylamme. A-2) o-Ami-nophenol. A-3)p-Aminophenol.

B) Acetophenetidin. B-1) p-Ethoxyphenylhydroxyla-mine. C-2l ..-Hydroxyphenetidin

C) Sulfanilamide. C-1) p-Hydroxylammobenzosulfona-, mide. C-2) 3 Hydroxysulfanilamide.

l/v'-D} Salicylic acid. D-1) Gentisic acid.

E) 6-Methoxyaminoquinofone derivative. E-1) 5,6-Quinoline quinone.



etanilid and acetophenetidin, the well-known analgesics, have been reported to cause hemolysis in G-6-PD deficient individuals following therapeutic doses, 1 These compounds can also induce hemolysis, although to a lesser degree, in normal subjects when taken in large “toxic doses,” Upon ingestion a small part of these drugs is deacetylated in man and in most laboratory animals,1112 Acetanilid which undergoes more extensive deacetylation is far more hemolytic than acetophenetidin. N-acety p-aminophenol which is the major metabolite of these compounds undergoes no significant deacetylation and this drug has been found to be innocuous to patients with G-6-PD deficiency.10 The concentration of deacetylated products depends not only on the rate of deacetylation, but also on the rate of reacetylation. According to Bray and associates,the deacetylase from rabbit liver has significantly higher activity for the orthosubstituted aromatic acetamido compounds than for the para-substituted drugs. While deacetylation remains an important step for the production of “toxic” metabolites, N- or ring-hydroxylation are essential steps. These latter biologic reactions, as most other reactions involving the metabolism of lipid-soluble drugs, are catalyzed by NADPH dependent enzymes in liver microsomes. Thus, aniline and p-phenetidin which are respectively deacetylated products of acetanilid and acetophenetidin, are assumed to undergo both ring- and N-hydroxylation.14'10 Phenylhydroxylamine, which is the product of N-hydroxylation of aniline, oxidizes hemoglobin in the presence of oxygen.16 Nitrosobenzene is the reaction product of phenylhydroxylamine.1. It has been shown in cats that one mole of phenylhydroxylamine produces up to 50 equivalents of methemoglobin.16 The mechanism whereby phenylhydroxylamine produces several equivalents of methemoglobin was elucidated by Kiese et al.19 These investigators showed that in the red cell nitrosobenzene is reduced back to phenylhydroxylamine by electron transfer from NADPH. The reaction is catalyzed by NADPH dependent diapho-rase. It should be recalled that the same diaphorase is responsible for the reduction of methylene blue and similar dyes. Indeed, as shown by Lohr and Waller,20 the rate of methemoglobin formation with nitrobenzene is significantly slower in G-6-PD deficient-red cells as compared to normal erythrocytes. The fact that acetanilid, which is partially, transformed to phenylhydroxylamine, does cause hemolysis in G-6-PD deficient individuals, suggests that either other biotransformation products of acetanilid are involved or the nitrosobenzene is reduced outside of the red cell. These questions remain unanswered. The role of o-aminophenol in the production of methemoglobinemia has also to be considered. In this respect, it is of interest to note that animals who excrete more o-aminophenol as compared to p-aminophenol are more susceptible to the toxic effect of aniline.11 From studies by Kiese,21 however, it seems that N-hydroxylation plays a more important role in the aniline-induced methemoglobinemia than ringhydroxylation. Acetophenetidin (phenacetin) differs from acetanilid in that it has an ethoxy group in para position to the aromatic nitrogen. This analgesic is less extensively deacetylated than acetanilid and, as a result, its hemolytic activity is not as great as that of acetanilid.

The possibility of N-hydroxylation of p-phenetidin resulting in the formation of p-ethoxyphenylhydroxylamine and its product of oxidation, nitrosophenetol. was investigated by Baader et al’~ who found no relationship between the concentration of blood nitrosophenetol and that of methemoglobin. From their studies they concluded that other metabolites were probably involved in p-phenetidin-induced methemoglobinemia. Recent studies have indicated that ring-hydroxylation of p-phenetidin resulting in the formation of 2-hydroxyphenetidin may play a role in acetophenetidin-induced methemoglobinemia?

Sulfanilamide and its derivatives, which are also known to cause severe hemolysis in G-6-PD deficient individuals, belong to the aniline family and consequently are subject to similar type biotransformation. Except in the dog the main biochemical reaction of sulfanilamide is acetylation. A small portion of this compound undergoes ring-hydroxylation with the formation of 3-hydroxylsulfanilamide both in man and in laboratory animals.'4 This compound which is an o-aminophenol could oxidize hemoglobin to methemoglobin.14 More recent studies have shown that both rat and human liver microsomes catalyze N-4-hydroxylation of sulfanilamide in the presence of NADPH and molecular oxygen.23 It has been further demonstrated that p-hydroxyaminobenzolsulfonamide and its product, of oxidation p-nitrososulfanilamide are more potent methemoglobin formers than 3-by-droxysulfanilamide.24

.Acetylsalicylic acid (ASA), which is one of the most widely used drugs, is known as a mild hemolytic agent in individuals with G-6-PD deficiency even in high doses. However, severe red cell destruction following ingestion of ASA has been reported on several occasions to occur following therapeutic doses of _         24 2b

.aspirin.

It i" known that upon ingestion ASA is rapidly deacetylated and thus converted to salicylic acid. It is obvious as judged by structural formulas that neither ASA nor salicylate are redox compounds. The hemolytic. effect of salicylate which will be discussed later is probably partially due to ring-hydroxylation of this compound. Roseman and Dorfman2' have reported that 3rr of a 1.8 gm dose in man is converted to gentisic acid. Higher values, 4 to 8'7, have been reported by Kapp and Cobum.26 The occurrence of traces of other congeners such as 2:3-dihydroxy benzoic and 2:3:5:-trihydroxy benzoic acid have also been reported.14 It has been shown that gentisate can markedly stimulate pentose phosphate pathway."

12 DRUG-INDUCED HEMOLYSIS: BIOCHEMICAL CONSIDERATIONS

This action has been ascribed to the loss of electrons resulting in the formation of 2-carboxy-l ,4-benzo-quinone. Our studies have revealed that the incubation of gentisate and hemoglobin as intact red cell, results in the accumulation of methemoglobin accompanied by a drop in GSH (Table IF).

Finally, 8-amindquinoline drugs deserve particular emphasis for not only are they useful as antimalarials, but also because of their historic place in the discovery of biochemical abnormalities of sensitive erythrocytes. Although several reports have indicated that primaquine in vitro can cause red cel! damage/0 "i'! there are reasons to believe that the hemolytic effect of primaquine is due to the product of its biotransformation. First of all, in vitro, primaquine is not more deleterious to G-6-PD deficient erythrocytes as compared to normal cells'10 ,2; secondly, it has been found that following ingestion of primaquine, the clinical onset of hemolysis appears two to four days after the ingestion of the initial dose/4 In addition, during administration of primaquine an anticatalase factor has been demonstrated in the plasma of both normal and G-6-PD deficient individuals/0 This anticatalase activity, which could not be demonstrated in the plasma until four to six hours after drug administration/’ reached a maximum in eight hours and was maintained for at least another 16 hours. From the study of Zubrod and associates36 it seems that the highest plasma concentration of undergraded drug is reached in six hours and thereafter it falls rapidly and is barely detectable after 24 hours. The first step in the biotransformation of primaquine is the 0-dealkylation of 6-methoxy group followed by hydroxylation at 5 position on the quinoline ring. Josephson and associates3’ have identified 5, 6 quinoline-quinone derivative which i.-< throught to be the active metabolite. Quinoline-quinone derivatives are redox compounds and capable of

Salicylate (10a* moles) and gentisate (6 g moles) were incubated alone and in combination for two hours at 37 C° with 1 ml of 50% suspension of normal red cells in buffered isotonic saline containing 2 gm% glucose. Note the additive effect of salicylate.

acting as oxidants. Detailed studies of biotransformations of 8-aminoquinoIines have not been carried out in man. Brodie and Udenfriend18 observed that a few drops of urine or plasma from dogs or humans who were receiving primaquine produced methemoglobin when added to hemolyzed red cells and hemolysis when added to intact red cells.

II. The Mechanism of Action of "Hemolytic" Drags or Their Siotransformation on Red Cells

There is now ample evidence to suggest that redox compounds either by autooxidation or coupled oxidation with oxyhemoglobin result in the formation of hydrogen peroxide or free radicals. The involvement of radicals or hydrogen peroxide in the formation of methemoglobin by redox compounds in the presence of oxygen has been considered since 1878 by Hoppe-Seyler/9 The formation of H2O2 by phenylhydroxylamine in the presence of oxyhemoglobin was demonstrated by Rostorfer and Cormier/6 That free radicals may also appear in the reaction of phenylhydroxylamine was suggested by paramagnetic resonance absorption studies by Wahler and associates/1 Using irreversible inhibition of catalase by 3-amino-1, 2, 4-triazole as an indicator of hydrogen peroxide, Cohen and Hochstein42 have shown that hydrogen peroxide is produced by a variety of “oxidants.” However, some hemolytic compounds such as acetylphenylhydrazine seem to possess both properties, namely, to generate hydrogen peroxide and to catalyze directly the interaction between NADPH and oxygen.43

The free radical or hydrogen peroxide do not attack hemoglobin or other red cell constituents in the same fashion. For instance, while coupled oxidation of oxyhemoglobin and ascorbic acid or phenylhydrazine produces methemoglobin, but also a significant amount of sulfhemoglobin (denatured hemoglobin), the coupled oxidation of aminophenols or phenylhydroxylamine with oxyhemoglobin produces methemoglobin and no noticeable amounts of sulfhemoglobin. No ready explanation for these findings is presently available.

It has been shown that reduced glutathione is oxidized more rapidly than hemoglobin when red cells are exposed to a variety of oxidant compounds.4J'44 Methemoglobin and sulfhemoglobin appear only after depletion of GSH.4'

Ilie mechanism whereby “oxidant” agents cause hemolysis in vitro or in vivo remains unknown. It is obvious that there is no direct relationship between methemoglobinemia and hemolysis. Methemoglobinemia may be present in drug-induced red cell damage in high concentration in normal individuals in whom little or no hemolysis occurs. On the other hand, if the methemoglobin-containing cell is rapidly destroyed, such as in G-6-PD deficient individuals, methemoglobinemia is absent or only moderate. The concentration of methemoglobin, when measured along with other parameters of cell injury, ie GSH, sulfhemoglobin and hemolysis, is of great value to assess the toxic effects of drugs in vitro on erythrocytes.

' From various investigations it is apparent that hemolysis of red cells is more related to erythrocyte GSH.45 47 It is now well established that this compound which is present in high concentration in red cells is maintained in the reduced form through the action of glutathione reductase which is a NADPH dependent enzyme.

It has been proposed48 that. HaO2 generated at low concentration within the red cells is detoxified mainly by glutathione peroxidase. This enzyme which was described by Mills49 is GSH dependent. Inadequate regeneration of GSH as in G-6-PD deficiency would curtail the activity of this enzyme and would result in the accumulation of hydrogen peroxide. However, the role of catalase in the detoxification of hydrogen peroxide has also been emphasized.44 A recent report by Paniker and Iyer50 suggests that both catalase and glutathione peroxidase are involved in the detoxification of hydrogen peroxide produced by diffusion technic. Recent studies have shown that disappearance of intracellular GSH, as caused by N-ethylmaleimide, . does not result in appreciable hemolysis in vitro.51'52

In addition, G-6-PD deficient red cells may rapidly become GSH depleted when incubated with acetylphenylhydrazine or related compounds,33 and yet they are not more sensitive to hemolysis than normal cells similarly treated.30'i2,04 Using various sulfhydryl inhibitors Jacob and Jandl0,0 have shown that blockade of the membrane SH group of red cells results in their rapid trapping in the spleen. Weed and associates56 have shown that low concentration of oxidant compounds causes membrane injury as evidenced by leakage of potassium and entry of sodium. Another important factor in drug-induced hemolysis is enzyme inhibition or inactivation by hemolytic drugs or products of their biotransformation. The oxidant drugs can exert their damaging effect on enzymes through various' mechanisms. The oxidation of Fe++ in iron-containing enzyme such as catalase is to be expected. Indeed, it has been observed11 that the activity of catalase decreases markedly in G-6-PD deficient individuals as early as 24 hours after the initial dose of primaquine. It has been shown that some redox compounds in low concentration inhibit ■ catalase.01 Inactivation of SH dependent enzymes by SH oxidation is another possible mechanism. It has been suggested’8 that oxidative destruction of glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GA-3-PD), an SH dependent enzyme, may play a role in the mechanism of drug-induced hemolysis. Powell et al,M however, could not demonstrate a drop in GA-3-PD during primaquine-induced hemolysis in sensitive subjects. Studies by Kosower and associates60 indicate that a decline in the concentration of GSH following incubation of red cells with acetylphenylhydrazine is not associated with a decrease in the activity of GA-3-PD. However, a decrease in the activity of GA-3-PD as induced by N-ethylmaleimide may occur in the terminal stage where the cellular GSH has completely disappeared. There has been more agreement on the inhibition of hexokinase by “hemolytic” agents such as phenylhydrazine?1,63 Mohler and Williams63 have shown that the ATP content of G-6-PD deficient red cells incubated in vitro with phenylhydrazine decreases more markedly than in normal red cells incubated under the same conditions. ■

Finally, another mechanism affecting the enzyme system of red cells is the direct inhibition of certain red cell enzymes by hemolytic drugs. It has been known for many years that atabrine and quinine,64 as well as sulfanilamide,63 inhibit G-6-PD.'Nitrofurantoin has been shown to inhibit glutathione reductase?6 The inhibitory effect of several drugs known to induce hemolysis in G-6-PD deficient subjects has been investigated by Desforges and associates6' on yeast G-6-PD and 6-phosphogkiconic dehydrogenase. These investigators found that these two NADPH dependent dehydrogenases were inhibited by most common hemolytic agents. Data on the inhibitory effects of drugs on various mutants of G-6 PD are not available. Such studies may explain individual variation in response to the same drug. Our own interest in this aspect of drug hemolysis began with the study of a nine-year-old boy with G-6-PD deficiency associated with congenital nonsphero-cytic hemolytic anemia. The patient, as previously reported by Westring and Pisciotta,36 developed severe intravascular hemolysis following therapeutic doses of aspirin on several occasions. Although it has been repeatedly emphasized that salicylates are mild hemolytic agents in patients with G-6-PD deficiency even in high dosage, the review of the literature revealed that acute red cell destruction following ASA ingestion has been reported.24'36

Since salicylate itself is not a redox compound and has no oxidative properties on hemoglobin it was thought that a metabolite of salicylate, probably gentisic acid, was the hemolytic agent. On this basis the red cells from this nine-year-old patient were tagged with °‘Cr and transfused into a normal compatible individual who then received 75 mg/day of gentisic acid. This resulted in no noticeable change in the OICr la T. However, when 150 mg of gentisic acid were given, which is approximately equivalent to 3 gm of salicylate, the chromium I? T was reduced by 50G. Further increase in the dosage of gentisic acid resulted in further decrease in red cell survival. The survival of the red cells of two other patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (A type) known to have taken salicylates without side effects was not effected even with doses of gentisic acid as high as 450 mg. In comparing the effect of

-                                                   ■                                . f .                                                                             i.

14 DRUG-INDUCED HEMOLYSIS: BIOCHEMICAL CONSIDERATIONS

salicylate and gentisic acid on the survival of the patient’s red cell, it was found that salicylate had more pronounced effect on the erythrocyte survival than gentisic acid. Consequently, it was thought that salicylate may have additional effect on the patient’s erythrocytes. In vitro studies, indeed, revealed that while salicylate alone did not have any noticeable oxidative effect on the patient’s red cells, it enhanced markedly the oxidative properties of gentisic acid. Further investigation66 revealed that while salicylate competitively inhibited the normal G-6-PD and A type to a small extent, it markedly inhibited the enzyme from the patient.
