Discussion

TIMOS- VALAES asked why small children are much more sensitive to drug-induced hemolysis than older adults with the same kind of defect. SHAHIDI replied that the drug maybe present in higher concentrations in children because of differences in the metabolism or handling of the drug.

SUMNER YAFFE raised the question whether gentisic acid itself would cause hemolysis and pointed out that in normal subjects, the rate of formation of gentisic acid constitutes less than IT of all metabolites formed by salicylates. SHAHIDI replied that gentisic acid did not cause hemolysis in normal subjects indicating that only in this patient is the red cell metabolism different. Ac- ' cording to various investigations it seems that 3 to 8'7 of therapeutic doses of salicylate are converted to gentisic acid.

RUDI SCHMID commented on the fact that there is increasing evidence that hemoglobin is destroyed by the oxidative processes such as hydrogen peroxide or other oxidizing agents, and this hemoglobin is no longer related to bilirubin. He pointed out that when Heinz bodies or heme exposed to phenylhydrazine is given to the animal, it is not converted to bilirubin but is excreted in the form of other labeled metabolites which are different from bilirubin.

TIMOS VALAES mentioned that all newborn infants with Heinz body formation also showed extreme jaundice. SCHMID agreed with this and explained that in every case of Heinz body hemolytic anemia, there is a vast overproduction of bile pigment, but emphasized that it has not been possible to show a quantitative relationship between the anemia and the jaundice.

AUDREY BROWN asked whether the Heinz bodies are unstable in drug-induced anemia. SCHMID did not know, but said that if you take Heinz bodies produced in vitro and inject them into animals as in experimental protoporphyrin, the heme is to a large extent not recovered as bilirubin or CO:, but comes out in bile in the form of other labeled breakdown products. SY’DNEY GELLIS asked how you make Heinz bodies. SCHMID described the method published by Jandi where you take a hemoglobin solution and expose it to phenylhydrazine in the presence of air, and get a precipitating material from which you can spin off Heinz bodies. BROWN pointed out that red cells of newborn Infants uniformly act like G-6-PD deficiency red cells in forming Heinz bodies. SCHMID said that red cells in the newborn and particularly in the premature are sensitive to many of these drugs and cited a report where a baby was rubbed with camphor in the chest for respiratory distress and came down with a massive nonspherocytic hemolytic anemia. ROGER LESTER asked why tbe”Hemz”5offies do"noT get~converted to bilirubin. SCHMID replied that when heme is attacked by hydrogen peroxide and other oxidative reductive compounds, there is no longer a substrate for heme oxygenase and this leads to a different pathway for metabolism.

Aspirin and the Newborn

Obstetricians might do well to warn their patients that they should not take

HDRA-33


. . -aspirin products for early labor pains, a study at the University of Alabama Medi- -cal Center suggests. Salicylate was found in the cord serum from 9.5% of 272 neonates tested, but most of the mothers were not aware that products they had taken contained aspirin"In normZTm'fants~T;'a7isitory salicylate toxicity probably has very little effect, says Dr. Paul Palmisano. But he adds that it could be harmful to those threatened by hyperbilirubinemia. One infant had a serum salicylate level of 10.9 mg%. Dr. Palmisano notes that this level ties up 0.35 mg% of the infant’s serum aibumin, which appears to play a role in averting jaundice in the newborn.'

MEDICAL WORLD NEWS/Januory 3, 1969

Cdfltrb hexachlorophene in the oorsery?

In an action disputed by many clinicians, FDA early this month advised the nation’s doctors (via its Drug Bulletin) to discontinue using 3%-or-more hexachlorophene (HCP) products for total-body bathing of infants, and to have those in the nursery wash their hands "scrupulously" before and after handling each infant. The Bulletin noted that with the concurrence of the American Academy of Pediatrics “we recommend dry skin care or washing with plain soap and water or tap water alone for infant care.”

FDA also proposed that the makers (Winthrop produces the most widely used cleanser, pHisoHex) be required to warn users on the label: "Do not use for total body bathing," and “rinse thoroughly after use." The safety action was based on a Winthrop study in which rhesus monkeys scrubbed with pHisoHex daily for three months were shown to have lesions in the cerebellum and brain-stem and accompanying HCP plasma levels of 2.3 pg/ml, not much higher than levels found in neonates discharged from hospital.

The agency challenged HCP efficacy, too, declaring that (based on NAS review findings) "whereas there is no doubt that HCP bathing decreases skin colonization of gram-positive organisms, there is a lack of substantial evidence that HCP washings by themselves will prevent staphylococcal disease. . . .”

Winthrop had 30 days to protest the FDA labeling proposal. A spokesman pointed out that "our researchers scrubbed five to ten times as much pHisoHex into the monkeys’ skin for 90 days instead of the three to six days a baby would receive it; and there wasn't the slightest sign of neurotoxicity in the monkeys at sacrifice These findings must be balanced against 22 years of pHisoHex use on millions of babies without a single recorded case of neurotoxicity when used as directed."

Dr. Louis Gluck, professor of pediatrics at the University of California, San Diego, whose studies at Yale in the early 1960s helped establish the safety and effectiveness of pHisoHex, called the FDA action “abominable." He added: "The agency doesn’t have the hard data to justify its precipitate action, which risks an epidemic of Staphylococcus in nurseries. The simian lesion has never been observed in babies. At this point, the average practitioner doesn’t know what to do.”

May 1972

HDRH-62


EDITOR AS OBSERVER Vol. 11 No. 5 CLINICAL PEDIATRICS 254

Hexachlorophene and "Skin Protection" in the Newborn

r .

JUzY now most pediatricians have heard that not only the safety but even the need for hexachlorophene for routine bathing of infants is being questioned by the FDA and other regulatory agencies. From their review of published studies, a Committee of the American Academy of Pediatrics has placed a number of general principles on record:

  • 1. The levels of hexachlorophene which mav be attained in the blood of newborn infants receiving daily baths with a three per cent solution are close to levels which are neurotoxic for adult rats, Similar brain lesions have been produced in monkevs by applying hexachlorophene to the skin in high doses.

  • 2. "At this time there is little microbiolotjic justification for routine, daily hexachlorp-phene baths for newborn infants. . . . There is no documented experience where this technic has arrested a serious nnrsei-V epidemic. . . . 1 he use of hexachlorophene increases colonization with gram-negative organisms and the incidence of gram-negaiive disease.”

  • 3. “For reasons that have not been defined, the problem of serious staphylococcal disease in nurseries has not been of major importance during the last five scars. as it was ten to 15 years ago.” This epidemiologic subsidence has been unrelated to whether hexachlorophene was used for the skin care of the newborn infants.

  • 4. Because of these considerations, “The safety of daily bathing of infants with hexa-chlurophene-containing solutions has not been established. . . . The use of hexachlorophene for total body bathing of newborn infants in hospital nurseries or at home is contraindicated.”

  • 5. At present the Committee on Fetus and Newborn recommends dry skin care for the newborn infant. Washing when needed should be with tap water, either alone or with plain nonmedicated soap.

G "The two most import int factors iti the transmission of infection from infant to infant are hand contact and breaks in technic. These factors can be minimized In scrupulous liaml v, Lt &>5e entering the nursery as well as just before and just after handling each infant. Either iodophor preparations or a three per cent hexachlorophene emulsion are recommended for hand washing.”.—Condensed from <i '‘Statement’' of the Committee on Fetus and Xc-ivborn. Hmerican Academy of Pediatrics, 1972.

Amer, J, Obstet. Gynec,? January 1, 1971

FETUS, PLACENTA, AND NEWBORN

Reducing neonatal mortality rate with nurse-midwives

BARRY S. LEVY, M.P.H.

FREDERICK S. WILKINSON, M . D .

WILLIAM M . MARINE, M . D ., M.P.H.*

Berkeley, California, and Atlanta, Georgia

Newborn health indices were measured before, during, and after a demonstration nurse-midwife program introduced to relieve a health manpower shortage at a. county hospital in rural California. During the program, prenatal care increased, and prematurity and neonatal mortality rate decreased at the county hospital. After the 3 year program, prenatal care decreased while prematurity rose from 6.6 to 9.8 per cent (p <f 0.02) and neonatal mortality rate rose from 10,3 to 32.1 per 1,000 live births (p jP 005). No significant changes occurred in the same indices for births elsewhere the county throughout the period of study. It is concluded that the discontinuation of the nurse-midwives1 services was the major factor in these changes, and it is suggested that nurse-midwives be used more extensively.

More infants die in the United States than older people with diabetes, breast cancer, and tuberculosis combined,1 In 1968, when our infant mortality rate was 21.7 per 1,000 live births, over 75,000 American-born infants died during their first year of life.2 Our rank among 7 “advanced” countries in infant deaths has declined from fourth to seventh since 1950?

From the Epidemiology Research Training Program, California State Department of Public Health, Berkeley, and the Department of Preventive Medicine and Community Health, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta.

This work supported by N.I.H. Training Grant 5T1 GM 214-16 and Dr. Marine's Milbank Faculty Fellowship.

* Address reprint requests to: William M. Marine, M.D., M.P.H., 69 Buller Street, SE, Atlanta, Georgia 30303.

About two thirds of infant deaths in the United States occur during _the first month pf_life.4 Since most of these first-month, or neonatal, deaths are associated with prematurity, significant reduction in neonatal mortality rate depends on reduced prematurity.5

It has been demonstrated that prematurity (and in turn neonatal deaths) can be reduced by providing prenatal care to more pregnant women. Although 12 visits are generally recommended,®1" studies have shown that infants whose mothers have had any prenatal care have a lower risk of being premature8,9 and, hence, a lower risk of dying during the first month of life. In addition to more prenatal care, another way of reducing neonatal deaths may be with improved care during labor and delivery, and during the infant’s first few days of life.

Volume 109

Number 1


Reducing neonatal deaths with nurse-midwives 51

These objectives of improved and more extensive care might be easily achieved were it not for the shortage and maldistribution of physicians in maternal and infant care in the United States. With the available physician manpower and the predicted increase in American births, Hellman recently estimated that by 1980 about half of all deliveries in this country would be on the ward services of hospitals without assignable physicians.10 This shortage in manpower for deliveries reflects similar shortages for prenatal and postnatal care.

One proposed solution to these shortages is the more extensive use of nurse-midwives, or nurse obstetric assistants (NOA’s) as they are sometimes called. A nurse-midwife is a registered nurse who has had additional formal training (from 6 to 24 months) in maternal and infant care so that she can manage normal pregnancies. Nurse-midwives are never independent practitioners; they always function within the framework of a physician-directed health service. With NOA’s managing normal pregnancies, physicians can concentrate on the few abnormal pregnancies.

The effectiveness of nurse-midwives in reducing infant mortality has been demonstrated abroad, and in the U. S. by the Frontier Nursing Service in Kentucky since 1935.11 With few states allowing nursemidwives to practice, however, few opportunities were available to test further the feasibility and the potential benefits of nursemidwives. Such an opportunity became available from 1960 to 1963 with the nurse obstetric assistant (NOA) program at Madera County Hospital in California.

The Madera County NOA Program. This program was established in response to critical problems at the county hospital in the late 1950’s. Serving mainly the medically indigent in a poor agricultural county of about 40,000, the 148 bed hospital -was plagued with serious physician and nurse shortages. The full-time staff had been ranging from two to five general practitioners. There were no Board-certified specialists in any field in the entire county. More than half of the pregnant women received late prenatal care or none at all, and it was estimated (but not documented) that about one fifth of the 400 annual deliveries there were not attended by physicians. The prematurity and neonatal mortality rates were much higher than at the two other hospitals in the county.12

Attempting to solve these problems, the Health Department established a 3 year, $68,400, demonstration nurse-midwife (NOA) program with special legal permission from the State for the nurse-midwives to perform normal deliveries. From July, I960, through June, 1963, two nurse-midwives managed most normal pregnancies, from prenatal care to labor and delivery, and the care of mothers and infants after delivery. But beyond “routine” care, they ' overcame many cultural and educational barriers to motivate many more women to seek prenatal care. When a woman first came to the prenatal clinic, she was examined by a physician. If no abnormality were found, she was then assigned to a aurse-midwife for the remainder of her pregnancy. By the middle of the program, the two nurse-midwives were managing the vast majority of the pregnancies and performing 78 per cent" of the hospital deliveries. They were assisted by hospital staff physicians, who managed complications as they developed, and by obstetricians and pediatricians from a neighboring county who consulted for a total of a half-day, on the average, each week. At the end of the 3 years, the program was initially evaluated. Significant improvements the program included: (1) more prenatal care given more frequently to a larger proportion of expectant mothers; (2) a greater proportion of mothers returned for routine 6 week postpartum examinations; (3) a decrease in the prematurity rate (based On a birth weight of 5/2 pounds or less); and most importantly, (4) a decrease in neonatal mortality.12

Despite these improvements, the program was not continued beyond its initial 3 year demonstration period. The Council of the California Medical Association refused to

52 Levy, Wilkinson, and Marine

January 1, 1971 Amcr. J. Obstet. Gyncc.


support a permanent change in the State law which would have permitted nurse-midwives to practice as they iiad during the program. Soon after the program, there were indications that the situation had deteriorated with the neonatal mortality rate for all births in the county increasing from 17.6 (per 1,000 live births) in 1963 to 30.0 in 1964, the first full year after the prograni.13

This retrospective study (performed in 1968) was done to determine whether the situation had, in fact, grown worse after the discontinuation of the program. It is a second evaluation of the NO A program, comparing parameters of medical care and infant health and deaths, during and after the program. The discontinuation of a medical care program that was thought to be beneficial is a rare occurrence in American medicine, and thus offers an unusual opportunity for critical examination of possible, cause-and-effect relationships.

Materials and methods

Two studies were done comparing parameters during and after the program: (1) a County Records Study, comparing data abstracted mainly from birth and death certificates for January, 1961, through June, 1962 (during) and 1965 (after), and (2) a Vital Statistics Records Study comparing data abstracted mainly'from state birth and death records for January, 1961, through June, 1963 (during) and January, 1964, through June, 1966 (after). There was a high correlation between data of the two studies and between data from different sources, such as birth certificates and hospital charts.

County records study. Data gathered in the initial earlier evaluation (before vs. during) of the program for January, 1961-June, 1962 (during) was used along with data we gathered, using the same methods of data collection, for the 1965 (after) period. From all county certificates of live birth and fetal death, data were abstracted on mothers’ obstetric histories and demographic characteristics and infants’ birth weights (with prematurity defined on the basis of a birth weight of 5JA pounds or less).

We did not use the increasingly accepted definition of prematurity based on 'weeks of gestation because this information was missing from many birth certificates.

All infant deaths of infants born in Madera County in the “during” and “after” periods were recorded. Infant deaths were traced by Bureau of Vital Statistics records and the California Death Index. Each infant death was matched with its birth certificate to confirm it as a Madera County birth. Because of the relative stability of the county population and our efforts to determine if infants born in the county to noncounty residents died anywhere in the state, we felt that few, if any, infant deaths were missed.

For all Madera County Hospital live births and fetal deaths, data on prenatal and postpartum care were abstracted from mothers’ hospital charts. The 60 per cent of county births not occurring at the county hospital were grouped together under the category “other.” (Only 2.5 per cent of these did not occur in hospitals.)

Public health nurse records were used to determine how many of the mothers had postpartum home visits.

Vital statistics records study. From state Bureau of Vital Statistics records, data were accumulated for live births and fetal deaths for January, 1961-June, 1963 (during) and January, 1964-June, 1966 (after). Infant deaths were determined as in the county records study. This study provided data for longer time periods, but in slightly less detail, than did the county records study.

Other data. County welfare department personnel were interviewed regarding eligibility requirements for county hospital clinics. Information was obtained, from public health nurse files, on the number of mothers attending the county hospital prenatal clinic. The number of county hospital outpatient clinic visits, inpatient days, and average daily census, and number and turnover of hospital physicians were obtained from the hospital administrator.

Results

Prematurity and deaths. As seen in Table I (A), Vital Statistics records study data

  • Table I. Prematurity and mortality rates in relation to nurse-midwife program— Vital Statistics records study*

fp < 0.02.

tp < 0.005.

show that the prematurity and neonatal mortality rates of county hospital births increased significantly after the program. The prematurity rate incre.i ..d by almost 50 per cent, and the neonatal mortality rate more than tripled.

There were no significant changes in the fetal mortality rate (based on stillbirths after the twentieth week of gestation), in the total infant mortality rate, nor in the postneonatal mortality rate (based on deaths from the end of the first month to the end of the first year of life).

While the prematurity and neonatal mortality rates increased among county hospital births after the program, there was no significant change in any of the mortality or prematurity rates among infants born elsewhere in the county, as shown in Table I (B).     _                         .................

Analysis of county records study data (1965) showed that premature infants had more than a tenfold greater chance of dying during the first year of life than mature infants: of the premature infants, 16.4 per cent died during the first year of life; of the mature ones, only 1.4 per cent died.

Prenatal care.

Over-aTl use of county hospital clinic. When the program became fully operational in late 1960, there was a large increase in the number of expectant mothers attending the prenatal clinic (Fig. 1). In 1961, total visits reached an annual pea!- of 1,905, compared with 1,231 in 1959. The ratio of prenatal clinic visits to total births rose significantly, from 3.57 in 1959 to 4.62 in 1961. Visits reached a quarter peak of 560 in July-September, 1961. In January, 1961-Junc, 1963 (during), the average number of visits for women receiving prenatal care was 4.5; in January, 1964-June, 1966 (after), it fell significantly to 3.6.

After the program, the number of visits dropped sharply, even below preprogram levels. At the same time that there was an abrupt decrease in the number of prenatal clinic visits at the county hospital in mid-1963, there was a 27 per cent decline in total outpatient clinic visits. In February and May, 1963, eligibilty criteria for the use of county hospital outpatient clinics (including the prenatal clinic) were made stricter. No detailed written information is available to document these changes, but a welfare department employee, who was involved in determining eligibility before and after these changes, observed in an interview that these changes had a great effect on reducing clinic utilization. She also stated that there were

54 Levy, Wilkinson, and Marine

January 1, 1971 Amer. J. Obstct. Gynec.


minor changes for those receiving categorical aid starting in early 1962, but that these affected only a small fraction of mothers using the county hospital.

Individual use of county hospital clinic. The amount of prenatal care women received after the program decreased. As seen in Table II, the percentage of women receiving no prenatal care doubled after the program (p < 0.001) and the percentage of women beginning care during the first two trimesters decreased by about one-fourth (p < 0.001). There was a uniform increase after the program in the proportion of mothers of different parity receiving no prenatal care.

Decreased prenatal care was reflected also by a higher incidence of no known care for expectant mothers with previous fetal deaths after the program (10 of 48, or 20.8 per cent), as compared with during the program (4 of 51, or 7.9 per cent).

None of these changes in prenatal care occurred among mothers giving birth elsewhere in the county.

Review of mothers’ county hospital charts provided yet further corroboration of decreased utilization after the program. As

Fig. 1. over a 5 year period were analyzed to determine the effect of prenatal care on prematurity and fetal deaths. It was found, as seen in Table IV, that mothers having no prenatal care had significantly higher risks of giving birth to stillborn infants (more than three times as high) and to premature infants (almost twice as high). Even subtracting fetal deaths, the prematurity rate is much greater without prenatal care (10.2 per cent) than with any prenatal care (5.9 per cent).

The greatest increase among mortality indices among Madera County Hospital births after the program was in neonatal deaths (see Table I). Although the proportion of mothers receiving no prenatal care doubled after the program (Table II), the increased neonatal mortality rate was not only confined to mothers who received no prenatal care. As seen in Table V, the neonatal mortality rate of infants whose mothers had no prenatal care (only care during labor and deli vs ry and afterward) almost doubled after the program; but the neonatal mortality rates of infants whose mothers began

56 Levy, Wilkinson, and Marine

January 1, 1971 Amer. J. Obstct. Gynec.


prenatal care during the first two trimesters increased almost fourfold after the program.

Postpartum care. The increased amount of postpartum care brought about by improved coordination through public health nurse home visits during the program was maintained afterward. No objective data could be obtained to indicate amount of postnatal care to infants.

Changes in Madera County population and health care resources. The total population of the county and its composition were relatively stable. The county hospital maternity population was also stable, with a higher percentage of Mexican-American and Negro mothers, mothers under the age of 20, and fathers employed in farm labor, as compared with the population delivering elsewhere in the county. There were no significant changes in the characteristics of the county hospital maternal population after the program. However, while the overall county births decreased by 15 per cent after the program, the number of births decreased by 23 per cent at the county hospital and only by 10 per cent elsewhere in the county.

The physician population in the county was also quite stable, increasing only from 20 to 25 from 1958 to 1965, and then decreasing to 23 in 1967, with the vast majority still being general practitioners. In 1958, only one physician did specialty work in obstetrics and gynecology; in 1961 and 1963, there were no physicians practicing this specialty; and in 1965 and 1967, one physician did specialty work in both surgery and obstetrics.

At the county hospital, the average number of full-time staff physicians per year went from a low of 2.9 in 1959 to a high of 5.1 in 1962. The hospital had no interns or residents. The number of staff physicians was approximately the same during and after the program. The inpatient to physician ratio during the program was 23.2, and decreased to 16.9 after.

Comment

Significant increases in neonatal mortality rate and prematurity among county hospital births occurred after the discontinuation of the NOA program (Table I, A). There were no significant changes among the other indices for county hospital births, although there was a trend of an increased postneonatal mortality rate during the program and a decreased postneonatal mortality rate after it.

Since this was a retrospective study with many uncontrolled variables, we investigated several possible explanations for the increased neonatal mortality and prematurity rates after the program.

First, we found no unusual events, such as nursery epidemics or an increased multiplebirth rate, to account for these increased rates. In addition, there was no countywide trend of increased prematurity and neonatal deaths since these rates did not change among infants born elsewhere in the. county (Table I, B).                                   '

Second, there was no significant change in the number or types of doctors on the county hospital staff nor in the entire county after the program to account for these increased rates.

Third, we noted that the total births at the county hospital declined by 23 per cent after the program while the total births elsewhere in the county only declined by 10 per cent. This raises the possibility that some low-risk mothers who were delivered normally at the county hospital went elsewhere to be delivered after the program, possibly as a result of the stricter eligibility criteria then. Such a shift would have left a higher percentage of high-risk mothers at the county hospital, possibly accounting for these increased rates. No evidence among data gathered on the maternal population during and after the program, however, indicated such a shift. But even if one were to assume that such a shift occurred, it alone cannot reasonably account for the increased rates: there are still significant increases when one extrapolates a uniform decrease in birth rates after the program for both the county hospital and elsewhere in the county.

While prematurity and neonatal mortality rates increased among county hospital births after the program, prenatal care for mothers being delivered there decreased. Twice

Volume 109

Number 1


Reducing neonatal deaths with nurse-midwives 57

as many women received no known prenatal care after the program and far fewer women made six or more visits (Tables II and III). Part of this decrease in prenatal care may have been due to the stricter eligibility criteria.

The prenatal care of one identifiable group of mothers at high risk, those having previous fetal deaths, reflected the over-all decrease in prenatal care. This suggests that the decrease in prenatal care, which affected the county hospital maternity population in general, also affected those with high-risk pregnancies.

Pooled data on all county births for 5 years (Table IV) indicate the lower risk of fetal deaths and prematurity among women receiving any prenatal care, and further corroborate studies by others.7, s-14 The value of prenatal care per se, then, is clearly established. However, the relation of the content and quality of prenatal care and of care during and after delivery to prematurity and death is another matter.

Indirectly we measured this content and quality of care during pregnancy and after delivery by calculating the neonatal mortality rates for infants whose mothers had about the same amount of care during and after the program. As seen in Table V, the neonatal mortality rates of infants whose mothers began prenatal care in the first two trimesters (who received about the same amount of care) was almost four times greater after the program than during it. This suggests that the quality of care, both prenatal care and care during and after delivery’, was lower after the program. Table V also indicates that the neonatal mortality rate of infants whose mothers had no prenatal care at all (only care during and after delivery) almost doubled after the program. Since the amount of care for all these infants was about the same, this increased trend suggests that the quality of care during and after delivery was; lower after the program.

We found then that there were significantly higher prematurity and neonatal mortality rates, significantly less prenatal care, and probably’ a lower quality of maternal and infant care for births occurring at the county hospital after the discontinuation of the nursemidwife program. We believe that the discontinuation of the nurse-midwife program created new manpower shortages in the prenatal clinic, on the maternity ward, and in the newborn nursery. These manpower shortages, it appears, brought about both lower quantity and probably lower quality of care for mothers and infants. And, finding no other reasonable explanations, we conclude that this lower quantity and probably lower quality of care were the main causes of the increased prematurity and neonatal mortality after the program.

As Hellman recently predicted, the physician shortage in maternal and infant care is likely to grow much worse in the next decade unless appropriate steps are taken. Currently, only six states and New York City in this country permit nurse-midwives to practice. On the basis of our study, we recommend that similar nurse-midwife (or NOA) programs be set up elsewhere, at least on a trial basis, especially where there are critical physician shortages and high prematurity and neonatal mortality rates.

The authors would like to express their appreciation to Mrs. Nedra Belloc of the California Department of Public Health for her technical assistance, to Mrs. Lillie Herschfclt of the Madera County Department of Public Health, and to Mrs. Carolyn Martin and Mr. Ralph Castro of the Madera County Hospital for their cooperation, and to Dr. T. A. Montgomery of the California Department of Public Health, and Dr. Carolyn Williams of the Emory University School of Nursing for their critical review of the manuscript.

Medical JVews Around the WoM

Dispatches from overseas bureaus and correspondents of Medical World News

AMSTERDAM... Although 70% of babies born in the Netherlands are delivered at home by GPs and midwives, the Dutch can boast one of the lowest .jHHHfr infant mortality rates in the world. A report by the U.S. National Center for Health Statistics shows that Holland has reduced infant mortality by one half in each of three periods—1900 to 1922, 1923 to 1939, and 1948 to 1964. In 1930 infant mortality was 50 per 1,000 live births and by 1964 it had been reduced to 15.

The country's low infant death rates, as compared with those in the U.S., England, and Wales, reflect Holland’s long tradition of basic infant care in the family, aided by district nurses and supported by social security measures and a rising standard of living, the report observes.

Another study, which deals specifically with midwifery in the Netherlands, notes that a maternity aide assists in most home deliveries. The aide stays in the home for ten days after the infant is born, acting as a nurse and also doing the cooking and laundry.

G1


MEDICAL WORLD NEWS/J an 3/69. Vol 10, No. 1,

■U.S, professor'says


TORONTO DAILY STAR 76 Wed,, Oct, 18, 1067


Nurses could do all deliveries

Special to The Star

CHICAGO—A Harvard professor of medicine says .nurse-midwives could take over most of the child deliveries in the United States and free scarce physicians for other duties.                                      '

The system operates in Sweden, where the infant mortality rate is far lower than in this country, said Dr. David D. Rutstein. "

In Sweden, the trained midwife follows the patient through pregnancy, reports untoward events to the physician and enables him to follow the patient more closely than the unaided doctor in the United States, he said.

“At term, if the pregnancy has been normal, the nursemidwife, working under the supervision of the physician, is in attendance on the patient from the moment she arrives in labor unlti she is delivered," Rutstein pointed out.

“In contrast, when one walks into the labor room of an American hospital, one finds the inexperienced husband

rather than the trained midwife holding the hand of the patient.’’                .

Because of the midwife’s ability to perform normal delivery, it is unnecessary to schedule these in Swe'den "as busy American physicans are forced-to do," said Rutstein, adding; .                               ’

“As a result, in normal deliveries in Sweden, membranes are rarely ruptured, drugs to induce labor are infrequently prescribed, instruments are less commonly used and there are fewer surgical interventions. ■

"It is not surprising for Sweden to have a lower infant mortality rate than the United State's?*

In a book, “The Coming Revolution In Medicine," published yesterday by the Mit Press, Rutstein said that in view of our unsatisfactory infant mortality rate,” it is necessary to study Sweden’s system and those in all other, western countries where the nurse-midwifery system operates,                     ■                                                    ■

Air pollution ‘unseen killer’ of infants

By BETTY LOU LEE Spectator Staff

TORONTO — Sudden unexplained deatiiMrf infants - so^aligd crib deaths -athpOTOorms of mental refaction to children may be linked to various air polite tants, a Chicago chest specialist said yesterday.

Dr. Bertram W. Carnow, director of the Environmental Health Resource Centre and professor of occupational and environmental medicine at the University of Illinois. has spent more than five years directing research into the effects of air pollutants on human health.

In a retrospective study of 1,600 infants who died suddenly in their beds during the past four years in Chicago, Dr. Carnow found that there was a “very significant correlation’’ between the time that they died and the amount of sulphur dioxide in the air in their neighborhood.

“WE THINK they die of severe respiratory infection, probably viral, that pollution aggravates. Infants are at high risk: They have a limited ability to resist a hostile environment, and the pollution may be the added insult that killed them.”

Cheeks of the post-mortem findings on the babies on whom autopsies were done showed that most of them had problems in their windpipes and bronchial tubes, and some had pneumonia.

“One of the biggest problems is that air pollution affects children more than other people, and they have nothing to say about it,” Dr. Carnow said at a press conference.

He was able to correlate the deaths with air pollution because of a sophisticated pollution information system that has recorded the differing levels of sulphur dioxide and particulate matter in each square mile of the city for every 15 minutes of a day.

HE ALSO bgHeves tha: njap.y children in Chicago are mentally retarded because of a-combination, <4 paljiutritipf] mid .lead.

.aiL

He became particularly concerned when he found that his own four-year-old daughter had an almost toxic level of lead in her blood, that decreased when she stopped playing outdoors.

Dr. Carnow said a lot of publicity has been given to lead poisoning in children from eating lead-based paint, or food stored in some types of pottery. But lead in the air, particularly from automobile exhaust, may be more hazardous. When lead is eaten, he said, the body absorbs only about five per cent of it. It gets into the

(Continued on Page 31

Pollution — straw that
broke imfcnoit health

Continued from Page 1) circulation only after going through the liver, where much of it can be detoxified.

But inhaling it from the air, 60 per cent is absorbed. It gets directly into the blood stream from the lungs, when the blood exchanges carbon dioxide for oxygen.

BECAUSE LEAD particles inhaled are small, they also tend to stay deep in the lungs.

Dr. Carnow said traffic policemen and gas station attendants have been found to have high blood levels of lead, and he has applied for a research grant to study any correlations between retardation and blood lead levels in children. He thinks children whose homes are along expressways and other major traffic arteries may be particularly susceptible.

Another study done at his centre has linked lung cancer to air pollution. It has been known for some time that there is a higher rate of lung cancer in cities than the country, but his centre analyzed all the air pollution and lung cancer statistics from studies in 48 states and 20 countries. They found that a similar conclusion could be drawn from them all.

FOR EVERY microgram of benzopyrene in 1,000 cubic meters of air, there is a five per cent increase in the incidence of lung cancer. Benzopyrene is an aromatic hydrocarbon, a byproduct of combustion of fossil fuels, including gasoline. It is known to produce cancer in experimental animals.

“If we could reduce air pollution by 50 per cent we could reduce lung cancer by 20 per cent,” said Mr. Carnow. “This doesn’t negate the importance of smoking — probably accounts for the other 80 per cent.

“But these things act synergistically (each one enhances the action of the other). The smoker who lives in a city and works in an asbestos factory — the poor devil doesn’t have a chance. His chance of getting lung cancer is 90 times that of someone who has none of these factors.”

THE CHICAGO group also has a study of hospital admissions related to air pollution under way, but some preliminary figures show that heart and lung problems aren’t the only things aggravated by a high pollution index.

At Cook County Hospital, primarily a charity hospital where people have to sit for hours in the emergency department to be seen, there has been an unusual incidence of intense headaches during high pollution episodes. These pains are so severe the patients are willing to wait to be seen by a doctor.

Another hospital reports an increase m patients with epileptic attacks during high pollution.

And Dr. Carnow says the emphasis on air pollution research has uncovered some possibly dangerous industrial standards.

“There has been a realization that industrial workers are subjected to tremendous levels of pollution."

Dr. Carnow was brought to Toronto by the York-Toronto TB and Respiratory Disease Association and the University of Toronto. He gave both a medical seminar and a public address yesterday.

THE SPECTATOR, Hamilton, Canada, February 5, 1972 pp 1&3



28 The Spectator. Monday, October 26, 1970

MD invents delivery chair

BUENOS AIRES (AP) — Childbirth should not be taken lying down, an Argentine doctor says. He advocates a natural vertical position which he says people used before doctors introduced the “modern torture” of the delivery table.

Dr. Tucho Perrusi, honored by the Argentine Medical Association for his studies, has , invented a special chair for delivering babies.

“Look at the ease with which mothers give birth in taxis and trains, without assistance of any kind,” he says.

“The seated « c^aatiang / position obviously wc a de-7 cisive role In the ease and speed of "birth?'

A biologist who later obtained a medical degree, the 52-year-old general practitioner says women in so-called primitive societies still deliver in a vertical position.

When physicians interfered in this heretofore private act about SCO years ago, Perussi claims, they placed the moth. er on a table as a matter of \/ convenience and their own pride.

“Of course, it was easier for the doctor to work. And / physicians could not be seen J in such a humble position, on their knees, in front of the patient.”

Perusal’s device, resem-r blissg a dentist's chair per' mite the obstetrician to stand

while delivering the baby.

A study of 3,520 babies, half of them delivered in Perussi’s chairs and half on the conventional table, indicated that £hair^eliyered infants had a better recorded blood pres


slire, temperature, pulse and other physiological signs.

The chair assists the mother in pushing out the child and she does not need the physician’s help in expelling the placenta, Perussi says.

• BRITISH MEDICAL JOURNAL

LONDON SATURDAY 9 NOVEMBER 1968

Smoking during Pregnancy

During the last trimester of pregnancy the rate of growth of the foetus depends on a number of factors of which the more important are its sex. the number of previous pregnancies, the size of the mother, and the number of foetuses in the uterus. Some of these variables may have a considerable effect on birth weight. Females at term are on average 5 oz. (140 g.) lighter than males, first-born are 4 oz. (113 g.) lighter than second-born, and babies of short mothers are often a pound (454 g.) or more lighter than those of tall mothers.1 The average weight of a twin of 38 weeks’ gestation is about li- lb. (680 g.) less than that of a singleton of the same gestation, and a triplet weighs 4- lb. (340 g.) less than a twin.2 Other influences which retard foetal growth are maternal disorders such as hypertension and pre-eclampsia. Serious defects of the foetus such as anencephalus and mongolism may also be associated with impaired growth.

While most of these variables are not susceptible to control, there is one important cause of retardation of foetal growth—tobacco smoking— which we ought to be able to influence. The first evidence of the effect of tobacco smoke on birth weight came from animal experiments,3 but there have since been a number of human studies all of which have shown jhat women who smoke during pregnancy have, on average, smaller babies than women who do not smoke. The smallness of these infants cannot be explained by differences of parity or duration of gestation,4 or of maternal size, or social class.5 These results have recently been confirmed by C. S. Russell, R. Taylor, and C. E. Law,6 who also showed that differences of age, education, and work done during pregnancy between smokers and non-smokers could not account for the differences in birth weight. It seems to be established beyond all doubt that smoking during pregnancy has a restricting effect on foetal growth.

The extent to which growth is impaired depends on the amount smoked.7 8 On average, smoking causes a depression of birth weight of about 6 oz. (170 g.), but growth is unaffected by smoking before the start of pregnancy,8 9 and if the mother stops smoking early in pregnancy normal foetal growth can be expected.7

The mechanism by which smoking retards foetal growth is not fully understood. It has been suggested that non-smokers eat more than smokers and indulge particularly in foods of high sugar content.10 But it seems that there is no difference between smokers and non-smokers in their weight halfway through pregnancy, and both groups gain equally in weight over the next 10 weeks.5 Furthermore there is some evidence that maternal dietary intake has to be seriously curtailed before foetal growth is impaired.11

A more likely explanation, suggested by C. R. Lowe,4 is that smoking restricts the blood flow to the placenta and so reduces the quantity of nutrients to the foetus. This view is consistent with what is known about the action of nicotine on the cardiovascular system and with the haemo-

No.56279 page 339

389


340    9 November 1968

dynamic hypothesis .which has been advanced to explain variations in foetal growth rates in experimental animals.1213 It may be asked whether the -infants of smoking mothers, because of their smaller size, are less likely to survive and develop normally than the infants of non-smokers. It is well known that small babies in general are at greater risk of disability and death than babies of normal size, but there is some evidence that infants whose low birth weight has been caused by smoking are more likely to survive than infants of the same weight whose mothers did not smoke.14 Since there is some risk that this statement may be misinterpreted, it should be pointed out that it means only that if a patient has a small baby one would prefer the smallness to be due to smoking rather than to some other condition.

It is possible that when contracted pelvis was a greater obstetrical problem than it is today some benefits could have been claimed for cigarette smoking during pregnancy, because, by causing the foetus to be smaller than normal, it reduced the possibility of disproportion. The earlier studies in fact showed that smoking women required surgical induction and forceps delivery less frequently than non-smokers,1 and there was little difference in the perinatal mortality of the two groups. But the 1958 British Perinatal Mortality Survey showed that the rate was 40% higher when mothers smoked during pregnancy, and this was not due to parity or social-class differences between smokers and non-smokers.

i I F- Frazier and colleagues16 also recorded higher stillbirth ' and neonatal mortality rates for the offspring of smokers ;

Leading Articles


British

Medical Journal

and Russell, Taylor, and Law3 found that smoking women had a much higher foetal and infant wastage than nonsmokers ; the combined death rates from abortion, stillbirth, and neonatal death were respectively 79 and 41 per 1,000 pregnancies.

There are many more women smoking now than there were some years ago, and this is reflected in their rising mortality from lung cancer. It seems that the time has come when women should be tpld frankly that if they smoke they not only put their own lives in jeopardy but, if they continue to dp so during pregnancy, also expose their unborn infants to an unnecessary risk.

1 Cawley, R. H., McKeown, T., and Record, R. G., Amer. 7- hum. Genet., 1954, 6, 448.

3 McKeown, T., and Record, R. G., J. Endocrin., 1952, 8, 386.

• Essenberg, J. M., Schwind, J. V., and Patras, A. R-, J. Lab. din. Med., 1940, 25, 708.

f Hemot, A., Bxllewicz, V7. Z., and Hytten, F. E., Lancet, 1962, 1,

’ MacMahon, B., Alpert, M., and Salber, E. J., Amer. J. Epidem., 1965, 82, 247.

I Survey finds link between infant mortality, cigarettes

WASHINGTON <AP) -New evidence linking cigarette smoking to stillbirths and newborn infant deaths was cited yesterday in the seventh annual U.S. government report on smoking and health.

The document suggests “the strong . . . association between cigarette smoking and higher rate tW_and_jnfent mortality among smokers’ infants.”

The report said several recent studies have demonstrated a “statistically significant relationship between cigarette smoking and an elevated mortality risk among the infants of smokers” and that the risk increases proportionately with the number of cigarettes smoked.

And. the report adds, “new evidence suggests that, if a woman gives up smoking by the fourth month of pregnancy she will have the same risk of incurring a fetal or neonatal loss as a non-smoker.”

STUDIES HAVE shown that ‘the fetus of a smoking mother may be directly exposed to agents such as carbon monoxide within tobacco smoke” at levels which produce stillbirth in animals, the report said.

A mother’s smoking habit will not influence the Child's sex, according to the studies, and “no firm conclusion” can be made about any relationship between maternal smoking and congenital malformation.

Experiments with animals do suggest, however, that the mother’s milk may contain nicotine and nitrosamines, the latter powerful carcinogens which pass through to suckling young.

The offspring of sjnukmg mothers are nearly twice as likely to have a low birth weight at delivery, the report says, but they grow faster the first six months because “a toxic influence” has been removed.

THE REPORT says clinical studies involving healthy, young men have shown that cigarette smoking impairs exercise performance “especially for many types of athletic i events and activities involving 1 maximal work capacity.” I

Pipe and cigar smokers experience death rates “slightly higher” than those of non-smokers but “substantially lower” than those of cigarette smokers, the report said.

The reason, it says, are that pipe and cigar smokers either do not inhale or do so infrequently or slightly.

“As a result, the harmful effects of cigar and pipe smoking appear to be largely , limited . to increased death rates from cancer at those sites which are exposed to the smoke of these products,” the report says.

Although cancers of the mouth, larynx, pharynx and esophagus are serious, it says “they account for only about five per cent of the cancer mortality among men.”

IN THE first official study of the health hazards of smoking the relatively new little cigars, criticized by some as cigarettes in disguise, the report said “it is reasonable to conclude that smoking little cigars may result in health defects similar to those associated with smoking cigarettes if both are smoked in the same way.

“Smoking those brands of little cigars which can be inhaled by a significant portion of the population in a manner similar to the present use cf cigarettes would probably result,” the report says, “m an increased risk of developing those pulmonary and cardiovascular diseases which have been associated with cigarette smoke.”

Dr. Merlin K. Du Vai, who

Hamilton, Ontario, The Spectator, Thursday recently resigned as assistant health secretary of the department of health, education and welfare, told Congress the report “reiterates, strengthens and extends the findings in earlier reports that cigarette smoking is a major health problem in the United States.”

AWAKE!


June 22, 1972


Babies Could Be Saved

O A medical correspondent of the London Times writes: “ffundreds of infant lives could be saved ‘ each year if expectant mothers could be persuaded to give up smoking by the end of the fourth month of pregnancy.” That conclusion was based on extensive research done by British doctors on 95 percent of all infant deaths occurring late in pregnancy or shortly after birth. The research showed that the risk of a baby dying just before or shortly after birth is increased by 28 percent if the mother continues to smoke during pregnancy.


He said new research confirms that cigarette smoking is a major cause of lung cancer ar.d chronic bronchitis and contributes to chronic bronchopulmonary disease, cardiovascular disease and other ailments.

5 Canada

, January 18, 1973 S

HTB-73

HTB-73


SmoOcmg starts

peraO gffowtth

JX tew findings that extend previous I\j evidence of smoking’s baleful influence during pregnancy are presented in the latest report prepared by the National Clearinghouse for Smoking and Health. In a statement accompanying the report, Dr. Merlin K. DuVal, lame-duck HEW Assistant Secretary for Health, notes that the latest evidence not only "strongly indicates a causa! relationship between cigarette smoking during pregnancy and low infant birth weight," but points to "a strong, probably causal association’’ between smoking and a higher rate of fetal and infant mortality.

"When a variety of known or suspected factors that also exert an influence on birth weight have been controlled, cigarette smoking has consistently been shown to be independently related to low birth weight,” says pediatrician H. Stephen Williams, assistant medical director of the reporting panel. There is new evi-t dence, he goes on, suggesting that if a woman gives up smoking by the fourth month of pregnancy, her risk of delivering an infant of low birth weight is similar to that of a nonsmoker. The effect of smoking on fetal growth, he says, reflects the number of cigarettes smoked daily during a pregnancy, not the cumulative effect of smoking before pregnancy.

The NCSH report cites recent studies indicating that smoking is most strongly associated with a higher rate of stillbirths among poorer women. Blacks have a higher stillbirth rate than whites in this country, it notes.

Twelve retrospective and prospective studies have revealed a statistically significant relationship between a mother’s smoking habit and her chance of delivering a dead child, according to the report. It adds that in three of these studies-each of them of sufficient size to allow adjustment for other risk factors—a highly significant independent association between smoking and infant mortality was established. And it is this adjustment, says Dr. Williams, that partly explains the discrepancy be-.

Dr. Williams links cigarettes to a higher infant death risk, too.



tween these studies and others in which no link was demonstrated.

There is a seeming paradox here, however. The NCSH paper notes that within groups of infants of similar birth weight, the offspring of nonsmokers appear to have a higher mortality rate than do those of smokers. According to the report, though, the reason is "that the infants of nonsmokers within such similar-birthweight groups are, on the average, gestationaliy less mature than the infants of cigarette smokers. Available evidence indicates that within groups of similar gestational age. infants of lower birth weight experience a higher mortality risk.”

Available evidence also strongly supports the idea that cigarette smoking is one cause of fetal growth retardation, says the report. The causes of the excess deaths among smokers' babies are those associated with small-for-date infants.

Two epidemiological investigations cited suggest that smoking may possibly affect lactation, too. Studies in rats have demonstrated that nicotine can interfere with the usual suckling-induced rise in prolactin, the pituitary hormone that stimulates milk secretion in mammals. The report admits that "with only limited numbers of women and without control of other potentially significant variables, no firm conclusions can be drawn.” Nevertheless, there is evidence indicating that nicotine passes into breast milk, and the report notes that results from experiments with mice suggest that nitrosamines— known carcinogens-pass through the milk to the suckling young^

Emphatically ruled out on the basis of available evidence is the suggestion that maternal cigarette smoking can influence the sex of newborn infants. And given the considerable variation in the design of the 42 studies reviewed by the NCSH, no firm conclusion can be made at this time about the relationship between maternal smoking and congenital malformation.

One intriguing finding was that smoking mothers seem to run a significantly lower risk of developing pre-eclampsia than do nonsmokers. But this possible benefit from smoking does not impress Dr. Williams. "If a woman who smokes during pregnancy develops pre-eclampsia," he remarks, "her infant has a higher mortality risk than that of a nonsmoker with pre-eclampsia.” o

MEDICAL WORLD NEWS/February 2. 7973

19


The New England

Journal of Medicine

Copyright, 1962. by the Massachusetts Medical Society               t

Volume”266                         JANUARY 25, 1962                          Number 4

RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH EXCHANGE TRANSFUSION*

.                William J. Jablonski, M.D.f

BOSTON AND DORCHESTER, MASSACHUSETTS

ALTHOUGH most medical centers perform exchange transfusions on newborn infants if the bilirubin reaches levels of 18 to 20 mg. per 100 ml. in the first few days of life1"* there are many who doubt its necessity as a routine procedure at these levels.5'8 Since the decision to perform an exchange transfusion is based essentially on the risks inherent in the procedure itself versus those associated-with the concentration of serum bilirubin, more precise knowledge of these hazards would enable the operator to snake his decision on a more rational basis. Moreover, there is still wide variation in the literature about the dangers associated with these factors.9'15 the present study was undertaken in this institution, therefore, to determine the risks of exchange transfusion and of different levels of bilirubinemia in newborn infants.

Materials and Methods

St. Margaret’s Hospital is a maternity hospital with approximately 5000 deliveries per year. In recent years about 100 exchange transfusions have been performed annually, as a rule by the responsible pediatrician and the pediatric resident.

Throughout this paper the term “bilirubin” will refer to the total serum bilirubin concentration, expressed in milligrams per 100 ml. (van den Bergh niicromethod) since most of the exchanges were performed on the basis of this value. The indirect bilirubin usually remained only about 1 or 2 mg. per 100 ml. below the total bilirubin.

To correlate these determinations with those of other hospitals a sample of serum obtained from an infant during exchange transfusion was sent to five other hospitals in the Boston area. The total bilirubins ranged from 12.4 to 16,5 mg. per 100 ml. The average determination was 14.5 mg., and that obtained at St. Margaret’s Hospital was 16.0 mg. per 100 ml.

This study was then divided into three parts: the mortality figures associated with exchange transfu-

‘From the Department of Pediatrics, Tufts University School of Medicine, and St. Margaret’s Hospital, Dorchester.

1 Senior assistant resident physician, Boston Floating Hospital. sions over a seven-year period were studied; the records of 100 infants who underwent exchange trans- . fusion were analyzed for various pre-existing factors; and a follow-up study on 204 infants with hyperbilirubinemia was attempted.

Results

Mortality

The statistics on all exchange transfusions performed between 1954 and 1960, inclusive, were reviewed. Accurate records of the number of exchange transfusions performed and the indications for these were obtained from the blood bank. Reasonably accurate information on all the deaths was available. During this period there were 558 replacement transfusions, with 26 neonatal deaths. The distribution by years, indication and mortality is shown in Table 1. In 1960 the average number of exchange transfusions per infant requiring the procedure was 1.7 for hemolytic disease and 1.2 for physiologic jaundice. The condition of infants before transfusion who died during or shortly after the procedure was studied; the results are shown in Table 2. The great majority of those who died were in poor condition before exchange transfusion.

In an attempt to determine the mortality due to the procedure itself, only infants with unexplained hyperbilirubinemia were analyzed. It was believed that patients with erythroblastosis fetalis had so many complicating factors that an accurate representation of the true state of affairs in this group would not be possible. There were 6 deaths in the 263 transfusions performed for nonhemolytic jaundice. In only 4 cases was there any possibility that exchange transfusion contributed to death. These included 2 small premature infants weighing 1049 gm. (2 pounds, 5 ounces) and 1757 gm. (3 pounds, 14 ounces), a premature infant weighing 2381 gm. (5 pounds, 4 ounces), who tolerated the procedure poorly and died afterward, and an infant with hyaline-membrane disease and kernicterus who went into heart failure during the procedure and died several hours later. In the other 2 cases it was thought that the procedure could not reasonably be

156


considered a major contributing factor in the deaths of the infants. These included a child cyanotic at birth who succumbed to probable aspiration pneumonia three days after his last exchange, and an infant with signs of intestinal obstruction after exchange arid evidence of disseminated toxoplasmosis at autopsy. Thus, the procedure possibly played a part in the deaths of a maximum of 4 infants, an average of 1,5 per cent.                        .

Pre-existing Factors

In an effort to determine the effects of possible sepsis and low birth weights on the mortality of

It may be noted that there were 24 isolations of staphylococci and 15 of gram-negative rods. Only 1 infant had clinical signs of septicemia, and this child had positive cultures before and after exchange transfusion and evidence of septicemia at autopsy.

Follow-up Data

To evaluate the incidence of kernicterus in patient'

157


Figure 1. Neurologic Defects on Discharge (Actual Number of Cases Noted in the Bars).


with hyperbilirubinemia the records of 204 infants born in 1957, 1958 and 1959 with negative Coombs tests and total bilirubin levels exceeding 15 mg. per 100 ml. in the first seven days of life were reviewed. This number included only patients who were followed by private pediatricians. The records were analyzed for condition on discharge and whether any neurologic, defects were noted or suggested while the patients were in the hospital. In addition questionnaires were sent to the pediatricians asking them when the patients were last seen by them and whether any neurologic defects were noted at that time. Forty-five of the infants had peak bilirubin levels of 20 mg. per 100 ml. or more, and 9 reached levels of 25 mg. per 100 ml. or greater. Ninety-six patients were seen after discharge, and 81 six months or more after leaving the hospital. One hundred and fifty-two were full term, and 52 were premature. The neurologic status of the infants on discharge and at the time of the follow-up report is summarized in Figures

Normal

Neuro.Defect

Questionable Neuro. Defect

1 let re 2. Neurologic Defects on Six-Month Follow-up Study (Actual Number of Cases Noted in the Bars).

1, 2 and 3. The percentage of possible neurologic complications, as determined generally by abnormal "r slow motor activity, appeared to be slightly greater in the infants with bilirubin levels of 20 to 25 mg. 'nan in those with levels of 15 to 20 mg. per 100 ml. when seen at discharge. On follow-up study, however, no neurologic defects were noted in the former g'oup, but some were seen in the latter. No patients with definite evidence of kernicterus were seen in the '■ntire series. Of the 5 infants with possible neurologic defects on discharge from the hospital whose peak bilirubin levels were in the range of 15 to 20 mg. per 100 ml. 3 were normal on follow-up study, 1 showed some neurologic difficulty, and the fifth was not seen again. Both infants with a question of neurologic involvement on discharge and with maximum bilirubin levels in the range of 20 to 25 mg. per 100 ml. were normal on follow-up study. Two infants with peak bilirubin levels of 25 to 30 mg. per 100 ml. were thought to have neurologic involvement at discharge. One of these was retarded on follow-up study, and the other was not seen again.

Figure 3. Neurologic Defects on Twelve-Month Folloui-up Study (Actual Number of Cases Noted in the Bars).


Normal


Kernicterus has long been the dreaded complication of jaundice in the newborn period. In 1950 Allen, Diamond and Vaughn16 demonstrated that kernicterus could be prevented in erythroblastotic infants by the use of exchange transfusions, and in 1952 Hsia and his associates3 showed an increasing incidence of kernicterus with higher levels of bilirubin in these infants. Allen and Diamond17 then recommended exchange transfusion on infants with hemolytic disease whose bilirubin levels exceeded 20 mg. per 100 ml. whereas several British workers1,13 considered 18 mg. an indication for exchange transfusion in newborn premature infants. In general these recommendations have been widely followed. However, the same levels of bilirubin that were recommended as an indication for exchange transfusion in erythroblastotic infants have been applied to cases of unexplained neonatal jaundice, even though these are widely different problems. The present series included no cases of kernicterus in infants with jaundice of unknown etiology and with peak bilirubin levels ranging from 15 to 29 mg. per 100 ml. Gerrard19 has described the ‘ clinical course of a iarge number of infants with kernicterus and noted that 50 out of 52 cases were manifest clinically by the fifth day of life. Since the average stay of infants born at St. Margaret’s Hospital is five days, it appears unlikely that any significant number of cases of kernicterus were undiagnosed before discharge.

Although neonatal jaundice without hemolytic disease is commonly associated with prematurity, the majority of the infants in the present experience were full term.

158

Sepsis was not a major factor in this series. A large number of positive blood cultures were obtained at exchange, but only 1 infant had clinical signs of septicemia. These results correspond to those of Lipsitz and Cornet,20 who obtained many positive cultures via catheterization of the umbilical vein in normal newborn infants.

criterion, they reported a mortality of 1.9 per cern with an overall 4.3 per cent neonatal mortality i-.-infants undergoing exchange transfusion. Again, this figure is similar to the present experience of a gm-., mortality rate of 4.7 per cent. Table 7 summarizes th-mortality experience of several reports in the literatim-

—

The fact that no cases of kernicterus occurred in infants with “physiologic” jaundice and bilirubin values greater than 20 mg. per 100 ml. is in line with the findings of Newns and Norton5 and of Killander et ah,® who reported 10 and 94 full-term infants, respectively, with bilirubin levels in excess of 20 mg. per 100 ml., without a single case of kernicterus. Newns and Norton5 also found no cases of kernicterus in premature infants with bilirubin levels greater than 20 mg. per 100 ml., in contrast to the findings of Crosse, Meyer and Gerrard,1 Rapmund, Bowman and Harris2 and Meyer,18 all of whom reported a high incidence of kernicterus in premature infants with bilirubin levels in excess of 18 to 20 mg. per 100 ml. The present follow-up studies showed no increase in the frequency of neurologic defects in babies with levels of 20 to 25 mg. per 100 ml. over those whose bilirubin levels never appeared to exceed 15 to 20 mg. A comparison of these findings with those in several other reports in the literature is summarized in Tables 5 and 6.

The estimate of a mortality of 1.5 per cent due to exchange transfusion is similar to that of several other authors. Boggs and Westphal13 consider a death caused by exchange transfusion as one occurring during or within six hours after transfusion. Using this proved hemolytic disease at which exchange transfusion is mandatory is still debatable. Newns and Norton5 believe that transfusions should not be performed as a routine procedure simply because the serum bili-

Using this set of criteria, they reported no cases of kernicterus in their follow-up study. 603

a I nrc

♦Exchange transfusion for hemolytic disease.

^Exchange transfusion in premature infants. tHcparinized blood used for exchange transfusion.

Silverman7 found no significant correlation between uncomplicated hyperbilirubinemia in premature infants and neurologic deficits at three years of age. They questioned the validity of applying the same criteria and treatment that are used for hyperbilirubinemia caused by erythroblastosis fetalis to uncomplicated hyperbilirubinemia of prematurity.

The present results are compatible with these suggestions, with no evidence that in so-called uncomplicated hyperbilirubinemia the risk is greater in infants with peak bilirubin levels of 25 mg. than in those whose levels do not exceed 15 to 20 mg. per 100 ml. However, it has been shown that hypoxia24 and certain drugs such as sulfisoxazole25 increase the incidence of kernicterus with given levels of bilirubin. Infants with these complicating factors should not be considered in the class of those described as having uncomplicated or physiologic jaundice. However, since both the present experience and that reported in the literature show the mortality due to exchange transfusion to be in the range of 1 or 2 per cent, owing to the lack of very large numbers of infants followed tvith bilirubin levels above 20 mg. per 100 ml., it cannot be stated definitely that the risk of kernicterus does not exceed that of exchange transfusion in intents with levels of 20 to 25,mg. per 100 ml. It is of note, however, that this report and those by Newns and Norton5 and Killander, Muller-Eberhard and Sjolin1'- discuss a total of 133 full-term infants with bilirubin levels in excess of 20 mg. per 100 ml. with-riut a single case of kernictcius, and papers by Hugh-l”ces and his associates,21 Koch ct al.,22 Newns and •■Orton/ Shiller and Silverman7 and the current re-i*>n cover 108 premature infants with levels over 18 1,1 20 mg. per 100 ml., the only cases of kernicterus in rubinemia of unknown etiology, there would be 10 exchange deaths for every full-term infant saved from athetosis, and 4 exchange deaths per premature infant escaping athetosis.

Summary and Conclusions

A study was undertaken to determine the relative risks of exchange transfusion and of kernicterus for given levels of serum bilirubin in newborn infants. The mortality due to exchange transfusion was approximately 1.5 per cent. In 204 infants with neonatal jaundice of undetermined origin and bilirubin levels greater than 15 mg. per 100 ml. there were 45 with levels over 20 mg. and 9 with levels over 25 mg. per 100 ml. There were no proved cases of kernicterus in the group. At follow-up study there was no greater incidence of neurologic deficit in the 19 infants whose bilirubin levels rose to 20 to 25 mg. per 100 ml. than in the 58 whose levels never exceeded 15 to 20 mg. per 100 ml. It is believed that in uncomplicated hyperbilirubinemia in full-term and larger premature infants there is no indication for exchange transfusion unless the bilirubin reaches at least 25 mg. per 100 ml.

I am indebted to Dr. James Marvin Baty for help in preparing the manuscript, to Drs. Robert Driscoll, Edward McGrath, Leo Smith, Francis Wenzler, John Bowers, David Weiner, Norman Leigh and John McCue for aid in providing the follow-up reports on their patients and to Drs. James Redmund, Wadi Bardawil and Jean Ross for help and suggestions.
