AMERICAN FAMILY PHYSICIAN / G P

August 1970s Volume 2, Number 2

Minimizing Risk

in Exchange Transfusion

CARL POCHEDLY, M.D., Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, New York



Certain precautions are essentia! to minimize risk while performing exchange transfusion. The baby should receive no formula for eight hours before the exchange. The stomach should be suctioned to remove gastric contents. Facilities should be available for tracheal intubation. An electronic cardiac monitor should be used. Donor blood should be warmed. If the baby is premature or severely ill, an attempt should be made to control the pH of the donor blood.

An editorial on page 62 details some of the legal problems that may arise alter unsuccessful exchange transfusions.


Despite various technical advances, such as a new disposable exchange transfusion kit, exchange transfusion is still not an innocuous procedure. Sudden death continues to occur. The overall mortality rate is between 0.5 and 4.0 percent, depending on how many premature or severely ill infants are included in the statistics. If the risk is to be minimized, the danger points of exchange transfusion need to be clearly defined (Figure J).

Stresses of Exchange Transfusion ,

Exchange transfusion imposes a tremendous phvsiologic stress on a newborn infant. There are three main sources of acute stress: cooling of the baby, rapid blood volume changes and acidosis.

HYPOTHERMIA

Cooling of the baby may be caused by room air, by inefficiency of the infant warmer or by cold donor blood. The use of ice-cold donor blood for exchange transfusion is the most dangerous of these factors since it causes selective chilling of the heart. During massive transfusion in adults, Boyan found a much higher incidence of cardiac arrest when cold blood was used than when warm blood was given.

If the umbilical catheter is inserted to a depth of more than 6 to 8 cm., the tip comes to lie in the right atrium and cold donor blood is then injected directly into the heart. The injection of cold donor blood may cause a serious arrhythmia by chilling the sinoatrial node or by vagal stimulation. Since the foramen ovale is patent for some time after birth, it is even possible for cold unmixed blood to reach the left side of the heart and the coronary arteries. When using cold acid-citrate-dextrose (ACD) blood for exchange, these arteries are perfused with blood that is not only cold but also acidotic, with a low Po2, low ionized calcium and high serum potassium. Hey suggested that this combination of factors could precipitate cardiac arrest.

To avoid hypothermic stress, the donor blood is passed through a coil of plastic tubing immersed in a water bath kept at 39° C. and inserted halfway along the donor set. The blood is warmed to within 5° C. of the water bath temperature as it moves through the 25 feet of tubing in the immersed coil (Figure 2).

HEMODYNAMIC STRESS

The degree of hemodynamic stress becomes apparent when one compares the magnitude of blood volume changes in a baby during exchange transfusion with the proportionate changes in a double-volume exchange transfusion on an adult.

The total blood exchanged (double blood volume) for a 3-kg. baby is 500 ml.; for a man weighing 70 kg., it would be 12.00'1 ml. The aliquot of blood exchanged per um'

74 volume 2, number 2 AFP/GP

FIGURE 1. Five principal danger points in performing exchange transfusion. (1) Donor blood: transfusion reaction due to mismatched blood, blood too cold, blood too old, blood too acidic. (2) Syringing technique: too-rapid hemodynamic changes, overloading of circulation due to errors

in syringing. (3) Umbilical catheter (external): air embolism, infection. (4) Umbilical catheter (internal): perforation of umbilical vessels, cardiac failure due to catheter irritation, rupture of spleen, subsequent portal hypertension. (5) Airway: asphyxia, aspiration pneumonitis.


time for a baby is 20 ml. per syringe, or one-twelfth of the baby’s blood volume. For a 70-kg. man, one-twelfth of his blood volume is 500 ml. Thus, in a double-volume exchange on an adult, one would withdraw and inject 1 pint of blood every two minutes and repeat this 24 times.

A slow rate of exchange transfusion permits the baby to adjust to the blood volume changes and to metabolize the citrate when ACD blood is used. Exchange transfusion of a normal baby should take an hour; a y,-sick baby needs more time.

ACIDOSIS

Acidosis is due to the ACD solution used to prevent coagulation of donor blood. The pH of ACD blood usually ranges between 6.5 and 6.9. During a double-volume exchange transfusion, about 85 percent of the infant’s blood is replaced with citrated donor blood, Povey showed that this often causes

75 August 1970 AFP/GP

FIGURE 2. Apparatus for warming blood during exchange transfusion. For demonstration purposes, the plastic coil is only partially inserted into the constant-temperature water bath. The tube containing warmed blood is about to be connected with the input tube of the exchange transfusion equipment.




The Author .

CARL E. POCHEDLY, m.d.

is director of pediatric hematology at Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, Long Island, N.Y. A graduate of Western Reserve University School of Medicine, he served his internship at Akron General Hospital and his pediatric residency at Children’s Hospital of the District of Columbia. He obtained a Master of Medical Sciences degree at Ohio State University. He completed a fellowship in pediatric hematology at New York Medical College and currently serves as consultant in pediatric hematology to several Nassau County (N.Y.) hospitals.

the baby’s pH to fall from the physiologic level of 7,4 to 7.0 or lower. The healthy infant adapts to this tremendous acidotic stress remarkably well. However, the premature or sick infant, who is already acidotic or who has had a previous exchange transfusion, may collapse under the heavy load of citrated donor blood. The acidotic stress from using A CD blood is much greater in infants who cannot ventilate adequately and who consequently have a high Pco2 and low pH at rest. Barrie proved that acidosis depresses cardiac function and impairs the binding of bilirubin by albumin.

Postexchange acidosis can be lessened by a slow rate of transfusion. To reduce the citrate load with A CD blood, 150 ml. of plasma may be removed from the unit of donor blood before use. The addition of sodium bicarbonate or tris (hydroxymethyl) aminomethane (THAM) to alkalinize or buffer the blood has also been advocated but overdose may result in alkalosis. The use of donor blood anticoagulated with heparin is another effective way to avoid postexchange acidosis. However, no single protocol for handling the problem of acidosis in the high-risk infant requiring exchange transfusion has been generally accepted.

The question of citrated versus heparinized blood is controversial. Each type has its advantages and disadvantages. Blood preserved with ACD solution can be used as long as three days after collection but, according to Varga, it has a very low pH and causes acidotic stress. Furthermore, citrate produces a fall in the blood calcium level, which necessitates the infusion of calcium gluconate. If given improperly, this infusion of calcium may cause severe bradycardia or intravascular clotting.

Heparinized blood has a physiologic pH but must be used within 24 hours of collection. Heparin also causes a rise in the plasma concentration of nonesterified fatty

76 volume 2, number 2 AFP/GP

KAB“42


acids. These fatty acids compete with bilirubin for albumin-binding sites and cause a shift of unbound bilirubin away from the plasma to the tissues. Johnson stated that this condition is potentially hazardous because the serum bilirubin then does not indicate the risk of kernicterus. The use of heparinized blood to avoid accentuation of acidosis may be advisable in premature or severely ill infants.

In view of the severe physiologic stress from cooling, rapid blood volume changes and acidosis, the morbidity and mortality of exchange transfusion are quite low.

Hazards in Technique

Lucid descriptions of exchange transfusion technique are available in the literature.


FIGURE 3. Items needed for resuscitation of infants during exchange transfusion: caffeine sodium benzoate and epinephrine 1:1000; sterile syringe; laryngoscope; endotracheal.tube; infant face mask and hand resuscitator.


Some of the hazards associated with this procedure are: airway obstruction, cardiac arrest, congestive heart failure, air embolism, perforation of the umbilical vein and infection.

AIRWAY OBSTRUCTION

Aspiration of the stomach does not ensure removal of all the gastric contents. The only way to be certain that the stomach does not contain a potentially lethal collection of coagulated milk is to restrict the infant to glucose-and-water feedings during the eight to 12 hours before exchange transfusion. When there is the slightest chance that an exchange transfusion may be necessary, no milk should be given. Direct laryngoscopy, tracheal intubation and direct suctioning may be lifesaving for a baby with sudden respiratory obstruction during exchange transfusion. Facilities should be immediately available for direct laryngoscopy and tracheal intubation (Figure 3). Someone who knows how to use them should be present.

CARDIAC ARREST

Unexplained cardiac arrest is a well-known complication of exchange transfusion. Arrhythmias and cardiac arrest are partially attributable to hypothermia, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia and acidosis. When ACD blood is used for exchange transfusion, it should be less than three days old and calcium gluconate should be given during the procedure. Infants who die during or soon after exchange transfusion may show sudden cardiac arrest, bradycardia followed by cardiac arrest or tachycardia followed by congestive heart failure. Atrial, nodal and ventricular arrhythmias have been recorded during exchange transfusion. However, the infant may show obvious distress only with the onset of ventricular fibrillation.

Monitoring the heart intermittently with a stethoscope taped to the chest does not

77 August 1970 AFP/GP

FIGURE 4. In preparation for exchange transfusion, the infant is placed in an infant warmer and an electronic cardiac monitor is attached to the infant. The cardiac monitor provides continuous ECG tracing and an automatic heart rate alarm if pulse exceeds prescribed limits Graphic recorder (right) provides permanent ECG record. The infant is kept warm by the heater assembly (above infant warmer). Thermistor is placed on the infant’s abdomen tc monitor skin temperature.


provide adequate appraisal of the infant’s cardiac status. Although this method is simple, it is unreliable. Rapid changes in heart rate, soft beats, dislodgement of the chest piece, poor sound conduction or unfamiliarity with the stethoscope may lead to serious inaccuracies. Even experienced observers have difficulty in rapidly estimating cardiac rate and evaluating quality of the heart sounds. The heart rate may remain unchanged despite evidence of imminent heart failure. ECG monitoring should be used to help provide early and accurate warning of impending danger (Figure 4).

Exchange transfusion should be stopped y if' the heart rate varies outside the range of V 100 to 160 per minute or if abnormal HCQ changes appear. Robinson stated that the most serious changes indicating ventricular embarrassment are bradycardia; widening, notching or low voltage of the QRS complex; S-T deviation and spiking of the T waves.

CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE

Heart failure due to overloading the baby’s circulation with donor blood may be the result of carelessness. Inaccurate measurement of blood volumes may occur during injection and withdrawal by careless overshooting or undershooting the 20 ml. or 10 ml. mark on the syringe. This may cause serious overloading of the baby’s circulation or postexchange anemia. Albumin loading before or during exchange transfusion is of doubtful value and may lead to hypervolemia and cardiac overload.

AIR EMBOLISM

Shock from air embolism may result from aspiration of air through the umbilical catheter. This may occur while the venous pressure is being measured or it may be due to air entering the stopcock system at loose fittings. When the infant is making strenuous inspiratory efforts against some obstruction, such as laryngeal spasm, air may readily be aspirated through an open umbilical catheter. The inserted catheter should be closed or kept under constant observation whenever it is disconnected.

PERFORATION

Sundal reported that forceful insertion of the umbilical catheter may cause perforation of the umbilical vein. Perforation is most likely to occur when using a catheter of

78 volume 2. number 2 AFP/GP

hard plastic or a plastic catheter with a sharpened point. If a soft plastic catheter with a rounded end is used, the risk is / greatly reduced. Undue trauma to the um' bilical vein may also lead to ascending phlebitis and thrombosis.

INFECTION

Sepsis may result from the use of infected blood or from nonsterile technique. Serum hepatitis may follow.

Portal hypertension may follow septic thrombophlebitis of the umbilical vein. Because of this danger, fluids should not be administered parenterally through an indwelling umbilical vein catheter and catheters should not be left in the umbilical vein between exchange transfusions. If the umbilical area seems infected, or if undue difficulty is encountered in catheterizing the umbilical vein, another site for transfusion should be used.

Other hazards include rupture of the spleen and postexchange bleeding from the umbilical stump. Transfusion reaction is also a possibility. This results from using blood not compatible with the serum of the mother, since a newborn infant has no significant blood group antibody production of his own. Viega warned that blood from a donor with sickle cell trait should not be used.

Materials illustrated in Figure I are from the disposable exchange transfusion kit available through Pharmaseal Laboratories. The plastic coil (Hemocoil®) and water bath (Hemokinetotherm®) shown in Figure 2 are manufactured by Dupaco. The infant warmer in Figure 4 is an Air-Shields'® Model DR and the electronic cardiac monitor is a Scopette® Model MTSX.

Figure 4 courtesy of Dr. S. Wayne Klein.

A coupon for ordering a bibliography accompanying this article may be found adjacent to the Index to Advertisers.

79 August 1970 AFP/GP

A                    MEOWE’g MDILOli. WM

Catheterization of the umbilical, artery or vein of newborns, which has become standard practice for diagnostic and therapeutic measures in many hospitals, is not without significant risk, warns a Florida 'team. In a SVa-year study of 253 Infants in respiratory distress or in danger of developing this condition, ths researchers found that nearly 10% had complications that could be linked to catheterization. In two cases, these complications—thrombosis and infarction—were considered severe enough to have been the possible cause of death.

Drs. Edmund A. Egan II and Donald V. Eitzman of the University of Florida College of Medicine in Gainesville report in the American Journal of Diseases of Children (Vol.

121, No. 3) that 16 neonates had clinical complications with this tech-■ nique, and autopsy complications ! were documented in 12 cases. In ; three cases, there were both clinical and autopsy complications.

■ Among the 18 patients with clini-I cai complications, five had a loss of J pulse. Two of these subsequently ' developed gangrene. Infection oc-I curred in five patients, accidental hemorrhage in three, and cardiac arrhythmia in three. In addition, extravascular placement of the ■"catheter occurred in two cases.

While the other clinical complications have all been reported previously by other investigators, Drs. Egan and Eitzman indicate that cardiac arrhythmias have not. Normal sinus rhythms were restored in all three infants upon removal of the catheter.

Catheterization complications were revealed in 12 out of the 68 autopsies in the series. Evidence of thrombosis was found in six cases, and in four, this complication was associated with infarcts. Hemorrhage without apparent thrombosis was seen in three cases, and inflammation unrelated to the primary disease, in three.

The team notes that catheterization facilitates therapy that includes supplemental oxygen, buffers, and fluids to treat neonatal respiratory distress. But they conclude that “an awareness of the possible complications is essential for any physician using this procedure to care for severely ill patients." n

MEDtCAL WORLD NEWS/April 9, >97?

48A


KCA-62

Vol„ 8 No. 2-1 Toronto

THE MEDICAL POST, OCTOBER 17, 1972   33

Catheter linked to arterial thrombosis

AN UNEXPECTEDLY high incidence of arterial thrombosis is associated with umbilical artery catheterization.              ~ ......

Of 100 consecutive admissions to a neonatal intensive care unit, 79 neonates had umbilical catheters inserted, 86% of which were arterial.

Significant'arterial thrombus formation was demonstrated in 18 of 21 infants submitted to aortography when the catheter was withdrawn.

Fifteen other umbilically cath-eterized infants died and of the 12 autopsied, seven had minimal to extensive arterial thrombus formation.

Umbilical arterial catheterization should be reserved for carefully selected patients. Speculatively, the authors are now placing the tip of the umbilical artery catheter much lower in the aorta, at the bifurcation, hoping to Jessen the hazard of the procedure. — “Umbilical artery catherizalion: Demonstration of arterial thrombosis bv aortography.” W. A. Neal et at. Pediatrics, July 19?2.

APRIL 5, 196?   ■ THE LANCET

COPPER CONTAMINATION IN EXCHANGE TRANSFUSIONS

Sir,—The free non-casruloplasmin copper level in the cord sera of 11 normal babies, measured by the atomic absorption method of Blomfield and MacMahon,1 has been found to have a range of 7-19 (mean 11) pig. per 100 ml., which is similar to the adult normal range of 5-15 (mean 9) ng. per 100 ml. In a series of 10 infants in our hospital with haemolytic disease of the newborn, the first blood-samples removed before exchange transfusion had a plasma-free-copper range of 13-176 (mean 62) |xg, per 100 ml. In 6 infants, undergoing exchange transfusions in a nearby maternity hospital, the plasma-free-copper range was 9-37 (mean 15) pg. per 100 ml. In our hospital metal 4-way stopcocks were often used, whereas the maternity hospital was routinely using disposable plastic transfusion sets. The disposable plastic sets were found to be copper-free, but squirting 5 ml. of copper-free deionised water through 7 sterilised metal stopcocks resulted in copper contamination of 3-384 (mean 96) pg. per 100 ml. The copper released did, however, tend to diminish with subsequent water rinsings. Since changing from metal stopcocks to plastic disposable 3-way stopcocks, the plasma-free-copper levels in 10 infants before exchange transfusion have been 6-37 (mean 14) pg. per 100 ml.

In patients with acute or chronic copper poisoning, one of the effects is intravascular haemolysis,5 and copper also enhances agglutination of red cells,® so that an excess of copper could conceivably contribute to the haemolytic process. In addition, copper may compete with bilirubin for binding sites on albumin, thereby increasing the toxicity of the bilirubin, or, in its free state, may act as an enzyme poison, perhaps causing brain and liver damage as in Wilson’s disease. The normal

732 APRIL 5, 1969

  • ■ newborn infant indeed resembles patients with Wilson’s disease in having a high level of copper in the liver and a diminished ability to synthesise cxruloplasmin. With the metal

' stopcocks further potential hazards were residual dried blood,

i and a white turbidity which was thought to be due to silicone grease.

' In view of these results, replacement of metal stopcocks for exchange transfusions by disposable plastic stopcocks or exchange-transfusion sets is advocated.

'   Children’s Medical Research Foundation,

.    Royal Alexandra Hospital for Children,

Sydney, New South Wales 2050. JEANETTE BLOMFIELD.

  • 4. Blomfield, J., MacMahon, R. A. J. din. Path, (in the press).

  • 5. Chuttani, H. K., Gupta, P. S., Gulati, S-, Gupta, D. N. Am. J. Med. -■    1965, 39, 849.

  • 6. Jandl, J. H., Simmons, R. L. Br. J. Hcemar. 1957, 3, 19.

BRITISH MEDICAL JOURNAL

Osteomyelitis after Exchange Transfusion

M. E. QURESHI, S. P. PURI

British Medical Journal, 1971, 2, 28-29

Gangrene of the big toe after exchange transfusion has been described but not to our knowledge osteomyelitis. We report osteomyelitis and gangrene in the big toe occurring in two out of 46b babies given exchange transfusions?-

  • Case 1

A male infant, born by induced labour at 36 weeks’ gestation because of rhesus isoimmunization, was clinically normal at birth with an Apgar score of 9/10 at three minutes. His weight was 2,480 g. Cord blood results were: direct Coombs teut positive; haemoglobin 108%; bilirubin 3 4 mg/100 ml; blood group A Rh-positive. Because of increasing jaundice, 86 hours after birth exchange transfusion was carried out with the two-catheter continuous technique (Saling, 1959; Ata and Holman, 1966) employing intravenous infant-feeding tubes (Warne Surgical Products)—a 4-5 F.G. size catheter for the umbilical artery and a 6 F.G. size for the umbilical vein. After 530 ml of 1-day-old acid citrate dextrose whole blood, group AB Rh-negative, had been exchanged uneventfully within two hours and 45 minutes, the catheters were left in situ for 60 hours filled with dilute heparinized saline solution and stoppered with three-way taps. Prophylactic antibiotics were not given.

About 24 hours after removal of the catheters the baby became lethargic and slow to feed, resented handling, looked ill, and had a rectal temperature of 38° C The whole of the right lower limb was swollen, with pregangrene discoloration on the middle of the sole, dorsum of foot, and lower third of shin. The right femoral artery was weakly palpable as compared with the left, but the microcirculation in the leg was satisfactory. The leg was held immobile in a position of slight flexion and abduction at the hip and slight flexion at the knee. Thromboembolism of the arterial tree of right lower limb was diagnosed, but as bone infection could not be ruled out blood culture was done and antibiotic cover with Ampiclox (sodium salts of ampicillin and cloxacillin) was started. Radiological examination of the leg was normal at

Lewisham Hospital, London S.E.13

M. E. QURESHI, M.R.C.P., d.C.ii., Paediatric Registrar

S. P. PURI, m.ch.(orth.), f.r.c.S., Orthopaedic Registrar this stage. To improve the microcirculation the baby was transfused with 45 ml of Rheomacrodex on three occasions (Gruber el al., 1965), and since the haemoglobin was only 50% a packed cell transfusion was given.

After 48 hours the general condition improved. The discoloured patches disappeared except on the tip of the big toe. Staphylococcus aureus grown from the blood culture was resistant to penicillin but sensitive to cioxacillin. After a week the swelling of the limb disappeared, except at the lower end of the femur. Repeat x-ray examination showed decalcification of the lower end of the femur and erosion of the metaphysial area indicative of osteomyelitis. The tip of the right big toe developed dry gangrene, which gradually separated in about 19 days. The antibiotics wen-continued for six weeks. Repeat x-ray examination of the lower limb four weeks later showed improvement in bone texture am! periosteal reaction in the metaphysial area. The baby w. > discharged home, aged 10 weeks, with normal movement of tl e hip and knee joints.

  • Case 2

A female baby was born on 3 March 1970 to an Rh-negative mother who had received intrauterine transfusions for rhesus incompatibility, the last one four days before spontaneous delivery at the 32nd week. The baby weighed 1,906 g, had an Apgar score of 9/10 at five minutes, appeared to be hydropic, and had a palpable liver (four fingerbreadths) and a palable spleen (three fingerbreadths). Cord blood results were: haemoglobin 37%; bilirubin 5-0 mg/100 ml; direct Coombs test positive; blood group O rhesus-positive. The first exchange transfusion was begun five hours aftei birth with rhesus- negative acid citrate dextrose partially packed blood by the two-catheter continuous technique. Altogether 360 ml of blood was transfused, while 326 ml was taken out. During the exchange I ml of 10% calcium gluconate was given after every 100 ml of blood; 8-4% sodium bicarbonate was given according to the Astrup results. A course of cephaloridine was started.

Another c :change Transfusion was carried out on 5 March and a third on the next day because of a rising serum bilirubin. On 7 March 80 ml of packed cells was transfused because the haemoglobin had fallen to 53%,. Next day the baby showed signs of paralytic ileus, and for five days was treated with intravenous fluids (including 10% dextrose) through the umbilical vein catheter end nasogastric suction. Two days later she developed sclerema n.onatorum and was given a five-day course of corticosteroids. During the last 48 hours the fluid therapy was given through the arterial umbilical catheter because the venous catheter became dislodged. The arterial catheter was removed after 10 days. On the same day petechial haemorrhages were teen over the body and the baby passed blood-stained stools. The right leg was swollen, the tip of the right big toe was blue, and there was a patch of bruising on the little toe and light knee, with the skin bruising easily. X-rat examination of the right leg showed nothing abnormal. Afte: a transfusion of 80 ml ot fresh whole blood no fresh bleeding occurred and the petechial haemorrhages faded away.

Six days later the tip of the big toe became gangrenous. Signs of an infection in the right knee joint developed, and one week later pus was aspirated from which Escherichia coli was grown. This was found resistant to cephaloridine and sensitive to gen-

BRITISH MEDICAL JOURNAL 3 APRIL 1971

tamicin and kanamycin. Blood culture also grew E. coli and Staph, aureus. Treatment with gentamicin and cloxacillin was started and within a few days the swelling of the knee abated and the baby started to move the leg. The tip of the big toe demarcated into dry gangrene, ■ which separated on 9 May.

The antibiotics were stopped after four weeks when the leg appeared normal and x-ray examination showed that the infection had settled. The baby was discharged home on 18 May when 11 weeks old and weighing 3,410 g.

Comment

Prolonged umbilical vein catheterization may cause local thrombosis, umbilical vein phlebitis and pyaemia, liver necrosis, and pulmonary embolism, (Scott, 1965). Portal hypertension (Thompson and Sherlock, 1964), bowel perforation (Corkery et al., 1968; Orme and Eades, 1968), and myocardial infarction have also been documented (Van Der Hauwaert et al., 1967). Umbilical artery catheterization has also been associated with a few complications. Gupta et al. (1968) reported complications in 10% of 335 babies, which included bleeding, clinical signs of arterial obstruction, and arterial thrombosis detected at necropsy. Only one baby lost the tip of the big toe. Cochran et al. (1968) reported complications in 8% of 387 babies. Gluteal muscle necrosis has been described (Ulan and Swyer, 1968).

The clinical picture in our two cases can be explained only by thrombosis induced by the catheter in the arterial tree with superimposed infection. When the catheters were removed multiple embolization must have occurred, affecting

29

the skin, the big toe, and lower end of the femur. In the second case the infection was not controlled so suppuration became widespread. These are the only two cases with permanent sequalae in the 406 babies we have exchange transfused in the past four years.

We are grateful to Dr. B. Gans and Dr. C. A. Holman for permission to record these cases and for helpful advice and criticism. Our thanks are due to our resident pathologists for their help and to the nursing staff of the premature baby unit for their devoted nursing.

References

Cochran, W. D., Davies, H. T., and Smith, C. A. (1968). Paediatrics, 42, 769                                                                                  . .

Corlery, J. J„ Dubowitz, V., Lister, J., and Moosa, A. (1968). British Medical Journal, 4, 345

Gruber, U. F-, Bergentz, S- E., and Gelin, L. E. (1965). Scandinavian Journal of Clinical and Laboratory Investigation, 17, Suppl. No. 86, p. 143.

Gupta, J. M.s Robertson, N. R. C., and Wigglesworth, J. S., (1968). Archives of Disease in Childhood, 43, 382.

Orme, R. L. E., and Eades, S. M. (1968. British Medical Journal, 4, 349.

Saliug, E. (1959). Geburtshilfe und Frauen heilkunde, 19, 230.

Scott, J. M. (1965). Archives of Disease in Childhood, 40, 426.

Thompson, E. N., Sherlock, S. (1964). Quarterly Journal of Medicine, 33, 465.                                              ‘          ' '

Ulan, O. A., and Swyer, M. B. (1968). Canadian Pediatric Society Meeting, June 1968.

Van Der Hauwaert, L. G., Loos, M. C., and Verhaeghe, L. K. (1967). Journal of Pediatrics, 70, 745.

Reprint from THE JOURNAL OF PEDIATRICS

June 1958 Volume 58, Number 6, pps 694-700

UNEXPLAINED DEATH FROM EXCHANGE TRANSFUSION

William C. Taylor, M.B., Ch.B., Lloyd 0. Grisdale, M.D., and

.               Allan G. Stewart, Ph.D.

Edmonton, Alberta

DURING the XI years that have elapsed since the introduction of exchange transfusion for the treatment of hemolytic disease of the newborn, attention has been periodically focused on the fact, that, this pro-ycedure is not without its dangers and may occasionally be associated with unexpected fatality. Allen and Diamond1 have recently pointed out that, with few exceptions, it has been impossible to explain the deaths that / arise during or shortly after exchange transfusion. Walker and Mollison2 have listed the causes of death occurring in association with hemolytic disease of the newborn in England and Wales during the years 1953 and 1955. In 88 (16 per eent) of 550 deaths, the fatality arose during or within 4 hours of exchange transfusion. The immediate cause of death was not apparent in these cases but, from the clinical information available, it seemed that death should not otherwise have taken place at that time.

The following case reports are presented in the belief that they represent a sequence of events which must occur in a certain but at present unknown proportion of sudden deaths arising during exchange transfusion.

From the Department of PneilliitrleH, Unl-vi-rsdty of Alberta uml University or Alberta Hospital, Edmonton. Alberta,

CASE REPORTS

  • Case 1. —Cardiac Arrest During Exchange Transfusion.—      ~   ’

This female infant was delivered by cesarean section on the tenth of September, 1957. Cesarean section was performed at 35 weeks’ gestation because of a rise in maternal I) antibody, titer to y3 2, and because of the death of the 3 preceding siblings from hemolytic disease. The infant weighed 2,220 Gm. She cried spontaneously and on examination appeared normal except for yellow staining of the ver-nix and the umbilical cord. The spleen was not palpable. The cord blood serum bilirubin was 6.4 mg. per cent, hemoglobin 9.5 Gm, per cent, hematocrit 26 per cent, and reticulocyte count 14.4 per cent. The direct Coombs’ test was positive.

The first exchange transfusion was carried out within, one hour of delivery. Using a 10 e.e. syringe, 415 e.e. of blood were withdrawn and 384 c.c. of packed cells injected. Throughout the 1-hour procedure the infant’s condition remained satisfactory. Following the exchange, the serum bilirubin was 2.5 mg. per cent, the hemoglobin 13.4 Gm. per cent, and the hematocrit 35 per cent.

At the age of 7 hours, the serum bilirubin had risen to 9.0 mg. per cent and a second exchange transfusion was givem Using the same technique as before, 310 e.e. of blood were withdrawn and 290 e.e. injected in less than I hour. The infant’s condition remained satisfactory throughout and periodic electrocardiographic (ECG) tracings taken with a direct writing

094


Sanborn, electrocardiograph revealed At the age of 22 hours, the serum no abnormalities in the standard leads, bilirubin was 13.6 mg. per cent, the A few minutes after the exchange had hemoglobin 8.3 Gm. per cent, and the

change was attempted using 7-day-old blood which had been packed by removal of supernatant plasma a few hours before the exchange. After 80 c.c. of blood had been withdrawn and 70 c.c. injected, an EGG tracing taken

28 minutes after the commencement of the exchange showed evidence of slow nodal rhythm. (Figs. 1, 2, 3, and 4.) During the next 4 minutes, the cardiae slowing progressed, to ventricular fibrillation, and corppletecay-arrest, At the time of i^teetwn of the cardiac slowing the infant’s condition appeared satisfactory. There were no signs of respiratory distress, cyanosis, or pulmonary adventitious sounds. Clinical signs of collapse were only apparent when the ECG tracing showed evidence of ventricular fibrillation. The cardiac arrhythmia was uninfluenced by discontinuing the exchange and immediate injection of 2 c.e. calcium glucoheptonate into the umbilical vein. The heart remained in asystole for a pe-iod of 5 minutes, but responded to ntracardiac injection of Adrenalin, nd artificial respiration with tracheal ntubation and intermittent positive •ressure oxygen.

sis which showed no response to intravenous injection of % M lactate solution or sodium, bicarbonate solution.

Death occurred at the age of 38 hours.

Fig, 6.—Case 2. Bead I. Time from start of exchange—27 mln.; volume of blood injected— 185 c.c,; slow nodal rhythm, rate—80 per minute.


For the remaining 14 hours of her life the infant remained in a precarious condition. She was nursed in a high concentration of oxygen,- but her respiratory rate became irregular with intermittent periods of apnea and cyanosis. Her serum biochemistry showed evidence of a persistent aeido-

Autopsy.—This was performed 12 hours after death. There was a slight icteric tinge to the skin as well as subconjunctival hemorrhages and pete-ehiae over the trunk. Petechial hemorrhages were also seen subpleurally in the region of the trachea and lungs, in the heart, kidneys, and liver. The lungs were heimmh&sdt^^

in the lower portion and fleshy in consistence. Microscopic examination revealed areas of extramedullary hematopoiesis, which were marked in the liver but also present in the kidney. Hemorrhages were present within the lung, kidnev, thvmus, and adrenal. The lungs showed moderate atelectasis. Sections of the heart showed no remarkable histopathological change.

The causes of death were finally designated, according to their presumed degree of importance, as follows: (1) post-transfusion electrolyte imbalance; (2) hemolytic disease of the newborn; (3) prematurity; (4) hypoxia; and (5) pulmonary atelectasis.

  • Case 2. —Cardiac Arrhythmia, Dur-iiiiT fixchane/e Transfusion.—

Experience with electrocardiography in 50 exchange transfusions performed on 36 infants has revealed one other example of gross cardiac arrhythmia. This infant weighed 2,160 Gm. and was of 35 weeks’ gestation. The cord blood hemoglobin was 7.0 Gm. per cent and the bilirubin 6.82 mg. per cent. He received an exchange transfusion at the age of 1 hour, using 5-day-old partially packed blood. After injection of 185 c.c. of blood in 15 c.c. aliquots, the heart rate, was suddenly slowed although the infant’s general condition remained satisfactory. The ECG showed marked sinus bradycardia and occasional ectopic beats (Figs. 5 and-6). The arrhythmia was uninfluenced by injection of 1.5 c.e. calcium gluconate (10 per cent solution) and persisted until the end of a cautiously executed exchange of 450 re. of blood. The bradveard' . .mated with periods of normal E('G configuration. ECG tracings taken on the first, second, third, and seventh days after the exchange transfusion were not remarkable and the infant’s subsequent progress was uneventful.

Biochemical estimations on donor Mood ■

Potassium = 9.7 mEq./L.

Calcium — 5.2 mEq./L.

Biochemical estimations on infant’s blood

Before exchange transfusion Potassium ■= 6.9 mEq./L. Calcium = 5.0 mEq./L.

Mid-transfusion

Potassium = 5.1 mEq./L.

Calcium = 6.6 mEq./L.

Post-t r ansfusion

Potassium = 7.6 mEq./L.

Calcium = 8.6 mEq./L.

The high figures for calcium in the mid- and post-transfusion samples could be due to contamination from immediately preceding injections of calcium gluconate solution.

DISCUSSION

Two examples of 2:1 aurieuloven-tricular heart block detected by electrocardiographic examination during exchange transfusion have been reported by Joos, Yu, and Miller3 (Table I). One infant, transfused with donor blood containing a plasma potassium of 8.0 mEq./L., developed parasystoles and 2:1 block intermit-tenly during the fourth and fifth 100 c.e. of the exchange. The arrhythmia was uninfluenced by calcium administration and the infant’s serum potassium did not rise above 5.40 mEq./L. The second infant, a premature weighing 1,190 Gm., was transfused with donor blood containing a plasma potassium of 18.6 mEq./L. Arrhythmia consisting of 2:1 heart block developed during administration of the second 50 c.c. of exchange, persisted for 4 minutes, and then reverted to normal rhythm following the intravenous injection of 0.1 Gm. of calcium gluconate. The serum potassium just before the onset of the 2:1 block -was 9.12 mEq./L. This baby died within 24 hours of the exchange transfusion. Autopsy revealed the findings of prematurity, severe hemolytic disease of

698


THE JOt’Hi-WHUCS


the newborn, and kernicterus. The heart was not abnormal.

Examples of cardiac arrest during exchange transfusion have been reported by Walker and Neligan. (1 case).4 Pew (1 ease),5 and Bolan.de, Traisman, and Philipsborn (4 cases).® These eases are summarized in Table I. Campbell7 in a study of potassium levels in exchange transfusion has referred to 7 deaths in association with the transfusion. In 4 of these cases the infant’s maximum potassium level ranged between 6.13 and 10.23 mEq./L. manifested itself with clinical signs of pulmonary or cardiac distress, which have included rapid respiratory rate, cyanosis, pulmonary crepitations, gagging, and production of frothy mucus. In contrast to this, the clinical state of the infants, referred to in Table I, was such that no anxiety was felt regarding their condition until the sudden onset of the cardiac manifestations. It is most likely that these infants, suffered from a complication of exchange transfusion other than that of congestive heart failure.

Table I shows an analysis of 10 infants who shared in common the electrocardiographic features of sudden onset of arrhythmia, 2:1 heart block, or the clinical features of sudden cardiac arrest. In so 'far as it can be ascertained from reading the reports of these cases, it seemed unlikely that any of them suffered from the type of congestive heart failure described by Walker and Neligan,1 and Allen and Diamond.1 Congestive heart failure in hemolytic disease of the newborn can be an insidious process but has usually

There was no definite evidence other than the clinical features and the electrocardiographic findings that the mechanism of the cardiac arrhythmia was the same in all 10 eases. Case 1 which showed a sudden progression from a state of slow nodal rhythm, without associated clinical features, to complete cardiac arrest in a period of 4 minutes suggested that there was a possible interrelationship in this group ' of cases. It scented likely that in this case there was some biochemical derangement or other factor which, acting over a short period of time, severely embarrassed the heart action. Hyperpotassemia was not considered to be a likely cause. Serum potassium levels up to 7.8 mEq./L. have not been considered unusual (MeCance and Young8) during the normal newborn period. Sudden eardiac arrest occurred with a potassium level as low as 4.5 mEq./L. in the infant reported by Pew.5 In addition, Bolande® has reported 1 infant with a serum potassium of 17 mEq./L. who did not develop cardiac arrest during exchange and who survived the exchange transfusion for a period of 17 hours. A comparison of the potassium in the donor blood and the potassium in the infant’s circulation in Table I suggested that most infants could handle comparatively large loads of infused potassium. This confirmed the obser-. vations of Campbell7 and of Bolande? । The possibility of cardiac arrest 1 from hyperpotassemia also appeared unlikely from the experimental work of Baker and his co-workers? They have reported the use of potassium citrate in the arrest of the perfused isolated hearts obtained from 4 stillborn fetuses of 16 to 20 weeks’ gestation. A concentration of potassium citrate equivalent to 14.8 mEq./L. (calculated as tripotassium citrate) had to be directed as a continuous infusion into the coronary circulation to produce cardiac arrest. The volume of the potassium citrate solution required to produce this effect was not specified. Efficr and his co-workers10 have reported the use of potassium citrate solutions equivalent in strength to 230.0 mEq./L. (calculated as tripotassium citrate) and 6-20 c.c. volume to produce cardiac arrest in children Undergoing cardiac surgery.

In both reports the potassium solutions were directed into the coronary arteries and there was no opportunity for dilution to occur from mixture with venous blood. They have not, however, reported on the efficacy of weaker solutions of potassium. In exchange transfusion, the donor blood has ample opportunity to become diluted with the infant’s venous blood before being directed to the coronary circulation.

Hypocalcemia was also considered as a cause of cardiac arrest. In 9 out. of the 10 eases, calcium was given as a prophylactic measure during the exchange transfusion. In 2 eases of heart block and one of cardiac arrest, there was no response to immediate administration of calcium, It appeared unlikely, there Tore, that calcium deficiency per se was the cause of the cardiac phenomena.

Pew5 drew attention to the fact that his ease of cardiac arrest followed shortly after the introduction of a bottle of cool blood into the exchange transfusion and that the heart felt eold when it was massaged. In Case 1 no attempt was made to warm the blood other than allowing it to stand at room temperature for about 10 to 15 minutes. Information with regard to warming of the blood is not available on the other eases. Hoff and Stansfield11 and Deterling and his coworkers12 have provided experimental evidence in the dog that ventricular fibrillation could develop when the body temperature was reduced below 73° F. or the local ventricular temperature below 50° F.

One factor which has not been given much consideration in previous reports is the effect that the acid-ci-trate dextrose anticoagulant mixture

700


THE JOURNAL OF PEDIATRICS

has on reducing the pH and COa combining power of donor blood. On samples of donor blood tested at this hospital, the average pH was 6.2 and this level varied little with the duration of storage. In Case 1, severe and irreversible acidosis was an outstanding feature following the third replacement transfusion. Deterling12 demonstrated that the ventricular fibrillation induced in dogs by hypothermia did not develop when the blood was maintained in a state of alkalosis by hyperventilation.

At the present time it is not possible to state that any one specific factor or combinations of factors is responsible for the occurrence of cardiac arrest in infants undergoing exchange transfusion. According to circumstances several or all of the following factors may be present: hyperpotassemia, hypocalcemia, cooling of the heart, acidosis, prematurity, and the disease process of hemolytic disease. There may be other factors at present unsuspected. The combined use of electrocardiography and adequate biochemical study is one way of further elucidating the problems involved and, at the same time, ensuring maximum safety for the infant.

SUMMARY            •

Attention is drawn to the fact that sudden and unexpected death may occur during' or shortly after exchange transfusion for hemolytic disease of the newborn.

One case is reported of bradycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and eardiae arrest after 70 c.c. of blood had been exchanged. A second case is reported of bradycardia and arrhythmia developing after an exchange of 185 c.c. of blood.

These eases are compared with 8 other case reports in which there is a similarity of clinical or electrocardiographic findings. It is not possible from the data available to determine a common etiological factor for the sudden alteration in cardiac function.

It is suggested that possible factors which might be operating singly, or in combination, are hyperpotassemia, hypocalcemia, hypothermia, acidosis, prematurity, and the disease processes of hemolytic disease.

REFERENCES

  • 1. Allen, F. II., and Diamond, L. K.: Erythroblastosis Foetalis, New England J. Med. 257 : 761, 1957.

  • 2. Walker, W., and Mollison, P. L.: Haemolytic Disease of the Newborn, Lancet 272: 1309, 1957.

  • 3. Joos, H. A., Yu, P. N., and Miller, G.: Electrocardiographic Changes During Replacement Transfusion, A. M. A. Am, J. Dis. Child. 88: 471, 1954.

  • 4. Walker, W., and Neligan, G. A.: Exchange Transfusion in Haemolytic Disease of the Newborn, Brit. M. J. 332: 681, 1955.

  • 5. Pew, W. L.: Cardiac Arrest During Exchange Transfusion, J, Pediat. 47: 645, .1955.

  • 6. Holande, R. P., Traisman, H. S., and Pliilipsborn, II. F., Jr.: Electrolyte Considerations in Exchange Transfusions for Erythroblastosis Fetalis, J. Pediat. 49: 401, 1956.

  • 7. Campbell, W. A. B.: Potassium Levels in Exchange Transfusion, Arch, Dis. Child. 30: 513, 1955.

  • 8. MeCance, R. A., and Young, W. F.: .Secretion of Urine by Newborn Infants, J. Physiol. 99: 265, 1941.

  • 9. Baker, J, B. E., Bentall, H. H., Dreyer, B., and Melrose, D. G.: Arrest of Isolated Heart With Potassium Citrate, Lancet 273: 555, 1957.

CLINICAL PATHOLOGICAL

CONFERENCE

THE CHILDREN’S HOSPITAL MEDICAL CENTER, BOSTON, MASS.

Sidney Farber, M.D., Editor

Gordon F. Vander, M.D., Assistant Editor

The patient was a 6-hour-old male who was transferred to this hospital because of . hyperbilirubinemia. There are no details concerning the delivery of this baby. The birth weight was 6 pounds, 2 ounces. The mother was well and received no medication during pregnancy. Her blood type was AB, Rh negative, and anti-Rh titers of 1:32 were observed 2 and 3 weeks before delivery'. Albumin anti-Rh titer was 1:16. The infant was transferred to this hospital when total bilirubin was 10.5 mg. per cent at 6 hours of age. Two siblings wrere normal from birth.

/ • I he patient wras a well-developed and 1 active newborn boy in no               ^is

length was 50 cm.; head circumference, 35 cm.; and chest circumference, 33 cm. The skin was reddish yellow and dry. The sclerae were possibly icteric. The pulse was 100, and respirations were 40 when the infant was crying, and the temperature was 96° F. (axilla). The mouth and throat were reddened. Lungs were clear. No murmurs were heard. Cardiac rhythm was regular. The tip of the spleen was palpable. The liver was felt 1 cm. below the costal margin. The cord was slightly yellow and reddened at the base. Extremities were normal. On neurological examination there was a good grasp and cry, Moro reflexes were normal, and suck and neck traction were normal. Fontanels were normal.

On laboratory examination the hemoglobin was 22.5 Gm. per cent; white blood cells were 10,600 per cubic millimeter with 64 per cent polymorphonuclear leukocytes. 4 per cent band forms, 26 per cent lymphocytes, 2 per cent monocytes, 3 per cent eosinophils, and 1 per cent basophils. Platelets were considered decreased on smear. Erythrocytes were normal morphologically. Direct bilirubin was 0.9 mg. per 100 ml.; total was 11.3 mg. per 100 nd. Coombs' test was 3-plus positive. Blood type was A. Rh positive. Bacteriologic culture of umbilicus grew Staphylococcus aureus, coagulase positive; phage type, 3B/3C/55/71. A black stool culture grew Staph, aureus, coagulase positive, nontypahle; Streptococcus fccalis, rare coli, and aerobacter. Nose and throat culture showed Staphylococcus albus.

Eight hours after admission an exchange transfusion with neutralized, heparinized

940


type Os Rh negative blood was begun. The initial venous pressure was 50 mm. Exchange transfusion was performed in 20 ml. aliquots after removal of 30 ml. Twenty-five minutes after beginning the exchange (after removal of 90 ml. and replacement of 70 ml.), the > infant suddenly became dusky and cardiac i rhythm was irregular. The procedure was discontinued. The trachea was suctioned, with little return, and oxygen was given without improvement. Respirations became irregular. An electrocardiogram 15 minutes after the end of the transfusion showed gross irregularity in ventricular rhythm, coupled beats, variable R-S, QS, and RSR' waves, depressed S-T, and inverted T waves. Thirty minutes later, after intubation, external cardiac massage, and intermittent positive pressure, electrocardiogram showed a sine wave pattern with rare ventricular complexes, Adrenalin was given without prolonged benefit. The face and neck appeared I swollen. Heart beat ceased at 2:25 a.m., 7 | y hours after admission, and l/a hours after I the exchange.                                  !

Dm. William Pfeffer.88 We are presented an , infant with erythroblastosis, in itself not remarkable. However, the outcome was not only remarkable but unexpected. It is unfortunate that the issue here is not an isolated example, but has been seen before in this institution and has been reported in the literature fairly frequently. Very briefly, let us note some of the salient points in the protocol. This 6-hour-oId boy presented at the hospital with a very high degree of bilirubim-mia, a degree which all would agree necessitates immediate exchange transfusion if the very likely possibility of further rise of bilirubin and ultimate kernicterus is to be avoided. 1 he infant seemed to be in good condition; he was vigorous, the skin was red, the hemoglobin was not only adequate but quite high, 22 Gm. per cent. The culture from the umbilicus perhaps sounds frightening, but I don’t believe that the infant .survived long enough for the Staphylococcus to cause any trouble.

Oue thing I would like to emphasize is that although the details of delivery are unknown, we are told that the mother received no medication during the pregnancy. Drugs given to the ( mother during delivery may be extremely im-1 portant whether babies become jaundiced or not. However, we cannot follow this up, and let us assume that there is no problem in this area.

As is quite proper, exchange transfusion was carried out shortly after admission here. This procedure was begun at 12:45 in the morning. Perhaps this is significant because it is my I opinion that the skill, awareness, and alertness of the operator has something to do with the I outcome of any exchange transfusion. Possibly at quarter to one in the morning, judgment was . not as good as might be. I am in no position to be too critical of the outcome in this baby because the same thing has happened to me on more than one occasion.

Neutralized heparinized Group O, Rh negative blood was used. At the onset of the exchange, the infant was in good condition; the venous pressure was 50 mm., a measurement we would consider normal. Between 30 and 80 mm. pressure by direct measurement of the height of the column of blood above the umbilicus is usually considered normal. This is, of course, a relatively inaccurate method of measurement, but it seems to be clinically useful. Exchange transfusion was begun by removal of 30 c.c. of blood. Now, I am not sure that this harmed the baby, but I think it was more blood than was actually necessary to remove. It is my custom to remove blood in quantities as large as this only if the baby has evidence of hydrops or of high venous pressure. If there is rtp elevation of venous pressure, it is my custom to form a deficit, but to form a deficit slowly, removing 10 c.c., replacing 5, the next time removing 15 and replacing 10, so as to carry along with a deficit of about 10 to 15 c.c. of blood during the exchange. If, as is possible, after 30 c.c. of blood were removed, a further 20 c.c. were removed, we would then have a deficit of 50 c.c. In a baby with a large blood volume and high venous pressure, this would he beneficial, otherwise not. In this baby, 20 c.c. may have been reinjected, and then 20 c.c. removed. I assume that the exchange went along fairly slowly because 25 minutes elapsed before 90 c.c. were removed and 70 c.c. replaced. 1'hi.s is good. It is my personal feeling that while rapid exchange can be done with impunity in some babies, it is not always possible. Some babies do much better with a slower exchange, and some babies do better with smaller increments and withdrawals of blood.

Suddenly, after 25 minutes, the infant became dusky, cardiac rhythm became irregular, and from this point on, the course of the disease was downhill.

Unfortunately, we do see some babies who have sudden changes in. condition, but in most babies who are having adverse effects there is some small warning, which I shall describe later, which will enable the operator to slow his rate of exchange or even to discontinue it. If one has exchanged over 200 c.c. of blood, termination of the procedure is the safest plan; repeat exchange transfusion after 6 hours can be carried !out if necers: ry. Apparently, the heart bore the brunt of the; baby’s difficulty. The electrocardiogram would tppear to me to show irritation of the ventricle, premature ventricular beats, and as suggested by Dr. Nadas when I consulted him 2 days ago, the other findings could possibly be interpreted as evidence of myocardial ischemia. In any case, the myocardium was not very healthy and the infant died shortly thereafter, one and one-quarter hours after the ex- . change transfusion with the comment that the face and neck appeared swollen. At the end of 500 c.c. exchange, with no increase in venous pressure, I have seen one baby develop marked congestive failure with accuinuhition of large amounts of pericardial and pl oral fluid, very loud moist rales in the chest, .d a picture of drowned lung at autopsy. Whether or not this process was present in this baby, or whether this ! explains the swelling, I do not know. In any case, I assume that this represents an unexpected effect related to exchange transfusion, rather than effect of erythroblastosis, which did not seem too severe in this baby. When the baby is in as good condition initially as this one was and dies at the age of 7% hours, some special explanation is required.

There is no question in my mind that exchange transfusion should have been carried out. What happened to the baby? Why did it happen? How could this be prevented in the future?

My experience with this procedure is centered in the years 1950 through 1960, during । which time I performed between 800 and 1,000 i exchange transfusions and observed between । 1,000 to 1,200 babies with erythroblastosis as | well as other infants with jaundice. I will say, | to reassure any operator who loses a baby, that I I have lost at least 12 to 15 babies during my years of experience in exactly the same way. I wish I knew more about what went wrong. In du- past, pathologic examination of babies who have died under these circumstances has, usually been unreveaiing.

Let us, for a moment, go over some of the known untoward effects of exchange transfusion and some of the untoward effects that do not occur, but that we worry about. It has become obvious that any baby with hydrops or severe anemia, or severe erythroblastosis, is immediately a worse risk for exchange transfusion than one in good condition, and, therefore, any mortality figures are going to show a more serious effect of exchange on the babies who are more sick. Since any sick baby is a candidate for adverse reaction to exchange, exchange should be done more slowly and, in my opinion, should be done to only half the quantity that one would ordinarily use. An exchange of 200 to 300 c.c. in a baby with severe anemia, enlargement of liver and spleen, and elevated venous pressure usually is sufficient to result in immediate clinical improvement. Further exchange should then be deferred to see if bilirubin rises. Frequently, in this type of baby, marked elevation of bilirubin does not occur and further exchange may not be necessary. In general, if an exchange transfusion of 500 c.c. occurs in a sick baby, this type of untoward reaction becomes almost common before the end of the exchange.

The possibility of embolization has always bothered us. When you put the catheter into the umbilical vein, particularly when the baby is over 24 hours old, and suck out a 2 cm. clot, which is 3 mm. in thickness, you wonder what would happen if instead of sucking it out, you inadvertently pushed it forward. So far as I know, this has never occurred. Some years ago Dr. Landing made a careful study of the lungs of babies who died shortly after exchange and was unable to demonstrate any embolic phenomenon there or anywhere else. There have been several cases reported, and I have seen at least one, of a septic thrombus forming. (In my case, in the radial artery 2 days after exchange.) I think this is an unusual complication. Air embolism should not occur, with any care.

Septicemia is sometimes difficult to distinguish from asymptomatic bacteremia found in babies after exchange transfusion. The incidence of positive blood cultures following an exchange transfusion is fairly high, but I have seen only one or two babies who have had clinical evidence of septicemia with fever and illness. Probably septicemia is not a problem here. The umbilical vein may be ruptured, usually close enough to the surface that the rupture is observed and the catheter can be replaced in the proper place. It is quite possible to form a false passage in the cord dividing Wharton’s jelly as one goes along for a surprisingly large distance, even to 3 or 4 cm. Fortunately, one is able to check this. The rule is: Do not inject blood until you can withdraw blood freely and in large amounts. There has been at least one instance of blood being poured out into the retroperitoneal space when blood was given, not in the vein but into the cord substance. Hepatic necrosis has been reported twice, and I have seen one case. These babies die after 2 or 3 days of lethargy and apparent hepatic coma. The timing excludes this possibility in the present child. Hemolytic transfusion reactions, in the usual sense, do not occur, perhaps because of the age of the baby and relative inadequacy of his antibody system. Adrenal hemorrhage has occasionally been seen, I think, more or less as an incidental finding.

Dr. Van Praagh, in 1961, recorded several cases of ruptured spleen, none of which were diagnosed before death and all of which, in retrospect, had in common enlargement of the abdomen with difficulty in feeling the liver and spleen, profound anemia and pallor, and death with diagnosis made only at autopsy. This is something to be considered in a baby who is not doing well because it is a curable disease, once the diagnosis is made.

Any baby from whom you remove more blood than his vascular system is capable of losing wilt have an adverse reaction. I have seen this at least once; a 3 pound baby who inadvertently had about 40 c.c. of blood removed before any was injected. He promptly went into shock and died very soon thereafter. I think, perhaps, that the adverse effect of decrease in circulating blood volume, or the swings in pressure involved, may enter into this case, perhaps only as an auxiliary factor. Perhaps in this baby, sudden congestive failure caused swelling of the face and neck, and perhaps cardiac tamponade from pericardial fluid.

Dr. Van Praagh’s1 study in 1961 is interesting tn regard to this case because he analyzed 882 patients from this hospital with erythroblastosis; 650 received a total of 902 exchange transfusions. Of these babies, 82 died and 32 per cent of them died during or within 6 hours of exchange transfusion. This comes to 3 per cent of deaths in association with exchange transfusions. Of this inurnbcr, 1 per cent (that is, one third of the babies who died) showed no adequate cause of death at autopsy. In 13 babies there was evidence i that cardiac irregularity and arrhythmia played I some role in the death of the baby. These fig- ' ures agree with other figures quoted in the literature. Boggs3 reports, from Philadelphia, an incidence of only 0.2 per cent death during exchange transfusion in babies who are vigorous and healthy at the time exchange is done. However, he does have 73 babies who were classified as being weak or having early kernicterus, and in this group 13 per cent died during or shortly after exchange transfusion. It is not surprising that 46 per cent of hydropic or moribund babies died during or shortly after exchange transfusion. My own experience would closely parallel that ( recorded by Von Praagh.

.Babies showing this reaction, fortunately, are recognizable clinically. I have no figures on how often a reaction of this kind occurs during exchange and how often a bad outcome is averted by proper steps. I would think that such a figure would be very high, perhaps as high as 25 per cent, and perhaps more if your worry quotient is low.

What can be done? You can learn more by watching the baby’s face, respiration, and color than you can by electrocardiographic monitor or even with a nurse listening with a stethoscope. The babies who get into trouble usually begin to show some clinical evidence of difficulty in the form of a weak cry and pallor, of a distressed expression on the face, if you wall. I think everybody knows what I mean. The pulse rises. The patient becomes lethargic, and pinching the ear docs not result in crying. When such symptoms appear, exchange should be discontinued immediately. You can often proceed again in a few minutes with the exchange, going more slowly and more cautiously than before. If this happens twice during an exchange, discontinue the procedure and try again some 6 hours later. Some babies act a little differently. Some babies have immediate, unforseen cardiac arrest. Some seem to have apnea with a closed glottis. It is not always possible to blame Jack of calcium for this because I have had this oc

cur 10 minutes after having given calcium. Since this baby received heparinized blood, we cannot blame citrate binding of calcium because heparin causes no difficulty of this sort. Heparinized blood has several other advantages; you are required Io use fresh blood, excluding increased levels of potassium. There may be .some benefit when the blood is still warm from the donor.

Dr. Kevy tells me that this case represents

Fig. 1. Lung: Hypoventilated air spaces contain some squames, round or irregular meconium bodies, and amorphous material. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain. Original magnification x225.)

the only untoward effect of exchange transfusion by using heparinized blood at this hospital in approximately 200 exchanges, an incidence of 0.5 per cent. I would like to have another visit on a Clinical Pathological Conference after 1,000 have been done, because my own feeling is that, although the citrate may be contributory, it is not the entire cause of these deaths. The ‘ temperature of the blood ordinarily does not seem to be a deciding factor. Wc have used cold blood many times with no adverse effects. The electrolyte balance probably is not a problem, although it is quite obvious that potassium and calcium levels are important if blood over 5 days old is used. I feel that the speed of giving the exchange transfusion, the volume of blood removed, and the volume of blood reintroduced each time is very important. I wish I knew more about the possible reflex changes i that might occur, but from a common sense viewpoint, 20 c.c. of blood in a baby of this size is a large amount, comparable to 500 c.c. of blood in an adult. If you take from an adult I one pint of blood by phlebotomy 20 times over I a period of one hour, the incidence of syncope in these donors is going to be considerably raised above what happens with a single bleeding. It has always been my opinion, that these babies die because of reflex changes initiated by rapid changes in pressure and volume within the heart or within the great vessels around the heart. Whatever the cause of these deaths, the most important preventive factors are good clinical judgment in the use of exchange transfusion and acute observation of the baby during the procedure.

Dr. Nadas, would you comment on the electrocardiogram?

Dr. Alexander Nadas. I would think that these represent atrial and ventricular conduction disturbances w'ith premature beats. There is nothing specific about the tracing. It is not the kind of tracing one finds in potassium intoxication or in hypocalcemia. The tracing simply shows disintegrating cardiac function. I am not sure why, but I would think possibly in terms of ischemia.

Dr. Pfeffer. Could some of this represent pericardial disease?

Dr. Nadas. I cannot be specific about that,

Fig. 2. Bronchus: Fine acid fast positive granular deposits, are found in bronchial epithelial cells-(Hematoxylin and eosin stain. Original magnification x 1,000.)

Fig. 3. Liver: Modest, mostly late stages of normoblastic activity are found in hepatic sinus* oids. Parenchymal cells contain fine “vacuoles.” The arrow indicates a hyaline mass in the wall of a portal vein having a partial endothelial overgrowth. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain. Original magnification *225.)


but there seems to be a good deal more to it than that.

Da. Sherwin Kevy. I would like to pass on some of the comments of Dr. Diamond, who could not be here.

Dr. Pfeffer’s masterful discussion has already touched on many points made by Dr. Diamond, but he wanted to stress the fact that the figure 20 is not a magic one. One cannot predict, absolutely, that serious complications will occur

only when the bilirubin reaches 20 mg, per cent. Removal of 20 c.c. of blood at a time or maintaining a 20 ml. deficit during exchange is definitely not possible in some babies, especially those that are small. Dr. Muirhead, from the Boston Lying-in Hospital, has measured some pulse pressures during exchange transfusion. We have noted, quite consistently, that when you have a child who weighs 5 pounds, 8 ounces, and you withdraw' 20 c.c. of blood, these children very frequently have a marked drop in I pulse- This is quite similar to what may occur in a blood donor who develops marked syncope.

We learned long ago that atropine seemed very i helpful at such times, and recently we have had

2 babies who developed bradycardia during exchange; the pulse rate quickly recovered after atropine was administered. If there be such a thing, this is what we call the vasovagal reaction. Atropine tends to block this reaction, and Adrenalin pharmacologically would tend to aggravate the problem as it may have done in this case. As we look over the record in this youngster, we noticed that at one time the pulse dropped from 140 to 88. Another group of patients, particularly prone to such .reactions, apparently, are adults with high hematocrits, often accompanied by a relatively small plasma volume. There is no reason to think that children react differently under similar circumstances.

Dr, Nadas, is this a proper vasovagal reaction, or some such thing?

Dr, Nadas. Cali it shock, perhaps.

Dr. Kevy. Yes, that is correct loo.

Dr. Nadas. Vasovagal ideas remind me of statistics. We all know that quite a lot can become lost in a number. We know very little about the hemodynamics of what is happening during exchange transfusion in these little babies. ' We really only guess at what happens to cardiac output, to arterial and other pressures. I can’t

replace it with some bad blood. Right? 1

Dr. Kevy. Well, the blood has been heparinized.

Dr. Nadas. Do we know, for instance, how much catechol amine you are taking out of this baby's circulation and perhaps not replacing? By the Starling hypothesis, the pressure-volume business, cardiac output depends on diastolic filling. From what Dr. Pfeffer has said, you are obviously taking out 10 or 15 per cent of the filling volume. This must change the pressure volume curve. Add to this a change in the chemical milieu and all kinds of strange things may rise up to plague you. We just don’t understand all these possibilities.

Dr. Kevy. I wonder if there wasn’t something wrong with his heart before the exchange began. The pulse was only 100 at a time he was said to be crying.

Dr. Huches. Were there blood cultures drawn other than from the umbilical vein?

I wonder if we can exclude a variety of traumas, possibly caused by the catheter itself.

Dr. Pfeffer. Usually one can tell by how easily the blood flows in and out. Usually, such accidents occur at the beginning of the exchange.

Dr. Vawter. First, I would like to remind you that not long ago we discussed here a child who, after the fourth exchange transfusion, had a massive fatal pulmonary embolism. Second, some of the comments made this morning recall a story of a child at another hospital who went into profound collapse with virtual cessation of cardiac activity following the intravenous injection of 20 c.c. of radioopaque dye. This was a very small infant and this must have represented a relatively large volume quickly given; if nothing else, it resulted in major distention of the cardiac chambers or a momentary period in which no oxygen was getting to the tissues. That child ultimately was left with what appeared to be anoxic cerebral damage.

To return to the questions at hand—one properly should not take a case that has so many complications for a Clinical Pathological Conference, but it was of interest for several reasons.

The mottled puffiness of the head and neck was associated with massive subcutaneous emphysema, the external evidence of mediastinal em-pLyscma, pneumothorax, and the blebs of interstitial emphysema in the lungs. Air had dissected along pulmonary veins to rupture into the pericardial space, and, since bubbles were found in coronary arteries, it must have ruptured into a pulmonary vein at some point. Some confirmation that this occurred while circulation was still present is the presence of interstitial hemorrhage in the lung. The hemorrhagic response and involvement of the coronary arteries indicate that this air embolism is at least a terminal phenomenon associated with attempts at resuscitation, perhaps. When air embolism has complicated exchange transfusion, no pulmonary, mediastinal, or subcutaneous emphysema has been reported.

When emphysema of this sort and degree exists, one thinks, of course, of high pressures in the airway, but just as often one finds that some, at least partial, obstructive factor is present in the airway. Indeed, this infant has a moderate degree of aspiration, including squames, meconium bodies, and thick material containing peculiarly acid-fast substances (Fig. 1). This acid-fast material, which is also present in bronchial epithelium (Fig. 2), is unusual and one suspects that a good deal is unknown about the pregnancy and delivery of this child. For one, a decreased volume of concentrated amniotic fluid is suggested. Moreover, postmaturity or dysmaturity is suggested. Other findings which might suggest intrauterine disturbances are: (1) some excess of feta! glomerulosclerosis in the kidney; (2) an unusual amount of splenic lymphoid tissue for a severe erythroblastotic infant (we often think that there is an inverse relationship between severity of erythroblastosis and amount of lymphoid tissue in spleen; (3) a liver which actually is less than half the expected weight, unlike the overweight liver expected in the usual erythroblastosis; and (4) a small thymus.

I have seen small livers of this sort under at least two circumstances: in infants thought to have ABO erythroblastosis and in infants considered to be dysmature. It is not easy to say why this liver is small; there is no evidence of necrosis, although anoxic vacuoles are present. Certainly, neither congestion nor erythropoiesis, while present, are very marked. Curiously, hyaline masses are occasionally found in walls of small portal veins. Could this represent ancient thrombosis or embolism? The element of endo-thelization of these masses suggests origin prior to transfusion (Fig. 3).

Careful gross and microscopic study of the heart revealed no abnormality, such as hemorrhage or necrosis. Perhaps one anatomic fact is of interest, however. The artery supplying the area of atrioventricular node is a terminal end artery, branching from the right coronary artery. This circulatory area might then be at a premium where delivery of blood to the coronary circuit fails or decreases for any reason.

To emphasize once more, the evidence of erythroblastosis (such as extramedullary erythropoiesis), while present is definitely not severe.

In summary, there are several peculiarities tn the disease presented by this infant, most of which point to the possibility of a grossly abnormal pregnancy, despite the lack of supportive

clinical details. Unfortunately, too, we have no information concerning the state of the placenta. In any event, one suspects that these lesions perhaps add up to an individual more susceptible than the anatomic degree of erythroblastosis might suggest. This includes amniotic aspiration. As has been suggested, we cannot show anatomic lesions which reflect the origin of the seemingly untoward effects of the exchange transfusion.

Dr. Pfeffer. Where did this air come from, and why ?

Dr. Vawter. 1 assume air introduced via the airway and partially trapped by aspiration dis-■etted into the interstitiuin of the lung and ihrnte to other sites. I also assume that this may be related to resuscitation after the exchange transfusion was interrupted.

Dr. Nadas. Are you saying that this might be associated with external cardiac massage or even that these troubles with air might have developed after cardiac massage?

Dr. Vawter. It is possible that (he evidence for intravital dissection of air may depend on the fact that external massage was used to support the circulation long enough to produce hemorrhages and for air to enter the coronary arteries.

Dr. Pi t h er. Then, since you feel that the air embolism may not have developed during the ext hange, but after it, we are left with no anatomic explanation for the p<«>r tolerance to the exchange, or, in other words, why the baby died.

Dr. Vawter. That is what I was trying to imply.

Dr. Pfeffer. Now, in relation to your statement about volume changes, I think it is interesting to point out (hat, quite frequently, while doing the exchange, the baby shows evidence of distress after you have finished injecting the 20 cc. and is likely not to show distress while removing it. I think the injection of blood is something that has to be carried out more slowly than the removal of blood.

It is also ini|x>rlant to point out that this is nm something th.it happens to that isolated 1 per wilt, but that probably this mechanism is operative in almost all of these babies. If the baby is itrong enough, or if we ate fortunate enough to ‘utth it in time, we gel away with it in all but ti'is I pci < ent.

,1(1 (losing 1 would make a plea for a bit of toiiimon sense in this situation. There is a vast ■mioiint of discussion about lh<- figure of 20 nig. P'T 100 ml. of fiilii tiltin being (he m.igiial figure

Final diagnoses are:

Erythroblastosis fetalis due to Rh incompatibility

Death during exchange transfusion.

(?) Dysmaturity with

Amniotic aspiration, fetal glomerulosclerosis

Hypotrophy of liver and thymus

(?) zXncient embolism or thrombosis of

small radicals of portal vein

Acid-fast pigments in bronchial epithelium

Terminal interstitial emphysema of lung

Secondary in part to aspiration, with pneubelow which you do not find kernicterus, above which you do, to the point where the nervous obstetrician can look at a baby’s report, see that it is 19.5 mg. per 100 ml. and go to bed happily; if he sees 20.5, he calls the pediatrician and says that a quick exchange is needed, or “we will be sued if anything happens.”

I have had two or three babies die of kernicterus whom I have followed closely. All of them died after one or two exchanges, in which we followed the criteria of trying to keep the level of bilirubin below 20. In other words, they died in spite of exchange transfusion, using the criteria as outlined in the literature. During the same time I have lost at least 12 babies who died as a result of the exchange. I do not wish to imply that 20 mg. per cent is not a useful figure on which to base the need for exchange transfusion. However, I would like to point out a few things. Kernicterus docs occur with bilirubin below 20; it occurs very' commonly with bilirubin above 30, and third, no one is quite sure that a bilirubin level of 22 or 23 mg. per 100 ml. for a period of 6 hours, or 12 hours, or 22 hours, or 3(i hours, is going to produce kernicterus. We do know, however, that exchange transfusion is not a procedure which is to be taken lightly, as is shown by today’s case and other cases. I shudder every time people say that I ext hange transfusion is conservative treatment J for erythroblastosis. At times exchange trans- ‘ fusion is the only treatment, but I hate to think that anyone thinks of exchange transfusion as being conservative in borderline cases. The level of 20, therefore, is one which is to be taken as a useful guide and not as an absolute indication. All too frequently pediatricians are pushed by a sense of legal responsibility (o do an exchange transfusion when a wait of perhaps 6 to 12 hours might be better for the patient.

This baby obviously needed an exchange, but there arc many other babies in whom the indications are less definite. There is one eminent clinician, whom we all respect deeply, who has made the bold statement that he would exchange no full-term baby at any level of bilirubin who did not have blood grouping incompatibility disease. Now, perhaps that is extreme, but it is a very valid viewpoint and indicates a healthy ri’spe< ( for (he dangers of ihis procedure. As Dr. Nadas said, the mechanism of death in these babies is a subiecl about which we know very little. This subject is a very important one. _I think that usually we are lucky in not having such complications more often.

REFERENCES

  • 1. Van Praagh, R.: Causes of death in infants with hemolytic disease of the newborn (erythroblastosis fetalis) Pediatrics 28: 223, 1961.
