May, 1967

The Journal o/ PEDIATRICS 7 4 5

Myocardial infarction during exchange transfusion in a newborn infant

Myocardial infarction teas demonstrated in a newborn infant teho developed cardiac failure during an exchange transfusion and died shortly afterward. Possibilities for the pathogenesis of the thrombus are discussed.

Luc G. Van der Hauwaert, M.D., Maree) C. Loos, M.D., and Luc K. Verhaeghe, M.D.

LOUVAIN, BELGIUM

Although exchange transfusion is safe and can lie a lifesaving procedure for the treatment of hemolytic disease of the newborn, complications and deaths arc occasionally encountered. In a recently reported series- of 902 exchange transfusions,1 the risk of death associated with the procedure was 4 per cent per patient and 3 per cent per transfusion. About one half of the deaths were related to a cardiac arrhythmia which developed during transfusion.

Because myocardial infarction has not been previously described as a complication of exchange transfusion, the following case is being reported. The diagnosis would not have been suspected without electrocardiographic. monitoring during the procedure. This observation and a similar complication tecently reported,2 in which severe electro-

Prom the Pep..riu eats of Pediatrics and Anatomy (Vesalius Institute), Unit ersity Clinic St. Raphael.

Supported in part by Clrant X’o. 774 from the Ponds voor U’etenschappelijk Geneeskundig Onderzoek. cardiographic changes were attributed to coronary air embolism, may shed some light on the causes of rhythm disturbances and cardiac deaths during exchange transfusion.

CASE REPORT

This female infant was the fourth-born child of young parents. The first and second child had been normal, but the third pregnancy had resulted in a full-term stillborn infant affected by hemolytic disease. Delivery was induced at 35 weeks because of a rise in maternal Rh antibody titer to 1:64. The infant weighed 3,050 grams at birth. She was edematous, limp, and icteric. The heart rate was slow (90 per minute), and the respirations were irregular and shallow. The liver was felt 4 cm. below the costal margin. The Moro reflex was abnormal. The cord blood bilirubin was 7.5 mg. per cent (0.25 mg. direct bilirubin), hemoglobin 70 per cent, red blood cell count 2.45 million per cubic millimeter. Numerous normoblasts were found in the peripheral blood. The results of the Coombs test were strongly positive.

A few hours after birth the infant became more icteric, but the general condition seemed to

Vol. 70, A'o. 5, pp. 745-750

7 4 6 Fan der Hauivacrt, Loos, and Verhacghc


The Journal of Pediatrics


May 1967


improve. Respirations became regular while the heart beats became more rapid (148 per minute) and vigorous.                              ■

Exchange transfusion with heparinized blood, via the umbilical vein, was carried out when the infant was 3 hours old. Technical difficulties were encountered, and the catheter had to be replaced and manipulated before a satisfactory blood flow could be obtained. As a routine procedure during the transfusion of critically ill infants, the electrocardiogram was monitored throughout the procedure. The pretransfusion tracing (Fig. 1, A) was normal, showing regular sinus rhythm at 160 per minute, a P-Q interval of 0.12 second and a QRS axis of plus 120“.

After 110 c.c. of blood had been exchanged, the infant suddenly became cyanotic, and very limp. The respiration became slow and gasping. The ECG revealed 2:1 atrioventricular block with a ventricular rate of 80 per minute and a short episode of complete atrioventricular block (Fig. 1, B). After a few minutes the condition improved, while the ECG (Fig. 1, C) revealed regular sinus rhythm at 170 per minute with a prolonged P-Q interval (0.24 second). The QRS complex was profoundly altered and showed a deep Q wave in II, HI, aVr, and an elevation of the SI' segment varying from 0.2 to 0.3 mv. in the same leads. These changes were interpreted as a severe disturbance of depolarization, but the possibility of a posterior myocardial infarction was not yet seriously entertained. After an interruption of 30 minutes, the condition had improved and the transfusion was resumed. However, after a total volume of 250 c.c. had been transfused, the procedure had to be abandoned because the heart rate again, became irregular and dropped to approximately 30 per minute. The ECG showed recurrence of complete atrioventricular block. The general condition remained precarious and did not respond to the administration of oxygen and intramuscular nikethamide. Later, sinus rhythm with a P-Q distance of 0.14 second was restored, but the deep Q wave and the current of injury in II, III, and aVr remained. Twelve hours after the exchange transfusion the infant suddenly became apneic and died.

Autopsy was restricted to the heart, which weighed 20 grams and had a normal gross appearance. Before any incision was made, the orifices of the coronary arteries were cannulated and a barium sulfate suspension, consisting of 45 parts of Ahibar Wander and 55 parts of 10



Fig. 1. The electrocardiogram before exchange transfusion. A, Normal, showing a regular sinus rhythm at 160 per minute, a P-Q distance of 0.12 second, and a QRS-axis of plus 120°. B, Following the transfusion of 110 c.c. of blood, the appearance of a complete atrioventricular block associated with a marked elevation of the ST segment in II and III is noted. C, A few minutes later, sinus rhythm with a prolonged P-Q distance (0.24 second) is restored, but deep Q waves and an elevation of the ST segment in the posterior leads persisted until death.



I'olume 70 /{umber 5


Myocardial infarction during exchange transfusion 7 4 7

psr cent formaldehyde, was injected by hand under minimal pressure. The size of the parti-cies was 2 Roentgenograms were taken on fine grain films (Structurix D2 Gevaert) and magnified to three times the natural size. Subsequently the heart was fixed in formaldehyde. On the angiograms the left coronary artery system was normally distributed and even its smallest ramifications, up to the precapillary level, were seen to fill. The major branch of the right coronary artery was equally normal. Upon close inspection, and after comparing roentgenograms taken in various exposures, it was noted that the terminal arteries of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery (according to Spalteholz’s3 classification the ramus ventriculi sinistri posterior) were not filled with radiopaque material. This branch was the major vessel supplying the posterior part of the left ventricle.

The heart valves appeared normal. A postmortem thrombus was found in the right atrium. The foramen ovale was widely patent, measuring 4 by 7 mm. The myocardium seemed to be healthy.

The histological examination of the heart was based on multiple transverse sections from the atria to the apex, made by means of a microtome set at a thickness of 7 P. Every twentieth section of the vcntr.cular mass was studied after staining with hematoxylin, eosin, and safranin. The major histological finding was a large zone of fresh infarction involving the subendocardial layers of the posterior and diaphragmatic parts of the left ventricle (Figs. 2 A and 2d). The myocardial fibers in this region took a deep eosinophilic stain, and their demarcation from the healthy myocardium was rather sharp. In some places, striation of. the muscle fibers was weak; in other infarcted zones it had completely disappeared. The myocardial nuclei were hyper-chromic, pyknotic, or karyolytic. Parts of the infarcted area were infiltrated with mononuclear elements and interstitial fluid.

The histological structure of the wall of the coronary arteries was normal throughout. Approximately four fifths of the peripheral arteries and arterioles in the infarcted area contained fresh thrombi which had blocked the passage of the barium sulfate suspension (Fig. 3). Ai! occluded vessels belonged to the same posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. In the healthy myocardium no blood clots were found, and, as consistently seen with the technique employed, the barium sulfate suspension entered the smallest arterioles.

DISCUSSION

The sequence of events suggests that myocardial infarction in this newborn baby, severely affected by hemolytic disease, occurred during, and as a complication of, exchange transfusion. Although the baby was in cardiorespiratory distress, as are most newborn infants with hydrops fetalis, the pretransfusion electrocardiogram, was normal. The sudden deterioration while transfusing coincided with the development of electrocardiographic disturbances.

The etiology of this infarction remains unproved. Possibly it was due to a paradoxical coronary embolus. This exceptional form of embolism has been reported in adults.4’ 5 In this patient thrombotic material may have derived from the Umbilical vein and reached the heart via the ductus venosus. It is conceivable that; a blood clot was dislodged during manipulation of the catheter. Unfortunately the uinbilical vein could not be examined, as the autopsy had to be restricted to the heart. The anatomical and hemodynamic requirements for paradoxical embolism were certainly fulfilled. The foramen ovale was widely patent and the physiological pulmonary hypertension of the newborn baby is expected to be associated with relatively high pressure in the right atrium.® A further temporary increase of right atrial pressure during transfusion1 may have produced a right-to-left shunt and passage of an embolus through the foramen ovale.

The alternative explanation is that a thrombus developed in situ, possibly as a result of congestive heart failure and circulatory stasis; the infant presented with hydrops fetalis and was in poor cardiac condition before the transfusion was started.

Electrocardiographic changes during exchange transfusion, similar to the ones described, have recently been reported.2 The evidence of injury disappeared after 28 minutes and was tentatively attributed to

748 Van der Hauwaert, Loos, and Verhaeghe


The Journal of Pediatrics May 1967



-POSTERIOR


Fig. 2A, Transverse section through the left ventricle. An extensive, fresh infarction occupies almost the entire subendocardial region of the posterior wall and part of the interventricular septum. After coloration with hematoxylin, eosin, and safranine, the infarcted area takes a darker eosinophilic stain than the healthy myocardium Its distribution is indicated by the dotted area on the schematic drawing (Fig. 2B).

Fig. 2B. Schematic drawing of Fig. 2A.


I'olume 70

Number 5


Myocardial infarction during exchange transfusion 7 4 9

Fig. 3. Small artery belonging to the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery (magnification x 100). The passage of the injected barinm-sulfatc suspension (upper right) is blocked by an unorganized thrombus (lower left).                                    '


myocardium and the coronary' presented. Bradycardia,1, 2- s- 3


transient coronary ischemia caused by air embolism. The infant made an uneventful recovery. Unexplained disturbances of rhythm have been observed by many authors. Out of 25 infants who died during or soon after an exchange transfusion, no less than 13 were considered to’have. died as a result of cardiac arrythmia,1 but unfortunately the electrocardiogram was not monitored in this series and no details concerning the pathology of the vessels were prolongation of the P-R interval,2 2: 1 atrioventricular block,5 cardiac arrest,1’10-11 severe tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation9 have been encountered during exchange transfusion.

Hogg12 studied the hearts of 40 infants who died of hemolytic disease, and he found small infarctions in 6 of them. No clinical or electrocardiographic findings were mentioned. However, the infarcts measured only 1 to 2 mm., and it appears unlikely that they played any role in the clinical course and fatal outcome.

Myocardial infarction is extremely rare in the newborn infant. Congenital malformations of the coronary arteries include the aberrant origin of one or both of the coronary arteries from the pulmonary- artery. Idiopathic arterial calcification13-14 involving the coronary system is probably the next-to-most frequent cause. Coronary thrombosis in a newborn infant has been attributed to thickening and irregularity of the coronary intima.15 None of these anatomical changes were found in this patient.

SUMMARY

A case of fatal myocardial infarction which occurred in a newborn infant during exchange transfusion is reported. Its thrombotic origin was demonstrated by postmortem coronary angiography and histological studies. The etiology- remains obscure. Although it is possible that the thrombus developed in situ, the entertained hypothesis is that it resulted from a paradoxical coronary embolus, which had originated from the cannulated umbilical vein.

750 Fan der Hautvaert, Loos, and Verhaeghe


The Journal of Pediatrics May 1967

  • II. Wallgran, G., and Okmian, L.: Successful resuscitation of two immature infants with cardiac arrest during exchange transfusion, Acta pediat. 50: 399, 1961.

  • 12. Hogg, G. R.: Cardiac lesions in hemolytic disease of the newborn, J. Pediat. 60: 352, 1962.

  • 13. Stryker, W. A.: Arterial calcification in infancy with special reference to the coronary’ arteries, Am. J. Path. 22: 1007, 1946.

  • 14. Gower, N. D., and Pinkerton, J. R.: Idiopathic arterial calcification in infancy, Arch. Dis. Childhood 38: 408, 1963.

  • 15. Gault, M. H., and Usher, R.: Coronary thrombosis with myocardial infarction in a newborn infant, New England J. Med. 263: 379, 1960.

340         -

Neonatal Peritonitis and Exchange Transfusion

Peritonitis is a fairly uncommon condition in the newborn baby. A. G. Birtch and colleagues1 saw 99 cases during 25 years at the Children’s Medical Center in Boston and P. P. Rickham89 90 91 saw 17 in three and a half years in Liverpool. About four cases per year were seen, therefore, in two busy neonatal surgical units. Most of these babies had meconium peritonitis, and the usual cause of it is antenatal perforation of the gut above a congenital intestinal obstruction. The clinical picture is that of the obstruction, and the operative treatment and prognosis are not much affected by the presence of meconium in the peritoneum.

Bacterial peritonitis, due generally to a postnatal perforation, is much less common. About half of these cases are due to perforation of a peptic ulcer, as was shown in the excellent review of II. E. Thelander92 in 1939. The majority of other cases are due to intestinal perforations. Very occasionally perforated appendicitis or Meckel’s diverticulitis will be seen in the newborn, but most babies with intestinal perforation have an apparently spontaneous lesion of the large, or less often the small, intestine. Perinatal sepsis, trauma, vascular insufficiency, and pressure from faecal masses have all been suggested as possible causes.

It is therefore remarkable that in this issue of the

This has only previously been recorded in sporadic cases. Mr. J. J. Corkery and his colleagues, of Sheffield, report four cases at page 345, and Drs. R. L’E. Orme and Sheila AI. Eades six cases at page 349. The clinical picture was remarkably consistent. A newborn baby was given one or more exchange transfusions, apparently without technical difficulty. Some hours or days later the baby refused to feed or vomited. Five of the 10 babies passed blood per rectum, and all were.: found to have abdominal distension. Of the eight children who had an abdominal x-ray three were found to have a pneumoperitoneum and five showed signs of intestinal, obstruction.

To the paediatric surgeon these are the essential signs of neonatal peritonitis, of which abdominal distension is the sign which is unfailingly present. The importance of investigating this sign whenever it is seen cannot be overemphasized. The delay which sometimes occurred before transfer to a surgical unit may have been due to a belief that the signs were those of septic umbilical phlebitis, a rare complication of exchange transfusion, but this is unlikely to produce progressive distension and certainly not pneumoperitoneum.

Nine of the 10 children had a laparotomy, which showed a perforation of the colon, and in the tenth child multiple perforations of the bowel were found post mortem. Some complex surgery was needed, and one of the eight survivors required separate resections of jejunum, ileum, and colon. To have achieved these results in a condition with a high mortality is most creditable. There is certainly nothing to be gained by delaying surgery when this condition is suspected.                  .

What remains unsolved is the reason for this association of, colonic perforation"aha exchange transfusion. It seems reasonably certain that the agent must be the catheter in the umbilical vein, and this might produce septic, haemo-

9 November 1968 -


Leading Articles


British

Medical Journal


341


dynamic, or embolic complications. The cases reported this -week are similar to those described by J. E. S. Scott,93 and he thought his were due to perinatal sepsis. There seerna insufficient evidence on this point, and the suggestion of a Schwartzman type of anaphylactic reaction94 95 is also unproved.

What is certain is that exchange transfusion can seriously affect the circulation of the "newborn?' The site of the catheter tip during transfusion is crucial, and J. W. Farquhar and H. Smith .firmly recommend that the catheter should never be inserted more than 7-8 cm.’ Even so, considerable variations in portal venous pressure still occur with varying rates of injection, and little is known about patency of the ductus venosus or about portal and systemic vascular pressures ■ during transfusion. Systemic hypotension and portal hypertension or embolism could at times occur, and Drs. Orme and Eades reasonably adduce evidence from adult patients that per roti zing enterocolitis may be associated with systemic hypotension. The occurrence of rectal bleeding in five of the ten babies lends support to the concept of a vascular lesion.

It is now necessary to recognize a new complication of exchange tranfusion. Why it is rare in comparison with the large number of transfusions given is not yet clear. However, provisional acceptance of the vascular theory of^ origin certainly emphasizes the importance of scrupulous technique-The ready availability of the umbilical vein in the newborn only makes it the more necessary to remember the call, of W. Walker and P. L. Mollison96 that exchange transfusion should be recognized as a skilled manoeuvre, to be undertaken only in centres where the necessary experience and skill are always available.

papers and On&wls ’ „ .        _   ,4S KIP‘33

9 November 1968 .    Musical Journal

Coteiic Wdwstimi after Exchange Tmmfhsicm

J. J. CORKERYj,* m.ch., F.R.C.S., FJt.c.s.1.; V. DUBOWITZ,t m.d., ph.d., e.sc., m.r.c.p., d.cjh.

JAMES LISTER^: M.B., f.r.c.s ed. ; A. MOOSA,§ mjj., ch.b.

Brit, med.J., 1968, 4, 345-349

Summary: Four patients are reported in whom perforation of the colon followed exchange transfusion for haemolytic disease of the newborn. This association seems to be more than coincidental, and possibly the perforation is due to a vascular accident occurring as a mechanical result of the exchange transfusion. The insidious onset of colonic perforation may be recognized early by the passage of blood per rectum. There is no place for conservative treatmeat, and once the diagnosis has been made treatment must include broad-spectrum antibiotics and laparotomy.

Introduction

Spontaneous perforation of the colon in the neonate is a well. recognized but rare surgical emergency. We wish to report fourcases treated at the Children’s Hospital, Sheffield, in wEfoE " the " perforation followed exchange transfuslcn for haemolytic disease of the newborn, , to suggest a way in which the transfusion may have led to the perforation, and to indicate some of the difficulties in early diagnosis.

Case 4

■ This patient was the eighth child of a rhesus-negative mother and a homozygous rhesus-positive father. Four of his siblings had had exchange transfusions because of erythroblastosis foetalis ; he was delivered by caesarean section because of delay in the first stage (mother’s history) and weighed 5 lb. 5 oz. (2,410 g.) at birth.

When he was 5 hours old an exchange transfusion was performed ■ for haemolytic disea.se. The abdomen was noted to have been moderately distended at that time and the rectum was empty. At 48 hours a second exchange transfusion was carried out because of a rising scrum bilirubin. He tolerated this procedure well but six hours later passed blood per rectum. On the sixth day, because of abdominal distension, abdominal paracentesis was performed and gas and fluid were obtained. He was started on intravenous fluids and antibiotics. The following day he passed changing stools. On the eighth day he was transferred to the paediatric surgical unit of this hospital.

On examination he was moderately jaundiced though well hydrated. The abdomen was distended and there was oedema of the abdominal wall. No masses could be felt in the abdomen, and bowel sounds were absent. Rectal examination revealed a little blood-stained faeces. An x-ray film showed dilated loops of small bowel, but no free gas. 97 98 99 100

At laparotomy a large collection of faeces was found in the left side of the peritoneal cavity. The small bowel was inspected, and no perforation was found. The proximal transverse colon contained gas. A narrowed segment of bowel was noted in the region of the splenic flexure, but owing to adhesions and soiling could not be examined thoroughly. The actual site of perforation was not located. Peritoneal lavage was performed, a proximal colostomy made, and the abdomen closed with drainage. A swab taken from the peritoneal cavity grew Pseudomonas pyocyanea and Escherichia colt. Postoperatively he was treated with antibiotics, and made a good recovery.             ,

Two months later a barium enema showed “ an extremely narrow” segment, about 2 cm. long, proximal to the splenic flexure (Fig. 1). At 10 weeks of age a second laparotomy was performed. Frozen section revealed normal innervation in the rectosigmoid region. The narrow segment of bowel at the splenic flexure was excised and an end-to-end anastomosis was performed. Macroscopic examination failed to reveal a lumen in this narrow segment. ■ A month later his colostomy was closed, and he has made uneventful progress ever since. He was last seen at the age of 2% years, when he was free of complaints and was developing normally.

Fig. 1.—Case 1. Barium enema through distal limb of transverse colostomy showing a stricture at the -               splenic flexure.

  • Case 2

A female child, the second baby of a rhesus-negative mother and a homozygous rhesus-positive father, was born at the Jessop Hospital for Women, Sheffield, following induction of labour at 37 weeks’ gestation. Her birth weight was 6 lb. 4 oz. (2,835 g.). The cord bilirubin was 4.6 mg./100 ml., and an exchange transfusion was jSesfemed at 3 hoars of age. This procedure was uneventful. At 20 hours she passed normal meconium, and did so on two further occasions. Apart from a number of mucous vomits she remained well, but at 48 hours her general condition deteriorated rapidly. There was progressive abdominal distension, and she developed peripheral cyanosis and tachycardia. An x-ray film of the abdomen (Fig. 2) showed free gas in the peritoneal cavity, and she was transferred to the paediatric surgical unit

pneumoperitoneum.

At that stage she was still slightly jaundiced, but Was active and not acutely distressed. The abdomen was tensely distended and tympanitic. No masses could be felt. Rectal examination revealed normal meconium. At laparotomy a few hours after admission free gas, pus, and fibrinous exudate were found in the peritoneal cavity. There was no free meconium. A small pinhole perforation was found in the caecum on its antimesenteric border. Peritoneal lavage was performed and the caecal perforation exteriorized. The affected portion of caecum was excised for biopsy, but unfortunately was lost. A swab taken from the peritoneal cavity grew E- coli. Post-operatively antibiotics were continued, the caecostomy was closed after nine days, and, apart from a pseudomonal infection of her wound, she made a straightforward recovery. When last seen at 10 weeks of age she was gaining weight, and appeared normal in every way.

  • Case 3 ■

A male infant, the third child of a rhesus-negative mother, was born at home at full term weighing 7 lb. 13 oz. (3,545 g.). Cord blood bilirubin was 5.0 mg./lOO ml., and the Coombs test was positive. Ten hours after birth he was noticed to be jaundiced, and was admitted to hospital. Shortly after this he passed normal meconium. At 24 hours an exchange transfusion was performed because of a rising serum bilirubin and a falling haemoglobin. He tolerated this procedure well, but four hours afterwards passed a small amount of blood and mucus per rectum. Over the next 24 hours his general condition began to deteriorate, and he began to vomit At 48 hours he was admitted to the paediatric surgical unit.

On admission he was jaundiced (total bilirubin 12 mg./lOO ml.) and lethargic. There was moderate distension of the abdomen, and a mass could be felt in the left hypochondrium. This was thought to be an enlarged spleen. An x-ray film of the abdomen (Fig. 3) showed some distended loops of gut with a suggestion of free peritonea! fluid but no free gas. These appearances were thought to represent a paralytic ileus in a scpticacmic baby. The nest day he developed twitchings due to hypocalcaemia, which was corrected with intravenous calcium gluconate. Because of persistent abdominal distension and aspiration of bile-stained fluid from the stomach, laparotomy was performed when he was 4 days old.

_. Fig. 3.—Case 3. Erect x-ray film of abdomen showing distension of small bowel, with a few fluid levels and a suggestion of free peritoneal fluid'. Note -the, absence of free intraperitoneal gas.

A lot of clear yellow fluid was found in the peritoneal cavity. A large yellow mass in the region of the splenic flexure, corresponding to the mass felt preopcratively,' proved to be faeces in the colon, covered only by an extremely thin layer of serosa. There was no trace of the muscular or mucosal layers in the region of the splenic flexure, over an area about 2.5 cm. in diameter. The serosal layer was so thin that immediately an attempt was made to mobilize the affected bowel it burst, and there was gross faecal soiling. There were numerous purplish red patches on the antimesenteric border of the descending colon distal to the splenic flexure and down to the mid-sigmoid colon. The affected segment of colon was resected. A terminal right transverse colostomy was performed. The distal end of the sigmoid colon was oversewn and dropped hack into the peritoneal cavity. A swab from the peritoneal cavity grew E. coli. Culture of a segment of the umbilical vein grew E. coli (same sensitivities as the peritoneal one), Proteus vulgaris, and Streptococcus faecalis. Postoperatively he made a slow but steady recovery. At 6 weeks bowel continuity was restored, and he has remained perfectly well ever since.

  • Case 4 ,

A male child was born to a multiparous rhesus-negative woman. Birth weight was 5 lb 2$ oz. (2,340 g.). Cord blood bilirubin was 4.5 mg./lOO ml., and exchange transfusion was carried out when he was 4 hours old. He had one apnoeic episode towards the end of this procedure, but recovered spontaneously. At 24 hours another exchange transfusion was done because of a bilirubin level of 24 mg./lOO ml. There was no difficulty during this procedure. At 48 hours he passed some blood per rectum, together with normal meconium. At 65 hours a third exchange was done because the bilirubin was again rising. After a further 22 hours he was noted to have abdominal distension, and began to vomit. There were no further bowel movements. Oral fluids were withheld, and the abdominal distension was thought to decrease a little. The next day oral fluids were restarted and retained. There was, however, a slight increase in the degree of abdominal distension. The bilirubin was 24 mg./lOO ml. at this stage, but exchange transfusion was not repeated because of his poor general condition. When he was 5 days old his serum bilirubin rose to 28 mg./lOO ml., and a fourth exchange transfusion was performed. He seemed a little better after this, and tolerated feeds. On the sixth day the abdominal distension increased rapidly. The bilirubin then was 13.6 mg./IOO ml. On the seventh day an x-ray film of his abdomen showed an extensive pneumoperitoneum, and he was transferred to the paediatric surgical unit. Since birth he had had a four-day course of oxytetracycline followed by a combination of penicillin and streptomycin up to the time of admission.

Laparotomy, was performed du the seventh day of life. At operation a large amount of gas and faeces was found free in the peritoneal cavity. The whole of the anterior wail of the descending colon was necrotic (Fig. 4). In the sigmoid colon there were a few necrotic spots on the antimesenteric border. The caecum and transverse colon were intact. The affected segment of bowel was excised, and proximal and distal colostomies were performed. A swab from the peritoneal cavity grew Str. faecalis and Proteus vulgaris. Postopera lively he had a very stormy course, and developed extensive sclerema. However, he eventually recovered, and his progress has been satisfactory. At 5 months of age the colostomy was closed and bowel continuity restored.                      '         .

Fig. 4.—Case 4. Picture of descending colon showing extensive full-thickness necrosis and perforation of its wall

.   . Histology

The histological appearance of the damaged bowel was similar in the three cases in which materia! was available for examination. The lesion showed progression from necrosis confined . to the epithelium through necrosis involving epithelium and muscle and extending to full-thickness loss. In places there was a mild inflammatory reaction at the edges of the affected areas, together with scattered extravasation of red cells.

Discussion ■

Diagnosis          .                                            '

Spontaneous perforation of the colon in the newborn is rare, and its association with exchange transfusion in four cases seems more than coincidental. It is suggested that the perforations in these cases occurred after second, first, first, and third exchange transfusions, and in retrospect a distinct, diagnostic sequence of events can be recognized. All patients were well at birth apart from their haemolytic disease and a weight of just over 5 lb. (2,270 g.) in two of them; in three the first abnormal sign was the passage of blood per rectum 4 to 15 hours after exchange, and this was followed within 24 hours (in Case 2 within 40 hours of the sole transfusion) by general non-specific deterioration, with lethargy, poor peripheral circulation, abdominal distension, and usually vomiting. The pattern was so recognizable that in our fourth case the diagnosis was made over the telephone to the referring paediatrician 80 miles (130 km.) away. The diagnosis may be confirmed by x-ray films showing free intraperitoneal gas (Pig. 2) or less dramatically showing fluid levels in bowel and a suggestion of free intraperitoneal fluid (Fig. 3). Abdominal paracentesis does not seem to have a place in the diagnosis, though therapeutic aspiration of free intra-abdominal gas may greatly increase the, respiratory reserve preopcratively.

Aetiology

Though rare, spontaneous neonatal colonic perforation has been reported in the literature with many suggested causes. In

Samsa         2.A7

atoECAL JounNAl       J i f

small-bowel and large-bowel perforations localized bowel wal? defects (von Sury, 1912; Moretti, 1949), primary vascular in^ sufficiency (Paltauf, 1888 ; Helbing, 1908), and hypertrophy of the crypts of Lieberkuhn coupled with thinness of the bowel wall and lymphoid hyperplasia (Boikan, 1930 ; Lattes, 1943 ; Maguire and Moore, 1950) have been suggested. In the colon specifically bacterial and fungal infection (Levin and Isaacson, 1960; Waldhausen et cd., 1963), meconium and faecal plugs

■ (Zachary, 1957), and haemangiomatous malformations of the bowel wall (Haas,. 1958) have been put forward as causes, ’ -    '                                                       .

■ Linkner and Benson (1959) reported & neonatal gastric perforation in a child with erythroblastosis without exchange transfusion, and Nienhuis (1963) an intrauterine colonic perforation in a child with haemolyric disease who later required exchange transfusion. However, the association between exchange transfusion and colonic perforation has been noted by Waldhausen et al. (1963), Forshall (1964), and in particular in a well-documented case by Hermann (1965), who suggested that the ■ Shwartzman phenomenon was an aeriological factor. Thomas and Brockman (1966) could find no firm evidence for this-theory, and agreed with Waldhausen et al. in placing bacterial infection as the most important causal factor.

That colonic perforation following exchange transfusion ' should not be grouped with all “ spontaneous ” perforations in the neonate is suggested by its apparently good prognosis. All our cases survived; so did Hermann’s (1965) one case and two ' of the three cases reported' by Wagget (1968). The general mortality of neonatal colonic perforation is very different; of the seven' cases of Waldhausen et al. (1963) the only survivor was the one who had had an exchange transfusion, and both . patients of Levin and Isaacson (1960) died. Thomas and Brockman (1966) found 26 cases of uncertain aetiology, 17 were operated on, and only eight survived, all after operation;

■ there is no record of whether or not exchange transfusion was associated in these cases.                                             ■

Studying some of the hazards of exchange transfusion, using a catheter inserted into the umbilical vein, Mintz and Vallbona (1960) demonstrated that in the presence of upper respiratory tract obstruction markedly negative pressures are obtained in the catheterized vein during inspiration. It is common experience during the procedure of exchange transfusion that if the patient strains or cries and the fluid level in the umbilical catheter can be observed the pressure within the umbilical vein can be seen to be raised by forcible expiration. Farquhar and Smith (1958) noted disturbances in 7 out of 19 patients during exchange transfusion. In two patients in whom the catheter was inserted 11 cm. into the umbilical vein, cyanosis of the lower half of the body associated with pallor of the upper half was noticed ; increased venous filling and retrograde flow in the superficial veins were observed. These indicated that at that time there was a functional obstruction of the inferior vena cava. On withdrawing the catheter these signs subsided spontaneously and apparently without having produced any ill-effects. “ Shock ”—that is, the infants suddenly became quiet, theirr body temperature dropped, and they developed some abdominal distension which was not due to hepatomegaly—was noted in three of these cases, and no blood chemistry changes explained

The umbilical vein runs, in the free border of the falciform ligament, to join the left branch of the portal vein in the porta hepatis. From the point on the left portal vein opposite this junction the ductus venosus runs on the posterior surface of the liver to join the left hepatic vein just before it enters the inferior vena cava (Johnston and Whillis, 1949). Van Loghem et cd. '(1949), by catheterizing the umbilical veins of neonatal cadavers under x-ray control, have shown that usually it is easy to pass a catheter through the umbilical vein into the inferior vena cava via the ductus venosus. When the catheter had been inserted to a length of about 12 to 14 cm. it had reached the inferior

Sernas

Medical Jourmal

vena cava. They also demonstrated that it is sometimes difficult to thread the catheter through the ductus venosus owing to a *' stricture ” in the distal part of the latter. In these cases ■ they noted that the catheter whose passage is so obstructed is apt to turn off to the left or right side into the branches of the portal vein. As a rough guide they state that if the passage of the umbilical catheter is obstructed at II cm. the tip of the catheter is probably in a branch of the portal vein. The technique of exchange transfusion in general use at the present time involves inserting, usually, between 5 and 7 cm. of catheter well short of the junction of the umbilical and portal veins. lead to higher portal pressures during exchange. A further possibility may be that in catheterizing the umbilical vein a small thrombus may be dislodged and forced in a retrograde direction along the portal vein. The impressive cyanosis of the distal half of the body noticed by Farquhar and Smith (1958) in two of their patients in whom 11 era. of umbilical catheter was inserted should alert us to the possibility, and indeed the probability, that equally impressive changes may take place in the portal circulation if the catheter tip is in the appropriate place and there is some unusual increase in resistance to the Sow of blood into the systemic circulation. If the tip of the

Fig. 5.—Cadaver injection study. X-ray.film after injection of 5 ml. of radio-opaque medium with 5 cm. of catheter in umbilical vein.


Key to Fig. 5,


Most people who perform exchange transfusion assume that the exchange is of inferior vena cava blood. This may be so, but with the tip of the catheter proximal to the ductus venosus there can be little doubt that some at least of this exchange takes place in the portal circulation. Perhaps in a quiet child in whom there is a low central venous pressure this fraction may be very small, but if the central venous pressure is raised, say, in a restless child, much of the injected blood may enter the portal circulation. Some of this will flow centrally, but some will also flow peripherally and thus raise the portal pressure relatively suddenly. Similarly, a narrow ductus venosus will catheter has actually strayed into the portal vein itself then profound changes in pressure and turbulence undoubtedly must occur in the portal circulation.

Fig. 6.—Cadaver injection study. X-ray film taken after injection of 30 ml. of radioopaque medium with 5 cm. of catheter in -■ trmbiiical vein.



Key to Fig. 6.


It is difficult to devise any experimental injection of the umbilical vein which would exactly mimic the situation during an exchange transfusion. However, experimental injection of an opaque medium into the umbilical vein of cadavers has indicated the ease with which the portal venous system may be outlined, as shown in Figs. 5 and 6. An umbilical vein catheter was inserted 5 cm. into the umbilical vein and an opaque medium as used in other cadaveric angiographic studies (Lister,

1964) was injected. X-ray studies indicate that in a cadaver in which the cardiovascular system has not been perfused it is very much easier for the opaque medium to run into the portal system than into the vena cava.

That a vascular lesion was primarily responsible for the perforations in the four cases reported here is suggested by the fact that in three of these the passage of blood per rectum was the earliest sign that something was amiss, as it was in mo of Wagget’s (1968) three cases. This would suggest that a haemorrhagic infarct had occurred at the time of the exchange transfusion. It is suggested that, for one of the reasons already referred to, a vascular catastrophe of some sort (such as severe arteriospasm, venospasm, or sudden occlusion of the venous drainage due to a small retrograde embolus) occurred, resulting in infarction of the bowel wall with perforation, and in Case 1 an ischaemic stricture was produced in the region of the splenic flexure in addition. Further support is lent to this suggestion in that in the resected specimen in Case 3 there were numerous red patches on the antimesenteric border of the descending colon. These were acutely congested patches that had not actually infarcted, and in Case 4 similar patches in the sigmoid coion actually showed full-thickness necrosis which had not perforated, presumably because of the proximal perforation.

n xt.


Why these lesions should be more common in the colon than in the small bowel is difficult to explain if the condition is due to vascular changes resulting from back pressure. Cases 1, 3, and 4 perforated in inferior mesenteric vein territory, but Case 2 involved superior mesenteric vein territory, and Schaffer (1960) described a case in which there was an “ unexpectedly excellent result” in a “miracle baby” who had two ileal perforations closed at laparotomy, and these occurred after an exchange transfusion. More small-bowel perforations may be reported once the association between bowel perforation and exchange transfusion becomes more appreciated ; but it may be that the more complex venous system of the small bowel damps down any sudden rises in portal pressure more effectively than the large-bowel venous system. Continuous monitoring of the injection pressure during exchange transfusion could avoid large and dangerous pressure variations.

Rsferbnces

Waldhausen, J. A., Herendeen, T., and King, H. (1963). Surgery, 54, '365.                                            .               ..

Zachary, R. B. (1957). Arch. Dis. Childh., 32, 22.

KIP-34

Perforation of the Bowel' in the Newborn as a Com^licatiosi of . . -             • ' Exchange Transfusion '     •.. - ■ . '

,r            R. L’E. ORME,* M.A., m.r.c.p., d.c.h. ; SHEILA M. EADES,f mjr.c.p.ed, d.c.h.

Brit, med. J., 1968, 4, 349-351                    ’                                                    _                            ' t

Summary i Spoataaeous perforation of She bowel without evidence of intestinal obstruction is reported in six infants who had exchange..traasfusiflas fox rhesus incompatibility, and in a seventh who had prolonged mteavenaus fluids via the umbilical vein. The pathological findings resemble those found in acute necrotizing enterocolitis in- adults, which is known to be associated with arterial hypotension. The cause in these infants may also be due to a period of hypotension during the transfusion, and hypoxia and superimposed infection may also play an important part.

. Introdoction '

“ Spontaneous ” perforation of the bowel in the newborn, where perforation occurs in the absence of intestinal obstruction, was first described by Siebold (1826). Thelander (1939) reviewed the world literature up to 1939. Of her 85 cases 65 occurred in the neonatal period. Thomas and Brockman (1966) found 26 further cases in the colon between 1946 and 1965, and Fonkalsrud et al. (1966) reported 19 cases of “ spontaneous ” perforation in a study of neonatal peritonitis. Some of the earlier cases may have been associated with meconium ileus due to cystic fibrosis or Hirschsprung’s disease. . We describe six cases of “ spontaneous ” perforation in newborn infants who had had exchange transfusions shortly beforehand.                       .

.                                   Case 1        .

A male infant weighing 3.2 kg. was delivered normally following L induction at 36 weeks. The mother’s blood group was O negative

e Senior Registrar in Paediatrics, Devon and Exeter Clinical Area, f Consultant Paediatrician, Devon and Exeter Clinical Area. with rhesus antibodies present 1 in 40. There was no asphyxia at birth. Cord blood results were: group O positive ; Coombs test positive ; Hb 70% ; bilirubin 9.7 mg./100 ml. Three exchange transfusions were carried out without difficulty in the first 48 hours, calcium supplements being given. No antibiotics were used.

, At the age of 54 hours he became reluctant to feed and passed small quantities of bright blood rectally. Abdominal distension developed. Bowel sounds were normal. At 72 hours periumbilical oedema and erythema developed. Portal vein thrombosis was suspected. An abdominal x-ray picture was suggestive of ileus. There was no gas under the diaphragm.

Laparotomy at 130 hours showed faecal peritonitis with two perforations of the large bowel, in the caecum and descending colon. The affected bowel was resected and an ileostomy fashioned. Postoperative recovery was good. Microscopy (Fig. !)■ showed an acute colitis with extensive necrosis of the mucosa and submucosa. Associated vessels were thrombosed, but it was not possible to say whether this was primary or secondary.

■ .       ' Case 2

A male infant weighing 3 kg. was delivered by lower segment caesarean section for foetal distress after induction at 38 weeks. ■ The liquor was meconium-slained. The infant had white asphyxia and required endotracheal oxygen for resuscitation. Maternal blood group: A negative, with antibodies 1 in 20. 'Cord blood: group O positive : Coombs test positive; Hb 85%.. Fxrhange transfusion was carried out at three hours with calcium surrie-jnents, Streptomycin was given.

At the age of 4 days the infant developed bilious vomitinv and passed blood and mucus rectally. Abdominal distension, grr’-r-Vr respiration, and periumbilical oedema and erythema followed. Bowel sounds were absent and peritonitis was sqscected. An x-ray film of the abdomen showed gas under the diaphragm. A* operation three large perforations were found in the rirrnrid critn. The affected bowel was resected with an end-to-end anastomosis.

a ■’                      Perforation in

KIP-34

ifc-jiiftd..eight days postopeja.tiyelv.. Microscopy showed that near the perforations the whole colonic wall was necrotic, haemorrhagic, and densely infiltrated with polymorphs. FuVther away there was less inflammation, but deep necrotizing ulcers were destroying isolated sections of mucosae, muscularis mucosa, and submucosa.

Case 1. Full width of bowel wall to show haemorrhagic necrosis of mucosa and submucosa (A) and thrombosis of serosal blood vessels (B).

  • Case 3

This female infant weighing 3 kg, had a normal delivery at 38 weeks. There was no birth asphyxia. The mother’s blood group was rhesus negative with antibodies. ' Cord blood results: Coombs test strongly positive ; Hb 82% ; bilirubin 3.2 mg./lOO ml. An exchange transfusion was carried out at two hours. jSxygen was required during tl:e procedure. On the fourth day abdominal distension and bilious vomiting developed. She continued to pass meconium but no blood. X-ray examination of the abdomen showed fluid levels. At operation multiple gangrenous areas of bowel necessitated resection of 6 in. (15 cm.) of jejunum, 7 in. (17.5 cm.) of ileum, and 7 in, (17.5 cm.) of transverse colon. Postoperative recovery was excellent, and when last seen, aged 3 years, she was well. Microscopy showed extensive necrosis of the mucosa, which extended into the submucosa and in places through the entire wall. Haemorrhage into the coats of the gut and a mononuclear exudate into the serosa were found. There was no evidence of mesenteric thrombosis. The appearances were compatible with a diagnosis of acute necrotizing enterocolitis.

  • Case 4

This infant, a female weighing 2.6 kg., was severely asphyxiated at birth and required two exchange transfusions for rhesus incompatibility. At the age of 4 days she developed vomiting and abdominal distension but still passed meconium.- A straight x-ray film of the abdomen did not show obstruction. The symptoms subsided and she was discharged home at two weeks. However, vomiting and frequent loose motions recurred later, and x-ray films now showed fluid levels. A barium enema demonstrated an ileocolic fistula. At operation two loops of Ileum and jejunum were adherent to the splenic flexure. Each of these communicated separately with the lumen of the colon. The affected length of colon was excised .and the holes in the small bowel were closed. Microscopy showed that the perforations were lined by necrotic tissue infiltrated with acute inflammatory cells. The intramural the Newborn—Orme and Eades

nerve plexuses were normal. Subsequent rectal biopsy confirmed this.                             .

  • Case 5

. A female infant weighing 2.1 kg. was delivered normally following induction at 3'4 weeks. Maternal group A negative with antibodies 1 in 256. Cord blood results: group A positive ; Coombs test positive ; Hb 92% ; bilirubin 4.5 mg./lOO ml- Exchange transfusions were carried out on the third and fourth days, the first with some difficulty. Signs of intestinal obstruction now devefopgd., with vomiting and abdominal distension,, which was treated conservatively with gastric aspiration and intravenous .fluids. After an initial ^improvement she collapsed and died. Necropsy showed multiple perforations of the bowel,                     .

.                  '. Case 6

This male infant weighing 2.4 kg. was delivered normally. The maternal blood group was rhesus negative with antibodies. Cord blood: Coombs test positive ; Hb 84% ; bilirubin 3.5 mg./lOQ ml. Two exchange transfusions Were performed, at 41 and 65 hours. At the age of 6 days bilious vomiting and abdominal distension developed. Bowel sounds were absent. At laparotomy a large perforation of the transverse colon was found and closed. Postoperative recovery was complicated by a faecal fistula. At the age of 3 months a second episode of obstruction was found to be due to adhesions and a Richter’s hernia of the proximal duodenum. Since the second operation he has thrived. Pathological findings are not available.                 -

We also record a seventh case in which prolonged intravenous fluids via the umbilical vein were given, but no exchange transfusion.

'    .           Case 7

This infant, a male weighing 1.5 kg., was born into a bucket in a caravan. On his admission the rectal temperature was 82° F. (27.8° C.), pulse 80. _ The temperature rose to 92° F. (33.3° C.) over eight hours. Antibiotics were" given.

At 12 hours he became apnoeic and was treated with intermittent positive-pressure respiration and dextrose via umbilical vein catheter. A chest x-ray film showed hyaline membrane appearances. On the third day jaundice developed, the bilirubin, reaching 12 mg./lOO ml. No blood group incompatibility was demonstrated. Attempts to wean the infant off the respirator failed and .he died aged ..7 day;. Necropsy revealed a perforation of the ileum, and microscopy showed non-specific inflammation and necrosis, reported by the pathologist as similar to those in Case 1.

We have found, four other cases associated with exchange transfusion in the literature (Nienhuis, 1963 ; Waldhausen et al., 1963 ; Hermann, 1965 ; Schaffer, 1965). In Nienhuis’s case the perforation was thought to have occurred in utero and thus would have preceded the transfusion.

Clinical Manifestations

i                     .

Though spontaneous perforation of the bowel in the newborn is well documented we believe insufficient emphasis has been laid on the early manifestations, which may lead to a mistaken diagnosis. We think it helpful to divide these into two groups, early and late, as follows:

(a) Early.—(1) Refusal to feed. (2) Passage of blood and mucus rectally. (3) Abdominal distension. (4) Bilious vomiting. (5) Absent bowel sounds, A'-ray examination of the abdomen may be normal at this stage or show distended loops of bowel (Case 1 and the case described by Hermann, 1965).

(i>) Later, after perforation has occurred.—(1) Erythema and oedema of the anterior umbilical wall. This may suggest a diagnosis of umbilical sepsis and cellulitis, or portal pyaemia and thrombosis in a baby who has had umbilical catheterization. (2) Grunting. (3) Pallor. (4) Hypothermia. (5) Peripheral circulatory failure. A'-ray examination, of the abdomen now • shows gas under the diaphragm.

Discussion ■• •

The aetiology of this condition has never been satisfactorily elucidated. A variety of possible causes have been suggested, including congenital weakness of the bowel wall (Rudnew, 1915 ; Fischer, 1928 ; Boikan, 1930) and trauma (Fonkalsrud et al., 1966). Infection, either generalized septicaemia or primary peritonitis, has been incriminated (Waldhausen et al., 1963 ; Hermann, 1965 ; Thomas and Brockman, 1966). Hypoxia due to asphyxia or the respiratory distress syndrome is a factor (Lloyd et al., 1964 ; Thelander, 1939).

We think that in our cases the association between exchange transfusion and subsequent perforation is more than coincidental and that the cause is likely to be vascular, related to local vasomotor disturbances, or systemic hypotension exacerbated by hypoxia.

The term ’“necrotizing 'enterocolitis” has been used to describe the pathological findings in these infants (Waldhausen et al., 1963 ; Hermann, 1965 ; Fonkalsrud et al., 1966). The lesions in this condition are diffuse non-specific areas of necrosis with acute inflammation, which has not followed obstruction to a major blood vessel, supplying the bowel. Hermann (1965) believed that this was due to an anaphylactic reaction of the Shwartzman type. This requires a sensitizing dose of antigen locally, followed after an interval by a second dose intravenously, causing necrosis at the site of the sensitizing dose. In this case sensitization of the bowel wall by bacteria could occur during colonization of the bowel. Umbilical catheterization later could introduce further bacteria into the circulation.

However, necrotizing enterocolitis has been widely described in elderly adults, and in them its association with hypotension is well recognized. McGovern and Goulston (1965) described 33 cases- of "ischaemic enterocolitis,” in 19 of which hypotension was recognized before the onset of symptoms, and in another seven in which they considered there was microscopical evidence of hypotension in the form of zonal necrosis of the liver or epithelial necrosis in the proximal renal tubules. Kay et al. (1958) described another 16 cases, all of which were associated with an acute hypotensive episode, though these authors suspected that the colitis preceded rather than followed the hypotension. Marston (1962) has postulated that, as arterioles obey Laplace’s law, the smaller the blood vessel the narrower is the margin between rupture on the one hand and collapse on the other, Small falls in pressure in the mesenteric vessels can therefore exceed the critical closing pressure of minute vessels in the bowel wall and cause widespread shutdown. Because these vessels vary in length and position, and are affected by the tone and diameter of the bowel wall, the resulting changes may be patchy.                 t-

. We can find no recorded evidence of systemic blood-pressure readings during exchange transfusion. We are endeavouring in this unit to monitor the blood pressure in the aorta during the procedure in some cases and hope to present our findings in a future paper.

Another possibility (Kay et al., 1958) is that the anatomy of the vessels in the bowel wall is such that shunting may take place, bypassing the mucosa. Such shunts are well recognized in the lung, and in the respiratory distress syndrome hypoxia increases the flow through the shunt. It is interesting to speculate that hypoxia might have a similar effect on shunts in the bowel wall. Once ischaemia has occurred bacteria in the bowel could proliferate and invade the bowel wall and the effect of their endotoxins might be superimposed. Coliform endotoxins are sympathomimetic, and, possibly by potentiating adrenaline, • can bring about further vasoconstriction and ischaemia, of the bowel wall (Lillehei, 1957).

We wish to thank Dr. F. S. W. Brimblecombe, Dr. Beryl Comer, Dr. R. H. Dobbs, Professor W. Gaisford, Dr. L. Haas, and Dr. Mary Wilmers^ for permission to quote cases in their, care, and for their encouragement and advice. We are indebted to Dr. N. J. Brown, Dr. R. A. Caldwell, and Dr. N. France for the pathological findings, and to Dr. Sheila Lewis and Sister Mary Chase for help in tracing details of Case 6.                     .

Requests for reprints should be addressed to S.M.E., North Devon Infirmary, Barnstaple.                         . '

Exchange Transfusion and Perlorauun

Sir,—We were interested to read the reports of Mr. J. J. Corkery and others (9 November, p. 345) and Drs. R. L’E. Orme and Sheila M. Eades (p. 349) on perforation of the bowel in the newborn period as a complication of exchange transfusion. Perforation, however, is only the most dramatic result of mesenteric vascular occlusion, and is not inevitable.

At a meeting of the South West Paediatric Club on 26 May this year, and again at a meeting of the Neonatal Society in London on 17 October, we presented six personally studied cases of neonatal gut infarc-tion. Two ofour cases had been preceded by at least one prolonged and technically difficult exchange transfusion. In the first of these two cases there was a positive blood culture for E. coll associated with bowel necrosis extending from the caecum to the descending colon. Our second case had diarrhoea for seven days, which preceded the onset of abdominal distension and peripheral circulatory collapse owing to necrosis and perforation of the terminal ileum only. Unfortunately both these infants died without laparotomy being undertaken, and at necropsy we were able to demonstrate antemortem thrombi in the ductus venosus and portal vein in the first and in the portal and splenic veins in the second. We note that in tin series quoted there is no comment on the star of the portal vein in those infants who died A fuller report is being prepared for publi cation.—We are, etc.,

E. S. Mucklow.

D. J. de Sa’.

Department of Paediatrics and Pathology, United Oxford Hospitals, Oxford.

Spontaneous Perforation of the Bowel in the Newborn Following Exchange Transfusion

W. R. CASTOR, M.D./ Port Arthur, Ont.

‘TyECAUSE of the increasing number of reported cases, perforation of the gastrointestinal tract in the newborn must be considered more commop thfl.it was once acknowledged. Without early recognition and immediate operation there is little chance of the infant’s survival.

The term “spontaneous” is restricted to those cases occurring within the neonatal period, not associated with a more distal obstruction or known incident of trauma, such as perforation of the rectum by a thermometer or of the colon by a cleansing or barium enema. Various theories of etiology for spontaneous bowel rupture have been suggested, such as mural defects, peptic ulceration, laceration from birth trauma, meconium stasis and infection. A smaller group, composed chiefly of those cases in which the distal ileum and colon arc involved, has not been explained.

'i'iii’i pireports Iwo cases of colon pefloratiorj iollowing exchange trmisfitsion in eryihrobkistotic newborn infants. Reported instances of spontaneous perforation of the gut in the first 14 days of life are surveyed in order to demonstrate the similar clinical features and radiographic findings, despite the apparent variations in cause.

Case 1.—The mother was 32 years old, para III, gravida IV, Group A, Rh-negative, with mild dia-

“‘rtadioioffisi, Department of Itadiology, The General Hospital of Port Arthur, Port Arthur, Ontario.

Reprint requests to: Dr. W. R. Castor. betes. At the 30th week of gestation and '.gain at the 34th week Rh antibodies were present vith a titre of 1:8. Amniocentesis at the 34th week recovered fluid of optical density that placed it in Liley’s mid-zone. Because of the diabetes and the presence of antibodies it was considered advisable to induce labour when the 37th week was reached. Spontaneous delivery of a male child weighing 9 lbs. 8 oz. followed the administration of an intravenous oxytocin drip. The infant was* Rh-positive and the direct Coombs’ test was negative. The cord blood showed a bilirubin of 7.S mg. per 100 ml. and the hemoglobin was 20.2 g. Jaundice was evident in the child at birth; the following day the bilirubin rose to 16 mg. and the indirect Coombs’ test was positive. No abnormal abdominal findings were apparent. By the third day the bilirubin was 22 mg. per 100 ml. An exchange transfusion was given, using 500 c.c. of Group O blood. The umbilical venous pressure was recorded as 8 cm. of water at the commencement and 30 cm. of water during the exchange transfusion. On the fourth day the infant’s stool was streaked with, blood; later in the evening the child was irritable and refused its feeding, and its rectal temperature was 101’ F.

Early in the morning of the next day abdominal distension, bile-stained vomiting and respiratory distress became evident. Radiographs demonstrated marked pneumoperitoneum (Fig. 1). Operation was performed without delay. A perforation of the transverse colon was repaired and a colostomy performed. From the margin of the perforation gangrenous tissue was obtained and a swab from the abdominal cavity resulted in moderate growth of E. coli. The infant tolerated the procedure well; the colostomy was subsequently closed and the patient discharged from hospital.

934 Castor: Exchange Tbansfusion


Cunad. Asa. J.

Nov. 16. 1&68, vol.


KIP-36


Case 2.—A 36-year-old woman, para V, gravida VI, Rh-negative, presented with symptoms suggestive of acute pelvic inflammatory disease, A pregnancy test gave a positive result. A Papanicolaou smear from the cervix was positive and at the twelfth week of gestation conization of the cervix was performed. The pathologist reported carcinoma in situ with no evidence of invasion. The pregnancy continued un-, evcntfully to term and the patient was delivered v spontaneously of a female infant weighing 6 lbs. 7 oz. Some jaundice was noticed; the cord blood gave a positive Coombs’ test, the bilirubin was 8.2 mg. per 100 ml. and the hemoglobin was 10.7 g. There ■ was some suspicion of a congenital cardiac anomaly.

Eight hours after birth an exchange transfusion of 440 ml. was given, and 460 ml. was removed, the deficit being allowed because of increased rightsided pressure. Following this the bilirubin was 7.0 mg. and the hemoglobin 13.4 g. On the third day, because the bilirubin had risen to 15.5 mg. with a fall in hemoglobin to 10.7 g., a repeat exchange transfusion was necessary, during which slight cardiac embarrassment occurred. Thirty-six hours later the baby refused its feeding, the ab-' domen became distended and free air within the abdomen became apparent by radiography (Fig. 2). An operation was performed within 12 hours and disclosed gangrene of the left transverse colon extending down to tire sigmoid region, with multiple perforations. Resection of the diseased bowel and colostomy were necessary. Microscopic examination of the surgical specimen showed marked congestion of all vessels and early infarction in one area. The serosa and attached mesentery were edematous with acute inflammatory infiltration. Inflammatory cells were present throughout the bowel wall and the mucosa was superficially ulcerated. Culture of the swab from the infant’s abdominal cavity yielded a scanty growth of staphylococci and diphtheroid bacilli. The colostomy was closed within four weeks and the baby was later discharged from hospital.

The following illustrative cases have been collected from the literature:

Case 3.1(1—A full-term male infant received an exchange transfusion at 4 hours and a second at 48 hours. On the fourth day abdominal distension and pneumoperitoneum were evident. An operation within 24 hours revealed perforation of the terminal ileum. Two days later re-operation was necessary after recurrence of the clinical picture of perforation and two more ileal perforations were repaired. The infant survived.

Case 4.21*—On the second day following an exchange transfusion for Rh incompatibility, marked abdominal distension became apparent and there was radiographic evidence of fluid within the abdomen. No mention of pneumoperitoneum is made in ■ the description of the case. At operation, perforations of tire transverse colon wer'c present. Because of the extent of the disease, resection of the terminal ileum, ascending colon and transverse colon was necessary. The patient survived.

Nov. 16, 1968, vol. 'J'J


936 Castor: Exchange Transfusion

(a)                                                                (b)

Fig. 2.—Case 2: (a) On the left the supine view demonstrates the air dome sign or so-called football sign of pneumoperitoneum (arrow) : (b) subphrenic free air on upright view.



Case 5.3—An erythroblastotic male infant whose cord blood gave a positive serological reaction for syphilis needed an exchange transfusion on the second day and another on the fourth day. Blood was passed with the stool on the fifth day. On the ninth day, marked respiratory distress and ab-t/c// dotninal distension developed and the child died shortly afterwards. At autopsy, a large rent was found in the anterior mid-portion of the stomach. It was attributed to a muscular defect.

Case 6.7—A full-term male infant who was jaundiced at birth was given an exchange transfusion at 3 hours, at 10 hours, at 24 hours and late on the second day. During the last transfusion the infant was noticeably fussy and irritable. Abdominal distension developed. Over the next three days this diminished somewhat but streaks of blood appeared in the stool. Abdominal distension suddenly increased and pneumoperitoneum was demonstrated radiologically. At operation the entire colon above the rectosigmoid was involved in a necrotizing process, with multiple areas of gangrene and perforation. Histological examination showed a diffuse necrotizing colitis with areas of infarction and perforation; the process was considered to be consistent with a type of Shwartzman reaction. It was necessary to resect the colon and anastomose the ileum to the rectum; an ileostomy was performed. The patient survived.

Case 7.13—A full-term male infant was born with a markedly distended abdomen, and with two loops of the umbilical cord tightly wound about the neck, causing cyanosis in a “hood” distribution. An exchange transfusion was performed without incident at eight hours, and shortly afterwards radiographs indicated free intraperitoneal air. An operation was

performed 14 hours after birth, and meconium and fluid were found within the peritoneal cavity, as well as a fibrinous exudate covering the peritoneum and congestion of the intestines. A linear perforation in the hepatic flexure of the colon was discovered; this was closed. The patient survived. -

From the available literature a total of 35 cases of pneumoperitoneum attributed to spontaneous perforation of the bowel in the newborn wore reviewed.1- 3'7, u'13,10> 24

The following data were collected:

Maturity: premature, 15; term, 19; not stated, 1.

Sex: males, 25; females, 10.                   .

Age: see Table II.

Site: stomach, 15; small bowel, 9 (terminal ileum, 6); colon, 11.

Results: survived, 8; died, 27. Of the 16 cases in which no operation was recorded, all died. There were 8 survivors among the 19 patients who underwent surgery. In two of the cases a second operation was necessary.7' 18

Clinical Findings

Generally, there is no indication at birth that anything is amiss, as the infant is usually vigorous and healthy in appearance. One to five days later the neonate possibly refuses feeding and abdominal distension develops, frequently followed by severe respiratory distress. Some cases show blood in the stool before the appearance of the distension. The diagnosis is confirmed by radiographic evidence of pneumoperitoneum.

Radiological Findings

in the supine view of Case 1 massive intraperitoneal free air is apparent as it outlines the peritoneal cavity and is divided centrally by the faint linear shadow of the falciform ligament (Fig. 1). On the erect film the gas is seen to have accumulated above the liver and spleen with elevation of the diaphragm. In Case 2 a chest study before perforation included an anteroposterior recumbent and lateral projection using a horizontal beam, and failed to demonstrate pneumoperitoneum. From the emergency plain film of the abdomen (Fig. 2a) radiographic indications of pneumoperitoneum arc more ' subtle. The air-dome sign is present, as is the falciform ligament sign, while the evidence from the erect view (Fig. 2b) is pathognomonic of free air.

The literature calls attention to the radiographic signs of free air on the anteroposterior supine view; several of these are mentioned, such as the air-dome sign,10 the falciform liga-

Fig. 3,-—Photomicrographs of Case 2. (Original magnification X 300.;

ment sign,3 gaseous outlining of both sides of the bowel wall,12 and gas within the scrotum.4 There may be massive free air above the liver and spleen, giving the so-called saddle-bag sign.13 By inverting the infant the free gas will outline the pelvic structures and enter the scrotum.4 A lateral decubitus study allows the free air to accumulate along the flank, while in a recumbent study (supine) using a horizontal beam there is a crescent of air under the anterior abdominal wall and above the viscera.4, 21

Nearly all cases show massive accumulation of gas, whether from a rent in the stomach or from perforation of the rectum by a thermometer.12 Since neonatal respiration is largely diaphragmatic and abdominal,-2 the amount of gas is significant, as it may elevate the diaphragm and hamper respiration. Immediate paracentesis has been recommended as a lifesaving procedure while the patient is being prepared for operation.13

Failure to appreciate the presence of free air within the abdomen will lessen the patient’s chances for survival by delaying or preventing prompt surgery. In Case 2 (Fig. 2a) only a plain film of the abdomen was obtained so as not to

WO

Can ad. Med. Ass. J , JsTov, lu, 1 9GS, vol. ^9

disturb the gravely ill inFant. It is partly underexposed, obscuring the already subtle and frequently unfamiliar signs of free air bent alb the dome of the abdomen, and a second view would be most desirable, as a safety factor. Minute amounts of free air arc best detected by an erect film, but when there-is perforation of the bowel a large volume of air is present, which is a strong argument for the routine use of recumbent projections with the x-ray tube in a horizontal plane, so that no manipulation of the baby is required.

Gas may be present within the abdomen secondary to pneumomediastinum, having been compressed from the mediastinum into the perivascular spaces and into the retroperitoneal region,4 but this is usually not a diagnostic problem. Purposely to demonstrate gas within the scrotum, to which it makes its way through the open processus vaginalis,4 is unnecessary and increases gonadal irradiation. Gas may be present in the portal vein in cases of severe necrosis of the colon but also, as demonstrated by Schmidt,20 following administration of fluid via the umbilical vein.

Discussion

All the cases of spontaneous perforation of the bowel that have been reviewed present in a wav that is strikingly similar and show similar radiographic findings, although no common p-athogenesis has been described. In cases other than those involving the stomach, enterocolitis and necrosis are repeatedly demonstrated at operation or autopsy; it is curious why rupture is seen most commonly in the colon and so infrequently in the small bowel, except for the terminal ileum. To account for the distribution of the lesion in the gastrointestinal tract, the portal vein appears to be a common denominator. Its hemodynamics are altered during an exchange transfusion and, in essence, reversal of the physiologic process occurs. But other local factors must exist in the bowel wall; otherwise the incidence of spontaneous rupture of the bowel would be much greater in association with exchange transfusions. Swenson”3 has pointed out ' that infants with Hirschsprung’s disease are prone to enterocolitis which may lead to perforation, and in cases of meconium plug syndrome, necrosis may develop in the adjacent bowel wall. In our cases, no abnormality of the alimentary tract was suspected at birth and the baby survived surgical correction of the perforation with no such abnormality becoming apparent later.

TABIM II. Casus from Literature: KstiVA’fuw A«b in Days at Demonstration of I’neiimoferitom’.rm

Aye in dayis                               Kt>. 0/<ws

At birth

  • I

  • 2

  • 3

  • 4

  • 5

  • 6

  • 7 ............................

  • 8 •

  • 9

  • 10

Table II indicates the relationship of the age of the majority of patients at perforation to the postnatal period of transition within the portal circulation. Meyer and Lind® found that functional closure of the ductus venosus occurs during the first minute of life owing to the decrease in pressure with the cessation of placental blood flow, while organic closure may not be completed until the twentieth day. With the beginning of intestinal function, blood flow through the portal vein increases considerably, while there is a distinct alteration from the oxygenated placental blood. The same authors claim that acute pathological lesions can be observed as a consequence of the postnatal change in liver circulation.9 According to Potter,10 acute necrosis of the liver unaccompanied by evidence of infection is not uncommon in young infants, especially newborns, and the amount of involvement varies. Potter describes similar changes suggestive of infarction following exchange transfusions, where partial thrombosis of the ductus venosus was found. The colon that was removed in Case 2 had an appearance very similar to that described in other reported cases. An area of early infarction was present; the veins were congested while the arteries were relatively unremarkable (Fig. 3). In some cases reported as necrotizing enterocolitis,1- 24 the pathological description resembles that of our case. According to Bobbins,17 occlusion of venous return will lead to infarction in about 18 hours. The macroscopic changes progress from intense congestion -with a dusky red to purple hue, and a fibrinosuppuralive, somewhat granular exudate appears later, followed by ulceration of the mucosa which is inevitably complicated by secondary bacterial contamination. Perforation of the wail may occur within the next two or three days. Any stage of the process may be seen, depending on the duration.

In attempting to cannulate the inferior vena cava via the umbilical vein, Peck and Lowman14

Cillliul. Meii. Ass.

Nov. I (i. 1 SfljS; vnl. 99


Castor: Exchange Transfusion 939

demons crated that in only 3 out of 30 cases of blind placement (without radiological guidance) did the tip of die catheter enter the inferior vena cava. Rudolph ei «Z.,18 when cannulating the right atrium using the umbilical vein, found that there is a tendency for the catheter to enter the portal vein. In both of oui- cases of exchange transfusion a high right-sided pressure was noticed.

It is reasonable to assume that transient portal hypertension, or even stasis in one or more tributaries of the portal vein, can be present, causing venous thrombosis and/or hemorrhagic infarction in a small or large portion of the bowel. Why the terminal ileum and colon arc most often affected in cases associated with erythroblastosis is not apparent, and whether erythroblastosis is a primary cause cannot be determined from the series reported.7,11119 Potter 13 notes intestinal tract lesions in erythroblastosis which she attributes to replacement of Peyer’s patches by erythropoietic cells. I would y rather conclude that a complication of portal fetal circulation and/or the exchange transfusion — is responsible. Neonatal portal vein thrombosis can occur as a complication of exchange transfusion19 or independently of it.2 Furthermore, increased frequency of bowel perforation is not reported in crylhroblastotic babies who have not V received.....exchange transfusion, while on the

other hand seven cases following exchange transfusions are on record. It is more difficult to assign this pathogenesis to Case 7, as the process appeared to have occurred before delivery, but the interference with the cord circulation may be of significance.

Surgical correction of the condition is mandatory and should be performed as soon as possible; bowel resection and temporary colostomy arc frequently necessary. A grave prognosis is suggested by the perusal of the literature, but the majority of the reported cases which were associated with erythroblastosis survived. Case 5 was an exception, but operation was not performed. Of six cases of perforation with necrotizing colitis reported by Wahlhausen, Herendeen and King,2'1 the lone survivor was an erythroblastotic baby.

e .     , Two cases of spontaneous perforation

. mmn.ny        colon following exchange trans

fusions for erythroblastosis are described. Five additional cases have been reported in the literature? and these are briefly described. The importance of the radiological signs of pneumoperitoneum in the newborn and the need for prompt surgery to repair or resect the necrotic bowel are emphasized. It is postulated that the condition may be a complication of the transition in the fetal portal circulation following delivery and/or a complication of the exchange transfusions.

... ,     , L’auteur presente deux cas de perfora

tion spontanee consecutive a unc ex-sanguin j-transfusion pour erythroblastose. II passe briever, tent en revue les cinq cas supplcmentaires qui ont etc cites dans la littcrature. Il souligne /importance des signes de pneumoperitoine chez 1c nouveau-ne et la necessite d'une correction chirurgi-cale rapide ou de la resection de la portion d’intestin necrose. Il emet 1’hypothese que cette pathologic peut ctre une complication de la transition dans la circulation ports du fetus apres 1’accouche- -, meat ou une complication des transfusions sanguines dechange, ou, peut-etre des deux precedes.

I gratefully acknowledge the assistance of Dr. F. J. Lone, Dr. W. A. Hargan and Dr. F. J. Xeelands in the preparation of this paper.

  • 16. Idem : Ibid., p. 387.
