  • 18. Rudolph, A. M. et al.: Pediatrics, 27: 551. 1961.

  • 19. Schaffer, A. J.: Diseases of the newborn. 2nd ed., W. B. Saunders Company, Philadelphia, 1965, p. 373.

  • 20. SCHMIDT, A. G.: Radiology, 38: 293. 1907.

  • 21. Schwarz, E.: Amer. J, Roentgen., 85: 714, 1961.

  • 22. SMITH, C. A,: Ibid., 74: 791. 1955.

  • 23. Swenson. O.: Atm. Surg.. 146: 706. 1957.

  • 24. WaldhaUsen, J. A.. Herendeen, T. and King, I-L: Surgery, 54: 365, 1963.

Bowel perforation after exchange transfusion in

the neonate: Review of the literature and report of a case

  • J. M. CARALPS-RIERA, M.D.

B. D. COHN, M.D, F.A.A.P.

BROOKLYN, N. Y.

From the Departments of Surgery, Maimonides Medical Center and State University of New York Downstate Medical Center


owel perforation following exchange . transfusion in the neonate hag often been J designated as idiopathic. However, review of the reported cases and a recent experience in our institution suggest that exchange transfusion itself may be an etiologic factor.

ETIOLOGY

Several possible pathogenetic mechanisms in bowel gangrene and perforation in the newborn infant following exchange transfusion have been discussed previously.

Sudden pressure increase in the portal system. If the baby cries or strains, the pressure in the inferior vena cava may suddenly rise, and if the catheter tip is proximal to the ductus venosus, retrograde flow into the portal system may result.3

Hypoxia or hypotension. Either condition may precipitate widespread small-vessel collapse or arteriovenous shunting to protect the cerebral and coronary' blood supply.11 Resultant bacterial growth may compromise the integrity of the bowel wall6; coliform endotoxins, in particular, are known to have sympathomimetic effects.7

Schwartzman reaction localized to the bowel. This possibility was pointed out by Hermann.5

Embolism from the umbilical vein. This appears to be the least likely of the proposed mechanisms.5

In the cases reviewed, clear-cut hypoxic episodes during or preceding exchange trans-

Received for publication Apiil 24, 1970.

Vol. 68, No. 5, pp. 895-898 fusion were present in only 11 patients. However, the blood pressure was not continuously monitored; therefore, it is not possible to determine the significance of hypoxia as an etiologic factor in the reported cases. In most of the patients, there was no record of the pressure at which the blood was transfused, and donor or umbilical vein blood specimens obtained before or after transfusion were not cultured.

Although the evidence in favor of hypoxia as the most likely etiologic factor is not conclusive, this appears to be the most reasonable possibility, either as the primary cause or as the result of increased portal pressure or hypotension.

CLINICAL MATERIAL

To date, 20 cases of bowel perforation J. after exchange transfusion have been reported ; this literature includes the present case.3’5,10,111 J3'1S In three instances, the sex of the patient was not reported; of the remaining 17, 11 were male and 6 were, female. Eleven patients had multiple transfusions, with five being the maximum. Nine presented with multiple perforations. No relationship between the number of transfusions and the number of perforations could be recognized. The interval between transfusion and perforation varied from a few hours to four days.

The colon was affected in 14 instances,3"5, io, ii, n the sma]j an(] large bowel in four,11’14115 and the terminal ileum alone in one.13

November, 1970 SURGERY 895

KIP-42

336 Pediatric surgery

Surgical exploration was undergone by 18 patients. The infants’ ages at this time ranged from a few hours to 28 days. All but two of these patients survived. One died of pulmonary complications on the eighth postoperative day; the other, who had been treated conservatively for 28 days before laparotomy, died during the immediate postoperative period.

Two patients were treated conservatively. One died, and the autopsy findings disclosed multiple perforations involving the small and large bowel.11 The other baby was reported to have recovered.14 However, since proof of the diagnosis and follow-up data were not presented, it is difficult to accept this as a case in which conservative treatment of bowel perforation was successful.

DIAGNOSIS

Bowel gangrene should be suspected in any newborn infant in whom abdominal distention develops after exchange transfusion. The bowel sounds may be absent or hypoactive and the abdomen tender. The patient may vomit bilious or mucous material, and blood may be present in the stool.

Pneumoperitoneum seen in an abdominal plain film confirms the diagnosis. Several patterns of intraperitoneal air distribution have been described: the air dome sign,® the falciform ligament sign,1 the football sign,12 and air in the scrotum.2, 9 The presence of gas in the portal vein branches cannot be considered as diagnostic of bowel gangrene secondary to vascular abnormality because it has also been seen following the administration of fluids via the umbilical vein.

TREATMENT

Emergency treatment consists of intubation for nasogastric suction, rehydration, and intravenous antibiotics. Until culture reports become available, penicillin and kana-mycin offer broad coverage. If pneumoperitoneum is present, needle paracentesis may facilitate respiratory exchange.

If perforation is suspected, laparotomy is mandatory. The surgical procedure depends upon the findings. Primary resection and anastomosis, with or without diverting colostomy, diverting colostomy alone, ileostomy, Hartmann procedure, and suture of the perforation, with or without proximal colostomy, have been done. Irrigation of the peritoneal cavity with antibiotic solution may help to prevent postoperative complications.

PATHOLOGY

Microscopic examination of the resected bowel has disclosed essentially similar findings, varying from areas of mucosal ulceration and inflammatory changes in all layers of the wall to necrosis and perforation. Areas of congestion in the antimesenteric border, with or without infarction, have also been present in most specimens.

PROPHYLAXIS

The possibility of bowel damage from exchange transfusion must be kept in mind. The use of a radiopaque catheter18 or injection of contrast material will allow placement of the catheter in the inferior vena cava. The administration of a sedative prevents sudden increase in inferior vena cava pressure. Also helpful in reducing the hazards of the procedure are meticulous aseptic technique and culture reports on umbilical vein blood specimens taken before and after transfusion.

CASE REPORT

A male infant was delivered after 40 weeks’ gestation by low forceps extraction. The mother was 21 years old and para 2-1-0-3. The baby’s Apgar score was 9 at one minute and 10 at five minutes. The mother’s blood type was Rh negative. The antibody titer had increased from 1:16 on March 26, 1969, to 1:256 by August 21.

Physical examination indicated that the infant was ftdl term and in no distress. When the baby was nine hours of age, jaundice was observed. The baby’s blood type was A, Rh positive. The Coombs test gave a value of 3+. The serum bilirubin level was 2.8 mg. per 100 ml.; twelve hours later, it was 7.2 mg. per 100 ml. (direct, 0.4) and at 2 p.m., 9.7 mg. per 100 ml. Exchange transfusion was performed when the infant was 21 hours of age and the serum bilirubin level was 10.4 mg. per 100 ml. The procedure was well tolerated.

Caralps-Riera and Cohn: Bowel perforation 897

On the next day, the patient was still jaundiced and less active; the sucking reflex was poor but the baby cried lustily. A nasogastric tube was passed and the baby was given glucose in water.

On the following day, three, days ,.after birth, the patient was lethargic, manifested a poor sucking reflex, and did not tolerate feedings. At 10 p.m., the baby’s abdomen was very distended and the bowel sounds were absent. The temperature at this time was 100.4° F., the heart rate, 180 beats per minute, and the respiratory rate, 52 per minute. The passage of a rectal tube did not relieve the distention. Gastric suction yielded a small quantity of greenish mucoid material. The stool gave a 2+ positive reaction to the guaiac test. There was tenderness and rebound tenderness in the lower abdominal quadrants.

An x-ray examination of the abdomen disclosed free air under both hemidiaphragms. To improve the baby’s respirations, an abdominal tap was done and 100 c.c. of air removed. Intravenous administration of fluids was started and penicillin and kanamycin were given. Blood cultures taken before and after exchange transfusion were negative.

Laparotomy was performed eight hours later, when the infant was 3 days and 9 hours old, and about 200 c.c. of fecaloid material were removed from the peritoneal cavity. The colon from the J splenic flexure to the distal sigmoid was gangrenous with a large antimesenteric perforation of the sigmoid colon. After a left hemicolectomy was performed, an end-transverse colostomy with a sigmoid mucous fistula was fashioned. The peritoneal cavity was irrigated with a four percent kanamycin solution.

Pathological examination disclosed recent hemorrhagic infarction in the specimen, with marked peritonitis; the presence of ganglion cells was noted.

The colostomy started functioning 20 hours after the operation; by the fourth day, fullstrength formula was being given. The baby remained afebrile and the reflexes were normal. On the seventh day, a subcutaneous wound infection was noted and the skin opened; the wound was irrigated with saline solution and packed. Escherichia coli grew in cultures taken from the wound. On the twenty-ninth postoperative day the i patient was discharged. Continuity of the bowel V is to be re-established eventually.

SUMMARY

Review of reported cases of bowel perforation following exchange transfusion in the neonate suggests that the blood replacement procedure per sc may be a factor in the etiology of this complication.

Of the proposed pathogenetic mechanisms, hypoxia of the bowel, either as the primary event or secondary to hypotension, appears to be the most likely factor in most instarices. The diagnosis should be suspected whenever abdominal distention develops following exchange transfusion. Pneumoperitoneum in an abdominal plain film is diagnostic of the condition.

Laparotomy is mandatory if perforation is suspected. The pathologic findings in specimens of resected bowel are essentially similar, ranging from mucosal ulceration and inflammatory changes affecting all layers of the bowel wall to necrosis and perforation.

To the 19 previously reported cases is added that of a male infant in whom signs of abdominal distress developed approximately two days after exchange transfusion. The infant responded well to colectomy and end-transverse colostomy.

REFERENCES

I

tanateS Colonic Perforation After Exchange Tmstesbn A Case Report

A. A, Kerr MB MRACP, Paediatric Registrar Paediatric Department, Wellington Hospital, Wellington

SUMMARY

The case of a severely affected rhesus sensitised infant is described in which four exchange transfusions were followed by perforation of the large bowel on the fifth day of life, which was successfully treated by primary closure. The relationship of colonic perforation to exchange transfusion and its pathogenesis is discussed. From a survey of reported cases it is apparent that colonic perforation is directly related to exchange transfusion but the exact pathogenesis is not understood.

INTRODUCTION

Spontaneous perforation of the large bowel in the neonatal period is a rare event, but its occurence following exchange transfusion has recently been emphasised by Corkery, Dubowitz, Lister and Moosa (1968), and Orme and Eadcs (1968) in Britain, and Castor (1968) in Canada. A further case is presented here.

CASE REPORT

Female baby G.O., Wellington Hospital Number 227681, was born on 15.9.69, to a Group AB, rhesus negative mother who had had two previously unaffected infants but during this pregnancy amniocentesis had shown a severe degree of Rh incompatibility in spite of low scrum antibody levels earlier in the pregnancy.

At 36 weeks' gestation, labour was induced by artificial rupture of the membranes and the child was born vaginally after a normal labour. Birth weight was 2.73kg. At birth she was clinically anaemic, had gross hepatosplenomegaly with a distended abdomen, her heart rate was 130 with normal heart sounds and she had slight indrawing and grunting respiration with bilateral crepitations. The cord blood findings were Hb 4.4g/100ml, bilirubin 6.lmg/100inl with a strongly positive Coombs' test, and the blood group was AB Rh positive.

Her first exchange transfusion al two hours was of 500ml in 10ml cycles and because of a high venous pressure of 15cm a deficit of 20ml was lefti The polythene catheter was inserted only 4< m into the umbilical vein. Her second exchange transfusion at 18t hours was of 440ml during which the baby had a short

18


July 1970


N.Z. med. 72, 18.


episode of tachypnoca, tachycardia, and cyanpajs w'*h crepitations being noted at both bases. This settled ■ with temporary cessation of the transfusion, oxygen and intravenous calcium-gluconate. The third exchange transfusion at 47 hours of age was a 480ml exchange and again she had an episode of deterioration in her condition-with increased venous pressure and slight cyanosis just before the end of the procedure. Her fourth exchange transfusion at 67 hours was uneventful.                                           ............'

Citrated blood, warmed by passage through a coil, was used for all the exchange transfusions which were performed over 60 to 80 minutes in 10ml cycles. Prophylactic kanamycin 15mg intramuscularly 12 hourly was administered after the first exchange. She was digitalised after the second exchange.

Figure 1.—Plain abdominal and chest x-ray showing a large volume of air between the liver and diaphragm.

On her fifth day, 40 hours after the fourth exchange, she was noted to have marked abdominal distension with oedema of the lower abdomen and legs, absent bowel sounds, but no vomiting and normal bowel motions, At that stage abdominal x-ray showed a pneumoperitoneum (Figure 1). At laparotomy, performed at the age of 110 hours, there was a loosely walled-ofT abscess in the left paracolic gutter with some minor soiling of the immediate area. The peritoneal cavity also contained free fluid and a large volume of air. The transverse colon showed a 7 x 3mm hole proximal to the splenic flexure. This appeared to be in an area of1 infarction and a biopsy from the edge showed non-specific acute inflammation. This defect was closed in two layers. The area was drained through the left hypochondrium. Cultures from the peritoneal fluid and later from the drainage site grew Escherichia coli sensitive to kanamycin.

For the post-operative period she was maintained on intravenous fluids and her antibiotic was changed to cephaloridine. Five days post-opcratively she showed signs of digitalis toxicity and her drugs were stopped temporarily. At this stage there was some twitching of her limbs and her serum calcium was 1.8mEq/L and blood sugar was 12mg/100ml. Extra glucose was added to her infusion and supplementary calcium gluconate was given. Over the next few days her condition improved and she was changed on to normal oral feeding. Apart from a top-up transfusion of 100ml the rest of her admission was uneventful.

When seen at the age of five months her development was normal.

DISCUSSION

Although exchange transfusion is a major procedure in the newborn, involving as it does replacement of 95 percent of the infant’s total blood volume, in experienced hands it seems to carry little risk in terms of mortality. Weldon and Odell (1968), in a series of 351 exchanges in 232 infants gave a mortality rate of 3.1 percent.

There seems little doubt that such a rare event as colonic perforation following exchange transfusion is more than a coincidence and is a complication of the procedure. One feature of this complication however, is its relatively benign course as compared with other types of spontaneous perforation. There were only two deaths in the 12 cases reported by Corkery and others (1968), Orme and Eades (1968) and Castor (1968). Hermann’s (1965) case (which survived) and the only survivor of the six cases of Waldhausen, Herendeen and King (1963) both fall into this group of post-exchange perforations. The mortality for other types of spontaneous perforation scums to be at least 75 percent (Brennan, 1967; Corkery and others, 1968).

Figure 2.-—Diagram to show the anatomical connections of the umbilical vein at birth.

The most likely pathogenesis would seem to relate to the presence of the umbilical catheter in the region of the portal vein and ductus venosus (Figure 2). That this is so is further evidenced by a case described by Orme and Eades (1968) in which perforation of the ileum occurred following infusion of dextrose via an umbilical catheter in a premature infant with hyaline membrane disease. The mechanism of this remains speculative. That profound alteration in blood flow during infusion can occur is demonstrated by two cases described by Farquhar and Smith (1958) in -which manipulation of the umbilical catheter and re-insertion to 11cm resulted in cyanosis of the lower half of the body associated with increased venous filling over the trunk and the abdominal veins draining superiorly. They felt that the catheter was in the portal system and attributed the apparent inferior vena caval obstruction to spasm of the ductus venosus spreading to the vena cava. Corkery and others (1968) in studies on two cadavers demonstrated rapid back flow of the infused radio-opaque dye up the portal and mesenteric veins. They suggested that spasm of the small vessels in the mucosal -wall due to the variation in portal pressure resulted in necrosis with consequent perforation. Micro-embolism from the catheter site could produce a similar picture. The removal and replacement of blood during the exchange may also lead to episodes of systemic hypotension which, in association with increased sympathetic nervous discharge as expected during a traumatic procedure, may lead to bowel necrosis as is postulated in the mechanism of shock.

A local effect of the polyvinyl-chloride (PVC) catheters which have recently gained widespread popularity has been suggested by Rogers and Dunn (1969). They point out that human umbilical arteries perfused with Ringer-Locke solution show clear-cut responses to normal physiological stimuli for up to 12 hours after birth. However, when PVC apparatus is used for the perfusion the responses are abolished. The implication is that toxic substances are leached out from the PVC and during exchange transfusion may cause either direct chemical necrosis or alteration in the normal portal vasculature.

Although the size of the biopsy was very small, no bowel resection having been done, the histological appearances in this case were of non-specific inflammation. These findings are the same as most others have found and because of this an infective aetiology has been suggested. Scott (1963), described six cases of colonic perforation unrelated to exchange transfusion which he attributed to perinatal sepsis leading to intestinal gangrene. He based his assumption on the histological picture with support from peritoneal swabs which grew colifeim bacilli in four cases and Candida albicans in one. Wahlhausen and others (1963). in their six cases demonstrated Pstudom >nas aeruginosa in four of them and ascribed the condition to this organism. However, these cases were not associated with exchange transfusion and the high mortality in both these series suggests a different syndrome to that of post-transfusion perforation.

Hermann (1965) has taken the infective theory a stage further and suggested a Shwartzman-tvpe reaction to explain the vasculitis present in the histology. His case was similar to the present one with moderately severe rhesus incompatibility requiring four exchange transfusions and followed within 24 hours with abdominal distension and poor feeding due to perforation of the colon. He postulated that the colonic mucosa was sensitised by the bowel flora and was later challenged by organisms introduced via the umbilical vein at the time of exchange transfusion.

The possibility that the general metabolic upset during the exchange is a causative factor has been suggested and the use of citrated blood has been questioned on these grounds. Farquha’r and Smith (1958) demonstrated an early rise in plasma citrate followed by a flattening off at a much higher level during exchange transfusion. These changes were associated with a reciprocal drop in the serum ionised calcium while the total calcium tended to rise gradually throughout the exchange. The potassium usually remained constant although a few cases showed episodes of hyperkalaemia. None of these changes, however, could be related to any clinical abnormalities observed. Also the severe and prolonged acidosis of the respiratory distress syndrome and cyanotic heart disease has not been associated ■with bowel perforation.

None of these explanations accounts, adequately for the occurrence of the perforation in the colon in preference to other parts of the gut.

Ficvri; 3.—Diagram to show the sites of perforation following exchange transfusion as described in 18 cases from the literature and the present case.

Figure 3 shows the sites of 25 perforations in the 13 cases referred to abuse (Corkery and others, 1968: Oinic and Eades, 1968; and Castor, 1968) as well as the present case and five others Castor described from the literature. It will be noted that these are distributed equally between the drainage areas of the superior and inferior mesenteric veins but that there is a predominance of large bowel perforations. No explanation can be suggested for this other than a local susceptibility of the colon wall.

N.Z. med. J., 72, 21.

21


■ One must conclude that colonic perforation is a definite risk of exchange transfusion but the exact mechanism of this complication remains unexplained^

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

The author wishes to thank Dr R. T. Bush and Mr J. Mcliwainc for permission to publish this case and for their help in preparing the manuscript.

REFERENCES

Corkery, J. J., Dubowitz, V., Lister, J., and Moosa, A. (1968). Colonic perforation after exchange transfusion. Br. med. J., 4, 345-349.

Farquhar, J. W., Smith, H. (1958). Clinical and biochemical changes during exchange transfusion. Arch. Dis. Childh., 33, 142-159.

Hermann, R. E. (1963). Perforation of the colon from nccrotising colitis in the newborn: Report of a survival and a new aetiologic concept. Surg,, 58, 436-441.                              ‘

Orme, R. L’E., and Fades, S. M. (1963). Perforation of the bowel in the newborn as a complication of exchange transfusion. Br. med. 4, 349-351.

Rogers, A. F., and Dunn, P. M. (1969). Intestinal perforation, exchange transfusion and PVC. Lancet 2, 1246.

Scott, J. E. (1963). Intestinal obstruction in the newborn associated with peritonitis. Arch. Dis. Childh., 38, 120-123.     '

Waldhausen, J. A., Herendeen, T., King, H. (1963' Necrotising colitis of the newborn: common cause of perforation of the colon. Surg., 54, 365-372.

ENTEROCOLITIS FOLLOWING EXCHANGE TRANSFUSION

J. M. Beck, F.R.C.S., Principal Paediatric Surgeon, Baragwanath Hospital,

M. Dinner, F.R.C,S.(Ed.), Chief Surgeon. Transvaal Memorial Hospital for Children ■                           and

J. Chappel, F.C.S. S.A., Senior Surgeon, Transvaal Memorial Hospital for Children

Since the articles by Corkery et al. (1968), Orme and Eades (1968) and Castor (1968) exchange transfusion has been recognised as one of the causes of neonatal gastro-intestinal perforation. In several previous reports (Wahlhausen et al., 1963, Forshall, 1964, Hermann, 1965 and Nienhuis, 1963) of perforations of the bowel in babies the association of jaundice and exchange transfusion has been mentioned. The present paper reports five babies who developed entero-co’itis after exchange transfusion, and the suggestion arising from our experience is that these cases should have conservative management unless there is evidence of gastro-intestinal perforation. The similarity of this condition to ischemic colitis in adults as described by Marston et al. (1966), Watt (1968) and McGovern and Goulston (1965) is discussed.

Material

From 1967 to 1969, approximately four and a half thousand exchange transfusions were performed by the South African Blood Transfusion Service in Johannesburg (Shapiro, 1970). In this period five babies were admitted to the paediatric surgical unit with evidence of entero-colitis following exchange transfusion. The apparent incidence of this complication is 1:900 exchange transfusions.

CASE REPORTS

Case 1. A 10-day old African male weighing 5 lb. 10 oz. was admitted one week after an, exchange transfusion. Twelve hours after the transfusion he had passed blood per rectum, followed by several more blood-stained stools. He had vomited feeds intermittently and for two days prior to admission he had been vomiting bile and had had no bowel action.

On admission the baby was shocked and hypothermic with gross abdominal distension, oedema and discolouration of the abdominal wall. Following rapid resuscitation a laparotomy was performed. There was gross faecal peritonitis with discolouration and necrosis of the transverse colon and splenic flexure which had a large, ragged perforation on its anti-mesenteric border. Resection with proximal colostomy was performed. The baby died twelve hours later.

Case?.. A seven-day old African male weighing 4 lb. 12 oz. was admitted five days after exchange transfusion. He had passed blood-stained stools the day after the exchange transfusion, and had refused feeds before the appearance of the bloody stool. Abdominal distension and bile-stained vomiting developed, and bowel actions ceased.

On admission there were signs of gastro-intestinal perforation. Vigorous resuscitation was necessary. An x-ray showed pneumoperitoneum.

At laparotomy the descending colon and proximal sigmoid colon were necrotic and

Suid-Afrikaanse Tydskrif vir Chirurgie, Vol. 9: Nr. t: Januarie-Maarl 1971                                   39

South African Journal of Surgery

Vol, 9s No. 1, January-March 1971

40                                           J. M. Beck. M. Dinner and J. Chappd

avascular with multiple small perforations. The bowel proximal to this had a greyish discolouration but was thought to be viable. Left hemicolectomy and transverse colostomy were performed. The mucosa of the colostomy showed small, superficial ulcerations.

The colostomy failed to work but remained apparently viable. The baby died two dv, post-operatively.

  • Case 3. An Asiatic male infant, whose birth weight was 5 lb. 11 oz., was admitted to hospital on the 3rd day of life with haemolytic jaundice due to ABO incompatibility. Exchange transfusions were performed on the 3rd and 4th days. The baby became shocked during the second transfusion but recovered quickly.

He developed severe diarrhoea with blood-stained stools during the next few days. He also had abdominal distension and bile-stained vomitus. Septicaemia was diagnosed and he was treated with broad spectrum antibiotics, intravenous fluids, and naso-gastric suction. He eventually recovered four weeks later but had a disaccharide intolerance.

He made slow progress after discharge from hospital. At the age of IS weeks he was admitted with low intestinal obstruction and an upper abdominal mass. There was a one-week history of absolute constipation.                                                 ■

Barium enema showed a stricture at the splenic flexure with proximal faecal impaction.

Laparotomy showed a tight fibrous stricture at the splenic flexure and a fistula between the terminal ileum and the ascending colon. Massive mesenteric lymphadenopathy was present. Subtotal colectomy with ileo sigmoid anastamosis was performed. The resected colon showed mucosal ulceration at the stricture with fibrosis of all layers of the bowel wall. The lymph nodes showed reactive hyperplasia only.

This baby is now well and can take a full normal infant’s diet.

  • Case 4. A male infant, weighing 6 lbs. and suffering from RH incompatibility, developed moderate abdominal distension and passed stools mixed with fresh blood six hours after his third exchange transfusion. Investigation showed a platelet count of 30,000 per cu. mm., normal bleeding and clotting time and a PI of 82%.

X-rays showed intra-mural gas in the descending colon and distension proximal to the splenic flexure.

The baby was treated with broad spectrum antibiotics, naso-gastric suction and intravenous fluids, and made a good recovery after three days.

One month later when the baby had irregular loose stools a barium enema was performed. This showed a constant area of narrowing in the descending colon. Apart from dietary management no therapy was given and four weeks later the baby was perfectly well. A repeat barium enema was normal at this time.

  • Case 5. This infant developed severe abdominal distension and bile-stained vomiting 2 days after its second exchange transfusion. He had passed a blood-stained stool a feu hours after his last transfusion. On admission he had marked oedema and discolouration of the abdominal wall and x-ray showed pneumoperitoneum. After rapid resuscitation a laparotomy was performed. The terminal ileum and colon were necrotic, and there were multiple small perforations. Total colectomy and ileostomy were performed. There was a stormy post-operative course but the baby eventually recovered and ileo-rectal anastamosis was possible. Since then the baby has been well.

DISCISSION

The 5 cases have certain features in common. AH the babies were jaundiced and needed one or more exchange transfusions. Within one da}. usually a few hours, of exchange transfusion all the babies passed blood or blood-stained stools. There was a varying degree of abdominal distension and the babies showed signs of shock. In those cases where earl}

South Afruan Journal of Surgw. V I January- *

I ntero-Colitis Following Exchange Transfusion

41


symptoms and signs were overlooked, perforation and peritonitis developed, but the babies treated early did not develop free perforations. The presenting features in these cases are similar to those discussed by Corkery et al. (196S) and Orme and Eades (1968) who describe early manifestations of impending perforation and late manifestations after the advent of perforation. The symptoms are similar to those of entero-colitis in premature babies and secondary' to other lesions (Touloukian et al., 1967).

■ Management

The disease usually affects the colon and terminal ileum but cases of more widespread involvement of the gastro-intestinal tract have been recorded, Orme and Eades (1968). Not all affected babies develop free perforation and, as illustrated by case 4, complete recovery is possible. Once an early diagnosis has been made, the process can be arrested in a proportion of babies by vigorous conservative therapy consisting of naso-gastric suction, intravenous fluid and broad spectrum antibiotics. During this stage the baby must be kept under continuous observation and, if there is any deterioration in his condition, laparotomy must be performed. Serial x-rays of the abdomen may be of assistance in assessing progress, particularly if there is intra-mural gas. (Touloukian 1967). Barium enema and other contrast studies should be avoided for fear of causing perforation.

There is no doubt that laparotomy must be performed if there is a perforation, and in these cases rapid resuscitation is necessary so that operation may be performed as soon as possible. Resuscitation must be directed to restoration of blood volume, correction of acid-base and other metabolic disturbances, correction of coagulation defects, and maintenance of adequate respiration. At operation appropriate resection is better than attempts at repair of perforations, and proximal colostomy or ileostomy is better than primary' anastamosis.

This management differs from that recommended by Corkery et al. (1968) who suggest early operation in all cases. We think that it is possible to prevent perforation by early vigorous conservative therapy. This policy is in agreement with that suggested by Touloukian et al. (1967) and by Stevenson et al. (1970).

Pathology

Ischemic colitis in adults has been described by Marston et al. (1966). Transient, stenosing and gengrenous forms were described. The patients were elderly people with underlying vascular disease and colitis was precipitated by a hypotensive episode. The majority of patients gave a history of passage of blood and mucus per rectum, accompanied by disturbance of bowel function and abdominal pain. Apart from the age difference the presentation, radiological features and progress of these patients were very' similar to those in the babies presented in our series. The findings in McGovern and Goulston (1965) series of fatal cases in adults were similar.

Suid-Afrikaanse Tydskrif vir Chirurgie. Va! 9 Nr. I Januarie-Maart I97J

42                                           J. M. Beck, M. Dinner and J. Chappel

In the babies under discussion histological examination was carried out only in one acute case. In this patient (Case 5) there were, patchy changes throughout the resected specimen with mucosal ulceration and features of haemorrhagic infarction. The histology of the specimen in Case 3 who had a stricture showed mucosal ulceration with surrounding inflammation and fibrosis at the site of the stricture.

It is unlikely that any of the babies had any pre-existing vascular disease, but three of the babies had had two or more exchange transfusions before developing the ischemic colitis.

Some portal venous damage may have been caused by one of the earlier transfusions rendering the bowel more susceptible to effects of hypotension. It may be argued that sensitisation for the development of the Schwartzman reaction is equally likely (Hermann, 1965). Alternatively with the relatively unstable and sensitive cardiovascular system of the newborn, hypotension alone may be sufficiently severe to precipitate ischemic bowel damage, particularly at the junction of superior and inferior mesenteric territories.

Intestinal mucosa is the most sensitive part of the bowel to the. effects of ischemia, and ulceration results Marston (1966). Intestinal motility would be affected next and either spasm or distension might occur, both of which have demonstrably adverse effects on local circulation. Mucosal ulceration allows invasive infection by normal intestinal flora and further necrosis develops (McGovern and Goulston, 1965 and Marston et al., 1966). Possibly the infection is responsible for the intramural and intravenous gas bubbles which can be demonstrated radio-logically and at operation in some, but not all, cases. The larger bacterial content of the terminal ileum and colon is as likely to be the cause of the more frequent involvement of this area of the gastro intestinal tract as any peculiarities of local arterial supply or venous drainage.

SUMMARY

Five cases of entero-colitis occurring after exchange transfusion in jaundiced babies are presented. 7’he features are similar to the transient, stenosing and gangrenous types of ischemic colitis in adults described by Marston. Non-operative management is recommended unless there is evidence of perforation or the patient’s condition shows deterioration while on adequate conservative therapy.

ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS

The authors wish to thank the Superintendents of Johannesburg Genera! Hospital-

Baragwanath Hospital and Coronation Hospital for permission to publish details of patients admitted to these hospitals.

We also thank the staff of the School of Pathology for the pathological examination of the specimens.

Intestinal perforation in as a complication in umbilical vein infusion or exchange transfusion

the newborn infant

H. C. SOMMERSCHILD, M.D.*

UPSALA, SWEDEN

From the Pediatric Surgical Clinic, Akademiska sjukhuset, Upsala University Hospital

I

JL.ntestmal perforation in the newborn is usually due to mechanical obstruction (atresia), traumatic damage (enema) or volvulus with gangrene (malrotation), but spontaneous perforation is not uncommon (necrotizing enteritis).

It seems, however, that spontaneous perforation as a complicating factor in an uneventful exchange transfusion through the umbilical vein in a healthy newborn infant is a new experience.

CASE REPORT

A male infant was born Nov. 22, 1966, to a healthy, primagravida mother. It was a norm^^ delivery five weeks before term. The birth weight was 2,070 grams. There were no complications during the infant’s first three days of life. On the fourth day, an exchan^^t^£®f“donthmughthe umbilical vein was done with no irregularities. During the following 24 hours, the infant developed vomiting and abdominal distention, An x-ray examination of the abdomen revealed pneumoperitoneum, A laparotomy was immediately performed, and generalized peritonitis was found. From the cecum to the splenic flexure, the colon was dilated and gangrenous, as in necrotizing colitis, with three perforations in the transverse colon. From the splenic flexure to the rectosigmoid, the colon appeared normal. The affected part of the colon was resected and an ileostomy was constructed. The. macroscopically normal part of the colon was biopsied, and the oral end was left as a colostomy. However, the patient died on the sixth postoperative day and an autopsy was performed.

Histologic examination. The entire wall of the colon showed stasis, hemorrhage, and infarction. Leukocyte infiltration was marked at the sites of

Accepted for publication Feb. 22, 1971.

^Present address: Pediatric Suigicai Dept,, Rikshospiiakl, Oslo University Hospital, Oslo, Norway.

Fol. 70, Ate. 4, pp. 609-613

perforation; it was marked most on the mucosal side of the wall. Microthrombi could not be identified, not even by Lendrum staining for deposits of fibrin. In the normal part of the colon, there was no evidence of aganglionosis.

Bacteriology. Bacterial cultures from tissue specimens from the heart, lung, spleen, and liver revealed the presence, of Klebsiella and pyocyanea; the interpretation was septicemia.

MATERIAL

We have found 20 more reports of similar cases in the literature.1’215110'13-15 From this total of 21 cases, there are detailed reports regarding 18 (Table I).

Prematurity. At least six patients (30 percent) weighed less than 2,500 grains at birth.

Umbilical vein catheterizations. One patient had an umbilical vein infusion for seven days to treat respiratory distress syndrome. Seven patients had one exchange transfusion, while in ten cases this procedure was repeated one to three times.

Symptoms. In nine patients (50 percent), the abdominal symptoms began within 24 hours following the exchange transfusion. In the other cases, perforation was suspected two to four days after the procedure.

Localization of the perforations. Twelve patients (65 percent) had perforation of the colon. In two other cases, both the colon and the ileum were perforated. Two patients had perforation of the ileum only, and in two cases, the localization was not specified. Nine of the patients (50 percent) showed a single perforation, while the others had a more extensive affection of the intestine.

Operations. Two patients did not undergo

Ocfoter, 1971 SURGERY 609

KIP-53


610 Soirnnerschild

Surgery

October 1971


operation, Resection of the colon with colostomy or colectomy with ileostomy were the most frequent procedures (seven cases, 40 percent). Resection of the colon with primary colo-colo-anastornosis was performed in five cases. Simple suture of the perforation was done three times, and in one case, the treatment was exteriorization of the perforation as a colostomy.

RESULTS

Histologic examination. Reports are available in 13 cases and they are all similar. They show cell infiltration, capillary stasis, and hemorrhages throughout the intestinal wall with necrosis and ulceration. In a number of patients, the changes fulfilled the conditions of necrotizing enteritis, while in others they were localized to the areas of perforation. Microscopic thrombi were found in four patients.5’10’ 15 In two other cases4 (this author’s case), they were investigated despite lack of indication. In the remaining case reports, this phenomenon was not discussed.

Bacteriology. Swabs for bacterial culture were taken from the peritoneal cavity in eight patients. Examination revealed the presence of Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas, Klebsiella, Proteus, and pyocyanea, but without any common pattern.

Mortality rate. The over-all mortality rate was 25 percent. As evident from Table II, there was an overrepresentation among the deaths of low birth weight, multiple perforations, and complicating conditions. There was, on the other hand, no correlation between death and operative procedure, day of life of the exchange transfusion, the number of such procedures, or time elapsed from the exchange, transfusion to the initial signs of perforation. The operations were, in all cases, performed immediately following the perforation.

DISCUSSION

Today we consider the procedure of exchange transfusion through the umbilical vein as an established method of treatment for neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, although

Table I

< 2,500 (premature)

> 2,500

10

9

2

2

Table II

Died: 5 patients or 25% (Details regarding 4)

Survived: 16 patients or 75% (Details regarding 14)

3

2

1

2

0

Ileostomy or colostomy

1

6

1

4

Primary suture of perforation

0

3

Exteriorization of perforation

0

1

we are well aware of the complications as infection, portal thrombosis, and cardiovascular irregularities. The risk of intestinal perforation, however, was not recognized before 1965.5 The reports during the last two years suggest that the occurrence is more frequent than it was formerly assumed to be.

Of the. 21 patients reported as having had intestinal perforation following exchange

Volume 70

Number 4


Intestinal perforation in newborn infant 611

transfusion during tbc first days of life, 16 have survived, giving a survival rate of 75 percent. This survival rate is far bettor than and inconsistent with the 15 percent survival rate given by Nienhuis® in his study of 72 cases of spontaneous colonic perforation of mixed etiology gathered from the literature.

The material presented here does not indicate that the difference in prognosis is caused by diagnostic or therapeutic conditions. The perforations complicating exchange transfusions in the newborn infant consequently arc suggested as having a common, specific etiology, the pathogenesis being primary, microvascular catastrophes.31 '*■ 51 M

So far, the etiologic mechanisms remains unknown although several theories have been proposed. Hermann5 discussed the possibility of an allergic Shwarzman reaction as a response to bacterial toxins. The experimental basis for this is supported by the report of Rapaport and co-workers.12 Our patient fulfilled the criteria for necrotizing colitis and hence the condition could have been based upon a Shwarzman reaction. However, the Lendrum staining of the histopathologic specimens did not in fact reveal the intravascular deposits of fibrin so characteristic for that reaction. Moreover, the fact that seven of the newborn infants had only one exchange transfusion does not support this hypothesis as a predominant factor.

The proposal of Lloyd7 that the diving reflex, if abnormally and locally enforced, may be responsible for spontaneous intestinal perforation in newborn infants does not seem to fit into this particular clinical picture, as all the babies thrived until signs of perforation appeared. Moreover, all the exchange procedures were reported to be unremarkable.

The patients considered here seem to have only one important common denominator, i.e., the exchange transfusion through the umbilical vein. This procedure, however, may be performed in different ways at the different hospitals. It is therefore tempting to suggest that the causal factors may correlate to the type of exchange procedure.

Meyer and Lind' have shown that the ductus venosus closes within a few days after

Fig. 1. The relevant anatomic interrelation showing the umbilical vein entering the left main branch of portal vein. (From Corkery, J. J., Dubowitz, V.j Lister, J., and Mossa, Au Colonic perforation after exchange transfusion, Brit. Med. J. 4: 345, 1968.

birth. As a result of this, the catheter through the umbilical vein finds its way to the desired position in the inferior vena cava in only 20 percent of the procedures. In the other 80 percent the tip of the catheter is found either in the effluent or the affluent branches of the portal vein.13, 36 The diameter of the portal vein in the newborn infant is 2 to 3 mm.8 and the catheters usually arc of 5 to 8 Ch, i.e., 2 to 2j/a mm. With such a catheter in a portal vein branch position in the mesenteric, direction, there exists a real risk of inducing great pressure variations during the procedure, even when done by expert hands. Pressure readings are widely used but are carried out in the static phase of the procedure. In fact, we know very little about the hemodynamic conditions during the exchange transfusion.

The primary damage is probably the change in the microcirculation, such as hemorrhage and thrombosis, because the capillaries in the intestinal wall have an extremely small pressure difference between rupture and collapse.10

The predominance of colonic perforation may indicate, as observed in other diseases,3

612 Sommerschild


Surgery

October 1971

that the colonic wall, above all the mucosa, is more vulnerable to circulatory' catastrophe than are other intestinal segments.

Some experiments may indicate -that the venous return from the intestine must be obstructed for at least 18 hours in order to cause macroscopic infarction of the intestinal wall,1 This finding, however, does not reveal anything about possible micro circulatory changes following obstruction of shorter duration. Moreover, variations of pressure and flow have not been induced in these experiments.

In the mechanical theory presented here, there are no mechanisms involved affecting the regulation of the systemic circulation. This may well explain the often observed localized affections of the intestinal wall which, in turn, may be the cause for the encouraging prognosis for these patients.

SUMMARY

The complication of intestinal perforation in exchange transfusion in newborn infants has been brought to our attention during the last two to three years.

Twenty case report's are traced and one more presented.

The survival rate is 75 percent in contrast to the 15 percent rate which occurred in spontaneous perforations of mixed etiology'.

Analysis of the 21 cases gives no evidence that the difference in the prognosis is caused by' diagnostic or therapeutic conditions. These patients, therefore, are suggested to have a common etiology.

Mechanical circumstances in the exchange procedure may' create the risk of great pressure variations in the microcirculation in the intestinal wall. The capillaries, particularly' those in the colonic mucosa, are very sensitive to such variations. Hemorrhage and/or thrombosis may therefore be the result of these variations, leading to the development of necrosis and perforation.

The author wants to thank Dr. Arne Bjorkheim, Department of Pathology, Rikshospitalet, Oslo University Hospital, for the histopathologic examination and interpretation of the biopsy and autopsy specimens and also Johan Ek, M.D., of the pediatric department, Rikshospitalet, Oslo University Hospital, who gave me information about the patient.

ADDENDUM

After submitting the manuscript, I have seen, in the Pediatric Department, Rikshospitalet, Oslo University Hospital, another particular patient with case history and symptoms relevant to the problem discussed.

The fourth child of healthy parents was de-1 vered four weeks before term with no perinatal p roblems other than hyperbilirubinemia. The mother was typed Rh negative and the father was Rh positive.

The first exchange transfusion was given immediately after birth; the second was given at 40 hours post partum; and the third was administered during the third day of life. The exchange transfusions were performed at different hospitals, but were all reported to be uneventful. Following the second exchange transfusion, the baby vomited once, the abdomen became distended, and some fresh, coagulated blood was discharged per anum. The general condition deteriorated. Intestinal perforation was suspected, and the patient was referred to the pediatric clinic, Rikshospitalet, Oslo, where the third exchange transfusion was performed. There was some fresh blood from the anus the first two days. X-ray investigation revealed slight evidence of paralytic ileus, but no free air in the peritoneum. Symptoms of peritonitis never developed. The baby made a rapid recovery and was referred to the parents 16 days post partum; the patient was symptomless and thriving.

Indeed, this may have been an actual perforation, immediately and spontaneously sealed, not giving cause to peritonitis. The main symptoms, however, were the melena and the distended abdomen following the administration of an exchange transfusion. It is assumed that this particular case represents the situation in which the damage to the intestinal wall is restricted to the mucosa, leaving the muscular and serosal layers intact. The patient therefore illustrates the first step in a pathogenetic, sequence which eventually leads to frank perforation. The demonstration of this first step seems extremely rare and has never before been reported. It strongly supports the pathogenetic theory proposed.

Erythroderma and Erythroblastosis Fetalis

To the Editor.—The appearance of a rash during the course of therapy tor neonatal hyperbilirubinemia has Been recognized.1,3 The first report associated a macular erythematous rush tothe use of phototherapy for the reduction of serum bilirubin. The second report noted the occurrence of a macular erythematous rash as a possible complication following intensive transfusion therapy for severe hemolytic disease of the newborn. No other references relating hyperbilirubinemia and a macular erythroderma could be found in the available literature. This com-munication further documents our clinical observations of this peculiar skin reaction in four severely affected erytTroblastolic infants, none of which were exposed to bilirubin reduction lamps.

Report of Cases.—Case 1.—A 1.9-kg (4 lb 2 oz) male infant was delivered spontaneously at 33 weeks gestation. He had received three intrauterine transfusions beginning at 28 weeks gestation. The total cord bilirubin value was 4.6 mg/100 ml, and the cord Coombs test was 2+ reactive. The total bilirubin value peaked at 14.0 mg/100 ml at 48 hours, and the direct reacting bilirubin peaked at 2.6 mg/100 ml on the tenth day. One exchange transfusion was required on the first day. A generalized macular erythematous rash appeared on the third day and was gone by the fifth day.

Case 2.—A 2.3-kg (5 lb 2 oz) moderately hydropic male infant was delivered by cesarean section at 36 weeks gestation. He had received four intrauterine transfusions beginning at 28 weeks of gestation. The total cord bilirubin value was 4.8 mg/100 ml, and the cord Coombs test was 2 + reactive. The I total bilirubin and direct reacting bilirubin values peaked at 22.1 mg/100 ml and 14.5 mg/100 ml, respectively, at 84 hours. Two exchange transfusions were required, the first at 3 hours and the second at 70 hours of life. A generalized macular rash appeared on the third day and cleared by the fifth day. Maternal and infant titers for cytomegalovirus, rubella, and toxoplasmosis were negative.

Case 3.—A 2.3-kg (5 lb 1 oz) hydropic female infant was delivered following induction of labor at 38 weeks gestation. No fetal transfusions had been performed. The total cord bilirubin value was 5.2 mg/100 ml, and the eord Coombs test was 4-f- reactive. The total and direct reacting bilirubin values peaked at 20.2 mg/100 ml and 12.4 mg/100 ml, respectively, at 96 hours of : life. An exchange transfusion was per- |

KRS-43 formed on the first and fourth day of life. A generalized macular erythematous rash appeared on the third day and cleared by the fourth day.

Case 4.—A 2.0-kg (4 ib 8 oz) moderately hydrop’c female infant was delivered following induction of labor at 35 weeks of gestation. No fetal transfusions had been performed. The total cord bilirubin value was 10.0 mg/100 ml, and the cord Coombs test was 3+ reactive. The total bilirubin value peaked at 36.5 mg/100 ml on the fifth day. The direct reacting bilirubin fraction rose to a peak of 13.9 mg/100 m! on the seventh day. A total of nine exchange transfusions was required throughout the first four days of life to control the persistently rising levels of unconjugated bilirubin. On the third day a generalized macular rash appeared and lasted until the fifth day.


Comment.—Four severely affected Rh-isoimmunized infants have been described wherein a generalized macular erythroderma developed following intensive transfusion therapy. The rash occurred on the third day and cleared by the fifth day in all four patients. It was faint, evanescent, and varied in intensity from time to time during its 24 to 48 hours of existence. The maculae were 2 to 4 mm in diameter, blanched easily with pressure, and at times appeared circinate. In the first report’ a very similar rash occurred in moderately-to-severely jaundiced infants undergoing phototherapy for bilirubin reduction, but the etiology of the hyperbilirubinemia was not indicated. None of our patients received phototherapy at any time. The rash was noted to co-incide with a plateau in the rise of bilirubin levels seen in both our patients and those previously reported. Giunta' proposed that the rash resulted from the rapid pooling of pig-ment~or breakdown products of the photochemical reaction of light and bilirubin in the skin. This would imply atoxic feature of the photo-oxiHTzccrproducts, butto date photo-tH.erap y.Ras not Been related to any specific toxic tissue effects of either the light itself or the breakdown products?4

CDR J. E. Schanberger, NIC, USN LCUR M. D. Cunningham, MC, USN ECDR J, w. Mace. MC, USN San Diego. Cali I

Hans G. Keitel, MJJ.

Jefferson Medical College of Philadelphia

Hans G. Keitel is Professor and Head of the Department of Pediatrics at Jefferson Medical College of Philadelphia. After graduation from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, he served successively as Instructor of Pediatrics at New York University, as Clinical Assistant and Research Fellow in Pediatrics at Harvard Medical School, and as Assistant Clinical Professor of Pediatrics at Georgetown University. This is Doctor Keitel’s fifth article in CONSULTANT.

OUR CARE OF NEWBORN INFANTS IS OFTEN NOT GOOD ENOUGH

We should not be smug about the medical care given to newborns; infant mortality in the U.S, is higher, than it is in many advanced nation^. Infant mortality in Sweden, for instance, is only 60% of that in the U.S.; in the Netherlands, only 63%. Granted, care given in certain American hospitals is very good indeed, but nationwide we have nothing to brag about.

However, it is quite likely that poor neonatal care is not solely responsible for our higher infant mortality. There are many reasons for it, and socioeconomic causes may well be more important than medical ones. But we should try in every way to reduce infant mortality, and better neonatal care is one of those ways. Certainly we must guard against the natural tendency to accept old practices as being good enough. They have to be improved.

Routine Gare in the Delivery Room Nasal, Esophageal, and Gastric Catheterization, In my opinion, subjecting all normal newborns to nasal, esophageal, or gastric catheterization is more hazardous than performing these procedures only when choanal obstruction or a tracheo-esophageal fistula is suspected. To exclude choanal obstruction, cover the baby's mouth and then separately block each nostril. Only if air does not pass through one or both nares need you pass a catheter to determine whether thick mucus or a true anatomical obstruction accounts for the blockage. Even then, be cautious about diagnosing an obstruction based on catheterization; the canal may be too narrow to admit any but the smallest

The American Academy of Pcdiairics has recently revised its "Standard and Recommends-

tions for Hospital Care of Newborn Infants" {May, 1964). Those who assume responsibility

for newborns should review this carefully.

20

CONSULTANT is published by Smith Kline & French Laboratories ten times a year. Authors are chosen because of expert knowledge of their topics, and their participation does not imply endorsement of any of the products advertised. As a service to readers the authors will answer questions pertaining to their topics. Copyright © 1965, Smith Kline & French Laboratories. Printed in U.S.A.

catheter yet may permit air to pass freely.

Nor do I believe that the benefits of gastric aspiration justify routine gastric intubation, as some have recommended. Recent data do not confirm that gastric aspiration influences the clinical course of the respiratory distress syndrome; moreover, gastric intubation may rarely cause gastric perforation. Naso-esophageal intubation with even a soft, blunt-ended catheter may cause hematomas Of the turbinates or the posterior pharyngeal wall, esophageal perforation and laryngeal or tracheal irritation, which may be associated with edema and infection. I, therefore, prefer to reserve intubation for those cases which show clinical symptoms, even though these are minimal. When an infant shows signs of respiratory distress, excessive mucus or other evidence of tracheo-esophageal fistula, the patency of his esophagus must be checked immediately.

Preventing Gonorrheal Ophthalmia. Recent studies have again demonstrated the value of instilling silver nitrate in the infant’s eyes, as required by law. However, it does not protect every infant, so always take a smear if purulent conjunctivitis develops. Whether gonorrheal ophthalmia occurs in infants who are given silver nitrate prophylaxis because we use a "modified” Grade method cannot be determined. Crede’s original method called for the use of 2% silver nitrate (not 1%) and did not include immediate flushing of the eyes with a salt solution.

Giving Vitamin K Routinely. Some have questioned the need for and the safety of giving vitamin K to all newborns. In our clinic, controlled studies in premature infants have shown that a single dose of mg. of vitamin Ki (KonakionJ given either orally or intramuscularly increases survival significantly. Repeated doses, however, serve no purpose; in fact, when given parenterally they increase the risk of complications. Male full-term infants who are given vitamin Ki bleed less following circumcision. The administration of vitamin K (rather than Kx) is potentially hazardous since it may lead to hyperbilirubinemia.

Umbilical Cord Ligature. Since we began using rubber tubing for umbilical cord ligature in our clinic, only one of thousands of infants has had umbilical cord hemorrhage because the ligature slipped. Previously, when we used linen cord ligatures, several dozen infants developed severe umbilical cord hemorrhage. In some this was severe enough to cause hypovolemic shock. The hemorrhage was usually attributed to hemorrhagic disease of the newborn because the prothrombin time was prolonged. Yet, because in each case the ligature had slipped, we now believe that failure of the umbilical cord blood vessels to contract was the real problem. [Prothrombin time is prolonged in many otherwise-normal newborns.)

Based on our experience, we do not recommend leaving a long section of cord; pustules often form under the cord (see Figure). Nor can we recommend metal clamps because cellulitis often forms at the base of the cord. The rubber cord ligature method is superior to all others we have tried.

Routine Nursery Care

Feeding. Formulas varying as much as 200% in protein, vitamin, and mineral content can be used safely for most newborn infants, but bear

in mind these four precautions. Avoid: (1) formulas high in chlorides, which can cause hyperchloremic acidosis; (2) formulas high in vitamin D, which predispose infants to hypercalcemia; (3) formulas high in protein, which are associated with a higher mortality rate in immature infants as well as a higher incidence of allergy and an increased need to excrete urinary solutes; and (4) formulas high in phosphorus, which predispose to neonatal tetany. ■

Usually the first feeding, six to nine hours after birth, is a 5% sugar solution. Some doctors are convinced 'that an early feeding of sugar [or saline) benefits the newborn, but ■ ■ there is little published evidence to .-support their view except for one study of babies of diabetic mothers. In our clinic, we have evaluated concentrated formulas containing 34 rather than 20 calories per ounce for feeding premature infants. We have found that their use safely accelerates growth. The accelerated growth, however, does not exceed the physiologic rate, that is, the growth rate of the fetus in the uterus.

Many physicians were reluctant to use glucose and bicarbonate solutions for combating the respiratory distress syndrome until Doctor Robert Usher

of McGill University reported that this therapy, carefully timed and controlled, helped control acidosis and hyperkalemia, and thereby increased survival rates. However, very accurate biochemical studies are required to use the Usher regimen safely.

Venipuncture Techniques. Using any deep vein for obtaining blood carries a small but definite risk of major morbidity and mortality. Therefore, blood should be procured from a superficial vein, either the antecubital or external jugular vein, or from a capillary stab. Even from a premature baby weighing only 1 or 2 Kg., you can obtain 5 to 10 ml. of blood from a superficial vein. Do the venipuncture using a good light and a #21 or 22 needle with a trace of heparin on the barrel of the syringe.

Rapidly Fatal Infection

Premature Rupture of the Membranes.' Premature rupture threatens the fetus with infection that may be fatal even before the infant is born. There may be no time to culture the infecting organism from the infant before giving antimicrobial drugs. Nevertheless, it is possible to get circumstantial evidence of presence of a bacterial pathogen by obtaining a culture of the mother's cervix. If you find hemolytic streptococcus, enterococcus or pneumococcus, start penicillin therapy immediately. This should be given to the mother in large doses if the baby is unborn, and to the baby if already delivered. However, if any signs of infection (even though minimal) are present, antimicrobial therapy should be used to include at least the organisms obtained via cervical culture. Antimicrobial drugs are potentially harmful to the fetus and should be used as specifically and rationally as possible.

Choice of Antimicrobial’ Drug for Neonatal Infections. Therapy must begin promptly when you see any signs of infection such as unexplained fever, jaundice, apathy, or vomiting. For many years, many have given combinations of antibiotics such as chloramphenicol plus penicillin or streptomycin plus penicillin. Currently, I give the infant penicillin and two or three doses of kanamycin at 12-hour intervals, each dose exactly 716 mg. per Kg. of body weight in a sufficiently dilute solution to minimize the danger of inadvertent over- or underdosage. (A dilute form of kanamycin for infant use will soon become available commercially.)

Why kanamycin? First, it kills most bacteria that cause serious infection in the newborn, including almost all strains of E. coli, as well as many strains of Staphylococci, Streptococci, and most strains of Pneumococci. Gram-negative bacteria such as E. coli now cause 60% or more of serious neonatal infections and the majority of strains have become resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline.

Second, although there is evidence that kanamycin is toxic when given in high doses over long periods, I believe it is safe as a stopgap antibiotic for treating possible neonatal sepsis. Two or three doses give an adequate blood level for 24 to 36 hours; by this time, one usually has the results of blood, urine, or spinal fluid cultures. If E. coli are recovered, kanamycin can be continued until sensitivity studies show that a less toxic drug is effective. If pneumococci or hemolytic streptococci are recovered, the penicillin should be continued and the kanamycin discontinued.

The two-to-three-dose kanamycin-penicillin regimen is adequate prophylaxis against suspected infection. However, when infection is probable, we add Staphcillin for penicillinaseproducing staphylococci and tetracycline for Listeria. Since tetracycline (particularly the demethylchlor-ana-log) has reportedly caused dental staining, I recommend using oxytetracycline. This form of tetracycline has not been reported to cause cosmetically disfiguring dental staining. If Pseudomonas is a possible infecting organism, the use of colistin should be considered.

Abnormalities in Older Children and Adults May Be Normal in Newborns

For several years, some have advocated establishing neonatology as a subspecialty of pediatrics. (There are cogent reasons for labeling it perinatology.) Many of the clinical signs and laboratory findings in newborns are quite different than at any other time in the life of man. For example, during the first two to four days, the majority of newborn infants develop one or more petechia, toxic erythema, and jaundice. In the first week, the majority of babies vomit once or twice (rarely is vomitus bile stained). Five percent of normal newborns do not void or pass meconium during the first 48 hours.

Unusual Blood Values. The following laboratory findings are found in normal newborn babies;

WBC .............as high as 25,000 mm.3

Serum phosphorus . .as high as 9 mg. % Blood sugar ........as low as 30 mg. %

Serum calcium .....as low as fl mg. %

Hemoglobin ........from 15 to 23 gram %

The urine of normal newborns may contain red blood cells and a considerable amount of protein. These are

24


but a few of the unusual laboratory findings in the neonatal period.

Exchange Transfusions for Newborns with Hyperbilirubinemia. All newborn babies develop jaundice if adult bilirubin concentrations are used as the criterion. Most of tfopge whose bilirubin concentrations gxggpd ZP mg. % reach this level between ths third and fifth day after birth, then-fall spontaneously. Not all recent datTcompIetely'support the earlier1 recommendation that an exchange transfusion be performed whenever the indirect bilirubin concentration exceeds 20 mg. % during the first week of life. Before deciding to perform an exchange, consider twp facts' first, the mortality from exchange transfusions ranges from 1 to 10% ; second, bilirubin concentrations under

25 mg. ^causeTraindamage incn.ty a very small percent" of infants —

some estimate less "than 0.1%. ~ "

The Challenge

During the past few years, infant f mortality has remained about the { same in the U.S. One might conclude I from this apparent lack of progress I that we are approaching an irreducible minimal level. However, a grow- I ing number of nations have reduced their infant mortality rates well below ours. What a tragedy for the U.S, to become a nation of second rank in this regard. Whether socioeconomic j reasons alone account for this differ- ' ence remains to be determined, but ■ even if they do, physicians should work to correct them.

KEITH HAMMOND, M.D., Associate Editor

PITFALLS IN NEONATOLOGY              210

349. Failing to appreciate fully the risks of exchange transfusion.

Zl          The basic question which must be raised is whether

or not the risk of death due to the exchange (1 to 2 per cent) outweighs the small risk of brain damage (manifested at most by mild deafness) in asymptomatic patients who have bilirubin values under 25 (? 80) mg. per 100 ml. (See pitfall number 234.’) The /'routine performance of an exchange if the bilirubin level rises to or approaches 20 mg. per 100 ml. in the first week of life is most unfortunate. We must have the fortitude to tell parents the whole truth and to inform them of the uncertainties and the risks. Many believe that it is far better to have a live child who has only a small chance of brain damage (if the bilirubin level does not rise over 25 mg. per 100 ml. for less than a day in the first week of life) than to risk the chances of a fatality.

Cj

587


The implications of this work are clear. (1) need better ground rules for exchange transfusion in healthy jaundiced prematures, (d) If your batting average when exchanging prematures isn t pretty good, perhaps you should think twice before interfering at 26.1 mg.% of bilirubin. (3) These authors dont deny kernicterus in prematures; they just didn’t see it often in this (small) series.

6 6 U ncomplicated” Hyperbilirubinemia of Prematurity

The Lack of Association with Neurologic Deficit at 3 Years of Age

JACK C. SHILLER, M.D.

AND

WILLIAM A. SILVERMAN, M.D.

NEW YORK

The role that bilirubin plays in brain damage associated with prematurity has not been completely defined. The hazards in these infants of hyperbilirubinemia in association with isoimmunization and excessive

Accepted for publication Oct. 6, 1960.

20 Bay St., Westport, Conn.

Aided by a grant from the U.S. Public Health Service R.G. B-I067.

From Babies Hospital, Presbyterian Hospital, and the Department of Pediatrics, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. amounts of vitamin K analogue,1 are well known; it has also been shown that when sulfisoxazole 2 is given to jaundiced premature infants, a significant proportion die with kernicterus. However, the magnitude of the risk of hyperbilirubinemia in the absence of these known complicating factors has not been established.

Meyer3 and Crosse et al.4 stated that hyperbilirubinemia is harmful to the newborn premature infant, and suggested that 18 mg/100 ml be considered the “critical” concentration of bilirubin in the blood, above which brain damage is likely to occur. Corner,5 Dundon,6 and Newns et al.T agreed in principle but believed that the critical concenti ation is higher. Another group8 found a correlation between increasing concentrations of bilirubin in the blood of newborn premature infants and decreasing levels of gross motor development at one year of age. This correlation appeared to be more striking in boys than in girls.

. Holman,9 Rapmund et al.,10 and Mores 11 have presented data which cast some doubt on these views. The latter authors questioned the advisability of routinely' performing exchange transfusions on all premature infants in whom the concentration of bilirubin in the serum exceeds 18 to 20 mg. ■ per 100 ml.

The purpose of the present study was to evaluate the association between neurologic status at 3 years of age, and the maximal serum concentration of bilirubin in newborn premature infants who had not been exposed to influences (already discussed) which have been shown to affect the incidence of kernicterus. We also wished to learn whether brain damage in expremature children resembled the clinical kernicterus which has been observed in children who survived erythroblastosis fetalis.                                                 .

Subjects and Methods

Tn the premature nursery of the Babies Hospital during a 22-month period in calendar years 195a and 19o6, the highest con-

588


AMERICAN JOURNAL OF DISEASES'


Pram of uro Infont Population /BO

3 Voor-old Children Exam mad HO

FATE OF REMAINDER 7 e

Fig. 1.—The fate of 78 infants whose degree of neonatal bilirubinemia was studied, but who were not able to be examined at 3 years of age.


centrations of bilirubin in the serums of 188 newborn premature infants were determined by daily measurements during their first week of life.

Eliminated from the study were ail infants who had a birth weight greater than 2.000 gm,, who were more than 72 hours old on admission, who did not survive 48 hours, or who had a positive Coombs’ test. None of the infants received sulfisoxazole in the neonatal period.

Venous blood was obtained daily from each infant until the concentration of bilirubin in the serum had begun to fall. Determinations were performed by a modification of the method of Malloy and Evelyn.12 Bilirubin concentrations reported in this paper are expressed as total bilirubin, since in no instance was there a significant elevation of the concentration of direct-reacting bilirubin. Further technical details may be found in a previous paper.10

At 3 years of age, these children were examined by a pediatrician, neurologists, a psychologist, speech and hearing therapists, and a dentist. All of the follow-up studies were conducted ‘'blindly,” i.e., the examiners had no knowledge of each infant’s previous history or the concentration of bilirubin in the serum during the first week of life.

Only the results of the neurologic and psychometric evaluations will be included in this report. The neurologists sought evidence of brain damage in any form, but especially rigidity, chorcoathetosis. and deafness. The Stanford-Binet test ■was used for psychometric evaluation.

Fig. 5.—The neurologic status of "compatible” children, by maximal concentrations of bilirubin in the serum.


neonatal infection, high or low gestational age, race, sex, and birth weight. None of these factors was found to significantly influence the final result.

Of 188 infants who were studied in the neonatal period, 110 were available for examination at 3 years of age. The fate of the remainder is illustrated in Figure 1. One patient was treated with exchange transfusion because erythroblastosis fetalis could not be excluded as a cause of hyperbilirubinemia. The distribution of maximal concentrations of bilirubin in the serums of 31 survivors who were lost to follow-up was comparable to that of the general study population. This was also true of 11 babies who died and were not examined post mortem.

Figure 2 shows the distribution of cases examined at autopsy by maximal concentration of bilirubin in the serum. In 5 of 35 cases (14.3%) the maximal concentrations of bilirubin exceeded 18 mg/100 ml of serum. The only infant who died of kernicterus (proved at autopsy) had a maximal concentration of bilirubin of 12 mg/100 ml of serum on the third day of life; death occurred on the fifth day of life.

Data on infants compatible with their mothers with respect to ABO and Rh antigens are shown in Figure 3 distributed according to the maximal concentration of
