bilirubin in the serum. Figure 4 shows the distribution of data of “incompatible” infants by maximal concentrations of bilirubin in the serum. Direct Coombs’ tests were performed on the blood of all infants; all were negative.

Figures 5-8 present the neurologic and mental status of children examined at 3 years of age by maximal concentrations of bilirubin in the serum. As can be seen, the diagnoses of brain damage and mental re

AMERICAN JOt’RXAL (.)/• I>1:<!■.. ISES or CHI LIO RI LX


tardation were made in many of the children examined at 3 years of age; results on these damaged children appeared to be distributed at random with respect to the degree of neonatal bilirubinemia.

Two children could not be adequately examined by the neurologists. The maximal concentrations of bilirubin in the plasma of these children were 6.6 and 18.2 mg/100 ml of serum; data on these children are omitted in Figures 5-8. A fairly high proportion of children could not be adequately examined by the psychologist; these intractable children had maximal concentrations of bilirubin in their serum comparable to the general study population (Figs. 7-9).

In Figure 9 the children whose bilirubin concentrations never exceeded 18 mg. per 100 ml. are compared with children whose neonatal concentrations did rise above this value. The observed differences in the proportions of definitely and of suspiciously damaged children in the “high” bilirubin and “low” bilirubin categories were not greater than would reasonably be expected to occur simply as the result of normal sampling variation.


Fig. 9.—Neurologic and mental status of 3-year-old children in relation to the "critical” concentration of bilirubin in the serum (18 mg. per 100 ml.). The observed numbers of children in each category are given in each of these figures. Next to each figure the lower and upper- true value estimates (95% confidence interval)'13 of the proportions of children classified as definitely damaged are indicated by solid-line brackets; the 95% confidence limits for the proportions of children classified as suspiciously damaged are indicated by broken-line brackets. and />’, neurologic stains C and D, mental status.

Vol. 101, May, 1061

; ■J TERBI LIR I; BIN EMI A                                                          591

No case of definite loss of perceptive hearing was found in any of the study patients. In the 9 patients diagnosed by the neurologists as definitely damaged, strabismus and palsy of extraocular muscles were most frequently observed. Spastic paraplegia was found in 1 case; quadri-plegia was found in 2 cases. The remaining damaged patients demonstrated hypotonia, mental retardation, disorders of behavior and speech, and “nonspecific” signs of brain damage.

Comment

The present study fails to demonstrate a significant correlation between uncomplicated hyperbilirubinemia in premature infants and neurologic deficit at 3 years of age. Damaged children were found to have had varying degrees of bilirubinemia in the neonatal period, and the differences which were observed in the groups with high and with low maximal concentrations of bilirubin in the serum could easily be explained on the basis of sampling variation alone.

The type of neurologic deficit noted in the damaged children in the present study does not resemble the classical picture of kernicterus residua described by Gerrard14 and by Evans and Polani.15 The most frequent findings described by the latter authors were opisthotonos, choreoathetosis, convulsions, muscular rigidity, ataxia, and hypotonia or atonic diplegia.

In this connection it is of some interest to recount the findings of Churchill16 in a recent study of a group of brain damaged children. He observed a close correlation between “simple spastic diplegia” (corticospinal and pyramidal tracts) and low birth weight or low gestational age. However, he found no significant correlation between “complex diplegia” (athetosis and extrapyramidal tract signs) and low birth weight or low gestational age.

We believe that the results of the present study suggest that premature infants may be able to tolerate moderately high concentrations of bilirubin in the serum when this

SJii/fer—Sihrrinan

state is not complicated by erythroblastosis fetalis, excessive doses of vitamin K, or the administration of sulfisoxazole. Since it is possible that the concentration of bilirubin in the serum is only one of a number of factors which influence the penetration of this pigment into the brain, we wish to question whether the same criteria and treatment that are used for hyperbilirubinemia caused by erythroblastosis fetalis should be applied to uncomplicated hyperbilirubinemia of prematurity.

It should be emphasized that the evidence gathered in the present study did not result from experiment but rather from experience. The infants were “found” to have high or to have low concentrations of bilirubin in the serum; they were not allocated to these categories according to an experimental plan. Data from this and other similar observational studies can be used only to seek hypotheses. Proof of these hypotheses can be obtained only by carefully designed clinical trials. For example, Forfar et al.17 have undertaken a small trial (using concurrent controls) of the influence of exchange transfusion in the management of uncomplicated hyperbilirubinemia of prematurity. When the results of this and other experimental studies are known, answers may be available to the questions which have arisen from our experience.

Conclusions

We reported on 110 expremature children who were examined at 3 years of age. Approximately one-fifth of these children exhibited signs that were interpreted as either suspicious or definite evidence of brain damage or mental retardation.

Although approximately one-fourth of the children had uncomplicated hyperbilirubinemia (maximal concentrations between 18 and 22 mg. per 100 ml.) in the neonatal period, there was no apparent association between hyperbilirubinemia and neurologic deficit or mental retardation. Moreover, none of the children exhibited signs which were suggestive of kernicterus residua.

592


AMERICAN JOURNAL OF DISEASES OF CHILDREN

January, 1970

1 2 The Journal of PEDIATRICS

Studies in kernicterus

III. The saturation of serum proteins with bilirubin during neonatal life and its relationship to brain damage at five years

Psychometric studies were performed on a group of 5-year-old children who had been jaundiced during neonatal life. On the basis of the test results, 14 children were considered normal and 19 were classified as having brain damage. The presence or absence of brain damage was compared with clinical and laboratory determinations that had been made on the children during their period of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia. No significant correlations were found between the presence or absence of brain damage and the maximum bilirubin concentration, birth weight, sex, presence or absence of hemolytic disease, or the use of exchange transfusion. A significant correlation was found between the presence or absence of brain damage and the saturation of the serum proteins with bilirubin during infancy.

Gerard B. Odell, M.D., G. N. Bruce Storey, M.D., and Leon A. Rosenberg, Ph.D.

BALTIMORE, MD.

A causal relationship between hyperbilirubinemia during neonatal life and kernicterus in infants is well established and has been reproduced in many animal species.1'7 Ghorcoathetosis, asymmetrical spasticity, and sensorineural hearing impairment are the most commonly described sequelae in infants who survive neonatal kemictcrus.8'12 A few studies have reported a reduction of

From the Department of Pediatrics of the

Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and the Harriet Lane Service of the Children’s Medical and Surgical Center of The Johns Hopkins Hospital.

Supported in part by United States Public Health Service Grants, No. AM 07156 from the National Institute of Arthritic and Metabolism, and Nos. HD 02268 and HD 00091 from the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. the intelligence quotient as a manifestation of bilirubin encephalopathy, but others have not found such abnormalities in the absence of cerebral palsy.13'19 However, the pathology of kernicterus indicates that other cranial nuclei are affected in addition to the basal ganglia.20'22 Injury to many of these nuclei, particularly the hippocampus, may affect learning, memory, and adaptive behavior.23'2S Impairment of perceptual (interpretative) functioning may result without necessarily producing cerebral palsy or reducing the intelligence quotient (I.Q.) to subnormal levels.2®

Many of the published studies have depended upon disturbances of either sensory or motor performance in early infancy as criteria of central nervous system injury due

Volume 76 Number I


Studies in kernicicrtis. Ill 1 3

to bilirubin.27"31 Since cognitive functions of the brain cannot be adequately tested in infancy, abnormalities of memory, learning, and adaptive behavior can be determined only at later ages.

The purpose of the present study was to re-examine by comprehensive psychometric tests a group of children of 4 to 7 years of age who had been jaundiced during neonatal life. The results of the psychometric tests were correlated to a number of observations that had been made on the children during their period of neonatal jaundice. The results demonstrate a correlation between brain damage and the degree to which the serum proteins were saturated with bilirubin during the period of hyperbilirubinemia.

MATERIALS AND METHODS

The 32 children reported in this study were between the ages of 4 and 7 years and had been patients on the nursery services of The Johns Hopkins Hospital. These children were from families which still resided in the Baltimore area and could be located. None of the families who were located refused to have their children examined. The 32 children represented only a third of the total population on whom studies were performed during neonatal life. The other families ' could not be traced.

Although all had been jaundiced, only 24 Had "been treated . by exchange transfusion. None had physical signs of classical kernicterus (opisthotonus, shrill cry, or absent Moro lenex). Hemolytic disease due to a fetal-maternal blood group incompatibility was established as the cause of jaundice in 16 of the children, 8 due to Rh and 8 due to ABO isoimmunization. In addition to ‘serial measurements of serum bilirubin and total protein concentrations, the saturation index of the serum proteins with bilirubin was determined by the salicylate displacement technique. The methodologies for these analyses of sera have been previously described by this laboratory;-'2 The saturation indices in the present report are the values of either pre-exchange sera in the transfused infants or the value obtained on the serum sample with the highest bilirubin concentration in the nonexchanged infants, except where noted in the tables.

When the children were 4 to 7 years of age, a complete medical history was obtained and a physical examination was performed. Abnormal neurologic signs were confirmed by a pediatric neurologist (Dr. William McLean). All the children were then examined by the same psychologist, who was unaware of the child’s medical history apart from the history- of jaundice.

The psychometric tests performed for evaluation of cognitive functioning were as follows: (I) Intelligence quotient was measured by the Stanford-Binet test for those children who were less than 5 years of age, and the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children for those 5 and over; (2) visualmotor coordination was assessed by the Bender Visual-Motor Gestalt test and the Sequin Form Board; (3) short-term memory and resistance to distraction were evaluated by the Children’s Embedded Figures test and Reitan’s Trail Making test adapted for children.

Two “scores” were determined for each subject: (1) the measured I.Q.; and (2) the designation “abnormal” or “normal” with reference to the presence or absence of cognitive dysfunction. The latter measure of brain damage involved the psychologist’s over-all impression of the test data.

The most characteristic results from the test protocols which led to a designation of “abnormal” cognitive functioning were as follows:

  • 1. Difficulties in visual-motor coordination were evidenced by slow, inaccurate, and “clumsy” performances on the Sequin Form Board. Disturbances on the Bender-Gestalt test were noted by distortion or loss of the shape of the designs, sketchy and tumulous lines, rotations, and a tendency toward perseveration.

  • 2. Dchciences in short-term memory tasks were found in “coding” .on the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children, digit-span, ’ and pictme-mvinory items on the Stanford-

    1 4 Odell, Stony, and Rosenberg


    The Journal of Pediatrics January 197.)



    Binet, and the type of learning required by Reitan’s Trail Making test.

    • 3. Inability for abstract reasoning appropriate for age was measured by the “similarities” subtest of the Wechsler and similar items in the Stanford-Binet tests.

    • 4. Evidence of distractibility to a degree greater than expected for the age of the child was demonstrable during the Children’s Embedded Figures and Reitan’s Trail Making tests, as well as by the child’s behavior during the entire testing period. Additional behavioral findings closely related to the de


    gree of distractibility were hyperactivity and short attention span.

    The relationship between cognitive dysfunction and the obtained I.Q. score is complex. The more seriously damaged children have both low I.Q. and many of the abnormalities described in the tests above; the less damaged children may have I.Q. scores -within the normal range but the same “organic” signs of brain damage in the tests for cognitive functioning.

RESULTS

The pertinent data about the 32 patients are summarized in Tables I and II. The 18 children listed in Table I are those wlw> had evidence of brain damage in the results of their psychometric, tests. The 14 children of Table II had normal performances on the psychometric tests.                         ■ •

The median value for the maximum scrum bilirubin concentration of the entire group of 32 children was 19 mg. per 100 ml. For chi square analyses, the patients were divided into two groups: those with serum bilirubin values less than 19 mg. per 100 ml., and those with concentrations of 19 mg. per 100 ml. or greater. The second variable was the I.Q. result: Scores below 80 were considered to be abnormal, and values of 80 or more were considered as being in the dull normal and better categories.33 Five additional analyses were performed using the maximum concentrations of bilirubin, 20, 21,

22, 23, and 24. In each of these 6 chi square analyses, no statistically significant relationship was found (p > 0.05). Similar analyses were performed by employing the same 6 maximum concentrations of the serum bilirubin and comparing them with the results of the psychometric tests, of which the presence or absence of brain damage was used as the second variable. No significant relationship between the maximum bilirubin concentration during neonatal life and brain damage at 5 years was found.

The presence of brain damage was then tested for a correlation with the degree to which the serum was saturated with bilirubin during neonatal life. The children were divided into the groups as listed in Tables I and II, and the results of the psychometric tests of cognitive functions were compared with the saturation indices of Table III. tuted for the results of the psychometric tests, no significant correlation with the saturation index was found.

The results in Table III indicate that 16 of the 18 damaged children had had a saturation index which equalled or exceeded 8.0. The 2 brain-damaged children with saturation indices Jess than 8.0 are Patients 2 and 20 of Table I. Patient 20 was born spontaneously at home and required repeated epinephrine injections because of apnea and bradycardia for the first 48 hours of life. Thus hypoxic injury related to her cardiorespiratory' distress rather than the hyperbilirubinemia. may have been responsible for the cerebral injury. Patient 2 had an ABO incompatibility; the saturation index was done when the total bilirubin value was 15 mg. per 100 mi. The bilirubin concentration subsequently rose to 18 mg. per 100 ml., at which time the saturation index might have exceeded 8.0.

Tables II and III indicate that 5 (Patients 3, 4, 16, 30, and 37) of the 14 children with normal psychometric test results had saturation indices which exceeded 8. Patient 30 was treated by exchange transfusion, the first of which was initiated at 30 minutes of age, and subsequently' repeated 2 more times within the next 48 hours. The saturation of the serum with bilirubin to an index value above 8 was of less than 8 hours’ duration. Patient 4 had a saturation index of 8.1 when the serum bilirubin level was 14.8 mg. per 100 ml. on the fourth day of life. The bilirubin concentration on the fifth day was still 14.0 mg. per 100 ml., but the saturation index had fallen to 2.0. Thus, the excessive saturation of this patient’s serum with bilirubin may also have been of brief dura-

1 8 Odell, Storey, and Rosenberg


tion. The remaining 3 patients (3, 16, and 37) were females, and Patients 3 and 16 had hyperbilirubinemia in excess of 15 mg. per 100 ml. of less than 3 days’ duration.

In contrast to the clinical course of the hyperbilirubinemia of the children with normal psychometric test results, the elevation of the serum bilirubins above 15 mg, per 100 ml. in the abnormal children was of relatively greater duration (3.29 days versus 1.73 days; the mean difference of 1.56 is significantly different, p < 0.01). Twelve of the damaged children were not given exchange transfusion until the concentration of serum bilirubin exceeded 18 mg. per 100 ml.; the exchange transfusion in 9 of them was not performed until the fourth day of life or later.

Three of the 18 damaged children had physical findings of neurologic impairment in motor and/or sensory functions characteristic of kernicterus; choreiform movements were demonstrable in Patients 10 and 29, and spasticity with sensorineural deafness in Patient 5. One additional child, Patient 33, has defective enamel formation and staining of his incisors.

Table IV lists the frequency of additional features of the children that were tested for a possible relationship to the results in their psychometric performances and were not

The Journal of Pediatrics January 1970 ,, r-

found to have any statistical significance. Worthy of emphasis are the almost identical mean values of the maximum bilirubin concentration which the damaged and normal children had during neonatal life.

The comparison of the incidence and severity of complications of pregnancy and delivery could not be measured, but qualitatively, no particular events appeared to predispose in this series to subsequent cognitive dysfunction.

As has been found in other surveys on the ■ incidence of hyperbilirubinemia1 •’34 there was a preponderance of male infants in the present series. Clinically it was found that about half the damaged children demonstrated hyperkinesis, poor attention span, and more aggressive behavior.

DISCUSSION

Any study which attempts to relate neonatal events to subsequent cognitive performance of the brain must recognize the many variables which can influence the maturation of the central nervous system, e.g.. genetic endowment, maternal health during gestation, nutrition, critical-period imprinting, economic status, and educational opportunity, as well as inflammatory and toxic injuries during prenatal and postnatal life. In the present study, the only consistent feature of the children was the occurrence of jaundice during neonatal life. A correlation was not found between the maximum scrum bilirubin concentration and the subsequent presence of either low I.Q. and psychometric scores or cerebral palsy. This observation is similar to those of previous reports in which neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, unrelated to hemolytic disease, was found not to correlate with the subsequent neurologic outcome of the children.17- -!l-3" A relationship between hyperbilirubinemia and subsequent evidence of brain injury’ has occurred in infants with coexistent clinical disturbances such as hemolytic diseases/- 131 i... i< prematurity,1'1 respiratory insufficiency and acidosis,"7' and the exogenous administration of organic anions.3" When a very large collaborative series of infants was

483

Volume 76

Number 1


Slurlies in kcrnicterus. Ill 19

studied, a statistically significant relationship between hyperbilirubinemia, per se, and neurologic impairment was demonstrated.31 Because of the relatively weak correlation of brain damage with hyperbilirubinemia and the absence of an abrupt change in incidence with increasing concentrations, the serum bilirubin concentration is not a precise measure of the risk of brain damage. We have previously emphasized that the absolute concentration of bilirubin is of less importance than the fraction of the' scrum bilirubin which is dissociated from albumin and therefore free to diffuse into cells.32’ 371 38 It follows that the albumin concentration in extracellular fluids is as important as the total bilirubin in determining the concentration of the diffusible fraction. The previously cited clinical complications which have demonstrated a relationship of hyperbilirubinemia to neurologic damage are often associated with an increase in the concentration of diffusible bilirubin. The increase in diffusible bilirubin may be due to either hypo-albuminemia or to interference with the capacity of albumin to bind bilirubin. Under these circumstances the diffusible bilirubin can reach damaging concentrations at relatively low levels for the total serum bilirubin.

Currently there is no reliable method to measure the diffusible concentration of bilirubin in serum, but an indirect estimate can

tion of the serum albumin with bilirubin by the salicylate displacement technique.32 When this saturation index was tested for a relationship to neurologic impairment, a significant correlation -was found between poor psychometric performance and high saturations of the serum albumin with bilirubin during neonatal life. When I.Q. scores alone were compared to the saturation index a statistically significant relationship was not found, but all of the children with I.Q. scores of less than 80 -were in the damaged group, and 8 of the 9 children with abnormal I.Q. scores also had had saturation indices greater than 8.0. As previously reported.11, 13 the effect of hyperbilirubinemia on the I.Q. might have been demonstrable if the scores were compared within sibships, but our distinction of normal and abnormal depended on the single criterion of scores above or below 80. Thus, it is quite possible the hyperbilirubinemia affected the I.Q. of the children, but not sufficiently to reduce it to frankly abnormal levels.

This study also demonstrated that neonatal hyperbilirubinemia can be associated with subsequent brain injury in the absence of cerebral palsy. Many clinicians have been under the impression that the encephalopathy characteristic of bilirubin toxicity will be manifested only as kernicterus with a depressed Moro reflex, opisthotonus, and shrill cry. The more recent reports of kemicterus in autopsied premature infants indicates that the classical signs of kernicterus were not present during life.35’ 39 Three of the damaged patients in this report were found to have cerebral palsy characteristic of survivors of kernicterus without having had clinical signs during neonatal life.

The neuropathologic evidence of bilirubin encephalopathy indicates extensive nuclear involvement of the ventral cortex and suggests that the toxicity of bilirubin to the central nervous system is broad and might not be detectable until later life. The sensorineural hearing impairment is but one example.12’18 The frequent involvement of the hippocampus seen in brains of kernic-teric infants and the role of the hippocampus in memory23-25 may be particularly relevant to the memory defects found in our patients with high saturation indices.

A number of the patients who had had high saturation indices during the period of neonatal jaundice were found to have normal psychometric test results. However, the duration of high saturation was considerably shorter than in the damaged children. Since the study was not designed to test temporal factors, these observations can only suggest that the duration of exposure, as well as the degree of saturation of the serum with bilirubin, may be important in determining the risk of bilirubin encephalopathy.

Although 16 of the 18 damaged children were treated by exchange transfusion, im-

2 0 Odell, Storey, and Rosenberg

t he Jnuinal of Pedwliit'i January 1971)


pairmcnt of cognitive functions was not prevented. The transfusions may have prevented lethal kcrnicterus, but were employed too late to prevent the milder injuries which were detectable at 5 years of age.

One optimistic finding in these studies is the indication that if hyperbilirubinemia is properly managed, the incidence of mental deficiency in premature infants may be significantly reduced. The use of the saturation index as a guide in the management of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia permits more precision in the identification of those infants at risk from the toxicity of bilirubin.

SUMMARY

A group of 32 children who had been significantly jaundiced during neonatal life were re-examined at 5 years of age for neurologic and psychometric evidence of brain damage. From the results of the psychologic tests two scores were obtained: (1) the measured I.Q., and (2) the designation of presence or absence of brain damage derived from the performance of the children on psychometric tests of cognitive functions. These two determinants of mental function were tested for possible correlations to a number of clinical and laboratory measurements that had been performed on the children when they were infants.

Of the total, 18 of the children were found to have brain damage; 14 were considered normal. No correlations were found between the determinants of mental function at 5 years and the birth tveights, sex, presence or absence of hemolvtic disease, exchange transfusion, and the maximum serum bilirubin concentrations. A significant correlation (p < 0.01) was found between the presence or absence of brain damage and the degree to which the patients’ sera had been saturated with bilirubin. It was found that 16 of the 18 damaged children had had a saturation index of 8.0 or greater, -whereas this had occurred in only 5 of the 14 normal children. It was also found that the damaged children had had bilirubin concentrations in excess of 15 mg. per 100 ml. for 3.29 days, which was significantly longer than the 1.73 days in the normal children.

The results indicate that the determination of the saturation index is a more precise measurement than the serum bilirubin concentration for predicting which infants arc at risk to central nervous system damage. These findings also indicate that impairment of cognitive functioning is associated with hyperbilirubinemia in the neonatal period without the occurrence of the classical findings of kernicterus during neonatal life or of cerebral palsy in later life. These results suggest that hyperbilirubinemia is associated with a continuum of morbidity of which classical neonatal kernicterus, with or without immediate death, is only one end of the spectrum of cerebral damage.

The authors are grateful to Joseph Dallas of the Department of Pediatrics who was able to locate many of the patients for us and encourage their cooperation with the evaluation.

  • 36. Silverman, W. A., Anderson, D. H-, Blanc, W. A., and Crozier, D. N. A.: A difference in mortality rate and incidence of kernicterus among premature infants allotted to two prophylactic antibacterial regimens, Pediatrics 18: 614, 1956.

  • 37. Odell, G. B.: Studies in kernicterus. I. Protein binding of bilirubin, J. Clin. Invest. 38: 823, 1959.                 '

  • 38. Odell, G. B.: The distribution of bilirubin between albumin and mitochondria, J. Pediat. 68: 164, 1966.                     ‘

  • 39. Gartner, L. M., Snyder, R. N., Chavon, R. A., and Bernstein, J.: Kernicterus: High incidence in prematures with mild jaundice, Program. The American Pediatric Soc. Inc., Atlantic City, N. J., 1968.

DEVELOPMENTAL MEDICINE AND CHILD NEUROLOGY

June 1972 Vol. 14 No. 3

BILIRUBIN NEUROTOXICITY

395 In recent years there has been a renewed interest in cerebral lesions resulting from unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Our earlier concepts of age of occurrence and its correlation with the degree of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia have required modification. The initial impressions that cerebral lesions secondary to hyperbilirubinemia occurred only in the first eight days of the neonatal period1, and only with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia over 20 mg per cent, have not held true.

In an analysis of 3? patients aged 4 to 7 years who had been jaundiced in the neonatal period, Odell2 was unable to correlate the level of hyperbilirubinemia with cerebral palsy or iqs of less than 80. On the other hand, the degree to which serum albumin was saturated with unconjugated bilirubin, as measured by the salicytate displacement test, correlated well with subsequent brain damage. The many case reports of bilirubin encephalopathy occurring in infants at levels less than 20 mg per cent, of whom the few cases reported by Stern and Denton3 are an example, serve to emphasize that factors other than the absolute level of unconjugated bilirubin are critical. Studies such as the original one by Silverman et al* demonstrate that agents (such as sulfa, salicytate and some antibiotics) which compete with unconjugated bilirubin for albumin-binding sites lead to bilirubin encephalopathy at lower levels of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Mort recent information, such as that reported by Silberberg et «/.5, demonstrates that cerebellar tissue cultures are more sensitive to bilirubin-induced toxicity at low pH values of the media. On the other hand, at pH levels of 7.62, tissue cultures containing up to 50 mg per cent of bilirubin, with a ■ bilirubin-to-albumin ratio of?:9, were spared evidence of cytotoxicity. There is no doubt that factors such as acidosis, hypoxia and hypoglycemia, which alter the brain's susceptibility to bilirubin, as well as agents which compete with bilirubin for albumin-binding sites, are critical factors in the production of bilirubin encephalopathy in the newborn period.

39&         It is true that kernicterus occurs most frequently in the immediate neonatal period. The

reason for this age susceptibility is probably the frequency of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in this age group, rather than immaturity of the blood brain barrier.

The apparent increased permeability of the blood brain barrier in the neonate to certain substances may very well be a reflection of the metabolism of the neonate rather than his immaturity. At any rate, there is no apparent difference between the blood brain barrier in the newborn or adult animal as far as bilirubin is concerned.

Although it is uncommon, when unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia occurs in later childhood at levels comparable to those seen in the newborn period, bilirubin encephalopathy does occur. Several cases have been described in children with congenital nonhemolytic jaundice due to glucuronyl transferase deficiency beginning in early infancy® or with onset as late as 15 years7. More recently, Jellinger et al.* have once again called our attention to bilirubin encephalopathy in the Crigler-Najjar syndrome by describing a child with a prolonged course of hyperbilirubinemia (over 30 mg per cent), associated with spasticity, choreoathetosis, lethargy, feeding difficulty and eventual death at 8 months of age. At autopsy, the brain showed lesions of varying ages. Symmetrical neuronal depletion and gffosis were found fn the basal ganglia, including the pafh'dum, subthalamic nucleus, and lateral thalamus. These lesions were felt to be older than the spongy cortical necrosis

39& with intense giial mesodermal reaction found in the cerebral cortex, Ammon’s Horn and striatum, which were indicative of more recent bilirubin toxicity. The case described by Jellinger et al. resembles clinically those cases previously described by other authors, and neuropathologically is quite consistent with the histology of bilirubin encephalopathy as described in the review of kernicterus by Larroche.9

■ It has long been known that the basal ganglia, hippocampus and brain-stem nuclei are most apt to concentrate bilirubin. In infants and animals dying acutely of kernicterus, the " brain often shows diffuse n on-localized yellow discoloration. It may be that the localization of pigment in the above-mentioned areas simply reflects susceptibility of these structures to bilirubin toxicity. Further bilirubin staining may occur because of the propensity of bilirubin to involve damaged areas of brain.

From the ultrastructural work of Chen et a!.10, we have information concerning the flow of bilirubin into and within nerve cells. In Chen’s experimental rabbits, bilirubin appears to be transported from vessels to the neuron by the astrocyte and its processes. Flow within the neuron appears to occur from the dendrite centripetally to the neuronal soma and eventually to the axon. The astrocytic process then attempts to release the waste products of the damaged neuron.

At present we have a wealth of information concerning the binding and diffusion of bilirubin, as well as. the numerous factors which predispose to bilirubin encephalopathy. Although we also have reasonable ultrastructural information concerning the flow of bilirubin within the neuron, we still lack an understanding of the basic mechanism of bilirubin neurotoxicity.                                          Michael J. Painter

College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University,

'            Division of Child Neurology,

710 West 168th Street,

New York, N.Y. 10032, USA.                    ■

REFERENCES

  • 6. Crigler, J. F., Najjar, V. A. (1952) ‘Congenital familial non-hemolytic jaundice with kernicterus.' Pediatrics, 10, 169.

  • 7. Gardner, \V. A., Konigsmark, B. W. (1968) ‘Congenital non-hemolytic jaundice with visceral bilirubin-osis and onset of encephalopathy at age 15.' Journal of Neuropathology and Experimental Neurology, 27, 154.                       '            ..     ..

  • 8. Jellinger, K., Minauf, M., Weissenbacher, G. (1970) Hirnveriinderungen bei kongenitalem nichthamo-lytischen Jkterus (Crigler-Najjar-Syndrom).’ Acta Neuropathplogica, 16, 141.

  • 9. Larroche, J. Cl. (1968) ‘Kernicterus.’ In Vinken, P. J., Bruyn, G. W. (Eds.) Handbook of Clinical Neurology, Vol. 6, Diseases of the Basal Ganglia. Amsterdam: North Holland, p. 491.

  • 10. Chen, H. C., Wang, C. H., Tasau, K. W., Chen, Y. C. (1971) ‘An electron microscopic and radioautographic study on experimental kernicterus. II. Bilirubin movement within neurons and release of waste products via astroglia.’ American Journal of Pathology, 64, 45.

Mortality and Morbidity of Exchange Transfusion

W. C. TAYLOR, M.B.„ Ch.B., F.R.C.P.[C], Edmonton, Alta.

UNTIL the publication of the reports of Farquhar and Smith,1 Boggs and Westphal,2 and Van 1’raagh,3 few reports in the medical literature considered the risks of exchange transfusion. Because of this a clinical investigation was conducted in the Maternity Unit of the University of Alberta Hospital, Edmonton, Alta., with the following main objectives; (1) to determine the incidence and cause of death in infants dying during or shortly after exchange transfusion; and (2) to investigate the biochemical, electrocardiographic and clinical disorders which might arise during exchange transfusion.

. Clinical Material and Duration of Study

During a period of 34 months, 104 infants underwent a total of 150 exchange transfusions (Table I). Seventy-two infants suffered from Rh hemolytic disease, 22 infants suffered from ABO hemolytic disease, and in 10 infants the cause of the jaundice could not be determined. The overall mortality was calculated from this group of 104 infants.

TABLE I,—Exchange Transfusions, University of Alberta Hospital, 1957 - 1960

No. of

Infants exchange exchanged transfusions

Rh hemolytic disease........... 72

ABO hemolytic disease.......... 22

Other causes.................. 10

104

Method

The decision to undertake exchange transfusion and the technicalities. of the procedure were left to the discretion of the pediatrician in charge of the patient. In all cases, the exchange was performed with donor blood preserved by the standard acid-citrate-dextrose anticoagulant. Detailed clinical records were maintained on all exchange transfusions performed during the period of study.

Samples of blood for biochemical measurements and electrocardiographic tracings were obtained during 62 exchange transfusions performed on 44 infants. The incidence of clinical disturbances, biochemical disorders, and electrocardiographic changes was calculated from this group of 62 exchange transfusions.

  • 1. Blood samples were obtained from the umbilical vein before the start of the exchange. Samples were also obtained at the mid-point and after completion of the exchange. Contamination of samples with donor blood was avoided by discarding the first 2-5 ml. of blood withdrawn.

•From the Department of Pediatrics, University of Alberta.

ABSTRACT

One hundred and fifty exchange transfusions, using citrated donor blood, were investigated to determine the mortality rate from the procedure. One infant died during manipulation of the catheter in the umbilical vein. Four infants died of combined causes including anemia, prematurity and elevated potassium in the donor blood. Sixty-two exchange transfusions were investigated in detail to determine the incidence of clinical disturbances. Vomiting, retching, respiratory distress, convulsions or tetany developed during 23 exchanges. A rapid rate of exchange, elevated potassium in the donor blood, and failure to administer calcium during the exchange were major factors contributing to these disturbances. Exchange transfusion with citrated blood can be safeguarded by (1) using donor blood less than five days old, (2) employing a rate of exchange of 2 ml./kg./min. and (3) injecting calcium gluconate during the exchange.

  • 2. Total bilirubin was measured by a micromodification of the method of Malloy and Evelyn.

  • 3. Calcium was measured by the method of EDTA titration.

  • 4. Potassium was measured by flame photometry.

  • 5. Measurement of whole blood pH was determined during 15 exchange transfusions by means of a glass electrode.

  • 6. Electrocardiographic tracings were recorded on a direct writing Sanborn electrocardiograph.

Results

  • 1. Mortality

Eight of the 104 infants died during transfusion5 or within 72 hours of exchange transfusion- Three infant deaths occurring 23 to 72 hours after exchange transfusion appeared to have resulted from ; factors unrelated to the procedure.

The remaining five deaths are summarized in the appendix to this report. Exchange transfusion was considered to be partly responsible for death in four of these infants and to be the only cause of death in one infant (Case 5). In this vigorous in-\ fant who was mildly affected by hemolytic disease, death followed immediately after withdrawal of the first 10 ml. of blood from the umbilical catheter. Biochemical findings on the cord blood and a detailed autopsy revealed no obvious cause of death.

The factors contributing to the five deaths are listed in Table II. From ibis table it can be seen

that the severity of the hemolytic disease and prematurity are the main factors contributing to the deaths. High plasma potassium in the donor blood contributed to three deaths.

On the basis of five infant deaths, the mortality yate for 104 infants undergoing exchange transfusion was 4.8%. The mortality rate for 150 ex-

■ change transfusions was 3.3%.

  • 2. Clinically Recognizable Disturbances

Clinically recognizable disturbances were recorded in 23 (37%) of the 62 exchange transfusions that were investigated in some detail. The incidence of each svmptom is presented in Table III.

TA OLE III.—Clinically Recognizable Disturbances in 62 Exchange Transfusions .

Retching and vomiting........................ 14 (23%)

Respiratory distress.......................... 6 (10%)

Convulsions or tetany........................ 5 ( 8%)

Hiccups..................................... 1

Retching or vomiting was encountered in 14 (23%) of the 62 exchange transfusions. The incidence of these symptoms increased in relation to the rate at which the .exchange transfusion was performed (Table IV). It also increased in relation

respiratory rate, an expiratory grunt and cyanosis, was recognizable during the course of six exchange transfusions. In three premature infants, respiratory

distress was present before the start of the exchange transfusion. Two infants developed respiratory distress after a convulsion. A sixth infant with respiratory distress had severe hemolytic disease and developed an expiratory grunt during the course of two exchange transfusions.

Generalized convulsions or tetany developed during five exchange transfusions. Tetany was manifested by increased irritability, muscle tremors and hyperactive reflexes. During four of the five exchange transfusions in which these symptoms developed, no calcium had been administered as a prophylactic measure. The average volume of blood exchanged before the development of convulsions or tetany was 250 ml. The smallest volume exchanged was 150 ml. In each case the convulsion or tetany was immediately relieved by the intravenous injection of 10% calcium gluconate.

  • 3. Electrocardiographic Findings

Electrocardiographic tracings were obtained before, during and after 62 exchange transfusions (Table VI).

The following abnormalities were detected;

  • 1. Ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest oc- ’ gurred.in one infant.4 The plasma potassium of the , donor blood used for this exchange transfusion was in excess of 20 mEq./l. Subsequent experimental work on rabbits has shown that similar electrocardiographic findings can be reproduced following exchange transfusion with hyperpotassemic blood.’1

  • 2. Tachycardia.—A heart rate in excess of 200 beats per minute developed in four infants. The . maximum heart rate recorded was 242/min. Tachycardia of this severity developed only in infants weighing more than 3000 g. All four of the infants who manifested tachycardia suffered from mild hemolytic disease, and in each the heart rate returned to normal after the exchange was completed.

  • 3. Bradycardia.—Temporary slowing of the heart rate was usually apparent one to two minutes after the injection of 10% calcium gluconate. The maximum volume of 10% calcium gluconate injected at any one time was 3 ml. .The speed of injection of the calcium gluconate did not appear to be an important factor in determining slowing of the heart rate. The slowest heart rate recorded was 70/min. after injection of calcium. A heart rate of less than 100/min. was recorded during the course of six exchange transfusions.

  • 4. Muscle tremor, relieved by the injection of calcium gluconate, was recorded during 14 exchange transfusions.

  • 4. Biochemical Results

  • 1. Potassium.—One death was attributed directly to the use of donor blood with a plasma potassium greater than 20 mEq./l.3 Elevation of the plasma potassium in the donor blood above a level of 10 mEq./I. was considered to be a contributing factor in the death of two other infants. Fifty per cent of infants exchanged with donor blood containing plasma potassium in excess of 10 mEq./l. developed retching or vomiting.

  • 2. pH.—Measurement of the pH of the donor blood and of the infant’s blood before, during and after exchange transfusion was performed during 15 exchange transfusions. The average pH of donor blood was 6.59. During the 15 exchange transfusions the pH of the infant’s blood fell from an average of 7.32 before the exchange to an average of 7.12 at the end of the exchange. The fall in pH could not be correlated with clinical disturbances.

TABLE VI.- I*’i.ectrocardiocrapuic Findings During 62 Exchange Transfusions

Ventricular fibrillation

Tachycardia (heart rate >200/min.)

Bradycardia (heart rate < 100/min.)

Muscle tremor relieved by calcium

  • 3. Measurements of serum calcium and plasma carbon dioxide content were also performed on infants before and after exchange transfusion. The results, however, were inconsistent and could not be correlated with clinical disturbances or electrocardiographic abnormalities.

Discussion

, ] Recent reports in the literature have emphasized ■T /that a major problem in determining the mortality of exchange transfusion has been to differentiate those cases in which the procedure itself was the •4*. cause of death from those cases in which the procedure was one of several factors contributing to death. Of the five deaths in this series only one was directly atnibuted to the procedure. In the remaining four deaths anemia, prematurity and thrombocytopenia were additional factors contributing to a fatal outcome. The mortality rate of 4.8%

. of 104 infants undergoing exchange transfusion represented the maximum mortality rate which could be attributed to the procedure at the University of Alberta Hospital.

Boggs and Westphal2 have reported on their experience with 1139 exchange transfusions on 519 infants. They arbitrarily decided that all deaths occurring during or within six hours of an exchange transfusion should be considered as having resulted l.Oni the procedure. They reported a mortality rate of 46.2% in hydropic or moribund infants. 13.7% in weak or kernicteric infants, and 0.2% in vigorous mi ants.

Van Praagh3 reported a total risk of death during or soon after the exchange transfusion of 4% in 822 infants with hemolytic disease. The risk of death was higher in the more severely affected infants. On the basis of ausculatory findings, cardiac arrhythmia developed in 13 of 25 infants whose deaths were related to exchange transfusion.

Jablonski0 reported that in 263 exchange transfusions performed for non-hemolytic jaundice, the procedure possibly played a part in the deaths of a maximum of four infants, an average mortality rate of 1.5%. He believed that patients with erythroblastosis fetalis were affected by so many complicating factors that determination of an accurate mortality rate due to exchange transfusion would not be possible.

Farquhar and Smith1 reported on the high incidence of clinical disturbances during exchange ‘transfusion. Of the 19 infants they studied, one died during transfusion and six others showed clinical disturbances.

There is sufficient evidence from the present study to suggest that an appreciable number of hazards attend the use of citrated donor blood for exchange transfusion. Fortunately most of these hazards can be prevented by taking suitable precautions. The greatest danger is from elevation of the plasma potassium in the donor blood. The plasma potassium of stored citrated blood rises at the rate of 1 mEq./I. day, and a dangerous level of 10 mEq./l. is reached by the fifth day of storage. Donor blood therefore should not be more than five ■ days old. The rapidity of the exchange influences the incidence of retching and vomiting. A desirable rate for the exchange transfusion should be 2 ml./kg./min. For example, a 6-lb. infant requiring 80 ml./lb. body weight of donor blood should be transfused over a period of 80 minutes. Convulsions and tetany are unlikely to appear if 1 ml. of 10% calcium gluconate is injected after every 100 ml. of blood has been exchanged. The suggestion of Boggs and Westphal that exchange transfusion should commence with the injection of 1 ml. of 10% calcium gluconate has considerable merit.

The use of heparinized blood will eliminate the dangers of raised plasma potassium and lowered ionized calcium. The main disadvantage of heparinized blood is the limited time for which it can 'be stored, necessitating the ready availability of a panel of blood donors.

Case 5 in this series emphasizes the fact that the ■ unexpected can happen at any time during an exchange transfusion. In this case death resulted from manipulation of the catheter in the umbilical vein . before any exchange of blood had taken place, The j only comfort which can be derived from such a tragedy is the knowledge that the exchange transfusion was performed as a calculated risk with the potential benefits to the baby outweighing the dangers of the procedure.

Summary

Although prematurity and severity of the hemolytic disease are major factors contributing to neonatal deaths from hemolytic disease, recent reports suggest that an appreciable mortality may be related to exchange trans

fusion. The results of a three-year investigation into thei causes of death in 104 infants undergoing transfusion . are presented, Two infants died during the exchange and three infants died within 24 hours of the exchange. / In all five deaths, factors related to the exchange trans-/ fusion contributed to the fatal outcome.              '

Biochemical measurements and electrocardiographic tracings were obtained during 62 exchange transfusions performed on 44 infants. Clinically recognizable disturbances were recorded in 23 (37%) of the 62 exchange transfusions. These disturbances included retching, vomiting, respiratory distress, convulsions, tetany, and cardiac arrest. A rapid rate of exchange transfusion and increased plasma potassium in the donor blood were the major factors contributing to the high incidence of clinical abnormalities.

This investigation was supported by Public Health Research Grant No. 608-7-15.

I should like to thank the pediatricians on the attending staff of the University Hospital for permission to carry out the investigations on their patients.

References

  • 1. Kahquhar, J. W. and Smith, H.: Arch. Dis. Child., 33: 142, 1958.

  • 2. Bonos, T. R., Jr. and Westphal, M. C., Jr. : Pediatrics, 26: 745, 1960.

  • 3. Van Praagh, R.: Ibid., 23: 223, 1961.

  • 4. Taylor, W. C., Ghisdale, Li. C. and Stewart, A. G.: ./. Pediat., 52: 6 94, 1956.

  • 5. Taylor, W, C. et al.: Ibid., 58: 470, 1961.

  • 6. Jablonski, W. J.: New Engl. J. Med., 266: 155, 1962.

APPENDIX

Case 1.—The birth weight of this infant was 2126 g. It was delivered by Cesarean section at 35 weeks' gestation. The coni hemoglobin value was 9.5 g. and the serum bilirubin 6.4 nig. %; the infant appeared vigorous after delivery, The first exchange transfusion was performed one hour after delivery; a second exchange, at seven hours after delivery. At the age of 22 hours, the infant’s condition was assessed as deteriorating. The hemoglobin value was 8.3 g. % and the total serum bilirubin was 13.6 mg. %. A third. ffiifihangc transfusion., was undertaken, using seven-day-old , blood which had been packed by the removal of super- < natant plasm. Cardiac arrest, recorded electrocardiographic- I ally, occurred after 70 ml. of blood had been exchanged. I Cardiac asystole persisted for live minutes, but responded to intracardiac injection of adrenaline, intravenous administration of calcium and artificial respiration. The infant’s* condition remained precarious after this eriisodc~and deaths occurred at the age of 38 hours. The plasma potassium in the donor blood was over 20 mEq./l. ~

Factors contributing to death were: fl) severity of hemolytic disease. (2) hyperpotassemic donor blood, (3) bleeding dyscrasia, and (4) prematurity.

Case 2.—The birth weight of this infant was 2807 g. The period of gestation was 37 weeks. The delivery was a spontaneous vertex presentation. The cord blood hemoglobin value was 6.6 g. %. Exchange transfusion through the umbilical vein was commenced three hours after delivery., After considerable manipulation of the catheter, only 10 ml. of blood could be withdrawn. Exchange transfusion was then performed through the left saphenous vein, 300 ml. of the infant’s blood being replaced by 300 ml. of donor blood. The whole procedure lasted five hours. The/ infant was returned to the nursery in a state of shock, with I pallor, cold extremities and grunting respirations. He died/ 10 hours after delivery. Autopsy did not reveal anv anatomical cause .in the umbilical vein for the difficulty with the exchange transfusion, or any cause ofdeath other than hemolytic disease.

Factors contributing to death were: (1) technical difficulty’ with exchange, and (2) severity of hemolytic disease.

Case 3.—The birth weight of this infant was 2381 g. The infant was delivered by Cesarean section at 35 weeks’ gestation. The Cesarean section was performed for ante-, partum hemorrhage due to placenta previa. The infant was pale and edematous, with grunting respirations. The cord hemoglobin value was 8.9 g. % and the bilirubin 5.7 mg. %. Immediate exchange transfusion was performed, using 14-cIay-oId donor blood) Artificial respiration was maintained during the procedure. The infant expired after 140 ml, of blood had been exchangeSTThe plasma potassium in the donor blood was 12 mEq./l.

Factors contributing to death were: (1) severity of hemolytic disease—hydrops fetalis, and (2) hyperpotassemic donor blood.

Case 4.—The birth weight of this infant was 1860 g. Medical induction was performed at 35 weeks’ gestation because of a rising maternal Rh antibody titre, and the infant was delivered as a vertex presentation. The cord hemoglobin was 5.6 g. % and the bilirubin 7,7 mg. %. Exchange transfusions were performed at 1% hours, 1314 hours, 22’4 hours and 2914 hours of age. Because of difficulty in obtaining suitable donor blood, the first two exchange transfusions were performed with donor blood that was 13 and 14 days old. 26.2


The infant was digitalized within 10 minutes of delivery, and it was thought probable that this prevented cardiac arrest during the exchange transfusions.

Electrocardiography was performed during each transfusion. Although minor changes consistent with hyperpotassemia developed, there was no gross arrhythmia. The serum । bilirubin level reached a maximum of 38 mg. % at 13% hours of age. At 41 hours of age the infant suddenly1 [became apneic and failed to respond to resuscitative measures. At this time the infant's serum potassium value was 13 mEq./l. and the ECG showed bizarre ORS complexes consistent with hyperpotassemia- The heart beat recorded by the ECG ceased at 41% hours of age. Autopsy revealed no abnormality other than those changes attributable to erythroblastosis and prematurity.

Factors contributing to death were: (1) hyperpotassemic donor blood, (2) severe hemolytic disease (multiple Rh antibodies in the maternal serum), and (3) prematurity.

Case 5.—The birth weight .of this infant was 3771 g. The infant was delivered as a vertex presentation following induction at 38 weeks’ gestation. The cord hemoglobin value ’ was 11.8 g. %, and the bilirubin was 4.4 mg, %. Exchange f transfusion was started six hours after delivery. A catheter w*as easily inserted into the umbilical vein. The venous pressure was 6 cm. After withdrawal of the first IQ ml, of blood, the infant became cyanosed and the heart rate slowed. VVithin two minutes, breathing had stopped and' po heart beat could be detected by auscultation. Tracheal intubation and artificial respiration" vvere carried out. Cardiac massage was performed through the fourth intercostal space. Adrenaline and calcium were injected into the heart. The infant did not respond to these measures and was pronounced dead eight hours after delivery.

Electrolyte determination on a sample of cord blood obtained at the time of cardiac arrest were as follows: sodium 141 mEq./i.; calcium 10.3 mg. %; chloride 100 mEq./L; phosphorus 5.8 mg. '%; potassium 3.8 mEq./l.; bilirubin (total) 4.6 mg. %; and COa content 16.8 mEq./l.

Cardiac arrest occurred before any dopor blood had been infected. Postmortem examination revealed’ noabnoranalities that could have accounted for this’death,"

Tractors contributing to. death: bl one" ascertained.

112

Exchange Transfusion Mortality in a Community Hospital

Suggestions for Lowering the Patality Rate

EUGENE F. DIAMOND. MI), CHICAGO

.A.LTHOUGH THE technique of exchange transfusion is now two decades old, a lively discussion continues as to the indica-tipns for its use 1-3 and the safety of the procedure.4'3 Those with extensive experience with exchange transfusion recognize that sudden and poorly understood deaths occur during and soon after this procedure which tempers, the enthusiasm for its use de-spite its admitted effectiveness as therapy for severe erythroblastosis fetalis. Trolle5 has gone so far as to suggest that the use of exchange transfusion for idiopathic hyper-bilirubinemia in full-term and premature infants would result in a net loss of life in that the mortality of thc^troccdurevvouid exceed that of kermeterus, using present indications for exchange transfusion. Boggs,7 on the other hand, reports no mortality related to 506 exchange transfusions performed for idiopathic hyperbilirubinemia.

The purpose of this study was to investigate the exchange transfusion-related mortality on a large newborn service with particular attention to preventable factors observed. A program of prophylactic measures to reduce future mortality might then be evolved.

The general mortality in infants with

Received for publication March 3, 1966.

From the departments of pediatrics, Loyola University Stritch School of Medicine, Chicago, and Little Company of Mary Hospital, Evergreen Park, III.

Reprint requests to 11055 S St. Louis, Chicago 60655.

hemolytic disease has been studied thoroughly by Van I’raagh 8 and by Walker and Mollison.9 The results of these studies indicate that the principal cause of death is severe hemolytic disease ('59% of deaths in Van Praagh's series, 43% in the series of Walker and Mollison). Delay in therapy, resulting in mortality from kernicterus or late anemia, caused 21% of deaths in Van Praagh’s series and 30.6% of the deaths in Walker and Mollison’s report. The most significant feature of both reports, is the incidence ot exchange transtusion-related mortality (20% according to Van Praagh and 14% according to Walker and Morrison ).

Methods and Materials

During the period from Jan 1, 1962 through Dec 31, 1964, a total of 15,294 infants were delivered at Little Company of Mary Hospital in Evergreen Park, Ill. Positive Coombs tests were recorded for 189 infants. A total of 120 exchange transfusions were performed on 108 newborn infants. All exchange transfusions were performed by pediatricians, certified by the American Board of Pediatrics, who had a minimum of eight years experience in the performance of the procedure when the study began. Technique of exchange transfusion was that described by Allen and Diamond.10 There were nine fatalities. Eight occurred during or within six hours of an exchange transfusion and, therefore, would be considered as exchange-related mortalities according to the definition of Boggs.7 Autopsies were performed on all patients and none were excluded from the study. Of the total of 108 patients requiring exchange transfusions, six (5.5%) were

Amer J Dis Child—l ol 112, Aug 1966

EXCHANGE TRANSFUSION-DIAMOND

113


classified as having &liop:ithic hyperbilirubinemia. Offending antibodies encountered in the remaining patients were: Anti-D, 94%; Anti-B, 3%; Anti-A, 2% ; and Anti-E, 1%. All deaths occurred in infants who had isoimmunization with the Anti-D antibody.

Results

Deaths occurring during or within six hours of an exchange transfusion were classified into three groups according to the method of Van Praagh.8

Group 1,—Included in this group were tour infants whose deaths were primarily attributable to severe hemolytic disease. No indication of kernicterus was found in any infant. Although death occurred during the procedure in each case, it was not principally related to complications of the procedure itself. Autopsy disclosed extensive pulmonary hemorrhage in all four infants and

in two of the infants. These are typical causes of death among fatalities related to severe hemolytic disease with or without treatment.8'9 All four infants had hemoglobin levels before the procedure of less than 10 gm/100 cc and all had thrombocytopenia with petechial formation. Three additional infants with severe hemolytic disease who survived developed convulsions during or shortly after exchange transfusion. These convulsions may also have been related to cerebrovascular bleeding or they may have been due to low ionized calcium from accumulated citrate.

Group 2.—This group comprises four infants whose death was attributed to cardiac abnormalities developing during replacement transfusion. In each case auscultation disclosed cardiac arrhythmias immediately preceding a sudden unexpected demise of the infant. Arrythmias were of three types: (a) sudden cardiac arrest (two infants), (b) bradycardia followed by cardiac arrest (one infant), and (c) tachycardia followed by shock, sudden drop of venous pressure, and cardiac failure (one infant). Four additional infants developed cardiac decompensation during exchange transfusion, but these survived after digitalization. There , were no other pathological findings to which death could be attributed when autopsies

Amer J Dis Child, were performed on the four infants in this group. The relationship of ionized calcium levels to the onset of arrhythmias was not determined.

Group 3.- -Group 3 in the Van Praagh classification consisted of deaths following considerable technical difficulty during unsuccessful attempts to perform exchange transfusion. No deaths of this type occurred in this series. One additional death was observed which occurred before exchange transfusion was begun. This was a severely anemic infant with beginning hydrops. Autopsy disclosed pulmonary hemorrhage.

Mortality

The total risk of death during or within six hours of an exchange transfusion was 7.4% per patient, or 6.7% per exchange transfusion. If the infants in Group 1 are excluded (insofar as these deaths were primarily attributed to severe hemolytic disease), the risk is 3.7% per patient and 3.3% per exchange transfusion. If the figures of Vaughn et al11 are accepted, the mortality in Rhesus-sensitized infants without treatment would be 34%, with an additional 5% incidence of kernicterus in survivors.

The Table compares the mortality rate in this series to that previously reported in series dealing with exchange transfusions for hemolytic disease.1-'18

Comment

The emphasis on the performance of the exchange transfusion has gradually evolved over the years. The original purpose of removing antibody and the hemolyzable sensitized red-cell mass has been replaced by an

Mortality of li.

xchange

Transfusion

Exchange

Related Deaths

Total I>eaths

Author

fusions

No.

%

No.

%

Boggs A

875

17

1.9

21

4.3

Westphal

Forfar et al

45

4.4

4

S.9

Walker &

250

—

—

23

9.2

Neligan

Present report

120

4

3.3

8

6.7

Waters

41

—

—

4

9.8

Jablonski

295

—

—

20

6.8

Vol 112, Aug 1966

114


/..V( DANCE TRANSFUSION - DIAMOND

emphasis on the removal of bilirubin pud the prevention of kernicterus. Because of the considerable risk of mortality and morbidity involved in the procedure itself, recent authors have questioned standardized indications for the performance of exchange transfusions. Since signs of kernicterus constitute the only absolute indications for replacement transfusion, McKay6 emphasizes the importance of individualizing each patient with hemolytic disease. All contingencies should be weighed in each case, including the risks involved in various forms of therapy.

One method of reducing the number of exchange transfusions performed would be a modification of the rules for immediate exchange transfusion. The measurement of the reserve albumin-binding capacity as proposed by Odell17 and confirmed by Waters and Porter 18 may prove to be a more accm rate method of appraising the need for exchange transfusion than bilirubin levels alone. Likewise, the use of albumin-fortified blood may increase the efficiency of bilirubin removal and decrease the need for repeat exchange transfusions.19,20 Delay in treatment in order to evaluate the patient more critically does not increase the need for reexchange and may actually reduce the need for unnecessary procedures.18

If the procedure can be delayed 24 to 48 hours, one can frequently avoid the necessity of performing the procedure on an infant with respiratory insufficiency due to incomplete pulmonary expansion. It must be remembered, however, that kernicterus occurs at lower bilirubin levels when asphyxia is present.21,22 Cardiac arrest in infants has been shown to have a definite relationship to respiratory insufficiency.23 Since anemia is also contributory to the incidence of cardiac arrest,23 it may be advisable to treat some severely anemic neonates with packed-cell transfusions before attempting a complete replacement, providing bilirubin levels do not preclude a delay. The success of resuscitation after cardiac arrest depends largely on rapid recognition of cardiac standstill and the preceding arrhythmia that warns of its onset. Continuous monitoring of cardiac rate and rhythm provides an excellent means whereby the operator need not depend on semiskilled nursing personnel to monitor heart sounds by stethoscope.

Other factors, the control of which might reduce the incidence of cardiac arrhythmia ami arrest, are (1) reduction of ionized calcium,23 (2) hyperkalemia due to use of blood stored for long periods,25 (3) the use of cold donor blood,26 and f4) acid-base disturbances 8 during exchange transfusion. The significance of hypocalcemia and hyperkalemia in the pathogenesis of, cardiac arrest during exchange transfusion has been questioned.27 In any event, the risk of hyperkalemia may be reduced by the use of fresh donor blood and an adequate ionized-calcium level may be maintained by using heparinized blood or injecting calcium gluconate during the exchange transfusion. The latter procedure is not without its own risk, however. Cardiac monitoring will frequently disclose cardiac arrhythmia and a decrease in pulse rate of 20 to 30 beats/min after calcium gluconate is injected. The amount of calcium gluconate used should be individualized according to the needs and condition of the infant. Donor blood should be warmed in a water bath and a heating pad or some other source of external heat should be used to maintain the body temperatures of the infant being exchanged. We are presently evaluating a blood warmer (Therm-X-Change by McGraw Electric) at this center.

Newborn infants are born in a state of metabolic acidosis which persists for longer periods in premature28 than in full-term infants.29 The pH of stored blood to which acid-citrate-dextrose anticoagulant has been added is 7 or below,30 Thus, the infant undergoing exchange transfusion may develop significant acidosis.8 Serial evaluation of acid-base status is now being carried out during exchange transfusions to determine whether prophylactic measures are indicated. Oliver31 has recommended that 15 mg of Tham buffer be added to each 500 cc of whole blood for this purpose.

Summary

During a three-year period a total of 120 exchange transfusions was performed at

Amer J Dis Child—Vol 112, Aug 1966

EXCHANGE TEA NSFU SI ON—DIA MOND

115


Little Company of Mary Hospital, a private institution. Eight deaths occurred during? or within six hours of the procedure. Four deaths were attributed to severe hemolytic disease and four deaths were caused by sudden cardiac arrhythmia or cardiac arrest occurring during the exchange transfusion or both. The gross mortality was 7.4% per patient and 6.7% per exchange transfusion. True exchange transfusion-related mortality was 3.7% per patient and 3.3% per exchange transfusion. Factors related to the occurrence of sudden death during exchange transfusion are discussed. Measures to help reduce the frequency of cardiac arrest are proposed.

Volume 6


AUGUST 1950


Number 2


. ORIGINAL ARTICLES

ERYTHROBLASTOSIS FETALIS

I. Problems in the Interpretation of Changing Mortality in Erythroblastosis Fetalis

By Victor C. Vaughan III, M.D., Fred H. Allen, Jr., M.D., ,           and Louis K. Diamond, M.D. , ,

Boston                 ■

SINCE the demonstration1 almost a decade ago that erythroblastosis fetalis was associated with sensitization of the Rh-negative mother to the red blood cells of her Rh-positive infant, three major modifications of treatment have been made in the clinical management of such infants. It was first proposed2 that rational management of sick infants might demand that they be transfused with Rh-negative rather than Rh-positive blood. Early induction of labor in the sensitized mother was later proposed3 in the hope of sparing the infant a more severe illness dependent upon prolonged intra-uterine existence. Lastly, the technic of exchange transfusion, a theoretically reasonable procedure, has been developed to the point where it is entirely practical, and early reports of its use4’5 are very optimistic in presenting the results achieved.

It is the purpose of this paper to show that there are serious handicaps to the accurate assay of these therapeutic measures in two groups of cases of erythroblastosis fetalis at the authors’ disposal. With the introduction of each new measure, there have occurred changes in the nature of the clinical material being treated, and observed changes in overall mortality figures have been found to depend largely on factors other than the inherent

From the Department of Pediatrics, Harvard Medical School, the Children's Medical Center, the Boston Lying-in Hospital, and the Blood Grouping Laboratory, Boston.

Aided by a grant from the United States Public Health Service. Support of the Blood Bank of the Children’s Hospital from the Variety Club of Boston has been most helpful in caring for these patients.

Presented in part at the Annual Meeting of the Society for Pediatric Research, Atlantic City, May 1949.

(Received for publication Dec. 4, 1949.)

173

4-97


I7t V. ( . VAUGHAN III, I’. H. ALLEN. JR., L. K. DIAMOND

therapeutic xalue of atty measure adopted. This report presents the results of a 12 yc,lr survey of 539 eases of erythroblastosis fetalis seen by a single .group at the Children s Hospital, Boston, and the Boston Lying-in Hospital. It will be apparent that the cast material of the Boston Lying-in Hospital is very different from that at the Children’s Hos. pital and accordingly the two bodies of clinical material will be considered separately.

The authors have elected for this analysis to consider the clinical course of erythroblastosis fetalis as having five possible outcomes: (a) stillbirth of the fetus, with or without hydrops fetalis, (b) death in a live born infant without there being clinical or pathologic signs of kernicterus, (c) kernicterus in a live born infant, with or without survival of the acute phase of the illness, (d) complete recovery from an illness of whatever severity which is recognized as erythroblastosis fetalis, and (e) recovery without clinical evidence of disease in the Rh-positive infant of an Rh-negative mother in whom Rh antibodies have been demonstrated at the time of delivery. About one third of the cases of kernicterus in this series have survived the neonatal period, always with residual brain damage. They make up about 5% of the surviving cases of erythroblastosis fetalis. The cases of surviving kernicterus have not been separated from fatal kernicterus in preparing the tables, since it is the authors’ strong feeling that kemicterus, whether surviving or not, must be viewed as a unitary' problem. While it will be shown, for example, in reports to follow that kernicterus bears little relationship to other causes of death in erythroblastosis fetalis, there is no evidence that there is any qualitative difference between those cases of kernicterus which survive and those which do not. Quantitative differences may well exist.

It has been possible generally to recognize those offspring who show no clinical illness in spite of maternal sensitization only since the introduction of the slide test0 into the diagnostic repertory. Prior to 1944 only mothers with potent anti-Rh agglutinins active in a saline medium were likely to be recognized as sensitized. These mothers are generally in the minority. The use of serum and albumin as suspending media7 for the Rh testing has increased the ease with which the diagnosis of sensitization of the Rh-negative woman can be made.

Mortality of Erythroblastosis Fetalis at the Children’s Hospital

Table 1 summarizes 12 years’ experience with 349 cases of erythroblastosis fetalis at the Children’s Hospital. Included are four years (1937-1940) just preceding the discovery
